Text: I think we've seen a deterioration of values.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think for a while as a nation we condoned those things we should have condemned.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: For a while, as I recall, it even seems to me that there was talk of legalizing or decriminalizing marijuana and other drugs, and I think that's all wrong.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So we've seen a deterioration in values, and one of the things that I think we should do about it in terms of cause is to instill values into the young people in our schools.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We got away, we got into this feeling that value- free education was the thing.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I don't believe that at all I do believe there are fundamental rights and wrongs as far as use.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And, of course, as far as the how we make it better, yes, we can do better on interdiction.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But we've got to do a lot better on education, and we have to do, be tougher on those who commit crimes.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We've got to get after the users more.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We have to change this whole culture.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I saw the cocaine scene treated with humor, as though this was a humorous little incident.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Everybody ought to be in this thing.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Entertainment industry, people involved in the schools, education.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And it isn't a Republican or a Democrat or a liberal problem.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But we have got to instill values in these young people.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I have put forward a many-point drug program that includes what I would do as president of the United States; in terms of doing better on interdiction; and in terms of better in the neighborhoods.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I think we're all in this together, and my plea to the American people is values in the schools.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I agree with Mr. Bush that values are important.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But it's important that our leaders demonstrate those values from the top.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: That means those of us who are elected to positions of political leadership have to reflect those values ourselves.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Here we are with a government that's been dealing with a drug-running Panamanian dictator.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We've been dealing with him; he's been dealing drugs to our kids.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Governors like me and others have been trying to deal with the consequences.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I remember being in a high school in my own state as we were organizing something we call the Governor's Alliance Against Drugs, and a young 16 year old girl coming up to me, desperate, addicted, dependent, saying, Governor, I need help.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We're providing that young woman with help.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But I want to be a president of the United States who makes sure that we never again do business with a drug-running Panamanian dictator, that we never again funnel aid to the contras through convicted drug dealers.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Values begin at the top, in the White House.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Those are the values I want to bring to the presidency and to the White House beginning in January of 1989.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I'm saying that those of us who are elected to positions of political leadership, Jim, have a special responsibility, not only to come up with programs, and I have outlined in detail the very important, very strong program of enforcement as well as drug education prevention.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And Mr. Bush is right - the two go hand in hand.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But if our government itself is doing business with people who we know are engaged in drug profiteering and drug trafficking, if we don't understand that that sends out a very, very bad message to our young people, it's a little difficult for me to understand just how we can reach out to that youngster that I talked about and to young people like her all over the country, and say to them we want to help you.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Now, I've outlined in great detail a program for being tough on enforcement at home and abroad, doubling the number of drug enforcement agents, having a hemispheric summit soon after the 20th of January when we bring our democratic neighbors and allies together here in this hemisphere and go to work together.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But we also have to take demand seriously.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: You know, we have five percent of the world's population in this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We're consuming 50 percent of the world's cocaine.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Doing better in the neighborhoods.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But I think we're all in this together, and my plea to the American people is values in the schools.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I agree with Mr. Bush that values are important.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But it's important that our leaders demonstrate those values from the top.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: That means those of us who are elected to positions of political leadership have to reflect those values ourselves.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Here we are with a government that's been dealing with a drug-running Panamanian dictator.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We've been dealing with him; he's been dealing drugs to our kids.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Governors like me and others have been trying to deal with the consequences.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I remember being in a high school in my own state as we were organizing something we call the Governor's Alliance Against Drugs, and a young 16 year old girl coming up to me, desperate, addicted, dependent, saying, Governor, I need help.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We're providing that young woman with help.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But I want to be a president of the United States who makes sure that we never again do business with a drug-running Panamanian dictator, that we never again funnel aid to the contras through convicted drug dealers.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Values begin at the top, in the White House.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Those are the values I want to bring to the presidency and to the White House beginning in January of 1989.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I'm saying that those of us who are elected to positions of political leadership, Jim, have a special responsibility, not only to come up with programs, and I have outlined in detail the very important, very strong program of enforcement as well as drug education prevention.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And Mr. Bush is right - the two go hand in hand.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But if our government itself is doing business with people who we know are engaged in drug profiteering and drug trafficking, if we don't understand that that sends out a very, very bad message to our young people, it's a little difficult for me to understand just how we can reach out to that youngster that I talked about and to young people like her all over the country, and say to them we want to help you.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Now, I've outlined in great detail a program for being tough on enforcement at home and abroad, doubling the number of drug enforcement agents, having a hemispheric summit soon after the 20th of January when we bring our democratic neighbors and allies together here in this hemisphere and go to work together.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But we also have to take demand seriously.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: You know, we have five percent of the world's population in this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And in my state I'm proud to say we've organized a drug education and prevention program which the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration says is a model for the country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We're helping youngsters; we're reaching out to them.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And we're beginning with drug education and prevention beginning in the early elementary grades in every elementary school in our state, and that's the kind of effort we need in every elementary school in the United States of America.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And we've got to begin early, in the first, second and third grade, before our youngsters begin to experiment with these very, very dangerous substances.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I guess the question I would ask of Mr. Bush is how we instill those values, how we create this environment for the drug free schools that we want in this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: If he or representatives of the administration are either with or involving people like Noriega in our foreign policy, or don't pursue that connection in a way that makes it possible for us to cut it off and to be an example to our kids all over the country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Well, the other day my opponent was given a briefing by the CIA.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I asked for and received the same briefing.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I am very careful in public life about dealing with classified information.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And what I'm about to say is unclassified.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Seven administrations were dealing with Mr. Noriega.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It was the Reagan-Bush administration that brought this man to justice.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And as the governor of Massachusetts knows, there was no evidence that governor - that Mr. Noriega was involved in drugs, no hard evidence until we indicted him.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so I think it's about time we get this Noriega matter in perspective.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Panama is a friendly country.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I went down there and talked to the president of Panama about cleaning up their money laundering, and Mr. Noriega was there, but there was no evidence at that time, and when the evidence was there, we indicted him.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we want to bring him to justice.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so call off all those pickets out there that are trying to tear down seven different administrations.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Yes, I've been very specific about those, John.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And let me lay out for you my own strategy for bring that deficit down, because as a chief executive that's balanced ten budgets in a row, I've had to make those tough decisions and those tough choices.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: First, I've suggested that there are certain weapons systems which we don't need and we can't afford.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Mr. Bush has been critical of me for that, but I think those are the kinds of tough choices you have to make.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I've also suggested that there are weapons systems that we should proceed on, and I've outlined those in detail.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Secondly, we've got to invest in economic growth in this country, in every part of this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Building that kind of growth expands revenues and helps to bring down that deficit.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Thirdly, we have to bring interest rates down, and we will as we come up with a good, solid plan with the Congress for bringing that deficit down.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And, finally, we've got to go out there and collect billions and billions of dollars in taxes owed that aren't being paid to this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It's very unfair to the average taxpayer who pays his taxes and pays them on time to permit these monies to go uncollected.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I've also suggested that on the domestic side there are areas where we can make some cuts.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We ought to be able to come up with an agricultural policy in this country that gives our farm families a fair price and a decent future without spending $20-25 billion a year, which is what we've been doing under this administration.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We can help people to live better lives, and at the same time save money by helping hundreds of thousands of families on welfare to get off or welfare, and to become productive citizens again.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The thing I don't understand about Mr. Bush's approach to this is how he could possibly be serious about bringing that deficit down given what he says he wants to do.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: He seems to want to spend a great deal of money on just about every weapon system; he says he's against new taxes, although he's broken that pledge at least times in the last year that I know of; he wants to give the wealthiest taxpayers in this country a five year, $40 billion tax break.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: He also wants to spend a lot of money on additional programs.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: If he keeps this up, he's going to be the Joe Isuzu of American politics.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But I hope you won't take my five seconds away from me.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I will say this -
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: If he's serious about what he's saying, then the only place he can go to balance that budget is to raid the Social Security Trust Fund, and he tried that in 1985, and I think he's going to try it again.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Is this the time to unleash our one-liners?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: There are so many things there, I don't quite know where to begin.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: When you cut capital gains, you put people to work.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: John Kennedy proposed cutting capital gains.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Paul Tsongas, a liberal senator from Massachusetts said the dumbest thing I did was to oppose the capital gains cut.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It's not going to cost the government money.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It's going to increase revenues to the federal government, and it's going to create jobs.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So that's one of the things that I think makes a big difference between us.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Massachusetts doesn't have an enormous defense budget, but nevertheless, the governor raised taxes five different times.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That happens to be a fact.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so let's kind of stay on the issue, and I have made a specific proposal for what I call a flexible freeze.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And it permits - economists on the East Coast and West think it's good - it permits the president to sort out the priorities, and we continue to grow because I will not raise taxes.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think it's the Republican Party and my concern to bring it down.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And presidential leadership that I want to provide in this area will bring it down, but we've got to get the Democrats - Congress under control.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: They do all the spending, they appropriate every dime and tell us how to spend every dime.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'd like to ask the Governor to join in getting for the president what 43 governors have, the line-item veto.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He has to operate in Massachusetts under a balanced budget proviso.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I would like a balanced budget amendment.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But the dynamics of the economy - we cut the taxes and revenues are up by 25 percent in three years.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So the problem is - it's not that the working is being taxed too little or the person working out - the woman working in some factory being taxed too little.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It is that we are continuing to spend too much.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So, my formula says grow at the rate of inflation.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Permit the president to set the priorities on where we do the spending.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And remember the Federal deficit has come down $70 billion in one year, in 1987.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And if we - and the - actually this year Congress is doing a little better in controlling the growth of spending.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Spending was only up something like 4 percent.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So, it isn't that we're taking too little - from taxpayer - we're spending too much still.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And the formula I've given you works, we've put it through a good economic model, we've got good economists on the West Coast, Michael Boskin and Marty Feldstein up there who's a very respected economist in the - Massachusetts.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And they agree, that if we can do what I've said, we can get it down without going and socking the American taxpayer once again.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Capital gains, one more point on that, please let's learn from history.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: A capital gains differential will increase jobs, increase risk taking, increase revenues to the Federal Government.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, I hope all of those Americans out there who are watching us, listening to us and trying to make up their mind about which one of us ought to be president of the United States listen to the Vice President very carefully.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: What he's proposing after over a trillion in new debt which has been added in the Federal debt in the course of the past eight years, an IOU our children and grandchildren will be paying for years, is a tax cut for the wealthiest one percent of the people in this country, an average of about $30,000 that we're going to give to people making $200,000 a year.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Why that's more than the average teacher makes.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We've had enough of that, ladies and gentlemen.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It's time for a chief executive who can make tough choices, can work with the Congress, can get that deficit down and begin to build a strong fiscal foundation under this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: One thing I will not do is sock every business in the country and, thus, throw some people out of work.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to keep this economic recovery going.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: More Americans at work today than any time in history, a greater percentage of the work force.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: What I will do is permit people to buy into Medicaid.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I believe that's the answer.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I am proud to have been part of an administration that past the first catastrophic health bill.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And in that there are some Medicaid provisions that will be very helpful to the very kind of people we're talking about here.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But we've got to keep going forward without killing off the engine and throwing people out of work.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So, the answer lies, it seems to me, in full enforcement of the catastrophic program.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It lies to me in flexibility in Medicaid so people at the lowest end can buy in there and get their needs covered and then it also - I do not want to see us mandate across the board that every company has to do this, because I really think that marginal operators are going to go say, "We can't make it."
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I think then you're going to see that people are put out of work.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: All these programs - and this cost on his - is - was - I saw an estimate, I'd love to know what he thinks, $35 - $40 billion - and it seems to me that somebody pays that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: There isn't any such thing as something free out there.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It either gets passed along as increased prices or it gets passed along by people being put out of work so the business can continue to compete.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So, I think we ought to do it in the Medicaid system.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think we ought to do it by full enforcement of the catastrophic health insurance.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think we ought to do it by everybody doing what they can do out of conscience.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It's a terrible problems in terms of flexibility on private insurance.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I just don't want to mandate it and risk putting this - setting the recovery back.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But, George, that's no answer.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: You don't like the answer, but it's an answer.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, no, it's no answer to those 37 million people, most of them members of working families who don't have a dime of health insurance and don't know how to pay the bills if their kids get sick at night.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: All of them with little or no health insurance.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: One of them was a father who had been laid off a few months ago and lost his health insurance.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Has an 11 year old son and can't let that son compete in sports and Little League, because he's afraid he's going to get hurt and he won't be able to provide health insurance to pay those bills.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: My state just became the only state in the nation to provide for universal health care and we did it with the support of the business community and labor and the health care community and with virtually everybody in the state.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The fact of the matter is that employers who today are insuring their employees are paying the freight, because they're paying for those who aren't.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And I think it's time that when you got a job in this country it came with health insurance.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: That's the way we're going to provide basic health security for all of the citizens of this country of ours.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Well, Anne, let me just say before I answer your question that I didn't know that the Vice President attacked our program in Massachusetts.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Because has won the support of a great many people all over the state and I think it's a model for what I hope we can do across the country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But when I proposed my plan this past Tuesday, he or one of his spokesmen called it socialized medicine.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It was in 1964 and that's what he called Medicare.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Well, he was wrong then and he's wrong now.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Let me say this about AIDS.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It's the single most important public health crisis, single most important public health emergency we've had in our lifetimes and I think there are a number of things we have to do including supporting legislation which is now moving through the Congress, which will commit this nation to the resources to find a cure which will provide broad education and prevention, which will provide sensitive and caring treatment for the victims of AIDS.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And I would encourage the current administration to proceed with that kind of flexibility where it's appropriate and where it's done carefully and responsibly.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But we have not had the kind of leadership we should have had.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: In this particular area, I think the Vice President and I are in general agreement on what we have to do.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The special Federal commission made good solid recommendations.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think we're both supportive of them and I would strongly lead in that area as I have in my state as Governor.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Well, we're on the right track.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The NIH is doing a good job in research.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The Surgeon General is doing a good job in encouraging the proper kind of education.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I notice that the Governor did not mention any testing.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But we got to have a knowledge base.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Testing should be confidential, but we have to have a knowledge.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We can't simply stick our heads in the sands in terms of testing.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'm Chairman of the President's Task Force on Regulatory Relief and we are working with the FDA and they have sped up bringing drugs to market that can help.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And you got to be careful here, because there's a safety factor, but I think these things - and then also I am one who believes we've got to go the extra mile in clean - being sure that that blood supply is pure.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We cannot have a lack of confidence in the blood supply when it comes to operations and surgery and things of this nature.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So, research, speeding the drugs to market, testing, blood supply are very important elements of this.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, I don't question his passion.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I question - and I don't question his concern about the war in Vietnam.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He introduced or supported legislation back then that suggested that kids of Massachusetts should be exempt from going overseas in that war.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Now, that's a certain passion that in my view it's misguided passion.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He - we have a big difference on issues.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You see, last year in the primary, he expressed his passion.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He said, "I am a strong liberal Democrat" - August, '87.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Then he said, "I am a card-carrying member of the ACLU."
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That was what he said.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He is out there on out of the mainstream.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: My argument with the governor is, do we want this country to go that far left.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I wish we had time to let me explain.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I salute him for his passion.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We just have a big difference on where this country should be led, and in what direction it ought to go.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But just take a look at the positions of the ACLU.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But, Peter, please understand, the liberals do not like me talking about liberal They don't like it when I say that he says he's a card carrying member.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Now, if that quote was wrong, he can repudiate it, right here.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I've seen it authoritatively written twice, and if I've done him an injustice, and he didn't say it, I'm very, very sorry.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I don't agree with a lot of - most of the positions of the ACLU.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I simply don't want to see the ratings on movies.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't want my ten year old grandchild to go into an X-rated movie.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I like those ratings systems.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't think they're right to try to take the tax exemption away from the Catholic Church.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't want to see the kiddie pornographic laws repealed; I don't want to see "under God" come out from our currency.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Now, these are all positions of the ACLU.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I don't agree with them.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He has every right to exercise his passion, as what he said, a strong, progressive liberal.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't agree with that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I come from a different point.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I think I'm more in touch with the mainstream of America.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: They raised the same thing with me on the Pledge of Allegiance.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You see, I'd have found a way to sign that bill.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Governor Thompson of Illinois did.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'm not questioning his patriotism.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He goes out and says the man is questioning my patriotism.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And then all the liberal columnists join in.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I am questioning his judgment on these matters, or where he's coming from He has every right to do it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I believe that's not what the American people want, and when he said, when he said at the convention, ideology doesn't matter, just competence, he was moving away from his own record, from what his passion has been over the years.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And that's all I'm trying to do, is put it in focus.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I hope people don't think that I'm questioning his patriotism when I say he used his words to describe his participation in that organization.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, I hope this is the first and last time I have to say this.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Of course, the vice president is questioning my patriotism.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I don't think there's any question about that, and I resent it.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: My parents came to this country as immigrants.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: They taught me that this was the greatest country in the world.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I'm in public service because I love this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And nobody's going to question my patriotism as the vice president has now repeatedly.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The fact of the matter is if the Pledge of Allegiance was the acid test of one's patriotism--the vice president's been the presiding officer in the United States Senate for the past seven and a half years.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: To the best of my knowledge he's never once suggested that a session of the Senate begin with the Pledge of Allegiance.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Mr. Bush, I don't question your patriotism.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: When you're attacked for your military record, I immediately said it was inappropriate, it had no place in this campaign, and I rejected it.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I would hope that from this point on, we get to the issues that affect the vast majority of Americans, jobs, schools, health care, housing, the environment.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Those are the concerns of the people that are watching us tonight.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Not labels that we attach to each other, questions about each other's patriotism and loyalty.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I want to see the McKinney Act fully funded.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I believe that that would help in terms of shelter.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to see - when I talked at our convention about a thousand points of light, I was talking about the enormous numbers of shelters and organizations that help.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The governor's wife has been very active in the homeless.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: My campaign chairman, Secretary Jim Baker's wife.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: These are people that care, that are trying to give of themselves.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The government has a role.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It is to fully fund the McKinney Act.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: There are certain army bases that the act calls for that can be used in certain cases to shelter people when it's rough.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so I think that we're on the right track.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't see this, incidentally, as a Democrat or a Republican or a liberal or conservative idea.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I see an involvement by a thousand points of light.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I see the funding that is required, and I hope the Congress will fully fund this bill.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: They gave it a great deal of conscience and a great deal of work.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we're on the track on this one.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But - and I, look, mental - that was a little overstated it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'd say around 30 percent.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I think maybe we could look back over our shoulders and wonder whether it was right to let all those mental patients out.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Maybe we need to do a better job in mental clinics to help them.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Because there is a major problem there.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: A lot of them are mentally sick.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we've got to attend to them.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But fully, my short range answer is fully fund that McKinney Act.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, this is another fundamental difference that I have with the vice president, just as I do in the case of health care for 37 million members of working families in this country who don't have health insurance.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The problem, Mr. Bush, is that you've cut back by 90 percent on our commitment to affordable housing for families of low and moderate income.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And when you do that, you've have homeless families.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We didn't have two and a half million, or three million homeless people living on streets and in doorways in this country ten years ago.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We've got to begin to get back to the business of building and rehabilitating housing for families of low and moderate income in this country; housing for young families that they can look forward some day to buy.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We've got communities in this country increasingly where our own kids can't afford to live in the communities that they grew up in.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And I think the housing community is ready.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But it's going to take a president who's committed to housing, who's had experience in building and rehabilitating housing who understands that affordable housing for families of low and moderate income, for young families, first time home buyers, is an essential part of the American dream.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And while I'm all for the McKinney bill, that, by itself, simply won't do.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We've got to have a president that can lead on this issue, that can work with the Congress, and I'm prepared to do so.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: This is one of the most important priorities that faces this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Well, I certainly hope not.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And it's all a question of what our priorities are.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Mr. Bush talked about values.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Isn't providing housing for families of low and moderate income, isn't it making possible for young families, first time home buyers to own their own home some day something that's part of the American dream?
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: You know, back after World War II when we had hundreds of thousands of GIs who came back from the war, we didn't sit around.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We went out and built housing.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The government was very much involved; so was the housing industry; so was the banking industry; so were housing advocates; so were non-profit agencies; so were governors and mayors and people all over this country who believe deeply in home ownership and affordable housing.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Now, that's the kind of leadership that I want to provide as president of the United States.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: This is a question of organizing the housing community.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I've talked to bankers and builders and developers, the housing advocates, community development agencies, and they want leadership from Washington.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Washington, by itself, can't do it all.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But governors are ready; mayors are ready.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Builders and community leaders are ready.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It will require some funds, John.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And we ought to be prepared to provide those funds.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But that, too, will require some choices.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Mr. Bush wants to spend billions and trillions on Star Wars.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Well, that's a choice we have to make, isn't it?
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Do we spend money on that weapon system in the billions and trillions, or is providing some decent and affordable housing for families of this country something that is at least as important and probably more so.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Because it's so essential to our economic strength and to our future.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Now, that's the kind of presidency I believe in.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And simply to say, well, the McKinney bill will do it just doesn't do.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We need a president who will lead on this issue, who has had experience on this issue.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It's the kind of priority that will be at the top of our list beginning in January of 1989.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think the governor is blurring housing and the homeless.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Let's talk about housing which the question was.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: When you talk to those bankers, did they discuss where interest rates were when your party controlled the White House?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Ten days before I took the oath of office as president they were 21 and a half percent.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Now, how does that grab you for increasing housing?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We are serving a million more families now.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But we're not going to do it in that old Democratic, liberal way of trying to build more bricks and mortars.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to see more vouchers.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to see control of some of these projects, and I want to keep the interest rates down.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: They're half, now of what they were when we came into office, and with my policy of getting this deficit under control, they'll be a lot less.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But if we spend and spend and spend, that is going to wrap up the housing market, and we'll go right back to the days of the misery index and malaise that President Reagan and I have overcome - thank God for the United States on that one.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: No, I don't think there is.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: There are two very different issues here, and they've got to be dealt with separately.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I'm opposed to the death penalty.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think everybody knows that.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I'm also very tough on violent crime.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And that's one of the reasons why my state has cut crime by more than any other industrial state in America.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It's one of the reasons why we have the lowest murder rate of any industrial state in the country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It's one of the reasons why we have a drug education and prevention program that is reaching out and helping youngsters all over our state, the kind of thing I want to do as president of the United States.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: You know, the vice president says he wants to impose the death penalty on drug traffickers, and yet his administration has a federal furlough program which is one of the most permissive in the country, which gave last year 7,000 furloughs to drug traffickers and drug pushers, the same people that he says he now wants to execute.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The issue of abortion is a very difficult issue, one that I think that we all have to wrestle with, we have to come to terms with.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I don't think most people do.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The question is who makes the decision.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And I think it has to be the woman, in the exercise of her own conscience and religious beliefs, that makes that decision.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Well, the Massachusetts furlough program was unique.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It was the only one in the nation that furloughed murderers who had not served enough time to be eligible for parole.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The federal program doesn't do that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: No other state programs do that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I favor the death penalty.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I know it's tough and honest people can disagree.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But when a narcotics wrapped up guy goes in and murders a police officer, I think they ought to pay with their life.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I do believe it would be inhibiting.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so I am not going to furlough men like Willie Horton, and I would meet with their, the victims of his last escapade, the rape and the brutalization of the family down there in Maryland.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Maryland would not extradite Willie Horton, the man who was furloughed, the murderer, because they didn't want him to be furloughed again.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so we have a fundamental difference on this one.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I think most people know my position on the sanctity of life.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I do not favor abortion.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I haven't sorted out the penalties.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I do know, I do know that I oppose abortion.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And if we can get this law changed, everybody should make the extraordinary effort to take these kids that are unwanted and sometimes aborted, take the - let them come to birth, and then put them in a family where they will be loved.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And you see, yes, my position has evolved.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And it's continuing to evolve, and it's evolving in favor of life.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I have had a couple of exceptions that I support - rape, incest and the life of the mother.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Sometimes people feel a little uncomfortable talking about this, but it's much clearer for me now.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: As I've seen abortions sometimes used as a birth control device, for heavens sakes.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: See the millions of these killings accumulate, and this is one where you can have an honest difference of opinion.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But no, I'm for the sanctity of life, and once that illegality is established, then we can come to grips with the penalty side, and of course there's got to be some penalties to enforce the law, whatever they may be.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, I think what the vice president is saying is that he's prepared to brand a woman a criminal for making this decision.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It's as simple as that.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I don't think it's enough to come before the American people who are watching us tonight and say, well, I haven't sorted it out.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: This is a very, very difficult and fundamental decision that all of us have to make.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And what he is saying, if I understand him correctly, is that he's prepared to brand a woman a criminal for making this choice.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Let me simply say that I think it has to be the woman in the exercise of her own conscience and religious beliefs that makes that decision, and I think that's the right approach, the right decision, and I would hope by this time that Mr. Bush had sorted out this issue and come to terms with it as I have.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I respect his right to disagree with me.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But I think it's important that we have a position, that we take it, and we state it to the American people.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: One of the reasons, and I first would like to know which programs you're talking about, and then we could talk on the merits of the programs.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But, you see, my fundamental philosophy is give local and state government as much control as possible.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That might be the explanation, if you tell me the program.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I do strongly support the WIC program.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think it is good.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think part of the answer to this haunting of these children that are out there and suffering lies in extension of Medicaid, to challenge the states, and maybe we're going to have to enforce more on the states in terms of Medicaid taking care of these.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But, Peter, so much of it is, gets into a whole other phase of things.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The neighborhood, the kind of environment people are growing up in, and that leads me to the programs I'm talking about in terms of education.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think that part of it is the crime infested neighborhoods, and that's why I'm a strong believer in trying to control crimes in the neighborhood, why I was so pleased to be endorsed by the policemen on the beat, the Boston Police Department the other day.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think they understand my commitment to helping them in the neighborhoods.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so it's a combination of these things.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But do not erode out of the system the thousand points of light.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The people that are out there trying to help these kids, the programs like cities and schools, the work that Barbara Bush is doing so people can learn to read in this country and then go on and break this cycle of poverty.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'm for Head Start and moving that up.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I've already made a proposal - and yes, it will cost some money.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So these are the combination of things I want, and the fact that I don't think the federal government can endorse a $35 billion program does not mean I have less compassion than the person who endorses such a program.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, I must have been living through a different eight years then the ones the vice president's been living through, because this administration has cut and slashed and cut and slashed programs for children, for nutrition, for the kinds of things that can help these youngsters to live better lives.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It's cut federal aid to education; it's cut Pell grants and loans to close the door to college opportunity on youngsters all over this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And that, too, is a major difference between the vice president and me.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Let me just give you one other example.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We have a great many people, hundreds of thousands of people living on public assistance in this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The 50 governors of this nation have proposed to the Congress that we help those families to get off of welfare, help those youngsters, help their mothers to become independent and self-sufficient.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It's taken months and months and months to get Mr. Bush and the administration to support that legislation, and they're still resisting.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: That's the way you help people.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Being haunted, a thousand points of light - I don't know what that means.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I know what strong political leadership is.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I know what's happened over the course of the past eight years.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: These programs have been cut and slashed and butchered, and they've hurt kids all over this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Well, I said a few minutes ago, Peter, that you could improve the lives of families and youngsters and save money at the same time.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Welfare reform is one way to do it.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: If we invest in job training, in child care for those youngsters, in some extended health benefits so that that mother and her kids don't lose their health benefits when she goes to work, we can help literally hundreds of thousands, if not millions of families, to get off of welfare, to become independent and self-sufficient, to be taxpaying citizens, and to improve their lives, the quality of lives, their futures, and the futures of those children.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: That's just one example of how you can save money and improve the quality of life at the same time.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: In my own state, for example, we now have that universal health care system, which the vice president opposes, I think very unwisely.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: One of the greatest barriers to opportunity for a family and for those children is the threat that they mat lose their health insurance.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Think about that father down there in Houston who has to tell his youngster that he can't play little league ball that he can't go out on the ball field because he's afraid he's going to get hurt.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And yet, Mr. Bush says well, I don't think we ought to expect business to provide health insurance for their employees, when responsible employers, a majority of employers in this country do and are paying more for their insurance to reimburse hospitals for free care on account of people that are not insured, that have to go to that hospital.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: So these are the ways that you help families, you help youngsters to live better lives, and more decent lives.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Were ready to go to work at the state and local level, all of us.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I know the private sector is.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: People are all over the country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But it takes presidential leadership.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It takes a commitment to being involved and the leading.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And that's the kind of presidency I want to lead.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: What troubles me is that when I talk of the voluntary sector and a thousand points of light and a thousand different ways to help on these problems, the man has just said he doesn't understand what I'm talking about.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: This is the problem I have with the big spending liberals.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: They think the only way to do it is for the federal government to do it all.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The fact happens to be that education spending is up by the federal government; it is up.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But here's the point he misses.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But the federal spending for education is up, and I want to be the education president, because I want to see us do better.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We're putting more money per child into education, and we are not performing as we should.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We've gotten away fro values and the fundamentals.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I would like to urge the school superintendents and the others around the country to stand up now and keep us moving forward on a path towards real excellence.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we can do it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But itÃâ‚¬s not going to be dedicated by some federal bureaucracy in Washington, D.C.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Of course that's a charge that's always made against any governor who runs for the presidency.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think it was one of the things that Mr. Bush said about Mr. Reagan back in 1980.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And yet some of our finest presidents, some of our strongest international leaders were governors-Franklin Roosevelt, Woodrow Wilson, Theodore Roosevelt.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Its not the amount of time you spend in Washington.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It's not the length of your resume.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It's your strength, it's your values, it's the quality of the people you pick.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It's your understanding of the forces of change that are sweeping the world, and whether or not you're in a position to provide leadership to make those forces of change work for us and not against us.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The vice president has a long resume.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But it didn't stop him from endorsing the sale of arms to the Ayatollah.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And we now know that he was not out of the loop; he was in meeting after meeting listening to Secretary Shultz and Secretary Weinberger opposing that, and yet he supported it.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: His experience didn't prevent him from participating or involving or in some way being involved in the relationship between this government and Mr. Noriega and drug trafficking in Panama.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: He went to Philippines in the early 80Ãâ‚¬s and commended Ferdinand Macros for his commitment to democracy.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And he continues to support a failed policy in Central America which is getting worse and worse, and which has in fact increased Cuban and Soviet influence in that region.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: So I don't believe that the fact you've got that long resume or had that experience is the real question.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The question is values; the question is strength, the question is your willingness to provide the kind of leadership that must be provided.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I'm ready to provide that leadership.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I want to be the commander in chief of this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think it take fresh leadership now, and an understanding of those forces of change to provide the kind of strength that we need, and perhaps the vice president can explain what he was doing when he supported the trading of arms to terrorist nation, and his involvement in Panama and that endorsement of Mr. Macros.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But I don't think it's just experience that makes the difference.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Well, I thought the question was about defense.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The governor was for a nuclear freeze that would have locked in a thousand Soviet intermediate nuclear force weapons and zero for the West.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And because we didn't listen to the freeze advocates, and strengthen the defense of this country, we now have the first arms control agreement in the nuclear age.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Now, we're sitting down and talking to the Soviets about strategic arms, and he wants to do away with the Midgetman and the MX, the modernization or our nuclear capability.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That is not the way you deal with the Soviets.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Met Mr. Shevardnadze and talked substance with him the other day.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But now we have a chance.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I few have experience and now how to handle it, but please do not go back to the days when the military was as weak as they could be, when the morale was down, and when we were the laughing stock around the world.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And now we are back, because we have strengthened the defenses of this country, and believe me, I don't want to see us return to those days.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: As to Ferdinand Marcos, he isn't there any more.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It was under our administration that Mrs. Aquino came in.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I flew a combat mission, my last one was over Manila.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And he was down there fighting against imperialism.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And he just lifted martial law.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And he just called for new elections.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And all of those things happened because the Philippines do crave democracy.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't think it's a question of eliminating.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I can tell him some I'm against.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I can go on and on.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I mean, there's plenty of them that I oppose, but what I am not going to do, when we are negotiating with the Soviet Union, sitting down talking to Mr. Gorbachev about how we achieve a 50 percent reduction in our strategic weapons, I'm not going to give away a couple of aces I that very tough card game.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And under me, when I lead this country, the secretary of defense is going to have to make the choices, between how we keep, how we protect the survivability of our nuclear deployment on the Midgetman missile, or on the Minuteman, whatever it is.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We're going to have to-the MX.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We're going to have to do that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Wouldn't it be nice to be perfect?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I hope it isn't Christmas when you make that decision.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: wouldn't it be nice to be the ice man so you never make a mistake?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: These are the-my answer is do not make these unilateral cuts, and everybody now realizes that peace through strength works, and so this is where I have a big difference.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Of course we're going to have to make some determination on this, and we're going to have to make it on the convention forces.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But now we've got a very good concept called competitive strategies.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We will do what we do best.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It's a strategy that we've been working on for a couple of years.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It is going to take us to much better advantage in conventional forces.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But look, let me sum it up.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to be the president that gets conventional forces balance.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to be the one to banish chemical and biological weapons from the face of the earth.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But you have to have a little bit of experience to know where to start.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I think I've had that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, first let me say with respect to the freeze, that back in the spring of 1982 Mr. Bush was a lot more sympathetic to the freeze than he seems to be today.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: As a matter of fact, he said it was not and should not be subject to partisan demagoguery because it was too important for the United States or for the world.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I didn't hear, John, exactly where he was going to cut and what he was going to do.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But I know this, we have serious financial problems in this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We've piled up over a trillion dollars in debt and the next president of the United States is going to have to make some choices.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Mr. Bush wants to spend billions on Star Wars.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: He apparently wants to spend billions on the MX on railroad cars, a weapons system we don't need and can't afford.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I thought the administration was opposed to the Midgetman.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I thought the administration was at the negotiating table in Geneva suggesting that we ban mobile missile systems entirely.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But those are the choices the next president of the United States is going to have to make.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I'm for the Stealth, I'm for the D-5, I'm for going ahead with the advance Cruise missile.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But I don't think we need these other systems.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I don't think we need them to remain strong.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We've got to move ahead with the strategic arms negotiation process, with the comprehensive test ban treaty and with negotiations leading to conventional force reduction in Europe with deeper cuts on the Soviet side and Senator Bentsen and I will pursue that policy.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: What I think we ought to do is take a look at perestroika and glasnost, welcome them, but keep our eyes open.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Because the Soviet change is not fully established yet.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Yes, I think it's fine to do business with them.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And, so, I'm encouraged with what I see when I talk to Mr. -- what I hear when I talk to Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Shevardnadze, but can they pull it off.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And when they have a --they a --deals that are good for us, as China started to do--the changes in China since Barbara and I lived there is absolutely amazing, in terms of incentive, in partnership and things of this nature.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And now the Soviet Union seems to be walking down that same path.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We ought to say this is good.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But where I differ with my opponent is I am not going to make unilateral cuts in our strategic defend systems or support some freeze when they have superiority.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'm not going to do that, because I think the jury is still out on the Soviet experiment.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And the interesting place-one of the things that fascinates me about this perestroika and glasnost is wheats going to happen in Eastern Europe.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You see the turmoil in Poland today.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I think we have enormous opportunity for trade.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't want to go back to the Carter grain embargo on the Soviets.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We are once again reliable suppliers and I would never use food as a political tool like our predecessors did.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But this is an exciting time.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But all I'm suggesting is let's not be naÃƒÂ¯ve in dealing with the Soviets and make a lot of unilateral cuts hoping against hope that they will match our bid.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Look at the INF treaty.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And if we haven't learned from the negotiating history on that, we'll never learn.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The freeze people were wrong.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The Reagan-Bush administration was right.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It was a very different George Bush who was talking much more sympathetically about the freeze in the spring of 1982 than he is today.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And you were right then, George, when you said it was no time for partisan demagoguery.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Nobody is suggesting that we unilaterally disarm or somehow reduce our strength, of course not.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: What we're talking about is a combination of a strong and effective and credible nuclear deterrent.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Strong, well-equipped, well-trained, well-maintained conventional forces.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And at the same time a willingness to move forward steadily, thoughtfully cautiously.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We have serious differences with the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We have very fundamental differences about human rights, democracy and our basic system, our basic view of human beings and of what life is all about.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But there are opportunities there now.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Senator Bentsen and I have a plan for the 1990Ãâ‚¬s and beyond.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Mr. Bush and Mr. Quayle do not.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And we want to pursue that plan in a way which will bring down the level of nuclear armament, will build a more stable and more peaceful world while making choices here at home.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Let's not forget that our national security and our economic security go hand in hand.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We cannot be strong militarily when we're teeter-tottering on top of a mountain of debt which has been created in the past eight years.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: That's why we need a Democratic administration in Washington in 1989.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: No, there's been no change of heart.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I said from the beginning that we ought to continue research into the strategic system at about the level that was added in 1983, that's about a billion dollars a year.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But I don't know of any reputable scientist who believed that this system, at least as originally conceived could possibly work, this notion of some kind of astrodome over ourselves that could protect us from enemy attack.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And as a matter of fact, the system that the administration is now talking about is very different from the one that was originally proposed in 1983.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: So, I'm for continued research, but I also want strong conventional forces.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Now, the other day, Mr. Bush said, Ã¢â€°Â¥Well, if we continue with Star War-Star Wars-we have to cut some place.Ã¢â€°Â¤ He hasn't told us where.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We know where they're cutting.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We know where you're cutting right now.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: You're cutting into the fiber and muscle of our conventional forces.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: You're cutting back on maintenance and equipment.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: An Air Force General not too long ago in Europe who said that pretty soon we'd have airplanes without engines, tank commanders who can't drive their tanks more than three-quarters of a mile, because they don't have enough fuel.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Coast Guard cutters tied up at the dock this summer, not patrolling.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: They're supposed to be our first line of defense against drugs and the war against drugs, because they don't have enough fuel.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: You have to make choices.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We're not making those choices.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And to spend billions and billions of dollars as Mr. Bush apparently wants to, although, he, himself has been all over the lot on this issue lately-on Star Wars-in my judgment makes no sense at all.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We need a strong, credible, effective nuclear deterrent.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We have 13,000 strategic nuclear warheads right now on land, on sea and in the air, enough to blow up the Soviet Union forty times over.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: So, we've got to move forward with those negotiations, get the level of strategic weapons down.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But to continue to commit billions to this system makes no sense at all and I think Mr. Bush has been reconsidering his position over the course of the past few weeks.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: That's-at least that's what I read.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Maybe he'll tell us where he stand on it tonight.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I'm not reconsidering my position.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Two questions: How do you deter nuclear attack without modernizing our nuclear forces when the Soviets are modernizing and how come you spend-willing to spend a dime on something that you consider a fantasy and a fraud.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Those are two hypo-rhetorical questions.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He is the man on conventional forces that wants to eliminate two carrier battle groups.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The armed forces, the conventional forces of the United States have never been more ready.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Every single one of the Joint Chiefs will testify to the fact that readiness is in an historic high.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And secondly, in terms of the cutting of the Coast Guard, the Democratic controlled Congress, so please help us with that, who cut $70 million from the Coast Guard out of the interdiction effort on narcotics.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Why do you spend a billion dollars on something you think is a fantasy and a fraud?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I will fully research it, go forward as fast as we can.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We've set up the levels of funding and when it is deployable, I will deploy it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That is my position on SDI and it's never wavered a bit.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Peter, it's one of the most agonizing decisions a president has to make.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: These are American citizens, we care deeply about them.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Their families care deeply about them, want them back and understandably so and we want to do everything we can to bring them back.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But if there's one thing we also understand it is that you cannot make concessions to terrorists, ever, ever.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Because if you do, it's an open invitation to other terrorists to take hostages and to blackmail us.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And that's the tragedy of the Iran/Contra scandal.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: As a matter of fact, Mr. Bush was the Chairman of a task force on international terrorism which issued a report shortly before that decision was made and said, and rightly so, that we never ever can make concessions to terrorists and hostage takers.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And, yet, after sitting through meeting after meeting, he endorsed that decision, endorsed the sale of arms to the Ayatollah in exchange for hostages, one of the most tragic, one of the most mistaken foreign policy decisions we've ever made in this country and I dare say encouraged others to take hostages as we now know.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: So, there can be no concessions under any circumstances, because if we do it's an open invitation to others to do the same.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We've got to be tough on international terrorism.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We've got to treat it as international crime.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We've got to attack at all points, we've go to use undercover operations.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We have to be prepared to use military force against terrorist base camps, we have to work closely with our allies to make sure that they're working with us and we with them and we can give no quarter when it comes to breaking the back of international terrorism.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: That was a tragic mistake that we made, a mistake that Mr. Bush made and others made and it should never ever be made again.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I wrote the anti-terrorist report for this government.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It is the best anti-terrorist report written.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Yes, we shouldn't trade arms for hostages.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But we have made vast improvements in our anti-terrorism.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Now, it's fine to say that sometimes you have to hit base camps, but when the president saw this state sponsored-fingerprints of Muammar Khadaffi on the loss of American life, he hit Libya.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And my opponent was unwilling to support that action.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And since that action, terrorist action against the United States citizens have gone down.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I have long ago said I supported the president on this other matter.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I've said mistakes were made.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Clearly nobody's going to think the president started out thinking he was going to trade arms for hostages.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That is a very serious charge against the president.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The matter has been thoroughly looked into.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But the point is sometimes the action-
Speaker: George Bush

Text: - has to be taken by the Federal Government and when we took action, it had a favorable response.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You're judged by the whole record.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You're judged by the entire record.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Are we closer to peace?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Are we doing better in anti-terrorism?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Should we have listened to my opponent who wanted to send the UN into the Persian Gulf or in spite of the mistakes of the past, are we doing better there?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: How is our credibility with the GCC countries on the Western side of the Gulf.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Is Iran talking to Iraq about peace?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You judge on the record.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Are the Soviets coming out of Afghanistan?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: How does it look in a program he called or some one of these marvelous Boston adjective up there and-about Angola-now, we have a chance-several Bostonians don't like it, but the rest of the country will understand.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Now we have a chance.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Now we have a chance.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And, so, I think that I'd leave it right there and say that you judge on the whole record.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And let me say this-all he can talk about-he goes around ranting about Noriega.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Now, I've told you what the intelligence briefing he received said about that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He can talk about Iran/Contra and also-I'll make a deal with you, I will take the blame for those two incidents if you give me half the credit for all the good things that have happened in world peace since Ronald Reagan and I took over from the Carter administration.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I still have a couple of minutes left.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And there is a difference principle -
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It's only on yellow here.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I said I wasn't perfect.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: 25th of December, Mr. Vice President.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: He can have another ten seconds if he wants, Jim.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Well, the matter of judgment is very important.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: A report on international terrorism chaired by the Vice President was released and made some very specific recommendations about how to deal with terrorism.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The Vice President ignored them.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: He says mistakes were made.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Very serious mistakes in judgment were made.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: He says, Ã¢â€°Â¥Well, let's concede that the administration has been doing business with Noriega.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Has made him a part of our foreign policy and has been funneling aid to Contras through convicted drug dealers.Ã¢â€°Â¤
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think those are very very serious questions of judgment, which those of you who are watching us here tonight have a right to judge and review.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We're not going to make those kinds of mistakes.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: If you do, you invite the taking of more hostages.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It was ignored in that case and it was a very very serious mistake in judgment.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I see a young man that was elected to the Senate twice, to the House of Representatives twice.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I see a man who is young and I am putting my confidence in a whole generation of people that are in their 30Ãâ‚¬s and 40Ãâ‚¬s.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I see a man that took the leadership in the Job Training Partnership Act and that retrains people in this highly competitive changing society we're in, so if a person loses his hob he is retrained for a benefit-for a-work that will be productive and he won't have to go on one of these many programs that the liberal-talking about.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I see a young man who is a knowledgeable-in defense and there are three people on our ticket that are knowledgeable-in the whole-in the race-knowledgeable in defense and Dan Quayle is one of them and I am one of them.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I believe that he will be outstanding.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And he took a tremendous pounding and everybody now knows that he took a very unfair pounding.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I'd like each person to say did I jump to conclusions running down rumors that were so outrageous and so brutal.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And he's kept his head up.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And he will do very very well.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And he has my full confidence and he'll have the confidence of people that are in their 30Ãâ‚¬s and 40Ãâ‚¬s and more.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So, judge the man on his record not on the-lot of rumors and innuendo and trying to fool around with his name.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: My opponent says J. Danforth Quayle.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Do you know who J. Danforth was, he was a man who gave his life in World War II, so ridiculing a person's name is a little beneath this process.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And he'll do very well when we get into the debates.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, when it comes to ridicule, George, you win a gold medal.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think we can agree on that in the course of this campaign.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But did I-did I sense a desire that maybe Lloyd Bentsen ought to be your running mate when you said there are three people on your ticket?
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: No, I think the debate ought to be between you and Lloyd.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think the American people have a right to judge us on this question, on how we picked a running mate, a person who is a heartbeat away from the presidency.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I picked Lloyd Bentsen, distinguished, strong, mature, a leader in the Senate, somebody whose qualifications nobody has questioned.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Mr. Bush picked Dan Quayle.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I doubt very much that Dan Quayle was the best qualified person for that job.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And as a matter of fact, I think for most people the notion of President Quayle is a very very troubling thought.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Well, John, I'm a man that's been a chief executive for ten years.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I've picked a lot of people.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I know that the people you pick make an enormous difference in your ability to govern and I set high standards.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I try to meet them and I insist that people who work for me meet them, if they don't, they don't stick around very long.
