Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But I didn't pick Lloyd Bentsen because he was a clone of Mike Dukakis.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I picked him because he was somebody who would be a strong Vice President, somebody who would be an active Vice President.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Somebody who would come to me if somebody came up with a crazy idea that we ought to trade arms to the Ayatollah for hostages and say, Ã¢â€°Â¥Mr.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We shouldn't do that.Ã¢â€°Â¤ That's the kind of Vice President I want.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: He, himself, has said, and rightly so, that he'll be a strong Vice President.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: When the Vice President makes a decision, that will be his decision.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And I'm very very proud of that choice.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And I didn't pick him because he agreed with me on everything.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: You know, Sam Rayburn once said that if two people agree on everything then only one person is doing the thinking.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The fact is I've picked somebody who not only will be a great Vice President, but if, God forbid, something happens to the president, could step into that office and do so with distinction and with strength and with leadership.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I doubt very much that Mr. Bush's selection for the Vice Presidency of the United States meets that test.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Well, I-we obviously have a difference.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I believe it does meet the test.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We'll have an opportunity to see the two of them in action in a friendly forum, wonderful friendly fashion like this.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I wanted to hitchhike a ride home in his tank with him.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But now we've got the lines too carefully drawn here.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But you talk about judgment.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I mean, what kind of judgment-I mean, jumping all over the president on his decision on one area of farm policy.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: What kind of judgment sense has your chief education adviser now in jail in Massachusetts?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I mean, there's-I don't think this is a fair argument.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But nevertheless, I support my nominee for Vice President and he'll do an outstanding job.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, I think we have to go to work on the problem of Third World debt and we've got to assist those Third World countries in dealing with this massive debt which they currently-which they have incurred and which is burdening them and which if we don't do something about it and assist them along with other nations around the world, we'll destroy their economies, destroy their future.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And at the same time will destroy markets that are important to our farmers.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But I also believe we need an agricultural policy which doesn't cost us 15 to 20 to 25 billion dollars a year that it's been costing us over the course of the past three or four years under this administration.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think it's going to require good, solid credit policies.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And thanks to the Congress we now have an agricultural credit bill which is helping and improving the situation with at least some of our farmers.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think it's going to require a combination of supply management and reasonable price supports to make sure that our farmers get a decent price and I think it also is going to require an administration that understand that there are tremendous opportunities out there for the development of new uses for agricultural products, new uses which can help us to clean up our environment at the same time.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Bio-degradable plastics-plastic-gasohol, which the Vice President has been involved in, road de-icers made from corn products.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I mean, there are enormous opportunities out there to expand markets and to build a strong future for our farmers.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But I don't think there's anything mutually exclusive or contradictory about building a strong farm economy in this country and assisting our family farms and providing a good strong future for rural communities and for rural America and at the same time working on Third World debt.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: As a matter of fact, Mexico, itself, is one of our biggest agricultural customers, so in the sense that we can work to help Mexico rebuild and expand and deal with these very serious economic problems we help our farmers at the same time.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I oppose supply management and production controls.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I support the farm bill, the 1985 farm bill and spending is moving in the right direction.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to expand our markets abroad and that's why I've called for that first economic summit to be on agriculture.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I will not go back to the way the Democrats did it and used food as a political weapon and throw a grain embargo on the farmers in this country.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to see rural redevelopment and I have been out front in favor of alternate sources of energy and one of them is gasohol and comes from using your corn and I think we can do better in terms of biodegradable for a lot of product, so I'm optimistic about the agricultural economy.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: In terms of the Third World, I support the Baker plan.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to see market economies spring up all around the world and to the degree they do, we are succeeding.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I don't want to see the banks let off the hook.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I would oppose that, but I think were on the right track in agriculture and I am very very encouraged.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But let's not go back to that-what they call supply management and production control, that'll simply price us out of the international market.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Let's try to expand our markets abroad.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I talked in New Orleans about a gentler and kinder nation and I have made specific proposals on education and the environment and on ethics and energy and how we do better in battling crime in our country.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But there are two main focal points of this election.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to keep this expansion going.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Yes, we want change but we are the change.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The best poverty program is a job with dignity in the private sector.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And in terms of peace, we are on the right track.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We've achieved an arms control agreement that our critics thought was never possible and I want to build on it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to see us finalize that START agreement and I want it to be the one to finally lead the world to banishing chemical and biological weapons.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to see asymmetrical reductions in conventional forces.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And then it gets down to a question of values.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We've had a chance to spell out our differences on the Pledge of Allegiance here tonight and on tough sentencing of drug king pins and this kind of thing.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I do favor the death penalty.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we've got a wide array of differences on those.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But in the final analysis-in the final analysis, the person goes into that voting booth, they're going to say, Ã¢â€°Â¥Who has the values I believe in?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Who has the experience that we trust?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Who has the integrity and stability to get the job done?Ã¢â€°Â¤ My fellow Americans, I am that man and I ask for your support.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: This has been an extraordinary 18 months for Kitty and me and for our family.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We've had an opportunity to campaign all over this country and to meet with so many of you in communities and states and regions to get to know you.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I'm more optimistic today than I was when I began about this nation providing we have the kind of leadership in Washington that can work with you, that can build partnerships, that can build jobs in every part of this country, not certain parts of this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: You know, my friends, my parents came to this country as immigrants like millions and millions of Americans before them and since, seeking opportunities, seeking the American dream.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: They made sure their sons understood that this was the greatest country in the world, that those of us especially who were the sons and daughters of immigrants had a special responsibility to give something to the country that had opened up its arms to our parents and given so much to them.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I believe in the American dream.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I'm a product of it and I want to help that dream come true for every single citizen in this land, with a good job and good wages, with good schools in every part of this country and every community in this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: With decent and affordable housing that our people can buy and own and live in, so that we end the shame of hopelessness in America.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: With decent and affordable healthcare for all working families.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Yes, it's a tough problem as Mr. Bush says, but itÃâ‚¬s not an insolvable problem.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It's one that we will solve and must solve, with a clean and wholesome environment and with a strong America that's strong militarily and economically as we must be, an America that provides strong international leadership because we're true to our values.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We have an opportunity working together to build that future, to build a better America, to build a best America, because the best America doesn't hide.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The best America doesn't leave some of its citizens behind.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We live-we bring everybody along.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And the best America is not behind us.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The best America is yet to come.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Mr. Kraft, I believe that the American people, in the next four years under a Ford administration, will be called upon to make those necessary sacrifices to preserve the peace which we have.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Which means, of course, that uh - we will have to maintain an adequate military capability - which means, of course, that we will have to add a uh - I think uh - a few billion dollars to our defense appropriations to make certain that we have adequate uh -strategic forces - adequate conventional forces.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I think the American people will be called upon to uh - uh - be in the forefront in giving leadership to the solution of those problems that must be solved in the Middle East, in southern Africa, and any problems that might arise in the Pacific.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The American people will be called upon to tighten their belts a bit in meeting some of the problems that we face domestically.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I don't think that uh - America can go on a big spending spree with a whole lot of new programs uh - that would add significantly to the federal budget.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I believe that the American people, if given the leadership that I would expect to give, would be willing to give this thrust to preserve the peace and the necessary restraint at home to hold the lid on spending so that we could, I think, have a long overdue and totally justified tax decrease for the middle-income people.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And then, with the economy that would be generated from a restraint on spending, and a tax uh reduction primarily for the middle-income people, then I think the American people would be willing to make those sacrifices for peace and prosperity in the next uh - four years.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Doesn't your policy really imply that we're going to have a fairly high rate of unemployment over a fairly long time, that growth is gonna be fairly slow, and that we're not gonna be able to do much - very much in the next four or five years to meet the basic agenda of our national needs in the cities, in health, uh in transit and a whole lot of things like that.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: overlapping, aren't those the real costs?
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: No, Mr. Kraft, we're spending very significant amounts of money now, some $200 billion a year, almost 50 percent of our total federal expenditure uh - by the federal government at the present time for human needs.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now we will probably need to increase that to same extent.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But we don't have to have - growth in spending that will blow the lid off and add to the problems of inflation.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I believe we can meet the problems within the cities of this country and still uh - give a tax reduction.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I proposed, as you know, a reduction to increase the personal exemption from seven hundred and fifty to a thousand dollars.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: With the fiscal program that I have, and if you look at the projections, it shows that we will reduce unemployment, that we will continue to win the battle against inflation, and at the same time give the kind of quality of life that I believe is possible in America.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Uh - a job, a home for all those that'll work and save for it, uh - safety in the streets, uh - health that is a - health care that is affordable.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: These things can be done if we have the right vision and the right restraint and the right leadership.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Well I might say first of all that I think in case of the Carter administration the sacrifices would be much less.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Mr. Ford's own uh - environmental agency has projected a 10 percent unemployment rate by 1978 if he's uh - president.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The American people are ready to make sacrifices if they are part of the process.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: If they know that they will be helping to make decisions and won't be excluded from being an involved party to the national purpose.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The major effort we must put forward is to put our people back to work.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I think that this uh - is one example where uh - a lot of people have selfish, grasping ideas now.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I remember 1973 in the depth of the uh - energy crisis when President Nixon called on the American people to make a sacrifice, to cut down on the waste of uh - gasoline, to cut down on the uh - speed of automobiles.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It was a - a tremendous surge of patriotism, that "I want to make a sacrifice for my country."
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think we uh - could call together, with strong leadership in the White House, business, industry and labor, and say let's have voluntary price restraints.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Let's lay down some guidelines so we don't have continuing inflation.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: At the other extreme, uh - just 1 percent of the richest people in our country derive 25 percent of all the tax benefits.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: So both those extremes grasp for advantage and the person who has to pay that expense is the middle-income family who's still working for a living and they have to pay for the rich who have privilege, and for the poor who are not working.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But I think uh - uh - a balanced approach, with everybody being part of it and a striving for unselfishness, could help as it did in 1973 to let people sacrifice for their own country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I know I'm ready for it.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think the American people are too.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think the major reason for a decrease in participation that we have experienced ever since 1960 has been the deep discouragement of the American people about the performance of public officials.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: When you've got seven and a half, eight million people out of work, and you've got three times as much inflation as you had during the last eight-year Democratic administration, when you have the highest deficits in history; when you have it uh - becoming increasingly difficult far a family to put a child through college or to own a home, there's a natural inclination to be turned off.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Also, in the aftermath of Vietnam and Cambodia and uh - Watergate and uh - the CIA revelations, people have feel - have felt that they've uh been betrayed by public officials, I have to admit that in the uh - heat of the campaign - I've been in thirty primaries during the springtime, I've been campaigning for twenty-two months - I've made some mistakes.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I think this is uh - uh - part of uh - of just being a human being.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I - I have to say that my campaign has been an open one.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And uh - the Playboy thing has been of great - very great concern to me.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I don't know how to deal with it exactly.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Uh - I uh - agreed to give the interview uh - to Playboy Other people have done it who are notable - uh - Governor Jerry Brown, uh - Walter Cronkite, uh - Albert Schweitzer, Mr. Ford's own secretary of the treasury, Mr. Simon, uh - William Buckley - many other people.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But they weren't running for president, and in retrospect, from hindsight, I would not have given that uh - interview had I do it - had it - I to do it over again.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: If I should ever decide in the future to discuss my - my deep Christian beliefs and uh - condemnation and sinfulness, I'll use another forum besides Playboy.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But I can say this, uh - I'm doing the best I can to get away from that, and during the next ten days, the American people will not see the Carter campaign running uh - television advertisements and newspaper advertisements based on a personal attack on President Ford's character.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I believe that the opposite is true with President Ford's campaign, and uh - I hope that we can leave those issues in this next ten days about personalities and mistakes of the past - we've both made some mistakes - and talk about unemployment, inflation, housing, education, taxation, government organization, stripping away of secrecy, and the things that are crucial to the American people.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I regret the things in my own long campaign that have been mistaken, but I'm trying to do away with those the last ten days.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I believe that the uh - American people have been turned off in this election, uh - Mr. Maynard, for a variety of reasons.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We have seen on Capitol Hill, in the Congress, uh - a great many uh - allegations of wrong-doing, of uh - alleged immorality, uh - those are very disturbing to the American people.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: They wonder how an elected representative uh - can serve them and participate in such activities uh - serving in the Congress of the United States.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Yes, and I'm certain many, many Americans were turned off by the revelations of Watergate, a very, very uh - bad period of time in American political history.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Yes, and thousands, maybe millions of Americans were turned off because of the uh - problems that came out of our involvement in Vietnam.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But on the other hand, I found on July fourth of this year, a new spirit born in America.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We were celebrating our Bicentennial; and I find that uh - there is a - a movement as I travel around the country of greater interest in this campaign.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now, like uh - any hardworking uh - person seeking public office uh - in the campaign, inevitably sometimes you will use uh - rather graphic language and I'm guilty of that just like I think most others in the political arena.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But I do make a pledge that in the next ten days when we're asking the American people to make one of the most important decisions in their lifetime, because I think this election is one of the mast vital in the history of America, that uh - we do together what we can to stimulate voter participation.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Well, Mr. uh - Nelson, uh - I testified before two committees, House and Senate, on precisely the questions that you have asked.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And the testimony under oath was to the effect that I did not talk to Mr. Nixon, to Mr. Haldeman, to Mr. Ehrlichman, or to any of the people at the White House.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I said I had no recollection whatsoever of talking with any of the White House legislative liaison people.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I indicated under oath that the initiative that I took was at the request of the ranking members of the House Banking and Currency Committee on the Republican side, which was a legitimate request and a proper response by me.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now that was gone into by two congressional committees, and following that investigation, both committees overwhelmingly approved me, and the House and the Senate did likewise.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now, in the meantime, the special prosecutor, within the last few days, after an investigation himself, said there was no reason for him to get involved because he found nothing that would justify it.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And then just a day or two ago, the attorney general of the United States made a further investigation and came to precisely the same conclusion.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now, after all of those investigations by objective, responsible people, I think the matter is closed once and for all.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But to add one other feature, I don't control any of the tapes.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Those tapes are in the jurisdiction of the courts and I have no right to say "yes" or "no."
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But all the committees, the attorney general, the special prosecutor, all of them have given me a clean bill of health.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I think the matter is settled once and for all.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: That's for the uh - proper authorities who have control over those tapes to make that decision.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I have given every bit of evidence, answered every question that's as- been asked me by any senator or any member of the House.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Plus the fact, that the special prosecutor, on his own initiation, and the attorney general on his initiation, the highest law enforcement official in this country, all of them have given me a clean bill of health.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And I've told everything I know about it.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I think the matter is settled once and for all.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I don't have a response.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In the last uh - two weeks, I've had a chance to talk to uh - two men who have visited uh - the Soviet Union, Yugoslavia and China.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: One is Governor Avell- Averell Harriman, who visited the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia, and the other is James Schlesinger, whom I think you accompanied to uh - China.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I got a- a complete report back from those countries from these two distinguished - uh - gentlemen.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Mr. Harriman talked to the leaders in Yugoslavia, and I think it's accurate to say that there is no uh - prospect in their opinion, of the Soviet Union invading uh - Yugoslavia should uh - Mr. Tito pass away.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The present leadership uh - there is uh - is fairly uniform in - in their purpose, and I think it's a close-knit group, uh - and uh - I think it would be unwise for us to say that we will go to war uh - in Yugoslavia uh - if the Soviets should invade, which I think would be an extremely unlikely thing.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I have maintained from the very beginning of my campaign, and this was a standard answer that I made in response to the Yugoslavian question, that I would never uh - go to war or become militarily involved, in the internal affairs of another country unless our own security was direc- rectly threatened.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And uh - I don't believe that our security would be directly threatened if the Soviet Union went uh - into Yugoslavia.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I certainly hope it won't.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I would take eh - the strongest possible measures short of uh - actual military uh - action there by our own troops, but I doubt that that would be an eventuality.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I firmly believe, uh - Mr. Kraft, that it's unwise for a president to signal in advance what uh - options he might exercise if any uhh - international problem arose.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I think we all recall with some sadness that at uh - the period of the nin- late nineteen forties, early nineteen fifties, there were some indications that the United States would not include uh - South Korea in an area of defense.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: There are some who allege, I can't prove it true or untrue, that uh - such a statement uh - in effect invited the North Koreans to invade South Korea.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It's a fact they did.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It's far better for a person sitting in the White House uh - who has a number of options to make certain that the uh - other side, so to speak, doesn't know precisely what you're going to do.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And therefore, that was the reason that I would not uh - identify any particular course of action uh - when I responded to a question a week or so ago.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I have indicated to General Brown that uh - the words that he used in that interview, in that particular case and in several others, were very ill advised.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And General Brown has indicated uh - his apology, his regrets, and I think that will, uh - in this situation, settle the matter.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It is tragic that uh - the full transcript of that interview was not released and that there were excerpts, some of the excerpts, taken out of context.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Not this one, however, that you bring up.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: General Brown has an exemply [sic] record of military performance.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: He served this nation with great, great skill and courage and bravery for thirty-five years.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And I think it's the consensus of the people who are knowledgeable in the military field, that he is probably the outstanding military leader and strategist that we have in America today.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now he did use uh - ill-advised words, but I think in the fact that he apologized, that he was reprimanded, uh - does permit him to stay on and continue that kind of leadership that's we so badly need as we enter into uh - negotiations uh - under the SALT II agreement, or if we have operations that might be developing uh in the Middle East or southern Africa, in the Pacific, uh - we need a man with that experience, that knowledge, that know-how, and I think, in light of the fact that he has uh - apologized, uh - would not have justified my asking for his resignation.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Well, just briefly, I - I think this is uh - the second time that General Brown has made a statement that - for which he did have to apologize.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think the first one was related to uh - the unwarranted influence of American Jews on the media and uh - in the Congress.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This one concerned uh - Great Britain.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think he said that Israel was a - a military burden on us and that Iran hoped to reestablish the Persian Empire.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Ah - I'm not uh - sure that I remembered earlier that President Ford had - had expressed uh - his concern about the statement or apologized for it.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is uh - something, though, that I think uh - is indicative of the need among the American people to know how its commander-in-chief, the president, feels and - and - and I think the only criticism that I would have uh - on - of Mr. Ford is that uh - immediately when the statement was re - re - revealed, uh - perhaps a - a statement from the president would have been a clarifying and a very beneficial thing.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I don't believe it does.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Uh - I began campaigning uh - twenty-two months ago.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: At that time, nobody thought I had a chance to win.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Uh - very few people knew who I was.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I came from a tiny town, as you know, Plains, and didn't hold public office, didn't have very much money.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And my first organization was just four or five people plus my wife and my children, my three sons and their wives.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And we won the nomination by going out into the streets - barbershops, beauty parlors, restaurants, stores, in factory shift lines also in farmers' markets and livestock sale barns - and we talked a lot and we listened a lot and we learned from the American people.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And we built up uh - an awareness among the uh - voters of this country, particularly those in whose primaries I entered - thirty of them, nobody's ever done that before - about who I was and what I stood for.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Now we have a very, very wide-ranging group of advisers who help me prepare for these debates and who teach me about international economics, and foreign affairs, defense matters, health, education, welfare, government reorganization.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I'd say, several hundred of them.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And they're very fine and very highly qualified.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The one major decision that I have made since acquiring the nomination, and I share this with President Ford, is the choice of a vice president.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think this should be indicative of the kind of leaders I would choose to help me if I am elected.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I chose Senator Walter Mondale.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And the only criterion I ever put forward in my own mind was who among the several million people in this country would be the best person qualified to be president, if something should happen to me and to join me in being vice president if I should serve out my term.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I'm convinced now, more than I was when I got the nomination, that Walter Mondale was the right choice, And I believe this is a good indication of the kind of people I would choose in the future.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Mr. Ford has had that same choice to make.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I don't want to say anything critical of Senator Dole, but I've never heard Mr. Ford say that that was his prim- primary consideration - Who is the best person I could choose in this country to be president of the United States?
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I feel completely at ease knowing that someday Senator Mondale might very well be president.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In the last five pres- vice presidential uh - nominees, uh - incumbents, three of them have become president.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But I think this is indicative of what I would do.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The Governor may not have heard my uh - established criteria for the selection of a vice president, but uh - it was a well-established criteria that the person I selected would be fully qualified to be president of the United States.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And Senator Bob Dole is so qualified: sixteen years in the House of Representatives and in the Senate, uhh - very high responsibilities on important committees.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I don't mean to be critical of uh - Senator Mondale, but uh - I was uh - very, very surprised when I read that uh - Senator Mondale made a very derogatory, very personal comment about General Brown uh - after the news story that uh - broke about General Brown.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: If my recollection is correct he indicated that uh - General Brown was not qualified to be a sewer commissioner.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I don't think that's a proper way to describe aayuh- chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff who has fought for his country for thirty-five years, and I'm sure the governor would agree with me on that.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Uh - I think Senator Dole would show more good judgment and discretion than to so describe uh - a heroic and brave and very outstanding leader of the military.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: So I think our selection uh - of Bob Dole as vice president uh - is based on merit.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And if he should ever become uh - the president of the United States, with his vast experience as member the House and a member of the Senate, as well as a vice president, I think he would do an outstanding job as president of the United States.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: That's a tribute to their interest in this election.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I vetoed the strip-mining bill, Mr. Kraft, because it was the overwhelming consensus of knowledgeable people that that strip-mining bill would have meant the loss of literally uh - thousands of jobs, something around a hundred and forty thousand jabs.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Number two, that strip-mining bill would've severely set back our need for more coal, and Governor Carter has said repeatedly that coal is the resource that we need to use more in the effort to become independent of the uh - Arab oil supply.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: So, I vetoed it because of a loss of jobs and because it would've interfered with our energy independence program.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The auto emissions - uh - it was agreed by Leonard Woodcock, the head of the UAW, and by the uh - heads of all of the automobile industry, we had labor and management together saying that those auto emission standards had to be modified.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But let's talk about what the Ford administration has done in the field of environment.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I have increased, as president, by over 60 percent the funding for water treatment plants in the United States, the federal contribution.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I have fully funded the land and water conservation program; in fact, have recommended and the Congress approved a substantially increased land and water conservation program.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Uh - I have uh - added in the current year budget the funds for the National Park Service.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: For example, we uh - proposed about $12 million to add between four and five hundred more employees for the National Park Service.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And a month or so ago I did uh - likewise say over the next ten years we should expand - double - this national parks, the wild wilderness areas, the scenic river areas.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And then, of course, the - the final thing is that I have signed and approved of more scenic rivers, more wilderness areas, since I've been president than any other president in the history of the United States.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Well, I might say that I think the League of Conservation Voters is absolutely right.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This uh - administration's record on environment is very bad.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Uh - I think it's accurate to say that the uh - strip-mining law which was passed twice by the Congress - uh - and was only like two votes I believe of being overridden - would have been good for the country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The claim that it would have put hundred and forty thousand miners out of work is uh - hard to believe, when at the time Mr. Ford vetoed it, the United Mine Workers was uh - supporting the bill.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I don't think they would have supported the uh - bill had they known that they would lose a hundred and forty thousand jobs.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: There's been a consistent policy on the part of this administration to lower or delay enforcement of air pollution standards and water pollution standards.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And under both President Nixon and Ford, monies have been impounded that would've gone to uh - cities and others to control uh - water pollution.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We have no energy policy.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We, I think, are the only developed nation in the world that has no comprehensive energy policy, to permit us to plan in an orderly way how to shift from increasing the scarce uh - energy uh - forms: oil, and have research and development concentrated on the increased use of coal, which I strongly favor.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The research and development to be used primary to make the coal burning uh - be clean.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We need a heritage trust program, similar to the one we had in Georgia, to set aside additional lands that have uh - geological and archeological importance, uh natural areas for enjoyment.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Uh - the lands that Mr. Ford uh - brags about having approved are in Alaska and they are enormous in uh - in size.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But as far as the accessibility of them by the American people, it's very uh - far in the future.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've taken no strong position in the uh - control of pollution of our oceans, and I would say the worst uh - threat to the environment of all is nuclear proliferation.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And this administration, having been in office now for two years or more, has still not taken strong and bold action to stop the proliferation of nuclear waste around the world, particularly plutonium.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Those are some brief remarks about the failures of this administration.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Yes, I'd be glad to.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In the first place, uh - as is the case with the environmental policy and the energy policy that I just described, and the policy for nonproliferation of uh - of nuclear waste, this administration has no urban policy.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It's impossible for mayors or governors to cooperate with the resident, because they can't anticipate what's gonna happen next.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This has not been done, unfortunately.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I remember the headline in the Daily News that said, "Ford to New York: Drop Dead."
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think it's very important that our cities know that they have a partner in the federal government.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Quite often Congress has passed laws in the past designed to help people with uh - the ownership of homes and with the control of crime and with adequate health care and education programs and so forth.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Uh - those uh programs were designed to help those who need it most.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And quite often this has been in the very poor people and neighborhoods in the downtown urban centers.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Because of the uh - great -ly- greatly uh - advantaged uh - tho- per - persons who live in the suburbs, better education, better organization, more articulate, more aware of what the laws are, quite often this money has been channeled out of the downtown centers where it's needed.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Also I favor all revenue sharing money being used for local governments, and also to remove prohibitions in the use of revenue sharing money so that it can be used to improve education, and health care.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We have now uh - for instance only 7 percent of the total education cost being financed by the federal government.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: When uh - the Nixon-Ford Administration started, this was 10 percent.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: That's a 30 percent reduction in the portion that the federal government contributes to education in just eight years.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And as you know, the education cost has gone up uh - tremendously.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've got an extraordinarily high unemployment rate among downtown urban ghetto areas, uh - particularly among the very poor and particularly among minority groups, sometimes 50 or 60 percent.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And the concentration of employment opportunities in those areas would help greatly not only to reestablish the tax base, but also to help reduce the extraordinary welfare cost.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: One of the major responsibilities on the shoulders of uh - New York City is to - is to finance welfare.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I favor a shifting of the welfare cost away from the local governments altogether.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Those things would help a great deal with the cities, but we still have a - a very serious problem there.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The Ford administration does have a very comprehensive program to help uh - our major metropolitan areas.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I fought for, and the Congress finally went along with a general revenue sharing program, whereby cities and uh - states, uh - the cities two-thirds and the states one-third, get over six billion dollars a year in cash through which they can uh - provide many, many services, whatever they really want.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In addition we uh - in the federal government make available to uh - cities about uh - three billion three hundred million dollars in what we call community development.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In adesh- in addition, uh - uh - as a result of my pressure an the Congress, we got a major mass transit program uh - over a four-year period, eleven billion eight-hundred million dollars.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We have a good housing program, uh - that uh - will result in cutting uh - the down payments by 50 percent and uh - having mortgage payments uh lower at the beginning of any mortgage period.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We're expanding our homestead uh - housing program.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The net result is uh - we think under Carla Hills, who's the chairman of my uh - urban development and uh - neighborhood revitalization program, we will really do a first-class job in helping uh - the communities throughout the country.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: As a matter of fact, that committee under Secretary Hills released about a seventy-five-page report with specific recommendations so we can do a better job uh - the weeks ahead.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And in addition, the tax program of the Ford administration, which provides an incentive for industry to move into our major uh - metropolitan areas, into the inner cities, will bring jobs where people are, and help to revitalize those cities as they can be.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Let me say at the outset, uh - I'm very proud of the record of this administration.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In the cabinet I have one of the outstanding, I think, administrators as the secretary of transportation, Bill Coleman.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: You're familiar, I'm sure, with the recognition given in the Air Force to uh - General James, and there was just uh - approved a three-star admiral, the first in the history of the United States Navy, so uh - we are giving full recognition to individuals of quality in the Ford administration in positions of great responsibility.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In addition, uh - the Department of Justice is fully enforcing, and enforcing effectively, the Voting Rights Act, the legislation that involves jobs, housing for minorities, not only blacks but all others.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Uh - the Department of uh - uh - HUD is enforcing the new legislation that uhh - outlaws, that takes care of redlining.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Uh - what we're doing is saying that there are opportunities, business opportunities, educational opportunities, responsibilities uh - where people with talent, black or any other minority, can fully qualify.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The Office of Minority Business in the Department of Commerce has made available more money in trying to help uh - black businessmen or other minority businessmen than any other administration since the office was established.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The Office of Small Business, under Mr. Kobelinski, has a very massive program trying to help the black community.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The individual who wants to start a business or expand his business as a black businessman is able to borrow, either directly or with guaranteed loans.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I believe on the record that this administration has been more responsive and we have carried out the law to the letter, and I'm proud of the record.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The uh - description just made of this administration's record is hard to uh - recognize.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think it's accurate to say that Mr. Ford voted against the uh - Voting Rights Acts and the uh - Civil Rights Acts in their uh - debative stage I think once it was assured they were going to pass he finally voted for it.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This country uh - changed drastically in 1969 when the uh - terms of John Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson were over and Richard Nixon and - and Gerald Ford became the presidents.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: There was a time when there was hope for those who uh - were poor and downtrodden and who were - uh elderly or who were - uh ill or who were in minority groups, but that time has been gone.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think the greatest thing that ever happened to the South was the passage of the Civil Rights Act and the opening up of opportunities - uh to black people - the chance to vote, to hold a job, to buy a house, to go to school, and to participate in public affairs.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It not only liberated - uh black people but it also liberated the whites.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've seen uh - in many instances in recent years a minority affairs uh - section of uh Small Loan Administration, uh - Small Business Administration lend uh - a black entrepreneur just enough money to get started, and then to go bankrupt.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The bankruptcies have gone up - uh in an extraordinary degree.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Uh - FHA, which used to be a very responsible agency, uh - that everyone looked to to help own a home, lost six million dollars last year.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: There've been over thirteen hundred indictments in HUD, over eight hundred convictions relating just to home loans.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And now the federal government has become the world's greatest slum landlord.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've got a 30 percent or 40 percent unemployment rate among minority uh - young people.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And there's been no concerted effort given to the needs of those who are both poor and black, or poor and who speak a foreign language.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And that's where there's been a great uh generation of despair, and ill health, and the lack of education, lack of purposefulness, and the lack of hope for the future.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But it doesn't take just a quiet uh - dormant uh minimum enforcement of the law.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It requires an aggressive searching out and reaching out to help people who especially need it.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And that's been lacking in the last eight years.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Uh - we've always had, I think, a lot of constitutional amendments proposed, but the passage of them has been uh - fairly slow, and uh - few and far between.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In the two-hundred-year history there's been a very uh - cautious approach to this.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We - quite often we have a transient problem.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I - I'm strongly against a- abortion.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I don't think the government oughta do anything to encourage abortion.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But I don't favor a constitutional amendment on the subject.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But short of the constitutional amendment, and within the confines of the Supreme Court rulings, I'll do everything I can to minimize the need for abortions with better sex education, family planning, with better adoptive procedures.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I personally don't believe that the federal government oughta finance abortions, but I - I draw the line and don't support a constitutional amendment.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: However, I honor the right of people who seek the constitutional amendments on school busing, on uh - prayer in the schools and an abortion.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But among those you named, I won't actively work for the passage of any of them.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: support the uh - Republican uh - platform, which calls for the constitutional amendment that would uh - outlaw abortions.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I favor the particular constitutional amendment that would turn over to the states the uh - individual right to the voters in those states uh - the chance to make a decision by public referendum.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Uh I call that the people amendment.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I think if you really believe that the people of a state ought to make a decision on a matter of this kind that uh - we ought to have a federal constitutional amendment that would permit each one of the fifty states to make the choice.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Uh - I think this is a responsible and a proper way to proceed.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Uhh - I believe also that uh - there is some merit to a - an amendment that uh - uh - Senator Everett Dirksen uh - proposed very frequently, an amendment that would uh - change the court decision as far as voluntary prayer in public schools.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Uh - it seems to me that there should have - be an opportunity, uh - as long as it's voluntary, as long as there is no uh - compulsion whatsoever, that uh - an individual ought to have that right.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: So in those two cases I think uh - such uh - a constitutional amendment would be proper, and I really don't think in either case they're trivial matters.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I think they're matters of very deep conviction, as far as many, many people in this country believe.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And therefore, they shouldn't be treated lightly.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But they're matters that are ah - important.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And in those two cases, I would favor them.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The record just doesn't prove that such legislation or action by a local city council is effective.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: What we have to do, and this is the crux of the matter, is to make it very, very uh - difficult for a person who uses a gun in the commission of a crime to stay out of jail.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: If we make the use of a gun in the commission.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: of a crime a serious criminal offense, and that person is prosecuted, then, in my opinion, we are going after the person who uses the gun for the wrong reason.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I don't believe in the registration of handguns or the registration of the handgun owner.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: That has not proven to be effective, and therefore, I think the better way is to go after the criminal, the individual who commits a crime in the possession of a gun and uses that gun for a part of his criminal activity.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Those are the people who ought to be in jail.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And the only way to do it is to pass strong legislation so that once apprehended, indicted, convicted, they'll be in jail and off the streets and not using guns in the commission of a crime.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And uh - the individuals that uh - with whom I've consulted have not uh - convinced me that uh - a national registration of handguns or handgun owners will solve the problem you're talking about.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The person who wants to use a gun for an illegal purpose can get it whether it's registered or outlawed.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And they are the people who ought to go behind bars.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: You should not in the process penalize the legitimate handgun owner.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And when you go through the process of registration, you in effect, are penalizing that individual who uses his gun for a very legitimate purpose.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I - I think it's accurate to say that Mr. Ford's position on gun control has changed.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Uh - earlier, uh - Mr. Levi, his uh - attorney general, put forward a gun control proposal, which Mr. Ford later, I believe, espoused, that called for the prohibition against the uh sale aw- of the uh - so-called Saturday Night Specials.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And it would've put uh - very strict uh - uh - control over who owned a handgun.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I have been a hunter all my life and happen to own both shotguns, rifles, and a handgun.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And uh - the only purpose that I would see in registering uh - handguns and not long guns of any kind would be to prohibit the uh - ownership of those guns by those who've used them in the commission of a crime, or who uh - have been proven to be mentally incompetent to own a gun.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I believe that limited approach to the - to the question would be uh - advisable, and - and I think, adequate.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But that's as far as I would go with it.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: While I was governor of Georgia, although I'm not a lawyer, we had complete reform of the Georgia court system.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We uh - streamlined the structure of the court, put in administrative officers, put a unified court system in, required that all uh - severe sentences be reviewed far uniformity.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And, in addition to that put forward a proposal that was adopted and used throughout my own term of office of selection of - for all judges and district attorneys or prosecuting attorneys, on the basis of merit.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Every time I had a vacancy on the Georgia Supreme Court - and I filled five of those vacancies out of seven total and about half the court of appeals judges, about 35 percent of the trial judges - I was given from an objective panel the five most highly qualified persons in Georgia.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And from those five, I always chose the first one or second one.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: So merit selection of judges is the most important single criterion.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I would institute the same kind of procedure as president, not only in judicial appointments, but also in diplomatic appointments.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Secondly, I think that the Burger Court has fairly well confirmed the major and - and most far-reaching and most controversial decisions of the Warren Court.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Civil rights - uh has been confirmed by the Burger Court, hasn't been uh - reversed, and I don't think there's any inclination to reverse those basic decisions.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The one-man, one-vote rule, which is a very important one that uh - s- struck down the unwarranted influence in the legislature of parsley - uh populated areas of - of the states.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The uh - right of indigent or very poor accused persons to uh - legal counsel.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Uh - I think the Burger Court has confirmed that basic and very controversial decision of the Warren Court.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Also the - the protection of an arrested person against unwarranted persecution in trying to get a false uh - confession.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But now I think there have been a couple of instances where the Burger Court has made technical rulings where an obviously guilty person was later found to be guilty.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I think that in that case uh - some of the more liberal uh - members of the uh - so-called Warren Court agreed with those decisions.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But the only uh - thing I uh - have pointed out was, what I've just said, and that there was a need to clarify the technicalities so that you couldn't be forced to release a person who was obviously guilty just because of a - of a small technicality in the law.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And - and that's a reversal of position uh by the Burger Court with which I do agree.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Okay, I thought I answered it by saying that it would be on the basis of merit.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Once the uh - search and analysis procedure had been completed, and once I'm given a list of the five or seven or ten uh - best qualified persons in the country, I would make a selection from among those uh - persons.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: If the uh - list was, uh - in my opinion, fairly uniform, if there was no outstanding person, then I would undoubtedly choose someone who would most accurately reflect my own basic politi- political philosophy as best I could determine it.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Which would be uh - to continue the progress that has been made under the last two uh - courts - the Warren Court and the Burger Court.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I would also like to uh - completely revise our criminal justice system - to do some of the things at the federal level in court reform that I've just described, as has been done in Georgia and other states.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And then I would like to appoint people who would be interested in helping with that.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I know that uh Chief Justice Burger is.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: He hasn't had help from the administration, from the Congress, to carry this out.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The uh - emphasis, I think, of the - of the court system uh - should be to interpret the uh - the Constitution and the laws uh - equally between property protection and personal protection.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But when there's uh - a very narrow decision - which quite often there's one that reaches the Supreme Court - I think the choice should be with human rights.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And uh - that would be another factor that I would follow.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I had one opportunity to nominate uh - an individual to the Supreme Court and I selected the Circuit Court of Appeals judge from Illinois, uh - John Paul Stevens.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I selected him because of his outstanding record as a Circuit Court of Appeals Judge, and I was very pleased that uh - an overwhelming Democratic United States Senate, after going into his background, came to the conclusion that he was uh - fit and should serve, and the vote in his behalf was overwhelming.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: So, I would say somebody in the format of uh - Justice Stevens would be the kind of an individual that I would uh - select in the future, as I did him in the past.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I uh - believe, however, a comment ought to be made about the direction of the uh - Burger Court, vis-a-vis the uh - court uh - that preceded it.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It seems to me that the Miranda case was a case that really made it very, very difficult for the - uh police, the law enforcement people in this country to uh - do what they could to make certain that the victim of a crime was protected and that those that commit crimes uh - were properly handled and uh - sent to jail.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The Miranda case, uh - the Burger Court uh - is gradually changing, and I'm pleased to see that there are some steps being made by the uh - Burger Court to modify the so-called Miranda decision.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Uh - I might make a correction uh - of what uh - Governor Carter said, uh speaking of uh - uh - gun control, uh - yes, it is true, I believe that the sale of uh - Saturday Night S- Specials should be cut out, but he wants the registration of handguns.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Well, Mr. Kraft, uh - I violently disagree with your assessment.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And I don't think the record justifies the conclusion that you come to.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Uh - let me uh - talk about uh - the economic announcements that were made just this past week.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Yes, it was announced that the uh - GNP real growth in the third quarter was at 4 percent.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But do you realize that over the last ten years that's a higher figure than the average growth during that ten-year period?
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now it's lower than the nine-point-point-two percent growth in the first quarter, and it's lower than the uh 5 percent growth in the second quarter.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But every economist - liberal, conservative that I'm familiar with - recognizes that in the fourth quarter of this year and in the fifth quar- uh - the first quarter of next year that we'll have an increase in real GNP.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But now let's talk about the pluses that came out this week.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We had an 18 percent increase in housing starts.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We had a substantial increase in new permits for housing.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: As a matter of fact, based on the announcement this week, there will be at an annual rate of a million, eight hundred and some thousand new houses built, which is a tremendous increase over last year and a substantial increase over the earlier part of this year.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now in addition, we had a very - some very good news in the reduction in the rate of inflation.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And inflation hits everybody: those who are working and those who are on welfare.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The rate of inflation, as announced just the other day, is under 5 percent; and the uh - 4.4 percent that was indicated at the time of the 4 percent GNP was less than the 5.4 percent.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It means that the American buyer is getting a better bargain today because inflation is less.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Uh Mr. Kraft, uh - I think the record can be put in this uh - in this way, which uh - is the way that I think satisfies most Americans.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Since the depths of the recession, we have added four million jobs.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Im- most importantly, consumer confidence as surveyed by the reputable organization at the University of Michigan is at the highest since 1972.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In other words, there is a growing public confidence in the strength of this economy.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And that means that there will be more industrial activity.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It means that there will be a reduction in the uhh - unemployment.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It means that there will be increased hires.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It means that there will be increased employment.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now we've had this pause, but most economists, regardless of their political philosophy, uh - indicate that this pause for a month or two was healthy, because we could not have honestly sustained a 9.2 percent rate of growth which we had in the first quarter of this year.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We're ahead of all of the Western European country.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The United States is leading the free world out of the recession that was serious a year, year and a half ago.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We're going to see unemployment going down, more jobs available, and the rate of inflation going down.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And I think this is a record that uh - the American people understand and will appreciate.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: With all due respect to President Ford, I think he ought to be ashamed of mentioning that statement, because we have the highest unemployment rate now than we had at any time between the Great Depression caused by Herbert Hoover and the time President Ford took office.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've got seven and a half million people out of jobs.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Since he's been in office, two and a half million more American people have lost their jobs.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In the last four months alone, five hundred thousand Americans have gone on the unemployment roll.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Anybody who says that the inflation rate is in good shape now ought to talk to the housewives.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: One of the overwhelming results that I've seen in the polls is that people feel that you can't plan anymore.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: There's no way to make a prediction that my family might be able to own a home or to put my kid through college.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Savings accounts are losing money instead of gaining money.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Under the present administration - Nixon's and Ford's - we've had three times the inflation rate that we experienced under President Johnson and President Kennedy.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And housing starts - he compares the housing starts with last year.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I don't blame him, because in 1975 we had fewer housing starts in this country, fewer homes built, than any year since 1940.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And we've got a 35 percent unemployment rate in many areas of this country among construction workers.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And Mr. Ford hasn't done anything about it.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I think this shows a callous indifference to the families that have suffered so much.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: He has vetoed bills passed by Congress within the congressional budget guidelines job opportunities for two million Americans.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We'll never have a balanced budget, we'll never meet the needs of our people, we'll never control the inflationary spiral, as long as we have seven and a half or eight million people out of work, who are looking for jobs.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And we've probably got two and a half more million people who are not looking for jobs any more, because they've given up hope.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: That is a very serious indictment of this administration.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It's probably the worst one of all.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Well, that's not exactly an accurate description of what happened.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: When I was that far ahead, it was immediately following the Democratic Convention, and before the Republican Convention.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: At that time, uh - 25 or 30 percent of the Reagan supporters said that they would not support President Ford.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But as occurred at the end of the con- Democratic Convention, the Republican Party unified itself.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I think immediately following the Republican Convention, there was about a ten-point spread.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I believe that to be accurate, I had 49 percent; President Ford, 39 percent.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Uh - the polls uh - are good indications of fluctuations, but they vary widely one from another.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And the only poll I've ever followed is the one that uh - you know, is taken on election day.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I was in uh - thirty primaries in the spring, and uh - at first it was obvious that I didn't have any standing in the poll.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: As a matter of fact, I think when Gallup ran their first poll in December of 1975 they didn't put my name on the list.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: They had thirty-five people on the list.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: My name wasn't even there.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And at the beginning of the year I had about 2 percent.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: So the polls to me are interesting, but they don't determine, you know, my hopes or - or my despair.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I've never depended on powerful political figures to put me in office.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I have a direct relationship with hundreds of people around - hundreds of thousands around the country who actively campaign for me.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In Georgia alone, for instance, I got 84 percent of the vote, and I think there were fourteen people uh - in addition to myself on the ballot, and Governor Wallace had been very strong in Georgia.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And today, we have about five hundred Georgians at their own expense - just working people who believe in me - spread around the country uh - involved in the political campaign.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: So, the polls are interesting, but uh - I don't know how to explain the fluctuation.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think a lot of it uh - depends on current events - uh - sometimes foreign affairs, sometimes domestic affairs.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But I think our hold uh - of support among those who uh - are crucial to the election has been fairly steady.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And my success in the primary season was, I think, notable for a newcomer, from someone who's from outside Washington, who - who never has been a part of the Washington establishment.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I think that we'll have good results uh - on November the second for myself and I hope for the country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think uh - the uh - increase and the uh - prospects as far as I'm concerned and the I - less favorable prospects for Governor Carter, reflect that Governor Carter uh - is inconsistent in many of the positions that he takes.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: He tends to distort on a number of occasions.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Uh - just a moment ago, for example, uh - he uh - was indicating that uh - uh - in the 1950s, for example, uh - unemployment was very low.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: He fails to point out that uh - in the 1950s we were engaged in the war in Vietnam.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We - I mean in Korea - we had uh - three million five hundred thousand young men uh - in the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marines.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: That's not the way to end unemployment or to reduce unemployment.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: At the present time we're at peace.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We are not at war.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We have reduced the military manpower by a million four hundred thousand.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: If we had that many more people in the Army, the Navy, the Air Force, and Marines, our unemployment figure would be considerably less.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But this administration doesn't believe the way to reduce unemployment is to go to war, or to increase the number of people in the military.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: So you cannot compare unemployment, as you sought to, uh - with the present time with the 1950s, because the then administration had people in the military - they were at war, they were fighting overseas, and this administration has reduced the size of the military by a million four hundred thousand.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: They're in the civilian labor market and they're not fighting anywhere around the world today.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: For twenty-five years I served in the Congress under five presidents.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I saw them work, I saw them make very hard decisions.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I didn't always agree with their decisions, whether they were Democratic or Republican presidents.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: For the last two years, I've been the president, and I have found from experience that it's much more difficult to make those decisions than it is to second-guess them.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I became president at the time that the United States was in a very troubled time.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We had inflation of over 12 percent, we were on the brink of the worst recession in the last forty years, we were still deeply involved in the problems of Vietnam.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The American people had lost faith and trust and confidence in the presidency itself.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I think most people know that I did not seek the presidency.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But I am asking for your help and assistance to be president for the next four years.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: During this campaign we've seen a lot of television shows, a lot of bumper stickers, and a great many uh - slogans of one kind or another.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But those are not the things that count.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: What counts is, that the United States celebrated its 200th birthday on July fourth.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: As a result of that wonderful experience all over the United States, there is a new spirit in America.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The American people are healed, are working together.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The American people are moving again, and moving in the right direction.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We have came out of the recession and we're well on the road to real prosperity in this country again.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: There has been a restoration of faith and confidence and trust in the presidency because I've been open, candid and forthright.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I have never promised more than I could produce and I have produced everything that I promised.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Not a single young American is fighting or dying on any foreign soil tonight.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We have peace with freedom.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I've been proud to be president of the United States during these very troubled times.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It would be the highest honor for me to have your support on November second and for you to say, "Jerry Ford, you've done a good job, keep on doing it."
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Thank you, and good night.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Thank you Barbara (barely audible).
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The major purpose of an election for president is to choose a leader.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Someone who can analyze the depths of feeling in our country to set a standard for our people to follow, to inspire our people to reach for greatness, to correct our defects, to answer difficult questions, to bind ourselves together in a spirit of unity.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I don't believe the present administration has done that.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We have been discouraged and we've been alienated.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Sometimes we've been embarrassed and sometimes we've been ashamed.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Our people are out of work, and there's a sense of withdrawal.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But our country is innately very strong.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Mr. Ford is a good and decent man, but he's in - been in office now more than eight hundred days approaching almost as long as John Kennedy was in office.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I'd like to ask the American people what, what's been accomplished.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: A lot remains to be done.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: My own background is different from his.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I served an a hospital authority.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I was in the state senate and I was governor and I'm an engineer, a Naval officer, a farmer, a businessman.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I believe we require someone who can work harmoniously with the Congress, who can work closely with the people of this country, and who can bring a new image and a new spirit to Washington.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Our tax structure is a disgrace, it needs to be reformed.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We never increased sales taxes or income tax or property tax.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: As a matter of fact, the year before I went out of office we gave a $50 million refund to the property taxpayers of Georgia.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We spend six hundred dollars per person in this country - every man, woman and child - for health care.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We still rank fifteenth among all the nations of the world in infant mortality.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And our cancer rate is uh - higher than any country in the world.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Employment ought to be restored to our people.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've become almost a welfare state.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We spend now 700 percent more on unemployment compensation than we did eight years ago when the Republicans took over the White House.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Our people wanna go back to work.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Our education system can be improved.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Secrecy ought to be stripped away from government and a maximum of personal privacy ought to be maintained.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Our housing programs have uh - gone bad.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It used to be that the average - uh family could own a house.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But now less than a third of our people can afford to buy their own homes.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The budget was more grossly out of balance last year than ever before in the history of our country - $65 billion - primarily because our people are not at work.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter
