Text: Inflation is robbing us, as we've already discussed, and the government bureaucracy is uh - just a horrible mess.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This doesn't have to be.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But I do know that if the president of the United States and the Congress of the United States and the people of the United States said, "I believe our nation is greater than what we are now."
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I believe that if we are inspired, if we can achieve a degree of unity, if we can set our goals high enough and work toward recognized goals with industry and labor and agriculture along with government at all levels, then we can achieve great things.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: There are no magic answers to do it.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But I believe together we can make great progress.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We can correct our difficult mistakes and answer those very tough questions.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've been drifting too long.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've been dormant too long.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've been discouraged too long.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And we have not set an example for our own people.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But I believe that we can now establish in the White House a good relationship with Congress, a good relationship with our people, set very high goals for our country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And with inspiration and hard work we can achieve great things.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And let the world know - that's very important.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But more importantly, let the people in our own country realize that we still live in the greatest nation on earth.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Well, thank you very much, Jim, for this opportunity.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I want to thank Governor Romney and the University of Denver for your hospitality.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There are a lot of points I want to make tonight, but the most important one is that 20 years ago I became the luckiest man on Earth because Michelle Obama agreed to marry me.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so I just want to wish, Sweetie, you happy anniversary and let you know that a year from now we will not be celebrating it in front of 40 million people.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, four years ago we went through the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Millions of jobs were lost, the auto industry was on the brink of collapse.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The financial system had frozen up.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And because of the resilience and the determination of the American people, we've begun to fight our way back.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Over the last 30 months, we've seen 5 million jobs in the private sector created.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The auto industry has come roaring back.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And housing has begun to rise.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But we all know that we've still got a lot of work to do.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so the question here tonight is not where we've been, but where we're going.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Governor Romney has a perspective that says if we cut taxes, skewed towards the wealthy, and roll back regulations, that we'll be better off.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I think we've got to invest in education and training.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I think it's important for us to develop new sources of energy here in America, that we change our tax code to make sure that we're helping small businesses and companies that are investing here in the United States, that we take some of the money that we're saving as we wind down two wars to rebuild America and that we reduce our deficit in a balanced way that allows us to make these critical investments.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, it ultimately is going to be up to the voters -- to you -- which path we should take.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Are we going to double on top-down economic policies that helped to get us into this mess or do we embrace a new economic patriotism that says America does best when the middle class does best?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's an honor to be here with you, and I appreciate the chance to be with the president.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm pleased to be at the University of Denver, appreciate their welcome, and also the Presidential Commission on these debates.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And congratulations to you, Mr. President, on your anniversary.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm sure this was the most romantic place you could imagine, here -- here with me.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is obviously a very tender topic.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I've had the occasion over the last couple of years of meeting people across the country.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Ann yesterday was at a rally in Denver and a woman came up to her with a baby in her arms and said, "Ann, my husband has had four jobs in three years, part-time jobs.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: He's lost his most recent job and we've now just lost our home.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And the answer is, yes, we can help, but it's going to take a different path.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Not the one we've been on, not the one the president describes as a top-down, cut taxes for the rich.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's not what I'm going to do.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: My plan has five basic parts.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: One, get us energy independent, North American energy independent.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That creates about 4 million jobs.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number two, open up more trade, particularly in Latin America.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number three, make sure our people have the skills they need to succeed and the best schools in the world.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're far away from that now.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number four, get to us a balanced budget.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number five, champion small business.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's small business that creates the jobs in America, and over the last four years, small business people have decided that America may not be the place to open a new business because new business startups are down to a 30-year low.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Now, I'm concerned that the path that we're on has just been unsuccessful.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The president has a view very similar to the view he had when he ran four years, that a bigger government, spending more, taxing more, regulating more -- if you will, trickle-down government -- would work.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's not the right answer for America.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'll restore the vitality that gets America working again.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, let me talk specifically about what I think we need to do.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: First, we've got to improve our education system and we've made enormous progress drawing on ideas both from Democrats and Republicans that are already starting to show gains in some of the toughest to deal with schools.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got a program called Race to the Top that has prompted reforms in 46 states around the country, raising standards, improving how we train teachers.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So now I want to hire another 100,000 new math and science teachers, and create 2 million more slots in our community colleges so that people can get trained for the jobs that are out there right now.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I want to make sure that we keep tuition low for our young people.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: When it comes to our tax code, Governor Romney and I both agree that our corporate tax rate is too high, so I want to lower it, particularly for manufacturing, taking it down to 25 percent.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I also want to close those loopholes that are giving incentives for companies that are shipping jobs overseas.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I want to provide tax breaks for companies that are investing here in the United States.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: On energy, Governor Romney and I, we both agree that we've got to boost American energy production, and oil and natural gas production are higher than they've been in years.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I also believe that we've got to look at the energy sources of the future, like wind and solar and biofuels, and make those investments.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So all of this is possible.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, in order for us to do it, we do have to close our deficit, and one of the things I'm sure we'll be discussing tonight is, how do we deal with our tax code?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And how do we make sure that we are reducing spending in a responsible way, but also, how do we have enough revenue to make those investments?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And this is where there's a difference, because Governor Romney's central economic plan calls for a $5 trillion tax cut -- on top of the extension of the Bush tax cuts -- that's another trillion dollars -- and $2 trillion in additional military spending that the military hasn't asked for.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: How we pay for that, reduce the deficit, and make the investments that we need to make, without dumping those costs onto middle-class Americans, I think is one of the central questions of this campaign.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I'd like to clear up the record and go through it piece by piece.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: First of all, I don't have a $5 trillion tax cut.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I don't have a tax cut of a scale that you're talking about.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: My view is that we ought to provide tax relief to people in the middle class.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But I'm not going to reduce the share of taxes paid by high-income people.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: High-income people are doing just fine in this economy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They'll do fine whether you're president or I am.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The people who are having the hard time right now are middle- income Americans.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Under the president's policies, middle-income Americans have been buried.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Middle- income Americans have seen their income come down by $4,300.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is a -- this is a tax in and of itself.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'll call it the economy tax.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: At the same time, gasoline prices have doubled under the president.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Middle-income families are being crushed.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And so the question is how to get them going again.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's energy and trade, the right kind of training programs, balancing our budget and helping small business.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Those are the -- the cornerstones of my plan.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But the president mentioned a couple of other ideas I'll just note.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I agree: Education is key, particularly the future of our economy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But our training programs right now, we've got 47 of them, housed in the federal government, reporting to eight different agencies.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We've got to get those dollars back to the states and go to the workers so they can create their own pathways to get in the training they need for jobs that will really help them.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The second area, taxation, we agree, we ought to bring the tax rates down.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I do, both for corporations and for individuals.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But in order for us not to lose revenue, have the government run out of money, I also lower deductions and credits and exemptions, so that we keep taking in the same money when you also account for growth.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Energy is critical, and the president pointed out correctly that production of oil and gas in the U.S. is up.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But not due to his policies.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: In spite of his policies.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Mr. President, all of the increase in natural gas and oil has happened on private land, not on government land.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: On government land, your administration has cut the number of permits and licenses in half.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: If I'm president, I'll double them, and also get the -- the oil from offshore and Alaska.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I'll bring that pipeline in from Canada.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And, by the way, I like coal.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm going to make sure we can continue to burn clean coal.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: People in the coal industry feel like it's getting crushed by your policies.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I want to get America and North America energy independent so we can create those jobs.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And finally, with regards to that tax cut, look, I'm not looking to cut massive taxes and to reduce the -- the revenues going to the government.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: My -- my number-one principal is, there will be no tax cut that adds to the deficit.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I want to underline that: no tax cut that adds to the deficit.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But I do want to reduce the burden being paid by middle-income Americans.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I -- and to do that, that also means I cannot reduce the burden paid by high-income Americans.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So any -- any language to the contrary is simply not accurate.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, I think -- let's talk about taxes, because I think it's instructive.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, four years ago, when I stood on this stage, I said that I would cut taxes for middle-class families.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's exactly what I did.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We cut taxes for middle-class families by about $3,600.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the reason is, because I believe that we do best when the middle class is doing well.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And by giving them those tax cuts, they had a little more money in their pocket, and so maybe they can buy a new car.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They are certainly in a better position to weather the extraordinary recession that we went through.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They can buy a computer for their kid who's going off to college, which means they're spending more money, businesses have more customers, businesses make more profits, and then hire more workers.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, Governor Romney's proposal that he has been promoting for 18 months calls for a $5 trillion tax cut, on top of $2 trillion of additional spending for our military.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And he is saying that he is going to pay for it by closing loopholes and deductions.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The problem is that he's been asked over 100 times how you would close those deductions and loopholes, and he hasn't been able to identify them.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I'm going to make an important point here, Jim.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: When you add up all the loopholes and deductions that upper-income individuals can -- are currently taking advantage of, you take those all away, you don't come close to paying for $5 trillion in tax cuts and $2 trillion in additional military spending.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's why independent studies looking at this said the only way to meet Governor Romney's pledge of not reducing the deficit or -- or -- or not adding to the deficit is by burdening middle-class families.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The average middle-class family with children would pay about $2,000 more.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, that's not my analysis.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's the analysis of economists who have looked at this.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And -- and that kind of top -- top-down economics, where folks at the top are doing well, so the average person making $3 million is getting a $250,000 tax break, while middle-class families are burdened further, that's not what I believe is a recipe for economic growth.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, but -- but virtually -- virtually everything he just said about my tax plan is inaccurate.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So if the tax plan he described were a tax plan I was asked to support, I'd say absolutely not.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm not looking for a $5 trillion tax cut.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: What I've said is I won't put in place a tax cut that adds to the deficit.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So there's no economist that can say Mitt Romney's tax plan adds $5 trillion if I say I will not add to the deficit with my tax plan.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number two, I will not reduce the share paid by high-income individuals.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I know that you and your running mate keep saying that and I know it's a popular thing to say with a lot of people, but it's just not the case.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Look, I've got five boys.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm used to people saying something that's not always true, but just keep on repeating it and ultimately hoping I'll believe it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But that -- that is not the case.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I will not reduce the taxes paid by high-income Americans.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And number three, I will not under any circumstances raise taxes on middle-income families.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I will lower taxes on middle-income families.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Now, you cite a study.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: There are six other studies that looked at the study you describe and say it's completely wrong.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I saw a study that came out today that said you're going to raise taxes by $3,000 to $4,000 on middle-income families.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: There are all these studies out there.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But let's get at the bottom line.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That is, I want to bring down rates.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I want to bring the rates down, at the same time lower deductions and exemptions and credits and so forth, so we keep getting the revenue we need.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And you'd think, well, then why lower the rates?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And the reason is because small business pays that individual rate; 54 percent of America's workers work in businesses that are taxed not at the corporate tax rate, but at the individual tax rate.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And if we lower that rate, they will be able to hire more people.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: For me, this is about jobs.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is about getting jobs for the American people.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, for 18 months he's been running on this tax plan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And now, five weeks before the election, he's saying that his big, bold idea is, "Never mind."
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the fact is that if you are lowering the rates the way you described, Governor, then it is not possible to come up with enough deductions and loopholes that only affect high-income individuals to avoid either raising the deficit or burdening the middle class.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, Governor Romney and I do share a deep interest in encouraging small-business growth.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So at the same time that my tax plan has already lowered taxes for 98 percent of families, I also lowered taxes for small businesses 18 times.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And what I want to do is continue the tax rates -- the tax cuts that we put into place for small businesses and families.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I have said that for incomes over $250,000 a year, that we should go back to the rates that we had when Bill Clinton was president, when we created 23 million new jobs, went from deficit to surplus, and created a whole lot of millionaires to boot.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the reason this is important is because by doing that, we cannot only reduce the deficit, we cannot only encourage job growth through small businesses, but we're also able to make the investments that are necessary in education or in energy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we do have a difference, though, when it comes to definitions of small business.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Under -- under my plan, 97 percent of small businesses would not see their income taxes go up.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Governor Romney says, well, those top 3 percent, they're the job creators, they'd be burdened.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But under Governor Romney's definition, there are a whole bunch of millionaires and billionaires who are small businesses.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Donald Trump is a small business.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, I know Donald Trump doesn't like to think of himself as small anything, but -- but that's how you define small businesses if you're getting business income.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that kind of approach, I believe, will not grow our economy, because the only way to pay for it without either burdening the middle class or blowing up our deficit is to make drastic cuts in things like education, making sure that we are continuing to invest in basic science and research, all the things that are helping America grow.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I think that would be a mistake.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Jim, let me just come back on that -- on that point, which is these...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: ... the small businesses we're talking about...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, President, you're -- Mr. President, you're absolutely right, which is that, with regards to 97 percent of the businesses are not -- not taxed at the 35 percent tax rate, they're taxed at a lower rate.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But those businesses that are in the last 3 percent of businesses happen to employ half -- half of all the people who work in small business.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Those are the businesses that employ one-quarter of all the workers in America.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And your plan is to take their tax rate from 35 percent to 40 percent.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Now, and -- and I've talked to a guy who has a very small business.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: He's in the electronics business in -- in St. Louis.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: He said he and his son calculated how much they pay in taxes, federal income tax, federal payroll tax, state income tax, state sales tax, state property tax, gasoline tax.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It added up to well over 50 percent of what they earned.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And your plan is to take the tax rate on successful small businesses from 35 percent to 40 percent.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The National Federation of Independent Businesses has said that will cost 700,000 jobs.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I don't want to cost jobs.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And so what I do is I bring down the tax rates, lower deductions and exemptions, the same idea behind Bowles-Simpson, by the way, get the rates down, lower deductions and exemptions, to create more jobs, because there's nothing better for getting us to a balanced budget than having more people working, earning more money, paying more taxes.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's by far the most effective and efficient way to get this budget balanced.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Jim, I -- you may want to move onto another topic, but I -- I would just say this to the American people.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If you believe that we can cut taxes by $5 trillion and add $2 trillion in additional spending that the military is not asking for, $7 trillion -- just to give you a sense, over 10 years, that's more than our entire defense budget -- and you think that by closing loopholes and deductions for the well-to-do, somehow you will not end up picking up the tab, then Governor Romney's plan may work for you.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I think math, common sense, and our history shows us that's not a recipe for job growth.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The approach that Governor Romney's talking about is the same sales pitch that was made in 2001 and 2003, and we ended up with the slowest job growth in 50 years, we ended up moving from surplus to deficits, and it all culminated in the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Bill Clinton tried the approach that I'm talking about.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We created 23 million new jobs.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We went from deficit to surplus.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And businesses did very well.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So, in some ways, we've got some data on which approach is more likely to create jobs and opportunity for Americans and I believe that the economy works best when middle-class families are getting tax breaks so that they've got some money in their pockets, and those of us who have done extraordinarily well because of this magnificent country that we live in, that we can afford to do a little bit more to make sure we're not blowing up the deficit.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Jim, the president began this segment, so I think I get the last word.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, but he gets the first word of that segment.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I get the last word (inaudible) I hope.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Let me just make this comment.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I think first of all, let me -- let me repeat -- let me repeat what I said.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm not in favor of a $5 trillion tax cut.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: My plan is not to put in place any tax cut that will add to the deficit.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So you may keep referring to it as a $5 trillion tax cut, but that's not my plan.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number two, let's look at history.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: My plan is not like anything that's been tried before.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: My plan is to bring down rates, but also bring down deductions and exemptions and credits at the same time so the revenue stays in, but that we bring down rates to get more people working.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: My priority is putting people back to work in America.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They're suffering in this country.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And we talk about evidence.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Look at the evidence of the last four years.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We've got 23 million people out of work or stopped looking for work in this country.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's just -- it's -- we've got -- when the president took office, 32 million people on food stamps; 47 million on food stamps today; economic growth this year slower than last year, and last year slower than the year before.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Going forward with the status quo is not going to cut it for the American people who are struggling today.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm glad you raised that, and it's a -- it's a critical issue.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I think it's not just an economic issue, I think it's a moral issue.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I think it's, frankly, not moral for my generation to keep spending massively more than we take in, knowing those burdens are going to be passed on to the next generation and they're going to be paying the interest and the principal all their lives.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And the amount of debt we're adding, at a trillion a year, is simply not moral.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So how do we deal with it?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, mathematically, there are three ways that you can cut a deficit.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: One, of course, is to raise taxes.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number two is to cut spending.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And number is to grow the economy, because if more people work in a growing economy, they're paying taxes, and you can get the job done that way.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The presidents would -- president would prefer raising taxes.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The problem with raising taxes is that it slows down the rate of growth.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And you could never quite get the job done.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I want to lower spending and encourage economic growth at the same time.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, first of all, I will eliminate all programs by this test, if they don't pass it: Is the program so critical it's worth borrowing money from China to pay for it?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And if not, I'll get rid of it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I use that term with all respect, by the way.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So I'll get rid of that.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm sorry, Jim, I'm going to stop the subsidy to PBS.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm going to stop other things.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I like PBS, I love Big Bird.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But I'm not going to -- I'm not going to keep on spending money on things to borrow money from China to pay for.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number two, I'll take programs that are currently good programs but I think could be run more efficiently at the state level and send them to the state.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number three, I'll make government more efficient and to cut back the number of employees, combine some agencies and departments.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: My cutbacks will be done through attrition, by the way.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is the approach we have to take to get America to a balanced budget.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The president said he'd cut the deficit in half.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Trillion-dollar deficits for the last four years.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The president's put it in place as much public debt -- almost as much debt held by the public as al prior presidents combined.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: When I walked into the Oval Office, I had more than a trillion-dollar deficit greeting me.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we know where it came from: two wars that were paid for on a credit card; two tax cuts that were not paid for; and a whole bunch of programs that were not paid for; and then a massive economic crisis.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And despite that, what we've said is, yes, we had to take some initial emergency measures to make sure we didn't slip into a Great Depression, but what we've also said is, let's make sure that we are cutting out those things that are not helping us grow.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So 77 government programs, everything from aircrafts that the Air Force had ordered but weren't working very well, 18 government -- 18 government programs for education that were well-intentioned, not weren't helping kids learn, we went after medical fraud in Medicare and Medicaid very aggressively, more aggressively than ever before, and have saved tens of billions of dollars, $50 billion of waste taken out of the system.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I worked with Democrats and Republicans to cut a trillion dollars out of our discretionary domestic budget.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's the largest cut in the discretionary domestic budget since Dwight Eisenhower.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, we all know that we've got to do more.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so I've put forward a specific $4 trillion deficit reduction plan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You can look at all the numbers, what cuts we make and what revenue we raise.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the way we do it is $2.50 for every cut, we ask for $1 of additional revenue, paid for, as I indicated earlier, by asking those of us who have done very well in this country to contribute a little bit more to reduce the deficit.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Governor Romney earlier mentioned the Bowles-Simpson commission.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, that's how the commission -- bipartisan commission that talked about how we should move forward suggested we have to do it, in a balanced way with some revenue and some spending cuts.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And this is a major difference that Governor Romney and I have.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Let -- let me just finish their point, because you're looking for contrast.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, when Governor Romney stood on a stage with other Republican candidates for the nomination and he was asked, would you take $10 of spending cuts for just $1 of revenue?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, if you take such an unbalanced approach, then that means you are going to be gutting our investments in schools and education.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It means that Governor Romney...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: ... talked about Medicaid and how we could send it back to the states, but effectively this means a 30 percent cut in the primary program we help for seniors who are in nursing homes, for kids who are with disabilities.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And -- and that is not a right strategy for us to move forward.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Simpson-Bowles, the president should have grabbed that.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I have my own plan.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's not the same as Simpson- Bowles.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But in my view, the president should have grabbed it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: If you wanted to make some adjustments to it, take it, go to Congress, fight for it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's what we've done, made some adjustments to it, and we're putting it forward before Congress right now, a $4 trillion plan...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But you've been -- but you've been president four years...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You've been president four years.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You said you'd cut the deficit in half.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's now four years later.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We still have trillion-dollar deficits.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The CBO says we'll have a trillion-dollar deficit each of the next four years.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: If you're re-elected, we'll get to a trillion-dollar debt.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I mean, you have said before you'd cut the deficit in half.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And this -- I love this idea of $4 trillion in cuts.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You found $4 trillion of ways to reduce or to get closer to a balanced budget, except we still show trillion-dollar deficits every year.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That doesn't get the job done.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Let me come back and say, why is it that I don't want to raise taxes?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Why don't I want to raise taxes on people?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And actually, you said it back in 2010.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You said, "Look, I'm going to extend the tax policies that we have now; I'm not going to raise taxes on anyone, because when the economy is growing slow like this, when we're in recession, you shouldn't raise taxes on anyone."
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, the economy is still growing slow.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: As a matter of fact, it's growing much more slowly now than when you made that statement.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And so if you believe the same thing, you just don't want to raise taxes on people.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And the reality is it's not just wealthy people -- you mentioned Donald Trump.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's not just Donald Trump you're taxing.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's all those businesses that employ one-quarter of the workers in America; these small businesses that are taxed as individuals.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You raise taxes and you kill jobs.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's why the National Federation of Independent Businesses said your plan will kill 700,000 jobs.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I don't want to kill jobs in this environment.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'll make one more point.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, we've had this discussion before.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There has to be revenue in addition to cuts.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, Governor Romney has ruled out revenue.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Look, the revenue I get is by more people working, getting higher pay, paying more taxes.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's how we get growth and how we balance the budget.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But the idea of taxing people more, putting more people out of work, you'll never get there.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You'll never balance the budget by raising taxes.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Spain -- Spain spends 42 percent of their total economy on government.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're now spending 42 percent of our economy on government.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I don't want to go down the path to Spain.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I want to go down the path of growth that puts Americans to work with more money coming in because they're working.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: If -- if we're serious, we've got to take a balanced, responsible approach.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And by the way, this is not just when it comes to individual taxes.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Let's talk about corporate taxes.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, I've identified areas where we can, right away, make a change that I believe would actually help the economy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Basically, they get deductions that those small businesses that Governor Romney refers to, they don't get.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, does anybody think that ExxonMobil needs some extra money, when they're making money every time you go to the pump?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Why wouldn't we want to eliminate that?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Why wouldn't we eliminate tax breaks for corporate jets?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: My attitude is, if you got a corporate jet, you can probably afford to pay full freight, not get a special break for it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: When it comes to corporate taxes, Governor Romney has said he wants to, in a revenue neutral way, close loopholes, deductions -- he hasn't identified which ones they are -- but that thereby bring down the corporate rate.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, I want to do the same thing, but I've actually identified how we can do that.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And part of the way to do it is to not give tax breaks to companies that are shipping jobs overseas.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Right now, you can actually take a deduction for moving a plant overseas.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I think most Americans would say that doesn't make sense.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And all that raises revenue.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so if we take a balanced approach, what that then allows us to do is also to help young people, the way we already have during my administration, make sure that they can afford to go to college.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It means that the teacher that I met in Las Vegas, a wonderful young lady, who describes to me -- she's got 42 kids in her class.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The first two weeks she's got them, some of them sitting on the floor until finally they get reassigned.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They're using text books that are 10 years old.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That is not a recipe for growth.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's not how America was built.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so budgets reflect choices.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Ultimately, we're going to have to make some decisions.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And if we're asking for no revenue, then that means that we've got to get rid of a whole bunch of stuff.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the magnitude of the tax cuts that you're talking about, Governor, would end up resulting in severe hardship for people, but more importantly, would not help us grow.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: As I indicated before, when you talk about shifting Medicaid to states, we're talking about potentially a 30 -- a 30 percent cut in Medicaid over time.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, you know, that may not seem like a big deal when it just is, you know, numbers on a sheet of paper, but if we're talking about a family who's got an autistic kid and is depending on that Medicaid, that's a big problem.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There's no doubt about it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But they're not creative enough to make up for 30 percent of revenue on something like Medicaid.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What ends up happening is some people end up not getting help.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Jim, let's -- we've gone on a lot of topics there, and so it's going to take a minute to go from Medicaid to schools...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: ... to oil, to tax breaks, then companies going overseas.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So let's go through them one by one.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: First of all, the Department of Energy has said the tax break for oil companies is $2.8 billion a year.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And it's actually an accounting treatment, as you know, that's been in place for a hundred years.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's time to end it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And in one year, you provided $90 billion in breaks to the green energy world.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Now, I like green energy as well, but that's about 50 years' worth of what oil and gas receives.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And you say Exxon and Mobil.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Actually, this $2.8 billion goes largely to small companies, to drilling operators and so forth.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But, you know, if we get that tax rate from 35 percent down to 25 percent, why that $2.8 billion is on the table.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Of course it's on the table.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's probably not going to survive you get that rate down to 25 percent.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But don't forget, you put $90 billion, like 50 years' worth of breaks, into -- into solar and wind, to Solyndra and Fisker and Tester and Ener1.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I mean, I had a friend who said you don't just pick the winners and losers, you pick the losers, all right?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So this -- this is not -- this is not the kind of policy you want to have if you want to get America energy secure.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The second topic, which is you said you get a deduction for taking a plant overseas.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Look, I've been in business for 25 years.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I have no idea what you're talking about.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I maybe need to get a new accountant.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But -- but the idea that you get a break for shipping jobs overseas is simply not the case.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: What we do have right now is a setting where I'd like to bring money from overseas back to this country.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And, finally, Medicaid to states?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm not quite sure where that came in, except this, which is, I would like to take the Medicaid dollars that go to states and say to a state, you're going to get what you got last year, plus inflation, plus 1 percent, and then you're going to manage your care for your poor in the way you think best.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I remember, as a governor, when this idea was floated by Tommy Thompson, the governors -- Republican and Democrats -- said, please let us do that.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We can care for our own poor in so much better and more effective a way than having the federal government tell us how to care for our poor.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So -- so let's state -- one of the magnificent things about this country is the whole idea that states are the laboratories of democracy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Don't have the federal government tell everybody what kind of training programs they have to have and what kind of Medicaid they have to have.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And, by the way, if a state gets in trouble, well, we can step in and see if we can find a way to help them.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But -- but the right -- the right approach is one which relies on the brilliance of our people and states, not the federal government.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You know, I suspect that, on Social Security, we've got a somewhat similar position.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Social Security is structurally sound.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's going to have to be tweaked the way it was by Ronald Reagan and Speaker -- Democratic Speaker Tip O'Neill.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But it is -- the basic structure is sound.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But -- but I want to talk about the values behind Social Security and Medicare, and then talk about Medicare, because that's the big driver of our deficits right now.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, my grandmother -- some of you know -- helped to raise me.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: My grandfather died a while back.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And she was fiercely independent.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: She worked her way up, only had a high school education, started as a secretary, ended up being the vice president of a local bank.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And she ended up living alone by choice.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the reason she could be independent was because of Social Security and Medicare.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: She had worked all her life, put in this money, and understood that there was a basic guarantee, a floor under which she could not go.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's the perspective I bring when I think about what's called entitlements.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, the name itself implies some sense of dependency on the part of these folks.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: These are folks who've worked hard, like my grandmother, and there are millions of people out there who are counting on this.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So my approach is to say, how do we strengthen the system over the long term?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And in Medicare, what we did was we said, we are going to have to bring down the costs if we're going to deal with our long-term deficits, but to do that, let's look where some of the money's going.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: $716 billion we were able to save from the Medicare program by no longer overpaying insurance companies by making sure that we weren't overpaying providers.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So the way for us to deal with Medicare in particular is to lower health care costs.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: When it comes to Social Security, as I said, you don't need a major structural change in order to make sure that Social Security is there for the future.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, Jim, our seniors depend on these programs, and I know anytime we talk about entitlements, people become concerned that something's going to happen that's going to change their life for the worse.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And the answer is neither the president nor I are proposing any changes for any current retirees or near retirees, either to Social Security or Medicare.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So if you're 60 or around 60 or older, you don't need to listen any further.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Oh, I just thought about one.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And that is, in fact, I was wrong when I said the president isn't proposing any changes for current retirees.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: In fact he is on Medicare.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: On Social Security he's not.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But on Medicare, for current retirees, he's cutting $716 billion from the program.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Now, he says by not overpaying hospitals and providers.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Actually just going to them and saying, "We're going to reduce the rates you get paid across the board, everybody's going to get a lower rate."
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's not just going after places where there's abuse.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's saying we're cutting the rates.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Some 15 percent of hospitals and nursing homes say they won't take anymore Medicare patients under that scenario.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We also have 50 percent of doctors who say they won't take more Medicare patients.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This -- we have 4 million people on Medicare Advantage that will lose Medicare Advantage because of those $716 billion in cuts.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I can't understand how you can cut Medicare $716 billion for current recipients of Medicare.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Now, you point out, well, we're putting some back.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're going to give a better prescription program.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's $1 -- that's $1 for every $15 you've cut.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They're smart enough to know that's not a good trade.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I want to take that $716 billion you've cut and put it back into Medicare.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: By the way, we can include a prescription program if we need to improve it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But the idea of cutting $716 billion from Medicare to be able to balance the additional cost of Obamacare is, in my opinion, a mistake.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And with regards to young people coming along, I've got proposals to make sure Medicare and Social Security are there for them without any question.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: First of all, I think it's important for Governor Romney to present this plan that he says will only affect folks in the future.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the essence of the plan is that you would turn Medicare into a voucher program.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's called premium support, but it's understood to be a voucher program.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And let me explain why.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: ... people, right, not for current retirees.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: For -- so if you're -- if you're 54 or 55, you might want to listen 'cause this -- this will affect you.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The idea, which was originally presented by Congressman Ryan, your running mate, is that we would give a voucher to seniors and they could go out in the private marketplace and buy their own health insurance.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The problem is that because the voucher wouldn't necessarily keep up with health care inflation, it was estimated that this would cost the average senior about $6,000 a year.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, in fairness, what Governor Romney has now said is he'll maintain traditional Medicare alongside it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But there's still a problem, because what happens is, those insurance companies are pretty clever at figuring out who are the younger and healthier seniors.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They recruit them, leaving the older, sicker seniors in Medicare.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And every health care economist that looks at it says, over time, what'll happen is the traditional Medicare system will collapse.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And then what you've got is folks like my grandmother at the mercy of the private insurance system precisely at the time when they are most in need of decent health care.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So, I don't think vouchers are the right way to go.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And this is not my own -- only my opinion.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: AARP thinks that the -- the savings that we obtained from Medicare bolster the system, lengthen the Medicare trust fund by eight years.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Benefits were not affected at all.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And ironically, if you repeal Obamacare, and I have become fond of this term, "Obamacare," if you repeal it, what happens is those seniors right away are going to be paying $600 more in prescription care.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They're now going to have to be paying copays for basic checkups that can keep them healthier.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the primary beneficiary of that repeal are insurance companies that are estimated to gain billions of dollars back when they aren't making seniors any healthier.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I don't think that's the right approach when it comes to making sure that Medicare is stronger over the long term.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What I support is no change for current retirees and near-retirees to Medicare.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And the president supports taking $716 billion out of that program.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So that's -- that's number one.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number two is for people coming along that are young, what I do to make sure that we can keep Medicare in place for them is to allow them either to choose the current Medicare program or a private plan.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They get to choose -- and they'll have at least two plans that will be entirely at no cost to them.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So they don't have to pay additional money, no additional $6,000.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's not going to happen.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They'll have at least two plans.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And by the way, if the government can be as efficient as the private sector and offer premiums that are as low as the private sector, people will be happy to get traditional Medicare or they'll be able to get a private plan.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I know my own view is I'd rather have a private plan.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'd just assume not have the government telling me what kind of health care I get.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'd rather be able to have an insurance company.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: If I don't like them, I can get rid of them and find a different insurance company.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But people make their own choice.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The other thing we have to do to save Medicare?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have to have the benefits high for those that are low income, but for higher income people, we're going to have to lower some of the benefits.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have to make sure this program is there for the long term.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's the plan that I've put forward.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And, by the way the idea came not even from Paul Ryan or -- or Senator Wyden, who's the co-author of the bill with -- with Paul Ryan in the Senate, but also it came from Bill -- Bill Clinton's chief of staff.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is an idea that's been around a long time, which is saying, hey, let's see if we can't get competition into the Medicare world so that people can get the choice of different plans at lower cost, better quality.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Jim, if I -- if I can just respond very quickly, first of all, every study has shown that Medicare has lower administrative costs than private insurance does, which is why seniors are generally pretty happy with it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And private insurers have to make a profit.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so you've got higher administrative costs, plus profit on top of that.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And if you are going to save any money through what Governor Romney's proposing, what has to happen is, is that the money has to come from somewhere.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And when you move to a voucher system, you are putting seniors at the mercy of those insurance companies.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And over time, if traditional Medicare has decayed or fallen apart, then they're stuck.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And this is the reason why AARP has said that your plan would weaken Medicare substantially.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's why they were supportive of the approach that we took.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: One last point I want to make.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We do have to lower the cost of health care, not just in Medicare and Medicaid...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: ... but -- but -- but overall.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's -- that's a big topic.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Can we -- can we stay on Medicare?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Is that a -- is that a separate topic?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Let's get back to Medicare.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Let's get back to Medicare.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The president said that the government can provide the service at lower cost and without a profit.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: If that's the case, then it will always be the best product that people can purchase.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But my experience -- my experience the private sector typically is able to provide a better product at a lower cost.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You can't have a free market work if you don't have regulation.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: As a businessperson, I had to have -- I need to know the regulations.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You couldn't have people opening up banks in their -- in their garage and making loans.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I mean, you have to have regulations so that you can have an economy work.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Every free economy has good regulation.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: At the same time, regulation can become excessive.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: No, it can become out of date.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And what's happened with some of the legislation that's been passed during the president's term, you've seen regulation become excessive, and it's hurt -- it's hurt the economy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Let me give you an example.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And it includes within it a number of provisions that I think has some unintended consequences that are harmful to the economy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: One is it designates a number of banks as too big to fail, and they're effectively guaranteed by the federal government.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is the biggest kiss that's been given to -- to New York banks I've ever seen.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is an enormous boon for them.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: There've been 122 community and small banks have closed since Dodd- Frank.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, I would repeal and replace it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're not going to get rid of all regulation.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You have to have regulation.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And there are some parts of Dodd-Frank that make all the sense in the world.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You need transparency, you need to have leverage limits for...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But let's -- let's mention -- let me mention the other one.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I think this is a great example.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The reason we have been in such a enormous economic crisis was prompted by reckless behavior across the board.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, it wasn't just on Wall Street.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You had loan officers were -- that were giving loans and mortgages that really shouldn't have been given, because the folks didn't qualify.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You had people who were borrowing money to buy a house that they couldn't afford.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You had credit agencies that were stamping these as A1 great investments when they weren't.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But you also had banks making money hand over fist, churning out products that the bankers themselves didn't even understand, in order to make big profits, but knowing that it made the entire system vulnerable.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So what did we do?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We stepped in and had the toughest reforms on Wall Street since the 1930s.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We said you've got -- banks, you've got to raise your capital requirements.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You can't engage in some of this risky behavior that is putting Main Street at risk.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've going to make sure that you've got to have a living will so -- so we can know how you're going to wind things down if you make a bad bet so we don't have other taxpayer bailouts.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In the meantime, by the way, we also made sure that all the help that we provided those banks was paid back every single dime, with interest.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, Governor Romney has said he wants to repeal Dodd-Frank.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, you know, I appreciate and it appears we've got some agreement that a marketplace to work has to have some regulation.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But in the past, Governor Romney has said he just want to repeal Dodd- Frank, roll it back.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so the question is: Does anybody out there think that the big problem we had is that there was too much oversight and regulation of Wall Street?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Because if you do, then Governor Romney is your candidate.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But that's not what I believe.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Sorry, but that's just not -- that's just not the facts.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Look, we have to have regulation on Wall Street.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's why I'd have regulation.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But I wouldn't designate five banks as too big to fail and give them a blank check.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's one of the unintended consequences of Dodd-Frank.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It wasn't thought through properly.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We need to get rid of that provision because it's killing regional and small banks.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Let me mention another regulation in Dodd-Frank.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You say we were giving mortgages to people who weren't qualified.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's one of the reasons for the great financial calamity we had.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And so Dodd-Frank correctly says we need to have qualified mortgages, and if you give a mortgage that's not qualified, there are big penalties, except they didn't ever go on and define what a qualified mortgage was.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We don't know what a qualified mortgage is yet.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So banks are reluctant to make loans, mortgages.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Try and get a mortgage these days.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's hurt the housing market because Dodd-Frank didn't anticipate putting in place the kinds of regulations you have to have.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's not that Dodd-Frank always was wrong with too much regulation.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Sometimes they didn't come out with a clear regulation.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I will make sure we don't hurt the functioning of our -- of our marketplace and our business, because I want to bring back housing and get good jobs.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, in part, it comes, again, from my experience.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: A woman came to me and she said, look, I can't afford insurance for myself or my son.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I met a couple in Appleton, Wisconsin, and they said, we're thinking of dropping our insurance, we can't afford it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And the number of small businesses I've gone to that are saying they're dropping insurance because they can't afford it, the cost of health care is just prohibitive.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And -- and we've got to deal with cost.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And, unfortunately, when -- when -- when you look at Obamacare, the Congressional Budget Office has said it will cost $2,500 a year more than traditional insurance.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So it's adding to cost.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And as a matter of fact, when the president ran for office, he said that, by this year, he would have brought down the cost of insurance for each family by $2,500 a family.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Instead, it's gone up by that amount.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So that's one reason I don't want it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Second reason, it cuts $716 billion from Medicare to pay for it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I want to put that money back in Medicare for our seniors.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number three, it puts in place an unelected board that's going to tell people ultimately what kind of treatments they can have.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I don't like that idea.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Fourth, there was a survey done of small businesses across the country, said, what's been the effect of Obamacare on your hiring plans?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And three-quarters of them said it makes us less likely to hire people.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I just don't know how the president could have come into office, facing 23 million people out of work, rising unemployment, an economic crisis at the -- at the kitchen table, and spend his energy and passion for two years fighting for Obamacare instead of fighting for jobs for the American people.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And the best course for health care is to do what we did in my state: craft a plan at the state level that fits the needs of the state.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And then let's focus on getting the costs down for people, rather than raising it with the $2,500 additional premium.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, four years ago, when I was running for office, I was traveling around and having those same conversations that Governor Romney talks about.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And it wasn't just that small businesses were seeing costs skyrocket and they couldn't get affordable coverage even if they wanted to provide it to their employees.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It wasn't just that this was the biggest driver of our federal deficit, our overall health care costs, but it was families who were worried about going bankrupt if they got sick, millions of families, all across the country.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If they had a pre-existing condition, they might not be able to get coverage at all.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If they did have coverage, insurance companies might impose an arbitrary limit.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so as a consequence, they're paying their premiums, somebody gets really sick, lo and behold, they don't have enough money to pay the bills, because the insurance companies say that they've hit the limit.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So we did work on this, alongside working on jobs, because this is part of making sure that middle-class families are secure in this country.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And let me tell you exactly what Obamacare did.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number one, if you've got health insurance, it doesn't mean a government takeover.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You keep your own insurance.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You keep your own doctor.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But it does say insurance companies can't jerk you around.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They can't impose arbitrary lifetime limits.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They have to let you keep your kid on their insurance -- your insurance plan until you're 26 years old.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And it also says that you're going to have to get rebates if insurance companies are spending more on administrative costs and profits than they are on actual care.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number two, if you don't have health insurance, we're essentially setting up a group plan that allows you to benefit from group rates that are typically 18 percent lower than if you're out there trying to get insurance on the individual market.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, the last point I'd make before...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: No, I think -- I had five seconds before you interrupted me, was ...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: ... the irony is that we've seen this model work really well in Massachusetts, because Governor Romney did a good thing, working with Democrats in the state to set up what is essentially the identical model and as a consequence people are covered there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And as a consequence, we now have a system in which we have the opportunity to start bringing down costs, as opposed to just leaving millions of people out in the cold.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, I did with my first statement.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: First of all, I like the way we did it in Massachusetts.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I like the fact that in my state, we had Republicans and Democrats come together and work together.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: What you did instead was to push through a plan without a single Republican vote.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: As a matter of fact, when Massachusetts did something quite extraordinary -- elected a Republican senator to stop Obamacare, you pushed it through anyway.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So entirely on a partisan basis, instead of bringing America together and having a discussion on this important topic, you pushed through something that you and Nancy Pelosi and Harry Reid thought was the best answer and drove it through.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: What we did in a legislature 87 percent Democrat, we worked together; 200 legislators in my legislature, only two voted against the plan by the time we were finished.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You've raised them by $1 trillion under Obamacare.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Of course, we don't have Medicare, but we didn't cut Medicare by $716 billion.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We didn't put in place a board that can tell people ultimately what treatments they're going to receive.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We didn't also do something that I think a number of people across this country recognize, which is put -- put people in a position where they're going to lose the insurance they had and they wanted.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Right now, the CBO says up to 20 million people will lose their insurance as Obamacare goes into effect next year.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And likewise, a study by McKinsey and Company of American businesses said 30 percent of them are anticipating dropping people from coverage.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So for those reasons, for the tax, for Medicare, for this board, and for people losing their insurance, this is why the American people don't want Medicare -- don't want Obamacare.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's why Republicans said, do not do this, and the Republicans had -- had the plan.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They put a plan out.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They put out a plan, a bipartisan plan.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I think something this big, this important has to be done on a bipartisan basis.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And we have to have a president who can reach across the aisle and fashion important legislation with the input from both parties.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Governor Romney said this has to be done on a bipartisan basis.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: This was a bipartisan idea.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In fact, it was a Republican idea.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And Governor Romney at the beginning of this debate wrote and said what we did in Massachusetts could be a model for the nation.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I agree that the Democratic legislators in Massachusetts might have given some advice to Republicans in Congress about how to cooperate, but the fact of the matter is, we used the same advisers, and they say it's the same plan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It -- when Governor Romney talks about this board, for example, unelected board that we've created, what this is, is a group of health care experts, doctors, et cetera, to figure out, how can we reduce the cost of care in the system overall?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Because there -- there are two ways of dealing with our health care crisis.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: One is to simply leave a whole bunch of people uninsured and let them fend for themselves, to let businesses figure out how long they can continue to pay premiums until finally they just give up, and their workers are no longer getting insured, and that's been the trend line.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Or, alternatively, we can figure out, how do we make the cost of care more effective?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And there are ways of doing it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So at Cleveland Clinic, one of the best health care systems in the world, they actually provide great care cheaper than average.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the reason they do is because they do some smart things.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They -- they say, if a patient's coming in, let's get all the doctors together at once, do one test instead of having the patient run around with 10 tests.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Let's make sure that we're providing preventive care so we're catching the onset of something like diabetes.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Let's -- let's pay providers on the basis of performance as opposed to on the basis of how many procedures they've -- they've engaged in.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, so what this board does is basically identifies best practices and says, let's use the purchasing power of Medicare and Medicaid to help to institutionalize all these good things that we do.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the fact of the matter is that, when Obamacare is fully implemented, we're going to be in a position to show that costs are going down.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So we're already beginning to see progress.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In the meantime, folks out there with insurance, you're already getting a rebate.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Let me make one last point.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Governor Romney says, we should replace it, I'm just going to repeal it, but -- but we can replace it with something.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But the problem is, he hasn't described what exactly we'd replace it with, other than saying we're going to leave it to the states.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But the fact of the matter is that some of the prescriptions that he's offered, like letting you buy insurance across state lines, there's no indication that that somehow is going to help somebody who's got a pre-existing condition be able to finally buy insurance.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In fact, it's estimated that by repealing Obamacare, you're looking at 50 million people losing health insurance...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: ... at a time when it's vitally important.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, actually it's -- it's -- it's a lengthy description.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But, number one, preexisting conditions are covered under my plan.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number two, young people are able to stay on their family plan.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's already offered in the private marketplace.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You don't have to have the government mandate that for that to occur.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But let's come back to something the president and I agree on, which is the key task we have in health care is to get the cost down so it's more affordable for families.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And then he has as a model for doing that a board of people at the government, an unelected board, appointed board, who are going to decide what kind of treatment you ought to have.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: In my opinion, the government is not effective in -- in bringing down the cost of almost anything.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: As a matter of fact, free people and free enterprises trying to find ways to do things better are able to be more effective in bringing down the cost than the government will ever be.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Your example of the Cleveland Clinic is my case in point, along with several others I could describe.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is the private market.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: These are small -- these are enterprises competing with each other, learning how to do better and better jobs.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I used to consult to businesses -- excuse me, to hospitals and to health care providers.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I was astonished at the creativity and innovation that exists in the American people.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: In order to bring the cost of health care down, we don't need to have a board of 15 people telling us what kinds of treatments we should have.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We instead need to put insurance plans, providers, hospitals, doctors on target such that they have an incentive, as you say, performance pay, for doing an excellent job, for keeping costs down, and that's happening.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Innermountain Healthcare does it superbly well, Mayo Clinic is doing it superbly well, Cleveland Clinic, others.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But the right answer is not to have the federal government take over health care and start mandating to the providers across America, telling a patient and a doctor what kind of treatment they can have.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's the wrong way to go.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The private market and individual responsibility always work best.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Let me just point out first of all this board that we're talking about can't make decisions about what treatments are given.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's explicitly prohibited in the law.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But let's go back to what Governor Romney indicated, that under his plan, he would be able to cover people with preexisting conditions.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, actually Governor, that isn't what your plan does.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What your plan does is to duplicate what's already the law, which says if you are out of health insurance for three months, then you can end up getting continuous coverage and an insurance company can't deny you if you've -- if it's been under 90 days.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But that's already the law and that doesn't help the millions of people out there with preexisting conditions.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There's a reason why Governor Romney set up the plan that he did in Massachusetts.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It wasn't a government takeover of health care.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It was the largest expansion of private insurance.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But what it does say is that "insurers, you've got to take everybody."
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, that also means that you've got more customers.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But when -- when Governor Romney says that he'll replace it with something, but can't detail how it will be in fact replaced and the reason he set up the system he did in Massachusetts was because there isn't a better way of dealing with the preexisting conditions problem.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It just reminds me of, you know, he says that he's going to close deductions and loopholes for his tax plan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's how it's going to be paid for, but we don't know the details.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: He says that he's going to replace Dodd-Frank, Wall Street reform, but we don't know exactly which ones.
Speaker: Barack Obama
