Text: He now says he's going to replace Obamacare and ensure that all the good things that are in it are going to be in there and you don't have to worry.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And at some point, I think the American people have to ask themselves, is the reason that Governor Romney is keeping all these plans to replace secret because they're too good?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Is it -- is it because that somehow middle-class families are going to benefit too much from them?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The reason is, is because, when we reform Wall Street, when we tackle the problem of pre-existing conditions, then, you know, these are tough problems and we've got to make choices.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the choices we've made have been ones that ultimately are benefiting middle-class families all across the country.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I -- I have to respond to that.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Which is -- which is my experience as a governor is if I come in and -- and lay down a piece of legislation and say, "It's my way or the highway," I don't get a lot done.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: What I do is the same way that Tip O'Neill and Ronald Reagan worked together some years ago.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: When Ronald Reagan ran for office, he laid out the principles that he was going to foster.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: He said he was going to lower tax rates.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: He said he was going to broaden the base.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You've said the same thing, you're going to simplify the tax code, broaden the base.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I want to bring down the tax burden on middle-income families.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I'm going to work together with Congress to say, OK, what -- what are the various ways we could bring down deductions, for instance?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: One way, for instance, would be to have a single number.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Make up a number, $25,000, $50,000.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Anybody can have deductions up to that amount.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And then that number disappears for high-income people.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's one way one could do it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: One could follow Bowles-Simpson as a model and take deduction by deduction and make differences that way.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: There are alternatives to accomplish the objective I have, which is to bring down rates, broaden the base, simplify the code, and create incentives for growth.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And with regards to health care, you had remarkable details with regards to my pre-existing condition plan.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You obviously studied up on -- on my plan.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: In fact, I do have a plan that deals with people with pre-existing conditions.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's part of my health care plan.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And what we did in Massachusetts is a model for the nation state by state.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I said that at that time.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The federal government taking over health care for the entire nation and whisking aside the 10th Amendment, which gives states the rights for these kinds of things, is not the course for America to have a stronger, more vibrant economy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, I definitely think there are differences.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The first role of the federal government is to keep the American people safe.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's its most basic function.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And as commander-in-chief, that is something that I've worked on and thought about every single day that I've been in the Oval Office.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I also believe that government has the capacity, the federal government has the capacity to help open up opportunity and create ladders of opportunity and to create frameworks where the American people can succeed.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Look, the genius of America is the free enterprise system and freedom and the fact that people can go out there and start a business, work on an idea, make their own decisions.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But as Abraham Lincoln understood, there are also some things we do better together.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So, in the middle of the Civil War, Abraham Lincoln said, let's help to finance the Transcontinental Railroad, let's start the National Academy of Sciences, let's start land grant colleges, because we want to give these gateways of opportunity for all Americans, because if all Americans are getting opportunity, we're all going to be better off.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That doesn't restrict people's freedom.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so what I've tried to do as president is to apply those same principles.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And when it comes to education what I've said is we've got to reform schools that are not working.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We use something called Race to the Top.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Wasn't a top-down approach, Governor.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What we've said is to states, we'll give you more money if you initiate reforms.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And as a consequence, you had 46 states around the country who have made a real difference.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But what I've also said is let's hire another 100,000 math and science teachers to make sure we maintain our technological lead and our people are skilled and able to succeed.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And hard-pressed states right now can't all do that.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In fact we've seen layoffs of hundreds of thousands of teachers over the last several years, and Governor Romney doesn't think we need more teachers.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I do, because I think that that is the kind of investment where the federal government can help.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It can't do it all, but it can make a difference.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And as a consequence we'll have a better trained workforce and that will create jobs because companies want to locate in places where we've got a skilled workforce.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, first, I love great schools.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Massachusetts, our schools are ranked number one of all 50 states.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And the key to great schools, great teachers.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So I reject the idea that I don't believe in great teachers or more teachers.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Every school district, every state should make that decision on their own.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The role of government: Look behind us.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The Constitution and the Declaration of Independence.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The role of government is to promote and protect the principles of those documents.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have a responsibility to protect the lives and liberties of our people, and that means a military second to none.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I do not believe in cutting our military.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I believe in maintaining the strength of America's military.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Second, in that line that says we are endowed by our creator with our rights, I believe we must maintain our commitment to religious tolerance and freedom in this country.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That statement also says that we are endowed by our creator with the right to pursue happiness as we choose.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I interpret that as, one, making sure that those people who are less fortunate and can't care for themselves are cared by -- by one another.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're a nation that believes that we're all children of the same god and we care for those that have difficulties, those that are elderly and have problems and challenges, those that are disabled.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And we -- we look for discovery and innovation, all these things desired out of the American heart to provide the pursuit of happiness for our citizens.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But we also believe in maintaining for individuals the right to pursue their dreams and not to have the government substitute itself for the rights of free individuals.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And what we're seeing right now is, in my view, a -- a trickle-down government approach, which has government thinking it can do a better job than free people pursuing their dreams.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And the proof of that is 23 million people out of work.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The proof of that is we've gone from 32 million on food stamps to 47 million on food stamps.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The proof of that is that 50 percent of college graduates this year can't find work.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We know that the path we're taking is not working.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's time for a new path.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, the primary responsibility for education is -- is, of course, at the state and local level.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But the federal government also can play a very important role.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I -- and I agree with Secretary Arne Duncan, he's -- some ideas he's put forward on Race to the Top, not all of them, but some of them I agree with and -- and congratulate him for pursuing that.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The federal government can get local and -- and state schools to do a better job.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: My own view, by the way, is I've added to that.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I happen to believe, I want the kids that are getting federal dollars from IDEA or Title I -- these are disabled kids or -- or -- or poor kids or -- or lower-income kids, rather, I want them to be able to go to the school of their choice.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So all federal funds, instead of going to the -- to the state or to the school district, I'd have go, if you will, follow the child and let the parent and the child decide where to send their -- their -- their student.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, as I've indicated, I think that it has a significant role to play.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Through our Race to the Top program, we've worked with Republican and Democratic governors to initiate major reforms, and they're having an impact right now.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, this is where budgets matter, because budgets reflect choices.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So when Governor Romney indicates that he wants to cut taxes and potentially benefit folks like me and him, and to pay for it we're having to initiate significant cuts in federal support for education, that makes a difference.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, his -- his running mate, Congressman Ryan, put forward a budget that reflects many of the principles that Governor Romney's talked about.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And it wasn't very detailed.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: This seems to be a trend.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But -- but what it did do is to -- if you extrapolated how much money we're talking about, you'd look at cutting the education budget by up to 20 percent.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: When it comes to community colleges, we are seeing great work done out there all over the country because we have the opportunity to train people for jobs that exist right now.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And one of the things I suspect Governor Romney and I probably agree on is getting businesses to work with community colleges so that they're setting up their training programs...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Let me just finish the point.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The -- where they're partnering so that they're designing training programs.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And people who are going through them know that there's a job waiting for them if they complete it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That makes a big difference, but that requires some federal support.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Let me just say one final example.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: When it comes to making college affordable, whether it's two-year or four-year, one of the things that I did as president was we were sending $60 billion to banks and lenders as middlemen for the student loan program, even though the loans were guaranteed.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So there was no risk for the banks or the lenders, but they were taking billions out of the system.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we said, "Why not cut out the middleman?"
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And as a consequence, what we've been able to do is to provide millions more students assistance, lower or keep low interest rates on student loans.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And this is an example of where our priorities make a difference.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Governor Romney, I genuinely believe cares about education, but when he tells a student that, you know, "you should borrow money from your parents to go to college," you know, that indicates the degree to which, you know, there may not be as much of a focus on the fact that folks like myself, folks like Michelle, kids probably who attend University of Denver, just don't have that option.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And for us to be able to make sure that they've got that opportunity and they can walk through that door, that is vitally important not just to those kids.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's how we're going to grow this economy over the long term.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Mr. President, Mr. President, you're entitled as the president to your own airplane and to your own house, but not to your own facts.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: All right, I'm not going to cut education funding.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I don't have any plan to cut education funding and -- and grants that go to people going to college.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm planning on (inaudible) to grow.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So I'm not planning on making changes there.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But you make a very good point, which is that the place you put your money just makes a pretty clear indication of where your heart is.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You put $90 billion into -- into green jobs.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I -- look, I'm all in favor of green energy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: $90 billion, that would have -- that would have hired 2 million teachers.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And these businesses, many of them have gone out of business, I think about half of them, of the ones have been invested in have gone out of business.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: A number of them happened to be owned by people who were contributors to your campaigns.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Look, the right course for America's government, we were talking about the role of government, is not to become the economic player, picking winners and losers, telling people what kind of health treatment they can receive, taking over the health care system that has existed in this country for a long, long time and has produced the best health records in the world.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The right answer for government is say, How do we make the private sector become more efficient and more effective?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: How do we get schools to be more competitive?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I propose we grade our schools so parents know which schools are succeeding and failing, so they can take their child to a -- to a school that he's being more successful.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I don't want to cut our commitment to education.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I wanted to make it more effective and efficient.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And by the way, I've had that experience.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I don't just talk about it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Massachusetts schools are ranked number one in the nation.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is not because I didn't have commitment to education.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's because I care about education for all of our kids.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You've done a great job.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Jim, I had the great experience -- it didn't seem like it at the time -- of being elected in a state where my legislature was 87 percent Democrat.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And that meant I figured out from day one I had to get along and I had to work across the aisle to get anything done.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We drove our schools to be number one in the nation.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We cut taxes 19 times.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We -- as president, I will sit on day one -- actually, the day after I get elected -- I'll sit down with leaders -- the Democratic leaders, as well as Republican leaders, and continue -- as we did in my state -- we met every Monday for a couple hours, talked about the issues and the challenges in the -- in the -- in our state in that case.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have to work on a collaborative basis, not because we're going to compromise our principle, but because there's common ground.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And the challenges America faces right now -- look, the reason I'm in this race is there are people that are really hurting today in this country.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And we face -- this deficit could crush the future generations.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: What's happening in the Middle East, there are developments around the world that are of real concern.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But we need to have leadership -- leadership in Washington that will actually bring people together and get the job done and could not care less if -- if it's a Republican or a Democrat.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, first of all, I think Governor Romney's going to have a busy first day, because he's also going to repeal Obamacare, which will not be very popular among Democrats as you're sitting down with them.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But, look, my philosophy has been, I will take ideas from anybody, Democrat or Republican, as long as they're advancing the cause of making middle-class families stronger and giving ladders of opportunity to the middle class.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's how we cut taxes for middle- class families and small businesses.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's how we cut a trillion dollars of spending that wasn't advancing that cause.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's how we signed three trade deals into law that are helping us to double our exports and sell more American products around the world.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's how we repealed "don't ask/don't tell."
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's how we ended the war in Iraq, as I promised, and that's how we're going to wind down the war in Afghanistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's how we went after Al Qaida and bin Laden.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So we've -- we've seen progress even under Republican control of the House of Representatives.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But, ultimately, part of being principled, part of being a leader is, A, being able to describe exactly what it is that you intend to do, not just saying, "I'll sit down," but you have to have a plan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number two, what's important is occasionally you've got to say no, to -- to -- to folks both in your own party and in the other party.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, you know, yes, have we had some fights between me and the Republicans when -- when they fought back against us reining in the excesses of Wall Street?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Absolutely, because that was a fight that needed to be had.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: When -- when we were fighting about whether or not we were going to make sure that Americans had more security with their health insurance and they said no, yes, that was a fight that we needed to have.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so part of leadership and governing is both saying what it is that you are for, but also being willing to say no to some things.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I've got to tell you, Governor Romney, when it comes to his own party during the course of this campaign, has not displayed that willingness to say no to some of the more extreme parts of his party.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, Jim, I want to thank you, and I want to thank Governor Romney, because I think was a terrific debate, and I very much appreciate it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I want to thank the University of Denver.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, four years ago, we were going through a major crisis.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And yet my faith and confidence in the American future is undiminished.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the reason is because of its people, because of the woman I met in North Carolina who decided at 55 to go back to school because she wanted to inspire her daughter and now has a job from that new training that she's gotten; because a company in Minnesota who was willing to give up salaries and perks for their executives to make sure that they didn't lay off workers during a recession.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The auto workers that you meet in Toledo or Detroit take such pride in building the best cars in the world, not just because of a paycheck, but because it gives them that sense of pride, that they're helping to build America.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so the question now is how do we build on those strengths.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And everything that I've tried to do, and everything that I'm now proposing for the next four years in terms of improving our education system or developing American energy or making sure that we're closing loopholes for companies that are shipping jobs overseas and focusing on small businesses and companies that are creating jobs here in the United States, or closing our deficit in a responsible, balanced way that allows us to invest in our future.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: All those things are designed to make sure that the American people, their genius, their grit, their determination, is -- is channeled and -- and they have an opportunity to succeed.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And everybody's getting a fair shot.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And everybody's getting a fair share -- everybody's doing a fair share, and everybody's playing by the same rules.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, four years ago, I said that I'm not a perfect man and I wouldn't be a perfect president.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's probably a promise that Governor Romney thinks I've kept.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I also promised that I'd fight every single day on behalf of the American people, the middle class, and all those who were striving to get into the middle class.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I've kept that promise and if you'll vote for me, then I promise I'll fight just as hard in a second term.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Thank you, Jim, and Mr. President.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And thank you for tuning in this evening.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is a -- this is an important election and I'm concerned about America.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm concerned about the direction America has been taking over the last four years.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I -- I know this is bigger than an election about the two of us as individuals.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's bigger than our respective parties.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's an election about the course of America.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: What kind of America do you want to have for yourself and for your children.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And there really are two very different paths that we began speaking about this evening, and over the course of this month we're going to have two more presidential debates and a vice presidential debate.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're talk about those two paths.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But they lead in very different directions.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And it's not just looking to our words that you have to take in evidence of where they go.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You can look at the record.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: There's no question in my mind that if the president were to be reelected you'll continue to see a middle-class squeeze with incomes going down and prices going up.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'll get incomes up again.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We've had 43 straight months with unemployment above 8 percent.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: If I'm president I will create -- help create 12 million new jobs in this country with rising incomes.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: If the president's reelected, Obamacare will be fully installed.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: In my view that's going to mean a whole different way of life for people who counted on the insurance plan they had in the past.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You're going to see health premiums go up by some $2,500 per family.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: If I'm elected we won't have Obama.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We'll put in place the kind of principles that I put in place in my own state and allow each state to craft their own programs to get people insured and we'll focus on getting the cost of health care down.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: If the president were to be reelected you're going to see a $716 billion cut to Medicare.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You'll have 4 million people who will lose Medicare Advantage.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You'll have hospital and providers that'll no longer accept Medicare patients.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'll restore that $716 billion to Medicare.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The president's reelected you'll see dramatic cuts to our military.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The secretary of defense has said these would be even devastating.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I will not cut our commitment to our military.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I will keep America strong and get America's middle class working again.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well I think this Republican administration has been almost all style, and spectacular, and not substance.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've uh - got a chance tonight to talk about, first of all, leadership, the character of our country, and a vision of the future.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In every one of these instances, the Ford administration has failed, and I hope tonight that I and Mr. Ford will have a chance to discuss the reasons for those failures.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Our country is not strong anymore; we're not respected anymore.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We can only be strong overseas if we're strong at home; and when I became president we'll not only be strong in those areas but also in defense - a defense capability second to none.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've lost in our foreign policy, the character of the American people.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've uh - ignored or excluded the American people and the Congress from participation in the shaping of our foreign policy.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It's been one of secrecy and exclusion.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In addition to that we've had a chance to became now, contrary to our long-standing beliefs and principles, the arms merchant of the whole world.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've tried to buy success from our enemies, and at the same time we've excluded from the process the normal friendship of our allies.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In addition to that we've become fearful to compete with the Soviet Union on an equal basis.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The Soviet Union knows what they want in detente, and they've been getting it.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We have not known what we've wanted and we've been out-traded in almost every instance.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The other point I wanna make is about our defense.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've got to be a nation blessed with a defense capability that's efficient, tough, capable, well organized, narrowly focused - fighting capability.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The ability to fight, if necessary, is the best way to avoid the chance for, or the requirement to fight.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And the last point I wanna make is this: Mr. Ford, Mr. Kissinger have uh - continued on with the policies and failures of Richard Nixon.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Even the Republican platform has criticized the lack of leadership in Mr. Ford and they've criticized the foreign policy of this administration.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is one instance where I agree with - with the Republican platform.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I might say this in closing, and that is that as far as foreign policy goes, Mr. Kissinger has been the president of this country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Mr. Ford has shown an absence of leadership, and an absence of a grasp of what this country is and what it ought to be.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: That's got to be changed.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And that's one of the major issues in this uh - campaign of 1976.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Governor Carter again is talking in broad generalities.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Let me take just one question that he raises - the military strength and capability of the United States.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Governor Carter in November of 1975 indicated that he wanted to cut the defense budget by $15 billion.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: A few months later, he said he wanted to cut the defense budget by eight or nine billion dollars.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And more recently, he talks about cutting the defense budget by five to seven billion dollars.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: There is no way you can be strong militarily and have those kind of reductions in our military uh - appropriation.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now let me just tell you a little story.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: About uh - late October of 1975, I asked the then Secretary of Defense, Mr. Schlesinger, to tell me what had to be done if we were going to reduce the defense budget by uh - three to five billion dollars.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: A few days later, Mr. Schlesinger came back and said if we cut the defense budget by three to five billion dollars, we will have to cut military personnel by two hundred and fifty thousand, civilian personnel by a hundred thousand, jobs in America by a hundred thousand.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We would have to stretch out our aircraft procurement, we would have to reduce our naval construction program, we would have to reduce the uh - research and development for the Army, the Navy, the Air Force and Marines by 8 percent.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We would have to close twenty military bases in the United States immediately.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: That's the kind of defense program that uh - Mr. Carter wants.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Let me tell you this straight from the shoulder.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: You don't negotiate with Mr. Brezhnev from weakness.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And the kind of defense program that Mr. Carter wants will mean a weaker defense and a poor negotiating position.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I don't believe we should move to a cold-war relationship.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I think it's in the best interest of the United States, and the world as a whole that the United States negotiate rather than go back to the cold-war relationship with the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I don't uh - look at the picture as bleakly as you have indicated in your question, Mr. Trewhitt.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We have been successful in Portugal, where a year ago it looked like there was a very great possibility that the uh - Communists would take over in Portugal.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We have a democracy in Portugal today.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: A few uh - months ago, or I should say, maybe two years ago, the Soviet Union looked like they had continued strength in the Middle East.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Today, according to Prime Minister Rabin, the Soviet Union is weaker in the Middle East than they have been in many, many years.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The facts are, there - the Soviet Union relationship with Egypt is uh - at a low level.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The Soviet Union relationship with Syria is at a very low point.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The United States today, according to Prime Minister Rabin of Israel, is a- at a peak in its uh - influence and power in the Middle East.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But let's turn for a minute to the uhh - southern African operations that are now going on.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The United States of America took the initiative in southern Africa.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We wanted to end the bloodshed in southern Africa.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We wanted to have the right of self-determination in southern Africa.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We wanted to preserve human dignity in southern Africa.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We have taken the initiative, and in southern Africa today the United States is trusted by the black front-line nations and black Africa.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The United States is trusted by other elements in southern Africa.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The United States foreign policy under this administration has been one of progress and success.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And I believe that instead of talking about Soviet progress, we can talk about American successes.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And may I make an observation - part of the question you asked, Mr. Trewhitt?
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I don't believe that it's in the best interest of the United States and the NATO nations to have a Communist government in NATO.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Mr. Carter has indicated he would look with sympathy to a Communist government in NATO.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I think that would destroy the integrity and the strength of NATO, and I am totally opposed to it.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Well, Mr. Ford, unfortunately, has just made a statement that's not true.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I have never advocated a Communist government for Italy.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: That would obviously be a ridiculous thing for anyone to do who wanted to be president of this country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think that this is uh - an instance of uh - deliberate distortion, and this has occurred also in the question about defense.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: As a matter of fact, uh - I've never advocated any cut of $15 billion in our defense budget.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: As a matter of fact, Mr. Ford has made a political football out of the defense budget.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: About a year ago he cut the Pentagon budget six point eight billion dollars.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: After he fired James Schlesinger, the political heat got so great that he added back about $3 billion.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: When Ronald Reagan won the Texas primary election, Mr. Ford added back another one and a half billion dollars.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Immediately before the Kansas City convention, he added back another one point eight billion dollars in the defense budget.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And his own uh - Office of Management and Budget testified that he had a $3 billion cut insurance added to the defense budget - defense budget under the pressure from the Pentagon.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Obviously, this is another indication of trying to use the defense budget for political purposes, which he's trying to do tonight.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Now, we went into south Africa late, after Great Britain, Rhodesia, the black nations had been trying to solve this problem for many, many years.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We didn't go in until right before the election, similar to what was taking place in 1972, when Mr. Kissinger announced peace is at hand just before the election at that time.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Well, I'm not gonna name my cabinet before I get elected.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I've got a little ways to go before I start doing that.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But I have uh - an adequate background, I believe.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Naval Academy, the first military graduate since uh - Eisenhower.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I've served as the Governor of Georgia and have traveled extensively in foreign countries and South America, Central America, Europe, the Middle East and in Japan.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I've traveled the last twenty-one months among the people of this country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I've talked to them and I've listened.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I've seen at first hand, in a very vivid way, the deep hurt that's come to this country in the aftermath of Vietnam and Cambodia, Chile, and Pakistan, and Angola, and Watergate, CIA revelations.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: What we were formerly so proud of - the strength of our country, its uh - moral integrity, the representation in foreign affairs of what our people are, what our Constitution stands for, has been gone.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And in the secrecy that has surrounded our foreign policy in the last few years, uh - the American people, the Congress have been excluded.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I believe I know what this country ought to be.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I've uh - been one who's loved my nation as many Americans do, and I believe that there's no limit placed on what we can be in the future, if we can harness the tremendous resources - militarily, economically, and the stature of our people, the meaning of the Constitution, in the future.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Every time we've made a serious mistake in foreign affairs, it's been because the American people have been excluded from the process.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: If we can just tap the intelligence and ability, the sound common sense and the good judgment of the American people, we can once again have a foreign policy to make us proud instead of ashamed.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I'm not gonna exclude the American people from that process in the future, as Mr. Ford and Kissinger have done.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is what it takes to have a sound foreign policy strong at home, strong defense, permanent commitments, not betray the principles of our country, and involve the American people and the Congress in the shaping of our foreign policy.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: So these are the ways that we can restore the strength of our country, and they don't require long experience in foreign policy.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Nobody has that except a president who has served a long time or a secretary of state.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But my background, my experience, my knowledge of the people of this country, my commitment to our principles that don't change - those are the best bases to correct the horrible mistakes of this administration and restore our own country to a position of leadership in the world.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: First of all, I would quit conducting the decision-making process in secret, as has been a characteristic of Mr. Kissinger and Mr. Ford.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In many instances we've made agreements, like in Vietnam, uh - that have uh - been revealed later on to our uh - embarrassment.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Recently Ian Smith, the uh - president of uh - Rhodesia, announced that he had unequivocal commitments from Mr. Kissinger that he could not reveal.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The American people don't know what those commitments are.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've seen uh - in the past the destruction of elected governments, like in Chile, and the strong support of military dictatorship there.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: These kinds of things have hurt us very much.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I would restore the concept of the fireside chat, which was an integral part of the administration of Franklin Roosevelt.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I would also restore the involvement of the Congress.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: When Harry Truman was president he was not afraid to have a strong secretary of defense.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Dean Acheson, George Marshall were strong secretaries of uh - state - excuse me - state.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But he also made sure that there was a bipartisan support.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The members of Congress, Arthur Vandenberg, Walter George, were part of the process, and before our nation made a secret agreement, or before we made a bluffing statement, we were sure that we had the backing not only of the president and the secretary of state, but also of the Congress and the people.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is a responsibility of the president.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I think it's very damaging to our country for Mr. Ford to have turned over this responsibility to the secretary of state.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Governor Carter again contradicts himself.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: He complains about secrecy and yet he is quoted as saying that in the attempt to find a solution in the Middle East that he would hold unpublicized meetings with the Soviet Union - I presume for the purpose of an - imposing a settlement on Israel and the Arab nations.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But let me talk just a minute about what we've done to avoid secrecy in the Ford administration.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: After the United States took the initiative in working with Israel and with Egypt and achieving the Sinai II agreement - and I'm proud to say that not a single Egyptian or Israeli soldier has lost his life since the signing of the Sinai agreement.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But at the time that uh - I submitted the Sinai agreement to the Congress of the United States, I submitted every single document that was applicable to the Sinai II agreement.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It was the most complete documentation by any president of any agreement signed by a president on behalf of the United States.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now as far as meeting with the Congress is concerned, during the twenty-four months that I've been the president of the United States I have averaged better than one meeting a month with responsible groups or committees of the Congress - both House and Senate.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The secretary of state has appeared in the several years that he's been the secretary before eighty different uh - committee hearings in the House and in the Senate.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The secretary of state has made better than fifty speeches all over the United States explaining American foreign policy.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I have made myself at least ten uh - speeches in various parts of the country where I have discussed with the American people defense and foreign policy.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I believe that we have uh - negotiated with the Soviet Union since I've been president from a position of strength.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And let me cite several examples.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Shortly after I became president in uh - December of 1974, I met with uh - General Secretary Brezhnev in Vladivostok and we agreed to a mutual cap on the ballistic missile launchers at a ceiling of twenty-four hundred - which means that the Soviet Union, if that becomes a permanent agreement, will have to make a reduction in their launchers that they now have or plan to have.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I've negotiated at Vladivostok with uh - Mr. Brezhnev a limitation on the MIRVing of their ballistic missiles at a figure of thirteen-twenty, which is the first time that any president has achieved a cap either on launchers or on MIRVs.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It seems to me that we can go from there to uh - the uh - grain sales.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The grain sales have been a benefit to American agriculture.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We have achieved a five and three quarter year uh - sale of a minimum six million metric tons, which means that they have already bought about four million metric tons this year and are bound to buy another two million metric tons to take the grain and corn and wheat that the American farmers have produced in order to uh - have full production.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And these grain sales to the Soviet Union have helped us tremendously in meeting the costs of the additional oil and - the oil that we have bought from overseas.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: If we turn to Helsinki - I'm glad you raised it, Mr. uh - Frankel.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In the case of Helsinki, thirty-five nations signed an agreement, including the secretary of state for the Vatican - I can't under any circumstances believe that the - His Holiness, the Pope would agree by signing that agreement that the thirty-five nations have turned over to the Warsaw Pact nations the domination of the - Eastern Europe.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And if Mr. Carter alleges that His Holiness by signing that has done it, he is totally inaccurate.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now, what has been accomplished by the Helsinki agreement?
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Number one, we have an agreement where they notify us and we notify them of any uh - military maneuvers that are to be be undertaken.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In both cases where they've done so, there is no Soviet domination of Eastern Europe and there never will be under a Ford administration.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I don't believe, uh - Mr. Frankel that uh - the Yugoslavians consider themselves dominated by the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I don't believe that the Rumanians consider themselves dominated by the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I don't believe that the Poles consider themselves dominated by the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Each of those countries is independent, autonomous: it has its own territorial integrity and the United States does not concede that those countries are under the domination of the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: As a matter of fact, I visited Poland, Yugoslavia and Rumania to make certain that the people of those countries understood that the president of the United States and the people of the United are dedicated to their independence, their autonomy and their freedom.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: (chuckle) Well, in the first place, I'm not criticizing His Holiness the Pope.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I was talking about Mr. Ford.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The uh - fact is that secrecy has surrounded the decisions made by the Ford administration.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In the case of the Helsinki agreement - it may have been a good agreement at the beginning, but we have failed to enforce the so-called basket three part, which insures the right of people to migrate, to join their families, to be free, to speak out.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've also seen a very serious uh - problem with the so-called Sonnenfeldt document, which apparently Mr. Ford has just endorsed, which said that there's an organic linkage between the Eastern European countries and the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I would like to see Mr. Ford convince the Polish-Americans and the Czech-Americans and the Hungarian-Americans in this country that those countries don't live under the domination and supervision of the Soviet Union behind the Iron - uh - Curtain.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We also have seen Mr. Ford exclude himself from access to the public.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: He hasn't had a tough cross-examination-type press conference in over thirty days.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: He's also shown a weakness in yielding to pressure.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The Soviet Union, for instance, put pressure on Mr. Ford and he refused to see a symbol of human freedom recognized around the world, Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The Arabs have put pressure on Mr. Ford, and he's yielded, and has permitted a boycott by the Arab countries of American businesses who trade with Israel, or who have American Jews owning or taking part in the management of American - companies.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: His own secretary of commerce had to be subpoenaed by the Congress to reveal the names of businesses who were subject to this boycott.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: They didn't volunteer the information.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: He had to be subpoenaed.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And the last thing I'd like to say is this: This grain deal with the Soviet Union in '72 was terrible, and Mr. Ford made up for it with three embargoes, one against our own ally in Japan.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: That's not the way to run our foreign policy, including international trade.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I would never single out food as a trade embargo item.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: If I ever decided to impose an embargo because of a crisis in international relationships, it would include all shipments of all equipment.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: For instance, if the Arab countries ever again declare an embargo against our nation on oil I would consider that not a military but an economic declaration of war, and I would respond instantly and in kind.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I would not ship that Arab country anything - no weapons, no spare parts for weapons, no oil-drilling rigs, no oil pipe, no nothing.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I wouldn't single out just food.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Another thing that I'd like to say is this: In our international trade, as I said in my op- opening statement, we have become the arms merchant of the world.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: When this Republican administration came into office we were shipping about $1 billion worth of arms overseas, now ten to twelve billion dollars worth of arms overseas to countries that quite often use these weapons to fight each other.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The shift in emphasis has been very disturbing to me, speaking about the Middle East.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Under the last Democratic administration 60 percent of all weapons that went into the Middle East were for Israel.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Nowadays - 75 percent were for Israel before.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Now 60 percent go to the Arab countries, and this does not include Iran.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: If you include Iran, our present shipment of weapons to the Middle East, only 20 percent goes to Israel.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is a deviation from idealism; it's a deviation from a commitment to our major ally in the Middle East, which is Israel; it's a yielding to economic pressure on the part of the Arabs on the oil issue; and it's also a tremendous indication that under the Ford administration we have not addressed the energy policy adequately.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We still have no comprehensive energy policy in this country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And it's an overall sign of weakness.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: When we are weak at home economically - high unemployment, high inflation, a confused government, a wasteful defense establishment, this encourages the kind of pressure that's been put on us successfully.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It would've been inconceivable ten - fifteen years ago, for us to be brought to our knees with an Arab oil embargo.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But it was done three years ago and they're still putting pressure on us from the Arab countries to our discredit around the world.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: These are the weaknesses that I see, and I believe it's not just a matter of idealism.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It's a matter of being tough.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It's a matter of being strong.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It's a matter of being consistent.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Our priorities ought to be first of all to meet our own military needs, secondly to meet the needs of our allies and friends, and only then should we ship military equipment to foreign countries.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And the shipment of Spruance-class destroyers to Iran are much more highly sophisticated than the Spruance-class destroyers that are present being delivered to our own Navy.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is ridiculous and it ought to be changed.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: If - Iran is not an Arab country, as you know, it is a Moslem country - but if Saudi Arabia should declare an oil embargo against us, then I would consider that an economic declaration of war.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I would make sure that the uh - Saudis understood this ahead of time so there would be no doubt in their mind.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think under those circumstances they would refrain from pushing us to our knees as they did in 1973 with their previous oil embargo.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Governor Carter uh - apparently doesn't realize that since I've been president we have sold to the Israelis over $4 billion in military hardware.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: So the Ford administration has done a good job in helping our good ally, Israel, and we're dedicated to the survival and security of Israel.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I believe that Governor Carter doesn't realize the need and necessity for arms sales to Iran.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: He indicates he would not make those.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Iran is bordered very extensively by the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The Soviet Union and the Communist-dominated government of Iraq are neighbors of Iran, and Iran is an ally of the United States.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It's my strong feeling that we ought to sell arms to Iran for its own national security, and as an ally - a strong ally of the United States.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The history of our relationship with Iran goes back to the days of President Truman when he decided that it was vitally necessary for our own security as well as that of Iran, that we should help that country, and Iran has been a good ally.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In 1973 when there was an oil embargo, Iran did not participate.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Iran continued to sell oil to the United States.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I believe that it's in our interest and in the interest of Israel and Iran, and Saudi Arabia, for the United States to sell arms to those countries.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It's for their security as well as ours.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Our relationship with the People's Republic of China is based upon the Shanghai Communique, of 1972, and that communique, calls for the normalization of relations between the United States and the People's Republic.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It doesn't set a times schedule.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It doesn't uh - make a determination as to how uh - that relationship should be achieved in relationship to our current uhh - diplomatic recognition and obligations to the Taiwanese Government.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The Shanghai Communique, does say that the differences between the People's Republic on the one hand and Taiwan on the other shall be settled by peaceful means.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The net result is this administration, and during my time as the president for the next four years, we will continue to move for normalization of relations in the traditional sense, and we will insist that the disputes between Taiwan and the People's Republic be settled peacefully, as was agreed in the Shanghai Communique, of 1972.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The Ford administration will not let down, will not eliminate or forget our obligation to the people of Taiwan.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We feel that there must be a continued obligation to the people, the some nineteen or twenty million people in Taiwan.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And as we move during the next four years, those will be the policies of this administration.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: There is no policy of this government to give to the People's Republic, or to sell to the People's Republic of China, military equipment.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I do not believe that we, the United States, should sell, give or otherwise transfer military hardware to the People's Republic of China, or any other Communist nation, such as the Soviet Union and the like.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Well, I'd like to go back just one moment to the previous question, where uh - Mr. Ford, I think, confused the issue by trying to say that we are shipping Israel 40 percent of our aid.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: As a matter of fact, during this current year uh we are shipping Iran, or have contracted to ship to Iran, about seven and a half billion dollars worth of arms and also to Saudi Arabia, about seven and a half billion dollars worth of arms.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Also in 1975, we almost brought Israel to their knees after the uh - Yom Kippur War by the so-called reassessment of our relationship to Israel.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We in effect tried to make Israel the scapegoat for the problems in the Middle East.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And this weakened our relationships with Israel a great deal and put a cloud on the total commitment that our people feel toward the Israelis.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: There ought to be a clear, unequivocal commitment without change to Israel.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In the Far East I think we need to continue to be uh - strong and uh - I would certainly uh - pursue the uh - normalization of uh - relationships with the People's Republic of China.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We opened a great opportunity in l972, which has pretty well been frittered - frit- frittered away under Mr. Ford, that ought to be a constant uh - inclination toward - uh - toward friendship.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But I would never let that friendship with the People's Republic of China stand in the way of the preservation of the independence and freedom of the people on Taiwan.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Well, always in the past we've had an ability to have a strong defense and also have - to have a strong uh - domestic economy, and also to be strong in our reputation and influence within the community of nations.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: These uh - characteristics of our country have been endangered under Mr. Ford.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We're no longer respected in a showdown vote in the United Nations or in - in any other international council we're lucky to get 20 percent of the other nations to vote with us.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Our allies feel that we've neglected them.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The so-called Nixon shock against Japan had weakened our relationships there.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Under this administration we've also had an inclination to keep separate the European countries, thinking that if they are separate, then we can dominate them and proceed with our secret, Lone Ranger-type diplomatic efforts.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The worst inflation since the Great Depression.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The highest unemployment of any developed nation of the world.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We have a higher unemployment rate in this country than Great Britain, and West Germany.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Our unemployment rate is twice as high as it is in Italy; it's three or four times as high as it is - as it is in Japan.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And that terrible circumstance in this country is exported overseas.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We comprise about 30 percent of the world's economic trade power influence.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And when we're weak at home - weaker than all our allies - that weakness weakens the whole free world.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: So strong economy is very important.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Another thing that we need to do is to reestablish the good relationships that we ought to have between the United States and our natural allies and friends.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And using that base of strength, and using the idealism, the honesty, the predictability, the commitment, the integrity of our own country, that's where our strength lies.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And that would permit us to deal with the developing nations in a position of strength.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Under this administration we've had a continuation of the so-called balance of power politics, where everything is looked on as a struggle between us on the one side, the Soviet Union on the other.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Our allies - the smaller countries get trampled in the rush.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: What we need is to try to seek individualized bilateral relationships with countries, regardless of their size, and to establish world-order politics, which means that we want to preserve peace through strength.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We also wanna revert back to the stature and the respect that our country had in previous administrations.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But I can guarantee it will not come if Gerald Ford is reelected and this present policy is continued; it will come if I'm elected.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Well let me say very quickly that under President Johnson, in spite of the massive investment in the Vietnam War, he turned over a balanced budget to Mr. Nixon.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The unemployment rate was less than 4 percent.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The inflation rate under Kennedy and Johnson was about 2 percent - one-third what it is under this administration.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: So we did have at that time with good management, the ability to do both.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I don't think that anybody can say that Johnson and Kennedy neglected the poor and the destitute people in this country or around the world.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But I can say this: The number one responsibility of any president, above all else, is to guarantee the security of our nation - an ability to be free of the threat of attack, or blackmail and to carry out our obligations to our allies and friends, and to carry out a legitimate foreign policy.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: They must go hand in hand, but the security of this nation has got to come first.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Let me say very categorically you cannot maintain the security of the United States with the kind of defense budget cuts that Governor Carter has indicated.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In 1975 he wanted to cut the budget $15 billion.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: He's now down to a figure of five to seven billion dollars.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Reductions of that kind will not permit the United States to be strong enough to deter aggression and maintain the peace.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Governor Carter apparently doesn't know the facts.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: As soon as I became president, I initiated a meeting with the NATO heads of state and met with them in Brussels to discuss how we could improve the re- defense relationship in Western Europe.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In uh - November of 1975 I met with the leaders of the five industrial nations in France for the purpose of seeing what we could do acting together to meet the problems of uh - the coming recession.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Our relations with Japan have never been better.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I was the first United States president to visit Japan.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And we uh - had the emperor of Japan here this uh - past year and the net result is Japan and the United States are working more closely together now than at any time in the history of our relationship.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: You can go around the world - and let me take Israel for example.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Just recently, President Rabin said that our relations were never better.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: First we have to understand that SALT I expires October third 1977.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Uh - Mr. Brezhnev and I met in Vladivostok in December of 1974 for the purpose of trying to take the initial step so we could have a SALT II agreement that would go to l985.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: As I indicated earlier, we did agree on a twenty-four-hundred limitation on uh - uh - launchers of ballistic missiles.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Uh - that would mean a cutback in the Soviet program; it would not interfere with our own program.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: At the same time, we put a limitation of thirteen hundred and twenty on MIRVs.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Our technicians have been working since that time in Geneva, trying to put into technical language a - an agreement that can be verified by both parties.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In the interim, there has been the development on our part primarily, the cruise missiles; cruise missiles that could be launched from land-based mobile installations; cruise missiles that could be launched - launched from high-performance aircraft, like the B-52s or the B-1s, which I hope we proceed with; cruise missiles which could be launched from either surface or submarine uh - naval vessels.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Those gray-area weapons systems are creating some problems in a - the agreement for a SALT II negotiation.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But I can say that I am dedicated to proceeding, and I met just last week with the foreign minister of the Soviet Union, and he indicated to me that uh - the Soviet Union was interested in narrowing the differences and making a realistic and a sound compromise.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I hope and trust, in the best interest of both countries, and in the best interests of all people throughout this globe, that the Soviet Union and the United States can make a mutually beneficial agreement.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Because if we do not and SALT I expires on October three, 1977, you will unleash again an all-out nuclear arms race with the potential of a nuclear holocaust of unbelievable dimensions.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: So it's the obligation of the president to do just that, and I intend to do so.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: They are a new weapons system that has a great potential, both conventional and nuclear armed.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: At the same time, we have to make certain that the Soviet Union's Backfire, which they claim is not an intercontinental aircraft and which some of our people contend is, must also be included if we are to get the kind of agreement which is in the best interest of both countries.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And I really believe that it - it's far better for us and for the Soviet Union, and more importantly for the people around the world, that these two superpowers find an answer for a SALT II agreement before October three, 1977.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I think good will on both parts, hard bargaining by both parties and a reasonable compromise will be in the best interests of all parties.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Well, Mr. Ford acts like he's uh - running for president for the first time.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: He's been in office two years, and there has been absolutely no progress made toward a new SALT agreement.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: He has learned the date of the expiration of SALT I, apparently.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've seen, in this world, a development of a tremendous threat to us.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: As a nuclear engineer myself, I know the limitations and capabilities of atomic power.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I also - know that as far as the human beings on this earth are concerned that the nonproliferation of atomic weapons is number one.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Only the last few days with the election approaching, has Mr. Ford taken any interest in a nonproliferation movement.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I advocated last May in a speech at the United Nations that we move immediately as a nation to declare a complete moratorium on the testing of all nuclear devices, both weapons and peaceful devices; that we not ship any more atomic fuel to a country that refuses to comply with strict controls over the waste which can be reprocessed into explosives.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I've also advocated that we stop the sale by Germany and France of - processing plants for Pakistan and Brazil.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Mr. Ford hasn't moved on this.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We also need to provide an adequate supply of enriched uranium.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Mr. Ford, again, under pressure from the atomic energy lobby, has insisted that this reprocessing or rather re-en- enrichment be done by private industry and not by the existing uh - government uh - plants.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This kind of confusion and absence of leadership has let us drift now for two years with a constantly increasing threat of atomic weapons throughout the world.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We now have five nations that have atomic bombs that we know about.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: If we continue under Mr. Ford's policy by 1985 or '90 we'll have twenty nations that have the capability of exploding atomic weapons.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This has got to be stopped.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: That is one of the major challenges and major undertakings that I will assume as the next president.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: No, it's not just campaign rhetoric.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think that militarily we are as strong as any nation on earth.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think we got to stay that way and continue to increase our capabilities to meet any potential threat.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But as far as strength derived from commitment to principles, as far as strength derived from the unity within our country, as far as strength derived from the people, the Congress, the secretary of state, the president, sharing in the evolution and carrying-out of a foreign policy, as far as strength derived from the respect of our own allies and friends, their assurance that we will be staunch in our commitment, that we will not deviate and that we'll give them adequate attention, as far as - as strength derived from doing what's right - caring for the poor, providing food, becoming the breadbasket of the world instead of the arms merchant of the world - in those respects, we're not strong.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Also, we'll never be strong again overseas, unless we're strong at home.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And with our economy in such terrible disarray and getting worse by the month.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've got five-hundred thousand more Americans unemployed today than we had three months ago.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've got two and a half million more Americans out of work now than we had when Mr. Ford took office.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This kind of deterioration in our economic strength is bound to weaken us around the world.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And we not only have uh problems at home but we export those problems overseas.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: So as far as the respect of our own people toward our own government, as far as participating in the shaping of uh - concepts and commitments, as far as the trust of our country among the nations of the world, as far as dependence of our country in meeting the needs and obligations that we've expressed to our allies, as far as the respect of our country - even among our potential adversaries - we are weak.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Under this administration that strength has not been realized.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Governor Carter uh - brags about the unemployment during Democratic administrations and condemns the unemployment at the present time.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I must remind him that we're at peace and during the period that he brags about unemployment being low, the United States was at war.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now let me correct one other comment that uh - Governor Carter has made.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I have recommended to the Congress that we develop the uranium enrichment plant at Portsmouth, Ohio, which is a publicly owned - U.S. government facility and have indicated that the private program which would follow on in Alabama is one that may or may not uhh - be constructed.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But I am committed to the one at Portsmouth, Ohio.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The governor also talks about morality in foreign policy.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The foreign policy of the United States meets the highest standards of morality.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: What is more moral than peace, and the United States is at peace today?
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: What is more moral in foreign policy than for the administration to take the lead in the World Food Conference in Rome in 1974 when the United States committed six million metric tons of food - over 60 percent of the food committed for the disadvantaged and underdeveloped nations of the world?
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The Ford administration wants to eradicate hunger and disease in our underdeveloped countries throughout the world.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: What is more moral than for the United States under the Ford administration to take the lead in southern Africa, in the Middle East?
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Those are initiatives in foreign policy which are of the highest moral standard and that is indicative of the foreign policy of this country.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I believe that uh - our foreign policy must express the highest standards of morality.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And the initiatives that we took in southern Africa are the best examples of what this administration is doing and will continue to do in the next four years.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: If the United States had not moved when we did in southern Africa, there's no doubt there would have been an acceleration of bloodshed in that tragic part of the world.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: If we had not taken our initiative, it's very, very possible that uh - the government of Rhodesia would have been overrun and that the Soviet Union and the Cubans would have dominated uh - southern Africa.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: So the United States, seeking to preserve the principle of self-determination, to eliminate the possibility of bloodshed, to protect the rights of the minority as we insisted upon the rights of the majority, uh - I believe followed the good conscience of the American people in foreign policy.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And I believe that we used our skill.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Secretary of State Kissinger has done a superb job in working with the black African nations, the so-called front-line nations.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: He has done a superb job in getting the prime minister of South Africa, Mr. Vorster, to agree that the time had come for a solution to the problem of Rhodesia.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Secretary Kissinger, in his meeting with uh - Prime Minister Smith of Rhodesia, was able to convince him that it was in the best interests of whites as well as blacks in Rhodesia to find an answer for a transitional government and then a majority government.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: This is a perfect example of the kind of leadership that the United States, under this administration, has taken.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And I can assure you that this administration will follow that high moral principle in our future efforts in foreign policy, including our efforts in the Middle East where it is vitally important because the Middle East is the crossroads of the world.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: There've been more disputes in its area where there's more volatility than any other place in the world.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But because Arab nations and the Israelis trust the United States, we were able to take the lead in the Sinai II Agreement.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And I can assure you that the United States will have the leadership role in moving toward a comprehensive settlement of the Middle Eastern problems, I hope and trust as soon as possible.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And we will do it with the highest moral principles.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I would hope that as we move to one area of the world from another - and the United States must not spread itself too thinly - that was one of the problems that helped to create the circumstances in Vietnam - but as we as a nation find that we are asked by the various parties, either one nation against another or individuals within a nation, that the United States will take the leadership and try to resolve the differences.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Let me take uh - South Korea as an example.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I have personally told President Pack that the United States does not condone the kind of repressive measures that he has taken in that country.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But I think in all fairness and equity we have to recognize the problem that South Korea has.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: On the north they have North Korea with five hundred thousand well-trained, well-equipped troops - they are supported by the People's Republic of China; they are supported by the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: South Korea faces a very delicate situation.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now the United States, in this case, this administration, has recommended a year ago and we have reiterated it again this year, that the United States, South Korea, North Korea and the uh - People's Republic of China sit down at a conference table to resolve the problems of the Korean peninsula.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: This is a leadership role that the United States under this administration is carrying out, and if we do it, and I think the opportunities and the possibilities are getting better, we will have solved many of the internal domestic problems that exist in South Korea at the present time.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I notice that Mr. Ford didn't comment on the uh - prisons in Chile.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is an - a typical example, maybe of many others, where this administration overthrew an elected government and helped to establish a military dictatorship.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This has not been an ancient history story.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Last year under Mr. Ford, of all the Food for Peace that went to South America, 85 percent went to the military dictatorship in Chile.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Another point I wanna make is this.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: He says we have to move from one area of the world to another.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: That's one of the problems with this administration's so-called shuttle diplomacy.
