Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: While the secretary of state's in one country, there are almost a hundred and fifty others that are wondering what we're gonna do next, what will be the next secret agreement.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We don't have a comprehensive understandable foreign policy that deals with world problems or even regional problems.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Another thing that concerned me was what Mr. Ford said about unemployment, that - insinuating that under Johnson and Kennedy that unemployment could only be held down when this country is at war.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Karl Marx said that the free enterprise system in a democracy can only continue to exist when they are at war or preparing far war.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Karl Marx was the grandfather of Communism.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I don't agree with that statement.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I hope Mr. Ford doesn't either.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: He has put pressure on the Congress - and I don't believe Mr. Ford would even deny this - to hold up on nonproliferation legislation until the Congress agreed for an $8 billion program for private industry to start producing enriched uranium.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And the last thing I wanna make is this.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: He talks about peace and I'm thankful for peace.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We were peaceful when Mr. Ford went into office.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But he and Mr. Kissinger and others tried to start a new Vietnam in Angola, and it was only the outcry of the American people and the Congress when their secret deal was discovered that prevented our involvement in that conflagration which was taking place there.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Well, here again, uh - the Panamanian question is one that's been confused by Mr. Ford.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Uh - he had directed his uh - diplomatic relation - uh - uh - representative to yield to the Panamanians full sovereignty over the Panama Canal Zone at the end of a certain period of time.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: When Mr. Reagan raised this uh - question in Florida uh - Mr. Ford not only disavowed his instructions, but he also even dropped, parenthetically, the use of the word "detente."
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I would never give up complete control or practical control of the Panama Canal Zone, but I would continue to negotiate with the Panamanians.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: When the original treaty was signed back in the early 1900s, when Theodore Roosevelt was president, Panama retained sovereignty over the Panama Canal Zone.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We retained control as though we had sovereignty.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I believe that we could share more fully responsibilities for the Panama Canal Zone with Panama.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I would be willing to continue to raise the payment for shipment of goods through the Panama Canal Zone.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I might even be willing to reduce to some degree our military emplacements in the Panama Canal Zane, but I would not relinquish practical control of the Panama Canal Zane any time in the foreseeable future.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The United States must and will maintain complete access to the Panama Canal.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The United States must maintain a defense capability of the Panama Canal.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And the United States will maintain our national security interest in the Panama Canal.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The negotiations far the Panama Canal started under President Johnson and have continued up to the present time.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I believe those negotiations should continue.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But there are certain guidelines that must be followed, and I've just defined them.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Let me take just a minute to comment on something that Governor Carter said.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: On non - nu- oh - uh - nonproliferation, in May of l975, I called for a conference of uh - nuclear suppliers.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: That conference has met six times.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In May of this year, Governor Carter took the first initiative, approximately twelve months after I had taken my initiative a year ago.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The White House did not uh - prevent the release of that report.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: On July twelfth of this year, we gave full permission for the release of that report.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I was very disappointed in the fact that the uh - GAO released that report because I think it interjected political partisan politics at the present time.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But let me comment on the report.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Somebody who sits in Washington, D.C., eighteen months after the Mayaguez incident, can be a very good grandstand quarterback.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And let me make another observation.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: This morning, I got a call from the skipper of the Mayaguez.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: He was furious because he told me that it was the action of me, President Ford, that saved the lives of the crew of the Mayaguez.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And I can assure you that if we had not taken the strong and forceful action that we did, we would have been uh - criticized very, very uh - severely for sitting back and not moving.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We did the right thing.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It seems to me that those who sit in Washington eighteen months after the incident are not the best judges of the decision-making process that had to be made by the National Security Council and by myself at the time the incident was developing in the Pacific.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Let me assure you that we made every possible overture to the People's Republic of China and through them to the Cambodian Government.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We made uh - diplomatic uh - protests to the Cambodian government through the United Nations.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Every possible diplomatic means was utilized.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But at the same time, I had a responsibility, and so did the National Security Coun- Council, to meet the problem at hand.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And we handled it responsibly and I think Captain Miller's testimony to that effect is the best evidence.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Well, I'm reluctant to uh comment on the recent report - I haven't read it.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think the American people have only one - uh requirement - that the facts about Mayaguez be given to them accurately and completely.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Mr. Ford has been there for eighteen months.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: He had the facts that were released today immediately after the Mayaguez incident.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I understand that the report today is accurate.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Mr. Ford has said, I believe, that it was accurate, and that the White House made no attempt to block the issuing of that report.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I don't know if that's exactly accurate or not.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I understand that both the - the uh - Department of State and the Defense Department have approved the accuracy of today's report, or yesterday's report, and also the National Security Agency.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I don't know what was right, or what was wrong, or what was done.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The only thing I believe is that whatever the - the knowledge was that Mr. Ford had should have been given to the American people eighteen months ago, immediately after the Mayaguez uh - incident occurred.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is uh - what the American people want.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: When something happens that endangers our security, or when something happens that threatens our stature in the world, or when American people are endangered by the actions of a foreign country, uh - just forty uh sailors on the Mayaguez, we obviously have to move aggressively and quickly to rescue them.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But then after the immediate action is taken, I believe the president has an obligation to tell the American people the truth and not wait eighteen months later for the report to be issued.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I believe that the boycott of American businesses by the Arab countries because those businesses trade with Israel or because they have American Jews who are owners or directors in the company is an absolute disgrace.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is the first time that I've - remember in the history of our country when we've let a foreign country circumvent or change our Bill of Rights.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I'll do everything I can as president to stop the boycott of American businesses by the Arab countries.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It's not a matter of diplomacy or trade with me.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It's a matter of morality.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I don't believe that Arab countries will pursue it when we have a strong president who will protect the integrity of our country, the commitment of our Constitution and Bill of Rights and protect people in this country who happen to be Jews.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I think it's a disgrace that so far Mr. Ford's administration has blocked the passage of legislation that would've revealed by law every instance of the boycott and it would've prevented the boycott from continuing.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Again Governor Carter is inaccurate.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The Arab boycott action was first taken in 1952.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And in November of 1975 I was the first president to order the executive branch to take action, affirmative action, through the Department of Commerce and other cabinet departments, to make certain that no American businessman or business organization should discriminate against Jews because of an Arab boycott.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And I might add that uh - my administration - and I'm very proud of it - is the first administration that has taken an antitrust action against companies in this country that have allegedly cooperated with the Arab boycott.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Just on Monday of this week I signed a tax bill that included an amendment that would prevent companies in the United States from taking a tax deduction if they have in any way whatsoever cooperated with the Arab boycott.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And last week when we were trying to get the Export Administration Act through the Congress - necessary legislation - my administration went to Capitol Hill and tried to convince the House and the Senate that we should have an amendment on that legislation which would take strong and effective action against those who uh - participate or cooperate with the Arab uh boycott.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Because the Congress failed to act, I am going to announce tomorrow that the Department of Commerce will disclose those companies that have uh - participated in the Arab boycott.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: This is something that we can do; the Congress failed to do it, and we intend to do it.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Let me restate uh - our policy.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: As long as Vietnam, North Vietnam, does not give us a full and complete accounting of our missing in action, I will never uh - go along with the admission of Vietnam to the United Nations.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: If they do give us a bona fide, complete uh - accounting of the eight hundred MIA's, then I believe that the United States should begin negotiations for the uh - admission of Vietnam to the United Nations.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: One of the uh - most embarrassing uh - failures of the Ford administration, and one that touches specifically on human rights, is his refusal to appoint a presidential commission to go to Vietnam, to go to Laos, to go to Cambodia and try to trade for the release of information about those who are missing in action in those wars.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is what the families of MIAs want.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: So far, Mr. Ford has not done it.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've had several fragmentary efforts by members of the Congress and by - by private citizens.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Several months ago the Vietnam government said, "We are ready to sit down and negotiate for release of information on MIAs.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: So far, Mr. Ford has not responded.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I would never normalize relationships with Vietnam, nor permit them to join the United Nations until they've taken this action.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We need to have an active and aggressive action on the part of the president, the leader of his country, to seek out every possible way to get that information which has kept the MIA families in despair and doubt, and Mr. Ford has just not done it.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The purpose of this debate and the outcome of the election will determine three basic things: Leadership, upholding the principles of our country, and proper priorities and commitments for the future.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This election will also determine what kind of world we leave our children.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Will it be a nightmare world threatened with the proliferation of atomic bombs, not just in five major countries but dozens of smaller countries that have been permitted to develop atomic weapons because of a failure of our top leadership to stop proliferation?
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Will we have a world of hunger and - and hatred, and will we be living in an armed camp stripped of our friendship and allies hiding behind a tight defense that's been drawn in around us because we are fearful of the outside world?
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Will we have a government of secrecy that excludes the American people from participation in making basic decisions and therefore covers up mistakes and makes it possible for our government - our government - to depart from the principles of our Constitution and Bill of Rights?
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Or will we have a world of peace with the threat of atomic weapons eliminated, with full trade, with our people at work, inflation controlled, openness in government, our people proud once again, Congress, citizens, president, secretary of state working in harmony and unity toward a common future?
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Or world where people have enough to eat and a world where we care about those who don't?
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Can we become a breadbasket of the world instead of the arms merchant of the world?
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I believe we can and we ought to.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Now we've been hurt in recent years in this country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In the aftermath of Vietnam, Cambodia, Chile, Pakistan, Angola, Watergate, CIA, we've been hurt.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Our people feel that we've lost something precious.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I wanna see our nation - return to a posture and an image and a standard to make us proud once again.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Why can't we have that once again?
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We ought to be a beacon for nations who search for peace and who search for freedom, who search for individual liberty, who search for basic human rights.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We can be once again.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We'll never have that world leadership until we are strong at home, and we can have that strength if we return to the basic principles.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It ought not to be a strength of bombast and threats.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It ought to be a quiet strength based on the integrity of our people, the vision of the Constitution, an in- innate strong will and purpose that God's given us in the greatest nation on earth - the United States.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: As we have seen tonight, foreign policy and defense policy are difficult and complex issues.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We can debate methods, we can debate one decision or another, but there are two uh things which cannot be debated - experience and results.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In the last two years, I have made policy decisions involving - long-range difficulties and policies and made day-to-day judgments not only as president of the United States but as the leader of the free world What is the result of that leadership?
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Thank you, and good night.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I can't think of a more important time for us to talk about the future of the country.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, we are at a defining moment in our history.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Our nation is involved in two wars, and we are going through the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And although we've heard a lot about Wall Street, those of you on Main Street I think have been struggling for a while, and you recognize that this could have an impact on all sectors of the economy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And you're wondering, how's it going to affect me?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: How's it going to affect my house?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: How's it going to affect my retirement savings or my ability to send my children to college?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So we have to move swiftly, and we have to move wisely.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I've put forward a series of proposals that make sure that we protect taxpayers as we engage in this important rescue effort.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number one, we've got to make sure that we've got oversight over this whole process; $700 billion, potentially, is a lot of money.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number two, we've got to make sure that taxpayers, when they are putting their money at risk, have the possibility of getting that money back and gains, if the market -- and when the market returns.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, number four, we've got to make sure that we're helping homeowners, because the root problem here has to do with the foreclosures that are taking place all across the country.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, we also have to recognize that this is a final verdict on eight years of failed economic policies promoted by George Bush, supported by Senator McCain, a theory that basically says that we can shred regulations and consumer protections and give more and more to the most, and somehow prosperity will trickle down.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I do have a sad note tonight.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Kennedy is in the hospital.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He's a dear and beloved friend to all of us.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Our thoughts and prayers go out to the lion of the Senate.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I also want to thank the University of Mississippi for hosting us tonight.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And, Jim, I -- I've been not feeling too great about a lot of things lately.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So have a lot of Americans who are facing challenges.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But I'm feeling a little better tonight, and I'll tell you why.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Because as we're here tonight in this debate, we are seeing, for the first time in a long time, Republicans and Democrats together, sitting down, trying to work out a solution to this fiscal crisis that we're in.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And have no doubt about the magnitude of this crisis.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we're not talking about failure of institutions on Wall Street.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We're talking about failures on Main Street, and people who will lose their jobs, and their credits, and their homes, if we don't fix the greatest fiscal crisis, probably in -- certainly in our time, and I've been around a little while.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But the point is -- the point is, we have finally seen Republicans and Democrats sitting down and negotiating together and coming up with a package.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: This package has transparency in it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It has to have accountability and oversight.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It has to have options for loans to failing businesses, rather than the government taking over those loans.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We have to -- it has to have a package with a number of other essential elements to it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And, yes, I went back to Washington, and I met with my Republicans in the House of Representatives.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And they weren't part of the negotiations, and I understand that.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And it was the House Republicans that decided that they would be part of the solution to this problem.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But I want to emphasize one point to all Americans tonight.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: This isn't the beginning of the end of this crisis.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: This is the end of the beginning, if we come out with a package that will keep these institutions stable.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we've got a lot of work to do.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we've got to create jobs.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And one of the areas, of course, is to eliminate our dependence on foreign oil.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We haven't seen the language yet.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I do think that there's constructive work being done out there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So, for the viewers who are watching, I am optimistic about the capacity of us to come together with a plan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The question, I think, that we have to ask ourselves is, how did we get into this situation in the first place?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Two years ago, I warned that, because of the subprime lending mess, because of the lax regulation, that we were potentially going to have a problem and tried to stop some of the abuses in mortgages that were taking place at the time.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Last year, I wrote to the secretary of the Treasury to make sure that he understood the magnitude of this problem and to call on him to bring all the stakeholders together to try to deal with it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So -- so the question, I think, that we've got to ask ourselves is, yes, we've got to solve this problem short term.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we are going to have to intervene; there's no doubt about that.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But we're also going to have to look at, how is it that we shredded so many regulations?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We did not set up a 21st-century regulatory framework to deal with these problems.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that in part has to do with an economic philosophy that says that regulation is always bad.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I -- I hope so.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But -- but let me -- let me point out, I also warned about Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and warned about corporate greed and excess, and CEO pay, and all that.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: A lot of us saw this train wreck coming.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But there's also the issue of responsibility.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You've mentioned President Dwight David Eisenhower.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: President Eisenhower, on the night before the Normandy invasion, went into his room, and he wrote out two letters.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: One of them was a letter congratulating the great members of the military and allies that had conducted and succeeded in the greatest invasion in history, still to this day, and forever.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And he wrote out another letter, and that was a letter of resignation from the United States Army for the failure of the landings at Normandy.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Somehow we've lost that accountability.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I've been heavily criticized because I called for the resignation of the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We've got to start also holding people accountable, and we've got to reward people who succeed.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But somehow in Washington today -- and I'm afraid on Wall Street -- greed is rewarded, excess is rewarded, and corruption -- or certainly failure to carry out our responsibility is rewarded.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: As president of the United States, people are going to be held accountable in my administration.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I promise you that that will happen.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, I think Senator McCain's absolutely right that we need more responsibility, but we need it not just when there's a crisis.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I mean, we've had years in which the reigning economic ideology has been what's good for Wall Street, but not what's good for Main Street.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And there are folks out there who've been struggling before this crisis took place.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's why it's so important, as we solve this short-term problem, that we look at some of the underlying issues that have led to wages and incomes for ordinary Americans to go down, the -- a health care system that is broken, energy policies that are not working, because, you know, 10 days ago, John said that the fundamentals of the economy are sound.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I do not think that they are.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, the -- John, 10 days ago, you said that the fundamentals of the economy are sound.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The -- and I just fundamentally disagree.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And unless we are holding ourselves accountable day in, day out, not just when there's a crisis for folks who have power and influence and can hire lobbyists, but for the nurse, the teacher, the police officer, who, frankly, at the end of each month, they've got a little financial crisis going on.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They're having to take out extra debt just to make their mortgage payments.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We haven't been paying attention to them.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And if you look at our tax policies, it's a classic example.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: No, I -- look, we've got to fix the system.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We've got fundamental problems in the system.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And Main Street is paying a penalty for the excesses and greed in Washington, D.C., and in the Wall Street.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So there's no doubt that we have a long way to go.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And, obviously, stricter interpretation and consolidation of the various regulatory agencies that weren't doing their job, that has brought on this crisis.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But I have a fundamental belief in the goodness and strength of the American worker.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And the American worker is the most productive, the most innovative.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: America is still the greatest producer, exporter and importer.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But we've got to get through these times, but I have a fundamental belief in the United States of America.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, the first thing we have to do is get spending under control in Washington.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It's completely out of control.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We Republicans came to power to change government, and government changed us.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And the -- the worst symptom on this disease is what my friend, Tom Coburn, calls earmarking as a gateway drug, because it's a gateway.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It's a gateway to out-of-control spending and corruption.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we have former members of Congress now residing in federal prison because of the evils of this earmarking and pork-barrel spending.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You know, we spent $3 million to study the DNA of bears in Montana.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I don't know if that was a criminal issue or a paternal issue, but the fact is that it was $3 million of our taxpayers' money.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And it has got to be brought under control.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: As president of the United States, I want to assure you, I've got a pen.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: This one's kind of old.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I will make them famous.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You will know their names.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, Senator Obama, you wanted to know one of the differences.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He has asked for $932 million of earmark pork-barrel spending, nearly a million dollars for every day that he's been in the United States Senate.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I suggest that people go up on the Web site of Citizens Against Government Waste, and they'll look at those projects.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That kind of thing is not the way to rein in runaway spending in Washington, D.C. That's one of the fundamental differences that Senator Obama and I have.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, Senator McCain is absolutely right that the earmarks process has been abused, which is why I suspended any requests for my home state, whether it was for senior centers or what have you, until we cleaned it up.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And he's also right that oftentimes lobbyists and special interests are the ones that are introducing these kinds of requests, although that wasn't the case with me.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But let's be clear: Earmarks account for $18 billion in last year's budget.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Senator McCain is proposing -- and this is a fundamental difference between us -- $300 billion in tax cuts to some of the wealthiest corporations and individuals in the country, $300 billion.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, $18 billion is important; $300 billion is really important.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And in his tax plan, you would have CEOs of Fortune 500 companies getting an average of $700,000 in reduced taxes, while leaving 100 million Americans out.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So my attitude is, we've got to grow the economy from the bottom up.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What I've called for is a tax cut for 95 percent of working families, 95 percent.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that means that the ordinary American out there who's collecting a paycheck every day, they've got a little extra money to be able to buy a computer for their kid, to fill up on this gas that is killing them.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And over time, that, I think, is going to be a better recipe for economic growth than the -- the policies of President Bush that John McCain wants to -- wants to follow.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, again, I don't mean to go back and forth, but he...
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama suspended those requests for pork-barrel projects after he was running for president of the United States.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He didn't happen to see that light during the first three years as a member of the United States Senate, $932 million in requests.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But the point is that -- you see, I hear this all the time.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Do you know that it's tripled in the last five years?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That's why we have, as I said, people under federal indictment and charges.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It's a system that's got to be cleaned up.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have fought against it my career.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have fought against it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I was called the sheriff, by the -- one of the senior members of the Appropriations Committee.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I didn't win Miss Congeniality in the United States Senate.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, Senator Obama didn't mention that, along with his tax cuts, he is also proposing some $800 billion in new spending on new programs.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, that's a fundamental difference between myself and Senator Obama.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I want to cut spending.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I want to keep taxes low.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I -- I don't know where John is getting his figures.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What I do is I close corporate loopholes, stop providing tax cuts to corporations that are shipping jobs overseas so that we're giving tax breaks to companies that are investing here in the United States.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I make sure that we have a health care system that allows for everyone to have basic coverage.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I think those are pretty important priorities.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I pay for every dime of it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But let's go back to the original point.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: John, nobody is denying that $18 billion is important.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, absolutely, we need earmark reform.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And when I'm president, I will go line by line to make sure that we are not spending money unwisely.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But the fact is that eliminating earmarks alone is not a recipe for how we're going to get the middle class back on track.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And when you look at your tax policies that are directed primarily at those who are doing well, and you are neglecting people who are really struggling right now, I think that is a continuation of the last eight years, and we can't afford another four.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well -- well, let me give you an example of what Senator Obama finds objectionable, the business tax.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Right now, in the United States of America, business pays the second-highest business taxes in the world, 35 percent.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, if you're a business person, and you can locate any place in the world, then, obviously, if you go to the country where it's 11 percent tax versus 35 percent, you're going to be able to create jobs, increase your business, make more investment, et cetera.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I want to cut that business tax.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I want to cut it so that businesses will remain in -- in the United States of America and create jobs.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But, again, I want to return.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It's a lot more than $18 billion in pork-barrel spending.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I can tell you, it's rife.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The United States Senate will take up a continuing resolution tomorrow or the next day, sometime next week, with 2,000 -- 2,000 -- look at them, my friends.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And Senator Obama is a recent convert, after requesting $932 million worth of pork-barrel spending projects.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So the point is, I want people to have tax cuts.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I want every family to have a $5,000 refundable tax credit so they can go out and purchase their own health care.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I want to double the dividend from $3,500 to $7,000 for every dependent child in America.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I know that the worst thing we could possibly do is to raise taxes on anybody, and a lot of people might be interested in Senator Obama's definition of "rich."
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, let me just make a couple of points.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: My definition -- here's what I can tell the American people: 95 percent of you will get a tax cut.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And if you make less than $250,000, less than a quarter-million dollars a year, then you will not see one dime's worth of tax increase.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, John mentioned the fact that business taxes on paper are high in this country, and he's absolutely right.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Here's the problem: There are so many loopholes that have been written into the tax code, oftentimes with support of Senator McCain, that we actually see our businesses pay effectively one of the lowest tax rates in the world.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And what that means, then, is that there are people out there who are working every day, who are not getting a tax cut, and you want to give them more.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's not like you want to close the loopholes.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You just want to add an additional tax cut over the loopholes.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Just one last point I want to make, since Senator McCain talked about providing a $5,000 health credit.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, what he doesn't tell you is that he intends to, for the first time in history, tax health benefits.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So you may end up getting a $5,000 tax credit.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Here's the only problem: Your employer now has to pay taxes on the health care that you're getting from your employer.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And if you end up losing your health care from your employer, you've got to go out on the open market and try to buy it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It is not a good deal for the American people.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But it's an example of this notion that the market can always solve everything and that the less regulation we have, the better off we're going to be.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, you know, let me just...
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We had an energy bill before the United States Senate.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It was festooned with Christmas tree ornaments.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It had all kinds of breaks for the oil companies, I mean, billions of dollars worth.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I voted against it; Senator Obama voted for it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: John, you want to give oil companies another $4 billion.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You've got to look at our record.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You've got to look at our records.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Who fought against wasteful and earmark spending?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Who has been the person who has tried to keep spending under control?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Who's the person who has believed that the best thing for America is -- is to have a tax system that is fundamentally fair?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I've fought to simplify it, and I have proposals to simplify it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Let's give every American a choice: two tax brackets, generous dividends, and, two -- and let Americans choose whether they want the -- the existing tax code or they want a new tax code.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And so, again, look at the record, particularly the energy bill.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But, again, Senator Obama has shifted on a number of occasions.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He has voted in the United States Senate to increase taxes on people who make as low as $42,000 a year.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And that's just a fact.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Again, you can look it up.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Look, it's just not true.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And if we want to talk about oil company profits, under your tax plan, John -- this is undeniable -- oil companies would get an additional $4 billion in tax breaks.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, look, we all would love to lower taxes on everybody.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But here's the problem: If we are giving them to oil companies, then that means that there are those who are not going to be getting them.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: With all due respect, you already gave them to the oil companies.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: No, but, John, the fact of the matter is, is that I was opposed to those tax breaks, tried to strip them out.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got an energy bill on the Senate floor right now that contains some good stuff, some stuff you want, including drilling off-shore, but you're opposed to it because it would strip away those tax breaks that have gone to oil companies.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, there are a range of things that are probably going to have to be delayed.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We don't yet know what our tax revenues are going to be.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The economy is slowing down, so it's hard to anticipate right now what the budget is going to look like next year.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But there's no doubt that we're not going to be able to do everything that I think needs to be done.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There are some things that I think have to be done.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We have to have energy independence, so I've put forward a plan to make sure that, in 10 years' time, we have freed ourselves from dependence on Middle Eastern oil by increasing production at home, but most importantly by starting to invest in alternative energy, solar, wind, biodiesel, making sure that we're developing the fuel-efficient cars of the future right here in the United States, in Ohio and Michigan, instead of Japan and South Korea.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We have to fix our health care system, which is putting an enormous burden on families.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Just -- a report just came out that the average deductible went up 30 percent on American families.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They are getting crushed, and many of them are going bankrupt as a consequence of health care.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I'm meeting folks all over the country.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We have to do that now, because it will actually make our businesses and our families better off.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The third thing we have to do is we've got to make sure that we're competing in education.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got to invest in science and technology.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: China had a space launch and a space walk.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I also think that we're going to have to rebuild our infrastructure, which is falling behind, our roads, our bridges, but also broadband lines that reach into rural communities.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Also, making sure that we have a new electricity grid to get the alternative energy to population centers that are using them.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We can't shortchange those things.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got to eliminate programs that don't work, and we've got to make sure that the programs that we do have are more efficient and cost less.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Look, we, no matter what, we've got to cut spending.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We have -- as I said, we've let government get completely out of control.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama has the most liberal voting record in the United States Senate.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It's hard to reach across the aisle from that far to the left.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The point -- the point is -- the point is, we need to examine every agency of government.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: First of all, by the way, I'd eliminate ethanol subsidies.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I think that we have to return -- particularly in defense spending, which is the largest part of our appropriations -- we have to do away with cost-plus contracts.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We now have defense systems that the costs are completely out of control.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We tried to build a little ship called the Littoral Combat Ship that was supposed to cost $140 million, ended up costing $400 million, and we still haven't done it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So we need to have fixed-cost contracts.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We need very badly to understand that defense spending is very important and vital, particularly in the new challenges we face in the world, but we have to get a lot of the cost overruns under control.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I know how to do that.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I saved the taxpayers $6.8 billion by fighting a contract that was negotiated between Boeing and DOD that was completely wrong.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we fixed it and we killed it and the people ended up in federal prison so I know how to do this because I've been involved these issues for many, many years.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But I think that we have to examine every agency of government and find out those that are doing their job and keep them and find out those that aren't and eliminate them and we'll have to scrub every agency of government.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: As I said before, Jim, there are going to be things that end up having to be ...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, look, I want to make sure that we are investing in energy in order to free ourselves from the dependence on foreign oil.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That is a big project.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That is a multi-year project.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Not willing to give up the need to do it but there may be individual components that we can't do.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But John is right we have to make cuts.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We right now give $15 billion every year as subsidies to private insurers under the Medicare system.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Doesn't work any better through the private insurers.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They just skim off $15 billion.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That was a give away and part of the reason is because lobbyists are able to shape how Medicare works.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They did it on the Medicaid prescription drug bill and we have to change the culture.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Tom -- or John mentioned me being wildly liberal.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Mostly that's just me opposing George Bush's wrong headed policies since I've been in Congress but I think it is that it is also important to recognize I worked with Tom Coburn, the most conservative, one of the most conservative Republicans who John already mentioned to set up what we call a Google for government saying we'll list every dollar of federal spending to make sure that the taxpayer can take a look and see who, in fact, is promoting some of these spending projects that John's been railing about.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: How about a spending freeze on everything but defense, veteran affairs and entitlement programs.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I think we ought to seriously consider with the exceptions of caring for our veterans national defense and several other vital issues.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The problem with a spending freeze is you're using a hatchet where you need a scalpel.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There are some programs that are very important that are under funded.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I went to increase early childhood education and the notion that we should freeze that when there may be, for example, this Medicare subsidy, I think, doesn't make sense.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Let me tell you another place to look for some savings.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We are currently spending $10 billion a month in Iraq when they have a $79 billion surplus.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It seems to me that if we're going to be strong at home as well as strong abroad, that we have to look at bringing that war to a close.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Some of that money ends up in the hands of terrorist organizations.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We have to have wind, tide, solar, natural gas, flex fuel cars and all that but we also have to have offshore drilling and we also have to have nuclear power.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama opposes both storing and reprocessing of spent nuclear fuel.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You can't get there from here and the fact is that we can create 700,000 jobs by building constructing 45 new nuclear power plants by the year 2030.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Nuclear power is not only important as far as eliminating our dependence on foreign oil but it's also responsibility as far as climate change is concerned.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: An issue I have been involved in for many, many years and I'm proud of the work of the work that I've done there along with Senator Clinton.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: There's no doubt itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s gonna affect our budgets.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There is no doubt about it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Not only -- Even if we get all $700 billion back, let's assume the markets recover, we're holding assets long enough that eventually taxpayers get it back and that happened during the Great Depression when Roosevelt purchased a whole bunch of homes, over time, home values went back up and in fact government made a profit.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If we're lucky and we do it right, that could potentially happen but in the short term there's an outlay and we may not see that money for a while.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And because of the economy's slowing down, I think we can also expect less tax revenue so there's no doubt that as president I'm going to have to make some tough decision.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The only point I want to make is this, that in order to make those tough decisions we have to know what our values are and who we're fighting for and what our priorities are and if we are spending $300 billion on tax cuts for people who don't need them and weren't even asking for them, and we are leaving out health care which is crushing on people all across the country, then I think we have made a bad decision and I want to make sure we're not shortchanging our long term priorities.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, I want to make sure we're not handing the health care system over to the federal government which is basically what would ultimately happen with Senator Obama's health care plan.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I want the families to make decisions between themselves and their doctors.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We have to obviously cut spending.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have fought to cut spending.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama has $800 billion in new spending programs.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I would suggest he start by canceling some of those new spending program that he has.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We can't I think adjust spending around to take care of the very much needed programs, including taking care of our veterans but I also want to say again a healthy economy with low taxes would not raising anyone's taxes is probably the best recipe for eventually having our economy recover.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And spending restraint has got to be a vital part of that.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And the reason, one of the major reasons why we're in the difficulties we are in today is because spending got out of control.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We owe China $500 billion.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And spending, I know, can be brought under control because I have fought against excessive spending my entire career.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I got plans to reduce and eliminate unnecessary and wasteful spending and if there's anybody here who thinks there aren't agencies of government where spending can be cut and their budgets slashed they have not spent a lot of time in Washington.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I just want to make this point, Jim.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: John, it's been your president who you said you agreed with 90 percent of the time who presided over this increase in spending.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: This orgy of spending and enormous deficits you voted for almost all of his budgets.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So to stand here and after eight years and say that you're going to lead on controlling spending and, you know, balancing our tax cuts so that they help middle class families when over the last eight years that hasn't happened I think just is, you know, kind of hard to swallow.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's well-known that I have not been elected Miss Congeniality in the United States Senate nor with the administration.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have opposed the president on spending, on climate change, on torture of prisoner, on - on Guantanamo Bay.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: On a -- on the way that the Iraq War was conducted.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have a long record and the American people know me very well and that is independent and a maverick of the Senate and I'm happy to say that I've got a partner that's a good maverick along with me now.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I think the lessons of Iraq are very clear that you cannot have a failed strategy that will then cause you to nearly lose a conflict.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Our initial military success, we went in to Baghdad and everybody celebrated.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And then the war was very badly mishandled.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I went to Iraq in 2003 and came back and said, we've got to change this strategy.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: This strategy requires additional troops, it requires a fundamental change in strategy and I fought for it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And finally, we came up with a great general and a strategy that has succeeded.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we are winning in Iraq.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we will come home with victory and with honor.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And that withdrawal is the result of every counterinsurgency that succeeds.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I want to tell you that now that we will succeed and our troops will come home, and not in defeat, that we will see a stable ally in the region and a fledgling democracy.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The consequences of defeat would have been increased Iranian influence.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It would have been increase in sectarian violence.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It would have been a wider war, which the United States of America might have had to come back.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So there was a lot at stake there.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And thanks to this great general, David Petraeus, and the troops who serve under him, they have succeeded.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we are winning in Iraq, and we will come home.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we will come home as we have when we have won other wars and not in defeat.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, this is an area where Senator McCain and I have a fundamental difference because I think the first question is whether we should have gone into the war in the first place.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now six years ago, I stood up and opposed this war at a time when it was politically risky to do so because I said that not only did we not know how much it was going to cost, what our exit strategy might be, how it would affect our relationships around the world, and whether our intelligence was sound, but also because we hadn't finished the job in Afghanistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We hadn't caught bin Laden.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We hadn't put al Qaeda to rest, and as a consequence, I thought that it was going to be a distraction.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now Senator McCain and President Bush had a very different judgment.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I wish I had been wrong for the sake of the country and they had been right, but that's not the case.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've spent over $600 billion so far, soon to be $1 trillion.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We have lost over 4,000 lives.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We have seen 30,000 wounded, and most importantly, from a strategic national security perspective, al Qaeda is resurgent, stronger now than at any time since 2001.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We took our eye off the ball.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And not to mention that we are still spending $10 billion a month, when they have a $79 billion surplus, at a time when we are in great distress here at home, and we just talked about the fact that our budget is way overstretched and we are borrowing money from overseas to try to finance just some of the basic functions of our government.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So I think the lesson to be drawn is that we should never hesitate to use military force, and I will not, as president, in order to keep the American people safe.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But we have to use our military wisely.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we did not use our military wisely in Iraq.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The next president of the United States is not going to have to address the issue as to whether we went into Iraq or not.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The next president of the United States is going to have to decide how we leave, when we leave, and what we leave behind.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That's the decision of the next president of the United States.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama said the surge could not work, said it would increase sectarian violence, said it was doomed to failure.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Recently on a television program, he said it exceed our wildest expectations.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But yet, after conceding that, he still says that he would oppose the surge if he had to decide that again today.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Incredibly, incredibly Senator Obama didn't go to Iraq for 900 days and never asked for a meeting with General Petraeus.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama is the chairperson of a committee that oversights NATO that's in Afghanistan.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: To this day, he has never had a hearing.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He raised a whole bunch of them.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Look, I'm very proud of my vice presidential selection, Joe Biden, who is the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and as he explains, and as John well knows, the issues of Afghanistan, the issues of Iraq, critical issues like that, don't go through my subcommittee because they're done as a committee as a whole.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But that's Senate inside baseball.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But let's get back to the core issue here.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Senator McCain is absolutely right that the violence has been reduced as a consequence of the extraordinary sacrifice of our troops and our military families.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They have done a brilliant job, and General Petraeus has done a brilliant job.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But understand, that was a tactic designed to contain the damage of the previous four years of mismanagement of this war.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so John likes -- John, you like to pretend like the war started in 2007.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You talk about the surge.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The war started in 2003, and at the time when the war started, you said it was going to be quick and easy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You said we knew where the weapons of mass destruction were.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You said that we were going to be greeted as liberators.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You said that there was no history of violence between Shia and Sunni.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so my question is...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: ... of judgment, of whether or not -- of whether or not -- if the question is who is best-equipped as the next president to make good decisions about how we use our military, how we make sure that we are prepared and ready for the next conflict, then I think we can take a look at our judgment.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I'm afraid Senator Obama doesn't understand the difference between a tactic and a strategy.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But the important -- I'd like to tell you, two Fourths of July ago I was in Baghdad.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: General Petraeus invited Senator Lindsey Graham and me to attend a ceremony where 688 brave young Americans, whose enlistment had expired, were reenlisting to stay and fight for Iraqi freedom and American freedom.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I was honored to be there.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I was honored to speak to those troops.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And you know, afterwards, we spent a lot of time with them.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And you know what they said to us?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: They said, let us win.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: They said, let us win.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We don't want our kids coming back here.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And this strategy, and this general, they are winning.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama refuses to acknowledge that we are winning in Iraq.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: They just passed an electoral...
Speaker: John McCain

Text: An election law just in the last few days.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: There is social, economic progress, and a strategy, a strategy of going into an area, clearing and holding, and the people of the country then become allied with you.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: They inform on the bad guys.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And peace comes to the country, and prosperity.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That's what's happening in Iraq, and it wasn't a tactic.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Jim, Jim, this is a big...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that same strategy will be employed in Afghanistan by this great general.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And Senator Obama, who after promising not to vote to cut off funds for the troops, did the incredible thing of voting to cut off the funds for the troops in Iraq and Afghanistan.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Jim, there are a whole bunch of things we have got to answer.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: First of all, let's talk about this troop funding issue because John always brings this up.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I opposed funding a mission that had no timetable, and was open- ended, giving a blank check to George Bush.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We had a difference on the timetable.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We didn't have a difference on whether or not we were going to be funding troops.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We had a legitimate difference, and I absolutely understand the difference between tactics and strategy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the strategic question that the president has to ask is not whether or not we are employing a particular approach in the country once we have made the decision to be there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The question is, was this wise?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We have seen Afghanistan worsen, deteriorate.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We need more troops there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We need more resources there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Senator McCain, in the rush to go into Iraq, said, you know what?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've been successful in Afghanistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There is nobody who can pose a threat to us there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: This is a time when bin Laden was still out, and now they've reconstituted themselves.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Secretary of Defense Robert Gates himself acknowledges the war on terrorism started in Afghanistan and it needs to end there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But we can't do it if we are not willing to give Iraq back its country.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, what I've said is we should end this war responsibly.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We should do it in phases.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But in 16 months we should be able to reduce our combat troops, put -- provide some relief to military families and our troops and bolster our efforts in Afghanistan so that we can capture and kill bin Laden and crush al Qaeda.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And right now, the commanders in Afghanistan, as well as Admiral Mullen, have acknowledged that we don't have enough troops to deal with Afghanistan because we still have more troops in Iraq than we did before the surge.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Admiral Mullen suggests that Senator Obama's plan is dangerous for America.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: What he said was a precipitous...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's what Admiral Mullen said.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: ... withdrawal would be dangerous.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: He did not say that.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And also General Petraeus said the same thing.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Osama bin Laden and General Petraeus have one thing in common that I know of, they both said that Iraq is the central battleground.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now General Petraeus has praised the successes, but he said those successes are fragile and if we set a specific date for withdrawal -- and by the way, Senator Obama's original plan, they would have been out last spring before the surge ever had a chance to succeed.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I'm -- I'm -- understand why Senator Obama was surprised and said that the surge succeeded beyond his wildest expectations.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It didn't exceed beyond mine, because I know that that's a strategy that has worked and can succeed.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But if we snatch defeat from the jaws of victory and adopt Senator Obama's plan, then we will have a wider war and it will make things more complicated throughout the region, including in Afghanistan.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Yes, I think we need more troops.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I've been saying that for over a year now.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I think that we have to do it as quickly as possible, because it's been acknowledged by the commanders on the ground the situation is getting worse, not better.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We had the highest fatalities among U.S. troops this past year than at any time since 2002.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we are seeing a major offensive taking place -- Al Qaida and Taliban crossing the border and attacking our troops in a brazen fashion.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we cannot separate Afghanistan from Iraq, because what our commanders have said is we don't have the troops right now to deal with Afghanistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So I would send two to three additional brigades to Afghanistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, keep in mind that we have four times the number of troops in Iraq, where nobody had anything to do with 9/11 before we went in, where, in fact, there was no Al Qaida before we went in, but we have four times more troops there than we do in Afghanistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that is a strategic mistake, because every intelligence agency will acknowledge that Al Qaida is the greatest threat against the United States and that Secretary of Defense Gates acknowledged the central front -- that the place where we have to deal with these folks is going to be in Afghanistan and in Pakistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So here's what we have to do comprehensively, though.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's not just more troops.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We have to press the Afghan government to make certain that they are actually working for their people.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I've said this to President Karzai.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number two, we've got to deal with a growing poppy trade that has exploded over the last several years.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number three, we've got to deal with Pakistan, because Al Qaida and the Taliban have safe havens in Pakistan, across the border in the northwest regions, and although, you know, under George Bush, with the support of Senator McCain, we've been giving them $10 billion over the last seven years, they have not done what needs to be done to get rid of those safe havens.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And until we do, Americans here at home are not going to be safe.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: First of all, I won't repeat the mistake that I regret enormously, and that is, after we were able to help the Afghan freedom fighters and drive the Russians out of Afghanistan, we basically washed our hands of the region.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And the result over time was the Taliban, Al Qaida, and a lot of the difficulties we are facing today.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So we can't ignore those lessons of history.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, on this issue of aiding Pakistan, if you're going to aim a gun at somebody, George Shultz, our great secretary of state, told me once, you'd better be prepared to pull the trigger.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I'm not prepared at this time to cut off aid to Pakistan.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So I'm not prepared to threaten it, as Senator Obama apparently wants to do, as he has said that he would announce military strikes into Pakistan.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We've got to get the support of the people of -- of Pakistan.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He said that he would launch military strikes into Pakistan.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, you don't do that.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You don't say that out loud.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: If you have to do things, you have to do things, and you work with the Pakistani government.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, the new president of Pakistan, Kardari (sic), has got his hands full.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And this area on the border has not been governed since the days of Alexander the Great.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I can see how tough that terrain is.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It's ruled by a handful of tribes.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And, yes, Senator Obama calls for more troops, but what he doesn't understand, it's got to be a new strategy, the same strategy that he condemned in Iraq.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It's going to have to be employed in Afghanistan.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we're going to have to help the Pakistanis go into these areas and obtain the allegiance of the people.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And it's going to be tough.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: They've intermarried with Al Qaida and the Taliban.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And it's going to be tough.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And the Pakistanis are going to have to understand that that bombing in the Marriott Hotel in Islamabad was a signal from the terrorists that they don't want that government to cooperate with us in combating the Taliban and jihadist elements.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So we've got a lot of work to do in Afghanistan.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But I'm confident, now that General Petraeus is in the new position of command, that we will employ a strategy which not only means additional troops -- and, by the way, there have been 20,000 additional troops, from 32,000 to 53,000, and there needs to be more.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So it's not just the addition of troops that matters.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It's a strategy that will succeed.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And Pakistan is a very important element in this.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I know how to work with them.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I guarantee you I would not publicly state that I'm going to attack them.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Nobody talked about attacking Pakistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And if John wants to disagree with this, he can let me know, that, if the United States has Al Qaida, bin Laden, top-level lieutenants in our sights, and Pakistan is unable or unwilling to act, then we should take them out.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, I think that's the right strategy; I think that's the right policy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, John, I -- you're absolutely right that presidents have to be prudent in what they say.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But, you know, coming from you, who, you know, in the past has threatened extinction for North Korea and, you know, sung songs about bombing Iran, I don't know, you know, how credible that is.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I think this is the right strategy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, Senator McCain is also right that it's difficult.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: This is not an easy situation.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You've got cross-border attacks against U.S. troops.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we've got a choice.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We could allow our troops to just be on the defensive and absorb those blows again and again and again, if Pakistan is unwilling to cooperate, or we have to start making some decisions.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the problem, John, with the strategy that's been pursued was that, for 10 years, we coddled Musharraf, we alienated the Pakistani population, because we were anti-democratic.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We had a 20th-century mindset that basically said, "Well, you know, he may be a dictator, but he's our dictator."
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And as a consequence, we lost legitimacy in Pakistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And in the meantime, they weren't going after Al Qaida, and they are more powerful now than at any time since we began the war in Afghanistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's going to change when I'm president of the United States.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I -- I don't think that Senator Obama understands that there was a failed state in Pakistan when Musharraf came to power.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Everybody who was around then, and had been there, and knew about it knew that it was a failed state.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But let me tell you, you know, this business about bombing Iran and all that, let me tell you my record.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Back in 1983, when I was a brand-new United States congressman, the one -- the person I admired the most and still admire the most, Ronald Reagan, wanted to send Marines into Lebanon.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I saw that, and I saw the situation, and I stood up, and I voted against that, because I was afraid that they couldn't make peace in a place where 300 or 400 or several hundred Marines would make a difference.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Tragically, I was right: Nearly 300 Marines lost their lives in the bombing of the barracks.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And then we had Somalia -- then we had the first Gulf War.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I supported -- I supported that.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I supported us going into Bosnia, when a number of my own party and colleagues was against that operation in Bosnia.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That was the right thing to do, to stop genocide and to preserve what was necessary inside of Europe.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I supported what we did in Kosovo.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I supported it because ethnic cleansing and genocide was taking place there.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I have a record -- and Somalia, I opposed that we should turn -- turn the force in Somalia from a peacekeeping force into a peacemaking force, which they were not capable of.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So I have a record.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have a record of being involved in these national security issues, which involve the highest responsibility and the toughest decisions that any president can make, and that is to send our young men and women into harm's way.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I'll tell you, I had a town hall meeting in Wolfeboro, New Hampshire, and a woman stood up and she said, "Senator McCain, I want you to do me the honor of wearing a bracelet with my son's name on it."
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He was 22 years old and he was killed in combat outside of Baghdad, Matthew Stanley, before Christmas last year.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: This was last August, a year ago.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I said, "I will -- I will wear his bracelet with honor."
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And this was August, a year ago.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And then she said, "But, Senator McCain, I want you to do everything -- promise me one thing, that you'll do everything in your power to make sure that my son's death was not in vain."
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That means that that mission succeeds, just like those young people who re-enlisted in Baghdad, just like the mother I met at the airport the other day whose son was killed.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And they all say to me that we don't want defeat.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I know what thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s like when an army is defeated.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: A war that I was in, where we had an Army, that it wasn't through any fault of their own, but they were defeated.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I know how hard it is for that -- for an Army and a military to recover from that.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And it did and we will win this one and we won't come home in defeat and dishonor and probably have to go back if we fail.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Jim, let me just make a point.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I've got a bracelet, too, from Sergeant - from the mother of Sergeant Ryan David Jopeck (ph), given to me in green bay.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: She asked me, can you please make sure another mother is not going through what I'm going through.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: No U.S. soldier ever dies in vain because they're carrying out the missions of their commander in chief.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we honor all the service that they've provided.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Our troops have performed brilliantly.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The question is for the next president, are we making good judgments about how to keep America safe precisely because sending our military into battle is such an enormous step.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the point that I originally made is that we took our eye off Afghanistan, we took our eye off the folks who perpetrated 9/11, they are still sending out videotapes and Senator McCain, nobody is talking about defeat in Iraq, but I have to say we are having enormous problems in Afghanistan because of that decision.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And it is not true you have consistently been concerned about what happened in Afghanistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: At one point, while you were focused on Iraq, you said well, we can "muddle through" Afghanistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You don't muddle through the central front on terror and you don't muddle through going after bin Laden.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You don't muddle through stamping out the Taliban.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I think that is something we have to take seriously.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And when I'm president, I will.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You might think that with that kind of concern that Senator Obama would have gone to Afghanistan, particularly given his responsibilities as a subcommittee chairman.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: By the way, when I'm subcommittee chairman, we take up the issues under my subcommittee.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But the important thing is -- the important thing is I visited Afghanistan and I traveled to Waziristan and I traveled to these places and I know what our security requirements are.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I know what our needs are.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So the point is that we will prevail in Afghanistan, but we need the new strategy and we need it to succeed.
Speaker: John McCain
