Text: But the important thing is, if we suffer defeat in Iraq, which General Petraeus predicts we will, if we adopted Senator Obama's set date for withdrawal, then that will have a calamitous effect in Afghanistan and American national security interests in the region.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama doesn't seem to understand there is a connected between the two.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: A testimony to you, Jim.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: My reading of the threat from Iran is that if Iran acquires nuclear weapons, it is an existential threat to the State of Israel and it is a threat to other countries in the region because the other countries in the region will feel compelling requirement to acquire nuclear weapons as well.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now we cannot allow a second Holocaust.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Let's just make that very clear.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: What I have proposed for a long time, and I've had conversation with foreign leaders about forming a league of democracies, let's be clear and let's have some straight talk.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The Russians are preventing significant action in the United Nations Security Council.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have proposed a league of democracies, a group of people - a group of countries that share common interests, common values, common ideals, they also control a lot of the world's economic power.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We could impose significant meaningful, painful sanctions on the Iranians that I think could have a beneficial effect.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The Iranians have a lousy government, so therefore their economy is lousy, even though they have significant oil revenues.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So I am convinced that together, we can, with the French, with the British, with the Germans and other countries, democracies around the world, we can affect Iranian behavior.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But have no doubt, but have no doubt that the Iranians continue on the path to the acquisition of a nuclear weapon as we speak tonight.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And it is a threat not only in this region but around the world.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: What I'd also like to point out the Iranians are putting the most lethal IEDs into Iraq which are killing young Americans, there are special groups in Iran coming into Iraq and are being trained in Iran.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: There is the Republican Guard in Iran, which Senator Kyl had an amendment in order to declare them a sponsor of terror.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama said that would be provocative.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So this is a serious threat.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: This is a serious threat to security in the world, and I believe we can act and we can act with our friends and allies and reduce that threat as quickly as possible, but have no doubt about the ultimate result of them acquiring nuclear weapons.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, let me just correct something very quickly.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I believe the Republican Guard of Iran is a terrorist organization.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What Senator McCain refers to is a measure in the Senate that would try to broaden the mandate inside of Iraq.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And ironically, the single thing that has strengthened Iran over the last several years has been the war in Iraq.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Iraq was Iran's mortal enemy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And what we've seen over the last several years is Iran's influence grow.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They have funded Hezbollah, they have funded Hamas, they have gone from zero centrifuges to 4,000 centrifuges to develop a nuclear weapon.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So obviously, our policy over the last eight years has not worked.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Senator McCain is absolutely right, we cannot tolerate a nuclear Iran.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It would be a game changer.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Not only would it threaten Israel, a country that is our stalwart ally, but it would also create an environment in which you could set off an arms race in this Middle East.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now here's what we need to do.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We do need tougher sanctions.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I do not agree with Senator McCain that we're going to be able to execute the kind of sanctions we need without some cooperation with countries like Russia and China that are, I think Senator McCain would agree, not democracies, but have extensive trade with Iran but potentially have an interest in making sure Iran doesn't have a nuclear weapon.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But we are also going to have to, I believe, engage in tough direct diplomacy with Iran and this is a major difference I have with Senator McCain, this notion that by not talking to people we are punishing them has not worked.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It has not worked in Iran, it has not worked in North Korea.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In each instance, our efforts at isolation have actually accelerated their efforts to get nuclear weapons.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That will change when I'm president of the United States.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Senator Obama twice said in debates he would sit down with Ahmadinejad, Chavez and Raul Castro without precondition.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Here is Ahmadinenene (ph), Ahmadinejad, who is, Ahmadinejad, who is now in New York, talking about the extermination of the State of Israel, of wiping Israel off the map, and we're going to sit down, without precondition, across the table, to legitimize and give a propaganda platform to a person that is espousing the extermination of the state of Israel, and therefore then giving them more credence in the world arena and therefore saying, they've probably been doing the right thing, because you will sit down across the table from them and that will legitimize their illegal behavior.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The point is that throughout history, whether it be Ronald Reagan, who wouldn't sit down with Brezhnev, Andropov or Chernenko until Gorbachev was ready with glasnost and perestroika.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Or whether it be Nixon's trip to China, which was preceded by Henry Kissinger, many times before he went.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Look, I'll sit down with anybody, but there's got to be pre-conditions.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Those pre-conditions would apply that we wouldn't legitimize with a face to face meeting, a person like Ahmadinejad.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, Senator Obama said, without preconditions.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So let's talk about this.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: First of all, Ahmadinejad is not the most powerful person in Iran.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So he may not be the right person to talk to.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I reserve the right, as president of the United States to meet with anybody at a time and place of my choosing if I think it's going to keep America safe.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I'm glad that Senator McCain brought up the history, the bipartisan history of us engaging in direct diplomacy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Senator McCain mentioned Henry Kissinger, who's one of his advisers, who, along with five recent secretaries of state, just said that we should meet with Iran -- guess what -- without precondition.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: This is one of your own advisers.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, understand what this means "without preconditions."
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It doesn't mean that you invite them over for tea one day.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What it means is that we don't do what we've been doing, which is to say, "Until you agree to do exactly what we say, we won't have direct contacts with you."
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There's a difference between preconditions and preparation.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Of course we've got to do preparations, starting with low-level diplomatic talks, and it may not work, because Iran is a rogue regime.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I will point out that I was called naive when I suggested that we need to look at exploring contacts with Iran.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: President Bush recently sent a senior ambassador, Bill Burns, to participate in talks with the Europeans around the issue of nuclear weapons.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Again, it may not work, but if it doesn't work, then we have strengthened our ability to form alliances to impose the tough sanctions that Senator McCain just mentioned.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And when we haven't done it, as in North Korea -- let me just take one more example -- in North Korea, we cut off talks.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They're a member of the axis of evil.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We can't deal with them.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And you know what happened?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They went -- they quadrupled their nuclear capacity.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They pulled out of the nonproliferation agreement.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And they sent nuclear secrets, potentially, to countries like Syria.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: When we re-engaged -- because, again, the Bush administration reversed course on this -- then we have at least made some progress, although right now, because of the problems in North Korea, we are seeing it on shaky ground.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And -- and I just -- so I just have to make this general point that the Bush administration, some of Senator McCain's own advisers all think this is important, and Senator McCain appears resistant.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: He even said the other day that he would not meet potentially with the prime minister of Spain, because he -- you know, he wasn't sure whether they were aligned with us.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Spain is a NATO ally.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If we can't meet with our friends, I don't know how we're going to lead the world in terms of dealing with critical issues like terrorism.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I'm not going to set the White House visitors schedule before I'm president of the United States.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I don't even have a seal yet.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Look, Dr. Kissinger did not say that he would approve of face-to- face meetings between the president of the United States and the president -- and Ahmadinejad.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He did not say that.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He said that there could be secretary-level and lower level meetings.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The Iranians have met with Ambassador Crocker in Baghdad.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: What Senator Obama doesn't seem to understand that if without precondition you sit down across the table from someone who has called Israel a "stinking corpse," and wants to destroy that country and wipe it off the map, you legitimize those comments.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It isn't just naive; it's dangerous.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And so we just have a fundamental difference of opinion.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: As far as North Korea is concerned, our secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, went to North Korea.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: By the way, North Korea, most repressive and brutal regime probably on Earth.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The average South Korean is three inches taller than the average North Korean, a huge gulag.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We don't know what the status of the dear leader's health is today, but we know this, that the North Koreans have broken every agreement that they've entered into.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we ought to go back to a little bit of Ronald Reagan's "trust, but verify," and certainly not sit down across the table from -- without precondition, as Senator Obama said he did twice, I mean, it's just dangerous.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Look, I mean, Senator McCain keeps on using this example that suddenly the president would just meet with somebody without doing any preparation, without having low-level talks.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Nobody's been talking about that, and Senator McCain knows it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: This is a mischaracterization of my position.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: When we talk about preconditions -- and Henry Kissinger did say we should have contacts without preconditions -- the idea is that we do not expect to solve every problem before we initiate talks.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, you know, the Bush administration has come to recognize that it hasn't worked, this notion that we are simply silent when it comes to our enemies.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the notion that we would sit with Ahmadinejad and not say anything while he's spewing his nonsense and his vile comments is ridiculous.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Nobody is even talking about that.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So let me get this right.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We sit down with Ahmadinejad, and he says, "We're going to wipe Israel off the face of the Earth," and we say, "No, you're not"?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: By the way, my friend, Dr. Kissinger, who's been my friend for 35 years, would be interested to hear this conversation and Senator Obama's depiction of his -- of his positions on the issue.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I've known him for 35 years.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We will take a look.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I guarantee you he would not -- he would not say that presidential top level.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Of course he encourages and other people encourage contacts, and negotiations, and all other things.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We do that all the time.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And Senator Obama is parsing words when he says precondition means preparation.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I am not parsing words.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: He's parsing words, my friends.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I'm using the same words that your advisers use.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, I think that, given what's happened over the last several weeks and months, our entire Russian approach has to be evaluated, because a resurgent and very aggressive Russia is a threat to the peace and stability of the region.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Their actions in Georgia were unacceptable.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And at this point, it is absolutely critical for the next president to make clear that we have to follow through on our six-party -- or the six-point cease-fire.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They have to remove themselves from South Ossetia and Abkhazia.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It is absolutely important that we have a unified alliance and that we explain to the Russians that you cannot be a 21st-century superpower, or power, and act like a 20th-century dictatorship.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we also have to affirm all the fledgling democracies in that region, you know, the Estonians, the Lithuanians, the Latvians, the Poles, the Czechs, that we are, in fact, going to be supportive and in solidarity with them in their efforts.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They are members of NATO.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And to countries like Georgia and the Ukraine, I think we have to insist that they are free to join NATO if they meet the requirements, and they should have a membership action plan immediately to start bringing them in.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, we also can't return to a Cold War posture with respect to Russia.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's important that we recognize there are going to be some areas of common interest.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They have not only 15,000 nuclear warheads, but they've got enough to make another 40,000, and some of those loose nukes could fall into the hands of Al Qaida.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: This is an area where I've led on in the Senate, working with a Republican ranking member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Dick Lugar, to deal with the proliferation of loose nuclear weapons.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's an area where we're going to have to work with Russia.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You deal with Russia based on, what are your -- what are the national security interests of the United States of America?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we have to recognize that the way they've been behaving lately demands a sharp response from the international community and our allies.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, I was interested in Senator Obama's reaction to the Russian aggression against Georgia.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: His first statement was, "Both sides ought to show restraint."
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Again, a little bit of naivete there.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He doesn't understand that Russia committed serious aggression against Georgia.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And Russia has now become a nation fueled by petro-dollars that is basically a KGB apparatchik-run government.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I looked into Mr. Putin's eyes, and I saw three letters, a "K," a "G," and a "B."
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And their aggression in Georgia is not acceptable behavior.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I don't believe we're going to go back to the Cold War.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I am sure that that will not happen.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But I do believe that we need to bolster our friends and allies.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And that wasn't just about a problem between Georgia and Russia.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It had everything to do with energy.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: There's a pipeline that runs from the Caspian through Georgia through Turkey.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And, of course, we know that the Russians control other sources of energy into Europe, which they have used from time to time.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It's not accidental that the presidents of Latvia, Estonia, Lithuania, Poland, and Ukraine flew to Georgia, flew to Tbilisi, where I have spent significant amount of time with a great young president, Misha Saakashvili.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And they showed solidarity with them, but, also, they are very concerned about the Russian threats to regain their status of the old Russian to regain their status of the old Russian empire.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, I think the Russians ought to understand that we will support -- we, the United States -- will support the inclusion of Georgia and Ukraine in the natural process, inclusion into NATO.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We also ought to make it very clear that the Russians are in violation of their cease-fire agreement.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: They have stationed additional troops in Abkhazia and South Ossetia.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: By the way, I went there once, and we went inside and drove in, and there was a huge poster.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And this is -- this is Georgian territory.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And there was a huge poster of Vladimir Putin, and it said, "Vladimir Putin, our president."
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It was very clear, the Russian intentions towards Georgia.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: They were just waiting to seize the opportunity.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So, this is a very difficult situation.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We want to work with the Russians.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But we also have every right to expect the Russians to behave in a fashion and keeping with a -- with a -- with a country who respects international boundaries and the norms of international behavior.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: This whole thing has got a lot to do with Ukraine, Crimea, the base of the Russian fleet in Sevastopol.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And the breakdown of the political process in Ukraine between Tymoshenko and Yushchenko is a very serious problem.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So watch Ukraine, and let's make sure that we -- that the Ukrainians understand that we are their friend and ally.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: No, actually, I think Senator McCain and I agree for the most part on these issues.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Obviously, I disagree with this notion that somehow we did not forcefully object to Russians going into Georgia.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I immediately said that this was illegal and objectionable.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, absolutely, I wanted a cessation of the violence, because it put an enormous strain on Georgia, and that's why I was the first to say that we have to rebuild the Georgian economy and called for a billion dollars that has now gone in to help them rebuild.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Because part of Russia's intentions here was to weaken the economy to the point where President Saakashvili was so weakened that he might be replaced by somebody that Putin favored more.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Two points I think are important to think about when it comes to Russia.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number one is we have to have foresight and anticipate some of these problems.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So back in April, I warned the administration that you had Russian peacekeepers in Georgian territory.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That made no sense whatsoever.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And what we needed to do was replace them with international peacekeepers and a special envoy to resolve the crisis before it boiled over.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But had it been done, it's possible we could have avoided the issue.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Russia is in part resurgent and Putin is feeling powerful because of petro-dollars, as Senator McCain mentioned.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That means that we, as one of the biggest consumers of oil -- 25 percent of the world's oil -- have to have an energy strategy not just to deal with Russia, but to deal with many of the rogue states we've talked about, Iran, Venezuela.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that means, yes, increasing domestic production and off-shore drilling, but we only have 3 percent of the world's oil supplies and we use 25 percent of the world's oil.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So we can't simply drill our way out of the problem.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What we're going to have to do is to approach it through alternative energy, like solar, and wind, and biodiesel, and, yes, nuclear energy, clean-coal technology.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, you know, I've got a plan for us to make a significant investment over the next 10 years to do that.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I have to say, Senator McCain and I, I think agree on the importance of energy, but Senator McCain mentioned earlier the importance of looking at a record.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Over 26 years, Senator McCain voted 23 times against alternative energy, like solar, and wind, and biodiesel.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so we -- we -- we've got to walk the walk and not just talk the talk when it comes to energy independence, because this is probably going to be just as vital for our economy and the pain that people are feeling at the pump -- and, you know, winter's coming and home heating oil -- as it is our national security and the issue of climate change that's so important.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: No one from Arizona is against solar.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And Senator Obama says he's for nuclear, but he's against reprocessing and he's against storing.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That's just not true, John.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: John, I'm sorry, but that's not true.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: ... it's hard to get there from here.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And off-shore drilling is also something that is very important and it is a bridge.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we know that, if we drill off-shore and exploit a lot of these reserves, it will help, at temporarily, relieve our energy requirements.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And it will have, I think, an important effect on the price of a barrel of oil.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I just have to respond very quickly, just to correct -- just to correct the record.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I supported Nunn-Lugar back in the early 1990s when a lot of my colleagues didn't.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That was the key legislation at the time and put us on the road to eliminating this issue of nuclear waste and the nuclear fuel that has to be taken care of.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I -- I just have to correct the record here.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I have never said that I object to nuclear waste.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What I've said is that we have to store it safely.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, Senator McCain, he says -- he talks about Arizona.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I've got to make this point, Jim.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I have voted for alternate fuel all of my time...
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He -- he -- he objects...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: No one can be opposed to alternate energy.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You've got one more energy -- you've got one more question.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I think it's much less than it was the day after 9/11.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I think it -- that we have a safer nation, but we are a long way from safe.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I want to tell you that one of the things I'm most proud of, among others, because I have worked across the aisle.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have a long record on that, on a long series of reforms.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But after 9/11, Senator Joe Lieberman and I decided that we needed a commission, and that was a commission to investigate 9/11, and find out what happened, and fix it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we were -- we were opposed by the administration, another area where I differed with this administration.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we were stymied until the families of 9/11 came, and they descended on Washington, and we got that legislation passed.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And there were a series of recommendations, as I recall, more than 40.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I'm happy to say that we've gotten written into law most of those reforms recommended by that commission.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I'm proud of that work, again, bipartisan, reaching across the aisle, working together, Democrat and Republican alike.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So we have a long way to go in our intelligence services.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We have to do a better job in human intelligence.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we've got to -- to make sure that we have people who are trained interrogators so that we don't ever torture a prisoner ever again.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We have to make sure that our technological and intelligence capabilities are better.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We have to work more closely with our allies.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I know our allies, and I can work much more closely with them.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But I can tell you that I think America is safer today than it was on 9/11.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But that doesn't mean that we don't have a long way to go.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I'd like to remind you, also, as a result of those recommendations, we've probably had the largest reorganization of government since we established the Defense Department.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I think that those men and women in those agencies are doing a great job.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But we still have a long way to go before we can declare America safe, and that means doing a better job along our borders, as well.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, first of all, I think that we are safer in some ways.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Obviously, we've poured billions of dollars into airport security.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We have done some work in terms of securing potential targets, but we still have a long way to go.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got to make sure that we're hardening our chemical sites.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We haven't done enough in terms of transit; we haven't done enough in terms of ports.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the biggest threat that we face right now is not a nuclear missile coming over the skies.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: This is why the issue of nuclear proliferation is so important.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It is the -- the biggest threat to the United States is a terrorist getting their hands on nuclear weapons.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we -- we are spending billions of dollars on missile defense.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I actually believe that we need missile defense, because of Iran and North Korea and the potential for them to obtain or to launch nuclear weapons, but I also believe that, when we are only spending a few hundred million dollars on nuclear proliferation, then we're making a mistake.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They are now operating in 60 countries.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We can't simply be focused on Iraq.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We have to go to the root cause, and that is in Afghanistan and Pakistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's going to be critical.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We are going to need more cooperation with our allies.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And one last point I want to make.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It is important for us to understand that the way we are perceived in the world is going to make a difference, in terms of our capacity to get cooperation and root out terrorism.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And one of the things that I intend to do as president is to restore America's standing in the world.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We are less respected now than we were eight years ago or even four years ago.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And this is the greatest country on Earth.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But because of some of the mistakes that have been made -- and I give Senator McCain great credit on the torture issue, for having identified that as something that undermines our long-term security -- because of those things, we, I think, are going to have a lot of work to do in the next administration to restore that sense that America is that shining beacon on a hill.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But in the case of missile defense, Senator Obama said it had to be, quote, "proven."
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That wasn't proven when Ronald Reagan said we would do SDI, which is missile defense.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And it was major -- a major factor in bringing about the end of the Cold War.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We seem to come full circle again.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama still doesn't quite understand -- or doesn't get it -- that if we fail in Iraq, it encourages Al Qaida.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: They would establish a base in Iraq.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The consequences of defeat, which would result from his plan of withdrawal and according to date certain, regardless of conditions, according to our military leaders, according to every expert, would lead to defeat -- possible defeat, loss of all the fragile sacrifice that we've made of American blood and treasure, which grieves us all.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: All of that would be lost if we followed Senator Obama's plan to have specific dates with withdrawal, regardless of conditions on the ground.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And General Petraeus says we have had great success, but it's very fragile.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we can't do what Senator Obama wants to do.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That is the central issue of our time.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I think Americans will judge very seriously as to whether that's the right path or the wrong path and who should be the next president of the United States.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Look, over the last eight years, this administration, along with Senator McCain, have been solely focused on Iraq.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That has been their priority.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That has been where all our resources have gone.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In the meantime, bin Laden is still out there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In the meantime, we've got challenges, for example, with China, where we are borrowing billions of dollars.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They now hold a trillion dollars' worth of our debt.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And they are active in countries like -- in regions like Latin America, and Asia, and Africa.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They are -- the conspicuousness of their presence is only matched by our absence, because we've been focused on Iraq.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We have weakened our capacity to project power around the world because we have viewed everything through this single lens, not to mention, look at our economy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We are now spending $10 billion or more every month.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that means we can't provide health care to people who need it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We can't invest in science and technology, which will determine whether or not we are going to be competitive in the long term.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There has never been a country on Earth that saw its economy decline and yet maintained its military superiority.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So this is a national security issue.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We haven't adequately funded veterans' care.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I sit on the Veterans Affairs Committee, and we've got -- I meet veterans all across the country who are trying to figure out, "How can I get disability payments?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I've got post-traumatic stress disorder, and yet I can't get treatment."
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So we have put all chips in, right there, and nobody is talking about losing this war.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What we are talking about is recognizing that the next president has to have a broader strategic vision about all the challenges that we face.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's been missing over the last eight years.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I've been involved, as I mentioned to you before, in virtually every major national security challenge we've faced in the last 20-some years.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: There are some advantages to experience, and knowledge, and judgment.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: As far as our other issues that he brought up are concerned, I know the veterans.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I've been proud of their support and their recognition of my service to the veterans.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I'll take care of them.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And they know that I'll take care of them.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But, also, I have the ability, and the knowledge, and the background to make the right judgments, to keep this country safe and secure.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Reform, prosperity, and peace, these are major challenges to the United States of America.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I'm ready to go at it right now.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, let me just make a closing point.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, my father came from Kenya.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's where I get my name.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And in the '60s, he wrote letter after letter to come to college here in the United States because the notion was that there was no other country on Earth where you could make it if you tried.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The ideals and the values of the United States inspired the entire world.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I don't think any of us can say that our standing in the world now, the way children around the world look at the United States, is the same.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And part of what we need to do, what the next president has to do -- and this is part of our judgment, this is part of how we're going to keep America safe -- is to -- to send a message to the world that we are going to invest in issues like education, we are going to invest in issues that -- that relate to how ordinary people are able to live out their dreams.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that is something that I'm going to be committed to as president of the United States.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Jim, when I came home from prison, I saw our veterans being very badly treated, and it made me sad.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I embarked on an effort to resolve the POW-MIA issue, which we did in a bipartisan fashion, and then I worked on normalization of relations between our two countries so that our veterans could come all the way home.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I guarantee you, as president of the United States, I know how to heal the wounds of war, I know how to deal with our adversaries, and I know how to deal with our friends.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And, by the way, our beloved Nancy Reagan is in the hospital tonight, so our thoughts and prayers are going with you.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It's good to see you again, Senator Obama.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: They're hurting, and they're angry.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And they want this country to go in a new direction.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And there are elements of my proposal that you just outlined which I won't repeat.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Let me just talk to you about one of the short-term fixes.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I am convinced that, until we reverse this continued decline in home ownership and put a floor under it, and so that people have not only the hope and belief they can stay in their homes and realize the American dream, but that value will come up.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, we have allocated $750 billion.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Let's take 300 of that billion and go in and buy those home loan mortgages and negotiate with those people in their homes, 11 million homes or more, so that they can afford to pay the mortgage, stay in their home.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That paid their mortgage payments?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It doesn't help that person in their home if the next door neighbor's house is abandoned.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We ought to put the homeowners first.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I am disappointed that Secretary Paulson and others have not made that their first priority.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, first of all, I want to thank Hofstra University and the people of New York for hosting us tonight and it's wonderful to join Senator McCain again, and thank you, Bob.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the financial rescue plan that Senator McCain and I supported is an important first step.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I pushed for some core principles: making sure that taxpayer can get their money back if they're putting money up.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Making sure that CEOs are not enriching themselves through this process.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I think that it's going to take some time to work itself out.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But what we haven't yet seen is a rescue package for the middle class.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Because the fundamentals of the economy were weak even before this latest crisis.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So I've proposed four specific things that I think can help.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number one, let's focus on jobs.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I want to end the tax breaks for companies that are shipping jobs overseas and provide a tax credit for every company that's creating a job right here in America.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number two, let's help families right away by providing them a tax cut -- a middle-class tax cut for people making less than $200,000, and let's allow them to access their IRA accounts without penalty if they're experiencing a crisis.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now Senator McCain and I agree with your idea that we've got to help homeowners.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's why we included in the financial package a proposal to get homeowners in a position where they can renegotiate their mortgages.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I disagree with Senator McCain in how to do it, because the way Senator McCain has designed his plan, it could be a giveaway to banks if we're buying full price for mortgages that now are worth a lot less.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we don't want to waste taxpayer money.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got some long-term challenges in this economy that have to be dealt with.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got to fix our energy policy that's giving our wealth away.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got to fix our health care system and we've got to invest in our education system for every young person to be able to learn.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I would like to mention that a couple days ago Senator Obama was out in Ohio and he had an encounter with a guy who's a plumber, his name is Joe Wurzelbacher.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Joe wants to buy the business that he has been in for all of these years, worked 10, 12 hours a day.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And he wanted to buy the business but he looked at your tax plan and he saw that he was going to pay much higher taxes.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You were going to put him in a higher tax bracket which was going to increase his taxes, which was going to cause him not to be able to employ people, which Joe was trying to realize the American dream.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now Senator Obama talks about the very, very rich.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That's 16 million jobs in America.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And what you want to do to Joe the plumber and millions more like him is have their taxes increased and not be able to realize the American dream of owning their own business.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He has been watching ads of Senator McCain's.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Let me tell you what I'm actually going to do.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I think tax policy is a major difference between Senator McCain and myself.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we both want to cut taxes, the difference is who we want to cut taxes for.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, Senator McCain, the centerpiece of his economic proposal is to provide $200 billion in additional tax breaks to some of the wealthiest corporations in America.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If you make more -- if you make less than a quarter million dollars a year, then you will not see your income tax go up, your capital gains tax go up, your payroll tax.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And 95 percent of working families, 95 percent of you out there, will get a tax cut.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In fact, independent studies have looked at our respective plans and have concluded that I provide three times the amount of tax relief to middle-class families than Senator McCain does.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, the conversation I had with Joe the plumber, what I essentially said to him was, "Five years ago, when you were in a position to buy your business, you needed a tax cut then."
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that requires us to make some important choices.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The last point I'll make about small businesses.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They produce the most jobs.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, when Senator Obama ended up his conversation with Joe the plumber -- we need to spread the wealth around.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I want Joe the plumber to spread that wealth around.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You told him you wanted to spread the wealth around.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The whole premise behind Senator Obama's plans are class warfare, let's spread the wealth around.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I want small businesses -- and by the way, the small businesses that we're talking about would receive an increase in their taxes right now.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We're not going to do that in my administration.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: If I can answer the question.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number one, I want to cut taxes for 95 percent of Americans.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We're talking about Joe the plumber.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: ... in order to give -- in order to give additional tax cuts to Joe the plumber before he was at the point where he could make $250,000.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Then Exxon Mobil, which made $12 billion, record profits, over the last several quarters, they can afford to pay a little more so that ordinary families who are hurting out there -- they're trying to figure out how they're going to afford food, how they're going to save for their kids' college education, they need a break.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So, look, nobody likes taxes.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Let's not raise anybody's taxes.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The fact is that businesses in America today are paying the second highest tax rate of anywhere in the world.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Where are companies going to go where they can create jobs and where they can do best in business?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We need to encourage business.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, what I've done throughout this campaign is to propose a net spending cut.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I haven't made a promise about...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What I want to emphasize, though, is that I have been a strong proponent of pay-as- you-go.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Every dollar that I've proposed, I've proposed an additional cut so that it matches.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And some of the cuts, just to give you an example, we spend $15 billion a year on subsidies to insurance companies.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It doesn't -- under the Medicare plan -- it doesn't help seniors get any better.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's not improving our health care system.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We need to eliminate a whole host of programs that don't work.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Programs that we need, we should make them work better.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, what is true is that Senator McCain and I have a difference in terms of the need to invest in America and the American people.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If we make investments now so that people have coverage, that we are preventing diseases, that will save on Medicare and Medicaid in the future.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If we invest in a serious energy policy, that will save in the amount of money we're borrowing from China to send to Saudi Arabia.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If we invest now in our young people and their ability to go to college, that will allow them to drive this economy into the 21st century.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But what is absolutely true is that, once we get through this economic crisis and some of the specific proposals to get us out of this slump, that we're not going to be able to go back to our profligate ways.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I just want to get back to this home ownership.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And they went out and bought up these mortgages.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And people were able to stay in their homes, and eventually the values of those homes went up, and they actually made money.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And, by the way, this was a proposal made by Senator Clinton not too long ago.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So, obviously, if we can start increasing home values, then there will be creation of wealth.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We have to stop sending $700 billion a year to countries that don't like us very much.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It's wind, tide, solar, natural gas, nuclear, off-shore drilling, which Senator Obama has opposed.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And the point is that we become energy independent and we will create millions of jobs -- millions of jobs in America.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I would have, first of all, across-the-board spending freeze, OK?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Some people say that's a hatchet.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That's a hatchet, and then I would get out a scalpel, OK?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Because we've got -- we have presided over the largest increase -- we've got to have a new direction for this country.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We have presided over the largest increase in government since the Great Society.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I know how to eliminate programs.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have fought against -- well, one of them would be the marketing assistance program.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Another one would be a number of subsidies for ethanol.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I oppose subsidies for ethanol because I thought it distorted the market and created inflation; Senator Obama supported those subsidies.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I would eliminate the tariff on imported sugarcane-based ethanol from Brazil.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I know how to save billions.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I saved the taxpayer $6.8 billion by fighting a deal for a couple of years, as you might recall, that was a sweetheart deal between an aircraft manufacturer, DOD, and people ended up in jail.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But I would fight for a line-item veto, and I would certainly veto every earmark pork-barrel bill.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: ... including $3 million for an overhead projector in a planetarium in his hometown.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That's not the way we cut -- we'll cut out all the pork.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, look, I think that we do have a disagreement about an across-the-board spending freeze.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, in fact, an across-the-board spending freeze is a hatchet, and we do need a scalpel, because there are some programs that don't work at all.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There are some programs that are underfunded.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, Senator McCain talks a lot about earmarks.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's one of the centerpieces of his campaign.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Earmarks account for 0.5 percent of the total federal budget.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There's no doubt that the system needs reform and there are a lot of screwy things that we end up spending money on, and they need to be eliminated.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But it's not going to solve the problem.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, the last thing I think we have to focus on is a little bit of history, just so that we understand what we're doing going forward.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It has doubled over the last eight years.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So one of the things that I think we have to recognize is pursuing the same kinds of policies that we pursued over the last eight years is not going to bring down the deficit.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, frankly, Senator McCain voted for four out of five of President Bush's budgets.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got to take this in a new direction, that's what I propose as president.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Senator Obama, I am not President Bush.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: If you wanted to run against President Bush, you should have run four years ago.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I'm going to give a new direction to this economy in this country.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama talks about voting for budgets.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Of course, we can take a hatchet and a scalpel to this budget.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It's completely out of control.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The mayor of New York, Mayor Bloomberg, just imposed an across- the-board spending freeze on New York City.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: They're doing it all over America because they have to.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Because they have to balance their budgets.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I will balance our budgets and I will get them and I will...
Speaker: John McCain

Text: ... reduce this -- I can -- we can do it with this kind of job creation of energy independence.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, look, Americans are hurting tonight and they're angry and I understand that, and they want a new direction.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I can bring them in that direction by eliminating spending.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama talks about the budgets I voted for.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He voted for the energy bill that was full of goodies for the oil companies that I opposed.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Let's look at it as graded by the National Taxpayers Union and the Citizens Against Government Waste and the other watchdog organizations.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have fought against spending.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have fought against special interests.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have fought for reform.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You have to tell me one time when you have stood up with the leaders of your party on one single major issue.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, there's a lot of stuff that was put out there, so let me try to address it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: First of all, in terms of standing up to the leaders of my party, the first major bill that I voted on in the Senate was in support of tort reform, which wasn't very popular with trial lawyers, a major constituency in the Democratic Party.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I support charter schools and pay for performance for teachers.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Doesn't make me popular with the teachers union.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I support clean coal technology.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Doesn't make me popular with environmentalists.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So I've got a history of reaching across the aisle.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now with respect to a couple of things Senator McCain said, the notion that I voted for a tax increase for people making $42,000 a year has been disputed by everybody who has looked at this claim that Senator McCain keeps on making.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Even FOX News disputes it, and that doesn't happen very often when it comes to accusations about me.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So the fact of the matter is that if I occasionally have mistaken your policies for George Bush's policies, it's because on the core economic issues that matter to the American people, on tax policy, on energy policy, on spending priorities, you have been a vigorous supporter of President Bush.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, you've shown independence -- commendable independence, on some key issues like torture, for example, and I give you enormous credit for that.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But when it comes to economic policies, essentially what you're proposing is eight more years of the same thing.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I think the American people understand it hasn't worked.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But it's very clear that I have disagreed with the Bush administration.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have disagreed with leaders of my own party.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I've got the scars to prove it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Whether it be bringing climate change to the floor of the Senate for the first time.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Whether it be opposition to spending and earmarks, whether it be the issue of torture, whether it be the conduct of the war in Iraq, which I vigorously opposed.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Whether it be on fighting the pharmaceutical companies on Medicare prescription drugs, importation.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Whether it be fighting for an HMO patient's bill of rights.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Whether it be the establishment of the 9/11 Commission.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have a long record of reform and fighting through on the floor of the United States Senate.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama, your argument for standing up to the leadership of your party isn't very convincing.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, this has been a tough campaign.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It's been a very tough campaign.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I know from my experience in many campaigns that, if Senator Obama had asked -- responded to my urgent request to sit down, and do town hall meetings, and come before the American people, we could have done at least 10 of them by now.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: When Senator Obama was first asked, he said, "Any place, any time," the way Barry Goldwater and Jack Kennedy agreed to do, before the intervention of the tragedy at Dallas.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And the fact is, it's gotten pretty tough.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I regret some of the negative aspects of both campaigns.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But the fact is that it has taken many turns which I think are unacceptable.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: One of them happened just the other day, when a man I admire and respect -- I've written about him -- Congressman John Lewis, an American hero, made allegations that Sarah Palin and I were somehow associated with the worst chapter in American history, segregation, deaths of children in church bombings, George Wallace.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That, to me, was so hurtful.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And, Senator Obama, you didn't repudiate those remarks.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Every time there's been an out-of-bounds remark made by a Republican, no matter where they are, I have repudiated them.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I hope that Senator Obama will repudiate those remarks that were made by Congressman John Lewis, very unfair and totally inappropriate.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And it's a matter of fact that Senator Obama has spent more money on negative ads than any political campaign in history.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I can prove it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And, Senator Obama, when he said -- and he signed a piece of paper that said he would take public financing for his campaign if I did -- that was back when he was a long-shot candidate -- you didn't keep your word.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And 100 percent, John, of your ads -- 100 percent of them have been negative.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And there is nothing wrong with us having a vigorous debate like we're having tonight about health care, about energy policy, about tax policy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's the stuff that campaigns should be made of.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The notion, though, that because we're not doing town hall meetings that justifies some of the ads that have been going up, not just from your own campaign directly, John, but 527s and other organizations that make some pretty tough accusations, well, I don't mind being attacked for the next three weeks.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What the American people can't afford, though, is four more years of failed economic policies.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And what they deserve over the next four weeks is that we talk about what's most pressing to them: the economic crisis.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Senator McCain's own campaign said publicly last week that, if we keep on talking about the economic crisis, we lose, so we need to change the subject.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I would love to see the next three weeks devoted to talking about the economy, devoted to talking about health care, devoted to talking about energy, and figuring out how the American people can send their kids to college.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that is something that I would welcome.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But it requires, I think, a recognition that politics as usual, as been practiced over the last several years, is not solving the big problems here in America.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, if you'll turn on the television, as I -- I watched the Arizona Cardinals defeat the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Every other ad -- ever other ad was an attack ad on my health care plan.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And any objective observer has said it's not true.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You're running ads right now that say that I oppose federal funding for stem cell research.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You're running ads that misportray completely my position on immigration.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So the fact is that Senator Obama is spending unprecedented -- unprecedented in the history of American politics, going back to the beginning, amounts of money in negative attack ads on me.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And of course, I've been talking about the economy.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Of course, I've talked to people like Joe the plumber and tell him that I'm not going to spread his wealth around.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I'm going to let him keep his wealth.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And of course, we're talking about positive plan of action to restore this economy and restore jobs in America.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That's what my campaign is all about and that's what it'll continue to be all about.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But again, I did not hear a repudiation of Congressman...
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I mean, look, if we want to talk about Congressman Lewis, who is an American hero, he, unprompted by my campaign, without my campaign's awareness, made a statement that he was troubled with what he was hearing at some of the rallies that your running mate was holding, in which all the Republican reports indicated were shouting, when my name came up, things like "terrorist" and "kill him," and that you're running mate didn't mention, didn't stop, didn't say "Hold on a second, that's kind of out of line."
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I think Congressman Lewis' point was that we have to be careful about how we deal with our supporters.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You've got to read what he said.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Let me -- let me complete...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I do think that he inappropriately drew a comparison between what was happening there and what had happened during the civil rights movement, and we immediately put out a statement saying that we don't think that comparison is appropriate.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, in fact, afterwards, Congressman Lewis put out a similar statement, saying that he had probably gone over the line.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And what they want is the ability to just focus on some really big challenges that we face right now, and that's what I have been trying to focus on this entire campaign.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We can have serious differences about our health care policy, for example, John, because we do have a difference on health care policy, but we...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: ... talking about it this evening.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, let me just say I would...
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Let me just say categorically I'm proud of the people that come to our rallies.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Whenever you get a large rally of 10,000, 15,000, 20,000 people, you're going to have some fringe peoples.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I've -- and we've always said that that's not appropriate.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But to somehow say that group of young women who said "Military wives for McCain" are somehow saying anything derogatory about you, but anything -- and those veterans that wear those hats that say "World War II, Vietnam, Korea, Iraq," I'm not going to stand for people saying that the people that come to my rallies are anything but the most dedicated, patriotic men and women that are in this nation and they're great citizens.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I'm not going to stand for somebody saying that because someone yelled something at a rally -- there's a lot of things that have been yelled at your rallies, Senator Obama, that I'm not happy about either.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: In fact, some T-shirts that are very...
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So the point is -- the point is that I have repudiated every time someone's been out of line, whether they've been part of my campaign or not, and I will continue to do that.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But the fact is that we need to absolutely not stand for the kind of things that have been going on.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, look, Bob, as I said...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, here's what I would say.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I suspect we won't agree here tonight.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What I think is most important is that we recognize that to solve the key problems that we're facing, if we're going to solve two wars, the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression, if we can -- if we're going to focus on lifting wages that have declined over the last eight years and create jobs here in America, then Democrats, independents and Republicans, we're going to have to be able to work together.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And what is important is making sure that we disagree without being disagreeable.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And it means that we can have tough, vigorous debates around issues.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What we can't do, I think, is try to characterize each other as bad people.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that has been a culture in Washington that has been taking place for too long.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, Bob, you asked me a direct question.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But as Senator Clinton said in her debates with you, we need to know the full extent of that relationship.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We need to know the full extent of Senator Obama's relationship with ACORN, who is now on the verge of maybe perpetrating one of the greatest frauds in voter history in this country, maybe destroying the fabric of democracy.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Bob, I think it's going to be important to just -- I'll respond to these two particular allegations that Senator McCain has made and that have gotten a lot of attention.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In fact, Mr. Ayers has become the centerpiece of Senator McCain's campaign over the last two or three weeks.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: This has been their primary focus.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So let's get the record straight.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Forty years ago, when I was 8 years old, he engaged in despicable acts with a radical domestic group.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I have roundly condemned those acts.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Ten years ago he served and I served on a school reform board that was funded by one of Ronald Reagan's former ambassadors and close friends, Mr. Annenberg.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Other members on that board were the presidents of the University of Illinois, the president of Northwestern University, who happens to be a Republican, the president of The Chicago Tribune, a Republican- leaning newspaper.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Mr. Ayers is not involved in my campaign.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: He has never been involved in this campaign.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And he will not advise me in the White House.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, with respect to ACORN, ACORN is a community organization.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Apparently what they've done is they were paying people to go out and register folks, and apparently some of the people who were out there didn't really register people, they just filled out a bunch of names.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It had nothing to do with us.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The only involvement I've had with ACORN was I represented them alongside the U.S. Justice Department in making Illinois implement a motor voter law that helped people get registered at DMVs.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, the reason I think that it's important to just get these facts out is because the allegation that Senator McCain has continually made is that somehow my associations are troubling.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: On economic policy, I associate with Warren Buffett and former Fed Chairman Paul Volcker.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If I'm interested in figuring out my foreign policy, I associate myself with my running mate, Joe Biden or with Dick Lugar, the Republican ranking member on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, or General Jim Jones, the former supreme allied commander of NATO.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Those are the people, Democrats and Republicans, who have shaped my ideas and who will be surrounding me in the White House.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I think the fact that this has become such an important part of your campaign, Senator McCain, says more about your campaign than it says about me.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, again, while you were on the board of the Woods Foundation, you and Mr. Ayers, together, you sent $230,000 to ACORN.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So -- and you launched your political campaign in Mr. Ayers' living room.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And that's not the facts.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And it's not the fact -- it's not the fact that Senator Obama chooses to associate with a guy who in 2001 said that he wished he had have bombed more, and he had a long association with him.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It's the fact that all the -- all of the details need to be known about Senator Obama's relationship with them and with ACORN and the American people will make a judgment.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And my campaign is about getting this economy back on track, about creating jobs, about a brighter future for America.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And that's what my campaign is about and I'm not going to raise taxes the way Senator Obama wants to raise taxes in a tough economy.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And that's really what this campaign is going to be about.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It's not just that he has some of the best foreign policy credentials of anybody.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And Democrats and Republicans alike, I think, acknowledge his expertise there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But it's also that his entire life he has never forgotten where he came from, coming from Scranton, fighting on behalf of working families, remembering what it's like to see his father lose his job and go through a downward spiral economically.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, as a consequence, his consistent pattern throughout his career is to fight for the little guy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's what he's done when it comes to economic policies that will help working families get a leg up.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's what he's done when it comes to, for example, passing the landmark 1994 crime bill, the Violence Against Women's Act.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Joe has always made sure that he is fighting on behalf of working families, and I think he shares my core values and my sense of where the country needs to go.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Because after eight years of failed policies, he and I both agree that what we're going to have to do is to reprioritize, make sure that we're investing in the American people, give tax cuts not to the wealthiest corporations, but give them to small businesses and give them to individuals who are struggling right now, make sure that we finally get serious about energy independence, something that has been languishing in Washington for 30 years, and make sure that our kids get a great education and can afford to go to college.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So, on the key issues that are of importance to American families, Joe Biden's always been on the right side, and I think he will make an outstanding president if, heaven forbid, something happened to me.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, Americans have gotten to know Sarah Palin.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: They know that she's a role model to women and other -- and reformers all over America.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: She is -- she took on a governor who was a member of her own party when she ran for governor.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: When she was the head of their energy and natural resources board, she saw corruption, she resigned and said, "This can't go on."
Speaker: John McCain

Text: She's given money back to the taxpayers.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: She's cut the size of government.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: She negotiated with the oil companies and faced them down, a $40 billion pipeline of natural gas that's going to relieve the energy needs of the United -- of what they call the lower 48.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: She's a reformer through and through.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And it's time we had that bresh of freth air (sic) -- breath of fresh air coming into our nation's capital and sweep out the old-boy network and the cronyism that's been so much a part of it that I've fought against for all these years.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And, by the way, she also understands special-needs families.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: She understands that autism is on the rise, that we've got to find out what's causing it, and we've got to reach out to these families, and help them, and give them the help they need as they raise these very special needs children.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: She understands that better than almost any American that I know.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And she has ignited our party and people all over America that have never been involved in the political process.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I can't tell how proud I am of her and her family.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You know, I think it's -- that's going to be up to the American people.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I think that, obviously, she's a capable politician who has, I think, excited the -- a base in the Republican Party.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I think it's very commendable the work she's done on behalf of special needs.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That is something that every family that advocates on behalf of disabled children talk about.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And if we have an across-the-board spending freeze, we're not going to be able to do it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's an example of, I think, the kind of use of the scalpel that we want to make sure that we're funding some of those programs.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: He voted against it and, obviously, we had to take Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait or it would've threatened the Middle Eastern world supply.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: In Iraq, he had this cockamamie idea about dividing Iraq into three countries.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We're seeing Iraq united as Iraqis, tough, hard, but we're seeing them.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We're now about to have an agreement for status of forces in Iraq coming up.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: There are several issues in which, frankly, Joe Biden and I openly and honestly disagreed on national security policy, and he's been wrong on a number of the major ones.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But again, I want to come back to, notice every time Senator Obama says, "We need to spend more, we need to spend more, that's the answer" -- why do we always have to spend more?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Why can't we have transparency, accountability, reform of these agencies of government?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Maybe that's why he's asked for 860 -- sought and proposed $860 billion worth of new spending and wants to raise people's taxes in a time of incredible challenge and difficulty and heartache for the American families.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I believe we can, for all intents and purposes, eliminate our dependence on Middle Eastern oil and Venezuelan oil.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: By the way, when Senator Obama said he would unilaterally renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement, the Canadians said, "Yes, and we'll sell our oil to China."
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You don't tell countries you're going to unilaterally renegotiate agreements with them.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We can eliminate our dependence on foreign oil by building 45 new nuclear plants, power plants, right away.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We can store and we can reprocess.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We can store and reprocess spent nuclear fuel, Senator Obama, no problem.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So the point is with nuclear power, with wind, tide, solar, natural gas, with development of flex fuel, hybrid, clean coal technology, clean coal technology is key in the heartland of America that's hurting rather badly.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So I think we can easily, within seven, eight, ten years, if we put our minds to it, we can eliminate our dependence on the places in the world that harm our national security if we don't achieve our independence.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I think that in ten years, we can reduce our dependence so that we no longer have to import oil from the Middle East or Venezuela.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I think that's about a realistic timeframe.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And this is the most important issue that our future economy is going to face.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Obviously, we've got an immediate crisis right now.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But nothing is more important than us no longer borrowing $700 billion or more from China and sending it to Saudi Arabia.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's mortgaging our children's future.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, from the start of this campaign, I've identified this as one of my top priorities and here is what I think we have to do.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number one, we do need to expand domestic production and that means, for example, telling the oil companies the 68 million acres that they currently have leased that they're not drilling, use them or lose them.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I think that we should look at offshore drilling and implement it in a way that allows us to get some additional oil.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's why I've focused on putting resources into solar, wind, biodiesel, geothermal.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: These have been priorities of mine since I got to the Senate, and it is absolutely critical that we develop a high fuel efficient car that's built not in Japan and not in South Korea, but built here in the United States of America.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now I just want to make one last point because Senator McCain mentioned NAFTA and the issue of trade and that actually bears on this issue.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I believe in free trade.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And NAFTA doesn't have -- did not have enforceable labor agreements and environmental agreements.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And what I said was we should include those and make them enforceable.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In the same way that we should enforce rules against China manipulating its currency to make our exports more expensive and their exports to us cheaper.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That is not free trade.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And you really have to pay attention to words.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He said, we will look at offshore drilling.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We can offshore drill now.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We've got to do it now.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We will reduce the cost of a barrel of oil because we show the world that we have a supply of our own.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The technology is there and we have to drill now.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I am a free trader.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I need -- we need to have education and training programs for displaced workers that work, going to our community colleges.
