Speaker: John McCain

Text: Right now, because of previous agreements, some made by President Clinton, the goods and products that we send to Colombia, which is our largest agricultural importer of our products, is -- there's a billion dollars that we -- our businesses have paid so far in order to get our goods in there.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Because of previous agreements, their goods and products come into our country for free.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The same country that's helping us try to stop the flow of drugs into our country that's killing young Americans.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And also the country that just freed three Americans that will help us create jobs in America because they will be a market for our goods and products without having to pay -- without us having to pay the billions of dollars -- the billion dollars and more that we've already paid.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Free trade with Colombia is something that's a no-brainer.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But maybe you ought to travel down there and visit them and maybe you could understand it a lot better.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Actually, I understand it pretty well.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The history in Colombia right now is that labor leaders have been targeted for assassination on a fairly consistent basis and there have not been prosecutions.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And what I have said, because the free trade -- the trade agreement itself does have labor and environmental protections, but we have to stand for human rights and we have to make sure that violence isn't being perpetrated against workers who are just trying to organize for their rights, which is why, for example, I supported the Peruvian Free Trade Agreement which was a well-structured agreement.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I think that the important point is we've got to have a president who understands the benefits of free trade but also is going to enforce unfair trade agreements and is going to stand up to other countries.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the last point I'll make, because we started on energy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: When I talked about the automakers, they are obviously getting hammered right now.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They were already having a tough time because of high gas prices.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And now with the financial crisis, car dealerships are closing and people can't get car loans.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's why I think it's important for us to get loan guarantees to the automakers, but we do have to hold them responsible as well to start producing the highly fuel-efficient cars of the future.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And Detroit had dragged its feet too long in terms of getting that done.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's going to be one of my highest priorities because transportation accounts for about 30 percent of our total energy consumption.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If we can get that right, then we can move in a direction not only of energy independence, but we can create 5 million new jobs all across America, including in the heartland where we can retool some of these plants to make these highly fuel-efficient cars and also to make wind turbines and solar panels, the kinds of clean energy approaches that should be the driver of our economy for the next century.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, let me just said that that this is -- he -- Senator Obama doesn't want a free trade agreement with our best ally in the region but wants to sit down across the table without precondition to -- with Hugo Chavez, the guy who has been helping FARC, the terrorist organization.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Free trade between ourselves and Colombia, I just recited to you the benefits of concluding that agreement, a billion dollars of American dollars that could have gone to creating jobs and businesses in the United States, opening up those markets.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So I don't -- I don't think there's any doubt that Senator Obama wants to restrict trade and he wants to raise taxes.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And the last president of the United States that tried that was Herbert Hoover, and we went from a deep recession into a depression.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We're not going to follow that path while I'm -- when I'm president of the United States.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We've got to do both, and that's exactly what my plan does.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Two women, both of them probably in their mid- to late-50s, had just been laid off of their plant.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Neither of them have health insurance.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And they were desperate for some way of getting coverage, because, understandably, they're worried that, if they get sick, they could go bankrupt.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So here's what my plan does.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If you have health insurance, then you don't have to do anything.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If you've got health insurance through your employer, you can keep your health insurance, keep your choice of doctor, keep your plan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we estimate we can cut the average family's premium by about $2,500 per year.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If you don't have health insurance, then what we're going to do is to provide you the option of buying into the same kind of federal pool that both Senator McCain and I enjoy as federal employees, which will give you high-quality care, choice of doctors, at lower costs, because so many people are part of this insured group.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We're going to make sure that insurance companies can't discriminate on the basis of pre-existing conditions.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We'll negotiate with the drug companies for the cheapest available price on drugs.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We are going to invest in information technology to eliminate bureaucracy and make the system more efficient.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we are going to make sure that we manage chronic illnesses, like diabetes and heart disease, that cost a huge amount, but could be prevented.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: This will cost some money on the front end, but over the long term this is the only way that not only are we going to make families healthy, but it's also how we're going to save the federal budget, because we can't afford these escalating costs.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, it is a terribly painful situation for Americans.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: They're seeing their premiums, their co-pays go up.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Forty-seven million Americans are without health insurance in America today.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And it really is the cost, the escalating costs of health care that are inflicting such pain on working families and people across this country.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That will -- that will reduce costs.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We need to have more community health centers.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We need to have walk-in clinics.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Every parent should know what's going on there.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We -- we need to have -- we need to have employers reward employees who join health clubs and practice wellness and fitness.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But I want to give every American family a $5,000 refundable tax credit.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Take it and get anywhere in America the health care that you wish.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, my old buddy, Joe, Joe the plumber, is out there.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, Joe, Senator Obama's plan, if you're a small business and you are able -- and your -- the guy that sells to you will not have his capital gains tax increase, which Senator Obama wants, if you're out there, my friend, and you've got employees, and you've got kids, if you don't get -- adopt the health care plan that Senator Obama mandates, he's going to fine you.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama wants to set up health care bureaucracies, take over the health care of America through -- as he said, his object is a single payer system.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: If you like that, you'll love Canada and England.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It is not and I just described it...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I just described what my plan is.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I'm happy to talk to you, Joe, too, if you're out there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Here's your fine -- zero.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You won't pay a fine, because...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Zero, because as I said in our last debate and I'll repeat, John, I exempt small businesses from the requirement for large businesses that can afford to provide health care to their employees, but are not doing it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I exempt small businesses from having to pay into a kitty.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But large businesses that can afford it, we've got a choice.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Either they provide health insurance to their employees or somebody has to.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Right now, what happens is those employees get dumped into either the Medicaid system, which taxpayers pick up, or they're going to the emergency room for uncompensated care, which everybody picks up in their premiums.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The average family is paying an additional $900 a year in higher premiums because of the uninsured.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In fact, what, Joe, if you want to do the right thing with your employees and you want to provide them health insurance, we'll give you a 50 percent credit so that you will actually be able to afford it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If you don't have health insurance or you want to buy into a group plan, you will be able to buy into the plan that I just described.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, what we haven't talked about is Senator McCain's plan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: He says he's going to give you all a $5,000 tax credit.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And you can go out and buy your own insurance.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Here's the problem -- that for about 20 million people, you may find yourselves no longer having employer-based health insurance.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: This is because younger people might be able to get health insurance for $5,000, young and healthy folks.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Older folks, less healthy folks, what's going to end up happening is that you're going to be the only ones left in your employer-based system, your employers won't be able to afford it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And once you're out on your own with this $5,000 credit, Senator McCain, for the first time, is going to be taxing the health care benefits that you have from your employer.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And this is your plan, John.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So if you've got $5,000 and it's going to cost you $12,000, that's a loss for you.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Last point about Senator McCain's plan is that insurers right now, the main restrictions on what they do is primarily state law and, under Senator McCain's plan, those rules would be stripped away and you would start seeing a lot more insurance companies cherry-picking and excluding people from coverage.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That, I think, is a mistake and I think that this is a fundamental difference in our campaign and how we would approach health care.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Hey, Joe, you're rich, congratulations, because what Joe wanted to do was buy the business that he's been working for 10-12 hours a day, seven days a week, and you said that you wanted to spread the wealth, but -- in other words, take Joe's money and then you decide what to do with it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, Joe, you're rich, congratulations, and you will then fall into the category where you'll have to pay a fine if you don't provide health insurance that Senator Obama mandates, not the kind that you think is best for your family, your children, your employees, but the kind that he mandates for you.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That's big government at its best.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, 95 percent of the people in America will receive more money under my plan because they will receive not only their present benefits, which may be taxed, which will be taxed, but then you add $5,000 onto it, except for those people who have the gold-plated Cadillac insurance policies that have to do with cosmetic surgery and transplants and all of those kinds of things.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And the good thing about this is they'll be able to go across America.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: This will give them a chance to choose their own futures, not have Senator Obama and government decide that for them.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: If you notice that in all of this proposal, Senator -- government wants -- Senator Obama wants government to do the job.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama wants government to do the job.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I want you to be able to choose the health care for you and your family.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we've got too much government and too much spending and the government is -- the size of government has grown by 40 percent in the last eight years.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We can't afford that in the next eight years and Senator Obama, with the Democrats in charge of Congress, things have gotten worse.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Have you noticed, they've been in charge the last two years.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You all just heard my plan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If you've got an employer-based health care plan, you keep it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, under Senator McCain's plan there is a strong risk that people would lose their employer-based health care.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's the choice you'll have is having your employer no longer provide you health care.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce, which generally doesn't support a lot of Democrats, said that this plan could lead to the unraveling of the employer-based health care system.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I would never and have never in all the years I've been there imposed a litmus test on any nominee to the court.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I thought it was a bad decision.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I think there were a lot of decisions that were bad.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I believe strongly that we should have nominees to the United States Supreme Court based on their qualifications rather than any litmus test.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, let me say that there was a time a few years ago when the United States Senate was about to blow up.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Republicans wanted to have just a majority vote to confirm a judge and the Democrats were blocking in an unprecedented fashion.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We got together seven Republicans, seven Democrats.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You were offered a chance to join.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You chose not to because you were afraid of the appointment of, quote, "conservative judges."
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I voted for Justice Breyer and Justice Ginsburg.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That's not the way we should judge these nominees.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: They should be judged on their qualifications.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I will find the best people in the world -- in the United States of America who have a history of strict adherence to the Constitution.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And not legislating from the bench.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I do not believe that someone who has supported Roe v. Wade that would be part of those qualifications.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But I certainly would not impose any litmus test.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, I think it's true that we shouldn't apply a strict litmus test and the most important thing in any judge is their capacity to provide fairness and justice to the American people.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It is very likely that one of us will be making at least one and probably more than one appointments and Roe versus Wade probably hangs in the balance.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I am somebody who believes that Roe versus Wade was rightly decided.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But what ultimately I believe is that women in consultation with their families, their doctors, their religious advisers, are in the best position to make this decision.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I think that the Constitution has a right to privacy in it that shouldn't be subject to state referendum, any more than our First Amendment rights are subject to state referendum, any more than many of the other rights that we have should be subject to popular vote.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So this is going to be an important issue.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I will look for those judges who have an outstanding judicial record, who have the intellect, and who hopefully have a sense of what real-world folks are going through.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I'll just give you one quick example.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Senator McCain and I disagreed recently when the Supreme Court made it more difficult for a woman named Lilly Ledbetter to press her claim for pay discrimination.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: For years, she had been getting paid less than a man had been paid for doing the exact same job.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And when she brought a suit, saying equal pay for equal work, the judges said, well, you know, it's taken you too long to bring this lawsuit, even though she didn't know about it until fairly recently.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We tried to overturn it in the Senate.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I supported that effort to provide better guidance to the courts; John McCain opposed it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I think that it's important for judges to understand that if a woman is out there trying to raise a family, trying to support her family, and is being treated unfairly, then the court has to stand up, if nobody else will.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's the kind of judge that I want.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Obviously, that law waived the statute of limitations, which you could have gone back 20 or 30 years.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It was a trial lawyer's dream.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Let me talk to you about an important aspect of this issue.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And then, on the floor of the State Senate, as he did 130 times as a state senator, he voted present.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And then, on the floor of the Illinois State Senate, he voted present.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I don't know how you vote "present" on some of that.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I don't know how you align yourself with the extreme aspect of the pro- abortion movement in America.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And that's his record, and that's a matter of his record.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And he'll say it has something to do with Roe v. Wade, about the Illinois State Senate.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It was clear-cut votes that Senator Obama voted, I think, in direct contradiction to the feelings and views of mainstream America.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: If it sounds incredible that I would vote to withhold lifesaving treatment from an infant, that's because it's not true.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The -- here are the facts.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There was a bill that was put forward before the Illinois Senate that said you have to provide lifesaving treatment and that would have helped to undermine Roe v. Wade.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The fact is that there was already a law on the books in Illinois that required providing lifesaving treatment, which is why not only myself but pro-choice Republicans and Democrats voted against it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the Illinois Medical Society, the organization of doctors in Illinois, voted against it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Their Hippocratic Oath would have required them to provide care, and there was already a law in the books.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: With respect to partial-birth abortion, I am completely supportive of a ban on late-term abortions, partial-birth or otherwise, as long as there's an exception for the mother's health and life, and this did not contain that exception.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I attempted, as many have in the past, of including that so that it is constitutional.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that was rejected, and that's why I voted present, because I'm willing to support a ban on late-term abortions as long as we have that exception.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The last point I want to make on the issue of abortion.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: This is an issue that -- look, it divides us.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And in some ways, it may be difficult to -- to reconcile the two views.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But there surely is some common ground when both those who believe in choice and those who are opposed to abortion can come together and say, "We should try to prevent unintended pregnancies by providing appropriate education to our youth, communicating that sexuality is sacred and that they should not be engaged in cavalier activity, and providing options for adoption, and helping single mothers if they want to choose to keep the baby."
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Those are all things that we put in the Democratic platform for the first time this year, and I think that's where we can find some common ground, because nobody's pro-abortion.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I think it's always a tragic situation.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: He's health for the mother.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You know, that's been stretched by the pro-abortion movement in America to mean almost anything.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That's the extreme pro-abortion position, quote, "health."
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But, look, Cindy and I are adoptive parents.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We know what a treasure and joy it is to have an adopted child in our lives.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We'll do everything we can to improve adoption in this country.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But that does not mean that we will cease to protect the rights of the unborn.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Of course, we have to come together.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Of course, we have to work together, and, of course, it's vital that we do so and help these young women who are facing such a difficult decision, with a compassion, that we'll help them with the adoptive services, with the courage to bring that child into this world and we'll help take care of it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: This probably has more to do with our economic future than anything and that means it also has a national security implication, because there's never been a nation on earth that saw its economy decline and continued to maintain its primacy as a military power.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So we've got to get our education system right.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, typically, what's happened is that there's been a debate between more money or reform, and I think we need both.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In some cases, we are going to have to invest.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Early childhood education, which closes the achievement gap, so that every child is prepared for school, every dollar we invest in that, we end up getting huge benefits with improved reading scores, reduced dropout rates, reduced delinquency rates.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I think it's going to be critically important for us to recruit a generation of new teachers, an army of new teachers, especially in math and science, give them higher pay, give them more professional development and support in exchange for higher standards and accountability.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I think it's important for us to make college affordable.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Right now, I meet young people all across the country who either have decided not to go to college or if they're going to college, they are taking on $20,000, $30,000, $50,000, $60,000 worth of debt, and it's very difficult for them to go into some fields, like basic research in science, for example, thinking to themselves that they're going to have a mortgage before they even buy a house.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's why I've proposed a $4,000 tuition credit, every student, every year, in exchange for some form of community service, whether it's military service, whether it's Peace Corps, whether it's working in a community.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But there's one last ingredient that I just want to mention, and that's parents.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We can't do it just in the schools.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They've got to turn off the TV set, put away the video games, and, finally, start instilling that thirst for knowledge that our students need.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, it's the civil rights issue of the 21st century.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: There's no doubt that we have achieved equal access to schools in America after a long and difficult and terrible struggle.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But what is the advantage in a low income area of sending a child to a failed school and that being your only choice?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So choice and competition amongst schools is one of the key elements that's already been proven in places in like New Orleans and New York City and other places, where we have charter schools, where we take good teachers and we reward them and promote them.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we find bad teachers another line of work.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we have to be able to give parents the same choice, frankly, that Senator Obama and Mrs. Obama had and Cindy and I had to send our kids to the school -- their kids to the school of their choice.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Charter schools aren't the only answer, but they're providing competition.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: They are providing the kind of competitions that have upgraded both schools -- types of schools.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You will find that some of the worst school systems in America get the most money per student.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We need to encourage programs such as Teach for America and Troops to Teachers where people, after having served in the military, can go right to teaching and not have to take these examinations which -- or have the certification that some are required in some states.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We need to give them a repayment schedule that they can meet.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We need to have full student loan program for in-state tuition.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we certainly need to adjust the certain loan eligibility to inflation.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, we have a tradition of local control of the schools and that's a tradition that has served us well.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I do think that it is important for the federal government to step up and help local school districts do some of the things they need to do.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now we tried to do this under President Bush.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: He put forward No Child Left Behind.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Unfortunately, they left the money behind for No Child Left Behind.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And local school districts end up having more of a burden, a bunch of unfunded mandates, the same kind of thing that happened with special education where we did the right thing by saying every school should provide education to kids with special needs, but we never followed through on the promise of funding, and that left local school districts very cash-strapped.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So what I want to do is focus on early childhood education, providing teachers higher salaries in exchange for more support.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Senator McCain and I actually agree on two things that he just mentioned.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Charter schools, I doubled the number of charter schools in Illinois despite some reservations from teachers unions.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we also agree on the need for making sure that if we have bad teachers that they are swiftly -- after given an opportunity to prove themselves, if they can't hack it, then we need to move on because our kids have to have their best future.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Where we disagree is on the idea that we can somehow give out vouchers -- give vouchers as a way of securing the problems in our education system.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I also have to disagree on Senator McCain's record when it comes to college accessibility and affordability.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Recently his key economic adviser was asked about why he didn't seem to have some specific programs to help young people go to college and the response was, well, you know, we can't give money to every interest group that comes along.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I don't think America's youth are interest groups, I think they're our future.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And this is an example of where we are going to have to prioritize.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We can't say we're going to do things and then not explain in concrete terms how we're going to pay for it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And if we're going to do some of the things you mentioned, like lowering loan rates or what have you, somebody has got to pay for it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's not going to happen on its own.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I'm sure you're aware, Senator Obama, of the program in the Washington, D.C., school system where vouchers are provided and there's a certain number, I think it's a thousand and some and some 9,000 parents asked to be eligible for that.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Because they wanted to have the same choice that you and I and Cindy and your wife have had.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And that is because they wanted to choose the school that they thought was best for their children.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we all know the state of the Washington, D.C., school system.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That was vouchers, Senator Obama.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I'm frankly surprised you didn't pay more attention to that example.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now as far as the No Child Left Behind is concerned, it was a great first beginning in my view.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It had its flaws, it had its problems, the first time we had looked at the issue of education in America from a nationwide perspective.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We need to sit down and reauthorize it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But, again, spending more money isn't always the answer.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: A lot of people, including me, said, look, it's not doing what it should do.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: By the third grade many times children who were in the Head Start program aren't any better off than the others.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Let's reform it and fund it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That was, of course, out-of-bounds by the Democrats.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We need to reform these programs.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We need to have rewards.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It's a system that cries out for accountability and transparency and the adequate funding.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I just said to you earlier, town hall meeting after town hall meeting, parents come with kids, children -- precious children who have autism.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Sarah Palin knows about that better than most.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we'll find and we'll spend the money, research, to find the cause of autism.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And all Americans will open their wallets and their hearts to do so.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But to have a situation, as you mentioned in our earlier comments, that the most expensive education in the world is in the United States of America also means that it cries out for reform, as well.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I will support those reforms, and I will fund the ones that are reformed.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But I'm not going to continue to throw money at a problem.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I've got to tell you that vouchers, where they are requested and where they are agreed to, are a good and workable system.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator McCain's absolutely right: The D.C. school system is in terrible shape, and it has been for a very long time.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we've got a wonderful new superintendent there who's working very hard with the young mayor there to try...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: ... who initiated -- actually, supports charters.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But the -- but here's the thing, is that, even if Senator McCain were to say that vouchers were the way to go -- I disagree with him on this, because the data doesn't show that it actually solves the problem -- the centerpiece of Senator McCain's education policy is to increase the voucher program in D.C. by 2,000 slots.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That leaves all of you who live in the other 50 states without an education reform policy from Senator McCain.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So if we are going to be serious about this issue, we've got to have a president who is going to tackle it head-on.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's what I intend to do as president.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Because there's not enough vouchers; therefore, we shouldn't do it, even though it's working.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, thank you again, Bob.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And it's great to be with you again.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I think we've had a very healthy discussion.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: My friends, as I said in my opening remarks, these are very difficult times and challenges for America.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And they were graphically demonstrated again today.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: America needs a new direction.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We cannot be satisfied with what we've been doing for the last eight years.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have a record of reform, and taking on my party, the other party, the special interests, whether it be an HMO Patients' Bill of Rights, or trying to clean up the campaign finance system in -- in this country, or whether it be establishment of a 9/11 Commission, I have a long record of it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I've been a careful steward of your tax dollars.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We have to make health care affordable and available.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We have to make quality education there for all of our citizens, not just the privileged few.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We have to stop the spending.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We have to stop the spending, which has mortgaged your children's futures.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: All of these things and all the promises and commitments that Senator Obama and I made (inaudible) made to you tonight will base -- will be based on whether you can trust us or not to be careful stewards of your tax dollar, to make sure America is safe and secure and prosperous, to make sure we reform the institutions of government.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That's why I've asked you not only to examine my record, but my proposals for the future of this country.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I've spent my entire life in the service of this nation and putting my country first.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: ThereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a long line of McCains that have served our country for a long time in war and in peace, it's been the great honor of my life, and I've been proud to serve.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I hope you'll give me an opportunity to serve again.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I'd be honored and humbled.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, I want to thank Senator McCain and Bob for moderating.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I think we all know America is going through tough times right now.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The policies of the last eight years and -- and Washington's unwillingness to tackle the tough problems for decades has left us in the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We need fundamental change in this country, and that's what I'd like to bring.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, over the last 20 months, you've invited me into your homes.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You've shared your stories with me.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And you've confirmed once again the fundamental decency and generosity of the American people.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's why I'm sure that our brighter days are still ahead.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But we're going to have to invest in the American people again, in tax cuts for the middle class, in health care for all Americans, and college for every young person who wants to go.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In policies that will lift wages and will grow our middle class.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: These are the policies I have fought for my entire career.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's not going to be quick.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It is going to be requiring all of us -- Democrats, Republicans, independents -- to come together and to renew a spirit of sacrifice and service and responsibility.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I would ask for your vote, and I promise you that if you give me the extraordinary honor of serving as your president, I will work every single day, tirelessly, on your behalf and on the behalf of the future of our children.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Thank you, Arizona State, for welcoming us.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And thank you to the Presidential Commission for undertaking this enormous task.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We're proud to be here.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Mr. President, I'm glad to be here with you again to share similarities and differences with the American people.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Will we ever be safe and secure again?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, how do we achieve it is the most critical component of it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I believe that this president, regrettably, rushed us into a war, made decisions about foreign policy, pushed alliances away.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And, as a result, America is now bearing this extraordinary burden where we are not as safe as we ought to be.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The measurement is not: Are we safer?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The measurement is: Are we as safe as we ought to be?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And there are a host of options that this president had available to him, like making sure that at all our ports in America containers are inspected.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Only 95 percent of them -- 95 percent come in today uninspected.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: People who fly on airplanes today, the cargo hold is not X-rayed, but the baggage is.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Firehouses don't have enough firefighters in them.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Police officers are being cut from the streets of America because the president decided to cut the COPS program.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: So we can do a better job of homeland security.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I can do a better job of waging a smarter, more effective war on terror and guarantee that we will go after the terrorists.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I will hunt them down, and we'll kill them, we'll capture them.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We'll do whatever is necessary to be safe.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But I pledge this to you, America: I will do it in the way that Franklin Roosevelt and Ronald Reagan and John Kennedy and others did, where we build the strongest alliances, where the world joins together, where we have the best intelligence and where we are able, ultimately, to be more safe and secure.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Bob, thank you very much.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to thank Arizona State as well.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Yes, we can be safe and secure, if we stay on the offense against the terrorists and if we spread freedom and liberty around the world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I have got a comprehensive strategy to not only chase down the Al Qaida, wherever it exists -- and we're making progress; three-quarters of Al Qaida leaders have been brought to justice -- but to make sure that countries that harbor terrorists are held to account.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: As a result of securing ourselves and ridding the Taliban out of Afghanistan, the Afghan people had elections this weekend.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And the first voter was a 19-year-old woman.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We held to account a terrorist regime in Saddam Hussein.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In other words, in order to make sure we're secure, there must be a comprehensive plan.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My opponent just this weekend talked about how terrorism could be reduced to a nuisance, comparing it to prostitution, illegal gambling.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think that attitude and that point of view is dangerous.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't think you can secure America for the long run if you don't have a comprehensive view as to how to defeat these people.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: At home, we'll do everything we can to protect the homeland.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I signed the homeland security bill to better align our assets and resources.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My opponent voted against it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're doing everything we can to protect our borders and ports.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But absolutely we can be secure in the long run.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It just takes good, strong leadership.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: When the president had an opportunity to capture or kill Osama bin Laden, he took his focus off of them, outsourced the job to Afghan warlords, and Osama bin Laden escaped.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Six months after he said Osama bin Laden must be caught dead or alive, this president was asked, "Where is Osama bin Laden? "
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He said, "I don't know.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I don't really think about him very much.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm not that concerned. "
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We need a president who stays deadly focused on the real war on terror.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Gosh, I just don't think I ever said I'm not worried about Osama bin Laden.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's kind of one of those exaggerations.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Of course we're worried about Osama bin Laden.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're on the hunt after Osama bin Laden.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're using every asset at our disposal to get Osama bin Laden.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My opponent said this war is a matter of intelligence and law enforcement.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: No, this war is a matter of using every asset at our disposal to keep the American people protected.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Bob, we relied upon a company out of England to provide about half of the flu vaccines for the United States citizen, and it turned out that the vaccine they were producing was contaminated.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so we took the right action and didn't allow contaminated medicine into our country.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're working with Canada to hopefully -- that they'll produce a -- help us realize the vaccine necessary to make sure our citizens have got flu vaccinations during this upcoming season.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My call to our fellow Americans is if you're healthy, if you're younger, don't get a flu shot this year.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Help us prioritize those who need to get the flu shot, the elderly and the young.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The CDC, responsible for health in the United States, is setting those priorities and is allocating the flu vaccine accordingly.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I haven't gotten a flu shot, and I don't intend to because I want to make sure those who are most vulnerable get treated.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We have a problem with litigation in the United States of America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Vaccine manufacturers are worried about getting sued, and therefore they have backed off from providing this kind of vaccine.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One of the reasons I'm such a strong believer in legal reform is so that people aren't afraid of producing a product that is necessary for the health of our citizens and then end up getting sued in a court of law.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But the best thing we can do now, Bob, given the circumstances with the company in England is for those of us who are younger and healthy, don't get a flu shot.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This really underscores the problem with the American health-care system.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It's not working for the American family.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And it's gotten worse under President Bush over the course of the last years.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Five million Americans have lost their health insurance in this country.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You've got about a million right here in Arizona, just shy, 950,000, who have no health insurance at all.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: 82,000 Arizonians lost their health insurance under President Bush's watch.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: 223,000 kids in Arizona have no health insurance at all.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: All across our country -- go to Ohio, 1.4 million Ohioans have no health insurance, 114,000 of them lost it under President Bush; Wisconsin, 82,000 Wisconsinites lost it under President Bush.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: This president has turned his back on the wellness of America.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And there is no system.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: In fact, it's starting to fall apart not because of lawsuits -- though they are a problem, and John Edwards and I are committed to fixing them -- but because of the larger issue that we don't cover Americans.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Children across our country don't have health care.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We're the richest country on the face of the planet, the only industrialized nation in the world not to do it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I have a plan to cover all Americans.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We're going to let everybody buy into the same health-care plan senators and congressmen give themselves.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I want to remind people listening tonight that a plan is not a litany of complaints, and a plan is not to lay out programs that you can't pay for.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He just said he wants everybody to be able to buy in to the same plan that senators and congressmen get.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That costs the government $7,700 per family.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If every family in America signed up, like the senator suggested, if would cost us $5 trillion over 10 years.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's called bait and switch.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Actually, it's not an empty promise.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It's really interesting, because the president used that very plan as a reason for seniors to accept his prescription drug plan.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He said, if it's good enough for the congressmen and senators to have choice, seniors ought to have choice.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: What we do is we have choice.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I choose Blue Cross/Blue Shield.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Other senators, other congressmen choose other programs.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But the fact is, we're going to help Americans be able to buy into it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Those that can afford it are going to buy in themselves.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We're not giving this away for nothing.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'll tell you exactly how I can do it: by reinstating what President Bush took away, which is called pay as you go.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: During the 1990s, we had pay-as-you-go rules.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: If you were going to pass something in the Congress, you had to show where you are going to pay for it and how.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: President Bush has taken -- he's the only president in history to do this.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He's also the only president in 72 years to lose jobs -- 1.6 million jobs lost.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He's the only president to have incomes of families go down for the last three years; the only president to see exports go down; the only president to see the lowest level of business investment in our country as it is today.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, I'm going to reverse that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm going to change that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We're going to restore the fiscal discipline we had in the 1990s.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Every plan that I have laid out -- my health-care plan, my plan for education, my plan for kids to be able to get better college loans -- I've shown exactly how I'm going to pay for those.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we start -- we don't do it exclusively -- but we start by rolling back George Bush's unaffordable tax cut for the wealthiest people, people earning more than $200,000 a year, and we pass, hopefully, the McCain-Kerry Commission which identified some $60 billion that we can get.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We shut the loophole which has American workers actually subsidizing the loss of their own job.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They just passed an expansion of that loophole in the last few days: $43 billion of giveaways, including favors to the oil and gas industry and the people importing ceiling fans from China.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I am going to do it in a way that's fiscally sound.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I show how I pay for the health care, how we pay for the education.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I have a manufacturing jobs credit.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We pay for it by shutting that loophole overseas.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We raise the student loans.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I pay for it by changing the relationship with the banks.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: This president has never once vetoed one bill; the first president in a hundred years not to do that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Well, his rhetoric doesn't match his record.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He been a senator for 20 years.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He voted to increase taxes 98 times.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He talks about being a fiscal conservative, or fiscally sound, but he voted over -- he voted 277 times to waive the budget caps, which would have cost the taxpayers $4.2 trillion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'll tell you what PAYGO means, when you're a senator from Massachusetts, when you're a colleague of Ted Kennedy, pay go means: You pay, and he goes ahead and spends.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He's proposed $2.2 trillion of new spending, and yet the so-called tax on the rich, which is also a tax on many small-business owners in America, raises $600 million by our account -- billion, $800 billion by his account.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There is a tax gap.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And guess who usually ends up filling the tax gap?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I propose a detailed budget, Bob.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I sent up my budget man to the Congress, and he says, here's how we're going to reduce the deficit in half by five years.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It requires pro-growth policies that grow our economy and fiscal sanity in the halls of Congress.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'd say, Bob, I've got policies to continue to grow our economy and create the jobs of the 21st century.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And here's some help for you to go get an education.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Here's some help for you to go to a community college.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've expanded trade adjustment assistance.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We want to help pay for you to gain the skills necessary to fill the jobs of the 21st century.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You know, there's a lot of talk about how to keep the economy growing.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We talk about fiscal matters.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But perhaps the best way to keep jobs here in America and to keep this economy growing is to make sure our education system works.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I went to Washington to solve problems.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I saw a problem in the public education system in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They were just shuffling too many kids through the system, year after year, grade after grade, without learning the basics.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so we said: Let's raise the standards.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're spending more money, but let's raise the standards and measure early and solve problems now, before it's too late.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: No, education is how to help the person who's lost a job.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Education is how to make sure we've got a workforce that's productive and competitive.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Got four more years, I've got more to do to continue to raise standards, to continue to reward teachers and school districts that are working, to emphasize math and science in the classrooms, to continue to expand Pell Grants to make sure that people have an opportunity to start their career with a college diploma.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so the person you talked to, I say, here's some help, here's some trade adjustment assistance money for you to go a community college in your neighborhood, a community college which is providing the skills necessary to fill the jobs of the 21st century.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's what I would say to that person.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want you to notice how the president switched away from jobs and started talking about education principally.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Let me come back in one moment to that, but I want to speak for a second, if I can, to what the president said about fiscal responsibility.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Being lectured by the president on fiscal responsibility is a little bit like Tony Soprano talking to me about law and order in this country.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: This president has taken a $5.6 trillion surplus and turned it into deficits as far as the eye can see.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Health-care costs for the average American have gone up 64 percent; tuitions have gone up 35 percent; gasoline prices up 30 percent; Medicare premiums went up 17 percent a few days ago; prescription drugs are up 12 percent a year.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The wages of Americans have gone down.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The jobs that are being created in Arizona right now are paying about $13,700 less than the jobs that we're losing.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And the president just walks on by this problem.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The fact is that he's cut job-training money.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They only added a little bit back this year because it's an election year.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They've cut the Pell Grants and the Perkins loans to help kids be able to go to college.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They've cut the training money.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They've wound up not even extending unemployment benefits and not even extending health care to those people who are unemployed.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm going to do those things, because that's what's right in America: Help workers to transition in every respect.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I don't blame them entirely for it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I blame the president for the things the president could do that has an impact on it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Outsourcing is going to happen.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've acknowledged that in union halls across the country.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: "And I've looked them in the eye and I've said, "No, I can't do that. "
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: What I can promise you is that I will make the playing field as fair as possible, that I will, for instance, make certain that with respect to the tax system that you as a worker in America are not subsidizing the loss of your job.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Today, if you're an American business, you actually get a benefit for going overseas.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You get to defer your taxes.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: So if you're looking at a competitive world, you say to yourself, "Hey, I do better overseas than I do here in America. "
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And when I'm president, we're going to shut that loophole in a nanosecond and we're going to use that money to lower corporate tax rates in America for all corporations, 5 percent.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The second thing that we can do is provide a fair trade playing field.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: This president didn't stand up for Boeing when Airbus was violating international rules and subsidies.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He discovered Boeing during the course of this campaign after I'd been talking about it for months.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The fact is that the president had an opportunity to stand up and take on China for currency manipulation.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: There are companies that wanted to petition the administration.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They were told: Don't even bother; we're not going to listen to it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The fact is that there have been markets shut to us that we haven't stood up and fought for.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm going to fight for a fair trade playing field for the American worker.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I will fight for the American worker just as hard as I fight for my own job.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's what the American worker wants.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And if we do that, we can have an impact.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Plus, we need fiscal discipline.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Restore fiscal discipline, we'll do a lot better.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Let me start with the Pell Grants.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In his last litany of misstatements.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He said we cut Pell Grants.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've increased Pell Grants by a million students.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You know, he talks to the workers.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Let me talk to the workers.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You've got more money in your pocket as a result of the tax relief we passed and he opposed.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If you have a child, you got a $1,000 child credit.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's money in your pocket.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If you're married, we reduced the marriage penalty.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The code ought to encourage marriage, not discourage marriage.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We created a 10 percent bracket to help lower-income Americans.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: A family of four making $40,000 received about $1,700 in tax relief.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The way my opponent talks, he said, "We're going to spend the government's money.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: "No, we're spending your money.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And when you have more money in your pocket, you're able to better afford things you want.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My opponent talks about fiscal sanity.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: His record in the United States Senate does not match his rhetoric.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He voted to increase taxes 98 times and to bust the budget 277 times.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Bob, anybody can play with these votes.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I have supported or voted for tax cuts over 600 times.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I broke with my party in order to balance the budget, and Ronald Reagan signed into law the tax cut that we voted for.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I voted for IRA tax cuts.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I voted for small-business tax cuts.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But you know why the Pell Grants have gone up in their numbers?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Because more people qualify for them because they don't have money.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But they're not getting the $5,100 the president promised them.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We have more people who qualify.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's not what we want.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Senator, no one's playing with your votes.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You voted to increase taxes 98 times.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You know, there's a main stream in American politics and you sit right on the far left bank.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: As a matter of fact, your record is such that Ted Kennedy, your colleague, is the conservative senator from Massachusetts.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I do know that we have a choice to make in America and that is to treat people with tolerance and respect and dignity.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's important that we do that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I also know in a free society people, consenting adults can live the way they want to live.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's to be honored.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But as we respect someone's rights, and as we profess tolerance, we shouldn't change -- or have to change -- our basic views on the sanctity of marriage.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe in the sanctity of marriage.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think it's very important that we protect marriage as an institution, between a man and a woman.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I proposed a constitutional amendment.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The reason I did so was because I was worried that activist judges are actually defining the definition of marriage, and the surest way to protect marriage between a man and woman is to amend the Constitution.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It has also the benefit of allowing citizens to participate in the process.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: After all, when you amend the Constitution, state legislatures must participate in the ratification of the Constitution.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm deeply concerned that judges are making those decisions and not the citizenry of the United States.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You know, Congress passed a law called DOMA, the Defense of Marriage Act.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My opponent was against it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It basically protected states from the action of one state to another.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It also defined marriage as between a man and woman.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I'm concerned that that will get overturned.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And if it gets overturned, then we'll end up with marriage being defined by courts, and I don't think that's in our nation's interests.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're all God's children, Bob.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I think if you were to talk to Dick Cheney's daughter, who is a lesbian, she would tell you that she's being who she was, she's being who she was born as.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think if you talk to anybody, it's not choice.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've met people who struggled with this for years, people who were in a marriage because they were living a sort of convention, and they struggled with it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I've met wives who are supportive of their husbands or vice versa when they finally sort of broke out and allowed themselves to live who they were, who they felt God had made them.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think we have to respect that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president and I share the belief that marriage is between a man and a woman.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I believe marriage is between a man and a woman.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You can't discriminate in the rights that you afford people.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You can't disallow someone the right to visit their partner in a hospital.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You have to allow people to transfer property, which is why I'm for partnership rights and so forth.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, with respect to DOMA and the marriage laws, the states have always been able to manage those laws.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And they're proving today, every state, that they can manage them adequately.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I completely respect their views.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I grew up learning how to respect those views.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But I disagree with them, as do many.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I believe that I can't legislate or transfer to another American citizen my article of faith.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: What is an article of faith for me is not something that I can legislate on somebody who doesn't share that article of faith.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I believe that choice is a woman's choice.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And that's why I support that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, I will not allow somebody to come in and change Roe v. Wade.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president has never said whether or not he would do that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But we know from the people he's tried to appoint to the court he wants to.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I will defend the right of Roe v. Wade.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, with respect to religion, you know, as I said, I grew up a Catholic.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I know that throughout my life this has made a difference to me.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And as President Kennedy said when he ran for president, he said, "I'm not running to be a Catholic president.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm running to be a president who happens to be Catholic. "
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: My faith affects everything that I do, in truth.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: There's a great passage of the Bible that says, "What does it mean, my brother, to say you have faith if there are no deeds?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Faith without works is dead. "
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I think that everything you do in public life has to be guided by your faith, affected by your faith, but without transferring it in any official way to other people.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's why I fight against poverty.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's why I fight to clean up the environment and protect this earth.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's why I fight for equality and justice.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: All of those things come out of that fundamental teaching and belief of faith.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But I know this, that President Kennedy in his inaugural address told all of us that here on Earth, God's work must truly be our own.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And that's what we have to -- I think that's the test of public service.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think it's important to promote a culture of life.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think a hospitable society is a society where every being counts and every person matters.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe the ideal world is one in which every child is protected in law and welcomed to life.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I understand there's great differences on this issue of abortion, but I believe reasonable people can come together and put good law in place that will help reduce the number of abortions.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Take, for example, the ban on partial birth abortion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: People from both political parties came together in the halls of Congress and voted overwhelmingly to ban that practice.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It made a lot of sense.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My opponent, in that he's out of the mainstream, voted against that law.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: What I'm saying is, is that as we promote life and promote a culture of life, surely there are ways we can work together to reduce the number of abortions: continue to promote adoption laws -- it's a great alternative to abortion -- continue to fund and promote maternity group homes; I will continue to promote abstinence programs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The last debate, my opponent said his wife was involved with those programs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I appreciate that very much.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: All of us ought to be involved with programs that provide a viable alternative to abortion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Gosh, I sure hope it's not the administration.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There's a -- no, look, there's a systemic problem.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Health-care costs are on the rise because the consumers are not involved in the decision-making process.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Most health-care costs are covered by third parties.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And therefore, the actual user of health care is not the purchaser of health care.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And there's no market forces involved with health care.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's one of the reasons I'm a strong believer in what they call health savings accounts.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: These are accounts that allow somebody to buy a low-premium, high-deductible catastrophic plan and couple it with tax-free savings.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Businesses can contribute, employees can contribute on a contractual basis.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But this is a way to make sure people are actually involved with the decision-making process on health care.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Secondly, I do believe the lawsuits -- I don't believe, I know -- that the lawsuits are causing health-care costs to rise in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's why I'm such a strong believer in medical liability reform.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In the last debate, my opponent said those lawsuits only caused the cost to go up by 1 percent.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, he didn't include the defensive practice of medicine that costs the federal government some $28 billion a year and costs our society between $60 billion and $100 billion a year.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Thirdly, one of the reasons why there's still high cost in medicine is because this is -- they don't use any information technology.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's like if you looked at the -- it's the equivalent of the buggy and horse days, compared to other industries here in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so, we've got to introduce high technology into health care.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're beginning to do it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We want there to be electronic medical records to cut down on error, as well as reduce cost.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: People tell me that when the health-care field is fully integrated with information technology, it'll wring some 20 percent of the cost out of the system.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And finally, moving generic drugs to the market quicker.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so, those are four ways to help control the costs in health care.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The reason health-care costs are getting higher, one of the principal reasons is that this administration has stood in the way of common-sense efforts that would have reduced the costs.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Let me give you a prime example.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: In the Senate we passed the right of Americans to import drugs from Canada.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But the president and his friends took it out in the House, and now you don't have that right.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president blocked you from the right to have less expensive drugs from Canada.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We also wanted Medicare to be able to negotiate bulk purchasing.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The VA provides lower-cost drugs to our veterans.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We could have done that in Medicare.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Medicare is paid for by the American taxpayer.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Medicare is for seniors, who many of them are on fixed income, to lift them out of poverty.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But rather than help you, the taxpayer, have lower cost, rather than help seniors have less expensive drugs, the president made it illegal -- illegal -- for Medicare to actually go out and bargain for lower prices.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's a large part of your 17 percent increase in Medicare premiums.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: When I'm president, I'm sending that back to Congress and we're going to get a real prescription drug benefit.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, we also have people sicker because they don't have health insurance.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: So whether it's diabetes or cancer, they come to hospitals later and it costs America more.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We got to have health care for all Americans.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think it's important, since he talked about the Medicare plan, has he been in the United States Senate for 20 years?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He has no record on reforming of health care.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He introduced some 300 bills and he's passed five.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I came to Washington to solve problems.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I was deeply concerned about seniors having to choose between prescription drugs and food.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And in 2006, our seniors will get a prescription drug coverage in Medicare.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Once again, the president is misleading America.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Well, two leading national news networks have both said the president's characterization of my health-care plan is incorrect.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The other called it untrue.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The fact is that my health-care plan, America, is very simple.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It gives you the choice.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I don't force you to do anything.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It's not a government plan.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The government doesn't require you to do anything.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: If you don't want to take the offer of the plan that I want to put forward, you don't have do.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You can keep what you have today, keep a high deductible, keep high premiums, keep a high co-pay, keep low benefits.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I don't think a lot of people are going to want to keep what they have today.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Here's what I do: We take over Medicaid children from the states so that every child in America is covered.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And in exchange, if the states want to -- they're not forced to, they can choose to -- they cover individuals up to 300 percent of poverty.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think they'll choose it, because it's a net plus of $5 billion to them.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We allow you -- if you choose to, you don't have to -- but we give you broader competition to allow you to buy into the same health care plan that senators and congressmen give themselves.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I believe that your health care is just as important as any politician in Washington, D. C.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You want to buy into it, you can.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We give you broader competition.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: In addition to that, we're going to allow people 55 to 64 to buy into Medicare early.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And most importantly, we give small business a 50 percent tax credit so that after we lower the costs of health care, they also get, whether they're self-employed or a small business, a lower cost to be able to cover their employees.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I'm going to offer it to America.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: In all due respect, I'm not so sure it's credible to quote leading news organizations about -- oh, never mind.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Anyway, let me quote the Lewin report.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The Lewin report is a group of folks who are not politically affiliated.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They analyzed the senator's plan.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The Lewin report accurately noted that there are going to be 20 million people, over 20 million people added to government-controlled health care.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It would be the largest increase in government health care ever.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If you raise the Medicaid to 300 percent, it provides an incentive for small businesses not to provide private insurance to their employees.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Why should they insure somebody when the government's going to insure it for them?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's estimated that 8 million people will go from private insurance to government insurance.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We have a fundamental difference of opinion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think government- run health will lead to poor-quality health, will lead to rationing, will lead to less choice.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Once a health-care program ends up in a line item in the federal government budget, it leads to more controls.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And just look at other countries that have tried to have federally controlled health care.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They have poor-quality health care.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Our health-care system is the envy of the world because we believe in making sure that the decisions are made by doctors and patients, not by officials in the nation's capital.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The president just said that government-run health care results in poor quality.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, maybe that explains why he hasn't fully funded the VA and the VA hospital is having trouble and veterans are complaining.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Maybe that explains why Medicare patients are complaining about being pushed off of Medicare.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He doesn't adequately fund it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But let me just say to America: I am not proposing a government-run program.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's not what I have.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I have Blue Cross/Blue Shield.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Senators and congressmen have a wide choice.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Talk about the VA: We've increased VA funding by $22 billion in the four years since I've been president.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's twice the amount that my predecessor increased VA funding.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Of course we're meeting our obligation to our veterans, and the veterans know that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're expanding veterans' health care throughout the country.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're aligning facilities where the veterans live now.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Veterans are getting very good health care under my administration, and they will continue to do so during the next four years.
