Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: First, let me make sure that every senior listening today understands that when we're talking about reforming Social Security, that they'll still get their checks.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I remember the 2000 campaign, people said if George W. gets elected, your check will be taken away.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, people got their checks, and they'll continue to get their checks.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And if we don't act today, the problem will be valued in the trillions.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so I think we need to think differently.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We'll honor our commitment to our seniors.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But for our children and our grandchildren, we need to have a different strategy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And recognizing that, I called together a group of our fellow citizens to study the issue.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It was a committee chaired by the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, a Democrat.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And they came up with a variety of ideas for people to look at.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe that younger workers ought to be allowed to take some of their own money and put it in a personal savings account, because I understand that they need to get better rates of return than the rates of return being given in the current Social Security trust.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And the compounding rate of interest effect will make it more likely that the Social Security system is solvent for our children and our grandchildren.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I will work with Republicans and Democrats.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It'll be a vital issue in my second term.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It is an issue that I am willing to take on, and so I'll bring Republicans and Democrats together.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we're of course going to have to consider the costs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I want to warn my fellow citizens: The cost of doing nothing, the cost of saying the current system is OK, far exceeds the costs of trying to make sure we save the system for our children.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You just heard the president say that young people ought to be able to take money out of Social Security and put it in their own accounts.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, my fellow Americans, that's an invitation to disaster.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The CBO said very clearly that if you were to adopt the president's plan, there would be a $2 trillion hole in Social Security, because today's workers pay in to the system for today's retirees.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And the CBO said -- that's the Congressional Budget Office; it's bipartisan -- they said that there would have to be a cut in benefits of 25 percent to 40 percent.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, the president has never explained to America, ever, hasn't done it tonight, where does the transitional money, that $2 trillion, come from?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He's already got $3 trillion, according to The Washington Post, of expenses that he's put on the line from his convention and the promises of this campaign, none of which are paid for.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Not one of them are paid for.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He's broken the pay-as-you-go rules.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I have a record of fighting for fiscal responsibility.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: In 1985, I was one of the first Democrats -- broke with my party.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We balanced the budget in the '90s.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We paid down the debt for two years.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I will not privatize it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I will not cut the benefits.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we're going to be fiscally responsible.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we will take care of Social Security.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: This is the same thing we heard -- remember, I appeared on "Meet the Press" with Tim Russert in 1990-something.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We heard the same thing.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: In fact, we put together a $5.6 trillion surplus in the '90s that was for the purpose of saving Social Security.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: If you take the tax cut that the president of the United States has given -- President Bush gave to Americans in the top 1 percent of America -- just that tax cut that went to the top 1 percent of America would have saved Social Security until the year 2075.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president decided to give it to the wealthiest Americans in a tax cut.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, Alan Greenspan, who I think has done a terrific job in monetary policy, supports the president's tax cut.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I support it for the middle class, not that part of it that goes to people earning more than $200,000 a year.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And when I roll it back and we invest in the things that I have talked about to move our economy, we're going to grow sufficiently, it would begin to cut the deficit in half, and we get back to where we were at the end of the 1990s when we balanced the budget and paid down the debt of this country.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, we can do that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, if later on after a period of time we find that Social Security is in trouble, we'll pull together the top experts of the country.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We'll do exactly what we did in the 1990s.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we'll make whatever adjustment is necessary.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But the first and most important thing is to start creating jobs in America.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The jobs the president is creating pay $9,000 less than the jobs that we're losing.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Eleven other presidents -- six Democrats and five Republicans -- had wars, had recessions, had great difficulties; none of them lost jobs the way this president has.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And if we're fiscally responsible and put America back to work, we're going to fix Social Security.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He forgot to tell you he voted to tax Social Security benefits more than one time.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I didn't hear any plan to fix Social Security.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I heard more of the same.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He talks about middle-class tax cuts.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's exactly where the tax cuts went.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Most of the tax cuts went to low- and middle-income Americans.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And now the tax code is more fair.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: People listening out there know the benefits of the tax cuts we passed.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If you have a child, you got tax relief.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If you're married, you got tax relief.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If you pay any tax at all, you got tax relief.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: All of which was opposed by my opponent.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And the tax relief was important to spur consumption and investment to get us out of this recession.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: People need to remember: Six months prior to my arrival, the stock market started to go down.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And it was one of the largest declines in our history.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And then we had a recession and we got attacked, which cost us 1 million jobs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And now this economy is growing.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We added 1.9 million new jobs over the last 13 months.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Sure, there's more work to do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's not to increase the scope of the federal government.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's to make sure we have fiscal sanity and keep taxes low.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I see it as a serious problem.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I see it as a security issue, I see it as an economic issue, and I see it as a human-rights issue.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're increasing the border security of the United States.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're using unmanned vehicles to spot people coming across.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we'll continue to do so over the next four years.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's a subject I'm very familiar with.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: After all, I was a border governor for a while.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Many people are coming to this country for economic reasons.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They're coming here to work.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If you can make 50 cents in the heart of Mexico, for example, or make $5 here in America, $5.15, you're going to come here if you're worth your salt, if you want to put food on the table for your families.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That has the benefit of making sure our employers aren't breaking the law as they try to fill their workforce needs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It makes sure that the people coming across the border are humanely treated, that they're not kept in the shadows of our society, that they're able to go back and forth to see their families.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: See, the card, it'll have a period of time attached to it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It also means it takes pressure off the border.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If somebody is coming here to work with a card, it means they're not going to have to sneak across the border.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It means our border patrol will be more likely to be able to focus on doing their job.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Now, it's very important for our citizens to also know that I don't believe we ought to have amnesty.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There are plenty of people standing in line to become a citizen.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we ought not to crowd these people ahead of them in line.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If they want to become a citizen, they can stand in line, too.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And here is where my opponent and I differ.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In September 2003, he supported amnesty for illegal aliens.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Let me just answer one part of the last question quickly, and then I'll come to immigration.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The American middle-class family isn't making it right now, Bob.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And what the president said about the tax cuts has been wiped out by the increase in health care, the increase in gasoline, the increase in tuitions, the increase in prescription drugs.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The fact is, the take-home pay of a typical American family as a share of national income is lower than it's been since 1929.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And the take-home pay of the richest .
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: 1 percent of Americans is the highest it's been since 1928.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Under President Bush, the middle class has seen their tax burden go up and the wealthiest's tax burden has gone down.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, with respect to immigration reform, the president broke his promise on immigration reform.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He said he would reform it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Four years later he is now promising another plan.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Here's what I'll do: Number one, the borders are more leaking today than they were before 9/11.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Secondly, we need a guest-worker program, but if it's all we have, it's not going to solve the problem.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The second thing we need is to crack down on illegal hiring.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It's against the law in the United States to hire people illegally, and we ought to be enforcing that law properly.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And thirdly, we need an earned-legalization program for people who have been here for a long time, stayed out of trouble, got a job, paid their taxes, and their kids are American.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We got to start moving them toward full citizenship, out of the shadows.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Well, to say that the borders are not as protected as they were prior to September the 11th shows he doesn't know the borders.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They're much better protected today than they were when I was the governor of Texas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We have much more manpower and much more equipment there.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He just doesn't understand how the borders work, evidently, to say that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That is an outrageous claim.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we'll continue to protect our borders.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're continuing to increase manpower and equipment.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Four thousand people a day are coming across the border.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The fact is that we now have people from the Middle East, allegedly, coming across the border.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we're not doing what we ought to do in terms of the technology.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We have thumbprint, fingerprint technology today.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We can know who the people are, that they're really the people they say they are when they cross the border.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We could speed it up.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The fact is our borders are not as secure as they ought to be, and I'll make them secure.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It's long overdue time to raise the minimum wage.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And, America, this is one of those issues that separates the president and myself.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We have fought to try to raise the minimum wage in the last years.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But the Republican leadership of the House and Senate won't even let us have a vote on it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We're not allowed to vote on it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They don't want to raise the minimum wage.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The minimum wage is the lowest minimum wage value it has been in our nation in 50 years.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: If we raise the minimum wage, which I will do over several years to $7 an hour, 9.2 million women who are trying to raise their families would earn another $3,800 a year.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president has denied 9.2 million women $3,800 a year, but he doesn't hesitate to fight for $136,000 to a millionaire.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Women work for 76 cents on the dollar for the same work that men do.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we had an initiative that we were working on to raise women's pay.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They don't enforce these kinds of things.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, I think that it's a matter of fundamental right that if we raise the minimum wage, 15 million Americans would be positively affected.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We'd put money into the hands of people who work hard, who obey the rules, who play for the American dream.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And if we did that, we'd have more consumption ability in America, which is what we need right now in order to kick our economy into gear.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I will fight tooth and nail to pass the minimum wage.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Actually, Mitch McConnell had a minimum-wage plan that I supported that would have increased the minimum wage.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But let me talk about what's really important for the worker you're referring to.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's to make sure the education system works.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's to make sure we raise standards.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Listen, the No Child Left Behind Act is really a jobs act when you think about it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The No Child Left Behind Act says, "We'll raise standards.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But in return for extra spending, we now want people to measure -- states and local jurisdictions to measure to show us whether or not a child can read or write or add and subtract. "
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we weren't diagnosing problems.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And therefore just kids were being shuffled through the school.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And guess who would get shuffled through?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Children whose parents wouldn't speak English as a first language just move through.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Many inner-city kids just move through.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've stopped that practice now by measuring early.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And when we find a problem, we spend extra money to correct it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I remember a lady in Houston, Texas, told me, "Reading is the new civil right," and she's right.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In order to make sure people have jobs for the 21st century, we've got to get it right in the education system, and we're beginning to close a minority achievement gap now.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You see, we'll never be able to compete in the 21st century unless we have an education system that doesn't quit on children, an education system that raises standards, an education that makes sure there's excellence in every classroom.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: What he's asking me is, will I have a litmus test for my judges?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And the answer is, no, I will not have a litmus test.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I will pick judges who will interpret the Constitution, but I'll have no litmus test.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, again, the president didn't answer the question.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'll answer it straight to America.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm not going to appoint a judge to the Court who's going to undo a constitutional right, whether it's the First Amendment, or the Fifth Amendment, or some other right that's given under our courts today -- under the Constitution.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I believe that the right of choice is a constitutional right.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: So I don't intend to see it undone.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Clearly, the president wants to leave in ambivalence or intends to undo it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But let me go a step further.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We have a long distance yet to travel in terms of fairness in America.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I don't know how you can govern in this country when you look at New York City and you see that 50 percent of the black males there are unemployed, when you see 40 percent of Hispanic children -- of black children in some cities -- dropping out of high school.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And yet the president who talks about No Child Left Behind refused to fully fund -- by $28 billion -- that particular program so you can make a difference in the lives of those young people.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now right here in Arizona, that difference would have been $131 million to the state of Arizona to help its kids be able to have better education and to lift the property tax burden from its citizens.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president reneged on his promise to fund No Child Left Behind.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He'll tell you he's raised the money, and he has.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But he didn't put in what he promised, and that makes a difference in the lives of our children.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: One, he clearly has a litmus test for his judges, which I disagree with.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And secondly, only a liberal senator from Massachusetts would say that a 49 percent increase in funding for education was not enough.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But more importantly, we've reformed the system to make sure that we solve problems early, before they're too late.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He talked about the unemployed.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He talked about children whose parents don't speak English as a first language?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's what the No Child Left Behind Act does.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You don't measure it by a percentage increase.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Mr. President, you measure it by whether you're getting the job done.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, that's not in my gut.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's not in my value system, and certainly not so that the wealthiest people in America can walk away with another tax cut.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: $89 billion last year to the top 1 percent of Americans, but kids lost their after-school programs.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Well, I think the fact that they're facing these repeated call-ups, some of them two and three deployments, and there's a stop- loss policy that prevents people from being able to get out when their time was up, is a reflection of the bad judgment this president exercised in how he has engaged in the world and deployed our forces.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Nine out of 10 active-duty Army divisions are either in Iraq, going to Iraq or have come back from Iraq.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: One way or the other, they're wrapped up in it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, I've proposed adding two active-duty divisions to the armed forces of the United States -- one combat, one support.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: In addition, I'm going to double the number of Special Forces so that we can fight a more effective war on terror, with less pressure on the National Guard and Reserve.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And what I would like to do is see the National Guard and Reserve be deployed differently here in our own country.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We ought to be doing that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And that would relieve an enormous amount of pressure.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But the most important thing to relieve the pressure on all of the armed forces is frankly to run a foreign policy that recognizes that America is strongest when we are working with real alliances, when we are sharing the burdens of the world by working through our statesmanship at the highest levels and our diplomacy to bring other nations to our side.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've said it before, I say it again: I believe the president broke faith with the American people in the way that he took this nation to war.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He said he would work through a real alliance.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He said in Cincinnati we would plan carefully, we would take every precaution.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And the result is our forces today are overextended.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The fact is that he did not choose to go to war as a last result.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And America now is paying, already $120 billion, up to $200 billion before we're finished and much more probably.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And that is the result of this president taking his eye off of Osama bin Laden.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The best way to take the pressure off our troops is to succeed in Iraq, is to train Iraqis so they can do the hard work of democracy, is to give them a chance to defend their country, which is precisely what we're doing.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We'll have 125,000 troops trained by the end of this year.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I remember going on an airplane in Bangor, Maine, to say thanks to the reservists and Guard that were headed overseas from Tennessee and North Carolina, Georgia.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Some of them had been there before.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The people I talked to their spirits were high.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They didn't view their service as a back-door draft.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They viewed their service as an opportunity to serve their country.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My opponent, the senator, talks about foreign policy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In our first debate he proposed America pass a global test.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In order to defend ourselves, we'd have to get international approval.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's one of the major differences we have about defending our country.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We'll continue to build strong coalitions.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I will never turn over our national- security decisions to leaders of other countries.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We'll be resolute, we'll be strong, and we'll wage a comprehensive war against the terrorists.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I have never suggested a test where we turn over our security to any nation.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: In fact, I've said the opposite: I will never turn the security of the United States over to any nation.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: No nation will ever have a veto over us.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's how you gain legitimacy with your own countrypeople, and that's how you gain legitimacy in the world.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But I'll never fail to protect the United States of America.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The international community, the international world said this is the right thing to do, but when it came time to authorize the use of force on the Senate floor, my opponent voted against the use of force.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Apparently you can't pass any test under his vision of the world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Actually, I made my intentions -- made my views clear.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I did think we ought to extend the assault weapons ban, and was told the fact that the bill was never going to move, because Republicans and Democrats were against the assault weapon ban, people of both parties.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe law-abiding citizens ought to be able to own a gun.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe in background checks at gun shows or anywhere to make sure that guns don't get in the hands of people that shouldn't have them.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But the best way to protect our citizens from guns is to prosecute those who commit crimes with guns.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's why early in my administration I called the attorney general and the U. S. attorneys and said: Put together a task force all around the country to prosecute those who commit crimes with guns.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And the prosecutions are up by about 68 percent -- I believe -- is the number.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Neighborhoods are safer when we crack down on people who commit crimes with guns.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: To me, that's the best way to secure America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe it was a failure of presidential leadership not to reauthorize the assault weapons ban.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I respect the Second Amendment and I will not tamper with the Second Amendment.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But I'll tell you this.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm also a former law enforcement officer.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I ran one of the largest district attorney's offices in America, one of the ten largest.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I put people behind bars for the rest of their life.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've broken up organized crime.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I know something about prosecuting.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And most of the law enforcement agencies in America wanted that assault weapons ban.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They don't want to go into a drug bust and be facing an AK-47.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I was hunting in Iowa last year with a sheriff from one of the counties there, and he pointed to a house in back of us, and said, "See the house over?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We just did a drug bust a week earlier, and the guy we arrested had an AK-47 lying on the bed right beside him. "
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Because of the president's decision today, law enforcement officers will walk into a place that will be more dangerous.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Terrorists can now come into America and go to a gun show and, without even a background check, buy an assault weapon today.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And that's what Osama bin Laden's handbook said, because we captured it in Afghanistan.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It encouraged them to do it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: So I believe America's less safe.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: If Tom DeLay or someone in the House said to me, "Sorry, we don't have the votes," I'd have said, "Then we're going to have a fight. "
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I'd have taken it out to the country and I'd have had every law enforcement officer in the country visit those congressmen.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We'd have won what Bill Clinton won.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: No, Bob, regrettably, we have not moved far enough along.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I regret to say that this administration has even blocked steps that could help us move further along.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'll give you an example.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I served on the Small Business Committee for a long time.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I was chairman of it once.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We used to -- you know, we have a goal there for minority set-aside programs, to try to encourage ownership in the country.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They don't reach those goals.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They don't even fight to reach those goals.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They've tried to undo them.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The fact is that in too many parts of our country, we still have discrimination.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And affirmative action is not just something that applies to people of color.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Some people have a mistaken view of it in America.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It also is with respect to women, it's with respect to other efforts to try to reach out and be inclusive in our country.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think that we have a long way to go, regrettably.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: If you look at what's happened -- we've made progress, I want to say that at the same time.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: During the Clinton years, as you may recall, there was a fight over affirmative action.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And there were many people, like myself, who opposed quotas, who felt there were places where it was overreaching.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: So we had a policy called "Mend it, don't end it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we fixed it for a reason: because there are too many people still in this country who feel the stark resistance of racism, and so we have a distance to travel.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: As president, I will make certain we travel it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: This president is the first president ever, I think, not to meet with the NAACP.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: This is a president who hasn't met with the Black Congressional Caucus.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: This is a president who has not met with the civil rights leadership of our country.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I see that as part of my job as president, and I'll make my best effort to do it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Well, first of all, it is just not true that I haven't met with the Black Congressional Caucus.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I met with the Black Congressional Caucus at the White House.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And secondly, like my opponent, I don't agree we ought to have quotas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But we ought to have an aggressive effort to make sure people are educated, to make sure when they get out of high school there's Pell Grants available for them, which is what we've done.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've expanded Pell Grants by a million students.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's the access I believe is necessary, is to make sure every child learns to read, write, add and subtract early, to be able to build on that education by going to college so they can start their careers with a college diploma.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Minority ownership of businesses are up, because we created an environment for the entrepreneurial spirit to be strong.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe part of a hopeful society is one in which somebody owns something.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Today in America more minorities own a home than ever before.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's hopeful, and that's positive.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think it's important and I share it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think that he just said that freedom is a gift from the Almighty.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Everything is a gift from the Almighty.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And as I measure the words of the Bible -- and we all do; different people measure different things -- the Koran, the Torah, or, you know, Native Americans who gave me a blessing the other day had their own special sense of connectedness to a higher being.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I was taught -- I went to a church school and I was taught that the two greatest commandments are: Love the Lord, your God, with all your mind, your body and your soul, and love your neighbor as yourself.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We have a separate and unequal school system in the United States of America.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: There's one for the people who have, and there's one for the people who don't have.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we're struggling with that today.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And the president and I have a difference of opinion about how we live out our sense of our faith.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I talked about it earlier when I talked about the works and faith without works being dead.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think we've got a lot more work to do.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And as president, I will always respect everybody's right to practice religion as they choose -- or not to practice -- because that's part of America.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Let me pay a compliment to the president, if I may.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think in those days after 9/11, I thought the president did a terrific job.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I really was moved, as well as impressed, by the speech that he gave to the Congress.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I think the hug Tom Daschle gave him at that moment was about as genuine a sense of there being no Democrats, no Republicans, we were all just Americans.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's not where we are today.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I regret to say that the president who called himself a uniter, not a divider, is now presiding over the most divided America in the recent memory of our country.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've never seen such ideological squabbles in the Congress of the United States.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've never seen members of a party locked out of meetings the way they're locked out today.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We have to change that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And as president, I am committed to changing that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I don't care if the idea comes from the other side or this side.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think we have to come together and work to change it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Over 20 years in the United States Senate, I've worked with John McCain, who's sitting here, I've worked with other colleagues.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've reached across the aisle.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've tried to find the common ground, because that's what makes us strong as Americans.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And if Americans trust me with the presidency, I can pledge to you, we will have the most significant effort, openly -- not secret meetings in the White House with special interests, not ideologically driven efforts to push people aside -- but a genuine effort to try to restore America's hope and possibilities by bringing people together.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And one of the ways we're going to do it is, I'm going to work with my friend, John McCain, to further campaign finance reform so we get these incredible amounts of money out of the system and open it up to average people, so America is really represented by the people who make up America.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: My biggest disappointment in Washington is how partisan the town is.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I had a record of working with Republicans and Democrats as the governor of Texas, and I was hopeful I'd be able to do the same thing.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we made good progress early on.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The No Child Left Behind Act, incredibly enough, was good work between me and my administration and people like Senator Ted Kennedy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we worked together with Democrats to relieve the tax burden on the middle class and all who pay taxes in order to make sure this economy continues to grow.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But Washington is a tough town.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And the way I view it is there's a lot of entrenched special interests there, people who are, you know, on one side of the issue or another and they spend enormous sums of money and they convince different senators to taut their way or different congressmen to talk about their issue, and they dig in.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'll continue, in the four years, to continue to try to work to do so.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My opponent said this is a bitterly divided time.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Pretty divided in the 2000 election.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So in other words, it's pretty divided during the 1990s as well.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're just in a period -- we've got to work to bring it -- my opponent keeps mentioning John McCain, and I'm glad he did.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: John McCain is for me for president because he understands I have the right view in winning the war on terror and that my plan will succeed in Iraq.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And my opponent has got a plan of retreat and defeat in Iraq.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: To stand up straight and not scowl.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I am -- you know it's really interesting.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I tell the people on the campaign trail, when I asked Laura to marry me, she said, "Fine, just so long as I never have to give a speech.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: "I said, "OK, you've got a deal.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: "Fortunately, she didn't hold me to that deal.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And she's out campaigning along with our girls.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And she speaks English a lot better than I do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think people understand what she's saying.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But they see a compassionate, strong, great first lady in Laura Bush.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I can't tell you how lucky I am.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: When I met her in the backyard at Joe and Jan O'Neill's in Midland, Texas, it was the classic backyard barbecue.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: O'Neill said, "Come on over.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think you'll find somebody who might interest you.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: "So I said all right.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There was only four of us there.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, I guess the president and you and I are three examples of lucky people who married up.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And some would say maybe me more so than others.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But I can take it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Can I say, if I could just say a word about a woman that you didn't ask about, but my mom passed away a couple years ago, just before I was deciding to run.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And she was in the hospital, and I went in to talk to her and tell her what I was thinking of doing.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And she looked at me from her hospital bed and she just looked at me and she said, "Remember: integrity, integrity, integrity.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: "Those are the three words that she left me with.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And my daughters and my wife are people who just are filled with that sense of what's right, what's wrong.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They also kick me around.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They don't let me get away with anything.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I can sometimes take myself too seriously.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They surely don't let me do that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I'm blessed, as I think the president is blessed, as I said last time.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've watched him with the first lady, who I admire a great deal, and his daughters.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I think we're both very lucky.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: My fellow Americans, as you heard from Bob Schieffer a moment ago, America is being tested by division.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: More than ever, we need to be united as a country.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And, like Franklin Roosevelt, I don't care whether an idea is a Republican idea or a Democrat idea.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I just care whether it works for America and whether it's going to make us stronger.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I believe I offer tested, strong leadership that can calm the waters of the troubled world.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I believe that we can together do things that are within the grasp of Americans.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We can lift our schools up.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We can create jobs that pay more than the jobs we're losing overseas.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We can have health care for all Americans.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We can further the cause of equality in our nation.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Let me just make it clear: I will never allow any country to have a veto over our security.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Just as I fought for our country as a young man, with the same passion I will fight to defend this nation that I love.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And, with faith in God and with conviction in the mission of America, I believe that we can reach higher.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I believe we can do better.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I ask you to embark on that journey with me.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I ask you for your help.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I ask you to allow me the privilege of leading this great nation of ours, of helping us to be stronger here at home and to be respected again in the world and, most of all, to be safer forever.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: In the Oval Office, there's a painting by a friend of Laura and mine named -- by Tom Lee.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And it's a West Texas painting, a painting of a mountain scene.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And he said this about it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He said, "Sarah and I live on the east side of the mountain.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's the sunrise side, not the sunset side.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we've been through a lot together during the last 3 3/4 years.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've come through a recession, a stock market decline, an attack on our country.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And yet, because of the hard work of the American people and good policies, this economy is growing.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Over the next four years, we'll make sure the economy continues to grow.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We reformed our school system, and now there's an achievement gap in America that's beginning to close.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Over the next four years, we'll continue to insist on excellence in every classroom in America so that our children have a chance to realize the great promise of America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Over the next four years, we'll continue to work to make sure health care is available and affordable.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Over the next four years, we'll continue to rally the armies of compassion, to help heal the hurt that exists in some of our country's neighborhoods.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm optimistic that we'll win the war on terror, but I understand it requires firm resolve and clear purpose.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We must never waver in the face of this enemy that -- these ideologues of hate.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And as we pursue the enemy wherever it exists, we'll also spread freedom and liberty.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We got great faith in the ability of liberty to transform societies, to convert a hostile world to a peaceful world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My hope for America is a prosperous America, a hopeful America and a safer world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well first of all, I don't agree with Senator Kennedy that Cuba is lost and certainly China was lost when this Administration came into power in 1953.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: As I look at Cuba today, I believe that we are following the right course, a course which is difficult but a course which under the circumstance is the only proper one which will see that the Cuban people get a chance to realize their aspirations of progress through freedom and that they get that with our cooperation with the other organi- of the states in the Organization of American States.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: He points to the fact that I visited Cuba while Mr. Batista was in power there.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I can only point out that if we are going to judge the Administrations in terms of our attitude toward dictators, we're glad to have a comparison with the previous administration.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Today there are only three left including the one in Cuba.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We think that's pretty good progress.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Senator Kennedy also indicated with regard to Cuba that he thought that I had made a mistake when I was in Cuba in not calling for free elections in that country.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now I'm very surprised that Senator Kennedy, who is on the Foreign Relations Committee, would have made such a statement as this kind.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: As a matter of fact in his book, The Strategy for Peace, he took the right position.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And that position is that the United States has a treaty - a treaty with all of the Organization of American States - which prohibits us from interfering in the internal affairs of any other state and prohibits them as well.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: For me to have made such a statement would been in direct uh - opposition to that treaty.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now with regard to Cuba, let me make one thing clear.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: There isn't any question but that we will defend our rights there.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: There also isn't any question but that the free people of Cuba - the people who want to be free - are going to be supported and that they will attain their freedom.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: No, Cuba is not lost, and I don't think this kind of defeatist talk by Senator Kennedy helps the situation one bit.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: In my speech last night I indicated that I thought that Cuba one day again would be free.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Where I've been critical of the Administration's policy, and where I criticized Mr. Nixon, was because in his press conference in Havana in 1955, he praised the competence and stability of the bicta- bict- Batista dictatorship - that dictatorship had killed over twenty thousand Cubans in seven years.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Secondly, I did not criticize him for not calling for free elections.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: What I criticized was the failure of the Administration to use its great influence to persuade the Cuban government to hold free elections, particularly in 1957 and 1958.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Thirdly, Arthur Gardner, a Republican Ambassador, Earl Smith, a Republican Ambassador, in succession - both have indicated in the past six weeks that they reported to Washington that Castro was a Marxist, that Raul Castro was a Communist, and that they got no effective results.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Instead our aid continued to Batista, which was ineffective; we never were on the side of freedom; we never used our influence when we could have used it most effectively - and today Cuba is lost for freedom.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I hope some day it will rise; but I don't think it will rise if we continue the same policies toward Cuba that we did in recent years, and in fact towards all of Latin America - when we've almost ignored the needs of Latin America; we've beamed not a single Voice of America program in Spanish to all of Latin America in the last eight years, except for the three months of the Hungarian uh - revolution.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Mr. Morgan, I suggested that if the United States felt that it could save the summit conference that it would have been proper for us to have expressed regrets.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: In my judgment that statement has been distorted uh - by Mr. Nixon and others in their debates around the country and in their discussions.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Mr. Lodge, on "Meet the Press" a month ago, said if there was ever a case when we did not have law an our side it was in the U-2 incident.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The U-2 flights were proper from the point of view of protecting our security.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But they were not in accordance with international law.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And I said that I felt that rather than tell the lie which we told, rather than indicate that the flights would continue - in fact, I believe Mr. Nixon himself said on May fifteenth that the flights would continue even though Mr. Herter testified before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that they had been canceled as of May twelfth - that it would have been far better that if we had expressed regrets, if that would have saved the summit, and if the summit is useful - and I believe it is.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The point that is always left out is the fact that we expressed regrets to Castro this winter; that we expressed regrets - the Eisenhower Administration expressed regrets - for a flight over Southern Russia in 1958.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We expressed regrets for a flight over Eastern Germany under this Administration.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The Soviet Union in 1955 expressed regrets to us over the Bering Sea incident.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The Chinese Communists expressed regrets to us over a plane incident in 1956.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: That is the accepted procedure between nations; and my judgment is that we should follow the advice of Theodore Roosevelt: Be strong; maintain a strong position; but also speak softly.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I believe that in those cases where international custom calls for the expression of a regret, if that would have kept the summit going, in my judgment it was a proper action.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I believe we should be stronger than we now are.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I believe we should have a stronger military force.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I believe we should increase our strength all over the world.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But I don't confuse words with strength; and in my judgment if the summit was useful, if it would have brought us closer to peace, that rather than the lie that we told - which has been criticized by all responsible people afterwards - it would have been far better for us to follow the common diplomatic procedure of expressing regrets and then try to move on.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think Kenne- Senator Kennedy is wrong on three counts.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: First of all, he's wrong in thinking th- er- even suggesting that Mr. Khrushchev might have continued the conference if we had expressed regrets.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: He knew these flights were going on long before and that wasn't the reason that he broke up the conference.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Second, he's wrong in the analogies that he makes.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The United States is a strong country.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Whenever we do anything that's wrong, we can express regrets.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now in that connection Senator Kennedy has criticized the President on the ground not only of not expressing regrets, but because he allowed this flight to take place while the summit conference - or immediately before the summit conference occurred.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: This seems to me is criticism that again is wrong on his part.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We all remember Pearl Harbor.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We lost three thousand American lives.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We cannot afford an intelligence gap.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And I just want to make my position absolutely clear with regard to getting intelligence information.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I don't intend to see to it that the United States is ever in a position where, while we're negotiating with the Soviet Union, that we discontinue our intelligence effort.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And I don't intend ever to express regrets to Mr. Khrushchev or anybody else if I'm doing something that has the support of the Congress and that is right for the purpose of protecting the security of the United States.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: My intentions in the field of civil rights have been spelled out in the Republican platform.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And there we would give statutory authority to the Committee on Government Contracts, which is an effective way of getting real progress made in this area, since about one out of every four jobs is held by and is allotted by people who have government contracts.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Certainly I think all of us agree that when anybody has a government contract, certainly the money that is spent under that contract ought to be disbursed equally without regard to the race or creed or color of the individual who is to be employed.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: That of course was rejected as was the government contracts provision by the special session of the Congress to - in which Mr. Kennedy was quite active.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And then as far as other areas are concerned, I think that we have to look to presidential leadership.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And when I speak of presidential leadership, I refer for example to our attitude on the sit-in strikes.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I have talked to Negro mothers.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I've heard them explain - try to explain - how they tell their children how they can go into a store and buy a loaf of bread but then can't go into that store and sit at the counter and get a Coca Cola.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: This is wrong, and we have to do something about it.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: So, under the circumstances, what do we do?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Well what we do is what the Attorney-General of the United States did under the direction of the President: call in the owners of chain stores and get them to take action.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now there are other places where the executive can lead, but let me just sum up by saying this: why do I talk every time I'm in the South on civil rights?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Not because I am preaching to the people of the South because this isn't just a Southern problem; it's a Northern problem and a Western problem; it's a problem for all of us.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I do it because it's the responsibility of leadership, I do it because we have to solve this problem together.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I do it right at this time particularly because when we have Khrushchev in this country - a man who has enslaved millions, a man who has slaughtered thousands - we cannot continue to have a situation where he can point the finger at the United States of America and say that we are denying rights to our citizens.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And so I say both the candidates and both the vice presidential candidates, I would hope as well - including Senator Johnson - should talk on this issue at every opportunity.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Well, Mr. Nixon hasn't discussed the two basic questions: what is going to be done and what will be his policy on implementing the Supreme Court decision of 1954?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Giving aid to schools technically that are trying to carry out the decision is not the great question.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Secondly, what's he going to do to provide fair employment?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: He's been the head of the Committee on Government Contracts that's carried out two cases, both in the District of Columbia.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: He has not indicated his support of an attempt to provide fair employment practices around the country, so that everyone can get a job regardless of their race or color.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Nor has he indicated that he will support Title Three, which would give the Attorney General additional powers to protect Constitutional rights.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: These are the great questions: equality of education in school.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: About two percent of our population of white people are - is illiterate, ten per cent of our colored population.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Sixty to seventy percent of our colored children do not finish high school.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: These are the questions in these areas that the North and South, East and West are entitled to know.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: What will be the leadership of the president in these areas to provide equality of opportunity for employment?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Equality of opportunity in the field of housing, which could be done on all federal supported housing by a stroke of the president's pen.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: What will be done to provide equality of education in all sections of the United States?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Those are the questions to which the president must establish a moral tone and moral leadership.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And I can assure you that if I'm elected president we will do so.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: From the standpoint of MR, KENNEDY: Well let me say that I think that the president operates in a number of different areas.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: First, as a legislative leader.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And as I just said that I believe that the passage of the so-called Title Three, which gives the Attorney General the power to protect Constitutional rights in those cases where it's not possible for the person involved to bring the suit.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Secondly, as an executive leader.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: There have been only six cases brought by this Attorney General under the voting bill passed in 1957 and the voting bill passed in 1960.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The right to vote is basic.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I do not believe that this Administration has implemented those bills which represent the will of the majority of the Congress on two occasions with vigor.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Thirdly, I don't believe that the government contracts division is operated with vigor.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Everyone who does business with the government should have the opportunity to make sure that they do not practice discrimination in their hiring.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And that's in all sections of the United States.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And then fourthly, as a moral leader.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: There is a very strong moral basis for this concept of equality of opportunity.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We are in a very difficult time.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We need all the talent we can get.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We sit on a conspicuous stage.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We have to practice what we preach.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We set a very high standard for ourselves.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: They set a low standard of materialism.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We preach in the Declaration of Independence and in the Constitution, in the statement of our greatest leaders, we preach very high standards; and if we're not going to be s- charged before the world with hypocrisy we have to meet those standards.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I believe the president of the United States should indicate it.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Now lastly, I believe in the case of Little Rock.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I would have hoped that the president of the United States would have been possible for him to indicate it clearly that uh - the Supreme Court decision was going to be carried out.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I would have hoped that it would have been possible to use marshals to do so.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But it wou- uh - evidently uh - under the handling of the case it was not.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I would hope an incident like that would not happen.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think if the president is responsible, if he consults with those involved, if he makes it clear that the Supreme Court decision is going to be carried out in a way that the Supreme Court planned - with deliberate speed - then in my judgment, providing he's behind action, I believe we can make uh - progress.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Now the present Administration - the President - has said - never indicated what he thought of the 1954 decision.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Unless the president speaks, then of course uh - the country doesn't speak, and Franklin Roosevelt said: "The pre - uh - the presidency of the United States is above all a place of moral leadership."
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And I believe on this great moral issue he should speak out and give his views clearly.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Senator Kennedy has expressed some hopes in this field, hopes which I think all Americans would share who want some problem - some progress in this area.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But let's look at the performance.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: When he selected his vice presidential running mate, he selected a man who had voted against most of these proposals and who opposes them at the present time.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I selected a man who stands with me in this field and who will talk with me and work with me on it.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now the Senator referred to the Committee on Government Contracts.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And yet that very committee of which I am chairman has been handicapped by the fact that we have not had adequate funds; we have not had adequate powers; we haven't had an adequate staff.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now in the special session of Congress and also in the session that preceded it, the Democratic Congress - in which there's a two-to-one Democratic majority - was asked by the President to give us the funds and give us the power to do a job and they did nothing at all, And in the special session in which Senator Kennedy was calling the signals, along with Senator Johnson, they turned it down and he himself voted against giving us the powers despite the fact that the bill had already been considered before, that it already had hearings on, and the Congress already knew what it had before it.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: All that I can say is this: what we need here are not just high hopes.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: What we need is action.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And in the field of executive leadership, I can say that I believe it's essential that the president of the United States not only set the tone but he also must lead; he must act as he talks.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Mr. Morgan, no matter how well we're doing in the cold war, we're not doing as well as we should.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And that will always be the case as long as the Communists are on the international scene, in the aggressive tac- uh - tendencies that they presently are following.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now as far as the present situation is concerned, I think it's time that we nail a few of these distortions about the United States that have been put out.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: First of all, we hear that our prestige is at an all-time low.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Senator Kennedy has been hitting that point over and over again.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I would suggest that after Premier Kush- Khrushchev's uh - performance in the United Nations, compared with President Eisenhower's eloquent speech, that at the present time Communist prestige in the world is at an all-time low and American prestige is at an all-time high.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now that, of course, is just one factor, but it's a significant one.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: When we look, for example, at the vote on the Congo.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We were on one side; they were on the other side.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Look at the votes in the United Nations over the past seven and a half years.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: That's a test of prestige.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Every time the United States has been an one side and they've been on the other side, our position has been sustained.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: In this cold war we have to recognize where it is being fought and then we have to develop programs to deal with it.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It's being fought primarily in Asia, in Africa, and in Latin America.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: What tools do we need to fight us?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Well we need, for example, economic assistance; we need technical assistance; we need exchange; we need programs of diplomatic and other character which will be effective in that area.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now Senator Kennedy a moment ago referred to the fact that there was not an adequate Voice of America program for Latin America.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I'd like to point out that in the last six years, the Democratic Congresses, of which he'd been a member, have cut twenty million dollars off of the Voice of America programs.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: They also have cut four billion dollars off of mutual security in these last six years.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: They also have cut two billion dollars off of defense.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now when they talk about our record here, it is well that they recognize that they have to stand up for their record as well.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: So let me summarize by saying this: I'm not satisfied with what we're doing in the cold war because I believe we have to step up our activities and launch an offensive for the minds and hearts and souls of men.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It must be economic; it must be technological; above all it must be ideological.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But we've got to get help from the Congress in order to do this.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Of course Mr. Nixon is wholly inaccurate when he says that the Congress has not provided more funds in fact than the President recommended for national defense.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Nineteen fifty-three we tried to put an appropriation of five billion dollars for our defenses.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I was responsible for the amendment with Senator Monroney in 1954 to strengthen our ground forces.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The Congress of the United States appropriated six hundred and seventy-seven million dollars mare than the President was willing to use up till a week ago.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Secondly, on the question of our position in the United Nations.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We all know about the vote held this week - of the five neutralists - and it was generally regarded as a defeat for the United States.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Thirdly, in 1952, there were only seven votes in favor of the admission of Red China into the United Nations.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Last year there were twenty-nine and tomorrow when the preliminary vote is held you will see a strengthening of that position or very closely to it.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We have not maintained our position and our prestige.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: A Gallup Poll taken in February of this year asking the - in eight out of nine countries - they asked the people, who do they think would be ahead by 1970 militarily and scientifically, and a majority in eight of the nine countries said the Soviet Union would be by 1970.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Governor Rockefeller has been far more critical in June of our position in the world than I have been.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The Rockefeller Brothers report, General Ridgway, General Gavin, the Gaither Report, various reports of Congressional committees all indicate that the relative strength of the p- United States both militarily, politically, psychologically, and scientifically and industrially - the relative strength of the so- of United States compared to that of the Soviet Union and the Chinese Communists together - has deteriorated in the last eight years and we should know it, and the American people should be told the facts.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We have been wholly indifferent to Latin America until the last few months.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The program that was put forward this summer, after we broke off the sugar quota with Cuba, really was done because we wanted to get through the O.A.S.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: meeting a condemnation of Russian infiltration of Cuba.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And therefore we passed an authorization - not an aid bill - which was the first time, really, since the Inter-American Bank which was founded a year ago was developed, that we really have looked at the needs of Latin America; that we have associated ourselves with those people.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Secondly, I believe that in the ca- that it's far better for the United States, instead of concentrating our aid, particularly in the underdeveloped world, on surplus military equipment - we poured three hundred million dollars of surplus military equipment into Laos.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We paid more military aid, more aid into Laos po- per - per person than in any country in the world and we ought to know now that Laos is moving from neutralism in the direction of the Communists.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I believe instead of doing that, we should concentrate our aid in long-term loans which these people can pay back either in hard money or in local currency.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: This permits them to maintain their self-respect.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: It permits us to make sure that the projects which are invested in are going to produce greater wealth.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And I believe that in cases of India and Africa and Latin America that this is where our emphasis should be.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I would strengthen the Development Loan Fund.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And Senator Fulbright, Senator Humphrey and I tried to do that.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And unless we're ready to carry out programs like that in the sixties, this battle for economic survival which these people are waging are going to be lost.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And if India should lose her battle, with thirty-five per cent of the people of the underdeveloped world within her borders, then I believe that the balance of power could move against us.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think the United States can afford to do these things.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think that we could not afford not to do these things.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: This goes to our survival.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And here in a country which if it is moving ahead, if it's developing its economy to the fullest - which we are not now - in my judgment, we'll have the resources to meet our military commitments and also our commitments overseas.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I believe it's essential that we do it because in the next ten years the balance of power is going to begin to move in the world from one direction or another - towards us or towards the Communists - and unless we begin to identify ourselves not only with the anti-Communist fight, but also with the fight against poverty and hunger, these people are going to begin to turn to the Communists as an example.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I believe we can do it.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: If we build our economy the way we should, we can afford to do these things and we must do it.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Senator Kennedy has put a great deal of stress on the necessity for economic assistance.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But it's also tremendously important to bear in mind that when you pour in money without pouring in technical assistance at w- as well, that you have a disastrous situation.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We need to step up exchange; we need to step up technical assistance so that trained people in these newly developing countries can operate the economies.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We also have to have in mind something else with regard to this whole situation in the world, and that is: that as America moves forward, we not only must think in terms of fighting Communism, but we must also think primarily in terms of the interests of these countries.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We must associate ourselves with their aspirations.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We must let them know that the great American ideals - of independence, of the right of people to be free, and of the right to progress - that these are ideals that belong not to ourselves alone, but they belong to everybody.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: This we must get across to the world.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And we can't do it unless we do have adequate funds for, for example, information which has been cut by the Congress, adequate funds for technical assistance.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The other point that I would make with regard to economic assistance and technical assistance is that the United States must not rest its case here alone.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: This is primarily an ideological battle - a battle for the minds and the hearts and the souls of men.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We must not meet the Communists purely in the field of gross atheistic materialism.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We must stand for our ideals.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: To combat unemployment we first must concentrate on the very areas to which you refer - the so-called depressed areas.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now in the last Congress - the special session of the Congress - there was a bill: one by the President, one by Senator Kennedy and members of his party.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now the bill that the President had submitted would have provided more aid for those areas that really need it - areas like Scranton and Wilkes-Barre and the areas of West Virginia - than the ones that Senator Kennedy was supporting.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: On the other hand we found that the bill got into the legislative difficulties and consequently no action was taken.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: So point one, at the highest priority we must get a bill for depressed areas through the next Congress.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I have made recommendations on that and I have discussed them previously and I will spell them out further in the campaign.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Second, as we consider this problem of unemployment, we have to realize where it is.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: In analyzing the figures we will find that our unemployment exists among the older citizens; it exists also among those who are inadequately trained; that is, those who do not have an adequate opportunity for education.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It also exists among minority groups.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: If we're going to combat unemployment, then, we have to do a better job in these areas.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: That's why I have a program for education, a program in the case of equal job opportunities, and one that would also deal with our older citizens.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now finally, with regard to the whole problem of combating recession, as you call it, we must use the full resources of the government in these respects: one, we must see to it that credit is expanded as we go into any recessionary period - and understand, I do not believe we're going into a recession.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I believe this economy is sound and that we're going to move up.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But second, in addition to that, if we do get into a recessionary period we should move on that part of the economy which is represented by the private sector, and I mean stimulate that part of the economy that can create jobs - the private sector of the economy.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: This means through tax reform and if necessary tax cuts that will stimulate more jobs.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I favor that rather than massive federal spending programs which will come into effect usually long after you've passed through the recessionary period.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: So we must use all of these weapons for the purpose of combating recession if it should come.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But I do not expect it to come.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I'm very familiar with it.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: It came out of the committee of which I was the chairman - the labor subcommittee - in fifty-five.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We passed an area redevelopment bill far more effective than the bill the Administration suggested, on two occasions, and the President vetoed it both times.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We passed a bill again this year in the cong- in the Senate and it died in the Rules Committee of the House of Representatives.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Let me make it very clear that the bill that Mr. Nixon talked about did not mention Wilkes-Barre or Scranton; it did not mention West Virginia.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Our bill was far more effective.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The bill introduced and erd- sponsored by Senator Douglas was far more effective in trying to stimulate the economy of those areas.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Secondly, he has mentioned the problem of our older citizens.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy
