Text: We should support uh - the laws which the United States has passed in order to protect us from uh - those who would destroy us from within.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We should sustain uh - the Department of Justice in its efforts and the F.B.I., and we should be continually alert.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think if the United States is maintaining a strong society here in the United States, I think that we can meet any internal threat.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The major threat is external and will continue.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I agree with Senator Kennedy's appraisal generally in this respect.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The question of Communism within the United States has been one that has worried us in the past.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It is one that will continue to be a problem for years to come.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We have to remember that the cold war that Mr. Khrushchev is waging and his colleagues are waging, is waged all over the world and it's waged right here in the United States.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It is also essential in being alert that we be fair; fair because by being fair we uphold the very freedoms that the Communists would destroy.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We uphold the standards of conduct which they would never follow.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And, in this connection, I think that uh - we must look to the future having in mind the fact that we fight Communism at home not only by our laws to deal with Communists uh - the few who do become Communists and the few who do become tra- fellow travelers, but we also fight Communism at home by moving against those various injustices which exist in our society which the Communists feed upon.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And in that connection I again would say that while Senator Kennedy says we are for the status quo, I do believe that he uh - would agree that I am just as sincere in believing that my proposals for federal aid to education, my proposals for health care are just as sincerely held as his.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The question again is not one of goals - we're for those goals - it's one of means.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: As a matter of fact your question brings out a point that I am very glad to make.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Too often in appraising whether we are moving ahead or not we think only of what the federal government is doing.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The test of whether America moves is whether the federal government, plus the state government, plus the local government, plus the biggest segment of all - individual enterprise - moves.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We have for example a gross national product of approximately five hundred billion dollars.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Roughly a hundred billion to a hundred and a quarter billion of that is the result of government activity.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Four hundred billion, approximately, is a result of what individuals do.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: That is the growth that we are looking for; it is the growth that this Administration has supported and that its policies have stimulated.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Well, I must say that the reason that the schools have been constructed is because the local school districts were willing to increase the property taxes to a tremendously high figure - in my opinion, almost to the point of diminishing returns in order to sustain these schools.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Secondly, I think we have a rich uh - country.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And I think we have a powerful country.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think what we have to do, however, is have the president and the leadership set before our country exactly what we must do in the next decade, if we're going to maintain our security in education, in economic growth, in development of natural resources.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The Soviet Union is making great gains.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: It isn't enough to compare what might have been done eight years ago, or ten years ago, or fifteen years ago, or twenty years ago.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I want to compare what we're doing with what our adversaries are doing, so that by the year 1970 the United States is ahead in education, in health, in building, in homes, in economic strength.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: First of all, I think it is well to put in perspective where we really do stand with regard to the Soviet Union in this whole matter of growth.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The Soviet Union has been moving faster than we have.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But the reason for that is obvious.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: They start from a much lower base.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Although they have been moving faster in growth than we have, we find, for example, today that their total gross national product is only forty-four per cent of our total gross national product.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: That's the same percentage that it was twenty years ago.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And as far as the absolute gap is concerned, we find that the United States is even further ahead than it was twenty years ago.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Is this any reason for complacency?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Not at all Because these are determined men.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And we have to get the very most of uh - out uh - out of our economy.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I agree with Senator Kennedy completely on that score.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Where we disagree is in the means that we would use to get the most out of our economy.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I respectfully submit that Senator Kennedy too often would rely too much on the federal government, on what it would do to solve our problems, to stimulate growth.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I believe that when we examine the Democratic platform, when we examine the proposals that he has discussed tonight, when we compare them with the proposals that I have made, that these proposals that he makes would not result in greater growth for this country than would be the case if we followed the programs that I have advocated.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: There are many of the points that he has made that I would like to comment upon.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The one in the field of health is worth mentioning.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Our health program - the one that Senator Javits and other Republican Senators, as well as I supported - is one that provides for all people over sixty-five who want health insurance, the opportunity to have it if they want it.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It provides a choice of having either government insurance or private insurance.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But it compels nobody to have insurance who does not want it.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: His program under Social Security, would require everybody who had Social Security to take government health insurance whether he wanted it or not.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And it would not cover several million people who are not covered by Social Security at all.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Here is one place where I think that our program does a better job than his.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The other point that I would make is this: this downgrading of how much things cost I think many of our people will understand better when they look at what happened when - during the Truman Administration when the government was spending more than it took in - we found savings over a lifetime eaten up by inflation.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We found the people who could least afford it - people on retired incomes uh - people on fixed incomes - we found them unable to meet their bills at the end of the month.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It is essential that a man who's president of this country certainly stand for every program that will mean for growth.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The point was made by Mr. Nixon that the Soviet production is only forty-four percent of ours.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I must say that forty-four percent and that Soviet country is causing us a good deal of trouble tonight.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I want to make sure that it stays in that relationship.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I don't want to see the day when it's sixty percent of ours, and seventy and seventy-five and eighty and ninety percent of ours, with all the force and power that it could bring to bear in order to cause our destruction.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Secondly, the Vice President mentioned medical care for the aged.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Our program was an amendment to the Kerr bill.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think it's a very clear contrast.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: In 1935, when the Social Security Act was written, ninety-four out of ninety-five Republicans voted against it.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Mr. Landon ran in 1936 to repeal it.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: In August of 1960, when we tried to get it again, but this time for medical care, we received the support of one Republican in the Senate on this occasion.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Thirdly, I think the question before the American people is: as they look at this country and as they look at the world around them, the goals are the same for all Americans.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The means are at question.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: If you feel that everything that is being done now is satisfactory, that the relative power and prestige and strength of the United States is increasing in relation to that of the Communists; that we've b- gaining more security, that we are achieving everything as a nation that we should achieve, that we are achieving a better life for our citizens and greater strength, then I agree.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think you should vote for Mr. Nixon.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But if you feel that we have to move again in the sixties, that the function of the president is to set before the people the unfinished business of our society as Franklin Roosevelt did in the thirties, the agenda for our people - what we must do as a society to meet our needs in this country and protect our security and help the cause of freedom.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: As I said at the beginning, the question before us all, that faces all Republicans and all Democrats, is: can freedom in the next generation conquer, or are the Communists going to be successful?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And if we meet our responsibilities I think freedom will conquer.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: If we fail, if we fail to move ahead, if we fail to develop sufficient military and economic and social strength here in this country, then I think that uh - the tide could begin to run against us.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And I don't want historians, ten years from now, to say, these were the years when the tide ran out for the United States.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I want them to say these were the years when the tide came in; these were the years when the United States started to move again.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: That's the question before the American people, and only you can decide what you want, what you want this country to be, what you want to do with the future.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think we're ready to move.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And it is to that great task, if we're successful, that we will address ourselves.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Miss Loomis, I think it's very appropriate that the first question in this first debate of Campaign '80 should relate to the economy of the country, because it seems to me that the people who are watching us tonight - 221 million Americans - are truly concerned about the poor rate of performance of the American economy over the last four years.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Governor Reagan is not responsible for what has happened over the last four years, nor am I.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: The man who should be here tonight to respond to those charges chose not to attend.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: But I want to answer as specifically as I can the question that you have just put to me.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Let me tell you that I, first of all, oppose an election year tax cut, whether it is the 10% across-the-board tax cut promised to the taxpayers by my opponent in this debate tonight, or whether it is the $27.5 billion tax cut promised on the 20th of August by President Carter.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I simply think that when we are confronting a budget deficit this year - and this fiscal year will end in about 10 days, and we are confronted with the possibility of a deficit of $60 billion, perhaps as much as $63 billion - that that simply would be irresponsible.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: That, once again, the printing presses will start to roll; once again we will see the monetization of that debt result in a higher rate of inflation.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Even though we've seen some hopeful signs, perhaps, in the flash report on the third quarter, that perhaps the economy is coming out of the recession, we've also seen the rise in the rate of the prime; we have seen mortgage rates back up again, a sure sign of inflation in the housing industry.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I think we've got to have fiscal restraint.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And I said at that time that one of the things that we could do, that perhaps would save as much as $5 billion to $7 billion, according, to one of the leading members of the House Budget Committee, was to recalculate the index that is used to determine the cost of living benefits that are paid to civil service retirees, to military retirees.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: That we ought to ... in addition to that, we ought to pay those retirement benefits on the basis of once a year, rather than twice a year, and save $750 billion.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: fiscal restraint, I think is necessary.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I believe that the only unpopular measures, actually, that could be, or would be applied, would be unpopular with the government, and with those.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: perhaps, some special interest groups who are tied closely to government.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I believe that inflation today is caused by government simply spending more than government takes in, at the same time that government has imposed upon business and industry, from the shopkeeper on the corner to the biggest industrial plant in America, countless harassing regulations and punitive taxes that have reduced productivity at the same time they have increased the cost of production.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And when you are reducing productivity at the same time that you are turning out printing-press money in excessive amounts, you're causing inflation.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And it isn't really higher prices, it's just, you are reducing the value of the money.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: You are robbing the American people of their savings.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And so, the plan that I have proposed - and contrary to what John says, my plan is for a phased-in tax cut over a three-year period, tax increase and depreciation allowances for business and industry to give them the capital to refurbish plant and equipment, research and development, improved technology - all of which we see our foreign competitors having, and we have the greatest percentage of outmoded industrial plant and equipment of any of the industrial nations - produce more, have stable money supply, and give the people of this country a greater share of their own savings.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, I know that this has been called inflationary by my opponent and by the man who isn't here tonight.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But I don't see where it is inflationary to have people keep more of their earnings and spend it, and it isn't inflationary for government to take that money away from them and spend it on the things it wants to spend it on.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I believe we need incentive for the individual, and for business and industry, and I believe the plan that I have submitted, with detailed backing, and which has been approved by a number of our leading economists in the country, is based on projections.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: conservative projections out for the next five years, that indicates that this plan would, by 1983, result in a balanced budget.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have to remember, when we talk a tax cut, we're only talking about reducing a tax increase, because this Administration has left us with a built-in tax increase that will amount to $86 billion next year.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: ...and $500 billion over the next five.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Mr. Movers, in addition to saying that this is no time for a tax cut, in view of the incipient signs of renewed inflation, in addition to calling for restraint in Federal spending, 15 months ago, I also suggested we ought to have an emergency excise tax on gasoline.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I say that because I think, this year, we will send $90 billion out of this country to pay for imported oil, even though that.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: those imports have been reduced.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And since I first made that proposal 15 months ago, the price of gasoline, which was then $.80, has gone up to about $1.30.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: In other words, we've had a huge increase of about $.50 a gallon since that time, and all of that increase has gone out of this country - or much of it - into the pockets of OPEC oil producers.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Whereas I have proposed we ought to take.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: put that tax on here at home, reduce our consumption of that imported oil.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Recycle those proceeds, then, back into the pockets of the American workers by reducing their tax payments.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: their Social Security tax payments by 50%.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: That, I think, in addition, would be an anti-inflationary measure that would strengthen the economy of this country.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Well, I cannot see where a $.50 a gallon tax applied to gasoline would have changed the price of gasoline.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It would still have gone up as much as it has, and the $.50 would be added on top of that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And it would be a tax paid by the consumers, and then we're asked to believe that some way, they would get this back to the consumers.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Why take it in the first place if you're going to give it back?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And John spoke about 15 years ago, on the position that he.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: or 15 months ago, on what he believed in.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Fifteen months ago, he was a cosigner and advocating the very tax cut that I am proposing, and said that that would be a forward step in fighting inflation, and that it would be beneficial to the working people of this country.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Anything that would preserve, or help us use less energy, that would be fine, and I'm for it.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But I do not believe that conservation alone is the answer to the present energy problem, because all you're doing then is staving off, by a short time, the day when you would come to the end of the energy supply.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: To say that we are limited, and at a dangerous point in this country with regard to energy, I think, is to ignore the fact.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The fact is, that in today's oil wells, there is more oil still there than we have so far taken out and used.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But it would require what is known as secondary or tertiary efforts to bring it out of the ground.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And this is known oil reserves, known supplies.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: There are hundreds of millions of acres of land that have been taken out of circulation by the Government for whatever reason they have, that is believed by the most knowledgeable oil geologists to contain probably more oil and natural gas than we have used so far since we drilled that first well 121 years ago.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have a coal supply that is equal to 50% of the world's coal supply, good for centuries, in this country.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I grant you that prices may go up, because as you go further and have to go deeper, you are adding to the cost of production.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have nuclear power, which, I believe, with the safest.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: the most stringent of safety requirements, could meet our energy needs for the next couple of decades while we go forward exploring the areas of solar power and other forms of energy that might be renewable and that would not be exhaustible.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: All of these things can be done.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: When you stop and think that we are only drilling on 2%.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: have leased only 2% of the possible.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: possibility for oil of the continental shelf around the United States; when you stop to think that the government has taken over 100 million acres of land out of circulation in Alaska, alone, that is believed by geologists to contain much in the line of minerals and energy sources, then I think it is the Government, and the Government with its own restrictions and regulations, that is creating the energy crisis.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: That we are, indeed, an energy-rich nation.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Well, Mr. Greenberg, I simply cannot allow to go unpassed the statements that have just been made by Mr. Reagan, who once again, has demonstrated, I think, a total misunderstanding of the energy crisis that confronts, not only this country, but the world, when he suggests that we have 27 years' supply of natural gas, 47 years' supply of oil, and all the rest, and that we really.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: all we have to do is to get the Government off the back of the oil industry, and that's going to be enough.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I agree with what I think is the major premise of your question, sir, that we are going to have to create a new conservation ethic in the minds of the American people.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: and that's simply why I proposed, 15 months ago, the emergency excise tax on gasoline that I did.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I did it as a security measure to be sure, because I would rather see us reduce the consumption of imported oil than have to send American boys to fight in the Persian Gulf.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: But at the same time, I think it's going to take a dramatic measure of that kind to convince the American people that we will have to reduce the use of the private automobile.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: We simply cannot have people sitting one behind the wheel of a car in these long traffic jams going in and out of our great cities.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: We are going to have to resort to van pooling, to car pooling.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: We're going to have to develop better community transportation systems, so that with buses and light rail, we can replace the private automobile in those places where it clearly is not energy-efficient.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I think that, with respect to housing, when we are consuming, even though our per capita income today is about the same as that of the Federal Republic of Germany, we are consuming about, by a factor of two, the amount of energy that they consume in that country.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Surely, there are things that we can do in the retrofitting, ;n the redesign of our homes, not only of our houses, but of our commercial structures, as well, that will make it possible for us to achieve.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: According to one study that was published a short time ago - the Harvard Business School study - indicated that just in the commercial sector alone of the economy, we could save between 30% and 40% of the energy that we consume in this country today.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: So I think, yes, we will have to change in a very appreciable way, some of the lifestyles that we now enjoy.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Well, as I've said, I am not an enemy of conservation.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I wouldn't be called a conservative if I were.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But, when my figures are challenged, as the President himself challenged them after I made them, I think it should be called to the attention of John and the others here that my figures are the figures of the Department of Energy, which has not been overly optimistic in recent years as to how much supply we have left.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: That is the same Government that, in 1920, told us we only had enough oil left for 13 years, and 19 years later, told us we only had enough left for another 15 years.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: As for saving energy and conserving, the American people haven't been doing badly at that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Because in industry today, we're producing more, over the last several years, and at 12% less use of energy than we were back in about 1973.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And motorists are using 8% less than they were back at that time of the oil embargo.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So, I think we are proving that we can go forward with conservation and benefit from that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But also, I think it is safe to say that we do have sources of energy that have not yet been used or found.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Mr. Greenberg, I think my opponent in this debate tonight is overlooking one other very important fact.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And that is, that we cannot look at this as simply a national problem.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Even though it's true that, perhaps, between now and the end of the decade, our total consumption of oil may not increase by more than, perhaps, a million or 2 million barrels of oil a day.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: The rest of the Western world, we are told, may see its consumption increase from 51 million barrels to about 66 million.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And that additional 15 million barrels is going to cause scarcity.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: It is going to cause scarcity in world markets because there are at least five reputable studies, one even by the American Petroleum Institute itself, that, I think, clearly indicate that somewhere along around the end of the present decade, total world demand for oil is simply going to exceed total available supplies.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I think that conservation - I think that a change in lifestyles - is necessary, and we had better begin to plan for that now rather than later.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Mr. Corddry, I am well aware of the present deficiencies in the Armed Forces of this country.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And in most cases, that failure to meet the test was because of a lack of manning requirements, an inability to fill many of the slots in those divisions.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Yes, I have seen figures that indicate that perhaps as of September, 1980 - this very month - that there is a shortage of about 104,000 in the ranks between E-4 and E-9.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: public reports not long ago about ships that could not leave American ports because of a lack of crews.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I talked to one of the leading former chiefs of Naval operations in my office a few weeks ago, who told me about 25,000 Chief Petty Officers being short.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: But, I think that that is clearly related to the fact that, going back to the time when the all-volunteer Army was created in 1973 - and I worked hard for it and supported it - we simply have failed to keep pace with the cost of living.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And today, on the average, the average serviceman is at least 15% - and I happen to think that's a very modest estimate - 15% below what has happened to the cost of living over that period of time.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And as a result, the families of some of our young servicemen are on food stamps today.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And I think that's shocking; it's shameful.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: So, yes, I told the American Legion National!
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Convention, the VFW National Convention - when I spoke to each of those bodies - I outlined a very specific program of increasing pay and allowances, reenlistment bonuses.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: But I would leave you with this thought, sir, to be quite specific in my answer to your question: that, of course, to protect the vital interests of this country, if that became impossible; if I could not, despite the very best efforts that I asked the Congress to put forward, to raise those pay and incentives and allowances, of course, I would not leave this country go undefended.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Mr. Corddry, it's a shame now that there are only two of us here debating, because the two that are here are in more agreement than disagreement on this particular issue, and the only one who would be disagreeing with us is the President, if he were present.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I. too, believe in the voluntary military.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: As a matter of fact, today the shortages of non-commissioned officers that John mentioned are such that if we tried to have a draft today, we wouldn't have the non-commissioned officers to train the draftees.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I believe the answer lies in just recognizing human nature and how we make everything else work in this country, when we want it to work.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Recognize that we have a voluntary military.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We are asking for men and women to join the military as a career, and we're asking them to deal with the most sophisticated of equipment.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And a young man is out there on a $1 billion carrier in charge of the maintenance of a $20 million aircraft, working 100 hours a week at times, and he's earning less for himself and his family, while he's away from his family, than he could earn if he were in one of the most menial jobs, working 40 hours a week here at home.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: As an aid to enlistment.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: we had an aid - 46% of the people who enlisted in the voluntary military up until 1977 said they did so for one particular reason, the G.I.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Bill of Rights - the fact that, by serving in the military, they could provide for a future college education.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: In 1977, we took that away from the military.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: That meant immediately 46% of your people that were signing up had no reason for signing up.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So I think it is a case of pay scale, of recognizing that if we're going to have young men and women responsible for our security, dealing with this sophisticated equipment, then for heaven's sakes, let's go out and have a pay scale that is commensurate with the sacrifice that we're asking of them.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Along with this, I think we need something else that has been allowed to deteriorate.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We need a million-man active reserve that could be called up on an instant's notice, and that would be also trained, ready to use that type of equipment.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Both of these, I think, would respond to the proper kind of incentives that we could offer these people.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The other day, I just - I'll hasten - I just saw one example.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I saw a high school that is military.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I'll catch up with it later.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I must say that I think I have better opportunity, however, of finding the necessary funds to pay what, admittedly, will be very, very substantial sums of money.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: or we passed one bill, just a couple of weeks ago in the House of Representatives for $500 million - a half a billion dollars.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: But, unlike Governor Reagan, I do not support a boondoggle like the MX missile.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I've just gotten a report from the Air Force that indicates that the 30-year lifecycle cost of that system is going to be $100 billion.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: The initial cost is about $54 billion, and then when you add in the additional costs - not only the construction of the system, the missiles and the personnel, and so on - when you add in the additional costs over the lifecycle of that system, over $100 billion.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I would propose to save the taxpayers of this country from that kind of costly boondoggle.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Well, let me just say that, with regard to that same missile system, I happen to support and believe in the missile, itself.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But that's not the $54 billion cost that John is talking about.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: He's talking about that fantastic plan of the Administration to take thousands and thousands of square miles out in the Western states.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And first, he was going to dig a racetrack and have it going around in the racetrack so it would meet the requirements of SALT II treaty, and now he's decided it'll have a straight up and down thing, so it can he both verifiable and yet hideable from the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We need the missile, I think, because we are so out of balance strategically that we lack a deterrent to a possible first assault.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And therefore, if I only had another second left, I'd say that that high school class in a military training - 40 of its 80 graduates last year entered the United States service academies; West Point, Annapolis and the Air Force Academy, and to see those young men made me very proud to realize that there are young people in this country that are prepared to go into that kind of a career in service of their country.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I don't think I'd have to go against that pledge.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think one of the problems today with the cities is Federal aid.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The mayors that I've talked to in some of our leading cities tell!
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: me that the Federal grants that come with.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: for a specific cause or a specific objective, come with such red tape, such priorities established by a bureaucracy in Washington, that the local government's hands are tied with regard to using that money as they feel could best be used, and for what they think might be the top priority.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: If they had that money without those government restrictions, every one of them has told me they could make great savings and make far greater use of the money.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: What I have been advocating is, why don't we start with the Federal Government turning back tax sources to states and local governments, as well as the responsibilities for those programs?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Seventy-five percent of the people live in the cities.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I don't know of a city in America that doesn't have the kind of problems you're talking about.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But, where are we getting the money that the Federal Government is putting out to help them?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: New York is being taxed for money that will then go to Detroit.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But Detroit is being taxed for money that, let's say, will go to Chicago, while Chicago is being taxed to help with the problems in Philadelphia.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Wouldn't it make a lot more sense if the government let them keep their own money there in the first place?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But there are other things that we can do with the inner cities, and I've believed.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I have talked of having zones in those cities that are run down, where there is a high percentage of people on welfare, and offer tax incentives.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The government isn't getting a tax now from businesses there because they aren't there, or from individuals who are on welfare rather than working.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And why don't we offer incentives for business and industry to start up in those zones?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Give them a tax moratorium for a period if they build and develop there.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The individuals that would then get jobs - give them a break that encourages them to leave the social welfare programs and go to work.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We could have an urban homestead act.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We've got thousands and thousands of homes owned by government boarded up, being vandalized, that have been taken in mortgage foreclosures.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: What if we had a homestead act, and said to the people, for $1 we sell you this house.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: All have to do is agree to refurbish it, make it habitable, and live in it - just as 100 or more years ago, we did with the open land in this country - urban .
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Mr. May, I recently saw a Princeton University study that indicated that the cities of America - the large cities of this country - are in worse shape today than they were in 1960.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: It seems to totally belie the claim that I heard President Carter make a few days ago, that he was the first President that had come forth with a real urban strategy to meet the problems of urban America.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Incidentally, just this past week, the crown jewel in that program that he had devised was stolen, I guess, because a conference committee turned down the ambitious plan that he had to increase the amount of money that would be available to the Economic Development Administration for loan guarantees and direct loans and credits.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I'm happy to say that, in contrast to that, the Anderson-Lucey platform for America, program for the 80s, has devoted considerable time, and in very specific detail, we have talked about two things that ought to be done to aid urban America.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: We call, first of all, for the creation of a $4 billion urban reinvestment trust fund to do exactly what you spoke about in your question - to rebuild the streets, to rebuild the cities, the leaking water mains.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I was in North Pittsburgh - I think it was a few weeks ago, on my campaign - the water mains in that city had begun to leak, and literally, there wasn't money available to fix them.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And until we can begin to recreate the basic infrastructure of the great cities of America, particularly in the upper Midwest and in the Northeast, they simply are not going to provide the kind of economic climate that will enable them to retain industry, enable them to retain the kind of solid industrial base that they need, so that they can provide jobs.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: It's going to come from the dedication, by 1984, of the excise revenues that today are being collected by the Federal Government on alcohol and tobacco.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: That money, I think, ought to be put into rebuilding the base of our cities.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: In addition to that, jobs programs to re-employ the youth in our cities would be very high on my priority list, both the Youth Opportunities Act of 1980 and a billion-dollar program that I would recommend to put youth to work in energy projects, in conservation projects, in projects that would carry out some of the great national goals of our country.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: John claims that he is making plain where the money will come from.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It will come from the pockets of the people.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It will come from the pockets of the people who are living in those very areas.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: if Pittsburgh does not have the money to fix the leaking water mains, it's because the Federal Government has pre-empted.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, the Federal Government is going to turn around and say, well you have this problem; we will now hand you the money to do it.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But the Federal Government doesn't make money.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It just takes - from the people.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And in my view, this is not the answer to the problem.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Stand in the South Bronx as I did, in the spot where Jimmy Carter made his promise that he was going to, with multi-billion dollar programs, refurbish that area that looks like bombed-out London in World War II.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I stood there, and I met the people.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I heard them ask just for something that would give them hope.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I believe that, while all of the promises have been broken, they've never been carried out.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But I believe that my plan might offer an opportunity for that, if we would move into those areas and let, encourage - with the tax incentive - the private sector, to develop and to create the jobs for the people.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Well, of course, where has the private sector been, Governor Reagan, during the years that our cities have been deteriorating?
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: It seems to me that to deny the responsibility of the Federal Government to do something about our crumbling cities is to deny the opportunity for one thing: To 55% of the black population of our country that is locked within the inner cities of the metropolitan areas of our country.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: We simply cannot ignore the fact that, in those cities today, we have 55% youth unemployment among black and Hispanic youth.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: It's because they have lost their industry.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And why have they lost their industry?
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: It's because they no longer present the kind of viable economic climate that makes it possible for industry to remain there, or to locate there.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I think Government has a responsibility to find jobs for the youth of this country, and that the place to start is to assist in the very important and necessary task of helping cities rebuild.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Miss Quinn, I would be very happy to accept the challenge of your question tonight, to tell the voters of this country exactly what I think it's going to cost, because I believe that all too often in past elections, politicians have simply been promising people things that they cannot deliver.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: When these Presidential Debates were held just four years ago, I remember the incumbent President, who was willing to debate, President Ford, telling the American people that they simply ought not to vote for somebody who promised more than they could deliver.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Well, we've seen what has happened.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: We haven't gotten either the economies in Government that were promised; we haven't gotten the 4% inflation that we were supposed to get at the end of Mr. Carter's first term.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Instead we had, I think, in the second quarter, a Consumer Price Index registering around 12%.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And nobody really knows, with the latest increase in the Wholesale Price Index - that's about 18% on an annualized basis - what it's going to be.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I think my programs are far less inflationary than those of Governor Reagan.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: His own running mate, when he was running for the Presidency, said that they would cost 30% inflation inside of two years, and he cited his leading economic advisor, a very distinguished economist, Paul Macavoy, as the source of that information.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: He went so far as to call it "brutal economics."
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I've been very careful - I have been very careful in saying that what I'm going to do is to bring Federal spending under control first.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I would like to stand here and promise the American people a tax cut, as Governor Reagan has done.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: But, you know, it's gotten to be about $122 difference.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And they figured out that between the tax cut that Governor Reagan is promising the American people, and the tax cut that Jimmy Carter is promising in 198I, his is worth about $122 more.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: So you, dear voters, are out there on the auction block, and these two candidates are bidding for your votes.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I'm going to wait until I see that that inflation rate is going down, before I even begin to phase in the business tax cuts that I've talked about.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: But I think, by improving productivity, they would be far less inflationary than the consumption-oriented tax cut that Governor Reagan is recommending.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Miss Quinn, I don't have to.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have a back-up paper to my economic speech of a couple of weeks ago in Chicago, that gives all of the figures.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And we used - yes, we used - the Senate Budget Committee's projections for five years, which are based on an average inflation rate of 7.5% - which, I think, that under our plan, can be eliminated.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And eliminated probably more quickly than our plan, but we wanted to be so conservative with it, that people would see how.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: how well it could be done.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, John's been in the Congress for 20 years.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And John tells us that first, we've got to reduce spending before we can reduce taxes.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Well, if you've got a kid that's extravagant, you can lecture him all you want to about his extravagance.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Or you can cut his allowance and achieve the same end much quicker.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But Government has never reduced Government does not tax to get the money it needs.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Government always needs the money it gets.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And when John talks about his non-inflationary plan, as far as I have been able to learn, there are 88 proposals in it that call for additional Government spending programs.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, I speak with some confidence of our plan, because I took over a state - California - 10% of the population of this nation - a state that, if it were a nation, would be the seventh-ranking economic power in the world.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And that state we controlled spending.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We cut the rate of increase in spending in half.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But at the same time, we gave back to the people of California - in tax rebates, tax credits, tax cuts - $5.7 billion.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I vetoed 993 measures without having a veto overturned.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And among those vetoes, I stopped $16 billion in additional spending.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And the funny thing was that California, which is normally above the national average in inflation and unemployment, for those six years for the first time, was below the national average in both inflation and unemployment.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have considered inflation in our figures.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We deliberately took figures that we, ourselves, believed were too conservative.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I believe the budget can be balanced by 1982 or 1983, and it is a combination of planned reduction of the tax increase that Carter has built into the economy, and that's what he's counting on for his plan.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But he's going to get a half-a-trillion dollars more over the next five years that he can use for additional programs, or hopefully, someplace down the line, balancing the budget.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We believe that that's too much additional money to take out of the pockets of the people.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Mr. Moyers, I'm not here to debate Governor Reagan's record as Governor.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: But I do know that, despite his pledge to reduce state Government spending, that it rose from $4.6 billion when he took office in 1967, to $10.2 billion during his eight years in office.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: more than doubled, and it rose at a faster rate than spending was rising in the Federal Government.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: But on his very optimistic figures about his tax cut producing a balanced budget by 1983, and the fact that he is using, he says, the figures of the Senate Budget Committee, that Senate Budget Committee Report does not accommodate all of the Reagan defense plans.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: It doesn't accommodate the expenditures that he calls for, for accelerated development and deployment of a new manned strategic bomber, for a permanent fleet in the Indian Ocean, for the restoration of the fleet to 600 ships, to the development and deployment of a dedicated modern aircraft interceptor.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: In other words, I have seen his program costed out to the point where it would amount to more than $300 million a year, just for the military.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And I think the figures that he has given are simply not going to stand up.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Well, some people look up figures, and some people make up figures.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And John has just made up some very interesting figures.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We took the Senate report, of course.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But we did factor in our own ideas with regard to increases in the projected military spending that we believe would, over a period of time, do what is necessary.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The truth of the matter is, we did cut the increase in spending in half.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It at the John doesn't quite realize - he's never held an executive position of that kind.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I think being Governor of California is probably the closest thing to the Presidency, if that's possible, of any executive job in America today - because it is the most populous state.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I can only tell him that we reduced, in proportion of other states, the per capita spending, the per capita size of Government - we only increased the size of Government one-twelfth what it had increased in the preceding eight years.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And one journal, the San Francisco Chronicle, a respected newspaper, said there was no question about the fact that Governor Reagan had prevented the State of California from going bankrupt.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Oh, I'm it's my question.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But whether I agree or disagree with some individual, or what he may say, or how he may say it, I don't think there's any way that we can suggest that because people believe in God and go to church, that they should not want reflected in those people and those causes they support, their own belief in morality, and in the high traditions and principles which we've abandoned so much in this country.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Going around this country, I think that I have found a great hunger in America for a spiritual revival.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: For a belief that law must be based on a higher law.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: For a return to traditions and values that we once had.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Our Government, in its most sacred documents - the Constitution and the Declaration of Independence and all - speak of man being created, of a Creator.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: That we're a nation under God.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, I have thought for a long time that too many of our churches have been too reluctant to speak up in behalf of what they believe is proper in Government, and they have been too too lax in interfering, in recent years, with Government's invasion of the family itself, putting itself between parent and child.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I vetoed a number of bills of that kind myself, when I was in California.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But I do believe that no one in this country should be denied the right to express themselves, or to even try to persuade others to follow their leader.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: That's what elections are all about.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Ms. Golden, certainly the church has the right to take a position on moral issues.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: But to try, as occurred in the case that you mentioned - that specific case - to try to tell the parishioners of any church, of any denomination, how they should vote, or for whom they should vote, I think violates the principle of separation of church and state.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I think that is a moral issue that ought to be left to the freedom of conscience of the individual.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And for the state to interfere with a Constitutional amendment, and tell a woman that she must carry that pregnancy to term, regardless of her personal belief, that, I think, violates freedom of conscience as much as anything that I can think of.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And he is also running on a platform that suggests a litmus test for the selection of judges - that only judges that hold a certain, quote, "view," on the sanctity of family life, ought to be appointed to the Federal Judiciary, one of the three great independent branches of our Government.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I believe in freedom of choice.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I don't believe in Constitutional Amendments that would interfere with that.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I don't believe in trying to legislate new tests for the selection of the Federal Judiciary.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And I have said freely, all over this country, that it was a mistake for me or anyone to ever try to put the Judeo-Christian heritage of this country, important as it is, and important as my religious faith is to me - it's a very deeply personal matter.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: But for me to try, in this very pluralistic society of ours, to try to frame any definition, whatever, of what that belief should be, is wrong.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And so, not once, but twice - in 1971 - I voted on the floor of the House of Representatives against a Constitutional amendment that tried to bring prayer back into the public schools.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I think mother ought to whisper to Johnny and to Susie, as they button their coats in the morning and leave for the classroom, "Be sure to say a prayer before you start your day's work."
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: But I don't think that the state, the Board of Regents, a Board of Education, or any state official, should try to compose that prayer for a child to recite.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: The litmus test that John says is in the Republican platform, says no more than the judges to be appointed should have a respect for innocent life.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, I don't think that's a bad idea.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think all of us should have a respect for innocent life.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: That's the one who is being aborted.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I've noticed that everybody that is for abortion has already been born.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I I think that, technically, I know this is a difficult and an emotional problem, and many people sincerely feel on both sides of this, but I do believe that maybe we could find the answer through medical evidence, if we would determine once and for all, is an unborn child a human being?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I happen to believe it is.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I also think that that unborn child has a right to be wanted.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And I also believe, sir, that the most personal intimate decision that any woman is ever called upon to make is the decision as to whether or not she shall carry a pregnancy to term.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And for the state to interfere in that decision, under whatever guise, and with whatever rationale, for the state to try to take over in that situation, and by edict, command what the individual shall do, and substitute itself for that individual's conscience, for her right to consult her rabbi, her minister, her priest, her doctor - any other counselor of her choice - I think goes beyond what we want to ever see accomplished in this country, if we really believe in the First Amendment: if we really believe in freedom of choice and the right of the individual.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Before beginning my closing remarks, here, I would just like to remark a concern that I have that we have criticized the failures of the Carter policy here rather considerably, both of us this evening.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And there might be some feeling of unfairness about this because he was not here to respond.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But I believe it would have been much more unfair to have had John Anderson denied the right to participate in this debate.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I want to express my appreciation to the League of Women Voters for adopting a course with which I believe the great majority of Americans are in agreement.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, as to my closing remarks: I've always believed that this land was placed here between the two great oceans by some divine plan.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: That it was placed here to be found by a special kind of people - people who had a special love for freedom and who had the courage to uproot themselves and leave hearth and homeland, and came to what, in the beginning, was the most undeveloped wilderness possible.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We came from 100 different corners of the earth.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We spoke a multitude of tongues.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We landed on this Eastern shore and then went out over the mountains and the prairies and the deserts and the far western mountains to the Pacific, building cities and towns and farms, and schools and churches.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: If wind, water or fire destroyed them, we built them again.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And in so doing, at the same time, we built a new breed of human called an American - a proud, an independent., and a most compassionate individual, for the most part.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Two hundred years ago, Tom Paine, when the 13 tiny colonies were trying to become a nation, said, we have it in our power to begin the world over again.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: we're confronted with the horrendous problems that we've discussed here tonight.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And some people in high positions of leadership, tell us that the answer is to retreat.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: That the best is over.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: That we must cut back.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: That we must share in an ever-increasing scarcity.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: That we must, in the failure to be able to protect our national security as it is today, we must not be provocative to any possible adversary.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Well, we, the living Americans, have gone through four wars.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We've gone through a Great Depression in our lifetime that literally was worldwide and almost brought us to our knees.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But we came through all of those things and we achieved even new heights and new greatness.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The living Americans today have fought harder, paid a higher price for freedom, and done more to advance the dignity of man than any people who ever lived on this earth.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: For 200 years, we've lived in the future, believing that tomorrow would be better than today, and today would be better than yesterday.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I'm not running for the Presidency because I believe that I can solve the problems we've discussed tonight.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We can meet our destiny - and that destiny to build a land here that will be, for all mankind, a shining city on a hill.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think we ought to get at it.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Mr. Movers, President Carter was not right a few weeks ago when he said that the American people were confronted with only two choices, with only two men, and with only two parties.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I think you've seen tonight in this debate that Governor Reagan and I have agreed on exactly one thing - we are both against the reimposition of a peacetime draft.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: We have disagreed, I believe, on virtually every other issue.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I respect him for showing tonight - for appearing here, and I thank the League of Women Voters for the opportunity that they have given me.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I am running for President as an Independent because I believe our country is in trouble.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I believe that all of us are going to have to begin to work together to solve our problems.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: If you think that I am a spoiler, consider these facts: Do you really think that our economy is healthy?
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Do you really think that 8 million Americans being out of work and the 50% unemployment among the youth of our country are acceptable?
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Do you really think that our armed forces are really acceptably strong in those areas of conventional capability where they should be?
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Do you think that our political institutions are working the way they should when literally only half of our citizens vote?
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I don't think you do think that.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And therefore, I think you ought to consider doing something about it, and voting for an Independent in 1980.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: You know, a generation of office seekers has tried to tell the American people that they could get something for nothing.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: It's been a time, therefore, of illusion and false hopes, and the longer it continues, the more dangerous it becomes.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: We've got to stop drifting.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: What I wish tonight so desperately is that we had had more time to talk about some of the other issues that are so fundamentally important.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: And he went on to cite three issues that their platforms totally ignore: atomic warfare, Presidential Directive 59 notwithstanding.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: If we don't resolve that issue, all others become irrelevant.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: The issue of our natural resources; the right of posterity to inherit the earth, and what kind of earth will it be?
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: The issue of nationalism - the recognition, he says, that every major problem confronting us is global, and cannot be solved by nationalism here or elsewhere - that is chauvinistic, that is parochial, that is as anachronistic as states' rights was in the days of Jefferson Davis.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: Those are some of the great issues - atomic warfare, the use of our natural resources, and the issue of nationalism - that I intend to be talking about in the remaining six weeks of this campaign, and I dare hope that the American people will be listening and that they will see that an Independent government of John Anderson and Patrick Lucey can give us the kind of coalition government that we need in 1980 to begin to solve our problems.
Speaker: John Anderson

Text: I appreciate your -- your question, and thank you for being here this evening and to all of those from Nassau County that have come, thank you for your time.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Thank you to Hofstra University and to Candy Crowley for organizing and leading this -- this event.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Your question -- your question is one that's being asked by college kids all over this country.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I can't find a job.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I've got three part- time jobs.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They're just barely enough to pay for my food and pay for an apartment.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I can't begin to pay back my student loans."
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So what we have to do is two things.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And also make sure that when they get out of college, there's a job.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: When I was governor of Massachusetts, to get a high school degree, you had to pass an exam.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: If you graduated in the top quarter of your airlines, we gave you a John and Abigail Adams scholarship, four years tuition free in the college of your choice in Massachusetts, it's a public institution.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I want to make sure we keep our Pell grant program growing.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're also going to have our loan program, so that people are able to afford school.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But the key thing is to make sure you can get a job when you get out of school.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And what's happened over the last four years has been very, very hard for America's young people.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I want you to be able to get a job.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: With half of college kids graduating this year without a college -- excuse me, without a job.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And without a college level job, that's just unacceptable.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And likewise you've got more and more debt on your back.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So more debt and less jobs.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I know what it takes to create good jobs again.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I know what it takes to make sure that you have the kind of opportunity you deserve.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And kids across this country are going to recognize, we're bringing back an economy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's not going to be like the last four years.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The middle-class has been crushed over the last four years, and jobs have been too scarce.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I know what it takes to bring them back, and I'm going to do that, and make sure that when you graduate -- when do you graduate?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: When you come out in 2014, I presume I'm going to be president.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm going to make sure you get a job.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And the fact that you're making an investment in higher education is critical.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Not just to you, but to the entire nation.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, the most important thing we can do is to make sure that we are creating jobs in this country.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But not just jobs, good paying jobs.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Ones that can support a family.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And there are a bunch of things we can do to make sure your future is bright.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number one, I want to build manufacturing jobs in this country again.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now when Governor Romney said we should let Detroit go bankrupt.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I said we're going to bet on American workers and the American auto industry and it's come surging back.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I want to do that in industries, not just in Detroit, but all across the country and that means we change our tax code so we're giving incentives to companies that are investing here in the United States and creating jobs here.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It also means we're helping them and small businesses to export all around the world to new markets.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number two, we've got to make sure that we have the best education system in the world.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the fact that you're going to college is great, but I want everybody to get a great education and we've worked hard to make sure that student loans are available for folks like you, but I also want to make sure that community colleges are offering slots for workers to get retrained for the jobs that are out there right now and the jobs of the future.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number three, we've got to control our own energy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, not only oil and natural gas, which we've been investing in; but also, we've got to make sure we're building the energy source of the future, not just thinking about next year, but ten years from now, 20 years from now.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's why we've invested in solar and wind and biofuels, energy efficient cars.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got to reduce our deficit, but we've got to do it in a balanced way.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Asking the wealthy to pay a little bit more along with cuts so that we can invest in education like yours.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And let's take the money that we've been spending on war over the last decade to rebuild America, roads, bridges schools.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We do those things, not only is your future going to be bright but America's future is going to bright as well.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And a lot of them, as you say, Candy, have been out of work for a long, long, long time.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The president's policies have been exercised over the last four years and they haven't put Americans back to work.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have fewer people working today than we had when the president took office.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: If the -- the unemployment rate was 7.8 percent when he took office, it's 7.8 percent now.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But if you calculated that unemployment rate, taking back the people who dropped out of the workforce, it would be 10.7 percent.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have not made the progress we need to make to put people back to work.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's why I put out a five-point plan that gets America 12 million new jobs in four years and rising take-home pay.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's going to help Jeremy get a job when he comes out of school.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's going to help people across the country that are unemployed right now.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And one thing that the president said, which I want to make sure that we understand, he said that I said we should take Detroit bankrupt.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: My plan was to have the company go through bankruptcy like 7-Eleven did and Macy's and Condell (ph) Airlines and come out stronger.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I know he keeps saying, you want to take Detroit bankrupt.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, the president took Detroit bankrupt.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You took General Motors bankrupt.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So when you say that I wanted to take the auto industry bankrupt, you actually did.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I think it's important to know that that was a process that was necessary to get those companies back on their feet, so they could start hiring more people.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That was precisely what I recommended and ultimately what happened.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Candy, what Governor Romney said just isn't true.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: He wanted to take them into bankruptcy without providing them any way to stay open.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we would have lost a million jobs.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that -- don't take my word for it, take the executives at GM and Chrysler, some of whom are Republicans, may even support Governor Romney.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But they'll tell you his prescription wasn't going to work.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And Governor Romney's says he's got a five-point plan?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Governor Romney doesn't have a five-point plan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: He has a one-point plan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that plan is to make sure that folks at the top play by a different set of rules.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's been his philosophy in the private sector, that's been his philosophy as governor, that's been his philosophy as a presidential candidate.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You can make a lot of money and pay lower tax rates than somebody who makes a lot less.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You can ship jobs overseas and get tax breaks for it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You can invest in a company, bankrupt it, lay off the workers, strip away their pensions, and you still make money.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's exactly the philosophy that we've seen in place for the last decade.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's what's been squeezing middle class families.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we have fought back for four years to get out of that mess.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The last thing we need to do is to go back to the very same policies that got us there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That -- that Detroit -- that Detroit answer...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: ... and the rest of the answer, way off the mark.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The most important thing we can do is to make sure we control our own energy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So here's what I've done since I've been president.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We have seen increases in coal production and coal employment.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But what I've also said is we can't just produce traditional source of energy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's why we doubled fuel efficiency standards on cars.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That means that in the middle of the next decade, any car you buy, you're going to end up going twice as far on a gallon of gas.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's why we doubled clean -- clean energy production like wind and solar and biofuels.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And all these things have contributed to us lowering our oil imports to the lowest levels in 16 years.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, I want to build on that.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that means, yes, we still continue to open up new areas for drilling.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We continue to make it a priority for us to go after natural gas.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we can do it in an environmentally sound way.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But we've also got to continue to figure out how we have efficiency energy, because ultimately that's how we're going to reduce demand and that's what's going to keep gas prices lower.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, Governor Romney will say he's got an all-of-the-above plan, but basically his plan is to let the oil companies write the energy policies.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So he's got the oil and gas part, but he doesn't have the clean energy part.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And if we are only thinking about tomorrow or the next day and not thinking about 10 years from now, we're not going to control our own economic future.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Because China, Germany, they're making these investments.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I'm not going to cede those jobs of the future to those countries.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I expect those new energy sources to be built right here in the United States.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's going to help Jeremy get a job.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's also going to make sure that you're not paying as much for gas.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, let's look at the president's policies, all right, as opposed to the rhetoric, because we've had four years of policies being played out.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And the president's right in terms of the additional oil production, but none of it came on federal land.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: As a matter of fact, oil production is down 14 percent this year on federal land, and gas production was down 9 percent.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Because the president cut in half the number of licenses and permits for drilling on federal lands, and in federal waters.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well a lot of it came from the Bakken Range in North Dakota.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: What was his participation there?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The administration brought a criminal action against the people drilling up there for oil, this massive new resource we have.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And what was the cost?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: 20 or 25 birds were killed and brought out a migratory bird act to go after them on a criminal basis.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Look, I want to make sure we use our oil, our coal, our gas, our nuclear, our renewables.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I believe very much in our renewable capabilities; ethanol, wind, solar will be an important part of our energy mix.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But what we don't need is to have the president keeping us from taking advantage of oil, coal and gas.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This has not been Mr. Oil, or Mr. Gas, or Mr. Coal.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Talk to the people that are working in those industries.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: People grabbed my arms and said, "Please save my job."
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The head of the EPA said, "You can't build a coal plant.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You'll virtually -- it's virtually impossible given our regulations."
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: When the president ran for office, he said if you build a coal plant, you can go ahead, but you'll go bankrupt.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's not the right course for America.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Let's take advantage of the energy resources we have, as well as the energy sources for the future.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And if we do that, if we do what I'm planning on doing, which is getting us energy independent, North America energy independence within eight years, you're going to see manufacturing jobs come back.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Because our energy is low cost, that are already beginning to come back because of our abundant energy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney
