Text: In the course of that, I think the president's campaign has tried to characterize me as -- as someone who's very different than who I am.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I care about 100 percent of the American people.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I understand what it takes to make a bright and prosperous future for America again.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I spent my life in the private sector, not in government.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm a guy who wants to help with the experience I have, the American people.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: My -- my passion probably flows from the fact that I believe in God.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I believe we're all children of the same God.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I believe we have a responsibility to care for one another.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I -- I served as a missionary for my church.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I served as a pastor in my congregation for about 10 years.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I've sat across the table from people who were out of work and worked with them to try and find new work or to help them through tough times.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I went to the Olympics when they were in trouble to try and get them on track.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And as governor of my state, I was able to get 100 percent of my people insured, all my kids, about 98 percent of the adults.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I was able also to get our schools ranked number one in the nation, so 100 percent of our kids would have a bright opportunity for a future.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I understand that I can get this country on track again.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We don't have to settle for what we're going through.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We don't have to settle for gasoline at four bucks.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We don't have to settle for unemployment at a chronically high level.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We don't have to settle for 47 million people on food stamps.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We don't have to settle for 50 percent of kids coming out of college not able to get work.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We don't have to settle for 23 million people struggling to find a good job.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: If I become president, I'll get America working again.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'll make sure we can reform Medicare and Social Security to preserve them for coming -- coming generations.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The president said he would.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'll get our incomes up.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And by the way, I've done these things.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I served as governor and showed I could get them done.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Barry, I think a lot of this campaign, maybe over the last four years, has been devoted to this nation that I think government creates jobs, that that somehow is the answer.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's not what I believe.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I believe in self-reliance and individual initiative and risk takers being rewarded.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I also believe that everybody should have a fair shot and everybody should do their fair share and everybody should play by the same rules, because that's how our economy's grown.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's how we built the world's greatest middle class.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And -- and that is part of what's at stake in this election.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There's a fundamentally different vision about how we move our country forward.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I believe Governor Romney is a good man.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Loves his family, cares about his faith.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I also believe that when he said behind closed doors that 47 percent of the country considered themselves victims who refuse personal responsibility, think about who he was talking about.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Folks on Social Security who've worked all their lives.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Veterans who've sacrificed for this country.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Students who are out there trying to hopefully advance their own dreams, but also this country's dreams.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Soldiers who are overseas fighting for us right now.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: People who are working hard every day, paying payroll tax, gas taxes, but don't make enough income.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's what I've been doing for the last four years.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Because if they succeed, I believe the country succeeds.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: When my grandfather fought in World War II and he came back and he got a G.I.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Bill and that allowed him to go to college, that wasn't a handout.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That was something that advanced the entire country.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I want to make sure that the next generation has those same opportunities.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's why I'm asking for your vote and that's why I'm asking for another four years.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I want to first, obviously, thank Belmont University, Tom, thank you, and to all of you who are participating tonight and those of you who sent e-mail questions in.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I think everybody knows now we are in the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And a lot of you I think are worried about your jobs, your pensions, your retirement accounts, your ability to send your child or your grandchild to college.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I believe this is a final verdict on the failed economic policies of the last eight years, strongly promoted by President Bush and supported by Senator McCain, that essentially said that we should strip away regulations, consumer protections, let the market run wild, and prosperity would rain down on all of us.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It hasn't worked out that way.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so now we've got to take some decisive action.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, step one was a rescue package that was passed last week.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got to make sure that works properly.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that means strong oversight, making sure that investors, taxpayers are getting their money back and treated as investors.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It means that we are cracking down on CEOs and making sure that they're not getting bonuses or golden parachutes as a consequence of this package.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I'll tell you what, the Treasury should demand that money back and those executives should be fired.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But that's only step one.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that means tax cuts for the middle-class.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It means help for homeowners so that they can stay in their homes.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It means that we are helping state and local governments set up road projects and bridge projects that keep people in their jobs.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You need somebody working for you and you've got to have somebody in Washington who is thinking about the middle class and not just those who can afford to hire lobbyists.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And Senator Obama, it's good to be with you at a town hall meeting.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Americans are angry, they're upset, and they're a little fearful.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We've got to stop sending $700 billion a year to countries that don't want us very -- like us very much.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We obviously have to stop this spending spree that's going on in Washington.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Do you know that we've laid a $10 trillion debt on these young Americans who are here with us tonight, $500 billion of it we owe to China?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I think that this problem has become so severe, as you know, that we're going to have to do something about home values.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You know that home values of retirees continues to decline and people are no longer able to afford their mortgage payments.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: As president of the United States, Alan, I would order the secretary of the treasury to immediately buy up the bad home loan mortgages in America and renegotiate at the new value of those homes -- at the diminished value of those homes and let people be able to make those -- be able to make those payments and stay in their homes.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But we all know, my friends, until we stabilize home values in America, we're never going to start turning around and creating jobs and fixing our economy.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I know how the do that, my friends.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And it's my proposal, it's not Senator Obama's proposal, it's not President Bush's proposal.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But I know how to get America working again, restore our economy and take care of working Americans.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You know, that's a tough question and there's a lot of qualified Americans.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: A supporter of Senator Obama's is Warren Buffett.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He has already weighed in and helped stabilize some of the difficulties in the markets and with companies and corporations, institutions today.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I like Meg Whitman, she knows what it's like to be out there in the marketplace.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Meg Whitman was CEO of a company that started with 12 people and is now 1.3 million people in America make their living off eBay.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Maybe somebody here has done a little business with them.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But the point is it's going to have to be somebody who inspires trust and confidence.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Because the problem in America today to a large extent, Tom, is that we don't have trust and confidence in our institutions because of the corruption on Wall Street and the greed and excess and the cronyism in Washington, D.C.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, Warren would be a pretty good choice -- Warren Buffett, and I'm pleased to have his support.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But there are other folks out there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The key is making sure that the next treasury secretary understands that it's not enough just to help those at the top.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got to help the middle class.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we've -- you know, Senator McCain and I have some fundamental disagreements on the economy, starting with Senator McCain's statement earlier that he thought the fundamentals of the economy were sound.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Part of the problem here is that for many of you, wages and incomes have flat-lined.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: For many of you, it is getting harder and harder to save, harder and harder to retire.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But underlying that is loss of jobs and loss of income.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's something that the next treasury secretary is going to have to work on.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, thank you, Oliver, and that's an excellent question, because as you just described it, bailout, when I believe that it's rescue, because -- because of the greed and excess in Washington and Wall Street, Main Street was paying a very heavy price, and we know that.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I left my campaign and suspended it to go back to Washington to make sure that there were additional protections for the taxpayer in the form of good oversight, in the form of taxpayers being the first to be paid back when our economy recovers -- and it will recover -- and a number of other measures.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But you know, one of the real catalysts, really the match that lit this fire was Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I'll bet you, you may never even have heard of them before this crisis.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But you know, they're the ones that, with the encouragement of Senator Obama and his cronies and his friends in Washington, that went out and made all these risky loans, gave them to people that could never afford to pay back.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And you know, there were some of us that stood up two years ago and said we've got to enact legislation to fix this.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We've got to stop this greed and excess.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Meanwhile, the Democrats in the Senate and some -- and some members of Congress defended what Fannie and Freddie were doing.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Meanwhile, they were getting all kinds of money in campaign contributions.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama was the second highest recipient of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac money in history -- in history.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So this rescue package means that we will stabilize markets, we will shore up these institutions.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That's why we're going to have to go out into the housing market and we're going to have to buy up these bad loans and we're going to have to stabilize home values, and that way, Americans, like Alan, can realize the American dream and stay in their home.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But Fannie and Freddie were the catalysts, the match that started this forest fire.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: There were some of us -- there were some of us that stood up against it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: There were others who took a hike.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, Oliver, first, let me tell you what's in the rescue package for you.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Right now, the credit markets are frozen up and what that means, as a practical matter, is that small businesses and some large businesses just can't get loans.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If they can't get a loan, that means that they can't make payroll.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If they can't make payroll, then they may end up having to shut their doors and lay people off.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And if you imagine just one company trying to deal with that, now imagine a million companies all across the country.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So it could end up having an adverse effect on everybody, and that's why we had to take action.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But we shouldn't have been there in the first place.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, I've got to correct a little bit of Senator McCain's history, not surprisingly.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Let's, first of all, understand that the biggest problem in this whole process was the deregulation of the financial system.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Senator McCain, as recently as March, bragged about the fact that he is a deregulator.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: On the other hand, two years ago, I said that we've got a sub-prime lending crisis that has to be dealt with.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I wrote to Secretary Paulson, I wrote to Federal Reserve Chairman Bernanke, and told them this is something we have to deal with, and nobody did anything about it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: A year ago, I went to Wall Street and said we've got to reregulate, and nothing happened.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And Senator McCain during that period said that we should keep on deregulating because that's how the free enterprise system works.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: He jumped on it a year after it had been introduced and it never got passed.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I never promoted Fannie Mae.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In fact, Senator McCain's campaign chairman's firm was a lobbyist on behalf of Fannie Mae, not me.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So -- but, look, you're not interested in hearing politicians pointing fingers.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What you're interested in is trying to figure out, how is this going to impact you?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: This is not the end of the process; this is the beginning of the process.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's why it's going to be so important for us to work with homeowners to make sure that they can stay in their homes.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The secretary already has the power to do that in the rescue package, but it hasn't been exercised yet.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the next president has to make sure that the next Treasury secretary is thinking about how to strengthen you as a home buyer, you as a homeowner, and not simply think about bailing out banks on Wall Street.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: No, I am confident about the American economy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But we are going to have to have some leadership from Washington that not only sets out much better regulations for the financial system.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The problem is we still have a archaic, 20th-century regulatory system for 21st-century financial markets.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We're going to have to coordinate with other countries to make sure that whatever actions we take work.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But most importantly, we're going to have to help ordinary families be able to stay in their homes, make sure that they can pay their bills, deal with critical issues like health care and energy, and we're going to have to change the culture in Washington so that lobbyists and special interests aren't driving the process and your voices aren't being drowned out.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I think if we act effectively, if we stabilize the housing market -- which I believe we can, if we go out and buy up these bad loans, so that people can have a new mortgage at the new value of their home -- I think if we get rid of the cronyism and special interest influence in Washington so we can act more effectively.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: My friend, I'd like you to see the letter that a group of senators and I wrote warning exactly of this crisis.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama's name was not on that letter.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The point is -- the point is that we can fix our economy.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: They're the fundamental aspect of America's economy.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: They're the best -- they're most -- have best -- we're the best exporters.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: They are the best workers in the world.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And they are the innocent bystanders here in what is the biggest financial crisis and challenge of our time.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, look, I understand your frustration and your cynicism, because while you've been carrying out your responsibilities -- most of the people here, you've got a family budget.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If less money is coming in, you end up making cuts.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Maybe you put off buying a new car.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's not what happens in Washington.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There is a lot of blame to go around.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I think it's important just to remember a little bit of history.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: When George Bush came into office, we had surpluses.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And now we have half-a-trillion-dollar deficit annually.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's now over $10 trillion.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And Senator McCain voted for four out of five of those George Bush budgets.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I'm going to spend some money on the key issues that we've got to work on.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, you may have seen your health care premiums go up.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got to reform health care to help you and your budget.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We are going to have to deal with energy because we can't keep on borrowing from the Chinese and sending money to Saudi Arabia.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got to have a different energy plan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got to invest in college affordability.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So we're going to have to make some investments, but we've also got to make spending cuts.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And what I've proposed, you'll hear Senator McCain say, well, he's proposing a whole bunch of new spending, but actually I'm cutting more than I'm spending so that it will be a net spending cut.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The key is whether or not we've got priorities that are working for you as opposed to those who have been dictating the policy in Washington lately, and that's mostly lobbyists and special interests.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got to put an end to that.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, Theresa (ph), thank you.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I can see why you feel that cynicism and mistrust, because the system in Washington is broken.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I have been a consistent reformer.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have advocated and taken on the special interests, whether they be the big money people by reaching across the aisle and working with Senator Feingold on campaign finance reform, whether it being a variety of other issues, working with Senator Lieberman on trying to address climate change.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have a clear record of bipartisanship.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The situation today cries out for bipartisanship.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And so let's look at our records as well as our rhetoric.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That's really part of your mistrust here.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And now I suggest that maybe you go to some of these organizations that are the watchdogs of what we do, like the Citizens Against Government Waste or the National Taxpayers Union or these other organizations that watch us all the time.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And you know what you'll find?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: This is the most liberal big-spending record in the United States Senate.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have fought against excessive spending and outrages.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have fought to reduce the earmarks and eliminate them.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Do you know that Senator Obama has voted for -- is proposing $860 billion of new spending now?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Do you know that he voted for every increase in spending that I saw come across the floor of the United States Senate while we were working to eliminate these pork barrel earmarks?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He voted for nearly a billion dollars in pork barrel earmark projects, including, by the way, $3 million for an overhead projector at a planetarium in Chicago, Illinois.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: My friends, do we need to spend that kind of money?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I think you have to look at my record and you have to look at his.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Then you have to look at our proposals for our economy, not $860 billion in new spending, but for the kinds of reforms that keep people in their jobs, get middle-income Americans working again, and getting our economy moving again.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You're going to be examining our proposals tonight and in the future, and energy independence is a way to do that, is one of them.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And drilling offshore and nuclear power are two vital elements of that.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I've been supporting those and I know how to fix this economy, and eliminate our dependence on foreign oil, and stop sending $700 billion a year overseas.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The three priorities were health...
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I think you can work on all three at once, Tom.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: My friends, we are not going to be able to provide the same benefit for present-day workers that we are going -- that present-day retirees have today.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We're going to have to sit down across the table, Republican and Democrat, as we did in 1983 between Ronald Reagan and Tip O'Neill.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I know how to do that.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have a clear record of reaching across the aisle, whether it be Joe Lieberman or Russ Feingold or Ted Kennedy or others.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We can work on nuclear power plants.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Build a whole bunch of them, create millions of new jobs.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We have to have all of the above, alternative fuels, wind, tide, solar, natural gas, clean coal technology.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: All of these things we can do as Americans and we can take on this mission and we can overcome it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: My friends, some of this $700 billion ends up in the hands of terrorist organizations.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: As far as health care is concerned, obviously, everyone is struggling to make sure that they can afford their premiums and that they can have affordable and available health care.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But we can do them all at once.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: There's no -- and we have to do them all at once.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: All three you mentioned are compelling national security requirements.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We're going to have to prioritize, just like a family has to prioritize.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, I've listed the things that I think have to be at the top of the list.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Energy we have to deal with today, because you're paying $3.80 here in Nashville for gasoline, and it could go up.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And it's a strain on your family budget, but it's also bad for our national security, because countries like Russia and Venezuela and, you know, in some cases, countries like Iran, are benefiting from higher oil prices.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's why I've called for an investment of $15 billion a year over 10 years.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Our goal should be, in 10 year's time, we are free of dependence on Middle Eastern oil.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, when JFK said we're going to the Moon in 10 years, nobody was sure how to do it, but we understood that, if the American people make a decision to do something, it gets done.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Health care is priority number two, because that broken health care system is bad not only for families, but it's making our businesses less competitive.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, number three, we've got to deal with education so that our young people are competitive in a global economy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But just one point I want to make, Tom.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Senator McCain mentioned looking at our records.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Senator McCain likes to talk about earmarks a lot.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I want to go line by line through every item in the federal budget and eliminate programs that don't work and make sure that those that do work, work better and cheaper.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But understand this: We also have to look at where some of our tax revenues are going.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So when Senator McCain proposes a $300 billion tax cut, a continuation not only of the Bush tax cuts, but an additional $200 billion that he's going to give to big corporations, including big oil companies, $4 billion worth, that's money out of the system.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so we've got to prioritize both our spending side and our tax policies to make sure that they're working for you.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I first proposed a long time ago that we would have to examine every agency and every bureaucracy of government.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we're going to have to eliminate those that aren't working.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I know a lot of them that aren't working.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: One of them is in defense spending, because I've taken on some of the defense contractors.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I saved the taxpayers $6.8 billion in a deal for an Air Force tanker that was done in a corrupt fashion.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And sometimes those projects, not -- not the overhead projector that Senator Obama asked for, but some of them that are really good projects, will have -- will have to be eliminated, as well.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And they'll have to undergo the same scrutiny that all projects should in competition with others.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So we're going to have to tell the American people that spending is going to have to be cut in America.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I recommend a spending freeze that -- except for defense, Veterans Affairs, and some other vital programs, we'll just have to have across-the-board freeze.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And some of those programs may not grow as much as we would like for them to, but we can establish priorities with full transparency, with full knowledge of the American people, and full consultation, not done behind closed doors and shoving earmarks in the middle of the night into programs that we don't even -- sometimes we don't even know about until months later.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We're not -- we're not -- we're not rifle shots here.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Frankly, I'm not going to tell that person without health insurance that, "I'm sorry, you'll have to wait."
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I'm going to tell you Americans we'll get to work right away and we'll get to work together, and we can get them all done, because that's what America has been doing.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You know, a lot of you remember the tragedy of 9/11 and where you were on that day and, you know, how all of the country was ready to come together and make enormous changes to make us not only safer, but to make us a better country and a more unified country.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And President Bush did some smart things at the outset, but one of the opportunities that was missed was, when he spoke to the American people, he said, "Go out and shop."
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so it's important to understand that the -- I think the American people are hungry for the kind of leadership that is going to tackle these problems not just in government, but outside of government.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And let's take the example of energy, which we already spoke about.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There is going to be the need for each and every one of us to start thinking about how we use energy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I believe in the need for increased oil production.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We're going to have to explore new ways to get more oil, and that includes offshore drilling.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It includes telling the oil companies, that currently have 68 million acres that they're not using, that either you use them or you lose them.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And one of the things I want to do is make sure that we're providing incentives so that you can buy a fuel efficient car that's made right here in the United States of America, not in Japan or South Korea, making sure that you are able to weatherize your home or make your business more fuel efficient.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's going to require effort from each and every one of us.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the last point I just want to make.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I think the young people of America are especially interested in how they can serve, and that's one of the reasons why I'm interested in doubling the Peace Corps, making sure that we are creating a volunteer corps all across this country that can be involved in their community, involved in military service, so that military families and our troops are not the only ones bearing the burden of renewing America.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's something that all of us have to be involved with and that requires some leadership from Washington.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, I think it starts with Washington.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got to show that we've got good habits, because if we're running up trillion dollar debts that we're passing on to the next generation, then a lot of people are going to think, "Well, you know what?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There's easy money out there."
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It means -- and I have to, again, repeat this.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It means looking (ph) at the spending side, but also at the revenue side.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I mean, Senator McCain has been talking tough about earmarks, and that's good, but earmarks account for about $18 billion of our budget.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so part of the problem, I think, for a lot of people who are listening here tonight is they don't feel as if they are sharing the burden with other folks.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I mean, you know, it's tough to ask a teacher who's making $30,000 or $35,000 a year to tighten her belt when people who are making much more than her are living pretty high on the hog.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's why I think it's important for the president to set a tone that says all of us are going to contribute, all of us are going to make sacrifices, and it means that, yes, we may have to cut some spending, although I disagree with Senator McCain about an across-the- board freeze.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's an example of an unfair burden sharing.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's using a hatchet to cut the federal budget.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I want to use a scalpel so that people who need help are getting help and those of us, like myself and Senator McCain, who don't need help, aren't getting it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's how we make sure that everybody is willing to make a few sacrifices.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There has been five or six of them and if you wait long enough, there will probably be another one.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But he wants to raise taxes.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: My friends, the last president to raise taxes during tough economic times was Herbert Hoover, and he practiced protectionism as well, which I'm sure we'll get to at some point.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You know, last year up to this time, we've lost 700,000 jobs in America.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The only bright spot is that over 300,000 jobs have been created by small businesses.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama's secret that you don't know is that his tax increases will increase taxes on 50 percent of small business revenue.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Small businesses across America will have to cut jobs and will have their taxes increase and won't be able to hire because of Senator Obama's tax policies.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You know, he said some time ago, he said he would forgo his tax increases if the economy was bad.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So let's not raise anybody's taxes, my friends, and make it be very clear to you I am not in favor of tax cuts for the wealthy.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I am in favor of leaving the tax rates alone and reducing the tax burden on middle-income Americans by doubling your tax exemption for every child from $3,500 to $7,000.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: To giving every American a $5,000 refundable tax credit and go out and get the health insurance you want rather than mandates and fines for small businesses, as Senator Obama's plan calls for.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And let's create jobs and let's get our economy going again.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And let's not raise anybody's taxes.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Tom, can I respond to this briefly?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The tax issue, because I think it's very important.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, Tom, we're going to have to take on entitlements and I think we've got to do it quickly.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We're going to have a lot of work to do, so I can't guarantee that we're going to do it in the next two years, but I'd like to do in the my first term as president.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I think it's important to understand, we're not going to solve Social Security and Medicare unless we understand the rest of our tax policies.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And you know, Senator McCain, I think the "Straight Talk Express" lost a wheel on that one.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I want to provide a tax cut for 95 percent of Americans, 95 percent.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If you make less than a quarter of a million dollars a year, you will not see a single dime of your taxes go up.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If you make $200,000 a year or less, your taxes will go down.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, Senator McCain talks about small businesses.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So the vast majority of small businesses would get a tax cut under my plan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we provide a 50 percent tax credit so that they can buy health insurance for their workers, because there are an awful lot of small businesses that I meet across America that want to do right by their workers but they just can't afford it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Some small business owners, a lot of them, can't even afford health insurance for themselves.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: He wants to give average Fortune 500 CEO an additional $700,000 in tax cuts.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, if we get our tax policies right so that they're good for the middle class, if we reverse the policies of the last eight years that got us into this fix in the first place and that Senator McCain supported, then we are going to be in a position to deal with Social Security and deal with Medicare, because we will have a health care plan that actually works for you, reduces spending and costs over the long term, and Social Security that is stable and solvent for all Americans and not just some.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Hey, I'll answer the question.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Look -- look, it's not that hard to fix Social Security, Tom.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Social Security is not that tough.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We know what the problems are, my friends, and we know what the fixes are.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We've got to sit down together across the table.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I saw it done with our -- our wonderful Ronald Reagan, a conservative from California, and the liberal Democrat Tip O'Neill from Massachusetts.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That's what we need more of, and that's what I've done in Washington.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I'm not too popular sometimes with my own party, much less his.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So Medicare, it's going to be a little tougher.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It's going to be a little tougher because we're talking about very complex and difficult issues.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: My friends, what we have to do with Medicare is have a commission, have the smartest people in America come together, come up with recommendations, and then, like the base-closing commission idea we had, then we should have Congress vote up or down.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Let's not let them fool with it anymore.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: There's too much special interests and too many lobbyists working there.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So let's have -- and let's have the American people say, "Fix it for us."
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, just back on this -- on this tax, you know, again, it's back to our first question here about rhetoric and record.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama has voted 94 times to either increase your taxes or against tax cuts.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You know he came to the Senate and never once proposed legislation to do that?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So let's look at our record.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have fought excess spending.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have fought to reform government.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Let's look at our records, my friends, and then listen to my vision for the future of America.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we'll get our economy going again.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Look, we are in tough economic times; we all know that.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And let's keep -- never forget the struggle that Americans are in today.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But when we can -- when we have an issue that we may hand our children and our grandchildren a damaged planet, I have disagreed strongly with the Bush administration on this issue.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I traveled all over the world looking at the effects of greenhouse gas emissions, Joe Lieberman and I.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I introduced the first legislation, and we forced votes on it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That's the good news, my friends.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The bad news is we lost.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But we kept the debate going, and we kept this issue to -- to posing to Americans the danger that climate change opposes.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama says that it has to be safe or disposable or something like that.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Look, I -- I was on Navy ships that had nuclear power plants.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And -- and I know that we can reprocess the spent nuclear fuel.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The Japanese, the British, the French do it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we can do it, too.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama has opposed that.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We can move forward, and clean up our climate, and develop green technologies, and alternate -- alternative energies for -- for hybrid, for hydrogen, for battery-powered cars, so that we can clean up our environment and at the same time get our economy going by creating millions of jobs.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We can do that, we as Americans, because we're the best innovators, we're the best producers, and 95 percent of the people who are our market live outside of the United States of America.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: This is one of the biggest challenges of our times.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And it is absolutely critical that we understand this is not just a challenge, it's an opportunity, because if we create a new energy economy, we can create five million new jobs, easily, here in the United States.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It can be an engine that drives us into the future the same way the computer was the engine for economic growth over the last couple of decades.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The same way the computer was originally invented by a bunch of government scientists who were trying to figure out, for defense purposes, how to communicate, we've got to understand that this is a national security issue, as well.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's why we've got to make some investments and I've called for investments in solar, wind, geothermal.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Contrary to what Senator McCain keeps on saying, I favor nuclear power as one component of our overall energy mix.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But this is another example where I think it is important to look at the record.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Senator McCain and I actually agree on something.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: He said a while back that the big problem with energy is that for 30 years, politicians in Washington haven't done anything.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What Senator McCain doesn't mention is he's been there 26 of them.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So it's easy to talk about this stuff during a campaign, but it's important for us to understand that it requires a sustained effort from the next president.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: One last point I want to make on energy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Senator McCain talks a lot about drilling, and that's important, but we have three percent of the world's oil reserves and we use 25 percent of the world's oil.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So what that means is that we can't simply drill our way out of the problem.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we're not going to be able to deal with the climate crisis if our only solution is to use more fossil fuels that create global warming.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We're going to have to come up with alternatives, and that means that the United States government is working with the private sector to fund the kind of innovation that we can then export to countries like China that also need energy and are setting up one coal power plant a week.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Tom, wave like that and I'll look at you.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I think once it gets into productive stages, that we ought to, obviously, turn it over to the private sector.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It was an energy bill on the floor of the Senate loaded down with goodies, billions for the oil companies, and it was sponsored by Bush and Cheney.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You know who voted for it?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You know who voted against it?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have fought time after time against these pork barrel -- these bills that come to the floor and they have all kinds of goodies and all kinds of things in them for everybody and they buy off the votes.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I vote against them, my friends.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But the point is, also, on oil drilling, oil drilling offshore now is vital so that we can bridge the gap.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We can bridge the gap between imported oil, which is a national security issue, as well as any other, and it will reduce the price of a barrel of oil, because when people know there's a greater supply, then the cost of that will go down.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We've got to drill offshore, my friends, and we've got to do it now, and we can do it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And as far as nuclear power is concerned, again, look at the record.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama has approved storage and reprocessing of spent nuclear fuel.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I'll stop, Tom, and you didn't even wave.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, you know, as I travel around the country, this is one of the single most frequently asked issues that I get, is the issue of health care.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It is breaking family budgets.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I can't tell you how many people I meet who don't have health insurance.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And your co-payments and deductibles have gone up 30 percent just in the last year alone.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If you're a small business, it's a crushing burden.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So one of the things that I have said from the start of this campaign is that we have a moral commitment as well as an economic imperative to do something about the health care crisis that so many families are facing.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So here's what I would do.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If you've got health care already, and probably the majority of you do, then you can keep your plan if you are satisfied with it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You can keep your choice of doctor.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We're going to work with your employer to lower the cost of your premiums by up to $2,500 a year.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we're going to do it by investing in prevention.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We're going to do it by making sure that we use information technology so that medical records are actually on computers instead of you filling forms out in triplicate when you go to the hospital.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That will reduce medical errors and reduce costs.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If you don't have health insurance, you're going to be able to buy the same kind of insurance that Senator McCain and I enjoy as federal employees.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Because there's a huge pool, we can drop the costs.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And nobody will be excluded for pre-existing conditions, which is a huge problem.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, Senator McCain has a different kind of approach.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: He says that he's going to give you a $5,000 tax credit.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What he doesn't tell you is that he is going to tax your employer-based health care benefits for the first time ever.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So what one hand giveth, the other hand taketh away.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: He would also strip away the ability of states to provide some of the regulations on insurance companies to make sure you're not excluded for pre-existing conditions or your mammograms are covered or your maternity is covered.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that is fundamentally the wrong way to go.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In fact, just today business organizations like the United States Chamber of Commerce, which generally are pretty supportive of Republicans, said that this would lead to the unraveling of the employer-based health care system.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That, I don't think, is the kind of change that we need.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got to have somebody who is fighting for patients and making sure that you get decent, affordable health care.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's something that I'm committed to doing as president.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You really identified one of the really major challenges that America faces.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Co-payments go up, costs go up, skyrocketing costs, which make people less and less able to afford health insurance in America.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Let's put health records online, that will reduce medical errors, as they call them.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Let's have community health centers.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But what is at stake here in this health care issue is the fundamental difference between myself and Senator Obama.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: As you notice, he starts talking about government.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He starts saying, government will do this and government will do that, and then government will, and he'll impose mandates.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: If you're a small business person and you don't insure your employees, Senator Obama will fine you.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: If you're a parent and you're struggling to get health insurance for your children, Senator Obama will fine you.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: They can take it anywhere, across state lines.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Of course it's OK to go across state lines because in Arizona they may offer a better plan that suits you best than it does here in Tennessee.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And if you do the math, those people who have employer-based health benefits, if you put the tax on it and you have what's left over and you add $5,000 that you're going to get as a refundable tax credit, do the math, 95 percent of the American people will have increased funds to go out and buy the insurance of their choice and to shop around and to get -- all of those people will be covered except for those who have these gold-plated Cadillac kinds of policies.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You know, like hair transplants, I might need one of those myself.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Every parent I know would acquire health insurance for their children if they could.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Obviously small business people want to give their employees health insurance.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Of course they all want to do that.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We can do it by giving them, as a start, a $5,000 refundable tax credit to go around and get the health insurance policy of their choice.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I think it's a responsibility, in this respect, in that we should have available and affordable health care to every American citizen, to every family member.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And with the plan that -- that I have, that will do that.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But government mandates I -- I'm always a little nervous about.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But it is certainly my responsibility.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It is certainly small-business people and others, and they understand that responsibility.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But they certainly are a little nervous when Senator Obama says, if you don't get the health care policy that I think you should have, then you're going to get fined.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And, by the way, Senator Obama has never mentioned how much that fine might be.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Perhaps we might find that out tonight.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, why don't -- why don't -- let's talk about this, Tom, because there was just a lot of stuff out there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, I think it should be a right for every American.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In a country as wealthy as ours, for us to have people who are going bankrupt because they can't pay their medical bills -- for my mother to die of cancer at the age of 53 and have to spend the last months of her life in the hospital room arguing with insurance companies because they're saying that this may be a pre-existing condition and they don't have to pay her treatment, there's something fundamentally wrong about that.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, Tom, I know that we're under time constraints, but Senator McCain through a lot of stuff out there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number one, let me just repeat, if you've got a health care plan that you like, you can keep it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You'll still have choice of doctor.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Small businesses are not going to have a mandate.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What we're going to give you is a 50 percent tax credit to help provide health care for those that you need.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, it's true that I say that you are going to have to make sure that your child has health care, because children are relatively cheap to insure and we don't want them going to the emergency room for treatable illnesses like asthma.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And when Senator McCain says that he wants to provide children health care, what he doesn't mention is he voted against the expansion of the Children's Health Insurance Program that is responsible for making sure that so many children who didn't have previously health insurance have it now.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, the final point I'll make on this whole issue of government intrusion and mandates -- it is absolutely true that I think it is important for government to crack down on insurance companies that are cheating their customers, that don't give you the fine print, so you end up thinking that you're paying for something and, when you finally get sick and you need it, you're not getting it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the reason that it's a problem to go shopping state by state, you know what insurance companies will do?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They will find a state -- maybe Arizona, maybe another state -- where there are no requirements for you to get cancer screenings, where there are no requirements for you to have to get pre-existing conditions, and they will all set up shop there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's how in banking it works.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Everybody goes to Delaware, because they've got very -- pretty loose laws when it comes to things like credit cards.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And in that situation, what happens is, is that the protections you have, the consumer protections that you need, you're not going to have available to you.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That is a fundamental difference that I have with Senator McCain.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: He believes in deregulation in every circumstance.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's what we've been going through for the last eight years.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It hasn't worked, and we need fundamental change.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I don't believe that -- did we hear the size of the fine?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But having said that, America -- and we'll hear a lot of criticism.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I've heard a lot of criticism about America, and our national security policy, and all that, and much of that criticism is justified.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But the fact is, America is the greatest force for good in the history of the world.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: My friends, we have gone to all four corners of the Earth and shed American blood in defense, usually, of somebody else's freedom and our own.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So we are peacemakers and we're peacekeepers.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But the challenge is to know when the United States of American can beneficially effect the outcome of a crisis, when to go in and when not, when American military power is worth the expenditure of our most precious treasure.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And that question can only be answered by someone with the knowledge and experience and the judgment, the judgment to know when our national security is not only at risk, but where the United States of America can make a difference in preventing genocide, in preventing the spread of terrorism, in doing the things that the United States has done, not always well, but we've done because we're a nation of good.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I am convinced that my record, going back to my opposition from sending the Marines to Lebanon, to supporting our efforts in Kosovo and Bosnia and the first Gulf War, and my judgment, I think, is something that I'm -- a record that I'm willing to stand on.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama was wrong about Iraq and the surge.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He was wrong about Russia when they committed aggression against Georgia.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And in his short career, he does not understand our national security challenges.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We don't have time for on-the-job training, my friends.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: There are some things I don't understand.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I don't understand how we ended up invading a country that had nothing to do with 9/11, while Osama Bin Laden and Al Qaeda are setting up base camps and safe havens to train terrorists to attack us.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That was Senator McCain's judgment and it was the wrong judgment.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: When Senator McCain was cheerleading the president to go into Iraq, he suggested it was going to be quick and easy, we'd be greeted as liberators.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That was the wrong judgment, and it's been costly to us.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So one of the difficulties with Iraq is that it has put an enormous strain, first of all, on our troops, obviously, and they have performed heroically and honorably and we owe them an extraordinary debt of gratitude.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But it's also put an enormous strain on our budget.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We're spending $10 billion a month in Iraq at a time when the Iraqis have a $79 billion surplus, $79 billion.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we need that $10 billion a month here in the United States to put people back to work, to do all these wonderful things that Senator McCain suggested we should be doing, but has not yet explained how he would pay for.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, Senator McCain and I do agree, this is the greatest nation on earth.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We are a force of good in the world.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But there has never been a nation in the history of the world that saw its economy decline and maintained its military superiority.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the strains that have been placed on our alliances around the world and the respect that's been diminished over the last eight years has constrained us being able to act on something like the genocide in Darfur, because we don't have the resources or the allies to do everything that we should be doing.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's going to change when I'm president, but we can't change it unless we fundamentally change Senator McCain's and George Bush's foreign policy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It has not worked for America.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If we could've stopped Rwanda, surely, if we had the ability, that would be something that we would have to strongly consider and act.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So when genocide is happening, when ethnic cleansing is happening somewhere around the world and we stand idly by, that diminishes us.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But understand that there's a lot of cruelty around the world.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We're not going to be able to be everywhere all the time.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's why it's so important for us to be able to work in concert with our allies.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Let's take the example of Darfur just for a moment.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We could be providing logistical support, setting up a no-fly zone at relatively little cost to us, but we can only do it if we can help mobilize the international community and lead.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If we had done what Senator Obama wanted done in Iraq, and that was set a date for withdrawal, which General Petraeus, our chief -- chairman of our Joint Chiefs of Staff said would be a very dangerous course to take for America, then we would have had a wider war, we would have been back, Iranian influence would have increased, al Qaeda would have re- established a base.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: There was a lot at stake there, my friends.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I can tell you right now that Senator Obama would have brought our troops home in defeat.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I'll bring them home with victory and with honor and that is a fundamental difference.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The United States of America, Tom, is the greatest force for good, as I said.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That requires a cool hand at the tiller.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: This requires a person who understands what our -- the limits of our capability are.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We went in to Somalia as a peacemaking organization, we ended up trying to be -- excuse me, as a peacekeeping organization, we ended up trying to be peacemakers and we ended up having to withdraw in humiliation.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: In Lebanon, I stood up to President Reagan, my hero, and said, if we send Marines in there, how can we possibly beneficially affect this situation?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Unfortunately, almost 300 brave young Marines were killed.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So you have to temper your decisions with the ability to beneficially affect the situation and realize you're sending America's most precious asset, American blood, into harm's way.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And, again, I know those situations.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I've been in them all my life.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I can tell you right now the security of your young men and women who are serving in the military are my first priority right after our nation's security.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I may have to make those tough decisions.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But I won't take them lightly.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But we had also better be darn sure we don't leave and make the situation worse, thereby exacerbating our reputation and our ability to address crises in other parts of the world.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Katie, it's a terrific question and we have a difficult situation in Pakistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I believe that part of the reason we have a difficult situation is because we made a bad judgment going into Iraq in the first place when we hadn't finished the job of hunting down bin Laden and crushing al Qaeda.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So what happened was we got distracted, we diverted resources, and ultimately bin Laden escaped, set up base camps in the mountains of Pakistan in the northwest provinces there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They are now raiding our troops in Afghanistan, destabilizing the situation.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They're stronger now than at any time since 2001.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's why I think it's so important for us to reverse course, because that's the central front on terrorism.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They are plotting to kill Americans right now.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: As Secretary Gates, the defense secretary, said, the war against terrorism began in that region and that's where it will end.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So part of the reason I think it's so important for us to end the war in Iraq is to be able to get more troops into Afghanistan, put more pressure on the Afghan government to do what it needs to do, eliminate some of the drug trafficking that's funding terrorism.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I do believe that we have to change our policies with Pakistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We can't coddle, as we did, a dictator, give him billions of dollars and then he's making peace treaties with the Taliban and militants.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What I've said is we're going to encourage democracy in Pakistan, expand our nonmilitary aid to Pakistan so that they have more of a stake in working with us, but insisting that they go after these militants.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We will kill bin Laden; we will crush Al Qaida.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That has to be our biggest national security priority.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, Katie (ph), thank you.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You know, my hero is a guy named Teddy Roosevelt.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Teddy Roosevelt used to say walk softly -- talk softly, but carry a big stick.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Senator Obama likes to talk loudly.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: In fact, he said he wants to announce that he's going to attack Pakistan.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: You know, if you are a country and you're trying to gain the support of another country, then you want to do everything you can that they would act in a cooperative fashion.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: When you announce that you're going to launch an attack into another country, it's pretty obvious that you have the effect that it had in Pakistan: It turns public opinion against us.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, let me just go back with you very briefly.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We drove the Russians out with -- the Afghan freedom fighters drove the Russians out of Afghanistan, and then we made a most serious mistake.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We washed our hands of Afghanistan.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The Taliban came back in, Al Qaida, we then had the situation that required us to conduct the Afghan war.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, our relations with Pakistan are critical, because the border areas are being used as safe havens by the Taliban and Al Qaida and other extremist organizations, and we have to get their support.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, General Petraeus had a strategy, the same strategy -- very, very different, because of the conditions and the situation -- but the same fundamental strategy that succeeded in Iraq.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We need to help the Pakistani government go into Waziristan, where I visited, a very rough country, and -- and get the support of the people, and get them to work with us and turn against the cruel Taliban and others.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: ... just a quick follow-up on this.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If we're going to have follow-ups, then I will want follow-ups, as well.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It'd be fine with me.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It'd be fine with me.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Just -- just -- just a quick follow-up, because I think -- I think this is important.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You're doing a great job, Tom.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Look, I -- I want to be very clear about what I said.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Nobody called for the invasion of Pakistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Senator McCain continues to repeat this.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What I said was the same thing that the audience here today heard me say, which is, if Pakistan is unable or unwilling to hunt down bin Laden and take him out, then we should.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, that I think has to be our policy, because they are threatening to kill more Americans.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, Senator McCain suggests that somehow, you know, I'm green behind the ears and, you know, I'm just spouting off, and he's somber and responsible.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Senator McCain, this is the guy who sang, "Bomb, bomb, bomb Iran," who called for the annihilation of North Korea.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That I don't think is an example of "speaking softly."
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: This is the person who, after we had -- we hadn't even finished Afghanistan, where he said, "Next up, Baghdad."
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So I agree that we have to speak responsibly and we have to act responsibly.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the reason Pakistan -- the popular opinion of America had diminished in Pakistan was because we were supporting a dictator, Musharraf, had given him $10 billion over seven years, and he had suspended civil liberties.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We were not promoting democracy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: This is the kind of policies that ultimately end up undermining our ability to fight the war on terrorism, and it will change when I'm president.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, Tom, if -- if we're going to go back and forth, I then -- I'd like to have equal time to go -- to respond to...
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I have, obviously, supported those efforts that the United States had to go in militarily and I have opposed that I didn't think so.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I understand what it's like to send young American's in harm's way.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I say -- I was joking with a veteran -- I hate to even go into this.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I was joking with an old veteran friend, who joked with me, about Iran.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But the point is that I know how to handle these crises.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And Senator Obama, by saying that he would attack Pakistan, look at the context of his words.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I'll get Osama bin Laden, my friends.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I know how to get him.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I'll get him no matter what and I know how to do it.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But I'm not going to telegraph my punches, which is what Senator Obama did.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I'm going to act responsibly, as I have acted responsibly throughout my military career and throughout my career in the United States Senate.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And we have fundamental disagreements about the use of military power and how you do it, and you just saw it in response to previous questions.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: General McKiernan, the commander in Afghanistan right now, is desperate for more help, because our bases and outposts are now targets for more aggressive Afghan -- Taliban offenses.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We're also going to have to work with the Karzai government, and when I met with President Karzai, I was very clear that, "You are going to have to do better by your people in order for us to gain the popular support that's necessary."
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I don't think he has to be a dictator.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But we have to have a government that is responsive to the Afghan people, and, frankly, it's just not responsive right now.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: General Petraeus has just taken over a position of responsibility, where he has the command and will really set the tone for the strategy and tactics that are used.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It is the same overall strategy.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Of course, we have to do some things tactically, some of which Senator Obama is correct on.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We have to double the size of the Afghan army.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We have to work much more closely with the Pakistanis.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But most importantly, we have to have the same strategy, which Senator Obama said wouldn't work, couldn't work, still fails to admit that he was wrong about Iraq.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He still will not admit that he was wrong about the strategy of the surge in Iraq, and that's the same kind of strategy of go out and secure and hold and allow people to live normal lives.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And once they feel secure, then they lead normal, social, economic, political lives, the same thing that's happening in Iraq today.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So I have confidence that General Petraeus, working with the Pakistanis, working with the Afghans, doing the same job that he did in Iraq, will again.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: First of all, as I say, I don't think that -- we're not going to have another Cold War with Russia.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But have no doubt that Russia's behavior is certainly outside the norms of behavior that we would expect for nations which are very wealthy, as Russia has become, because of their petro dollars.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, long ago, I warned about Vladimir Putin.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I said I looked into his eyes and saw three letters, a K, a G and a B.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He has surrounded himself with former KGB apparatchiks.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: He has gradually repressed most of the liberties that we would expect for nations to observe, and he has exhibited most aggressive behavior, obviously, in Georgia.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I said before, watch Ukraine.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Ukraine, right now, is in the sights of Vladimir Putin, those that want to reassemble the old Soviet Union.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We've got to show moral support for Georgia.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We've got to show moral support for Ukraine.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We've got to advocate for their membership in NATO.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: We have to make the Russians understand that there are penalties for these this kind of behavior, this kind of naked aggression into Georgia, a tiny country and a tiny democracy.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And so, of course we want to bring international pressures to bear on Russia in hopes that that will modify and eventually change their behavior.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, the G-8 is one of those, but there are many others.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It will not be a re-ignition of the Cold War, but Russia is a challenge.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, the resurgence of Russia is one of the central issues that we're going to have to deal with in the next presidency.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got to provide moral support to the Poles and Estonia and Latvia and all of the nations that were former Soviet satellites.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But we've also got to provide them with financial and concrete assistance to help rebuild their economies.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Georgia in particular is now on the brink of enormous economic challenges.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And some say that that's what Putin intended in the first place.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got to anticipate some of these problems ahead of time.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, back in April, I put out a statement saying that the situation in Georgia was unsustainable because you had Russian peacekeepers in these territories that were under dispute.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And you knew that if the Russians themselves were trying to obtain some of these territories or push back against Georgia, that that was not a stable situation.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So part of the job of the next commander-in-chief, in keeping all of you safe, is making sure that we can see some of the 21st Century challenges and anticipate them before they happen.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We haven't been doing enough of that.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We tend to be reactive.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's what we've been doing over the last eight years and that has actually made us more safe.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's part of what happened in Afghanistan, where we rushed into Iraq and Senator McCain and President Bush suggested that it wasn't that important to catch bin Laden right now and that we could muddle through, and that has cost us dearly.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got to be much more strategic if we're going to be able to deal with all of the challenges that we face out there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And one last point I want to make about Russia.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Energy is going to be key in dealing with Russia.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If we can reduce our energy consumption, that reduces the amount of petro dollars that they have to make mischief around the world.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That will strengthen us and weaken them when it comes to issues like Georgia.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I think they've engaged in an evil behavior and I think that it is important that we understand they're not the old Soviet Union but they still have nationalist impulses that I think are very dangerous.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Depends on how we respond to Russia and it depends on a lot of things.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: If I say yes, then that means that we're reigniting the old Cold War.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: If I say no, it ignores their behavior.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Obviously energy is going to be a big, big factor.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And that's one of the reasons why it's in our interest.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But the Russians, I think we can deal with them but they've got to understand that they're facing a very firm and determined United States of America that will defend our interests and that of other countries in the world.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I want to say, everything I ever learned about leadership I learned from a chief petty officer.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I thank you, and I thank you, my friend.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Let -- let -- let me say that we obviously would not wait for the United Nations Security Council.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I think the realities are that both Russia and China would probably pose significant obstacles.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And our challenge right now is the Iranians continue on the path to acquiring nuclear weapons, and it's a great threat.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It's not just a threat -- threat to the state of Israel.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It's a threat to the stability of the entire Middle East.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: If Iran acquires nuclear weapons, all the other countries will acquire them, too.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The tensions will be ratcheted up.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: What would you do if you were the Israelis and the president of a country says that they are -- they are determined to wipe you off the map, calls your country a stinking corpse?
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Now, Senator Obama without precondition wants to sit down and negotiate with them, without preconditions.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That's what he stated, again, a matter of record.
Speaker: John McCain
