Text: I want to make sure that the Iranians are put enough -- that we put enough pressure on the Iranians by joining with our allies, imposing significant, tough sanctions to modify their behavior.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I think, joining with our allies and friends in a league of democracies, that we can effectively abridge their behavior, and hopefully they would abandon this quest that they are on for nuclear weapons.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Well, Terry, first of all, we honor your service, and we're grateful for it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We cannot allow Iran to get a nuclear weapon.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Not only would it threaten Israel, our strongest ally in the region and one of our strongest allies in the world, but it would also create a possibility of nuclear weapons falling into the hands of terrorists.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we will never take military options off the table.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And it is important that we don't provide veto power to the United Nations or anyone else in acting in our interests.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It is important, though, for us to use all the tools at our disposal to prevent the scenario where we've got to make those kinds of choices.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's why I have consistently said that, if we can work more effectively with other countries diplomatically to tighten sanctions on Iran, if we can reduce our energy consumption through alternative energy, so that Iran has less money, if we can impose the kinds of sanctions that, say, for example, Iran right now imports gasoline, even though it's an oil-producer, because its oil infrastructure has broken down, if we can prevent them from importing the gasoline that they need and the refined petroleum products, that starts changing their cost-benefit analysis.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That starts putting the squeeze on them.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, it is true, though, that I believe that we should have direct talks -- not just with our friends, but also with our enemies -- to deliver a tough, direct message to Iran that, if you don't change your behavior, then there will be dire consequences.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If you do change your behavior, then it is possible for you to re-join the community of nations.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, it may not work.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But one of the things we've learned is, is that when we take that approach, whether it's in North Korea or in Iran, then we have a better chance at better outcomes.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: When President Bush decided we're not going to talk to Iran, we're not going to talk to North Korea, you know what happened?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: North Korea quadrupled its nuclear capability.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got to try to have talks, understanding that we're not taking military options off the table.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: My wife, Michelle, is there and she could give you a much longer list than I do.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And most of the time, I learn it by asking her.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But, look, the nature of the challenges that we're going to face are immense and one of the things that we know about the presidency is that it's never the challenges that you expect.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's the challenges that you don't that end up consuming most of your time.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I know that I wouldn't be standing here if it weren't for the fact that this country gave me opportunity.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I came from very modest means.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I had a single mom and my grandparents raised me and it was because of the help of scholarships and my grandmother scrimping on things that she might have wanted to purchase and my mom, at one point, getting food stamps in order for us to put food on the table.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Despite all that, I was able to go to the best schools on earth and I was able to succeed in a way that I could not have succeeded anywhere else in this country.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The same is true for Michelle and I'm sure the same is true for a lot of you.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Over the last eight years, we've seen that dream diminish.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Wages and incomes have gone down.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: People have lost their health care or are going bankrupt because they get sick.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got young people who have got the grades and the will and the drive to go to college, but they just don't have the money.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we can't expect that if we do the same things that we've been doing over the last eight years, that somehow we are going to have a different outcome.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's the reason I decided to run for president, and I'm hopeful that all of you are prepared to continue this extraordinary journey that we call America.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But we're going to have to have the courage and the sacrifice, the nerve to move in a new direction.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Senator Obama had the opening.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I think what I don't know is what all of us don't know, and that's what's going to happen both here at home and abroad.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: The challenges that we face are unprecedented.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: Americans are hurting tonight in a way they have not in our generation.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: So what I don't know is what the unexpected will be.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: But I have spent my whole life serving this country.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: My mother basically raised our family.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I know what it's like in dark times.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I know what it's like to rely on others for support and courage and love in tough times.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I know what it's like to have your comrades reach out to you and your neighbors and your fellow citizens and pick you up and put you back in the fight.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: That's what America's all about.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I believe in this country.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I believe in its future.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: I believe in its greatness.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: It's been my great honor to serve it for many, many years.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: And I'm asking the American people to give me another opportunity and I'll rest on my record, but I'll also tell you, when times are tough, we need a steady hand at the tiller and the great honor of my life was to always put my country first.
Speaker: John McCain

Text: First question is what's in the best interests of the United States?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: What's in the best interests of our people?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: When it comes to foreign policy that will be my guiding question.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Is it in our nation's interests?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Peace in the Middle East is in our nation's interests.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Having a hemisphere that is free for trade and peaceful is in our nation's interests.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Strong relations in Europe is in our nation's interest.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've thought a lot about what it means to be the president.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I also understand that an administration is not one person, but an administration is dedicated citizens who are called by the president to serve the country, to serve a cause greater than self, and so I've thought about an administration of people who represent all America, but people who understand my compassionate and conservative philosophy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I haven't started naming names except for one person, and that's Mr. Richard Cheney who I thought did a great job the other night.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He's a vice presidential nominee who represents -- I think people got to see why I picked him.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He's man of solid judgment and he's going to be a person to stand by my side.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One of the things I've done in Texas is I've been able to put together a good team of people.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've been able to set clear goals.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The goals ought to be an education system that leaves no child behind, Medicare for our seniors, a Social Security system that's safe and secure, foreign policy that's in our nation's interest, and a strong military, and then bring people together to achieve those goals.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's what a Chief Executive Officer does.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So I've thought long and hard about the honor of being the President of the United States.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've thought a lot about that particular question, and I see our greatest national strength coming from what we stand for in the world.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I see it as a question of values.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It is a great tribute to our founders that 224 years later this nation is now looked to by the peoples on every other continent and the peoples from every part of this earth as a kind of model for what their future could be.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I don't think that's just the kind of exaggeration that we take pride in as Americans.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It's really true, even the ones that sometimes shake their fists at us.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: As soon as they have a change that allows the people to speak freely, they're wanting to develop some kind of blueprint that will help them be like us more, freedom, free markets, political freedom.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: So I think first and foremost our power ought to be wielded to in ways that form a more perfect union.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The power of example is America's greatest power in the world.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And that means, for example, standing up for human rights.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It means addressing the problems of injustice and inequity, along the lines of race and ethnicity here at home, because in all these other places around the world where they're having these terrible problems, when they feel hope, it is often because they see in us a reflection of their potential.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: So we've got to enforce our civil rights laws.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We've got to deal with things like racial profiling.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And we have to keep our military strong.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We have the strongest military, and I'll do whatever is necessary, if I'm president, to make sure that it stays that way.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But our real power comes, I think, from our values.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Well, I think they ought to look at us as a country that understands freedom where it doesn't matter who you are or how you're raised or where you're from, that you can succeed.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't think they'll look at us with envy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It really depends upon how our nation conducts itself in foreign policy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If we're an arrogant nation, they'll resent us.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If we're a humble nation, but strong, they'll welcome us.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And it's -- our nation stands alone right now in the world in terms of power, and that's why we have to be humble.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And yet project strength in a way that promotes freedom.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So I don't think they ought to look at us in any way other than what we are.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're a freedom-loving nation and if we're an arrogant nation they'll view us that way, but if we're a humble nation they'll respect us.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think that one of the problems that we have faced in the world is that we are so much more powerful than any single nation has been in relationship to the rest of the world than at any time in history, that I know about, anyway.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: That there is some resentment of U.S. power.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: So I think that the idea of humility is an important one.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But I think that we also have to have a sense of mission in the world.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We have to protect our capacity to push forward what America's all about.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: That means not only military strength and our values, it also means keeping our economy strong.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: You know, in the last, or two decades ago, it was routine for leaders of foreign countries to come over here and say you guys have got to do something about these horrendous deficits because it's causing tremendous problems for the rest of the world, and we were lectured to all the time.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The fact that we have the strongest economy in history today is not good enough.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We need to do more.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But the fact that it is so strong enables us to project the power for good that America can represent.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Take, for example, Third World debt.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think we ought to be forgiving Third World debt under certain conditions.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think, for example, if we're convinced that a Third World country that's got a lot of debt would reform itself, that the money wouldn't go into the hands of a few but would go to help people, I think it makes sense for us to use our wealth in that way, or to trade debt for valuable rain forest lands, makes that much sense, yes.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We do have an obligation, but we can't be all things to all people.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We can help build coalitions but we can't put our troops all around the world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We can lend money but we have to do it wisely.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We shouldn't be lending money to corrupt officials.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So we got to be guarded in our generosity.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The first priority has to be on ending the violence, dampening down the tensions that have arisen there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We need to call upon Syria to release the three Israeli soldiers who have been captured.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We need to insist that Arafat send out instructions to halt some of the provocative acts of violence that have been going on.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that we also have to keep a weather eye toward Saddam Hussein because he is taking advantage of this situation to once again make threats, and he needs to understand that he's not only dealing with Israel, he is dealing -- he's dealing with us if he is making the kind of threats that he's talking about there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The use of diplomacy in this situation has already, well, it goes hour-by-hour and day-by-day now.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It's a very tense situation there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But in the last 24 hours there has been some subsiding of the violence there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It's too much to hope that this is going to continue, but I do hope that it will continue.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Our country has been very active with regular conversations with the leaders there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And we just have to take it day-to-day right now.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But one thing I would say where diplomacy is concerned, Israel should feel absolutely secure about one thing.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Our bonds with Israel are larger than agreements or disagreements on some details of diplomatic initiatives.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: They are historic, they are strong, and they are enduring.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And our ability to serve as an honest broker is something that we need to shepherd.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Well, I think during the campaign, particularly now during this difficult period, we ought to be speaking with one voice, and I appreciate the way the administration has worked hard to calm the tensions.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Like the vice president, I call on Chairman Arafat to have his people pull back to make the peace.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think credibility is going to be very important in the future in the Middle East.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want everybody to know should I be the president Israel's going to be our friend.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm going to stand by Israel.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Secondly, that I think it's important to reach out to moderate Arab nations, like Jordan and Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's important to be friends with people when you don't need each other so that when you do there's a strong bond of friendship.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's going to be particularly important in dealing not only with situations such as now occurring in Israel, but with Saddam Hussein.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The coalition against Saddam has fallen apart or it's unraveling, let's put it that way.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The sanctions are being violated.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We don't know whether he's developing weapons of mass destruction.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He better not be or there's going to be a consequence should I be the president.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But it's important to have credibility and credibility is formed by being strong with your friends and resolute in your determination.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One of the reasons why I think it's important for this nation to develop an anti-ballistic missile system that we can share with our allies in the Middle East if need be to keep the peace to be able to say to the Saddam HusseinÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s of the world or the Iranians, don't dare threaten our friends.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's also important to keep strong ties in the Middle East, credible ties, because of the energy crisis we're now in.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: After all, a lot of the energy is produced from the Middle East, and so I appreciate what the administration is doing.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I hope to get a sense of should I be fortunate to be the president how my administration will react to the Middle East.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, we stand with Israel, but we have maintained the ability to serve as an honest broker.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And one of the reasons that's important is that Israel cannot have direct dialogue with some of the people on the other side of conflicts, especially during times of tension, unless that dialogue comes through us.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And if we throw away that ability to serve as an honest broker, then we have thrown -- we will have thrown away a strategic asset that's important not only to us but also to Israel.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I do think this, though.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: When it comes to timetables it can't be the United States timetable as to how discussions take place.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's got to be a timetable that all parties can agree to, like the Palestinians and Israelis.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Secondly, any lasting peace is going to have to be a peace that's good for both sides.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And therefore, the term honest broker makes sense.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This current administration's worked hard to keep the parties at the table.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I will try to do the same thing.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But it won't be on my timetable, it will be on the timetable that people are comfortable with in the Middle East.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I haven't heard a big difference in the last few exchanges.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that, you know, I would hope to be able to convince people I could handle the Iraqi situation better.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I would like to, of course, and I presume this administration would as well.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We don't know -- there are no inspectors now in Iraq, the coalition that was in place isn't as strong as it used to be.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We don't want him fishing in troubled waters in the Middle East.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And it's going to be hard, it's going to be important to rebuild that coalition to keep the pressure on him.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, when I got to be a part of the current administration, it was right after -- I was one of the few members of my political party to support former President Bush in the Persian Gulf War resolution, and at the end of that war, for whatever reason, it was not finished in a way that removed Saddam Hussein from power.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I know there are all kinds of circumstances and explanations.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But the fact is that that's the situation that was left when I got there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And we have maintained the sanctions.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now I want to go further.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I want to give robust support to the groups that are trying to overthrow Saddam Hussein, and I know there are allegations that they're too weak to do it, but that's what they said about the forces that were opposing Milosevic in Serbia, and you know, the policy of enforcing sanctions against Serbia has just resulted in a spectacular victory for democracy just in the past week, and it seems to me that having taken so long to see the sanctions work there, building upon the policy of containment that was successful over a much longer period of time against the former Soviet Union in the communist block, seems a little early to declare that we should give up on the sanctions.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I know the governor's not necessarily saying that but, you know, all of these flights that have come in, all of them have been in accordance with the sanctions regime, I'm told, except for three where they notified, and they're trying to break out of the box, there's no question about it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I don't think they should be allowed to.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: No, of course not, absolutely not, I want them to be tougher.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think it's a triumph.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I thought the president made the right decision in joining NATO and bombing Serbia.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I supported them when they did so.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I called upon the Congress not to hamstring the administration, and in terms of forcing troop withdrawals on a timetable that wasn't necessarily in our best interest or fit our nation's strategy, and so I think it's good public policy, I think it worked, and I'm pleased I took -- made the decision I made.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm pleased the president made the decision he made.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Because freedom took hold in that part of the world, but there's a lot of work left to be done, however.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Yes, I think it is.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't think he would have fallen had we not used the force.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I know there are some in our party that disagree with that sentiment.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I thought he made the right decision to do so.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I didn't think he necessarily made the right decision to take land troops off the table right before we committed ourselves offensively, but nevertheless, it worked.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The administration deserves credit for having made it work.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It is important for NATO to have it work.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's important for NATO to be strong and confident and to help keep the peace in Europe.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And one of the reasons I felt so strongly that the United States needed to participate was because of our relations with NATO, and NATO is going to be an important part of keeping the peace in the future.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Now, there's more work to do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Remains to be seen, however, whether or not there's going to be a political settlement in Kosovo, and I certainly hope there is one.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m on record as saying at some point in time I hope our European friends become the peacekeepers in Bosnia and in the Balkans.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I hope that they put the troops on the ground so that we can withdraw our troops and focus our military on fighting and winning war.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, I've been kind of a hard-liner on this issue for more than eight years.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: When I was in the senate before I became vice president I was pushing for stronger action against Milosevic.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: He caused the death of so many people.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: He was the last communist party boss there and then he became a dictator that by some other label he was still essentially a communist dictator.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And unfortunately now he is trying to reassert himself in Serbian politics.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Already just today the members of his political party said that they were going to ignore the orders of the new president of Serbia, and that they question his legitimacy, and he's still going to try to be actively involved.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: He is an indicted war criminal.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: He should be held accountable.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, I did want to pick up on one of the statements earlier, and maybe I have heard, maybe I have heard the previous statements wrong, Governor.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: In some of the discussions we've had about when it's appropriate for the U.S. to use force around the world, at times the standards that you've laid down have given me the impression that if it's something like a genocide taking place or what they called ethnic cleansing in Bosnia, that that alone would not be, that that wouldn't be the kind of situation that would cause you to think that the U.S. ought to get involved with troops.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, have to be other factors involved for me to want to be involved.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But by itself, that to me can bring into play a fundamental American strategic interest because I think it's based on our values.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, have I got that wrong?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Trying to figure out who the questioner was.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If I think it's in our nation's strategic interest I'll commit troops.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I thought it was in our strategic interests to keep Milosevic in check because of our relations in NATO, and that's why I took the position I took.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think it's important for NATO to be strong and confident.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I felt like unchecked Milosevic would harm NATO, and so it depends on the situation, Mr. Vice President.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Can you run through the list again?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I thought that was a mistake.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Yes, I voted for it, supported it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Of course, and that again -- no, I think that that was ill-considered.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I did support it at the time.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It was in the previous administration, in the Bush-Quayle administration, and I think in retrospect the lessons there are ones that we should take very, very seriously.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Started off as a humanitarian mission and it changed into a nation-building mission, and that's where the mission went wrong.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And as a result, our nation paid a price.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so I don't think our troops ought to be used for what's called nation-building.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think our troops ought to be used to fight and win war.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think our troops ought to be used to help overthrow the dictator when it's in our best interests.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But in this case it was a nation-building exercise, and same with Haiti.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I wouldn't have supported either.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Some of them I've got a conflict of interest on, if you know what I mean.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think the administration did the right thing in that case.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It was a horrible situation, no one liked to see it on our TV screens, but it's a case where we need to make sure we have an early warning system in place in places where there could be ethnic cleansing and genocide the way we saw it there in Rwanda.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's a case where we need to use our influence to have countries in Africa come together and help deal with the situation.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The administration, seems like we're having a great love fest tonight, but the administration made the right decision on training Nigerian troops for situations just such as this in Rwanda, and so I thought they made the right decision not to send U.S. troops into Rwanda.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'd like to come back to the question of nation building, but let me address the question directly, first.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We did, actually, send troops into Rwanda to help with the humanitarian relief measures.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: My wife Tipper, who is here, actually went on a military plane with General Sholicatchvieli on one of those flights.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But I think in retrospect we were too late getting in there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We could have saved more lives if we had acted earlier.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But I do not think that it was an example of a conflict where we should have put our troops in to try to separate the parties for this reason, Jim.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: One of the criteria that I think is important in deciding when and if we should ever get involved around the world is whether or not our national security interest is involved, if we can really make the difference with military forces.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If we tried everything else, if we have allies.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: In the Balkans we have allies, NATO, ready, willing and able to go and carry a big part of the burden.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: In Africa we did not.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, we have tried -- our country has tried to create an Africa crisis response team there, and we've met some resistance.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We have had some luck with Nigeria, but in Sierra Leon, and now that Nigeria has become a democracy, and we hope it stays that way, then maybe we can build on that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But because we had no allies and because it was very unclear that we could actually accomplish what we would want to accomplish about putting military forces there, I think it was the right thing not to jump in, as heartbreaking as it was, but I think we should have come in much quicker with the humanitarian mission.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Well, I understand, and Africa is important.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we've got to do a lot of work in Africa to promote democracy and trade, and there are some -- Vice President mentioned Nigeria is a fledgling democracy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We have to work with Nigeria.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But there's got to be priorities, and Middle East is a priority for a lot of reasons, as is Europe and the Far East, our own hemisphere.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And those are my four top priorities should I be the president, not to say we won't be engaged nor work hard to get other nations to come together to prevent atrocity.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I thought the best example of a way to handle the situation was East Timor when we provided logistical support to the Australians, support that only we can provide.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But we can't be all things to all people in the world, Jim.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I think that's where maybe the vice president and I begin to have some differences.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm worried about overcommitting our military around the world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to be judicious in its use.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I wouldn't have sent troops to Haiti.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I didn't think it was a mission worthwhile.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It was a nation building mission, and it was not very successful.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It cost us billions, a couple billions of dollars, and I'm not so sure democracy is any better off in Haiti than it was before.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I would certainly also be judicious in evaluating any potential use of American troops overseas.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think we have to be very reticent about that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But look, Jim, the world is changing so rapidly.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The way I see it, the world is getting much closer together.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Like it or not, we are now -- the United States is now the natural leader of the world.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: All these other countries are looking to us.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, just because we cannot be involved everywhere, and shouldn't be, doesn't mean that we should shy away from going in anywhere.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, both of us are kind of, I guess, stating the other's position in a maximalist extreme way, but I think there is a difference here.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: This idea of nation building is kind of a pejorative phrase, but think about the great conflict of the past century, World War II.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: During the years between World War I and World War II, a great lesson was learned by our military leaders and the people of the United States.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The lesson was that in the aftermath of World War I, we kind of turned our backs and left them to their own devices and they brewed up a lot of trouble that quickly became World War II.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And acting upon that lesson in the aftermath of our great victory in World War II, we laid down the Marshall Plan, President Truman did.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We got intimately involved in building NATO and other structures there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We still have lots of troops in Europe.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And what did we do in the late '40's and '50's and '60's?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But it was also military.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And the confidence that those countries recovering from the wounds of war had by having troops there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We had civil administrators come in to set up their ways of building their towns back.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: First let me just say one comment about what the vice president said.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think one of the lessons in between World War I and World War II is we let our military atrophy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we can't do that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've got to rebuild our military.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But one of the problems we have in the military is we're in a lot of places around the world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I mentioned one, and that's the Balkans.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I would very much like to get our troops out of there.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I recognize we can't do it now, nor do I advocate an immediate withdrawal.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That would be an abrogation of our agreement with NATO.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: No one is suggesting that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I think it ought to be one of our priorities to work with our European friends to convince them to put troops on the ground.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And there is an example.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Now there are some places where I think -- you know, I've supported the administration in Columbia.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think it's important for us to be training Columbians in that part of the world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The hemisphere is in our interest to have a peaceful Columbia.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think what we need to do is convince people who live in the lands they live in to build the nations.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Maybe I'm missing something here.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I mean, we're going to have kind of a nation building core from America?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Our military is meant to fight and win war.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's what it's meant to do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And when it gets overextended, morale drops.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I strongly believe we need to have a military presence in the Korean peninsula, not only to keep the peace in the peninsula, but to keep regional stability.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I strongly believe we need to keep a presence in NATO, but I'm going to be judicious as to how to use the military.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It needs to be in our vital interest, the mission needs to be clear, and the extra strategy obvious.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't disagree with that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I certainly don't disagree that we ought to get our troops home from places like the Balkans as soon as we can, as soon as the mission is complete.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: That's what we did in Haiti.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: There are no more than a handful of American military personnel in Haiti now.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And Haitians have their problems, but we gave them a chance to restore democracy.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: That's really about all we can do.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But if you have a situation like that right in our backyard with chaos about to break out and flotillas forming to come across the water, and all kinds of violence there, right in one of our neighboring countries there, then I think that we did the right thing there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And as for this idea of nation building, the phrase sounds grandiose.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And, you know, we can't be -- we can't allow ourselves to get overextended.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I certainly agree with that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And that's why I've supported building up our capacity.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I've devoted in the budget I've proposed, as I said last week, more than twice as much as the governor has proposed.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that it's in better shape now than he generally does.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We've had some disagreements about that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: He said that two divisions would have to report not ready for duty, and that's not what the joint chiefs say.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But there's no doubt that we have to continue building up readiness and military strength.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And we have to also be very cautious in the way we use our military.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Well, I mentioned Third World debt.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's a place where we can use our generosity to influence in a positive way, influence nations.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe we ought to have foreign aid, but I don't think we ought to just have foreign aid for the sake of foreign aid.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think foreign aid needs to be used to encourage markets and reform.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think a lot of times we just spend aid and say we feel better about it and it ends up being spent the wrong way, and there's some pretty egregious examples recently.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One being Russia, where we had IMF loans that ended up in the pockets of a lot of powerful people and didn't help the nation.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think the IMF has got a role in the world, but I don't want to see the IMF out there as a way to say to world bankers, if you make a bad loan, we'll bail you out.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It needs to be available for emergency situations.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I thought the President did the right thing with Mexico and was very strongly supportive of the administration in Mexico.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I don't think the IMF ought to be a stop loss for people who ought to be able to evaluate risks themselves.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So I'll look at every place where we're investing money.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I just want to make sure the return is good.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: No, I would make some changes.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think there need to be reforms in the IMF.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I've generally supported it, but I've seen them make some calls that I thought were highly questionable.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I think that there's a general agreement in many parts of the world now that there ought to be changes in the IMF.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The World Bank I think is generally doing a better job, but I think one of the big issues here that doesn't get nearly enough attention is the issue of corruption.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The governor mentioned it earlier.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I've worked on this issue.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It's an enormous problem and corruption in official agencies, like militaries and police departments around the world, customs officials, that's one of the worst forms of it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And we have got to again lead by example and help these other countries that are trying to straighten out their situations find the tools in order to do it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I just think, Jim, that this is an absolutely unique period in world history.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The worldÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s coming together, as I said, they're looking to us.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And we have a fundamental choice to make.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Are we going to step up to the plate as a nation the way we did after World War II, the way that generation of heroes said okay, the United States is going to be the leader.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And the world benefitted tremendously from the courage that they showed in those post-war years.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that in the aftermath of the Cold War, it's time for us to do something very similar, to step up to the plate, to provide the leadership on the environment, leadership to make sure the world economy keeps moving in the right direction.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Again, that means not running big deficits here and not squandering our surplus.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It means having intelligent decisions that keep our prosperity going and shepherds that economic strength so that we can provide that leadership role.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Let me comment on that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm not so sure the role of the United States is to go around the world and say this is the way it's got to be.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And maybe it's just our difference in government, the way we view government.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to empower the people.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to help people help themselves, not have government tell people what to do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I just don't think it's the role of the United States to walk into a country and say, Ã¢â‚¬Å“we do it this way, so should you.Ã¢â‚¬Â I think we can help.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I know we've got to encourage democracy in the marketplaces.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But take Russia, for example.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We went into Russia, we said here is some IMF money, and it ended up in Viktor Chemomyrdin's pocket, and others, and yet we played like there was reform.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The only people that are going to reform Russia are Russia.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They're going to have to make the decision themselves.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Mr. Putin is going to have to make the decision as to whether or not he wants to adhere to rule of law and normal accounting practices so that if countries and/or entities invest capital, there's a reasonable rate of return, a way to get the money out of the economy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But Russia has to make the decision.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We can work with them on security matters, for example, but it's their call to make.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So I'm not exactly sure where the vice president is coming from, but I think one way for us to end up being viewed as the ugly American is for us to go around the world saying, Ã¢â‚¬Å“we do it this way, so should you.Ã¢â‚¬Â Now, we trust freedom.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We know freedom is a powerful, powerful, powerful force, much bigger than the United States of America, as we saw recently in the Balkans.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But maybe I misunderstand where you're coming from, Mr. Vice President, but I think the United States must be humble and must be proud and confident of our values, but humble in how we treat nations that are figuring out how to chart their own course.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Far be it from me to suggest otherwise.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The only thing an executive order can accomplish is to ban it in federal law enforcement agencies, but I would also support a law in the Congress that would have the effect of doing the same thing.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I just -- I think that racial profiling is a serious problem.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I remember when the stories first came out about the stops in New Jersey by the highway patrol there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I know it's been going on a long time.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: In some ways this is just a new label for something that has been going on for years.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But I have to confess that it was the first time that I really focused on it in a new way.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I was surprised at the extent of it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I think we've now got so many examples around the country that we really have to find ways to end this.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Imagine what it -- what it is like for someone to be singled out unfairly, unjustly, and feel the unfair force of law simply because of race or ethnicity.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, that runs counter to what the United States of America is all about at our core.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And it's not an easy problem to solve.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But if I am entrusted with the presidency, it will be the first Civil Rights Act of the 21st century.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Yeah, I can't imagine what it would be like to be singled out because of race and stopped and harassed.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's just flat wrong, and that's not what America is all about.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so we ought to do everything we can to end racial profiling.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One of my concerns, though, is I don't want to federalize the local police forces.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to -- obviously in the egregious cases we need to enforce civil rights law, but we need to make sure that internal affairs divisions at the local level do their job and be given a chance to do their job.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe in local control of governments, and obviously if they don't there needs to be a consequence at the federal level.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But it's very important that we not overstep our bounds and I think most people -- most police officers are good, dedicated, honorable citizens who are doing their job, putting their lives at risk who aren't bigoted or aren't prejudiced.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't think they ought to be held guilty.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I do think we need to find out where racial profiling occurs and do something about it and say to the local folks, get it done.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And if you can't, there will be a federal consequence.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I also agree that most police officers, of course, are doing a good job and hate this practice also.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I talked to an African-American police officer in Springfield, Massachusetts not long ago who raised this question and said that in his opinion one of the biggest solutions is in the training.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And not only the training in police procedures, but human relations.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I think that racial profiling is part of a larger issue of how we deal with race in America.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And as for singling people out because of race, you know, James Byrd was singled out because of his race in Texas.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And other Americans have been singled out because of their race or ethnicity.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And that's why I think we can embody our values by passing a hate crimes law.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think these crimes are different.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think they're different because they're based on prejudice and hatred, which gives rise to crimes that have not just a single victim, but they're intended to stigmatize and dehumanize a whole group of people.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We've got one in Texas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The three men who murdered James Byrd, guess what's going to happen to them?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They're going to be put to death.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: A jury found them guilty.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's going to be hard to punish them any worse after they get put to death.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And it's the right cause.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Secondly, there is other forms of racial profiling that goes on in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Arab-Americans are racially profiled in what is called secret evidence.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: People are stopped, and we have to do something about that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My friend, Senator Spencer Abraham of Michigan, is pushing a law to make sure that Arab-Americans are treated with respect.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So racial profiling isn't just an issue at local police forces.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's an issue throughout our society.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And as we become a diverse society, we're going to have to deal with it more and more.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe, though -- I believe, as sure as I'm sitting here, that most Americans really care.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's the very few that create most of the crises, and we just have to find them and deal with them.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Let me tell you where the biggest discrimination comes.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In public education when we just move children through the schools.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My friend, Phyllis Hunter, is here.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: She had one of the greatest lines of all lines.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: She said, reading is the new civil right.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And to make sure our society is as hopeful as it possibly can be, every single child in America must be educated.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It starts with making sure every child learns to read.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: K-2 diagnostic testing so we know whether or not there's a deficiency.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Curriculum that works and phonics needs to be an integral part of our reading curriculum.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Intensive reading laboratories, teacher retraining.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I mean, there needs to be a wholesale effort against racial profiling, which is illiterate children.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We can do better in our public schools.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We can close an achievement gap, and it starts with making sure we have strong accountability, Jim.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One of the cornerstones of reform, and good reform, is to measure.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Because when you measure you can ask the question, do they know?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Is anybody being discriminated against?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It becomes a tool, a corrective tool.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I believe the federal government must say that if you receive any money, any money from the federal government for disadvantaged children, for example, you must show us whether or not the children are learning.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And if they are, fine.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And if they're not, there has to be a consequence.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so to make sure we end up getting rid of basic structural prejudice is education.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There is nothing more prejudiced than not educating a child.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, I think we need tough enforcement of the civil rights laws.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think we still need affirmative action.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I would pass a hate crimes law, as I said, and I guess I had misunderstood the governor's previous position.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The Byrd family may have a misunderstanding of it in Texas also.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But I would like to shift, if I could, to the big issue of education.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Well, I had thought that there was a controversy at the end of the legislative session where the hate crimes law in Texas was -- failed, and that the Byrd family, among others, asked you to support it, Governor, and it died in committee for lack of support.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Am I wrong about that?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Well, you don't realize we have a hate crimes statute?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm talking about the one that was proposed to deal --
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: No -- well, what the Vice President must not understand is we've got a hate crimes bill in Texas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And secondly, the people that murdered Mr. Byrd got the ultimate punishment.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In this case when you murder somebody it's hate, Jim.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And they got the ultimate punishment.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm not exactly sure how you enhance the penalty any more than the death penalty.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We happen to have a statute on the books that's a hate crimes statute in Texas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't want to jump in.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I may have been misled by all the news reports about this matter, because the law that was proposed in Texas that had the support of the Byrd family and a whole lot of people in Texas did, in fact, die in committee.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: There may be some other statute that was already on the books, but certainly the advocates of the hate crimes law felt that a tough new law was needed.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And it's important, Jim, not only -- not just because of Texas, but because this mirrors the national controversy.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: There is pending now in the Congress a national hate crimes law because of James Byrd, because of Matthew Shepard, who was crucified on a split rail fence by bigots, and because of others.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And that law has died in committee also because of the same kind of opposition.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I would support the Orrin Hatch version of it, not the Senator Kennedy version.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But let me say to you, Mr. Vice President, we're happy with our laws on our books.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That bill did -- there was another bill that did die in committee.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I want to repeat, if you have a state that fully supports the law like we do in Texas, we're going to go after all crime.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we're going to make sure people get punished for the crime.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And in this case we can't enhance the penalty any more than putting those three thugs to death.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's what's gonna happen in the State of Texas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm not for gay marriage.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think marriage is a sacred institution between a man and a woman.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I appreciated the way the administration signed the Defense of Marriage Act.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I presume the Vice President supported it when the President signed that bill and supports it now.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I think marriage is a sacred institution.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm going to be respectful for people who may disagree with me.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've had a record of doing so in the State of Texas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've been a person that had been called a uniter, not a divider, because I accept other people's points of view.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I feel strongly that marriage should be between a man and a woman.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I agree with that, and I did support that law.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But I think that we should find a way to allow some kind of civic unions, and I basically agree with Dick Cheney and Joe Lieberman.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I think the three of us have one view and the Governor has another view.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I'm not sure what kind of view he's describing to me.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I can just tell you, I'm a person who respects other people.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I respect their -- I respect -- on the one hand he says he agrees with me and then he says he doesn't.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm not sure where he's coming from.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I will be a tolerant person.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've been a tolerant person all my life.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I just happen to believe strongly that marriage is between a man and a woman.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't think they ought to have special rights, but I think they ought to have the same rights.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, there's a law pending called the Employment Non-Discrimination Act.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: What it says is that gays and lesbians can't be fired from their job because they're gay or lesbian.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And it would be a federal law preventing that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, I wonder if the -- it's been blocked by the opponents in the majority in the Congress.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I wonder if the Governor would lend his support to that law.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Well, I have no idea.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I mean, he can throw out all kinds -- I don't know the particulars of this law.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I will tell you I'm the kind of person, I don't hire or fire somebody based upon their sexual orientation.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: As a matter of fact, I would like to take the issue a little further.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't really think it's any of my -- you know, any of my concerns what -- how you conduct your sex life.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I think that's the way it ought to be.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I'm going to be respectful for people, I'll tolerate people, and I support equal rights but not special rights for people.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, it would be if they're given special protective status.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That doesn't mean we shouldn't fully enforce laws and fully protect people and fully honor people, which I will do as the President of the United States.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Jim, I hope that we can come back to the subject of education because the governor made an extensive statement on it and I have a very different view than the one he expressed.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But that having been said, I believe that -- well, first of all, let me say that the governor and I agree on some things where this subject is concerned.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I will not do anything to affect the rights of hunters or sportsmen.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that homeowners have to be respected and their right to have a gun if they wish to.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The problem I see is that there are too many guns getting into the hands of children, and criminals, and people who, for whatever reason, some kind of history of stalking or domestic abuse really should not be able to get guns.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think these assault weapons are a problem.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: So I favor closing the gun show loophole.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: In fact, I cast the tie-breaking vote to close it, but then the majority in the House of Representatives went the other way.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If we could get agreement on that, maybe they could pass that in the final days of this Congress.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think we ought to restore the three-day waiting period under the Brady Law.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think we should toughen the enforcement of gun laws so that the ones that are already on the books can be enforced much more effectively.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Some of the restrictions that have been placed by the Congress in the last couple of years.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think -- in the last few years I think have been unfortunate.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that we ought to make all schools gun free.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Have a gun-free zone around every school in this country.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that measures like these are important.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Child safety trigger locks on a mandatory basis, and others.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Well, it starts with enforcing law.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: When you say loud and clear to somebody if you're going to carry a gun illegally, we're going to arrest you.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If you're going to sell a gun illegally, you need to be arrested.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If you commit a crime with a gun, there needs to be absolute certainty in the law.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that means that the local law enforcement officials need help at the federal level.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Programs like Project Exile where the federal government intensifies arresting people who illegally use guns.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we haven't done a very good job of that at the federal level recently.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I'm going to make it a priority.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Secondly, I don't think we ought to be selling guns to people who shouldn't have them.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's why I support instant background checks at gun shows.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One of the reasons we have an instant background check is so that we instantly know whether or not somebody should have a gun or not.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In Texas I tried to do something innovative.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There's a lot of talk about trigger locks being on guns sold in the future.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I said if you want a trigger lock to make your gun safe, come and get one for free.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So we're distributing in our State of Texas for free.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think we ought to raise the age at which a juvenile can carry a handgun from 18 to 21.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I disagree with the vice president on this issue.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He is for registration of guns.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think the only people that are going to show up to register or get a license -- I guess licensing like a driver's license for a gun, the only people that are going to show up are law-abiding citizens.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The criminal is not going to show up and say hey, give me my I.D.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's the law-abiding citizens who will do that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: An I don't think that is going to be an effective tool to make the -- keep our society safe.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, I'm not for registration.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I am for licensing by states of new handgun purchases.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: like a driver's license for new handguns and, you know, the Los Angeles --
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think states should do that for new handguns, because too many criminals are getting guns.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: There was a recent investigation of the number in Texas who got -- who were given concealed weapons permits in spite of the fact that they had records.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And the "Los Angeles Times" spent a lot of ink going into that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But I am not for doing anything that would affect hunters or sportsmen, rifles, shotguns, existing handguns.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I do think that sensible gun safety measures are warranted now.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Look, this is the year -- this is in the aftermath of Columbine, and Paducah, and all the places in our country where the nation has been shocked by these weapons in the hands of the wrong people.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The woman who bought the guns for the two boys who did that killing at Columbine said that if she had had to give her name and fill out a form there, she would not have bought those guns.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: That conceivably could have prevented that tragedy.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Well, I'm not for photo licensing.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Let me say something about Columbine.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Listen, we've got gun laws.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He says we ought to have gun-free schools.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm sure every state in the union has got them.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You can't carry a gun into a school.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And there ought to be a consequence when you do carry a gun into a school.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But Columbine spoke to a larger issue.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's really a matter of culture.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's a culture that somewhere along the line we've begun to disrespect life.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Where a child can walk in and have their heart turned dark as a result of being on the Internet and walk in and decide to take somebody else's life?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So gun laws are important, no question about it, but so is loving children, and character education classes, and faith-based programs being a part of after-school programs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Some desperate child needs to have somebody put their arm around them and say, we love you.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So there's a -- this is a society that -- of ours that's got to do a better job of teaching children right from wrong.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we can enforce law.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But there seems to be a lot of preoccupation on -- not certainly only in this debate, but just in general on law.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But there's a larger law.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Love your neighbor like you would like to be loved yourself.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's where our society must head if we're going to be a peaceful and prosperous society.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I also believe in the Golden Rule.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I agree with a lot of the other things that the governor has said.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We do have a serious problem in our culture.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Tipper and I have worked on the problem of violence in entertainment aimed at children.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: She's worked on it longer than I have.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But I feel very strongly about that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And if I'm elected president, I will do something about that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But I think that we -- I think we have to start with better parenting.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But I don't think that we can ignore the role played by guns.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I mean, the fact is that there -- even though no state wants them, there are guns in some schools.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And the reason it's so difficult for schools to control that is because in recent years there has been a flood of cheap handguns that are so widely available that kids are finding ways to get ahold of them.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I think that if you look at the situation as it exists here in the United States compared to any other country in the world, it seems to me pretty obvious that while we respect the rights of hunters and sportsmen, we do need some common sense gun safety steps to stem this flood of guns that are getting into the wrong hands.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Yeah, no question about that, but there also needs to be strong enforcement of the law.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Some kid who feels like -- doesn't matter where the gun comes from, it could be a cheap gun, expensive gun.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: What matters is something in this person's head says there is not going to be a consequence.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So in my state we toughen up the juvenile justice laws.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We believe in tough love.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We say, if you get caught carrying a gun, you're automatically detained.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's what needs to happen.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If laws need to be strengthened, like instant background checks, that's important.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, I've got a plan to do something about that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's to make health care affordable and available this way.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: First, there's some who should be buying health care who choose not to.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Some of the healthy folks, healthy young kids say I'll never get sick, therefore I don't need health care right now.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: For those what I think we need to do is to develop an investment-type vehicle that would be an incentive for them to invest, like medical savings accounts with rollover capacity.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In other words, you say to a youngster, it will be in your financial interest to start saving for future illness, but for the working folks that do want to have health care that can't afford it, a couple of things we need to do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One, we need more community health centers.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've developed -- put out money in my budget to expand community health centers all around the country.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: These are places where people can get primary care.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Secondly -- and they're good.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They're very important parts of the safety net of health care.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Secondly, that you get a $2,000 rebate from the government if you're a family of $30,000 or less -- it scales down as you get higher -- that you can use to purchase health care in the private markets.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It will be a huge down payment for a pretty darn good system.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If you allow -- also allow -- convince states to -- allow states to allow the mother to match some of the children's health insurance money with it, the pool purchasing power.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And to make health care more affordable, allow business associations like the National Federal of Independent Business or the Chamber of Commerce or the National Restaurant Association to write association plans across jurisdictional lines so that small businesses have got the capacity to have national pooling to drive the cost of insurance down.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think that's the very best way to go.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It empowers people, it trusts people, it makes -- and it's a practical way to encourage people to purchase health care insurance.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's one of my top priorities, Jim, to give every single child in the United States affordable health care within the next four years.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I would like to see eventually in this country some form of universal health care, but I'm not for a government-run system.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: In fact, I'm for shrinking the size of government.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I want a smaller and smarter government.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I have been in charge of this reinventing government streamlining project that's reduced the size of government by more than 300,000 people in the last several years.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And the budget plan that I've put out, according to the "Los Angeles Times" again, the way these things are typically measured as a percentage of the GDP, will bring government spending down to the lowest level in 50 years.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: So I want to proceed carefully to cover more people.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But I think we should start by greatly expanding the so-called child health insurance or CHIP program to give health insurance to every single child in this country.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think it's intolerable that we have so many millions of children without any health insurance.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: So it's one of my top priorities.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, I know that we have some disagreements on this.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I'm sorry to tell you that, you know, there is a record here.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And Texas ranks 49th out of the 50 states in health care -- in children with health care.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: 49th for women with health care, and 50th for families with health care.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: So it is a priority for me.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I'm not aware of any program -- well, I'll just leave it at that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think it ought to be a top priority.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: First of all, let me say he's not for a government-run health care system?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I thought that's exactly what he and Mrs. Clinton and them fought for in 1993 was a government-run health care system.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It was fortunately stopped in its tracks.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Secondly, we spend $4.7 billion a year on the uninsured in the State of Texas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Our rate of uninsured, the percentage of uninsured in Texas has gone down, while the percentage of uninsured in America has gone up.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Our CHIPS program got a late start because our government meets only four months out of every two years, Mr. Vice President.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It may come as a shock for somebody who has been in Washington for so long.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But actually limited government can work in the second largest state in the union.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've signed up over 110,000 children to the CHIPS program.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: For comparable states our size, we're signing them up as fast as any other state.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You can quote all the numbers you want, but I'm telling you we care about our people in Texas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We spent a lot of money to make sure people get health care in the State of Texas, and we're doing a better job than they are at the national level for reducing uninsured.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, I don't know about all these percentages that he throws out, but I do know that -- I speculate that the reason why he didn't answer your question directly as to whether my numbers were right, the facts were right about Texas ranking dead last in families with health insurance and 49th out of 50 for both children and women, is because those facts are correct.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And as for why it happened, I'm no expert on the Texas procedures, but what my friends there tell me is that the governor opposed a measure put forward by Democrats in the legislature to expand the number of children that would be covered.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And instead directed the money toward a tax cut, a significant part of which went to wealthy interests.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: He declared the need for a new tax cut for the oil companies in Texas an emergency need, and so the money was taken away from the CHIP program.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: There's -- you don't have to take my word for this.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: There is now a federal judge's opinion about the current management of this program ordering the State of Texas to do -- you should read that judge's language about this.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: 600,000 of whom, and maybe some of those have since gotten it, but as of a year ago 600,000 of them were actually eligible for it but they couldn't sign up for it because of the barriers that they had set up.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If he's trying to allege that I'm a hard-hearted person and I don't care about children, he's absolutely wrong.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And they get health care.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Now, it's not the most efficient way to get people health care.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I want to remind you, the number of uninsured in America during their watch has increased.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He can make any excuse he wants, but the facts are that we're reducing the number of uninsured percentage of our population.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And as the percentage of the population is increasing nationally, somehow the allegation that we don't care and we're going to give money for this interest or that interest and not for children in the State of Texas is totally absurd.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Let me just tell you who the jury is.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There's only been one governor ever elected to back-to-back four-year terms, and that was me.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I was able to do so with a lot of Democrat votes, nearly 50% of the Hispanic vote, about 27% of the African-American vote, because people know I'm a conservative person and a compassionate person.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So he can throw all the kinds of numbers around.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm just telling you our state comes together to do what is right.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We come together both Republicans and Democrats.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But it's not a statement about his heart.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I don't claim to know his heart.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think he's a good person.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I make no allegations about that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I believe him when he says that he has a good heart.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I know enough about your story to admire a lot of the things that you have done as a person.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But I think it's about his priorities.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And let me tell you exactly why I think that the choice he made to give a tax cut for the oil companies and others before addressing this -- I mean, if you were the governor of a state that was dead last in health care for families, and all of a sudden you found yourself with the biggest surplus your state had ever had in its history, wouldn't you want to maybe use some of it to climb from 50th to, say, 45 or 40 or something or maybe better?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, but here is why it's directly relevant, Jim.
Speaker: Al Gore
