Text: Because by his own budget numbers, his proposals for spending on tax cuts for the wealthiest of the wealthy are more than the new spending proposals that he has made for health care and education and national defense all combined.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: According to his own numbers.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: So it's not a question of his heart, as far as I know.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It's a question of priorities and values.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: First of all, that's simply not true what he just said, of course.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And secondly, I repeat to you --
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That we spent -- the top 1% receive 223 as opposed to 445 billion in new spending.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The top -- let's talk about my tax plan.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The top 1% will pay one-third of all the federal income taxes.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And in return, get one-fifth of the benefits, because most of the tax reductions go to the people at the bottom end of the economic ladder.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That stands in stark contrast, by the way, to a man who is going to leave 50 million -- 50 million Americans out of tax relief.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We just have a different point of view.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's a totally different point of view.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He believes only the right people ought to get tax relief.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe everybody who pays taxes ought to get tax relief.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Let me go back to Texas, for example, for a minute.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I can't emphasize to you how much.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I signed a bill that puts CHIPS in place.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The bill finally came out at the end of the 1999 session.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're working hard to sign up children.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're doing it faster than any other state our size, comparable state.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're making really good progress.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And our state cares a lot about our children.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My priority is going to be the health of our citizens.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: These folks have had eight years to get something done in Washington, D.C. on the uninsured.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They have not done it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They've had eight years to get something done on Medicare.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And they have not got it done.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And my case to the American people is, if you're happy with inactivity, stay with the horse.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The horse is up here now.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But if you want change, you need to get somebody that knows how to bring Republicans and Democrats together to get positive things done for America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think that in this 21st century we will soon see the consequences of what's called global warming.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: There was a study just a few weeks ago suggesting that in summertime the north polar ice cap will be completely gone in 50 years.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Already many people see the strange weather conditions that the old timers say they've never seen before in their lifetimes.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And what's happening is the level of pollution is increasing significantly.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, here is the good news, Jim.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If we take the leadership role and build the new technologies, like the new kinds of cars and trucks that Detroit is itching to build, then we can create millions of good new jobs by being first into the market with these new kinds of cars and trucks and other kinds of technologies.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: You know the Japanese are breathing down our necks on this.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: They're moving very rapidly because they know that it is a fast-growing world market.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Some of these other countries, particularly in the developing world, their pollution is much worse than anywhere else and their people want higher standards of living.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And so they're looking for ways to satisfy their desire for a better life and still reduce pollution at the same time.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that holding onto the old ways and the old argument that the environment and the economy are in conflict is really outdated.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We have to be bold.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We have to provide leadership.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now it's true that we disagree on this.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The governor said that he doesn't think this problem is necessarily caused by people.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: He's for letting the oil companies into the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Houston has just become the smoggiest city in the country.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We have a very different outlook.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I'll tell you this, I will fight for a clean environment in ways that strengthen our economy.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Well, let me start with Texas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We are a big industrial state.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We reduced our industrial waste by 11%.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We cleaned up more brown fields than any other administration in my state's history, 450 of them.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Our water is cleaner now.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: A brown field is an abandoned industrial site that just sits idle in some of our urban centers.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And people are willing to invest capital in the brown fields don't want to do so for fear of lawsuit.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think we ought to have federal liability protection, depending upon whether or not standards have been met.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The book you mentioned that Vice President Gore wrote, he also called for taxing -- big energy taxes in order to clean up the environment.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And now that the energy prices are high, I guess he's not advocating those big energy taxes right now.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe we ought to fully fund the Land and Water Conservation Fund to -- with half the money going to states so states can make the right decisions for environmental quality.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think we need to have clean coal technologies.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I propose $2 billion worth.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: By the way, I just found out the other day an interesting fact, that there is a national petroleum reserve right next to -- in Prudhoe Bay that your administration opened up for exploration in that pristine area.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And it was a smart move because there's gas reserves up there.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We need gas pipelines to bring the gas down.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Gas is a clean fuel that we can burn to -- we need to make sure that if we decontrol our plants that there's mandatory -- that the plants must conform to clean air standards, the grandfathered plants, that's what we did in Texas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In other words, there are practical things we can do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But it starts with working in a collaborative effort with states and local folks.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If you own the land, every day is Earth Day.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: People care a lot about their land and care about their environment.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Not all wisdom is in Washington, D.C. on this issue.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm really strongly committed to clean water and clean air, and cleaning up the new kinds of challenges like global warming.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: He is right that I'm not in favor of energy taxes.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I am in favor of tax cuts to encourage and give incentives for the quicker development of these new kinds of technologies.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And let me say again, Detroit is rearing to go on that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We differ on the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, as I have said.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We differ on whether or not pollution controls ought to be voluntary.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I don't think you can -- I don't think you can get results that way.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We differ on the kinds of appointments that we would make.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think it's a fundamental difference.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Let me give you an example.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Well, I don't believe in command and control out of Washington, D.C.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe Washington ought to set standards, but again I think we ought to be collaborative at the local levels and I think we ought to work with people at the local levels.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And by the way, I just want to make sure -- I can't let him just say something and not correct it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The electric decontrol bill that I fought for and signed in Texas has mandatory emission standards, Mr. Vice President.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's what we ought to do at the federal level when it comes to grandfathered plants for utilities.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think there's a difference.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think, for example, take -- when they took 40 million acres of land out of circulation without consulting local officials, I thought that was --
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Out in the west, yeah.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so -- on the logging issue.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's not the way I would have done it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Perhaps some of that land needs to be set aside.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I certainly would have consulted with governors and elected officials before I would have acted unilaterally.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Sure, absolutely, so long as they're based upon science and they're reasonable.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So long as people have input.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think it's an issue that we need to take very seriously.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I don't think we know the solution to global warming yet.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I don't think we've got all the facts before we make decisions.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I tell you one thing I'm not going to do is I'm not going to let the United States carry the burden for cleaning up the world's air.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Like Kyoto Treaty would have done.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: China and India were exempted from that treaty.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think we need to be more even-handed, as evidently 99 senators -- I think it was 99 senators supported that position.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, that vote wasn't exactly -- a lot of the supporters of the Kyoto Treaty actually ended up voting for that because the way it was worded.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But there's no doubt there's a lot of opposition to it in the Senate.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I'm not for command and control techniques either.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I'm for working with the groups, not just with industry but also with the citizen groups and local communities to control sprawl in ways that the local communities themselves come up with.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But I disagree that we don't know the cause of global warming.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that we do.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It's pollution, carbon dioxide, and other chemicals that are even more potent, but in smaller quantities, that cause this.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Look, the world's temperature is going up, weather patterns are changing, storms are getting more violent and unpredictable.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: What are we going to tell our children?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I want to be able to tell my grandson when I'm in my later years that I didn't turn away from the evidence that showed that we were doing some serious harm.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: In my faith tradition, it is -- it's written in the book of Matthew, "Where your heart is, there is your treasure also."
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I believe that -- that we ought to recognize the value to our children and grandchildren of taking steps that preserve the environment in a way that's good for them.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I just -- I think there has been -- some of the scientists, I believe, Mr. Vice President, haven't they been changing their opinion a little bit on global warming?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: A profound scientist recently made a different --
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've been trying so hard not to.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: That's an interruption, by the way.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I apologize, Mr. Vice President.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Of course they care about them.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Oh, you mean the rules.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I -- of course there's a lot -- look, global warming needs to be taken very seriously, and I take it seriously.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But science, there's a lot -- there's differing opinions.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And before we react, I think it's best to have the full accounting, full understanding of what's taking place.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I think to answer your question, I think both of us care a lot about the environment.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We may have different approaches.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We may have different approaches in terms of how we deal with local folks.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I just cited an example of the administration just unilaterally acting without any input.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I remember you gave a very good answer to New Hampshire about the White Mountains, about how it was important to keep that collaborative effort in place.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I feel very strongly the same place.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It certainly wasn't the attitude that took place out west, however.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, we all make mistakes.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've been known to mangle a syl-a-ble or two myself, you know, if you know what I mean.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think credibility is important.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It is going to be important for the president to be credible with Congress, important for the president to be credible with foreign nations.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And yes, I think it's something that people need to consider.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I read a report, or a memo, from somebody in his 1988 campaign -- I forgot the fellow's name -- warning then Senator Gore to be careful about exaggerating claims.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I thought during his debate with Senator Bradley saying he authored the EITC when it didn't happen.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I mention the last debate --
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The Earned Income Tax Credit, sorry.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: A lot of initials from a guy who's not from Washington, isn't it?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Anyway, he co-sponsored McCain-Feingold, and yet he didn't.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so I think this is an issue.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I found it to be an issue in trying to defend my tax relief package.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I thought there was some exaggerations about the numbers.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But the people are going to have to make up their mind on this issue.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I am going to continue to defend my record and defend my propositions against what I think are exaggerations.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Exaggerations like, for example, only 5% of seniors receive benefits under my Medicare reform package.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's what he said the other day, and that's simply not the case.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I have every right in the world to defend my record and positions.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's what debates are about and that's what campaigns are about.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I got some of the details wrong last week in some of the examples that I used, Jim, and I'm sorry about that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I'm going to try to do better.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: One of the reasons I regret it is that getting a detail wrong interfered several times with the point that I was trying to make.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: However many days that young girl in Florida stood in her classroom, however long, even if it was only one day, doesn't change the fact that there are a lot of overcrowded classrooms in America and we need to do something about that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: There are seniors who pay more for their prescriptions than a lot of other people, more than their pets, sometimes.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: More sometimes than people in foreign countries.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And we need to do something about that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Not with the measure that leaves the majority of them without any real basic help until the next president's term of four years is over.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And that means doing it under the Medicare program.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I can't promise that I will never get another detail wrong.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I can promise you that I will try not to, and hard.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But I will promise you this with all the confidence in my heart and in the world, that I will do my best if I'm elected president, I'll work my heart out to get the big things right for the American people.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: That's going to be up to the people, isn't it?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Depends on what he says in the future in the campaign.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I hope they're not awful things.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think they may be using the man's own words.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't believe I've used those words.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't use language like that and I don't think that we should.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The -- I haven't seen that, in my commercials?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: You haven't seen the commercial?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think that what -- I think the point of that is that anybody would have a hard time trying to make a tax cut plan that is so large, that would put us into such big deficits, that gives almost half the benefits to the wealthiest of the wealthy.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think anybody would have a hard time explaining that clearly in a way that makes sense to the average person.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: That's the kind of exaggeration I was just talking about.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, I wasn't the one having trouble explaining it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Jim, one of the issues that I would like to close with in my statement is education, because it's an example of the overall approach that I think is important.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: This race is about values, it's about change, it's about giving choices to the American people.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And education is my number one priority, because I think that it's the most important big major change that we can bring in our country.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I agree with Governor Bush that we should have new accountability, testing of students.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that we should require states to test all students, test schools and school districts, and I think that we should go further and require teacher testing for new teachers also.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The difference is that while my plan starts with new accountability and maintains local control, it doesn't stop there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Because I want to give new choices to parents.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: To send their kids to college with a $10,000 tax deduction for college tuition per child per year.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I want to reduce the size of the classrooms in this country.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: For one basic reason, so that students can get more one-on-one time with teachers.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And the way to do that is first to recruit more teachers.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I've a plan in my budget to recruit 100,000 new, highly qualified teachers and to help local school districts build new schools.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that we have to put more emphasis on early learning and pre-school.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, here is how that connects with all the rest of what we've been talking about.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you have -- if you squander the surplus on a huge tax cut that goes mostly to those at the top, then you can't make education the top priority.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If the tax cut is your number one, two, three and four priority, you can't do education.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I choose education and health care, the environment and retirement security, and I ask for your support.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Jim, thank you very much.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Mr. Vice President, thank you very much, and I would like to thank the folks here at Wake Forest, and I want to thank you all for listening.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm running to get some things done for America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There's too many issues left unresolved.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There's been too much finger pointing and too much name calling in Washington, D.C.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I would like to unite this country to get an agenda done that will speak to the hopes and aspirations of the future.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to have an education system that sets high standards, local control of schools and strong accountability.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: No child should be left behind in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to make sure we rebuild our military to keep the peace.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I worry about morale in today's military.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The warning signs are clear.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It is time to have a new commander in chief who will rebuild the military, pay our men and women more, make sure they're housed better and have a focused mission for our military.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Once and for all, I want to do something about Medicare.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This issue has been too long on the table because it's been a political issue.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's time to bring folks together to say that all seniors will get prescription drug coverage.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to do something about Social Security.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's an important priority, because now is the time to act and we're going to say to our seniors, our promises we've made to you will be promises kept.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But younger workers, in order to make sure the system exists tomorrow, younger workers ought to be able to take some of your own money and invest it in safe securities to get a better rate of return on that money.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And finally, I do believe in tax relief.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe we can set our priorities.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't believe, like the vice president does, in huge government.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe in limited government.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: By having a limited government and a focused government, we can send some of the money back to the people who pay the bills.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to have tax relief for all people who pay the bills in America, because I think you can spend your money more wisely than the federal government can.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm asking for your vote, and God bless.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Mr. Howe, Senator Kennedy, my fellow Americans.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Since this campaign began I have had a very rare privilege.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I have traveled to forty-eight of the fifty states and in my travels I have learned what the people of the United States are thinking about.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: There is one issue that stands out above all the rest, one in which every American is concerned, regardless of what group he may be a member and regardless of where he may live.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And that issue, very simply stated, is this: how can we keep the peace - keep it without surrender?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: How can we extend freedom - extend it without war?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now in determining how we deal with this issue, we must find the answer to a very important but simple question: who threatens the peace?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Who threatens freedom in the world?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: There is only one threat to peace and one threat to freedom - that that is presented by the international Communist movement.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And therefore if we are to have peace, we must know how to deal with the Communists and their leaders.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I also have had the opportunity of knowing and meeting other Communist leaders in the world.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I believe there are certain principles we must find in dealing with him and his colleagues - principles, if followed, that will keep the peace and that also can extend freedom.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: First, we have to learn from the past, because we cannot afford to make the mistakes of the past.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: In the seven years before this Administration came into power in Washington, we found that six hundred million people went behind the Iron Curtain.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And at the end of that seven years we were engaged in a war in Korea which cost of thirty thousand American lives.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: In the past seven years, in President Eisenhower's Administration, this situation has been reversed.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We ended the Korean War; by strong, firm leadership we have kept out of other wars; and we have avoided surrender of principle or territory at the conference table.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now why were we successful, as our predecessors were not successful?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I think there're several reasons.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: In the first place, they made a fatal error in misjudging the Communists; in trying to apply to them the same rules of conduct that you would apply to the leaders of the free world.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: One of the major errors they made was the one that led to the Korean War.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: In ruling out the defense of Korea, they invited aggression in that area.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: They thought they were going to have peace - it brought war.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We learned from their mistakes.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And so, in our seven years, we find that we have been firm in our diplomacy; we have never made concessions without getting concessions in return.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We have always been willing to go the extra mile to negotiate for disarmament or in any other area.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But we have never been willing to do anything that, in effect, surrendered freedom any place in the world.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: That is why President Eisenhower was correct in not apologizing or expressing regrets to Mr. Khrushchev at the Paris Conference, as Senator Kennedy suggested he could have done.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Why did the President feel this was wrong and why was the President right and his critics wrong?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Because again this showed a lack of understanding of dictators, a lack of understanding particularly of Communists, because every time you make such a concession it does not lead to peace; it only encourages them to blackmail you.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It encourages them to begin a war.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And so I say that the record shows that we know how to keep the peace, to keep it without surrender.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Let us move now to the future.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It is not enough to stand on this record because we are dealing with the most ruthless, fanatical... leaders that the world has ever seen.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: That is why I say that in this period of the sixties, America must move forward in every area.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: First of all, although we are today, as Senator Kennedy has admitted, the strongest nation in the world militarily, we must increase our strength, increase it so that we will always have enough strength that regardless of what our potential opponents have - if the should launch a surprise attack - we will be able to destroy their war-making capability.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: They must know, in other words, that it is national suicide if they begin anything.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We need this kind of strength because we're the guardians of the peace.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: In addition to military strength, we need to see that the economy of this country continues to grow.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It has grown in the past seven years.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It can and will grow even more in the next four.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And the reason that it must grow even more is because we have things to do at home and also because we're in a race for survival - a race in which it isn't enough to be ahead; it isn't enough simply to be complacent.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We have to move ahead in order to stay ahead.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And that is why, in this field, I have made recommendations which I am confident will move the American economy ahead - move it firmly and soundly so that there will never be a time when the Soviet Union will be able to challenge our superiority in this field.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Again we turn to the past.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Firmness but no belligerence, and by no belligerence I mean that we do not answer insult by insult.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: When you are proud and confident of your strength, you do not get down to the level of Mr. Khrushchev and his colleagues.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And that example that President Eisenhower has set we will continue to follow.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But all this by itself is not enough.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It is not enough for us simply to be the strongest nation militarily, the strongest economically, and also to have firm diplomacy.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We must have a great goal.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And that is: not just to keep freedom for ourselves but to extend it to all the world, to extend it to all the world because that is America's destiny.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: To extend it to all the world because the Communist aim is not to hold their own but to extend Communism.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And so I say that we believe that our policies of military strength, of economic strength, of diplomatic firmness first will keep the peace and keep it without surrender.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We also believe that in the great field of ideals that we can lead America to the victory for freedom - victory in the newly developing countries, victory also in the captive countries - provided we have faith in ourselves and faith in our principles.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Mr. Howe, Mr. Vice President.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: First uh - let me again try to correct the record on the matter of Quemoy and Matsu.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I have sustained it since then.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I've said that I agree with the Administration policy.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Mr. Nixon earlier indicated that he would defend Quemoy and Matsu even if the attack on these islands, two miles off the coast of China, were not part of a general attack an Formosa and the Pescadores.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I indicated that I would defend those islands if the attack were directed against Pescadores and Formosa, which is part of the Eisenhower policy.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: In the last week, as a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, I have re-read the testimony of General Twining representing the Administration in 1959, and the Assistant Secretary of State before the Foreign Relations Committee in 1958, and I have accurately described the Administration policy, and I support it wholeheartedly.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: So that really isn't an issue in this campaign.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: It isn't an issue with Mr. Nixon, who now says that he also supports the Eisenhower policy.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Nor is the question that all Americans want peace and security an issue in this campaign.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The question is: are we moving in the direction of peace and security?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Is our relative strength growing?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Is, as Mr. Nixon says, our prestige at an all-time high, as he said a week ago, and that of the Communists at an all-time low?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I don't believe it is.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I don't believe that our relative strength is increasing.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And I say that not as the Democratic standard-bearer, but as a citizen of the United States who is concerned about the United States.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I look at Cuba, ninety miles off the coast of the United States.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I talked to the American Ambassador there.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: He said that he was the second most powerful man in Cuba.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And yet even though Ambassador Smith and Ambassador Gardner, both Republican Ambassadors, both warned of Castro, the Marxist influences around Castro, the Communist influences around Castro, both of them have testified in the last six weeks, that in spite of their warnings to the American government, nothing was done.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Our d- security depends upon Latin America.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Can any American looking at the situation in Latin America feel contented with what's happening today, when a candidate for the presidency of Brazil feels it necessary to call - not on Washington during the campaign - but on Castro in Havana, in order to pick up the support of the Castro supporters in Brazil?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: At the American Conference - Inter-American Conference this summer, when we wanted them to join together in the denunciation of Castro and the Cuban Communists, we couldn't even get the Inter-American group to join together in denouncing Castro.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: It was rather a vague statement that they finally made.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Do you know today that the Com- the Russians broadcast ten times as many programs in Spanish to Latin America as we do?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Do you know we don't have a single program sponsored by our government to Cuba - to tell them our story, to tell them that we are their friends, that we want them to be free again?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Africa is now the emerging area of the world.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: It contains twenty-five percent of all the members of the General Assembly.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We didn't even have a Bureau of African Affairs until 1957.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: In the Africa south of the Sahara, which is the major new section, we have less students from all of Africa in that area studying under government auspices today than from the country of Thailand.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: If there's one thing Africa needs it's technical assistance.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We relied in the Middle East on the Baghdad Pact, and yet when the Iraqi Government was changed, the Baghdad Pact broke down.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We relied on the Eisenhower Doctrine for the Middle East, which passed the Senate.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We look to Europe uh - to Asia because the struggle is in the underdeveloped world.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Which system, Communism or freedom, will triumph in the next five or ten years?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: That's what should concern us, not the history of ten, or fifteen, or twenty years ago.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: What are freedom's chances in those areas?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: By 1965 or 1970, will there be other Cubas in Latin America?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Will Guinea and Ghana, which have now voted with the Communists frequently as newly independent countries of Africa - will there be others?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Will the Congo go Communist?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Is India going to win the economic struggle or is China going to win it?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Who will dominate Asia in the next five or ten years?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The question which we have to decide as Americans - are we doing enough today?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Is our strength and prestige rising?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Do people want to be identified with us?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Do they want to follow United States leadership?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I don't think they do, enough.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And that's what concerns me.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: In Africa - these countries that have newly joined the United Nations.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: On the question of admission of Red China, only two countries in all of Africa voted with us - Liberia and the Union of South Africa.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The rest either abstained or voted against us.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: More countries in Asia voted against us on that question than voted with us.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I believe that this struggle is going to go on, and it may be well decided in the next decade.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I have seen Cuba go to the Communists.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I have seen Communist influence and Castro influence rise in Latin America.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I have seen us ignore Africa.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: There are six countries in Africa that are members of the United Nations.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: There isn't a single American diplomatic representative in any of those six.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: When Guinea became independent, the Soviet Ambassador showed up that very day.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We didn't recognize them for two months; the American Ambassador didn't show up for nearly eight months.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I believe that the world is changing fast.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And I don't think this Administration has shown the foresight, has shown the knowledge, has been identified with the great fight which these people are waging to be free, to get a better standard of living, to live better.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The average income in some of those countries is twenty-five dollars a year.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The Communists say, "Come with us; look what we've done."
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And we've been in - on the whole, uninterested.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think we're going to have to do better.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Mr. Nixon talks about our being the strongest country in the world.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But we were far stronger relative to the Communists five years ago, and what is of great concern is that the balance of power is in danger of moving with them.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: They made a breakthrough in missiles, and by nineteen sixty-one, two, and three, they will be outnumbering us in missiles.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I'm not as confident as he is that we will be the strongest military power by 1963.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: He talks about economic growth as a great indicator of freedom.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: What we do in this country, the kind of society that we build, that will tell whether freedom will be sustained around the world.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And yet, in the last nine months of this year, we've had a drop in our economic growth rather than a gain.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We've had the lowest rate of increase of economic growth in the last nine months of any major industrialized society in the world.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I look up and see the Soviet flag on the moon.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The fact is that the State Department polls on our prestige and influence around the world have shown such a sharp drop that up till now the State Department has been unwilling to release them.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And yet they were polled by the U.S.I.A.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The point of all this is, this is a struggle in which we're engaged.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We want to be stronger.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We want freedom to gain.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But I don't believe in these changing and revolutionary times this Administration has known that the world is changing - has identified itself with that change.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think the Communists have been moving with vigor - Laos, Africa, Cuba - all around the world today they're on the move.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think we have to revita1ize our society.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think we have to demonstrate to the people of the world that we're determined in this free country of ours to be first - not first if, and not first but, and not first when - but first.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And when we are strong and when we are first, then freedom gains; then the prospects for peace increase; then the prospects for our society gain.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Our policies are very different.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I think that Senator Kennedy's policies and recommendations for the handling of the Castro regime are probably the most dangers- dangerously irresponsible recommendations that he's made during the course of this campaign.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: In effect, what Senator Kennedy recommends is that the United States government should give help to the exiles and to those within Cuba who oppose the Castro regime - provided they are anti-Batista.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now let's just see what this means.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We have five treaties with Latin America, including the one setting up the Organization of American States in Bogota in 1948, in which we have agreed not to intervene in the internal affairs of any other American country - and they as well have agreed to do likewise.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The charter of the United Nations - its Preamble, Article I and Article II - also provide that there shall be no intervention by one nation in the internal affairs of another.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now I don't know what Senator Kennedy suggests when he says that we should help those who oppose the Castro regime, both in Cuba and without.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But I do know this: that if we were to follow that recommendation, that we would lose all of our friends in Latin America, we would probably be condemned in the United Nations, and we would not accomplish our objective.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It would be an open invitation for Mr. Khrushchev to come in, to come into Latin America and to engage us in what would be a civil war, and possibly even worse than that.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: This is the major recommendation that he's made.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Well, we can do what we did with Guatemala.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: There was a Communist dictator that we inherited from the previous Administration.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The result was that the Guatemalan people themselves eventually rose up and they threw him out.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We are quarantining Mr. Castro today.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We're quarantining him diplomatically by bringing back our Ambassador; economically by cutting off trade, and Senator Kennedy's suggestion that the trade that we cut off is not significant is just one hundred percent wrong.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We are cutting off the significant items that the Cuban regime needs in order to survive.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: By cutting off trade, by cutting off our diplomatic relations as we have, we will quarantine this regime so that the people of Cuba themselves will take care of Mr. Castro.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But for us to do what Senator Kennedy has suggested would bring results which I know he would not want, and certainly which the American people would not want.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Mr. Nixon uh - shows himself i- misinformed.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: There isn't any doubt about that, number one.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Number two, I believe that if any economic sanctions against Latin America are going to be successful they have to be multilateral.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: They have to include the other countries of Latin America.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The very minute effect of the action which has been taken this week on Cuba's economy - I believe Castro can replace those markets very easily through Latin America, through Europe, and through Eastern Europe.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: If the United States had stronger prestige and influence in Latin America it could persuade - as Franklin Roosevelt did in 1940 - the countries of Latin America to join in an economic quarantine of Castro.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: That's the only way you can bring real economic pressure on the Castro regime - and also the countries of Western Europe, Canada, Japan and the others.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Number three, Castro is only the beginning of our difficulties throughout Latin America.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The big struggle will be to prevent the influence of Castro spreading to other countries - Mexico, Panama, Bolivia, Colombia.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We're going to have to try to provide closer ties, to associate ourselves with the great desire of these people for a better life if we're going to prevent Castro's influence from spreading throughout all of Latin America.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: His influence is strong enough today to prevent us from joi- getting the other countries of Latin America to join with us in economic quarantine.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: His influence is growing - mostly because this Administration has ignored Latin America.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: You yourself said, Mr. Vice President, a month ago, that if we had provided the kind of economic aid five years ago that we are now providing we might never have had Castro.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Mr. Edwards, I don't think it's a wise idea for presidential candidates to appoint the members of his cabinet prospectively, or to suggest four people - indicate that one of them surely will be appointed.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: This is a decision that the president of the United States must make.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The last candidate who indicated that he knew who his cabinet was going to be was Mr. Dewey in 1948.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: This is a race between the Vice President and myself for the presidency of the United States.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: There are a good many able men who could be secretary of state.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I've made no judgment about who should be secretary of state.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think that judgment could be made after election, if I'm successful.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The people have to make a choice between Mr. Nixon and myself, between the Republican party and the Democratic party, between our approach to the problems which now disturb us as a nation and disturb us as a world power.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The president bears the constitutional responsibility, not the secretary of state, for the conduct of foreign affairs.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Some presidents have been strong in foreign policy; others have relied heavily on the secretary of state.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I've been a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee; I run for the presidency with full knowledge that his great responsibility, really, given to him by the Constitution and by the force of events, is in the field of foreign affairs.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I'm asking the people's support as president.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We will select the best man we can get.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But I've not made a judgment, and I have not narrowed down a list of three or four people, among whom would be the candidate.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Well Mr. Edwards, as you probably know, I have consistently answered all questions with regard to who will be in the next cabinet by saying that that is the responsibility of the next president, and it would be inappropriate to make any decisions on that or to announce any prior to the time that I had the right to do so.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: If you don't mind, I'd like to use the balance of the time to respond to one of the comments that Senator Kennedy made on the previous question.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Eh- He was talking about the Castro regime and what we had been eh- doing in Latin America.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I would like to point out that when we look at our programs in Latin America, we find that we have appropriated five times as much for Latin America as was appropriated by the previous Administration; we find that we have two billion dollars more for the Export-Import Bank; we have a new bank for Latin America alone of a billion dollars; we have the new program which was submitted at the Bogota Conference - this new program that President Eisenhower submitted, approved by the last Congress - for five hundred million dollars.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We have moved in Latin America very effectively, and I'd also like to point this out: Senator Kennedy complains very appropriately about our inadequate ra- radio broadcasts for Latin America.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Let me point out again that his Congress - the Democratic Congress - has cut eighty million dollars off of the Voice of America appropriations.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now, he has to get a better job out of his Congress if he's going to get us the money that we need to conduct the foreign affairs of this country in Latin America or any place else.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Mr. Cronkite, I naturally am aware of it, because I, of course, pay attention to everything Senator Kennedy says, as well as Senator Fulbright.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now, in this connection I want to point out that the facts simply aren't as stated.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: First of all, the report to which Senator Kennedy refers is one that was made many, many months ago and related particularly to the uh - period immediately after Sputnik.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Third, I would say this with regard to this report, with regard to Gallup Polls of prestige abroad and everything else that we've been hearing about "what about American prestige abroad": America's prestige abroad will be just as high as the spokesmen for America allow it to be.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now, when we have a presidential candidate, for example - Senator Kennedy - stating over and over again that the United States is second in space and the fact of the matter is that the space score today is twenty-eight to eight - we've had twenty-eight successful shots, they've had eight; when he states that we're second in education, and I have seen Soviet education and I've seen ours, and we're not; that we're second in science because they may be ahead in one area or another, when overall we're way ahead of the Soviet Union and all other countries in science; when he says as he did in January of this year that we have the worst slums, that we have the most crowded schools; when he says that seventeen million people go to bed hungry every night; when he makes statements like this, what does this do to American prestige?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Well, it can only have the effect certainly of reducing it.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Well let me make one thing clear.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Senator Kennedy has a responsibility to criticize those things that are wrong, but he has also a responsibility to be right in his criticism.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Every one of these items that I have mentioned he's been wrong - dead wrong.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And for that reason he has contributed to any lack of prestige.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Finally, let me say this: as far as prestige is concerned, the first place it would show up would be in the United Nations.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now Senator Kennedy has referred to the vote on Communist China.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Let's look at the vote on Hungary.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: There we got more votes for condemning Hungary and looking into that situation than we got the last year.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Let's look at the reaction eh - reaction to Khrushchev and Eisenhower at the last U.N. session.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Did Khrushchev gain because he took his shoe off and pounded the table and shouted and insulted?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: America gained by continuing the dignity, the decency that has characterized us and it's that that keeps the prestige of America up, not running down America the way Senator Kennedy has been running her down.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I really don't need uh - Mr. Nixon to tell me about what my responsibilities are as a citizen.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I've served this country for fourteen years in the Congress and before that in the service.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I've just as high a devotion, just as high an opinion.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: What I downgrade, Mr. Nixon, is the leadership the country is getting, not the country.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Now I didn't make most of the statements that you said I made.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The s- I believe the Soviet Union is first in outer space.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We have - may have made more shots but the size of their rocket thrust and all the rest - you yourself said to Khrushchev, "You may be ahead of us in rocket thrust but we're ahead of you in color television" in your famous discussion in the kitchen.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think that color television is not as important as rocket thrust.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Secondly, I didn't say we had the worst slums in the world.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I said we had too many slums.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And that they are bad, and we ought to do something about them, and we ought to support housing legislation which this Administration has opposed.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I didn't say we had the worst education in the world.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And fourth, I believe that the polls and other studies and votes in the United Nations and anyone reading the paper and any citizen of the United States must come to the conclusion that the United States no longer carries the same image of a vital society on the move with its brightest days ahead as it carried a decade or two decades ago.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Part of that is because we've stood still here at home, because we haven't met our problems in the United States, because we haven't had a moving economy.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Part of that, as the Gallup Polls show, is because the Soviet Union made a breakthrough in outer space.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Mr. George Allen, head of your Information Service, has said that that made the people of the world begin to wonder whether we were first in science.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We're first in other areas of science but in space, which is the new science, we're not first.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Yes, I think the next president of the United States should make one last effort to secure an agreement on the cessation of tests, number one.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: If we fail then, if we're unable to come to an agreement - and I hope we can come to an agreement because it does not merely involve now the United States, Britain, France, and the Soviet Union as atomic powers.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Because new breakthroughs in atomic energy technology there's some indications that by the time the next president's term of office has come to an end, there may be ten, fifteen, or twenty countries with an atomic capacity, perhaps that many testing bombs with all the effect that it could have on the atmosphere and with all the chances that more and more countries will have an atomic capacity, with more and more chance of war.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: So one more effort should be made.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I don't think that even if that effort fails that it will be necessary to carry on tests in the atmosphere which pollute the atmosphere.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: They can be carried out underground, they c- could be carried on in outer space.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But I believe the effort should be made once more by who's ever elected president of the United States.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: If we fail, it's been a great serious failure for everyone - for the human race.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I hope we can succeed.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But then if we fail responsibility will be clearly on the Russians and then we'll have to meet our responsibilities to the security of the United States, and there may have to be testing underground.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think the Atomic Energy Committee is prepared for it.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: There may be testing in outer space.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I hope it will not be necessary for any power to resume uh - testing in the atmosphere.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: It's possible to detect those kind of tests.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The kind of tests which you can't detect are underground or in - in uh - perhaps in outer space.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: So that I'm hopeful we can try once more.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: If we fail then we must meet our responsibilities to ourselves.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But I'm most concerned about the whole problem of the spread of atomic weapons.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: China may have it by 1963, Egypt.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: War has been the constant companion of mankind, so to have these weapons disseminated around the world, I believe means that we're going to move through a period of hazard in the next few years.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We ought to make one last effort.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I would say first of all that we must have in mind the fact that we have been negotiating to get tests inspected and uh - to get an agreement for many, many months.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: As a matter of fact, there's been a moratorium on testing as a result of the fact that we have been negotiating.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I've reached the conclusion that the Soviet Union is actually filibustering.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I've reached the conclusion, too, based on the reports that have been made, that they may be cheating.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I don't think we can wait until the next president is inaugurated and then uh - select a new team and then all the months of negotiating that will take place before we reach a decision, I think that immediately after this election we should set a timetable - the next president, working with the present President, President Eisenhower - a timetable to break the Soviet filibuster.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: There should be no tests in the atmosphere; that rules out any fall-out.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But as far as underground tests for developing peaceful uses of atomic energy, we should not allow this Soviet filibuster to continue.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I think it's time for them to fish or cut bait.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I think that the next president immediately after his election should sit down with the President, work out a timetable, and - get a decision on this before January of next year.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Well the conditions I laid out in one of our previous television debates, and it's rather difficult to be much more specific than that.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Uh - First of all, we have to have adequate preparation for a summit conference.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: By adequate preparation I mean that at that level we must prepare an agenda, an agenda agreed upon with the approval of the heads of state involved.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now this agenda should delineate those issues on which there is a possibility of some agreement or negotiation.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now this may seem like a rigid, inflexible position.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But let's look at the other side of the coin.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: If we build up the hopes of the world by having a summit conference that is not adequately prepared, and then, if Mr. Khrushchev finds some excuse for breaking it up - as he did this one - because he isn't going to get his way - we'd set back the cause of peace.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We do not help it.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We can, in other words, negotiate many of these items of difference between us without going to the summit.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I think we have to make a greater effort than we have been making at the secretary of state level, at the ambassadorial level, to work out the differences that we have.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And so far as the summit conference is concerned, it should only be entered in upon, it should only be agreed upon, if the negotiations have reached the point that we have some reasonable assurance that something is going to come out of it, other than some phony spirit - a spirit of Geneva, or Camp David, or whatever it is.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: When I say "phony spirit," I mean phony, not because the spirit is not good on our side, but because the Soviet Union simply doesn't intend to carry out what they say.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now, these are the conditions that I can lay out.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I cannot be more precise than that, because until we see what Mr. Khrushchev does and what he says uh - we cannot indicate what our plans will be.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Well, I think the president of the United States last winter indicated that before he'd go to the summit in May he did last fall, he indicated that there should be some agenda, that there should be some prior agreement.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: He hoped that there would be uh - b- be an agreement in part in disarmament.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: He also expressed the hope that there should be some understanding of the general situation in Berlin.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The Soviet Union refused to agree to that, and we went to the summit and it was disastrous.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I believe we should not go to the summit until there is some reason to believe that a meeting of minds can be obtained on either Berlin, outer space, or general disarmament - including nuclear testing.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: In addition, I believe the next president in January and February should go to work in building the strength of the United States.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The Soviet Union does understand strength.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We arm to parley, Winston Churchill said ten years ago.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: If we are strong, particularly as we face a crisis over Berlin - which we may in the spring, or in the winter - it's important that we maintain our determination here; that we indicate that we're building our strength; that we are determined to protect our position; that we're determined to protect our commitment.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And then I believe we should indicate our desire to live at peace with the world.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But until we're strong here, until we're moving here, I believe a summit could not be successful.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I hope that before we do meet, there will be preliminary agreements on those four questions, or at least two of them, or even one of them, which would warrant such a meeting.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I think if we had stuck by that position last winter, we would have been in a better position in May.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: One of the areas, and of course the most vulnerable area is - I have felt, has been Eastern Europe.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I've been critical of the Administration's failure to suggest policies which would make it possible for us to establish, for example, closer relations with Poland, particularly after the fifty-five-fifty-six period and the Hungarian revolution.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We indicated at that time that we were not going to intervene militarily.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But there was a period there when Poland demonstrated a national independence and even the Polish government moved some differn- di- distance away from the Soviet Union.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I suggested that we amend our legislation so that we could enjoy closer economic ties.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We received the support first of the Administration and then not, and we were defeated by one vote in the Senate.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We passed the bill in the Senate this year but it didn't pass the House.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I would say Eastern Europe is the area of vulnerability of the uh - s- of the Soviet Union.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Secondly, the relations between Russia and China.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: They are now engaged in a debate over whether war is the means of Communizing the world or whether they should use subversion, infiltration, economic struggles and all the rest.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: No one can say what that course of action will be, but I think the next president of the United States should watch it carefully.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: If those two powers should split, it could have great effects throughout the entire world.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Thirdly, I believe that India represents a great area for affirmative action by the free world.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: India started from about the same place that China did.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Chinese Communists have been moving ahead the last ten years.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: India under a free society has been making some progress.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But if India does not succeed - with her four hundred and fifty million people, if she can't make freedom work - then people around the world are going to determine - particularly in the underdeveloped world - that the only way that they can develop their resources is through the Communist system.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Fourth, let me say that in Africa, Asia, Latin America, Eastern Europe, the great force on our side is the desire of people to be free.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: This has expressed itself in the revolts in Eastern Europe.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: It's expressed itself in the desire of the people of Africa to be independent of Western Europe.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: They want to be free.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And my judgment is that they don't want to give their freedom up to become Communists.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: They want to stay free, independent perhaps of us, but certainly independent of the Communists.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And I believe if we identify ourselves with that force, if we identify ourselves with it as Lincoln, as Wilson did, as Franklin Roosevelt did, if we become known as the friend of freedom, sustaining freedom, helping freedom, helping these people in the fight against poverty and ignorance and disease, helping them build their lives, I believe in Latin America, Africa, and Asia, eventually in the Eastern Europe and the Middle East, certainly in Western Europe, we can strengthen freedom.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We can put the Communists on the defensive.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: First, with regard to Poland, when I talked to Mr. Gomulka, the present leader of Poland, for six hours in Warsaw last year, I learned something about their problems and particularly his.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Right under the Soviet gun, with Soviet troops there, he is in a very difficult position in taking anything independent, a position which would be independent of the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And yet let's just see what we've done for Poland, A half a billion dollars worth of aid has gone to Poland, primarily economic, primarily to go to the people of Poland.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: This should continue and it can be stepped up to give them hope and to keep alive the hope for freedom that I can testify they have so deeply within them.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: In addition we can have more exchange with Poland or with any other of the Iron Curtain countries which show some desire to take a different path than the path that has been taken by the ones that are complete satellites of the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now as far as the balance of the world is concerned, I of course don't have as much time as Senator Kennedy had.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I would just like to s- add this one point.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: If we are going to have the initiative in the world, we must remember that the people of Africa and Asia and Latin America don't want to be pawns simply in a struggle between two great powers - the Soviet Union and the United States.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We have to let them know that we want to help them, not because we're simply trying to save our own skins, not because we're simply trying to fight Communism; but because we care for them, because we stand for freedom, because if there were no Communism in the world, we would still fight poverty and misery and disease and tyranny.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: If we can get that across to the people of these countries, in this decade of the sixties, the struggle for freedom will be won.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I would say that the issue will stay with us as a campaign issue just as long as Senator Kennedy persists in what I think is a fundamental error.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: He says he supports the President's position.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: He says that he voted for the resolution.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Well just let me point this out; he voted for the resolution in 1955 which gave the president the power to use the forces of the United States to defend Formosa and the offshore islands.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But he also voted then for an amendment - which was lost, fortunately - an amendment which would have drawn a line and left out those islands and denied the p- right to the president to defend those islands if he thought that it was an attack on Formosa.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: He repeated that error in 1959, in the speech that he made.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: He repeated it again in a television debate that we had.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now, my point is this: Senator Kennedy has got to be consistent here.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Either he's for the President and he's against the position that those who opposed the President in fifty-five and fifty-nine - and the Senator's position itself, stated the other day in our debate - either he is for the President and against that position or we simply have a disagreement here that must continue to be debated.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now if the Senator in his answer to this question will say "I now will depart, or retract my previous views; I think I was wrong in I 955; I think I was wrong in 1959; and I think I was wrong in our television debate to say that we should draw a line leaving out Quemoy and Matsu - draw a line in effect abandoning these islands to the Communists;" then this will be right out of the campaign because there will be no issue between us.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I support the President's position.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I have always opposed drawing a line.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I have opposed drawing a line because I know that the moment you draw a line, that is an encouragement for the Communists to attack - to step up their blackmail and to force you into the war that none of us want.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And so I would hope that Senator Kennedy in his answer today would clear it up.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It isn't enough for him to say "I support the President's position, that I voted for the resolution."
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Of course, he voted for the resolution - it was virtually unanimous.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But the point is, what about his error in voting for the amendment, which was not adopted, and then persisting in it in fifty-nine, persisting in it in the debate.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It's very simple for him to clear it up.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: He can say now that he no longer believes that a line should be drawn leaving these islands out of the perimeter of defense.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Well, Mr. Nixon, to go back to 1955.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The resolution commits the president in the United States, which I supported, to defend uh - Formosa, the Pescadores, and if it was his military judgment, these islands.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Then the President sent a mission, composed of Admiral Radford and Mr. Robertson, to persuade Chiang Kai-shek in the spring of fifty-five to withdraw from the two islands, because they were exposed.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The President was unsuccessful; Chiang Kai-shek would not withdraw.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I refer to the fact that in 1958, as a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, I'm very familiar with the position that the United States took in negotiating with the Chinese Communists on these two islands.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: General Twining, in January, fifty-nine, described the position of the United States.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The position of the United States has been that this build-up, in the words of the president, has been foolish.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Mr. Herter has said these islands are indefensible.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Chiang Kai-shek will not withdraw.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Because he will not withdraw, because he's committed to these islands, because we've been unable to persuade him to withdraw, we are in a very difficult position.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And therefore, the President's judgment has been that we should defend the islands if, in his military judgment and the judgment of the commander in the field, the attack on these islands should be part of an overall attack on Formosa.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: In view of the difficulties we've had with the islands, in view of the difficulties and disputes we've had with Chiang Kai-shek, that's the only position we can take.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: That's not the position you took, however.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The first position you took, when this matter first came up, was that we should draw the line and commit ourselves, as a matter of principle, to defend these islands.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Not as part of the defense of Formosa and the Pescadores.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: You showed no recognition of the Administration program to try to persuade Chiang Kai-shek for the last five years to withdraw from the islands.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And I challenge you tonight to deny that the Administration has sent at least several missions to persuade Chiang Kai-shek's withdrawal from these islands.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And that's the testimony of uh - General Twining and the Assistant Secretary of State in fifty-eight.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I uh - said that I've served this country for fourteen years.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I served it uh - in the war.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: If I lose this election, I will continue in the Senate to try to build a stronger country.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But I run because I believe this year the United States has a great opportunity to make a move forward, to make a determination here at home and around the world, that it's going to reestablish itself as a vigorous society.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: My judgment is that the Republican party has stood still here in the United States, and it's also stood still around the world.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Uh - We're using about fifty percent of our steel capacity today.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We had a recession in fifty-eight.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We had a recession in fifty-four.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We're not moving ahead in education the way we should.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We didn't make a judgment in fifty-seven and fifty-six and fifty-five and fifty-four that outer space would be important.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: If we stand still here, if we appoint people to ambassadorships and positions in Washington who have a status quo outlook, who don't recognize that this is a revolutionary time, then the United States does not maintain its influence.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And if we fail, the cause of freedom fails.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I believe it incumbent upon the next president of the United States to get this country moving again, to get our economy moving ahead, to set before the American people its goals, its unfinished business.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And then throughout the world appoint the best people we can get, ambassadors who can speak the language - no mere - not merely people who made a political contribution but who can speak the language.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Bring students here; let them see what kind of a country we have.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy
