Text: Mr. Nixon said that we should not regard them as pawns in the cold war; we should identify ourselves with them.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: If that were true, why didn't we identify ourselves with the people of Africa?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Why didn't we bring students over here?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Why did we suddenly offer Congo three hundred students last June when they had the tremendous revolt?
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: That was more than we had offered to all of Africa before from the federal government.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I believe that this party - Republican party - has stood still really for twenty-five years - its leadership has.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: It opposed all of the programs of President Roosevelt and others - the minimum wage and for housing and economic growth and development of our natural resources, the Tennessee Valley and all the rest.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And I believe that if we can get a party which believes in movement, which believes in going ahead, then we can reestablish our position in the world - strong defense, strong in economic growth, justice for our people, co- guarantee of constitutional rights, so that people will believe that we practice what we preach, and then around the world, particularly to try to reestablish the atmosphere which existed in Latin America at the time of Franklin Roosevelt.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: He was a good neighbor in Latin America because he was a good neighbor in the United States; because they saw us as a society that was compassionate, that cared about people, that was moving this country ahead.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I believe it my responsibility as the leader of the Democratic party in 1960 to try to warn the American people that in this crucial time we can no longer afford to stand still.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We can no longer afford to be second best.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I want people all over the world to look to the United States again, to feel that we're on the move, to feel that our high noon is in the future.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I want Mr. Khrushchev to know that a new generation of Americans who fought in Europe and Italy and the Pacific for freedom in World War II have now taken over in the United States, and that they're going to put this country back to work again.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I don't believe that there is anything this country cannot do.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I don't believe there's any burden, or any responsibility, that any American would not assume to protect his country, to protect our security, to advance the cause of freedom.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And I believe it incumbent upon us now to do that.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Franklin Roosevelt said in 1936 that that generation of Americans had a rendezvous with destiny.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I believe in 1960 and sixty-one and two and three we have a rendezvous with destiny.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And I believe it incumbent upon us to be the defenders of the United States and the defenders of freedom; and to do that, we must give this country leadership and we must get America moving again.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Senator Kennedy has said tonight again what he has said several times in the course of this - these debates and in the campaign, that American is standing still.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: America is not standing still.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It has not been standing still.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And let's set the record straight right now by looking at the record, as Al Smith used to say.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We built more houses in the last seven years than in any Administration and thirty percent more than in the previous Administration.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We talk about schools - three times as many classrooms built in the past Administration - and Eisenhower - than under the Truman Administration.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: More progress in the past eight years than in the whole eighty years before.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: He talks about the progress in the field of slum clearance and the like.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We find four times as many projects undertaken and completed in this Administration than in the previous one.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: He's been in some other country.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Let's get that straight right away.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now the second point we have to understand is this, however.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: America has not been standing still.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But America cannot stand pat.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We can't stand pat for the reason that we're in a race, as I've indicated.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We can't stand pat because it is essential with the conflict that we have around the world that we not just hold our own, that we not keep just freedom for ourselves.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It means keeping America even stronger militarily than she is.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It means seeing that our economy moves forward even faster than it has.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It means making more progress in civil rights than we have so that we can be a splendid example for all the world to see - a democracy in action at its best.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now, looking at the other parts of the world - South America - talking about our record and the previous one.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We had a good neighbor policy, yes.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But let's look at it.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: There were eleven dictators when we came into power in 1953 in Latin America.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: There are only three left.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Twenty new countries in Africa during the course of this Administration.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Not one of them selected a Communist government.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: All of them voted for freedom - a free type of government.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Does this show that Communism has the bigger pull, or freedom has the bigger pull?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Am I trying to indicate that we have no problems in Africa or Latin America or Asia?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: What I am trying to indicate is that the tide of history's on our side, and that we can keep it on our side, because we're on the right side.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We're on the side of freedom.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We're on the side of justice against the forces of slavery, against the forces of injustice.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But we aren't going to move America forward and we aren't going to be able to lead the world to win this struggle for freedom if we have a permanent inferiority complex about American achievements.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Because we are first in the world in space, as I've indicated; we are first in science; we are first in education, and we're going to move even further ahead with the kind of leadership that we can provide in these years ahead.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: One other point I would make: what could you do?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Senator Kennedy and I are candidates for the presidency of the United States.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And in the years to come it will be written that one or the other of us was elected and that he was or was not a great president.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: What will determine whether Senator Kennedy or I, if I am elected, was a great president?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It will not be our ambition that will determine it, because greatness is not something that is written on a campaign poster.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It will be determined to the extent that we represent the deepest ideals, the highest feelings and faith of the American people.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: In other words, the next president, as he leads America and the free world, can be only as great as the American people are great.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And so I say in conclusion, keep America's faith strong.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: See that the young people of America, particularly, have faith in the ideals of freedom and faith in God, which distinguishes us from the atheistic materialists who oppose us.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Mr. McGee, we have a contractual right to be in Berlin coming out of the conversations at Potsdam and of World War II.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: That has been reinforced by direct commitments of the president of the United States; it's been reinforced by a number of other nations under NATO.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I've stated on many occasions that the United States must meet its commitment on Berlin.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: It is a commitment that we have to meet if we're going to protect the security of Western Europe.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And therefore on this question I don't think that there is any doubt in the mind of any American; I hope there is not any doubt in the mind of any member of the community of West Berlin; I'm sure there isn't any doubt in the mind of the Russians.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We will meet our commitments to maintain the freedom and independence of West Berlin.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: As a matter of fact, the statement that Senator Kennedy made was that - to the effect that there were trigger-happy Republicans, that my stand on Quemoy and Matsu was an indication of trigger-happy Republicans.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I resent it because th- it's an implication that Republicans have been trigger-happy and, therefore, would lead this nation into war.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I would remind Senator Kennedy of the past fifty years.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I would ask him to name one Republican president who led this nation into war.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: There were three Democratic presidents who led us into war.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I do not mean by that that one party is a war party and the other party is a peace party.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But I do say that any statement to the effect that the Republican party is trigger-happy is belied by the record.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We had a war when we came into power in 1953.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We got rid of that; we've kept out of other wars; and certainly that doesn't indicate that we're trigger-happy.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We've been strong, but we haven't been trigger-happy.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: As far as Berlin is concerned, there isn't any question about the necessity of defending Berlin; the rights of people there to be free; and there isn't any question about what the united American people - Republicans and Democrats alike - would do in the event there were an attempt by the Communists to take over Berlin.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Von Fremd, it would be completely irresponsible for a candidate for the presidency, or for a president himself, to indicate the course of action and the weapons he would use in the event of such an attack.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I will say this: in the event that such an attack occurred and in the event the attack was a prelude to an attack on Formosa - which would be the indication today because the Chinese Communists say over and over again that their objective is not the offshore islands, that they consider them only steppingstones to taking Formosa - in the event that their attack then were a prelude to an attack on Formosa, there isn't any question but that the United States would then again, as in the case of Berlin, honor our treaty obligations and stand by our ally of Formosa.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But to indicate in advance how we would respond, to indicate the nature of this response would be incorrect; it would certainly be inappropriate; it would not be in the best interests of the United States.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I will only say this, however, in addition: to do what Senator Kennedy has suggested - to suggest that we will surrender these islands or force our Chinese Nationalist allies to surrender them in advance - is not something that would lead to peace; it is something that would lead, in my opinion, to war.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: This is the history of dealing with dictators.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: This is something that Senator Kennedy and all Americans must know.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We tried this with Hitler.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: He wanted first uh - we know, Austria, and then he went on to the Sudetenland and then Danzig, and each time it was thought this is all that he wanted.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now what do the Chinese Communists want?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: They don't want just Quemoy and Matsu; they don't want just Formosa; they want the world.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And the question is if you surrender or indicate in advance that you're not going to defend any part of the free world, and you figure that's going to satisfy them, it doesn't satisfy them.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It only whets their appetite; and then the question comes, when do you stop them?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I've often heard President Eisenhower in discussing this question, make the statement that if we once start the process of indicating that this point or that point is not the place to stop those who threaten the peace and freedom of the world, where do we stop them?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And I say that those of us who stand against surrender of territory - this or any others - in the face of blackmail, in the s- face of force by the Communists are standing for the course that will lead to peace.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The islands which Mr. Nixon is discussing are five or four miles, respectively, off the coast of China.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Now when Senator Green, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, wrote to the President, he received back on the second of October, 1958 - "neither you nor any other American need feel the U.S. will be involved in military hostilities merely in the defense of Quemoy and Matsu."
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Now, that is the issue.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I believe we must meet our commitment to uh - Formosa.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I support it and the Pescadores Island.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: That is the present American position.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Mr. Nixon suggests uh - that the United States should go to war if these two islands are attacked.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I suggest that if Formosa is attacked or the Pescadores, or if there's any military action in any area which indicates an attack on Formosa and the Pescadores, then of course the United States is at war to defend its treaty.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Now, I must say what Mr. Nixon wants to do is commit us - as I understand him, so that we can be clear if there's a disagreement - he wants us to be committed to the defense of these islands merely as the defense of these islands as free territory, not as part of the defense of Formosa.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Admiral Yarnell, the commander of the Asiatic fleet, has said that these islands are not worth the bones of a single American.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The President of the United States has indicated they are not within the treaty area.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: They were not within the treaty area when the treaty was passed in fifty-five.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We have attempted to persuade Chiang Kai-shek as late as January of 1959 to reduce the number of troops he has on them.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: This is a serious issue, and I think we ought to understand completely if we disagree, and if so, where.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Well I think we should st- strengthen our conventional forces, and we should attempt in January, February, and March of next year to increase the airlift capacity of our conventional forces.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: It may be a long period, but we must - we must get started immediately.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Now on the question of disarmament, particularly nuclear disarmament, I must say that I feel that another effort should be made by a new Administration in January of 1961, to renew negotiations with the Soviet Union and see whether it's possible to come to some conclusion which will lessen the chances of contamination of the atmosphere, and also lessen the chances that other powers will begin to possess a nuclear capacity.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: There are indications, because of new inventions, that ten, fifteen, or twenty nations will have a nuclear capacity - including Red China - by the end of the presidential office in 1964.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And to take a chance uh - now be - and not make every effort that we could make to provide for some control over these weapons, I think would be a great mistake.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: One of my disagreements with the present Administration has been that I don't feel a real effort has been made an this very sensitive subject, not only of nuclear controls, but also of general disarmament.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Less than a hundred people have been working throughout the entire federal government on this subject, and I believe it's been reflected in our success and failures at Geneva.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The Soviet Union may not agree to an inspection system.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We may be able to get satisfactory assurances.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: It may be necessary for us to begin testing again.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But I hope the next Administration - and if I have anything to do with it, the next Administration will - make one last great effort to provide for control of nuclear testing, control of nuclear weapons, if possible, control of outer space, free from weapons, and also to begin again the subject of general disarmament levels.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: If we cannot succeed, then we must strengthen ourselves.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But I would make the effort because I think the fate not only of our own civilization, but I think the fate of world and the future of the human race is involved in preventing a nuclear war.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I am going to make a major speech on this whole subject next week before the next debate, and I will have an opportunity then to answer any other questions that may arise with regard to my position on it.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: There isn't any question but that we must move forward in every possible way to reduce the danger of war; to move toward controlled disarmament; to control tests; but also let's have in mind this: when Senator Kennedy suggests that we haven't been making an effort, he simply doesn't know what he's talking about.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It isn't a question of the number of people who are working in an Administration.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It's a question of who they are.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: This has been one of the highest level operations in the whole State Department right under the President himself.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We have gone certainly the extra mile and then some in making offers to the Soviet Union on control of tests, on disarmament, and in every other way.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And I just want to make one thing very clear.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Yes, we should make a great effort.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But under no circumstances must the United States ever make an agreement based on trust.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: There must be an absolute guarantee.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now, just a comment on Senator Kennedy's last answer.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: He forgets that in this same debate on the Formosa resolution, which he said he voted for - which he did - that he voted against an amendment, or was recorded against an amendment - and on this particular - or for an amendment, I should say - which passed the Senate overwhelmingly, seventy to twelve.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And that amendment put the Senate of the United States on record with a majority of the Senator's own party voting for it, as well as the majority of Republicans - put them on record - against the very position that the Senator takes now of surrendering, of indicating in advance, that the United States will not defend the offshore islands.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Well Mr. Drummond, first of all, referring to Secretary Dulles' press conference, I think if you read it all - and I know that you have - you will find that Secretary Dulles also indicated in that press conference that when the troops were withdrawn from Quemoy, that the implication was certainly of everything that he said, that Quemoy could better be defended.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: There were too many infantrymen there, not enough heavy artillery; and certainly I don't think there was any implication in Secretary Dulles' statement that Quemoy and Matsu should not be defended in the event that they were attacked, and that attack was a preliminary to an attack on Formosa.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now as far as President Eisenhower is concerned, I have often heard him discuss this question.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: As I uh - related a moment ago, the President has always indicated that we must not make the mistake in dealing with the dictator of indicating that we are going to make a concession at the point of a gun.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Whenever you do that, inevitably the dictator is encouraged to try it again.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: So first it will be Quemoy and Matsu, next it may be Formosa.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: My point is this: that once you do this - follow this course of action - of indicating that you are not going to defend a particular area, the inevitable result is that it encourages a man who is determined to conquer the world to press you to the point of no return.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We went through this tragic experience leading to World War II.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We learned our lesson again in Korea, We must not learn it again.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: That is why I think the Senate was right, including a majority of the Democrats, a majority of the Republicans, when they rejected Senator Kennedy's position in 1955.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And incidentally, Senator Johnson was among those who rejected that position - voted with the seventy against the twelve.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The Senate was right because they knew the lesson of history.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And may I say, too, that I would trust that Senator Kennedy would change his position on this - change it; because as long as he as a major presidential candidate continues to suggest that we are going to turn over these islands, he is only encouraging the aggressors - the Chinese Communist and the Soviet aggressors - to press the United States, to press us to the point where war would be inevitable.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The road to war is always paved with good intentions.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And in this instance the good intentions, of course, are a desire for peace.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I don't think it's possible for Mr. Nixon to state the record in distortion of the facts with more precision than he just did.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: In 1955, Mr. Dulles at a press conference said: "The treaty that we have with the Republic of China excludes Quemoy and Matsu from the treaty area."
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: That was done with much thought and deliberation.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Therefore that treaty does not commit the United States to defend anything except Formosa and the Pescadores, and to deal with acts against that treaty area.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I completely sustained the treaty.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: What we're now talking about is the Vice President's determination to guarantee Quemoy and Matsu, which are four and five miles off the coast of Red China, which are not within the treaty area.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I do not suggest that Chiang Kai-shek - and this Administration has been attempting since 1955 to persuade Chiang Kai-shek to lessen his troop commitments.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Uh - He sent a mission - the President - in 1955 of Mr. uh - Robertson and Admiral Radford.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: General Twining said they were still doing it in 1959.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: General Ridgway said - who was Chief of Staff: "To go to war for Quemoy and Matsu to me would seem an unwarranted and tragic course to take.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: To me that concept is completely repugnant."
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: So I stand with them.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I stand with the Secretary of State, Mr. Herter, who said these islands were indefensible.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I believe that we should meet our commitments, and if the Chinese Communists attack the Pescadores and Formosa, they know that it will mean a war.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I would not ho- hand over these islands under any point of gun.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But I merely say that the treaty is quite precise and I sustain the treaty.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Mr. Nixon would add a guarantee to islands five miles off the coast of the re- Republic of China when he's never really protested the Communists seizing Cuba, ninety miles off the coast of the United States.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Well, I must say that uh - Mr. Truman has uh - his methods of expressing things; he's been in politics for fifty years; he's been president of the United States.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: They may - are not my style.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But I really don't think there's anything that I could say to President Truman that's going to cause him, at the age of seventy-six, to change his particular speaking manner.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Perhaps Mrs. Truman can, but I don't think I can.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I'll just have to tell Mr. Morton that.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: If you'd pass that message on to him.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Of course, both er - Senator Kennedy and I have felt Mr. Truman's ire; and uh - consequently, I think he can speak with some feeling on this subject.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I just do want to say one thing, however.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We all have tempers; I have one; I'm sure Senator Kennedy has one.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But when a man's president of the United States, or a former president, he has an obligation not to lose his temper in public.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: One thing I've noted as I've traveled around the country are the tremendous number of children who come out to see the presidential candidates.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I see mothers holding their babies up, so that they can see a man who might be president of the United States.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I know Senator Kennedy sees them, too.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It makes you realize that whoever is president is going to be a man that all the children of America will either look up to, or will look down to.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And I can only say that I'm very proud that President Eisenhower restored dignity and decency and, frankly, good language to the conduct of the presidency of the United States.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And I only hope that, should I win this election, that I could approach President Eisenhower in maintaining the dignity of the office; in seeing to it that whenever any mother or father talks to his child, he can look at the man in the White House and, whatever he may think of his policies, he will say: "Well, there is a man who maintains the kind of standards personally that I would want my child to follow."
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Well, Mr. Cater, of course it's a criticism that uh - is being made.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Uh - I obviously don't think it's valid.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I have supported the Administration's position and I think that that position has been correct; I think my position has been correct.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: As far as Indochina was concerned, I stated over and over again that it was essential during that period that the United States make it clear that we would not tolerate Indochina falling under Communist domination.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now, as a result of our taking the strong stand that we did, the civil war there was ended; and today, at least in the south of Indochina, the Communists have moved out and we do have a strong, free bastion there.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now, looking to the U-2 flights, I would like to point out that I have been supporting the President's position throughout.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I think the President was correct in ordering these flights.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I think the President was correct, certainly, in his decision to continue the flights while the conference was going on.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I noted, for example, in reading a - uh - a - a particular discussion that Senator Kennedy had with Dave Garroway shortly after the uh - his statement about regrets, that uh - he made the statement that he felt that these particular flights uh - were ones that shouldn't have occurred right at that time, and the indication was how would Mr. Khrushchev had felt if we had uh - had a flight over the uni- how would we have felt if Mr. Khrushchev ha - uh - had a flight over the United States while uh - he was visiting here.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And the answer, of course, is that Communist espionage goes on all the time.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The answer is that the United States can't afford to have a es- an es - a espionage lack or should we s- uh - lag - or should I say uh - an intelligence lag - any more than we can afford to have a missile lag.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now, referring to your question with regard to Quemoy and Matsu.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: What I object to here is the constant reference to surrendering these islands.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Senator Kennedy quotes the record, which he read from a moment ago, but what he forgets to point out is that the key vote - a uh - vote which I've referred to several times - where he was in the minority was one which rejected his position.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now, why did they reject it?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: For the very reason that those Senators knew, as the President of the United States knew, that you should not indicate to the Communists in advance that you're going to surrender an area that's free.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Because they know as Senator Kennedy will have to know that if you do that you encourage them to more aggression.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Well number one on Indochina, Mr. Nixon talked in - before the newspaper editors in the spring of 1954 about putting, and I quote him, "American boys into Indochina."
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The reason Indochina was preserved was the result of the Geneva Conference which Indochina.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Number two, on the question of the U-2 flights.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: U-2 flight in May just before the conference was a mistake in timing because of the hazards involved, if the summit conference had any hope for success.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I never criticized the U-2 flights in general, however.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I never suggested espionage should stop.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: It still goes on, I would assume, on both sides.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Number three, the Vice President - on May fifteenth after the U-2 flight - indicated that the flights were going on, even though the Administration and the President had canceled the flights on May twelfth.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Number three, the pre - Vice President suggests that we should keep the Communists in doubt about whether we would fight on Quemoy and Matsu.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: That's not the position he's taking.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: He's indicating that we should fight for these islands come what may because they are, in his words, in the area of freedom.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: He didn't take that position on Tibet.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: He didn't take that position on Budapest.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: He doesn't take that position that I've seen so far in Laos.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Guinea and Ghana have both moved within the Soviet sphere of influence in foreign policy; so has Cuba.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I merely say that the United States should meet its commitments to Que- to uh - Formosa and the Pescadores.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But as Admiral Yarnell has said, and he's been supported by most military authority, these islands that we're now talking about are not worth the bones of a single American soldier; and I know how difficult it is to sustain troops close to the shore under artillery bombardment.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And therefore, I think, we should make it very clear the disagreement between Mr. Nixon and myself.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: He's extending the Administration's commitment.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Well the que- the - Mr. Griffin, I believe, who is the head of the Klan, who lives in Tampa, Florida, indicated a - in a statement, I think, two or three weeks ago that he was not going to vote for me, and that he was going to vote for Mr. Nixon.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I do not suggest in any way, nor have I ever, that that indicates that Mr. Nixon has the slightest sympathy, involvement, or in any way imply any inferences in regard to the Ku Klux Klan.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I would disagree with it.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Mr. Nixon knows very well that in this - in this whole matter that's been involved with the so-called religious discussion in this campaign, I've never suggested, even by the vaguest implication, that he did anything but disapprove it.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And that's my view now.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I disapprove of the issue.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I do not suggest that Mr. Nixon does in any way.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Well I welcome this opportunity to join Senator Kennedy completely on that statement and to say before this largest television audience in history something that I have been saying in the past and want to - will always say in the future.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We can't settle for anything but the best.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And that means, of course, the best man that this nation can produce.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And that means that we can't have any test of religion.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We can't have any test of race.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It must be a test of a man.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Also as far as religion is concerned.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I have seen Communism abroad.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I see what it does.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Communism is the enemy of all religions; and we who do believe in God must join together.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We must not be divided on this issue.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The worst thing that I can think can happen in this campaign would be for it to be decided on religious issues.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I obviously repudiate the Klan; I repudiate anybody who uses the religious issue; I will not tolerate it, I have ordered all of my people to have nothing to do with it and I say - say to this great audience, whoever may be listening, remember, if you believe in America, if you want America to set the right example to the world, that we cannot have religious or racial prejudice.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We cannot have it in our hearts.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But we certainly cannot have it in a presidential campaign.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Mr. McGee, I am planning a speech on that subject next week.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Uh - I will say simply, in advance of it, that I believe that in this area, the laws which should be passed uh - as far as the big national emergency strikes are concerned, are ones that will give the president more weapons with which to deal with those strikes.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now, I have a basic disagreement with Senator Kennedy, though, on this point.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: He has taken the position, when he first indicated in October of last year, that he would even favor compulsory arbitration as one of the weapons the president might have to stop a national emergency strike.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I understand in his last speech before the Steelworkers Union, that he changed that position and indicated that he felt that government seizure might be the best way to stop a strike which could not be settled by collective bargaining.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I do not believe we should have either compulsory arbitration or seizure.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I think the moment that you give to the union, on the one side, and to management, on the other side, the escape hatch of eventually going to government to get it settled, that most of these great strikes will end up being settled by government, and that will be a - be in the end, in my opinion, wage control; it would mean price control - all the things that we do not want.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I do believe, however, that we can give to the president of the United States powers, in addition to what he presently has in the fact finding area, which would enable him to be more effective than we have been in handling these strikes.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: One last point I should make.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The record in handling them has been very good during this Administration.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We have had less man-hours lost by strikes in these last seven years than we had in the previous seven years, by a great deal.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And I only want to say that however good the record is, it's got to be better.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Because in this critical year - period of the sixties we've got to move forward, all Americans must move forward together, and we have to get the greatest cooperation possible between labor and management.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We cannot afford stoppages of massive effect on the economy when we're in the terrible competition we're in with the Soviets.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Well, I always have difficulty recognizing my positions when they're stated by the Vice President.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I never suggested that compulsory arbitration was the solution for national emergency disputes.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I'm opposed to that, was opposed to it in October, 1958.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I have suggested that the president should be given other weapons to protect the national interest in case of national emergency strikes beyond the injunction provision of the Taft-Hartley Act.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I don't know what other weapons the Vice President is talking about.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I'm talking about giving him four or five tools - not only the fact-finding committee that he now has under the injunction provision, not only the injunction, but also the power of the fact-finding commission to make recommendations - recommendations which would not be binding, but nevertheless would have great force of public opinion behind them.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: One of the additional powers that I would suggest would be seizure.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: By the president having five powers - four or five powers - and he only has very limited powers today, neither the company nor the union would be sure which power would be used; and therefore, there would be a greater incentive on both sides to reach an agreement themselves without taking it to the government.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: He can set up a fact-finding committee.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The fact-finding committee's powers are limited.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: He can provide an injunction if there's a national emergency for eighty days, then the strike can go on; and there are no other powers or actions that the president could take unless he went to the Congress.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: This is a difficult and sensitive matter.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But to state my view precisely, the president should have a variety of things he could do.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: He could leave the parties in doubt as to which one he would use; and therefore there would be incentive, instead of as now - the steel companies were ready to take the strike because they felt the injunction of eighty days would break the union, which didn't happen.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Yes, I have stated in both uh - debates and state again that I believe in a balanced budget and have supported that concept during my fourteen years in the Congress.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The only two times when an unbalanced budget is warranted would be during a serious recession - and we had that in fifty-eight in an unbalanced budget of twelve billion dollars - or a national emergency where there should be large expenditures for national defense, which we had in World War II and uh - during part of the Korean War.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: On the question of the cost of our budget, I have stated that it's my best judgment that our agricultural program will cost a billion and a half, possibly two billion dollars less than the present agricultural program.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We've spent more money on agriculture in the last eight years than the hundred years of the Agricultural Department before that.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Secondly, I believe that the high interest-rate policy that this Administration has followed has added about three billion dollars a year to interest on the debt - merely funding the debt - which is a burden an the taxpayers.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I would hope, under a different monetary policy, that it would be possible to reduce that interest-rate burden, at least a billion dollars.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Third, I think it's possible to gain a seven hundred million to a billion dollars through tax changes which I believe would close up loof- loopholes on dividend withholding, on expense accounts.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Fourthly, I have suggested that the medical care for the aged - and the bill which the Congress now has passed and the President signed if fully implemented would cost a billion dollars on the Treasury - out of Treasury funds and a billion dollars by the states - the proposal that I have put forward and which many of the members of my party support is for medical care financed under Social Security; which would be financed under the Social Security taxes; which is less than three cents a day per person for medical care, doctors' bills, nurses, hospitals, when they retire.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: So in my judgment we would spend more money in this Administration on aid to education, we'd spend more money on housing, we'd spend more money and I hope more wisely on defense than this Administration has.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But I believe that the next Administration should work for a balanced budget, and that would be my intention.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Mr. Nixon misstates my figures constantly, which uh - is of course his right, but the fact of the matter is: here is where I stand and I just want to have it on the public record.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Senator Kennedy has indicated on several occasions in this program tonight that I have been misstating his record and his figures.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I will issue a white paper after this broadcast, quoting exactly what he said on compulsory arbitration, for example, and the record will show that I have been correct.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now as far as his figures are concerned here tonight, he again is engaging in this, what I would call, mirror game of "here-it-is-and-here-it-isn't."
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Uh - On the one hand, for example, he suggests that as far as his medical care program is concerned that that really isn't a problem because it's from Social Security.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But Social Security is a tax.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It comes right out of your paycheck.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: This doesn't mean that the people aren't going to be paying the bill.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: He also indicates as far as his agricultural program is concerned that he feels it will cost less than ours.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Well, all that I can suggest is that all the experts who have studied the program indicate that it is the most fantastic program, the worst program, insofar as its effect on the farmers, that the - America has ever had foisted upon it in an election year or any other time.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And I would also point out that Senator Kennedy left out a part of the cost of that program - a twenty-five percent rise in food prices that the people would have to pay.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now are we going to have that when it isn't going to help the farmers?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I don't think we should have that kind of a program.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Then he goes on to say that he's going to change the interest-rate situation and we're going to get some more money that way.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Well, what he is saying there in effect, we're going to have inflation.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We're going to go right back to what we had under Mr. Truman when he had political control of the Federal Reserve Board.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Mr. Drummond, I am never satisfied with the economic growth of this country.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I'm not satisfied with it even if there were no Communism in the world, but particularly when we're in the kind of a race we're in, we have got to see that America grows just as fast as we can, provided we grow soundly.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Because even though we have maintained, as I pointed out in our first debate, the absolute gap over the Soviet Union; even though the growth in this Administration has been twice as much as it was in the Truman Administration; that isn't good enough.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Because America must be able to grow enough not only to take care of our needs at home for better education and housing and health - all these things we want.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: It's going to cost more money, and growth will help us to win that battle.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now, what do we do about it?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And here I believe basically that what we have to do is to stimulate that sector of America, the private enterprise sector of the economy, in which there is the greatest possibility for expansion.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: So that is why I advocate a program of tax reform which will stimulate more investment in our economy.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: In addition to that, we have to move on other areas that are holding back growth.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I refer, for example, to distressed areas.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We also have to see that all of the people of the United States - the tremendous talents that our people have - are used adequately.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: That's why in this whole area of civil rights, the equality of opportunity for employment and education is not just for the benefit of the minority groups, it's for the benefit of the nation so that we can get the scientists and the engineers and all the rest that we need.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And in addition to that, we need programs, particularly in higher education, which will stimulate scientific breakthroughs which will bring more growth.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now what all this, of course, adds up to is this: America has not been standing still.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Anybody who says America's been standing still for the last seven and a half years hasn't been traveling around America.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: He's been traveling in some other country.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We have been moving much faster than we did in the Truman years.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But we can and must move faster, and that's why I stand so strongly for programs that will move America forward in the sixties, move her forward so that we can stay ahead of the Soviet Union and win the battle for freedom and peace.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Well first may I correct a statement which was made before, that under my agricultural program food prices would go up twenty-five percent.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The fa- the farmer who grows wheat gets about two and a half cents out of a twenty-five-cent loaf of bread.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Even if you put his income up ten percent, that would be two and three-quarters percent three pers- or three cents out of that twenty-five cents.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The t- man who grows tomatoes - it costs less for those tomatoes than it does for the label on the can.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And I believe when the average hour for many farmers' wage is about fifty cents an hour, he should do better.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But anybody who suggests that that program would c- come to any figure indicated by the Vice President is in error.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The Vice President suggested a number of things.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: He suggested that we aid distressed areas.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The Administration has vetoed that bill passed by the Congress twice.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: He suggested we pass an aid to education bill.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But the Administration and the Republican majority in the Congress has opposed any realistic aid to education.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And the Vice President cast the deciding vote against federal aid for teachers' salaries in the Senate, which prevented that being added.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: This Administration and this country last year had the lowest rate of economic growth - which means jobs - of any major industrialized society in the world in 1959.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And when we have to find twenty-five thousand new jobs a week for the next ten years, we're going to have to grow more.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Governor Rockefeller says five per cent.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The Democratic platform and others say five per cent.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Many say four and a half per cent.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The last eight years the average growth has been about two and a half per cent.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: That's why we don't have full employment today.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Uh - Mr. McGee, there are about a hundred and four commodities that have some kind of depletion allowance - different kind of minerals, including oil.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I believe all of those should be gone over in detail to make sure that no one is getting a tax break; to make sure that no one is getting away from paying the taxes he ought to pay.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: That includes oil; it includes all kinds of minerals; it includes everything within the range of taxation.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We want to be sure it's fair and equitable.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Perhaps that oil abroad should be treated differently than the oil here at home.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Now the oil industry recently has had hard times.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Particularly some of the smaller producers.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: They're moving about eight or nine days in Texas.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: But I can assure you that if I'm elected president, the whole spectrum of taxes will be gone through carefully.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And if there is any inequities in oil or any other commodity, then I would vote to close that loophole, I have voted in the past to reduce the depletion allowance for the largest producers; for those from five million dollars down, to maintain it at twenty-seven and a half per cent.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: I believe we should study this and other allowances; tax expense, dividend expenses and all the rest, and make a determination of how we can stimulate growth; how we can provide the revenues needed to move our country forward.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Senator Kennedy's position and mine completely different on this.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I favor the present depletion allowance.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I favor it not because I want to make a lot of oil men rich, but because I want to make America rich.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Why do we have a depletion allowance?
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Because this is the stimulation, the incentive for companies to go out and explore for oil, to develop it.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: If we didn't have a depletion allowance of certainly, I believe, the present amount, we would have our oil exploration cut substantially in this country.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now, as far as my position then is concerned, it is exactly opposite to the Senator's.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And it's because of my belief that if America is going to have the growth that he talks about and that I talk about and that we want, the thing to do is not to discourage individual enterprise, not to discourage people to go out and discover more oil and minerals, but to encourage them.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: He suggests that there are a number of other items in this whole depletion field that could be taken into account.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: He also said a moment ago that we would get more money to finance his programs by revising the tax laws, including depletion.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I should point out that as far as depletion allowances are concerned, the oil depletion allowance is one that provides eighty percent of all of those involved in depletion, so you're not going to get much from revenue insofar as depletion allowances are concerned, unless you move in the area that he indicated.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I oppose it for the reasons that I mentioned.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Von Fremd, the first thing we have to do is to continue to keep confidence abroad in the American dollar.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: That means that we must continue to have a balanced budget here at home in every possible circumstance that we can; because the moment that we have loss of confidence in our own fiscal policies at home, it results in gold flowing out.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Secondly, we have to increase our exports, as compared with our imports.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And here we have a very strong program going forward in the Department of Commerce.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: This one must be stepped up.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Beyond that, as far as the gold supply is concerned, and as far as the movement of gold is concerned, uh - we have to bear in mind that we must get more help from our allies abroad in this great venture in which all free men are involved of winning the battle for freedom.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Now America has been carrying a tremendous load in this respect.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I think we have been right in carrying it.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I have favored our programs abroad for economic assistance and for military assistance.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: But now we find that the countries of Europe for example, that we have aided, and Japan, that we've aided in the Far East; these countries - some our former enemies, have now recovered completely.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: They have got to bear a greater share of this load of economic assistance abroad.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: That's why I am advocating, and will develop during the course of the next Administration - if, of course, I get the opportunity - a program in which we enlist more aid from these other countries on a concerted basis in the programs of economic development for Africa, Asia and Latin America.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: The United States cannot continue to carry the major share of this burden by itself.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We can a big share of it, but we've got to have more help from our friends abroad; and these three factors, I think, will be very helpful in reversing the gold flow which you spoke about.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Just to uh - correct the record, Mr. Nixon said on depletion that his record was the opposite of mine.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: What I said was that this matter should be thoroughly gone into to make sure that there aren't loopholes.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: If his record is the opposite of that, that means that he doesn't want to go into it.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Now on the question of gold.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The difficulty, of course, is that we do have heavy obligations abroad, that we therefore have to maintain not only a favorable balance of trade but also send a good deal of our dollars overseas to pay our troops, maintain our bases, and sustain other economies.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: In other words, if we're going to continue to maintain our position in the sixties, we have to maintain a sound monetary and fiscal policy.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We have to have control over inflation, and we also have to have a favorable balance of trade.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We have to be able to compete in the world market.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We have to be able to sell abroad more than we consume uh - from abroad if we're going to be able to meet our obligations.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: In addition, many of the countries around the world still keep restrictions against our goads, going all the way back to the days when there was a dollar shortage.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Now there isn't a dollar shortage, and yet many of these countries continue to move against our goods.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We have to be sure to maintain that.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: We have to persuade these other countries not to restrict our goods coming in, not to act as if there was a dollar gap; and third, we have to persuade them to assume some of the responsibilities that up till now we've maintained, to assist underdeveloped countries in Africa, Latin America and Asia make an economic breakthrough on their own.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Well, I think there are many uh - tests, Mr. Drummond, of prestige.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And the significance of prestige, really, is because we're so identified with the cause of freedom.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Therefore, if we are on the mount, if we are rising, if our influence is spreading, if our prestige is spreading, then those uh - who stand now on the razor edge of decision between us or between the Communist system, wondering whether they should use the system of freedom to develop their countries or the system of Communism, they'll be persuaded to follow our example.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: There have been several indications that our prestige is not as high as it once was.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Mr. George Allen, the head of our information service, said that a result of our being second in space, in the sputnik in 1957, and I quote him, I believe I paraphrase him accurately.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: He said that many of these countries equate space developments with scientific productivity and scientific advancement.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And therefore, he said, many of these countries now feel that the Soviet Union, which was once so backward, is now on a par with the United States.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Secondly, the economic growth of the Soviet Union is greater than ours.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Mr. Dulles has suggested it's from two to three times as great as ours.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: This has a great effect on the s- underdeveloped world, which faces problems of low income and high population density and inadequate resources.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Three, a Gallup Poll taken in February asked people in ten countries which country they thought would be first in 1970, both scientifically and militarily.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: And a majority in every country except Greece, felt that it would be the Soviet Union by l970.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Four, in the votes at the U.N., particularly the vote dealing with Red China last Saturday, we received the support on the position that we had taken of only two African countries - one, Liberia, which had been tied to us for more than a century, and the other, Union of South Africa, which is not a popular country in Africa.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: A - More countries voted against us in Asia on this issue than voted with us.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: On the neutralists' resolution, which we were so much opposed to, the same thing happened.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: The candidate who was a candidate for the president of Brazil, took a trip to Cuba to call on Mr. Castro during the election in order to get the benefit of the Castro supporters uh - within Brazil.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Guinea and Ghana, two independent countries within the last three years - Guinea in fifty-seven, Ghana within the last eighteen months - both now are supporting the Soviet foreign policy at the U.N. Mr. Herter said so himself.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Laos is moving in that direction.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: So I would say our prestige is not so high.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: No longer do we give the image of being on the rise.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: No longer do we give an image of vitality.
Speaker: John F. Kennedy

Text: Well, I would say first of all that Senator's - Kennedy's statement that he's just made is not going to help our Gallup Polls abroad and it isn't going to help our prestige either.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Let's look at the other side of the coin.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Let's look at the vote on the Congo, the vote was seventy to nothing against the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Let's look at the situation with regard to economic growth as it really is.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We find that the Soviet Union is a very primitive economy.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Its growth rate is not what counts; it's whether it is catching up with us and it is not catching up with us.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We're well ahead and we can stay ahead, provided we have confidence in America and don't run her down in order to build her up.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: We could look also at other items which Senator Kennedy has named, but I will only conclude by saying this: in this whole matter of prestige, in the final analysis, its whether you stand for what's right.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: And getting back to this matter that we discussed at the outset, the matter of Quemoy and Matsu.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: I can think of nothing that will be a greater blow to the prestige of the United States among the free nations in Asia than for us to take Senator Kennedy's advan- advice to go - go against what a majority of the members of the Senate, both Democrat and Republican, did - said in 1955, and to say in advance we will surrender an area to the Communists.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: In other words, if the United States is going to maintain its strength and its prestige, we must not only be strong militarily and economically, we must be firm diplomatically.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Thi- Certainly we have been speaking, I know, of whether we should have retreat or defeat.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: Let's remember the way to win is not to retreat and not to surrender.
Speaker: Richard M. Nixon

Text: There are many people who believe that the only way we can get this country turned around is to tax the middle class more and punish them more, but the truth is that middle-class Americans are basically the only group of Americans who've been taxed more in the 1980s and during the last 12 years, even though their incomes have gone down.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The wealthiest Americans have been taxed much less, even though their incomes have gone up.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Middle-class people will have their fair share of changing to do, and many challenges to face, including the challenge of becoming constantly re-educated.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But my plan is a departure from trickle-down economics, just cutting taxes on the wealthiest Americans and getting out of the way.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's also a departure from tax-and- spend economics, because you can't tax and divide an economy that isn't growing.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I propose an American version of what works in other countries -- I think we can do it better: invest and grow.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I believe we can increase investment and reduce the deficit at the same time, if we not only ask the wealthiest Americans and foreign corporations to pay their share; we also provide over $100 billion in tax relief, in terms of incentives for new plants, new small businesses, new technologies, new housing, and for middle class families; and we have $140 billion of spending cuts.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Raise some more money, spend the money on tax incentives to have growth in the private sector, take the money from the defense cuts and reinvest it in new transportation and communications and environmental clean-up systems.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: On this, as on so many other issues, I have a fundamental difference from the present administration.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I don't believe trickle down economics will work.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Most people are working harder for less money than they were making 10 years ago.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think we can do better if we have the courage to change.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Do I have 1 minute?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Just the ground rules here.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, he doesn't like trickle down government but I think he's talking about the Reagan-Bush years where we created 15 million jobs.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The rich are paying a bigger percent of the total tax burden.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And what I don't like is trickle down government.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And therein, I think Governor Clinton keeps talking about trickle down, trickle down, and he's still talking about spending more and taxing more.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Government -- he says invest government, grow government.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: If they do, they're make-work jobs.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It's the private sector that creates jobs.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And yes, we've got too many taxes on the American people and we're spending too much.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And that's why I want to get the deficit down by controlling the growth of mandatory spending.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think Mr. Perot put his finger on something there.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It won't be painless but we've got to get the job done.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But not by raising taxes.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Mr. and Mrs. America, when you hear him say we're going to tax only the rich, watch your wallet because his figures don't add up and he's going to sock it right to the middle class taxpayer and lower, if he's going to pay for all the spending programs he proposes.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So we have a big difference on this trickle down theory.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I do not want any more trickle down government.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to do something about that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The basic problem with it, it doesn't balance the budget.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If you forecast it out, we still have a significant deficit under each of their plans, as I understand them.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Our challenge is to stop the financial bleeding.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If you take a patient into the hospital that's bleeding arterially, step one is to stop the bleeding.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And we are bleeding arterially.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: There's only one way out of this, and that is to stop the deterioration of our job base, to have a growing, expanding job base, to give us the tax base -- see, balancing the budget is not nearly as difficult as paying off the $4 trillion debt and leaving our children the American dream intact.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We have spent their money.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We've got to pay it back.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: This is going to take fair, shared sacrifice.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: My plan balances the budget within 6 years.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We didn't do it faster than that because we didn't want to disrupt the economy.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We gave it off to a slow start and a fast finish to give the economy time to recover.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But we faced it and we did it, and we believe it's fair, shared sacrifice.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The one thing I have done is lay it squarely on the table in front of the American people.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You've had a number of occasions to see in detail what the plan is, and at least you'll understand it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I think that's fundamental in our country, that you know what you're getting into.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I disagree with both of them.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: For one thing, let me just follow up here.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I disagree with Mr. Perot that the answer is to raise -- put a 50-cent gas tax on the middle class and raise more taxes on the middle class and the working poor than on the wealthy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: His own analysis says that unemployment will be slightly higher in 1995 under his plan than it is today.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And as far as what Mr. Bush says, he is the person who raised taxes on the middle class after saying he wouldn't.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And just this year, Mr. Bush vetoed a tax increase on the wealthy that gave middle class tax relief.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: He vetoed middle class tax relief this year.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And furthermore, under this administration, spending has increased more than it has in the last 20 years and he asked Congress to spend more money than it actually spent.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now, it's hard to out-spend Congress but he tried to for the last 3 years.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So my view is the middle class is the -- they've been suffering, Jim.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now, should people pay more for Medicare if they can?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Should they pay more for Social Security if they get more out of it than they paid in, they're upper income people?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But look what's happened to the middle class.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Middle class Americans are working harder for less money than they were making ten years ago and they're paying higher taxes.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The tax burden on them has not gone down.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I don't think the answer is to slow the economy down more, drive unemployment up more and undermine the health of the private sector.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The answer is to invest and grow this economy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's what works in other countries and that's what'll work here.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think everybody's paying too much taxes.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He refers to one tax increase.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Let me remind you it was a Democratic tax increase, and I didn't want to do it and I went along with it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I said I make a mistake.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: If I make a mistake, I admit it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That's quite different than some.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I think that's the American way.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think everyone's paying too much, but I think this idea that you can go out and -- then he hits me for vetoing a tax bill.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And the American taxpayer ought to be glad they have a president to stand up to a spending Congress.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We remember what it was like when we had a spending president and a spending Congress, and interest rates -- who remembers that?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: They were at 21.5% under Jimmy Carter, and inflation was 15.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We don't want to go back to that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so yes, everybody's taxed too much and I want to get the taxes down, but not by signing a tax bill that's gonna raise taxes on people.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, the record in Arkansas.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I mean, look at it, and that's what we're asking America to have?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Now look, he says Arkansas's a poor state.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But in almost every category they're lagging.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'll give you an example.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He talks about all the jobs he's created in one or 2 years.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Over the last ten years since he's been governor, they're 30% behind, 30% -- they're 30% of the national average.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: On pay for teachers, on all these categories, Arkansas is right near the very bottom.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You haven't heard me mention this before, but we're getting close now and I think it's about time I start putting things in perspective.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I'm going to do that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It's not dirty campaigning because he's been talking about my record for a half a year here, 11 months here.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So we've got to do that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I gotta get it in perspective.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Admit it, that Arkansas is doing very, very badly against any standard -- environment, support for police officers, whatever it is.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Mr. Bush's Bureau of Labor Statistics says that Arkansas ranks first in the country in the growth of new jobs this year, first.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: 4th in manufacturing jobs, 4th in the reduction of poverty, 4th in income increase.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Over the last 10 years we've created manufacturing jobs much more rapidly than the national average.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Over the last 5 years our income has grown more rapidly than the national average.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We are 2nd in tax burden, the 2nd lowest tax burden in the country.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have the lowest per capita state and local spending in the country.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We're low spending, low tax burden.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We dramatically increased investment and our jobs are growing.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I wish America had that kind of record and I think most people looking at us tonight would like it if we had more jobs and a lower spending burden on the government.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I grew up 5 blocks from Arkansas.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Let's put it in perspective.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: It's a fairly rural state.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: It has a population less than Chicago or Los Angeles, about the size of Dallas and Forth Worth combined.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So I think probably we're making a mistake night after night after night to cast the nation's future on a unit that small.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: No, no, no, but I could say, you know, that I ran a small grocery store on the corner, therefore I extrapolate that into the fact that I can run Wal-Mart.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I can't protect an Arkansas company, you notice there, Governor.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Mr. Perot, with all respect, I think it is highly relevant, and I think that a 4-billion dollar budget of state and federal funds is not all that small, and I think the fact that I took a state that was one of the poorest states in the country and had been for 153 years and tried my best to modernize its economy and to make the kind of changes that have generated support from people like the presidents of Apple Computer and Hewlett-Packard and some of the biggest companies in this country, 24 retired generals and admirals and hundreds of business executives, are highly relevant.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And, you know, I'm frankly amazed that since you grew up 5 blocks from there you would think that what goes on in that state is irrelevant.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think it's been pretty impressive.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And the people who have jobs --
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The people who have jobs and educations and opportunities that didn't have them 10 years ago don't think it's irrelevant at all; they think it's highly relevant and they wish the rest of the country had them.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I don't have a dog in this fight, but I'd like to get in on this.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, you think it's relevant.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Governor Clinton has to operate under a balanced budget amendment -- he has to do it, that is the law.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'd like to see a balanced budget amendment for America, to protect the American taxpayers, and then that would discipline not only the executive branch but the spending Congress, the Congress that's been in control of one party, his party, for 38 years.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we almost had it done.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And that institution, the House of Representatives -- everyone is yelling "Clean House!"
Speaker: George Bush
