Text: One of the reasons is we almost had it done, and the speaker -- a very, able, decent fellow, I might add -- but he twisted the arms of some of the sponsors of that legislation and had them change their vote.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: What's relevant here is that tool, that discipline, that he has to live by in Arkansas, and I'd like it for the American people.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want the line-item veto.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want a check-off, so if the Congress can't do it, let people check off their income tax, 10% of it, to compel the government to cut spending.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And if they can't do it, if the Congress can't do it, let them then have to do it across the board.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That's what we call a sequester.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That's the discipline we need, and I'm working for that -- to protect the American taxpayer against the big spenders.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Jim, I don't think that's a fair shot.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I hear it -- I hear it echoed by political opponents.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I don't think it's fair.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think we've been fighting from day one to do something about the inner cities.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I have had it in every single proposal I've sent to the Congress.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And now we hear a lot of talk, oh, well, we all want enterprise zones, and yet the House and the Senate can't send it down without loading it up with a lot of, you know, these Christmas tree ornaments they put on the legislation.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't think in racial harmony that I'm a laggard on that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I've been speaking out since day 1.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We've gotten the Americans for Disabilities Act, which I think is one of the foremost pieces of civil rights legislation.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And yes, it took me to veto 2 civil rights quota bills because I don't believe in quotas, and I don't think the American people believe in quotas.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I beat back the Congress on that, and then we passed a decent civil rights bill that offers guarantees against discrimination in employment.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I've spoken out over and over again against antisemitism and racism, and I think my record as a member of Congress speaks for itself on that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: What was the other part of it?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't think that's true at all.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't think that's true, but you know, let others fire away on it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'd like to just talk about issues, and so --
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Well, no, but the point is that's a subjective thing.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: See, the subjective thing is when does President Bush react?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And it would be very difficult for me to answer that in any short period of time.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I will let the American people decide that.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I would rather not critique the 2 candidates.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The only thing I would say about that is, I think that on the economy, Mr. Bush said for a long time there was no recession, and then said it would be better to do nothing than to have a compromise effort with the Congress.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: He really didn't have a new economic program until over 1300 days into his presidency, and not all of his health care initiative has been presented to the Congress even now.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think it's important to elect a president who is committed to getting this economy going again, and who realizes we have to abandon trickle-down economics and put the American people first again, and who will send programs to the Congress in the first hundred days to deal with the critical issues that America is crying out for leadership on -- jobs, incomes, the health care crisis, the need to control the economy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Those things deserve to be dealt with from day one.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I will deal with them from day 1.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They will be my first priority, not my election year concern.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, I think you're overlooking that we have had major accomplishments in the first term.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But if you're talking about protecting the taxpayer against his friends in the US Congress, go back to what it was like when you had a Democratic president and a Democratic Congress.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You don't have to go back to Herbert Hoover.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Go back to Jimmy Carter, and interest rates were 21%, inflation was 15%.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The misery index -- unemployment and inflation added together -- it was invented by the Democrats -- went right through the roof.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We've cut it in half.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And all you hear about is how bad things are.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You know, remember the question, are you better off?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, is a homebuyer better off he can refinance the home, because interest rates are down?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Is the senior citizen better off because inflation is not wiping out their family's savings?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Is the guy out of work better off?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Of course he's not, but he's not gonna be better off if we grow the government, if we invest, as Governor Clinton says, invest in more government.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You've got to free up the private sector.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You've got to let small businesses have more incentives.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: For 3 months -- quarters I've been fighting, 3 quarters been fighting to get the Congress to pass some incentives for small business.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Capital gains, investment tax allowance, credit for first- time homebuyers.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And it's blocked by the Congress.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And then if a little of it comes my way, they load it up with Christmas trees and tax increases, and I have to stand up and favor the taxpayer.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think the General Motors thing is very relevant.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I did everything I could to get General Motors to face its problems in the mid-'80s while it was still financially strong.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They just wouldn't do it, and everybody now knows the terrible price they're paying by waiting until it's obvious to the brain-dead that they have problems.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, hundreds, thousands of good, decent people, whole cities up here in this state are adversely impacted because they would not move in a timely way.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Our government is that point now.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The thing that I am in this race for is to tap the American people on the shoulder and to say to every single one of you, fix it while we're still relatively strong.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If you have a heart problem, you don't wait till a heart attack to address it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So the General Motors experience is relevant.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: At the point when I could not get them to address those problems, I had created so much stress in the board, who wanted to just keep the Lawrence Welk music going, that they asked to buy my remaining shares.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I sold them my remaining shares.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I went my way because it was obvious we had a complete disagreement about what should be done with the company.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But let's take my life in perspective.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Again and again, on complex, difficult tasks, I have stayed the course.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: When I was asked by our government to do the POW project, within a year the Vietnamese had sent people into Canada to make arrangements to have me and my family killed.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And I had 5 small children, and my family and I decided we would stay the course, and we lived with that problem for 3 years.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Then I got into the Texas War on Drugs program and the big-time drug dealers got all upset.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Then when I had 2 people imprisoned in Iran, I could have left them there.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I could have rationalized it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We went over, we got them out, we brought them back home.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And since then, for years, I have lived with the burden of the Middle East, where it's eye for an eye and tooth for a tooth country, in terms of their unhappiness with the fact that I was successful in that effort.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Again and again and again, in the middle of the night, at 2 or 3 o'clock in the morning, my government has called me to take extraordinary steps for Americans in distress, and again and again and again I have responded.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And I didn't wilt and I didn't quit.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, what happened in July we've covered again and again and again.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But I think in terms of the American people's concern about my commitment, I'm here tonight, folks; I never quit supporting you as you put me on the ballot in the other 26 states; and when you asked me to come back in, I came back in.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And talk about not quitting, I'm spending my money on this campaign; the 2 parties are spending your money, taxpayer money.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I put my wallet on the table for you and your children.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Over $60 million at least will go into this campaign to leave the American dream to you and your children, to get this country straightened out, because if anybody owes it to you, I do.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I've lived the American dream; I'd like for your children to be able to live it, too.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I don't have any criticism of Mr. Perot.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think what I'd like to talk about a minute, since you're asking the question, is the General Motors issue.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I don't think there's any question that the automobile executives made some errors in the 1980s, but I also think we should look at how much productivity has increased lately, how much labor has done to increase productivity and how much management has done.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And we're still losing a lot of auto jobs, in my judgment, because we don't have a national economic strategy that will build the industrial base of this country.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Just today I met with the presidents and the vice presidents of the Willow Run union here, near here.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They both said they were Vietnam veterans supporting me because I had an economic program to put them back to work.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We need an investment incentive to modernize plant and equipment; we've got to control the health care costs for those people -- otherwise we can't keep the manufacturing jobs here; and we need a tough trade policy that is fair, that insists on open markets in return for open markets.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We ought to have a strategy that will build the economic and industrial base.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I think Mr. Perot was right in questioning the management practices.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But they didn't have much of a partner in government here as compared with the policies the Germans and the Japanese followed, and I believe we can do better.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's one of the things I want to change.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I know that we can grow manufacturing jobs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We did it in my state, and we can do it nationally.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, I wondered, when Governor Clinton was talking to the auto workers, whether he talked about his and Senator Gore's favoring CAFE standards, fuel efficiency standards, of 40 miles per gallon.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That would break the auto industry and throw a lot of people out of work.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: As regarding Mr. Perot, I take back something I said about him.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I once said, in a frivolous moment, when he got out of the race: If you can't stand the heat, buy an air conditioning company.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I take it back, because I think -- he said he made a mistake.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And the thing I find is if I make a mistake, I admit it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I've never heard Governor Clinton make a mistake.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But one mistake he's made is fuel efficiency standards at 40 to 45 miles a gallon will throw many auto workers out of work, and you can't have it both ways.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: There's a pattern here of appealing to the auto workers and then trying to appeal to the spotted owl crowds or the extremes in the environmental movement.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You can't do it as president: you can't have a pattern of one side of the issue one day and another the next.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So my argument is not with Ross Perot; it is more with Governor Clinton.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Let's just talk about the CAFE standards -- that's the fuel efficiency standards.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They are now 27.5 miles per gallon per automobile fleet.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I never said -- and I defy you to find where I said -- I gave an extensive environmental speech in April, and I said that we ought to have a goal of raising the fuel efficiency standards to 40 miles a gallon.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think that should be a goal.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I have never said we should write it into law if there is evidence that that goal cannot be achieved.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The Natl Science Foundation did a study which said it would be difficult for us to reach fuel efficiency standards in excess of 37 miles per gallon by the year 2000.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think we should try to raise the fuel efficiency.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And let me say this.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think we ought to have incentives to do it, I think we ought to push to do it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That doesn't mean we have to write it into the law.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Look, I am a job creator, not a job destroyer.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It is the Bush administration that has had no new jobs in the private sector in the last 4 years.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: In my state, we're leading the country in private sector job growth.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But it is good for America to improve fuel efficiency.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We also ought to convert more vehicles to compressed natural gas.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's another way to improve the environment.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, everybody's nibbling around the edges.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Let's go to the center of the bull's-eye, the core problem.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And believe me, everybody on the factory floor all over this country knows it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You implement that NAFTA, the Mexican trade agreement, where they pay people a dollar an hour, have no health care, no retirement, no pollution controls, et cetera, et cetera, et cetera, and you're going to hear a giant sucking sound of jobs being pulled out of this country right at a time when we need the tax base to pay the debt and pay down the interest on the debt and get our house back in order.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We've got to proceed very carefully on that.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: See, there's a lot I don't understand.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I do understand creating jobs.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I do understand how to make things work.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And I got a long history of doing that.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, if you want to go to the core problem that faces everybody in manufacturing in this country, it's that agreement that's about to be put into practice.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Everybody says it'll create jobs.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Yes, it'll create bubble jobs.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, you know, watch this -- listen very carefully to this.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: One-time surge while we build factories and ship machine tools and equipment down there.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Then year after year for decades, they will have jobs.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And I finally -- I thought I didn't understand it -- called all the experts, and they said, oh, it'll be disruptive for 12 to 15 years.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We haven't got 12 days, folks.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We cannot lose those jobs.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They were eventually saying, Mexican jobs will eventually come to $7.50 an hour, ours will eventually go down to $7.50 an hour.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Makes you feel real good to hear that, right?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Let's think it through here.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'm for free trade philosophically, but I have studied these trade agreements till the world has gone flat, and we don't have good trade agreements across the world.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I hope we'll have a chance to get into that tonight, because I can get right to the center of the bull's-eye and tell you why we're losing whole industries in this country.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Oh, no, it will cost jobs, but that's not -- let me say this.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'd rather, if you gave me 2 bad choices --
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'd rather have some jobs left here than just see everything head south, see?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: No, I'm saying our principal need now is to stabilize the tax base, which is the job base, and create a growing, dynamic base.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now please, folks, if you don't hear anything else I say, remember where the -- millions of people at work are our tax base.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If you confiscate the Forbes 400 wealth, take it all, you cannot balance the budget this year.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Kind of gets your head straight about where the taxes, year in and year out, have gotta come from.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Millions and millions of people at work.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'm caught in the middle on NAFTA.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Ross says, with great conviction, he opposes the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I am for the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: My problem with Governor Clinton, once again, is that one time he's gonna make up his mind, he sees some merit in it, but then he sees a lot of things wrong with it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Then the other day he says he's for it, however then we've got to pass other legislation.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: When you're president of the US, you cannot have this pattern of saying well, I'm for it but I'm on the other side of it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And it's true on this and it's true on CAFE.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Look, if Ross were right when we get a free trade agreement with Mexico, why wouldn't they have gone down there now?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You have a differential in wages right now.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I just have an honest philosophical difference.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think free trade is going to expand our job opportunity.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think it is exports that have saved us when we're in a global slowdown, a connected global slowdown, a recession in some countries.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And it's free trade, fair trade that needs to be our hallmark, and we need more free trade agreements, not fewer.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'd like to respond to that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You know, Mr. Bush was very grateful when I was among the Democrats who said he ought to have the authority to negotiate an agreement with Mexico.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Neither I nor anybody else, as far a I know, agreed to give him our proxy to say that whatever he did was fine for the workers of this country and for the interests of this country.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I am the one who's in the middle on this.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Mr. Perot says it's a bad deal.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Mr. Bush says it's a hunky-dory deal.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I say on balance it does more good than harm if, if we can get some protection for the environment so that the Mexicans have to follow their own environmental standards, their own labor law standards, and if we have a genuine commitment to reeducate and retrain the American workers who lose their jobs and reinvest in this economy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I have a realistic approach to trade.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I want more trade, and I know there are some good things in that agreement.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But it can sure be made better.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me just point out, just today in the Los Angeles Times Clyde Prestowitz, who was one of President Reagan's leading trade advisers and a life-long conservative Republican, endorsed my candidacy because he knows that I'll have a free and fair trade policy, a hard-headed, realistic policy, and not get caught up in rubber-stamping everything the Bush administration did.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: If I wanted to do that, why would I run for president, Jim?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Anybody else can run the middle class down and run the economy in a ditch.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I want to change it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think he made my case.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: On the one hand, it's a good deal but on the other hand I'd make it better.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You can't do that as president.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You can't do it on the war, where he says well, I was with the minority but I guess I would have voted with the majority.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: This is my point tonight.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We're talking about 2 weeks from now you've gotta decide who's gonna be president.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And there is this pattern that has plagued him in the primaries and now about trying to have it both ways on all these issues.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And if you make a mistake, say you made a mistake and go on about your business, trying to serve the American people.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Right now we heard it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He says on the one hand I am for it and on the other hand I may be against it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That's what's wrong with Mr. Bush.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: His whole deal is you've gotta be for it or against it, you can't make it better.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I believe we can be better.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think the American people are sick and tired of either/or solutions, people being pushed in the corner, polarized to extremes.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I want think they want somebody with common sense who can do what's best for the American people.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I'd be happy to discuss these other issues, but I can't believe he is accusing me of getting on both sides.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: He said trickle-down economics was voodoo economics; now he's it's biggest practitioner.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: He promised -- he -- you know -- let me just say --
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But I've always said trickle-down government is bad.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I could run this string out a long time, but remember this, Jim.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Those 209 Americans last Thursday night in Richmond told us they wanted us to stop talking about each other and start talking about Americans and their problems and their promise, and I think we ought to get back to that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'll be glad to answer any question you have, but this election ought to be about the American people.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Is there an equal time rule tonight?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Or do you just keep lunging in at will?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I thought we were going to have equal time, but maybe I just have to interrupt the other 2.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Is that the way it works?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now that we've talked all around the problem about free trade, let's go again to the center of the bull's- eye.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I just want to make -- foreign lobbyists, this whole thing.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Our country has sold out to foreign lobbyists.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We don't have free trade.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Both parties have foreign lobbyists on leaves in key roles in their campaigns.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And if there's anything more unwise than that, I don't know what it is.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Every debate I bring this up, and nobody ever addresses it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I would like for them to look you in the eye and tell you why they have people representing foreign countries working on their campaigns.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And you know, you've seen the list, I've seen the list, we won't go into the names, but no wonder they -- if I had those people around me all day every day, telling me it was fair and free, I might believe it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But if I look at the facts as a businessman, it's so tilted, the first thing you ought to do is just say, guys, if you like these deals so well, we'll give you the deal you gave us.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, Japanese couldn't unload the cars in this country if they had the same restrictions we had, and on and on and on and on and on.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I suggest to you that the core problem -- 1 country spent $400 million lobbying in 1988, our country.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And it goes on and on.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And you look at a who's who in these campaigns around the 2 candidates.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They're foreign lobbyists taking leaves.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: What do you think they're going to do when the campaign's over?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Go back to work at 30,000 bucks a month representing some other country.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I don't believe that's in the American people's interest.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I don't have a one of them, and I haven't taken a penny of foreign money, and I never will.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Most people that are lobbying are lobbying the Congress.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I don't think there's anything wrong with an honest person who happens to represent an interest of another country for making his case.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And what you're assuming is that that makes the recipient of the lobbying corrupt or the lobbyist himself corrupt.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't agree with that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But if I found somebody that had a conflict of interest that would try to illegally do something as a foreign -- registered lobby, the laws cover this.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't know why -- I've never understood quite why Mr. Perot was so upset it, because one of the guys he used to have working for him, I believe, had foreign accounts.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Could be wrong, but I think so.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And as soon as I found it out, he went out the door.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But I don't -- I think you got to look at the integrity and the honor of the people that are being lobbied and those that are lobbyists.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The laws protect the American taxpayer in this regard.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: If the laws are violated so much, but to suggest if somebody represents a foreign country on anything, that makes him corrupt or against the taxpayer, I don't agree with that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We're getting ready to dismantle the airlines industry in our country, and none of you know it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And I doubt in all candor if the president knows it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But this deal that we're doing with BAC and US Air and KLM and Northwest, guess who's on the president's campaign big time: a guy from Northwest.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: This deal is terribly destructive to the US airline industry.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: One of the largest industries in the world is the travel and tourist business.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We won't be making airplanes in this country 10 years from now if we let deals like this go through.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If the president has any interest tonight, I'll detail it to you; I won't take 10 minutes tonight.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: All these things take a few minutes.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But that's happening as we sit here today.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We hammerlock the American companies -- American Airlines, Delta -- the last few great we have, because we're trying to do this deal with these 2 European companies.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And never forget, they've got Airbus over there, and it's a government-owned, privately owned, consortium across Europe.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They're dying to get the commercial airline business.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Japan is trying to get the commercial airline business.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I don't think there are any villains inside government on this issue, but there's sure a lot of people who don't understand business.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And maybe you need somebody up there who understands when you're getting your pocket picked.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Why, I had a great response to that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think Ross is right and that we do need some more restrictions on lobbyists.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We ought to make them disclose the people they've given money to when they're testifying before congressional committees; we ought to close the lawyers' loopholes; they ought to have to disclose when they're really lobbying.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And we ought to have to limit -- we ought to have a much longer period of time, about 5 years, between the time when people can leave executive branch offices and then go out and start lobbying for foreign interests.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've wrecked the airline industry already because of all these leverage buyouts and all these terrible things that have happened to the airline industry.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We're going to have a hard time rebuilding it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But the real thing we got to have is a competitive economic strategy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Look what's happening to McDonnell Douglas; even Boeing is losing market share -- because we let the Europeans spend $25-$40 billion on Airbus without an appropriate competitive response.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: What I want America to do is to trade more but to compete and win by investing in competitive ways.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And we're in real trouble on that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I promise it's less than 10 seconds.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I heard Gov Clinton congratulate us on 1 thing -- first time he said something pleasant about this administration.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Productivity in this country is up, it is way up -- productivity is up.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And that's a good thing.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: There are many good ones, but I was glad he acknowledged that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Now give me 1 second...
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, look, I'm just kind of a, you know, cur dog here; I was put on the ballot by the people, not special interests.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, Jim, let me get it out.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: On the 2nd debate, I offered, since both sides want the enterprise zones and we can't get together, I said I'll take a few days off and go to Washington and hold hands with you and we'll get it done.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'll take a few days off and hold hands with you and get this airlines thing straightened, because that's important to this country.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: That's kind of pathetic I have to do it -- and nobody's called me yet to come up, I might mention.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But if they do -- if they do, it's easy to fix.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If you all want the enterprise zones, why don't we pass the dang thing and do it, right?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If I had it to do over again I might answer the questions a little better.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You know, I'd been in public life a long time and no one had ever questioned my role and so I was asked a lot of questions about things that happened a long time ago and I don't think I answered them as well as I could have.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Going back 23 years, I don't know, Helen.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I was opposed to the war.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I felt very strongly about it, and I didn't want to go at the time.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's easy to say in retrospect I would have done something differently.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: President Lincoln opposed the war and there were people who said maybe he shouldn't be president, but I think he made us a pretty good president in wartime.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've had a lot of other presidents who didn't wear their country's uniform who had to order our young soldiers into battle, including President Wilson and President Roosevelt.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So the answer is I could do that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I wouldn't relish doing it but I wouldn't shrink from it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think that the president has to be prepared to use the power of the nation when our vital interests are threatened, when our treaty commitments are at stake, when we know that something has to be done that is in the national interest, and that is a part of being president.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, I've expressed my heartfelt difference with Governor Clinton on organizing demonstrations while in a foreign land against your country, when young ghetto kids have been drafted and are dying.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: My argument with him on -- the question was about the draft -- is that there's this same pattern.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: In New Hampshire Senator Kerrey said you ought to level, you ought to tell the truth about it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: On April 17 he said he'd bring out all the records on the draft.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: They have not been forthcoming.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He got a deferment or he didn't.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He got a notice or he didn't.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I think it's this pattern that troubles me, more than the draft.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: A lot of decent, honorable people felt as he did on the draft.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And again, you might be able to make amendments all the time, Governor, but you've got to, as president, you can't be on all these different sides, and you can't have this pattern of saying well, I did this or I didn't, then the facts come out and you change it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That's my big difference with him on the draft.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It wasn't failing to serve.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I've spent my whole adult life very close to the military.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I feel very strongly about the people who go into battle for our country.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I appreciate their idealism, their sacrifices.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Appreciate the sacrifices their families make.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: That's been displayed again and again in a very tangible way.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I look on this as history.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I don't look on it personally as relevant, and I consider it really a waste of time tonight, when you consider the issues that face our country right now.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I wouldn't have taken any of the alternatives.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I believe that -- I believe I made a mistake.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I did it for the very reasons you say.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: There was one good thing that came out of that budget agreement, and that is we put a cap on discretionary spending.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: One-third of the president's budget is at the president's discretion, or really the Congress, since they appropriate every dime and tell a president how to spend every dime.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We've put a cap on the growth of all that spending, and that's good and that's helped.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I was wrong because I thought the tax compromise, going along with 1 Democratic tax increase, would help the economy.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I see no evidence that it has done it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So what would I have done?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: What should I have done?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I should have held out for a better deal that would have protected the taxpayer and not ended up doing what we had to do, or what I thought at the time would help.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So I made a mistake, and I -- you know, the difference, I think, is that I knew at the time I was going to take a lot of political flak.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I knew we'd have somebody out there yelling "read my lips", and I did it because I thought it was right.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I made a mistake.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That's quite different than taking a position where you know it's best for you.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That wasn't best for me and I knew it in the very beginning.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I thought it would be better for the country than it was.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: 101 in leadership is be accountable for what you do.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Let's go back to the tax and budget summit briefly.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Nobody ever told the American people that we increased spending $1.83 for every dollar of taxes raised.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Both parties carry a huge blame for that on their shoulders.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: This was not a way to pay down the deficit.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: This was a trick on the American people.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Let's go back in terms of accepting responsibility for your actions.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If you create Saddam Hussein, over a 10-year period, using billions of dollars of US taxpayer money, step up to the plate and say it was a mistake.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If you create Noriega, using taxpayer money, step up to the plate and say it was a mistake.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If you can't get your act together to pick him up one day when a Panamanian major has kidnapped him and a special forces team is 400 yards away and it's a stroll across the park to get him, and if you can't get your act together, at least pick up the Panamanian major, who they then killed, step up to the plate and admit it was a mistake.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, leaders will always make mistakes.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We've created, and I'm not aiming at any one person here, I'm aiming at our government -- nobody takes responsibility for anything.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The mistake that was made was making the "read my lips" promise in the first place just to get elected, knowing what the size of the deficit was.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Knowing what the size of the deficit was, knowing there was no plan to control health care costs and knowing that we did not have a strategy to get real economic growth back into this economy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The choices were not good then.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think at the time, the mistake that was made was signing off on the deal late on Saturday night in the middle of the night.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's just what the president did when he vetoed the Family Leave Act.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think what he should have done is gone before the American people on the front end and said listen, I made a commitment and it was wrong.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I made a mistake because I couldn't have foreseen these circumstances and this is the best deal we can work out at the time.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: He said it was in the public interest at the time and most everybody who was involved in it, I guess, thought it was.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The real mistake was the "read my lips" promise in the first place.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You just can't promise something like that just to get elected if you know there's a good chance that circumstances may overtake you.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You're talking about 2 different subjects.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: In order to lead, you first have to use the White House as a bully pulpit and lead; then you have to develop consensus or you can't get anything done, and that's where we are now.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We can't get anything done.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: How do you get anything done when you've got all of these political action committees, all of these thousands of registered lobbyists -- 40,000 registered lobbyists, 23,000 special interest groups -- and the list goes on and on and on.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And the average citizen out here is just working hard every day.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You've got to go to the people.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I just love the fact that everybody, particularly in the media, goes bonkers over the town hall.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I guess it's because you will lose your right to tell them what to think.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The point is, they'll get to decide what to think.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I love the fact that people will listen to a guy with a bad accent and a poor presentation manner talking about flip charts for 30 minutes, because they want the details.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: See, all the folks up there at the top said the attention span of the American people is no more than 5 minutes, they won't watch it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You want to have a new program in this country.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If you get grassroots America excited about it, and if they tap Congress on the shoulder and say do it, Charlie, it'll happen.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And that's a whole lot different from these fellows running up and down the halls whispering in their ears now and promising campaign funds for the next election if they do it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, I think that's going back to where we started.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: That's having a government from the people.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I think that's the essence of leadership, rather than cutting deals in dark rooms in Washington.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Well, I believe in the town hall meetings; they started with my campaign in New Hampshire.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I think Ross Perot has done a good job in having them.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I, as you know, pushed for the debate to include the 209 American citizens who were part of it in Richmond a few days ago.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I've done a lot of them, and I'll continue to do them as president.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But I'd also like to point out that I haven't been part of what we're criticizing in Washington tonight.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Of the 3 of us, I have balanced a government budget 12 times, I have offered and passed campaign finance reform, offered, pushed for and passed in public referendum lobbyist restrictions, done the kinds of things you have to do to get legislators together not only to establish consensus but to challenge them to change.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And in 12 years as governor I guess I've taken on every interest group there was in my state at one time or another to fight for change.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's why I tried to be so specific in this campaign to have a mandate, if elected, so that Congress will know what the American people have voted for.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I would like the record to show the panelists that Ross Perot took the first shot at the press.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: My favorite bumper sticker, though, is: Annoy the Media.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I just had to work that in.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'm going to pay for this later on.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Look, you have to build a consensus, but in some things -- Ross mentioned Saddam Hussein.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Yes, we tried, and, yes, we failed to bring him into the family of nations; he had the 4th largest army.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But then when he moved against Kuwait, I said this will not stand.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And it's hard to build a consensus.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We went to the UN, we made historic resolutions up there, the whole world was united, our Congress was dragging its feet.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Governor Clinton said, well, I might have been with the minority, let sanctions work -- but I guess I would have voted with the majority.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: A president can't do that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Sometimes he has to act.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And in this case I'm glad we did, because if we had let sanctions work and tried to build a consensus on that, Saddam Hussein today would be in Saudi Arabia controlling the world's oil supply, and he would be there maybe with a nuclear weapon.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We busted the 4th largest army, and we did it through leadership.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You don't see Margaret Tutwiler sitting in there with me today.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I happen to think she's a key person.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think our Cabinet members are key people.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think the woman that works with me, Rose Zamaria, is about as tough as a boot out there and makes some discipline and protects the taxpayer.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You talk about somebody strong.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Look at Lynn Martin, who's fighting against this glass ceiling and doing a first-class job on it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Look at our surgeon general, Dr. Novello.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You can look all around and you'll see first-class strong women.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Yeah, I plead guilty to that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But look who's around with him there.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I mean, this is a little defensive on your part, Susan, to be honest with you.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We've got a very good record appointing women to high positions and positions of trust, and I'm not defensive at all about it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: What we got to do is keep working, as the Labor Dept is doing a first-class job on, to break down discrimination, to break down the glass ceiling.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I am not apologetic at all about our record with women.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We've got, I think -- you know, you think about women in government, I think about women in business.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Why not try to help them with my small business program to build some incentives into the system?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think we're making progress here.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You got a lot of women running for office.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: As I said the other night, I hope a lot of them lose because they're liberal Democrats --
Speaker: George Bush

Text: -- and we don't need more of them in the Senate or more of them in the House.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But nevertheless, they're out there.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we got some very good Republican women running.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So we're making dramatic progress.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, I come from the computer business, and everybody knows the women are more talented than the men.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So we have a long history of having a lot of talented women.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: One of our first officers was a woman, the chief financial officer.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And it was so far back, it was considered so odd, and even though we were a tiny, little company at the time, it made all the national magazines.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But in terms of being influenced by women and being a minority, there they are right out there, my wife and my 4 beautiful daughters, and I just have 1 son, so he and I are surrounded by women, giving -- telling us what to do all the time.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And the rest of my minute, I want to make a very brief comment here in terms of Saddam Hussein.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We told him that we wouldn't get involved with his border dispute, and we've never revealed those papers that were given to Ambassador Glaspie on July the 25th.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I suggest, in the sense of taking responsibility for your actions, we lay those papers on the table.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They're not the secrets to the nuclear bomb.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Secondly, we got upset when he took the whole thing, but to the ordinary American out there who doesn't know where the oil fields are in Kuwait, they're near the border.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We told him he could take the northern part of Kuwait, and when he took the whole thing, we went nuts.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And if we didn't tell him that, why won't we even let the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and the Senate Intelligence Committee see the written instructions for Ambassador Glaspie?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I've got reply on that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That gets to the national honor.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We did not say to Saddam Hussein, Ross, you can take the northern part of Kuwait.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, where are the papers?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: -- and Glaspie's papers have been presented to the US Senate.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: If you have time, go through Nexis and Lexis, pull all the old news articles, look at what Ambassador Glaspie said all through the fall and what-have-you, and then look at what she and Kelly and all the others in State said at the end when they were trying to clean it up.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And talk to any head of any of those key committees in the Senate.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They will not let them see the written instructions given to Ambassador Glaspie.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And I suggest that in a free society owned by the people, the American people ought to know what we told Ambassador Glaspie to tell Saddam Hussein, because we spent a lot of money and risked lives and lost lives in that effort, and did not accomplish most of our objectives.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We got Kuwait back to the emir but he's still not his nuclear, his chemical, his bacteriological and he's still over there, right?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'd like to see those written instructions.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: When I make a mistake I say I'm sorry.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I apologize for it but that one got right to the national honor and I'm sorry.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I just couldn't let it stand.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Susan, I don't agree that there are no women and minorities in important positions in my campaign.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But I think even more relevant is my record at home.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: For most of my time as governor a woman was my chief of staff.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: An African American was my chief cabinet officer.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: An African American was my chief economic development officer.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: There was a story today or yesterday in the Washington Post about my economic programs and my chief budget officer and my chief economic officer were both African Americans, even though the Post didn't mention that, which I think is a sign of progress.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The Natl Women's Political Caucus gave me an award, one of their Good Guy Awards, for my involvement of women in high levels of government, and I've appointed more minorities to positions of high level in government than all the governors in the history of my state combined, before me.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So that's what I'll do as president.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I don't think we've got a person to waste and I think I owe the American people a White House staff, a Cabinet and appointments that look like America but that meet high standards of excellence, and that's what I'll do.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They're not correct and if you look at my life, until I got involved in this effort, I was one person.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And then after the Republican dirty tricks group got through with me I'm another person, which I consider an absolutely sick operation.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And all of you in the press know exactly what I'm talking about.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They investigated every single one of my children.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They interviewed all of my children's friends from childhood on.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They went to extraordinary sick lengths, and I just found it amusing that they would take 2 or 3 cases where I was involved in lawsuits and would engage an investigator -- the lawyers would engage an investigator, which is common.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And the only difference between me and any other businessman that has the range of businesses that I have is I haven't had that many lawsuits.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So that's just another one of those little fruit-loopy things they make up to try to, instead of facing issues, to try to redefine a person that's running against them.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: This goes on night and day.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I will do everything I can, if I get up there, to make dirty tricks a thing of the past.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: One of the 2 groups has raised it to an art form.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: It's a sick art form.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, let's go back to Saddam Hussein.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We gave Ambassador Glaspie written instructions.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We've never let the Congress and the Foreign Relations, Senate Intelligence Committees see them.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Ambassador Glaspie did a lot of talking right after July 25 and that's a fact and it's in all the newspapers.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And you pull all of it at once and read it and I did, and it's pretty clear what she and Kelly and the other key guys around that thing thought they were doing.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Then at the end of the war, when they had to go testify about it, their stories are a total disconnect from what they said in August, September and October.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So I say this is very simple.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Saddam Hussein released a tape, as you know, claiming it was a transcript of their meeting, where she said we will not become involved in your border dispute and, in effect, you can take the northern part of the country.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We later said no, that's not true.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I said well, this is simple.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: What were her written instructions?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We guard those like the secrets of the atomic bomb, literally.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, I say whose country is this?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Who will get hurt if we lay those papers on the table?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The worst thing is, again, it's a mistake.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Nobody did any of this with evil intent.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I just object to the fact that we cover up and hide things.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Whether it's Iran-contra, Iraq-gate or you name it, it's a steady stream.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Let's take Mr. Bush for the moment at his word -- he's right, we don't have any evidence at least that our government did tell Saddam Hussein he could have that part of Kuwait.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And let's give him the credit he deserves for organizing Operation Desert Storm and Desert Shield.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It was a remarkable event.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But let's look at where I think the real mistake was made.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: In 1988 when the war between Iraq and Iran ended, we knew Saddam Hussein was a tyrant, we had dealt with him because he was against Iran -- the enemy of my enemy maybe is my friend.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: All right, the war's over; we know he's dropping mustard gas on his own people, we know he's threatened to incinerate half of Israel.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Several government departments -- several -- had information that he was converting our aid to military purposes and trying to develop weapons of mass destruction.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But in late '89 the president signed a secret policy saying we were going to continue to try to improve relations with him, and we sent him some sort of communication on the eve of his invasion of Kuwait that we still wanted better relations.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I think what was wrong -- I give credit where credit is due -- but the responsibility was in coddling Saddam Hussein when there was no reason to do it and when people at high levels in our government knew he was trying to do things that were outrageous.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, it's awful easy when you're dealing with 90-90 hindsight.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We did try to bring Saddam Hussein into the family of nations; he did have the 4th largest army.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: All our Arab allies out there thought we ought to do just exactly that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And when he crossed the line, I stood up and looked into the camera and I said: This aggression will not stand.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we formed a historic coalition, and we brought him down, and we destroyed the 4th largest army.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And the battlefield was searched, and there wasn't one single iota of evidence that any US weapons were on that battlefield.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And the nuclear capability has been searched by the United Nations, and there hasn't been one single scintilla of evidence that there's any US technology involved in it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And what you're seeing on all this Iraq-gate is a bunch of people who were wrong on the war trying to cover their necks here and try to do a little revisionism.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I cannot let that stand, because it isn't true.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Yes, we had grain credits for Iraq, and there isn't any evidence that those grain credits were diverted into weaponry -- none, none whatsoever.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so I just have to say, it's fine.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You can't stand there, Governor Clinton, and say, well, I think I'd have been -- I have supported the minority, let sanctions work or wish it would go away -- but I would have voted with the majority.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Come on, that's not leadership.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Gene, there is a problem in the sense that there are some problem banks, and on December 19th new regulations will go into effect which will in effect give the government the responsibility to close some banks that are not technically insolvent but that are plainly in trouble.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: On the other hand, I don't think that we have any reason to believe that the dimensions of this crisis are anywhere near as great as the savings and loan crisis.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The mistake that both parties made in Washington with the S&L business was deregulating them without proper capital requirements, proper oversight and regulation, proper training of the executives.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Many people predicted what happened, and it was a disaster.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The banking system in this country is fundamentally sound with some weak banks.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think that our goal ought to be first of all not to politicize it, not to frighten people; secondly to say that we have to enforce the law in 2 ways.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We don't want to overreact, as the federal regulators have in my judgment, on good banks so that they've created credit crunches, that is, they have made our recession worse in the last couple of years -- but we do want to act prudently with the banks that are in trouble.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We also want to say that insofar as is humanly possible the banking industry itself should pay for the cost of any bank failures; the taxpayers should not.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And that will be my policy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I believe if we have a good balanced approach, we can get the good banks loaning money again, end the credit crunch, have proper regulation on the ones that are in trouble, and not overreact.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It is a serious problem, but I don't see it as the kind of terrible, terrible problem that the S&L problem was.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, I don't believe it would be appropriate for a president to suggest that the banking system is not sound.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: There are some problem banks out there.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But what we need is financial reform; we need some real financial reform, banking reform legislation.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I have proposed that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And when I am re-elected, I believe one of the first things ought to be to press a new Congress not beholden to the old ways to pass financial reform legislation that modernizes the banking system, doesn't put a lot of inhibitions on it, and protects the depositors through keeping the FDIC sound.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I think that -- I just was watching some of the proceedings of the American Bankers Assn, and I think the general feeling is most of the banks are sound, certainly there's no comparison here between what happened to the S&Ls and where the banks stand right now, in my view.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, nobody's gotten into the real issue yet on the savings and loan again -- nobody's got a business background, I guess.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The whole problem came up in 1984.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The president of the US was told officially it was a $20-billion problem.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: These crooks -- now, Willie Sutton would have gone to own a savings and loan rather than rob banks, because he robbed banks because that's where the money is; owning a savings and loan is where the money was.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, in 1984 they were told.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I believe the vice president was in charge of deregulation.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Nobody touched that tar baby till the day after election in 1988 because they were flooding both parties with crooked PAC money, and it was in many cases stolen PAC money.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, you and I never got a ride on a lot of these yachts and fancy things it bought, but you and I are paying for it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And they buried it till right after the election.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, if you believe The Washington Post and you believe this extensive study that's been done -- and I'm reading it -- right after election day this year they're going to hit us with a hundred banks, it will be a $100-billion problem.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, if that's true, just tell me now.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'm grownup, I can deal with it, I'll pay my share.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But just tell me now; don't bury until after the election twice.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I say that to both political parties.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The people deserve that since we have to pick up the tab; you got the PAC money, we'll pay the tab.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The debt and the deficit.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Well, if you watched my television show the other night, you saw it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And if you watch it Thursday, Friday, Saturday this week, you'll get more.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: A shameless plug there, Mr. President.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But in a nutshell we've got to reform our government or we won't get anything done.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We have a government that doesn't work.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: All these specific examples I'm giving tonight -- if you had a business like that, they'd be leading you away and boarding up the doors.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We have a government that doesn't work.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: It's supposed to come from the people, it comes at the people.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The people need to take their government back.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You've got to reform Congress, they've got to be servants of the people again; you've got to reform the White House.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We've got to turn this thing around.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And it's a long list of specific items.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And I've covered it again and again in print and on television.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But very specifically the key thing is to turn the government back to the people and take it away from the special interests and have people go to Washington to serve.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Who can give themselves a 23% pay raise anywhere in the world except Congress?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Who would have 1200 airplanes worth 2 billion a year just to fly around in?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I don't have a free reserved parking place at Natl Airport, why should my servants?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I don't have an indoor gymnasium and an indoor tennis and an indoor every other thing they can think of; I don't have a place where I can go make free TV to send to my constituents to try to brainwash them to elect me the next time.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And I'm paying for all that for those guys.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'm going to be running an ad pretty soon that shows they promised us they were going to hold the line on spending at the tax and budget summit, and I'm going to show how much they've increased this little stuff they do for themselves.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And it is silly putty, folks, and the American people have had enough of it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Step one, if I get up there, we're going to clean that up.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You say, how can I get Congress to do that?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'll have millions of people at my shoulder, shoulder to shoulder with me, and we will see it done work speed -- because it's wrong.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We've turned the country upside down.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I would just point out, on the point Mr. Perot made, I agree that we need to cut spending in Congress.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I've called for a 25% reduction in congressional staffs and expenditures.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But the White House staff increased its expenditures by considerably more than Congress has in the last 4 years under the Bush administration, and Congress has actually spent a billion dollars less than President Bush asked them to spend.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now, when you out-spend Congress you're really swinging.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That, however, is not my only passion.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The real problem in this country is that most people are working hard and falling farther behind.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: My passion is to pass a jobs program and get incomes up with an investment incentive program to grow jobs in the private sector, to waste less public money and invest more, to control health care costs and provide for affordable health care for all Americans and to make sure we've got the best trained workforce in the world.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've gotta get this country growing again and this economy strong again or we can't bring down the deficit.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Economic growth is the key to the future of this country.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, how about this for a government reform policy?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Reduce the White House staff by a 3rd after or at the same time the Congress does the same thing for their staff.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Term limits for members of the US Congress.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Give the government back to the people.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Let's do it that way.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The president has term limits.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Let's limit some of these guys sitting out here tonight.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And then how about a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Forty-3 -- more than that -- states have it, I believe.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And you want to do something about all this extra spending that concerns Mr. Perot and me?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: How about a line item veto?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And give it to the president, and if the Congress isn't big enough to do it, let the president have a shot at this excess spending.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That means you can take a line and cut out some of the pork out of a meaningful bill.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Governor Clinton keeps hitting me on vetoing legislation.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, that's the only protection the taxpayer has against some of these reckless pork programs up there, and I'd rather be able to just line it right out of there and get on about passing some good stuff but leave out the garbage.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Line item veto -- there's a good reform program for you.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: My plan -- you can read my plan.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: My plan says that we want to raise marginal incomes on family incomes above $200,000 from 31 to 36 percent, that we want to ask foreign corporations simply to pay the same percentage of taxes on their income that American corporations play (sic) in America, that we want to use that money to provide over $100 billion in tax cuts for investment in new plant and equipment, for small business, for new technologies, and for middle class tax relief.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now, I'll tell ya this.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I will not raise taxes on the middle class to pay for these programs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: If the money does not come in there to pay for these programs, we will cut other government spending or we will slow down the phase-in of the programs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I am not gonna raise taxes on the middle class to pay for these programs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now furthermore, I am not gonna tell you "read my lips" on anything because I cannot foresee what emergencies might develop in this country.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And the president said never, never, never would he raise taxes in New Jersey, and within a day Marlin Fitzwater, his spokesman, said now, that's not a promise.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I think even he has learned that you can't say "read my lips" because you can't know what emergencies might come up.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But I can tell you this.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'm not gonna raise taxes on middle class Americans to pay for the programs I've recommended.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And you know how you can trust me about that?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Because you know, in the first debate, Mr. Bush made some news.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: He'd just said Jim Baker was going to be secretary of state and in the first debate he said no, now he's gonna be responsible for domestic economic policy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'll make some news in the 3rd debate.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The person responsible for domestic economic policy in my administration will be Bill Clinton.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'm gonna make those decisions, and I won't raise taxes on the middle class to pay for my programs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's what worries me --
Speaker: George Bush

Text: -- that he's going to be responsible.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He's going to do -- and he would do for the US what he's done to Arkansas.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He would do for the US what he's done to Arkansas.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We do not want to be the lowest of the low.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We are not a nation in decline.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We are a rising nation.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Now, my problem is -- I heard what he said.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He said I want to take it from the rich, raise $150 billion from the rich.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: To get it, to get $150 billion in new taxes, you got to go down to the guy that's making $36,600.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And if you want to pay for the rest of his plan, all the other spending programs, you're going to sock it to the working man.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So when you hear "tax the rich," Mr. and Mrs. America, watch your wallet.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Lock your wallet because he's coming right after you just like Jimmy Carter did and just like you're going to get -- you're going to end up with interest rates at 21%, and you're going to have inflation going through the roof.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Yes, we're having tough times, but we do not need to go back to the failed policies of the past, when you had a Democratic president and a spendthrift Democratic Congress.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Jim, you permitted Mr. Bush to break the rules, he said, to defend the honor of the country.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: What about the honor of my state?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We rank first in the country in job growth, we got the lowest spending, state and local, in the country, and the 2nd lowest tax burden.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And the difference between Arkansas and the US is that we're going in the right direction and this country's going in the wrong direction.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I have to defend the honor of my state.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I'm the only one that's untarnished at this point?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'm sure I'll do it before it's over.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Key thing here, see, we all come up with images.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I think -- you know, I'm starting to understand it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You stay around this long enough, you think about -- if you talk about it in Washington, you think you did it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If you've been on television about it, you think you did it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: What we need is people to stop talking and start doing.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, our real problem here is they both have plans that will not work.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The Wall Street Journal said your numbers don't add up.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And you can take it out on charts, you look at all the studies the different groups have done, you go out 4, 5, 6 years, we're still drifting along with a huge deficit.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So let's come back to harsh reality, and what I -- you know, everybody says, gee, Perot, you're tough.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'm saying, well, this is not as tough as World War II and it's not as tough as the revolution.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And it's fair, shared sacrifice to do the right thing for our country and for our children.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And it will be fun if we all work together to do it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Well, I think the answer to why the drop, I think, has been the economy in the doldrums.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Why I'll win is I think I have the best plan of the 3 of us up here to do something about it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Mine does not grow the government, it does not invest, have government invest.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It says we need to do better in terms of stimulating private business.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We got a big philosophical difference here tonight between one who thinks the government can do all these things through tax and spend, and one who thinks it ought to go the other way.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so I believe the answer is, I'm going to win it because I'm getting into focus my agenda for America's renewal, and also I think that Governor Clinton's had pretty much of a free ride.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: On looking specifically at the Arkansas record -- he keeps criticizing us, criticizing me, I'm the incumbent, fine.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But he's an incumbent, and we've got to look at all the facts.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: They're almost at the bottom on every single category.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We can't do that to the American people.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And then, Helen, I really believe where people are going to ask this question about trust, because I do think there's a pattern by Governor Clinton of saying one thing to please one group, and then trying to please another group.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I think that pattern is a dangerous thing to suggest would work for the Oval Office.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It doesn't work that way when you're president.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And you have to make decisions even when it's against your own interest.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It's against my political interest to say go ahead and go along with the tax increase, but I did what I thought was right at the time.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So I think people are going to be looking for trust and experience.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And then, I mentioned it the other night, I think if there's a crisis, people are going to say, well, George Bush has taken us through some tough crises, and we trust him to do that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so I'll make the appeal on a wide array of issues.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Also I got a philosophical difference.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I got to watch the clock here.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The whole world has had economic problems.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We're doing better than a lot of the countries in the world.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we're going to lead the way out of this economic recession across this world and economic slowdown here at home.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That's why I think I'll win.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'm the last one, right?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'm totally focussed on the fact that we may have bank failures and nobody answered it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'm totally focussed on the fact that we are still evading the issue of the Glaspie papers.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'm totally focussed on the fact that we still could have enterprise zones, according to both parties, but we don't.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So I am still focussed on gridlock, I guess.
Speaker: Ross Perot
