Text: And I am also focussed on the fact that isn't it a paradox that we have the highest productivity in our workforce in the industrialized world and at the same time have the largest trade deficit, and at the same time rank behind 9 other nations in what we pay our most productive people in the world, and we're losing whole industries overseas.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, can't somebody agree with me that the government is breaking business's legs with these trade agreements?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They're breaking business's legs in a number of different ways.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We have an adversarial relationship that's destroying jobs and sending them overseas while we have the finest workers in the world.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Keep in mind a factory worker has nothing to do with anything except putting it together on the factory floor.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: It's our obligation to make sure that we give him the finest products in the world to put together and we don't break his legs in the process.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I really can't believe Mr. Bush is still trying to make trust an issue after "read my lips" and 15 million new jobs and embracing what he called voodoo economics and embracing an export enhancement program for farmers he threatened to veto and going all around the country giving out money in programs that he once opposed.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But the main thing is he still didn't get it, from what he said the other night to that fine woman on our program, the 209 people in Richmond.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They don't want us talking about each other.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They want us to talk about the problems of this country.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I don't think he'll be reelected because trickle down economics is a failure and he's offering more of it, and what he's saying about my program is just not true.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Look at the Republicans that have endorsed me.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: High tech executives in Northern California.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Look at the 24 generals and admirals, retired, that have endorsed me, including the deputy commander of Desert Storm.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Look at Sarah Brady, Jim Brady's wife, President Reagan's press secretary, who endorsed me because he knuckled under to the NRA and wouldn't fight for the Brady Bill.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've got a broad-based coalition that goes beyond party because I am going to change this country and make it better, with the help of the American people.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: First, I'd like to thank the commission and my opponents for participating in these debates and making them possible.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think the real winners of the debates were the American people.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I was especially moved in Richmond a few days ago when 209 of our fellow citizens got to ask us questions.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They went a long way toward reclaiming this election for the American people and taking their country back.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I want to say, since this is the last time I'll be on a platform with my opponents, that even though I disagree with Mr. Perot on how fast we can reduce the deficit and how much we can increase taxes on the middle class, I really respect what he's done in this campaign to bring the issue of deficit reduction to our attention.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'd like to say to Mr. Bush, even though I've got profound differences with him, I do honor his service to our country.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I appreciate his efforts and I wish him well.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I just believe it's time to change.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I offer a new approach.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's not trickle down economics.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's been tried for 12 years and it's failed.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: More people are working harder for less, 100,000 people a month losing their health insurance, unemployment going up, our economy slowing down.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And it's not tax and spend economics.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's invest and grow, put our people first, control health care costs and provide basic health care to all Americans, have an education system 2nd to none and revitalize the private economy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That is my commitment to you.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It is the kind of change that can open up a whole new world of opportunities to America as we enter the last decade of this century and move towards the 21st century.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I want a country where people who work hard and play by the rules are rewarded, not punished.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I want a country where people are coming together across the lines of race and region and income.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I know we can do better.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It won't take miracles and it won't happen overnight, but we can do much, much better if we have the courage to change.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Three weeks from now -- 2 weeks from tomorrow, America goes to the polls and you're going to have to decide who you want to lead this country to economic recovery.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: On jobs -- that's the number one priority, and I believe my program for stimulating investment, encouraging small business, brand-new approach to education, strengthening the American family, and, yes, creating more exports is the way to go.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't believe in trickle-down government, I don't believe in larger taxes and larger government spending.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: On foreign affairs, some think it's irrelevant.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We're living in an interconnected world.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The whole world is having economic difficulties.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The US is doing better than a lot.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But we've got to do even better.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And if a crisis comes up, I ask who has the judgment and the experience and, yes, the character to make the right decision?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And, lastly, the other night on character Governor Clinton said it's not the character of the president but the character of the presidency.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Horace Greeley said the only thing that endures is character.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I think it was Justice Black who talked about great nations, like great men, must keep their word.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so the question is, who will safeguard this nation, who will safeguard our people and our children?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I need your support, I ask for your vote.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And may God bless the US of America.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: To the millions of fine decent people who did the unthinkable and took their country back in their own hands and put me on the ballot, let me pledge to you that tonight is just the beginning.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: These next 2 weeks we will be going full steam ahead to make sure that you get a voice and that you get your country back.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: This Thursday night on ABC from 8:30 to 9, Friday night on NBC from 8 to 8:30, and Saturday night on CBS from 8 to 8:30, we'll be down in the trenches under the hood working on fixin' the old car to get it back on the road.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, the question is, can we win?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Absolutely we can win, because it's your country.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Question really is who do you want in the White House.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, you got to stop letting these people tell you who to vote for, you got to stop letting these folks in the press tell you you're throwing your vote away -- you got to start using your own head.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The "we" is you and me.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You bet your hat we can govern because we will be in there together and we will figure out what to do, and you won't tolerate gridlock, you won't tolerate endless meandering and wandering around, and you won't tolerate non-performance.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And, believe me, anybody that knows me understands I have a very low tolerance for non-performance also.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Together we can get anything done.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The president mentioned that you need the right person in a crisis.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Well, folks, we got one, and that one is a financial crisis.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Pretty simply, who's the best-qualified person up here on the stage to create jobs?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Make your decision and vote on November the 3rd.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I suggest you might consider somebody who's created jobs.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Who's the best person to manage money?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I suggest you pick a person who's successfully managed money.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Who's the best person to get results and not talk?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Look at the record and make your decision.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And, finally, who would you give your pension fund and your savings account to manage?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And, last one, who would you ask to be the trustee of your estate and take care of your children if something happened to you?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Finally, to you students up there -- God bless you, I'm doing this for you: I want you to have the American dream.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: To the American people, I'm doing this because I love you.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I don't know what the differences might be, because I don't know what Mr. Carter's policies are.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I do know what he has said about mine.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I'm only here to tell you that I believe with all my heart that our first priority must be world peace, and that use of force is always and only a last resort, when everything else has failed, and then only with regard to our national security.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, I believe, also, that this meeting this mission, this responsibility for preserving the peace, which I believe is a responsibility peculiar to our country, and that we cannot shirk our responsibility as a leader of the free world because we're the only ones that can do it.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Therefore, the burden of maintaining the peace falls on us.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And to maintain that peace requires strength.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: America has never gotten in a war because we were too strong.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We can get into a war by letting events get out of hand, as they have in the last three and a half years under the foreign policies of this Administration of Mr. Carter's, until we're faced each time with a crisis.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And good management in preserving the peace requires that we control the events and try to intercept before they become a crisis.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I have seen four wars in my lifetime.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I'm a father of sons; I have a grandson.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I don't ever want to see another generation of young Americans bleed their lives into sandy beachheads in the Pacific, or rice paddies and jungles in the in Asia or the muddy battlefields of Europe.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Mr. Stone, I have submitted an economic plan that I have worked out in concert with a number of fine economists in this country, all of whom approve it, and believe that over a five year projection, this plan can permit the extra spending for needed refurbishing of our defensive posture, that it can provide for a balanced budget by 1983 if not earlier, and that we can afford - along with the cuts that I have proposed in Government.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: spending - we can afford the tax cuts I have proposed and probably mainly because Mr. Carter's economic policy has built into the next five years, and on beyond that, a tax increase that will be taking $86 billion more out of the people's pockets than was taken this year.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And my tax cut does not come close to eliminating that $86 billion increase.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I'm only reducing the amount of the increase.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: In other words, what I'm talking about is not putting government back to getting less money than government's been getting, but simply cutting the increase in in spending.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Mr. Stone, I've had to make thousands of decisions since I've been President, serving in the Oval Office.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And with each one of those decisions that affect the future of my country, I have learned in the process.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think I'm a much wiser and more experienced man than I was when I debated four years ago against President Ford.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I've also learned that there are no simple answers to complicated questions.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: H. L. Mencken said that for every problem there's a simple answer.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It would be neat and plausible and wrong.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The fact is that this nation, in the eight years before I became President, had its own military strength decreased.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Seven out of eight years, the budget commitments for defense went down, 37% in all.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Since I've been in office, we've had a steady, carefully planned, methodical but, very effective increase in our commitment for defense.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But what we've done is use that enormous power and prestige and military strength of the United States to preserve the peace.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've not only kept peace for our own country, but we've been able to extend the benefits of peace to others.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In the Middle East, we've worked for a peace treaty between Israel and Egypt, successfully, and have tied ourselves together with Israel and Egypt in a common defense capability.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is a very good step forward for our nation's security, and we'll continue to do as we have done in the past.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I might also add that there are decisions that are made in the Oval Office by every President which are profound in nature.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: There are always trouble spots in the world, and how those troubled areas are addressed by a President alone in that Oval Office affects our nation directly, the involvement of the United States and also our American interests.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: That is a basic decision that has to be made so frequently, by every President who serves.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: That is what I have tried to do successfully by keeping our country at peace.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Mr. Stone, in my State of the Union address earlier this year, I pointed out that any threat to the stability or security of the Persian Gulf would be a threat to the security of our own country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In the past, we have not had an adequate military presence in that region.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Now we have two major carrier task forces.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We have access to facilities in five different areas of that region.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And we've made it clear that working with our allies and others, that we are prepared to address any foreseeable eventuality which might interrupt commerce with that crucial area of the world.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But in doing this, we have made sure that we address this question peacefully, not injecting American military forces into combat, but letting the strength of our nation be felt in a beneficial way.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This, I believe, has assured that our interests will be protected in the Persian Gulf region, as we have done in the Middle East and throughout the world.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Well yes, I question the figure about the decline in defense spending under the two previous Administrations in the preceding eight years to this Administration.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I would call to your attention that we were in a war that wound down during those eight years, which of course made a change in military spending because of turning from war to peace.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I also would like to point out that Republican presidents in those years, faced with a Democratic majority in both houses of the Congress, found that their requests for defense budgets were very often cut.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, Gerald Ford left a five-year projected plan for a military build-up to restore our defenses, and President Carter's administration reduced that by 38%, cut 60 ships out of the Navy building program that had been proposed, and stopped the the B-l, delayed the cruise missile, stopped the production line for the Minuteman missile, stopped the Trident or delayed the Trident submarine, and now is planning a mobile military force that can be delivered to various spots in the world which does make me question his assaults on whether I am the one who is quick to look for use of force.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Well, there are various elements of defense.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: One is to control nuclear weapons, which I hope we'll get to later on because that is the most important single issue in this campaign.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Another one is how to address troubled areas of the world.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think, habitually, Governor Reagan has advocated the injection of military forces into troubled areas, when I and my predecessors - both Democrats and Republicans - have advocated resolving those troubles in those difficult areas of the world peacefully, diplomatically, and through negotiation.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In addition to that, the build-up of military forces is good for our country because we've got to have military strength to preserve the peace.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But I'll always remember that the best weapons are the ones that are never fired in combat, and the best soldier is one who never has to lay his life down on the field of battle.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Strength is imperative for peace, but the two must go hand in hand.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Again it's important to put the situation in perspective.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In 1974, we had a so-called oil shock, wherein the price of OPEC oil was raised to an extraordinary degree.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We had an even worse oil shock in 1979.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The recession that resulted this time was the briefest since the Second World War.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Earlier this year, in the first quarter, we did have a very severe inflation pressure brought about by the OPEC price increase.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It averaged about 18% in the first quarter of this year.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In the second quarter, we had dropped it down to about 13%.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The most recent figures, the last three months, on the third quarter of this year, the inflation rate is 7% - still too high, but it illustrates very vividly that in addition to providing an enormous number of jobs - nine million new jobs in the last three and a half years - that the inflationary threat is still urgent on us.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I notice that Governor Reagan recently mentioned the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: which his own running mate, George Bush, described as voodoo economics, and said that it would result in a 30% inflation rate.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: So our proposals are very sound and very carefully considered to stimulate jobs, to improve the industrial complex of this country, to create tools for American workers, and at the same time would be anti-inflationary in nature.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: So to add nine million new jobs, to control inflation, and to plan for the future with an energy policy now intact as a foundation is our plan for the years ahead.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We have demanded that the American people sacrifice, and they have done very well.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: As a matter of fact, we're importing today about one-third less oil from overseas than we did just a year ago.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: At the same time, as I have said earlier, we have added about nine million net new jobs in that period of time - a record never before achieved.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Also, the new energy policy has been predicated on two factors: One is conservation, which requires sacrifice, and the other one, increase in production of American energy, which is going along very well - more coal this year than ever before in American history, more oil and gas wells drilled this year than ever before in history.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The new economic revitalization program that we have in mind, which will be implemented next year, would result in tax credits which would let business invest in new tools and new factories to create even more new jobs - about one million in the next two years.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And we also have planned a youth employment program which would encompass 600,000 jobs for young people.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This has already passed the House, and it has an excellent prospect to pass the Senate.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Mr. Ellis, I think this idea that has been spawned here in our country that inflation somehow came upon us like a plague and therefore it's uncontrollable and no one can do anything about it, is entirely spurious and it's dangerous to say this to the people.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: When Mr. Carter became President, inflation was 4.8%, as you said.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: President Carter also has spoken of the new jobs created.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Well, we always, with the normal growth in our country and increase in population, increase the number of jobs.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But that can't hide the fact that there are eight million men and women out of work in America today, and two million of those lost their jobs in just the last few months.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And yet, his 1980 economic message stated that we would reduce productivity and gross national product and increase unemployment in order to get a handle on inflation, because in January, at the beginning of the year, it was more than 18%.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Since then, he has blamed the people for inflation, OPEC, he has blamed the Federal Reserve system, he has blamed the lack of productivity of the American people, he has then accused the people of living too well and that we must share in scarcity, we must sacrifice and get used to doing with less.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have inflation because the Government is living too well.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And the last statement, just a few days ago, was a speech to the effect that we have inflation because Government revenues have not kept pace with Government spending.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I see my time is running out here.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Yes, you can lick inflation by increasing productivity and by decreasing the cost of government to the place that we have balanced budgets, and are no longer grinding out printing press money, flooding the market with it because the Government is spending more than it takes in.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And my economic plan calls for that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The President's economic plan calls for increasing the taxes to the point that we finally take so much money away from the people that we can balance the budget in that way.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But we will have a very poor nation and a very unsound economy if we follow that path.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: most people, when they think about cutting Government spending, they think in terms of eliminating necessary programs or wiping out something, some service that Government is supposed to perform.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I believe that there is enough extravagance and fat in government.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: As a matter of fact, one of the secretaries of HEW under Mr. Carter testified that he thought there was $7 billion worth of fraud and waste in welfare and in the medical programs associated with it.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We've had the Central Accounting.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Office estimate that there is probably tens of billions of dollars that is lost in fraud alone, and they have added that waste adds even more to that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have a program for a gradual reduction of Government spending based on these theories, and I have a task force now that has been working on where those cuts could be made.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I'm confident that it can be done and that it will reduce inflation because I did it in California.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And inflation went down below the national average in California when we returned the money to the people and reduced Government spending.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Governor Reagan's proposal, the Reagan-Kemp-Roth proposal, is one of the most highly inflationary ideas that ever has been presented to the American public.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: He would actually have to cut Government spending by at least $130 billion in order to balance the budget under this ridiculous proposal.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I notice that his task force that is working for his future plans had some of their ideas revealed in The Wall Street Journal this week.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: One of those ideas was to repeal the minimum wage, and several times this year, Governor Reagan has said that the major cause of unemployment is the minimum wage.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is a heartless kind of approach to the working families of our country, which is typical of many Republican leaders of the past, but, I think, has been accentuated under Governor Reagan.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In California - I'm surprised Governor Reagan brought this up - he had the three largest tax increases in the history of that state under his administration.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The figures that the President has just used about California is a distortion of the situation there, because while I was Governor of California, our spending in California increased less per capita than the spending in Georgia while Mr. Carter was Governor of Georgia in the same four years.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The size of government increased only one-sixth in California of what it increased in proportion to the population in Georgia.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And the idea that my tax-cut proposal is inflationary: I would like to ask the President why is it inflationary to let the people keep more of their money and spend it the way that they like, and it isn't inflationary to let him take that money and spend it the way he wants?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I have been talking to a number of Congressmen who have much the same idea that I have, and that is that in the inner city areas, that in cooperation with the local government and the national Government, and using tax incentives and with cooperating with the private sector, that we have development zones.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Let the local entity, the city, declare this particular area, based on the standards of the percentage of people on welfare, unemployed, and so forth, in that area.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And then, through tax incentives, induce the creation of businesses providing jobs and so forth in those areas.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The elements of government through these tax incentives For example, a business that would not have, for a period of time, an increase in the property tax reflecting its development of the unused property that it was making wouldn't be any loss to the city because the city isn't getting any tax from that now.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And there would simply be a delay, and on the other hand, many of the people who would then be given jobs are presently wards of the Government and it wouldn't hurt to give them a tax incentive, because they... that wouldn't be costing Government anything either.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think there are things to do in this regard.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I stood in the South Bronx on the exact spot that President Carter stood on in 1977.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: You have to see it to believe it.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It looks like a bombed-out city - great, gaunt skeletons of buildings.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Windows smashed out, painted on one of them "Unkept promises;" on another, "Despair."
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And this was the spot at which President Carter had promised that he was going to bring in a vast program to rebuild this department.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: There are whole or this area there are whole blocks of land that are left bare, just bulldozed down flat.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And nothing has been done, and they are now charging to take tourists there to see this terrible desolation.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I talked to a man just briefly there who asked me one simple question: "Do I have reason to hope that I can someday take care of my family again?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I am eternally optimistic, and I happen to believe that we've made great progress from the days when I was young and when this country didn't even know it had a racial problem.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I know those things can grow out of despair in an inner city, when there's hopelessness at home, lack of work, and so forth.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But I believe that all of us together, and I believe the Presidency is what Teddy Roosevelt said it was.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I think that something can be done from there, because a goal for all of us should be that one day, things will be done neither because of nor in spite of any of the differences between us - ethnic differences or racial differences, whatever they may be - that we will have total equal opportunity for all people.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I would do everything I could in my power to bring that about.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: When I was campaigning in 1976, everywhere I went, the mayors and local officials were in despair about the rapidly deteriorating central cities of our nation.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We initiated a very fine urban renewal program, working with the mayors, the governors, and other interested officials.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This has been a very successful effort.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: That's one of the main reasons that we've had such an increase in the number of people employed.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Of the nine million people put to work in new jobs since I've been in office, 1.3 million of those has been among black Americans, and another million among those who speak Spanish.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We now are planning to continue the revitalization program with increased commitments of rapid transit, mass transit.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Under the windfall profits tax, we expect to spend about $43 billion in the next 10 years to rebuild the transportation systems of our country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We also are pursuing housing programs.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've had a 73% increase in the allotment of Federal funds for improved education.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: These are the kinds of efforts worked on a joint basis with community leaders, particularly in the minority areas of the central cities that have been deteriorating so rapidly in the past.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It's very important to us that this be done with the full involvement of minority citizens.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I noticed that Governor Reagan said that when he was a young man that there was no knowledge of a racial problem in this country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Those who suffered from discrimination because of race or sex certainly knew we had a racial problem.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We have gone a long way toward correcting these problems, but we still have a long way to go.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Ours is a nation of refugees, a nation of immigrants.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Almost all of our citizens came here from other lands and now have hopes, which are being realized, for a better life, preserving their ethnic commitments, their family structures, their religious beliefs, preserving their relationships with their relatives in foreign countries, but still holding themselves together in a very coherent society, which gives our nation its strength.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In the past, those minority groups have often been excluded from participation in the affairs of government.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Since I've been President, I've appointed, for instance, more than twice as many black Federal judges as all previous presidents in the history of this country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I've done the same thing in the appointment of women, and also Spanish-speaking Americans.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: To involve them in the administration of government and the feeling that they belong to the societal structure that makes decisions in the judiciary and in the executive branch is a very important commitment which I am trying to realize and will continue to do so in the future.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The President talks of Government programs, and they have their place.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But as governor, when I was at that end of the line and receiving some of these grants for Government programs, I saw that so many of them were dead-end.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: They were public employment that these people who really want to get out into the private job market where there are jobs with a future.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, the President spoke a moment ago about that I was against the minimum wage.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I wish he could have been with me when I sat with a group of teenagers who were black, and who were telling me about their unemployment problems, and that it was the minimum wage that had done away with the jobs that they once could get.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And indeed, every time it has increased you will find there is an increase in minority unemployment among young people.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And therefore, I have been in favor of a separate minimum for them.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: With regard to the great progress that has been made with this Government spending, the rate of black unemployment in Detroit, Michigan, is 56%.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It's obvious that we still have a long way to go in fully incorporating the minority groups into the mainstream of American life.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We have made good progress, and there is no doubt in my mind that the commitment to unemployment compensation, the minimum wage, welfare, national health insurance, those kinds of commitments that have typified the Democratic party since ancient history in this country's political life are a very important element of the future.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In all those elements, Governor Reagan has repeatedly spoken out against them, which, to me, shows a very great insensitivity to giving deprived families a better chance in life.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This, to me, is a very important difference between him and me in this election, and I believe the American people will judge accordingly.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: There is no doubt in my mind that in the downtown central cities, with the, with the new commitment on an energy policy, with a chance to revitalize homes and to make them more fuel efficient, with a chance for our synthetic fuels program, solar power, this will give us an additional opportunity for jobs which will pay rich dividends.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Barbara, one of the blights on this world is the threat and the activities of terrorists.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: At one of the recent economic summit conferences between myself and the other leaders of the western world, we committed ourselves to take strong action against terrorism.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Airplane hijacking was one of the elements of that commitment.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: There is no doubt that we have seen in recent years - in recent months - additional acts of violence against Jews in France and, of course, against those who live in Israel, by the PLO and other terrorist organizations.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Ultimately, the most serious terrorist threat is if one of those radical nations, who believe in terrorism as a policy, should have atomic weapons.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Both I and all my predecessors have had a deep commitment to controlling the proliferation of nuclear weapons.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In countries like Libya or Iraq, we have even alienated some of our closest trade partners because we have insisted upon the control of the spread of nuclear weapons to those potentially terrorist countries.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: When Governor Reagan has been asked about that, he makes the very disturbing comment that non-proliferation, or the control of the spread of nuclear weapons, is none of our business.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And recently when he was asked specifically about Iraq, he said there is nothing we can do about it.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This ultimate terrorist threat is the most fearsome of all, and it's part of a pattern where our country must stand firm to control terrorism of all kinds.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We will maintain our position of neutrality in the Iran and Iraq war.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We have no plans to sell additional materiel or goods to Iran, that might be of a warlike nature.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: When I made my decision to stop all trade with Iran as a result of the taking of our hostages, I announced then, and have consistently maintained since then, that if the hostages are released safely, we would make delivery on those items which Iran owns - which they have bought and paid for - also, that the frozen Iranian assets would be released.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Barbara, you've asked that question twice.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think you ought to have at least one answer to it.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I have been accused lately of having a secret plan with regard to the hostages.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, this comes from an answer that I've made at least 50 times during this campaign to the press, when I am asked have you any ideas of what you would do if you were there?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I said, well, yes.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I think that anyone that's seeking this position, as well as other people, probably, have thought to themselves, what about this, what about that?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: These are just ideas of what I would think of if I were in that position and had access to the information, and which I would know all the options that were open to me.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I have never answered the question, however; second, the one that says, well, tell me, what are some of those ideas?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: First of all, I would be fearful that I might say something that was presently under way or in negotiations, and thus expose it and endanger the hostages, and sometimes, I think some of my ideas might require quiet diplomacy where you don't say in advance, or say to anyone, what it is you're thinking of doing.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Your question is difficult to answer, because, in the situation right now, no one wants to say anything that would inadvertently delay, in any way, the return of those hostages if there if there is a chance that they're coming home soon, or that might cause them harm.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: What I do think should be done, once they are safely here with their families, and that tragedy is over - we've endured this humiliation for just lacking one week of a year now - then, I think, it is time for us to have a complete investigation as to the diplomatic efforts that were made in the beginning, why they have been there so long, and when they came home, what did we have to do in order to bring that about - what arrangements were made?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I would suggest that Congress should hold such an investigation.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: In the meantime, I'm going to continue praying that they'll carne home.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The degree of unpopularity of a regime when the choice is total authoritarianism totalitarianism, I should say, in the alternative government, makes one wonder whether you are being helpful to the people.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And we've been guilty of that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Because someone didn't meet exactly our standards of human rights, even though they were an ally of ours, instead of trying patiently to persuade them to change their ways, we have, in a number of instances, aided a revolutionary overthrow which results in complete totalitarianism, instead, for those people.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think that this is a kind of a hypocritical policy when, at the same time, we're maintaining a detente with the one nation in the world where there are no human rights at all - the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, there was a second phase in the Iranian affair in which we had something to do with that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And that was, we had adequate warning that there was a threat to our embassy, and we could have done what other embassies did - either strengthen our security there, or remove our personnel before the kidnap and the takeover took place.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I didn't hear any comment from Governor Reagan about what he would do to stop or reduce terrorism in the future.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: What the Western allies did decide to do is to stop all air flights - commercial air flights - to any nation involved in terrorism or the hijacking of air planes, or the harboring of hijackers.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Secondly, we all committed ourselves, as have all my predecessors in the Oval Office not to permit the spread of nuclear weapons to a terrorist nation, or to any other nation that does not presently have those weapons or capabilities for explosives.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Third, not to make any sales of materiel or weapons to a nation which is involved in terrorist activities.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And, lastly, not to deal with the PLO until and unless the PLO recognizes Israel's right to exist and recognizes UN Resolution 242 as a basis for Middle East peace.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: These are a few of the things to which our nation is committed, and we will continue with these commitments.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And while I have a last word here, I would like to correct a misstatement of fact by the President.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I have never made the statement that he suggested about nuclear proliferation and nuclear proliferation, or the trying to halt it, would be a major part of a foreign policy of mine.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think I'm right because I believe that we must have a consistent foreign policy, a strong America, and a strong economy.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And then, as we build up our national security, to restore our margin of safety, we at the same time try to restrain the Soviet build-up, which has been going forward at a rapid pace, and for quite some time.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The SALT II treaty was the result of negotiations that Mr. Carter's team entered into after he had asked the Soviet Union for a discussion of actual reduction of nuclear strategic weapons.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And his emissary, I think, came home in 12 hours having heard a very definite nyet.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But taking that one no from the Soviet Union, we then went back into negotiations on their terms, because Mr. Carter had canceled the B-I bomber, delayed the MX, delayed the Trident submarine, delayed the cruise missile, shut down the Missile Man - the three - the Minuteman missile production line, and whatever other things that might have been done.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The Soviet Union sat at the table knowing that we had gone forward with unilateral concessions without any reciprocation from them whatsoever.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It has been blocked by a Senate in which there is a Democratic majority.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Indeed, the Senate Armed Services Committee voted 10 to 0, with seven abstentions, against the SALT II treaty, and declared that it was not in the national security interests of the United States.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Besides which, it is illegal, because the law of the land, passed by Congress, says that we cannot accept a treaty in which we are not equal.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And we are not equal in this treaty for one reason alone - our B-2 bombers are considered to be strategic weapons; their Backfire bombers are not.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Yes, I'd be glad to.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: unemployment, the cities are all very important issues, but they pale into insignificance in the life and duties of a President when compared with the control of nuclear weapons.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: He has never supported any of those arms control agreements - the limited test ban, SALT I, nor the Antiballistic Missile Treaty, nor the Vladivostok Treaty negotiated with the Soviet Union by President Ford - and now he wants to throw into the wastebasket a treaty to control nuclear weapons on a balanced and equal basis between ourselves and the Soviet Union, negotiated over a seven-year period, by myself and my two Republican predecessors.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The Senate has not voted yet on the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: There have been preliminary skirmishing in the committees of the Senate, but the Treaty has never come to the floor of the Senate for either a debate or a vote.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It's understandable that a Senator in the preliminary debates can make an irresponsible statement, or, maybe, an ill-advised statement.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: You've got 99 other senators to correct that mistake, if it is a mistake.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But when a man who hopes to be President says, take this treaty, discard it, do not vote, do not debate, do not explore the issues, do not finally capitalize on this long negotiation - that is a very dangerous and disturbing thing.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Yes, I'd like to respond very much.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: First of all, the Soviet Union if I have been critical of some of the previous agreements, it's because we've been out-negotiated for quite a long time.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And they have managed, in spite of all of our attempts at arms limitation, to go forward with the biggest military build-up in the history of man.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, to suggest that because two Republican presidents tried to pass the SALT treaty - that puts them on its side - I would like to say that President Ford, who was within 90% of a treaty that we could be in agreement with when he left office, is emphatically against this SALT treaty.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I would like to point out also that senators like Henry Jackson and Hollings of South Carolina - they are taking the lead in the fight against this particular treaty.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I am not talking of scrapping.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I am talking of taking the treaty back, and going back into negotiations.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I would say to the Soviet Union, we will sit and negotiate with you as long as it takes, to have not only legitimate arms limitation, but to have a reduction of these nuclear weapons to the point that neither one of us represents a threat to the other.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: That is hardly throwing away a treaty and being opposed to arms limitation.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Governor Reagan is making some very misleading and disturbing statements.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: He not only advocates the scrapping of this treaty - and I don't know that these men that he quotes are against the treaty in its final form - but he also advocates the possibility, he said it's been a missing element, of playing a trump card against the Soviet Union of a nuclear arms race, and is insisting upon nuclear superiority by our own nation, as a predication for negotiation in the future with the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: If President Brezhnev said, we will scrap this treaty, negotiated under three American Presidents over a seven-year period of time, we insist upon nuclear superiority as a basis for future negotiations, and we believe that the launching of a nuclear arms race is a good basis for future negotiations, it's obvious that I, as President, and all Americans, would reject such a proposition.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This would mean the resumption of a very dangerous nuclear arms race.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It would be very disturbing to American people.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It would change the basic tone and commitment that our nation has experienced ever since the Second World War, with al Presidents, Democratic and Republican.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And it would also be very disturbing to our allies, all of whom support this nuclear arms treaty.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In addition to that, the adversarial relationship between ourselves and the Soviet Union would undoubtedly deteriorate very rapidly.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This attitude is extremely dangerous and belligerent in its tone, although it's said with a quiet voice.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I know the President's supposed to be replying to me, but sometimes, I have a hard time in connecting what he's saying, with what I have said or what my positions are.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I sometimes think he's like the witch doctor that gets mad when a good doctor comes along with a cure that'll work.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: My point I have made already, Mr. President, with regard to negotiating: it does not call for nuclear superiority on the part of the United States.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It calls for a mutual reduction of these weapons, as I say, that neither of us can represent a threat to the other.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And to suggest that the SALT II treaty that your negotiators negotiated was just a continuation, and based on all of the preceding efforts by two previous Presidents, is just not true.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It was a new negotiation because, as I say, President Ford was within about 10% of having a solution that could be acceptable.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I think our allies would be very happy to go along with a fair and verifiable SALT agreement.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think, to close out this discussion, it would be better to put into perspective what we're talking about.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I had a discussion with my daughter, Amy, the other day, before I came here, to ask her what the most important issue was.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: She said she thought nuclear weaponry - and the control of nuclear arms.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is a formidable force.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Some of these weapons have 10 megatons of explosion.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: If you put 50 tons of TNT in each one of railroad cars, you would have a carload of TNT - a trainload of TNT stretching across this nation.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: That's one major war explosion in a warhead.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We have thousands, equivalent of megaton, or million tons, of TNT warheads.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The control of these weapons is the single major responsibility of a President, and to cast out this commitment of all Presidents, because of some slight technicalities that can be corrected, is a very dangerous approach.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I don't think there's any doubt that, in the future, the cost of oil is going to go up.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: What I've had as a basic commitment since I've been President is to reduce our dependence on foreign oil.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It can only be done in two ways: one, to conserve energy - to stop the waste of energy - and, secondly, to produce more American energy.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've been very successful in both cases.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We imported today 2 million barrels of oil less than we did the same date just a year ago.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This commitment has been opening up a very bright vista for our nation in the future, because with the windfall profits tax as a base, we now have an opportunity to use American technology and American ability and American natural resources to expand rapidly the production of synthetic fuels, yes; to expand rapidly the production of solar energy, yes; and also to produce the traditional kinds of American energy.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We will drill more oil and gas wells this year than any year in history.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We'll produce more coal this year than any year in history.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We are exporting more coal this year than any year in history.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And we have an opportunity now with improved transportation systems and improved loading facilities in our ports, to see a very good opportunity on a world international market, to replace OPEC oil with American coal as a basic energy source.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This exciting future will not only give us more energy security, but will also open up vast opportunities for Americans to live a better life and to have millions of new jobs associated with this new and very dynamic industry now in prospect because of the new energy policy that we've put into effect.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I'm not so sure that it means steadily higher fuel costs, but I do believe that this nation has been portrayed for too long a time to the people as being energy-poor when it is energy-rich.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The coal that the President mentioned - yes, we have it - and yet one-eighth of our total coal resources is not being utilized at all right now.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The mines are closed down; there are 22000 miners out of work.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Most of this is due to regulations which either interfere with the mining of it or prevent the burning of it:.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: With our modern technology, yes, we can burn our coal within the limits of the Clean Air Act.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think, as technology improves, we'll be able to do even better with that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The other thing is that we have only leased out - begun to explore - 2% of our outer continental shelf for oil, where it is believed, by everyone familiar with that fuel and that source of energy, that there are vast supplies yet to be found.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Our Government has, in the last year or so, taken out of multiple use millions of acres of public lands that once were - well, they were public lands subject to multiple use - exploration for minerals and so forth.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It is believed that probably 70% of the potential oil in the United States is probably hidden in those lands, and no one is allowed to even go and explore to find out if it is there.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: This is particularly true of the recent efforts to shut down part of Alaska.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Nuclear power: There were 36 power plants planned in this country.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And let me add the word safety; it must be done with the utmost of safety.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But 32 of those have given up and canceled their plans to build, and again, because Government regulations and permits, and so forth, take - make it take - more than twice as long to build a nuclear plant in the United States as it does to build one in Japan or in Western Europe.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have the sources here.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We are energy rich, and coal is one of the great potentials we have.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: To repeat myself, we have this year the opportunity, which we'll realize, to produce 800 million tons of coal - an unequaled record in the history of our country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Governor Reagan says that this is not a good achievement, and he blames restraints on coal production on regulations - regulations that affect the life and the health and safety of miners, and also regulations that protect the purity of our air and the quality our water and our land.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We cannot cast aside these regulations.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We have a chance in the next 15 years, insisting upon the health and safety of workers in the mines, and also preserving the same high air and water pollution standards, to triple the amount of coal we produce.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Governor Reagan's approach to our energy policy, which has already proven its effectiveness, is to repeal, or to change substantially, the windfall profits tax - to return a major portion of $227 billion back to the oil companies; to do away with the Department of Energy; to short-circuit our synthetic fuels program; to put a minimal emphasis on solar power; to emphasize strongly nuclear power plants as a major source of energy in the future.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: He wants to put all our eggs in one basket and give that basket to the major oil companies.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: That is a misstatement, of course, of my position.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The Department of Energy has a multi-billion-dollar budget in excess of $10 billion.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It hasn't produced a quart of oil or a lump of coal, or anything else in the line of energy.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And for Mr. Carter to suggest that I want to do away with the safety laws and with the laws that pertain to clean water and clean air, and so forth.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: As Governor of California, I took charge of passing the strictest air pollution laws in the United States - the strictest air quality law that has even been adopted in the United States.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And we created an OSHA - an Occupational Safety and Health Agency - for the protection of employees before the Federal Government had one in place.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And to this day, not one of its decisions or rulings has ever been challenged.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So, I think some of those charges are missing the point.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I am suggesting that there are literally thousands of unnecessary regulations that invade every facet of business, and indeed, very much of our personal lives, that are unnecessary; that Government can do without; that have added $130 billion to the cost of production in this country; and that are contributing their part to inflation.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I would like to see us a little more free, as we once were.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: As a matter of fact,.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: the air pollution standard laws that were passed in California were passed over the objections of Governor Reagan, and this is a very well-known fact.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Also, recently, when someone suggested that the Occupational Safety and Health Act should be abolished, Governor Reagan responded, amen.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The offshore drilling rights is a question that Governor Reagan raises often.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: As a matter of fact, in the proposal for the Alaska lands legislation, 100% of all the offshore lands would be open for exploration, and 95% of all the Alaska lands, where it is suspected or believed that minerals might exist.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We have, with our five-year plan for the leasing of offshore lands, proposed more land to be drilled than has been opened up for drilling since this program first started in 1954.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: So we're not putting restraints on American exploration, we're encouraging it in every way we can.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: If it is a well-known fact that I opposed air pollution laws in California, the only thing I can possibly think of is that the President must be suggesting the law that the Federal Government tried to impose on the State of California - not a law, but regulations - that would have made it impossible to drive an automobile within the city limits of any California city, or to have a place to put it if you did drive it against their regulations.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It would have destroyed the economy of California, and, I must say, we had the support of Congress when we pointed out how ridiculous this attempt was by the Environmental Protection Agency.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We still have the strictest air control, or air pollution laws in the country.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: As for offshore oiling, only 2% now is so leased and is producing oil.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The rest, as to whether the lands are going to be opened in the next five years or so - we're already five years behind in what we should be doing.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: There is more oil now, in the wells that have been drilled, than has been taken out in 121 years that they've been drilled.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The Social Security system was based on a false premise, with regard to how fast the number of workers would increase and how fast the number of retirees would increase.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It is actuarially out of balance, and this first became evident about 16 years ago, and some of us were voicing warnings then.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, it is trillions of dollars out of balance, and the only answer that has come so far is the biggest single tax increase in our nation's history - the payroll tax increase for Social Security - which will only put a band-aid on this and postpone the day of reckoning by a few years at most.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: What is needed is a study that I have proposed by a task force of experts to look into this entire problem as to how it can be reformed and made actuarially sound, but with the premise that no one presently dependent on Social Security is going to have the rug pulled out from under them and not get their check.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We cannot frighten, as we have with the threats and the campaign rhetoric that has gone on in this campaign, our senior citizens - leave them thinking that in some way, they're endangered and they would have no place to turn.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: They must continue to get those checks, and I believe that the system can be put on a sound actuarial basis.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But it's going to take some study and some work, and not just passing a tax increase to let the load - or the roof - fall in on the next administration.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: As long as there is a Democratic President in the White House, we will have a strong and viable Social Security System, free of the threat of bankruptcy.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Although Governor Reagan has changed his position lately, on four different occasions, he has advocated making Social Security a voluntary system, which would, in effect, very quickly bankrupt it.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I noticed also in The Wall Street Journal early this week, that a preliminary report of his task force advocates making Social Security more sound by reducing the adjustment in Social Security for the retired people to compensate for the impact of inflation.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: These kinds of approaches are very dangerous to the security, the well being and the peace of mind of the retired people of this country and those approaching retirement age.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But no matter what it takes in the future to keep Social Security sound, it must be kept that way.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And although there was a serious threat to the Social Security System and its integrity during the 1976 campaign and when I became President, the action of the Democratic Congress working with me has been to put Social Security back on a sound financial basis.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: That is the way it will stay.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Well, that just isn't true.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It has, as I said, delayed the actuarial imbalance falling on us for just a few years with that increase in taxes, and I don't believe we can go on increasing the tax, because the problem for the young people today is that they are paying in far more than they can ever expect to get out.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, again this statement that somehow, I wanted to destroy it and I just changed my tune, that I am for voluntary Social Security, which would mean the ruin of it.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Mr. President, the voluntary thing that I suggested many years ago was that with a young man orphaned and raised by an aunt who died, his aunt was ineligible for Social Security insurance because she was not his mother.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I suggested that if this is an insurance program, certainly the person who is paying in should be able to name his own beneficiary.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: That is the closest I have ever come to anything voluntary with Social Security.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I, too, am pledged to a Social Security program that will reassure these senior citizens of ours that they are going to continue to get their money.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: There are some changes that I would like to make.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I would like to make a change in the regulation that discriminates against a wife who works and finds that she then is faced with a choice between her father's or her husband's benefits, if he dies first, or what she has paid in; but it does not recognize that she has also been paying in herself, and she is entitled to more than she presently can get.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I'd like to change that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: These constant suggestions that the basic Social Security System should be changed does call for concern and consternation among the aged of our country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It is obvious that we should have a commitment to them, that Social Security benefits should not be taxed and that there would be no peremptory change in the standards by which Social Security payments are made to retired people.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We also need to continue to index Social Security payments, so that if inflation rises, the Social Security payments would rise a commensurate degree to let the buying power of a Social Security check continue intact.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In the past, the relationship between Social Security and Medicare has been very important to providing some modicum of aid for senior citizens in the retention of health benefits.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Governor Reagan, as a matter of fact, began his political career campaigning around this nation against Medicare.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Now, we have an opportunity to move toward national health insurance, with an emphasis on the prevention of disease, an emphasis on out-patient care, not in-patient care; an emphasis on hospital cost containment to hold down the cost of hospital care far those who are ill, an emphasis on catastrophic health insurance, so that if a family is threatened with being wiped out economically because of a very high medical bill, then the insurance would help pay for it.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: These are the kinds of elements of a national health insurance, important to the American people.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Governor Reagan, again, typically is against such a proposal.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: When I opposed Medicare, there was another piece of legislation meeting the same problem before the Congress.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I happened to favor the other piece of legislation and thought that it would be better for the senior citizens and provide better care than the one that was finally passed.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I was not opposing the principle of providing care for them.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I was opposing one piece of legislation versus another.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: There is something else about Social Security.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Of course, it doesn't come out of the payroll tax.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It comes out of a general fund, but something should be done about it.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think it is disgraceful that the Disability Insurance Fund in Social Security finds checks going every month to tens of thousands of people who are locked up in our institutions for crime or for mental illness, and they are receiving disability checks from Social Security every month while a state institution provides for all of their needs and their care.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think this debate on Social Security, Medicare, national health insurance typifies, as vividly any other subject tonight, the basic historical differences between the Democratic Party and Republican Party.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The allusions to basic changes in the minimum wage is another, and the deleterious comments that Governor Reagan has made about unemployment compensation.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: These commitments that the Democratic Party has historically made to the working families of this nation have been extremely important to the growth in their stature and in a better quality of life for them.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I noticed recently that Governor Reagan frequently quotes Democratic presidents in his acceptance address.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I have never heard a candidate for President, who is a Republican, quote a Republican president, but when they get in office, they try to govern like Republicans.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: So, it is good fo the American people to remember that there is a sharp basic historical difference between Governor Reagan and me on these crucial issues - also, between the two parties that we represent.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Barbara, reluctant as I am to say anything critical about Governor Reagan, I will try to answer your question.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: First of all, there is the historical perspective that I just described.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is a contest between a Democrat in the mainstream of my party, as exemplified by the actions that I have taken in the Oval Office the last four years, as contrasted with Governor Reagan, who in most cases does typify his party, but in some cases, there is a radical departure by him from the heritage of Eisenhower and others.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The most important crucial difference in this election campaign, in my judgment, is the approach to the control of nuclear weaponry and the inclination to control or not to control the spread of atomic weapons to other nations who don't presently have it, particularly terrorist nations.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The inclination that Governor Reagan has exemplified in many troubled times since he has been running for President - I think since 1968 - to inject American military forces in places like North Korea, to put a blockade around Cuba this year, or in some instances, to project American forces into a fishing dispute against the small nation of Ecuador on the west coast of South America.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is typical of his long-standing inclination, on the use of American power, not to resolve disputes diplomatically and peacefully, but to show that the exercise of military power is best proven by the actual use of it.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Obviously, no President wants war, and I certainly do not believe that Governor Reagan, if he were President, would want war, but a President in the Oval Office has to make a judgment on almost a daily basis about how to exercise the enormous power of our country for peace, through diplomacy, or in a careless way in a belligerent attitude which has exemplified his attitudes in the past.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Well, Barbara, I believe that there is a fundamental difference - and I think it has been evident in most of the answers that Mr. Carter has given tonight - that he seeks the solution to anything as another opportunity for a Federal Government program.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I happen to believe that the Federal Government has usurped powers of autonomy and authority that belong back at the state and local level.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It has imposed on the individual freedoms of the people, and there are more of these things that could be solved by the people themselves, if they were given a chance, or by the levels of government that were closer to them.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, as to why I should be and he shouldn't be, when he was a candidate in 1976, President Carter invented a thing he called the misery index.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: He added the rate of unemployment and the rate of inflation, and it came, at that time, to 12.5% under President Ford.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: He said that no man with that size misery index has a right to seek reelection to the Presidency.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Today, by his own decision, the misery index is in excess of 20%, and I think this must suggest something.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But, when I had quoted a Democratic President, as the President says, I was a Democrat.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I said many foolish things back in those days.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But the President that I quoted had made a promise, a Democratic promise, and I quoted him because it was never kept.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And today, you would find that that promise is at the very heart of what Republicanism represents in this country today.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: That's why I believe there are going to be millions of Democrats that are going to vote with us this time around, because they too want that promise kept.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It was a promise for less government and less taxes and more freedom for the people.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I mentioned the radical departure of Governor Reagan from the principles or ideals of historical perspective of his own party.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I don't think that can be better illustrated than in the case of guaranteeing women equal rights under the Constitution of our nation.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: For 40 years, the Republican Party platforms called for guaranteeing women equal rights with a constitutional amendment.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Governor Reagan and his new Republican Party have departed from this commitment - a very severe blow to the opportunity for women to finally correct discrimination under which they have suffered.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: When a man and a women do the same amount of work, a man gets paid $1.00, a women only gets paid 59 cents.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And the equal rights amendment only says that equality of rights shall not be abridged for omen b the Federal Government or by he state governments.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: That is all it says a simple guarantee of equality of opportunity which typifies the Democratic arty, and which is a very important commitment of mine, as contrasted with Governor Reagan's radical departure from the long-standing policy of his own party.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Mr. President, once again, I happen to be against the amendment, because I think the amendment will take this problem out of the hands of elected legislators and put it in the hands f unelected judges.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I am for equal rights, and while you have been in office for four ears and not one single state - and most f them have a majority of Democratic legislators - has added to the ratification r voted to ratify the equal rights amendment.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: While I was Governor, more than eight years ago, I found 14 separate instances where women were discriminated against in the body of California law, and I had passed and signed into law 14 statutes that eliminated those discriminations, including the economic ones that you have just mentioned - equal pay and so forth.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I believe that if in all these years that we have spent trying to get the amendment, that we had spent as much time correcting these laws, as we did in California - and we were the first to do it.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: If I were President, I would also now take a look at the hundreds of Federal regulations which discriminate against women and which go right on while everyone is looking for an amendment.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I would have someone ride herd on those regulations, and we would start eliminating those discriminations in the Federal Government against women.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Howard, I'm a Southerner, and I share the basic beliefs of my region that an excessive government intrusion into the private affairs of American citizens and also into the private affairs of the free enterprise system.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: One of the commitments that I made was to deregulate the major industries of this country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've been remarkably successful, with the help of a Democratic Congress.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We have deregulated the air industry, the rail industry, the trucking industry, financial institutions.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We're now working on the communications industry.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In addition to that, I believe that this element of discrimination is something that the South has seen so vividly as a blight on our region of the country which has now been corrected - not only racial discrimination but discrimination against people that have to work for a living - because we have been trying to pick ourselves up by our bootstraps, since the long depression years, and lead a full and useful life in the affairs of this country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We have made remarkable success.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It is part of my consciousness and of my commitment to continue this progress.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: So, my heritage as a Southerner, my experience in the Oval Office, convinces me that what I have just described is a proper course for the future.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter
