Text: Well, my last word is again to say this: We were talking about this very simple amendment and women's rights.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I make it plain again: I am for women's rights.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But I would like to call the attention of the people to the fact that that so-called simple amendment would be used by mischievous men to destroy discriminations that properly belong, by law, to women respecting the physical differences between the two sexes, labor laws that protect them against things that would be physically harmful to them.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Those would all, could all be challenged by men.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And the same would be true with regard to combat service in the military and so forth.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But, if we're talking about how much we think about the working people and so forth, I'm the only fellow who ever ran for this job who was six times President of his own union and still has a lifetime membership in that union.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: First of all, I'd like to thank the League of Women Voters for making this debate possible.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think it's been a very constructive debate and I hope it's helped to acquaint the American people with the sharp differences between myself and Governor Reagan.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Also, I want to thank the people of Cleveland and Ohio for being such hospitable hosts during these last few hours in my life.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I've had to make thousands of decisions, and each one of those decisions has been a learning process.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I've had to deal with those crises as best I could.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: As I've studied the record between myself and Governor Reagan, I've been impressed with the stark differences that exist between us.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think the result of this debate indicates that that fact is true.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I consider myself in the mainstream even of the bipartisan list of Presidents who served before me.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The United States must be a nation strong; the United States must be a nation secure.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We must have a society that's just and fair.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I believe that since I've been in office, there have been six or eight areas of combat evolved in other parts of the world.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In each case, I alone have had to determine the interests of my country and the degree of involvement of my country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I've done that with moderation, with care, with thoughtfulness; sometimes consulting experts.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But, I've learned in this last three and a half years that when an issue is extremely difficult, when the call is very close, the chances are the experts will be divided almost 50-50.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And the final judgment about the future of the nation - war, peace, involvement, reticence, thoughtfulness, care, consideration, concern - has to be made by the man in the Oval Office.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It's a lonely job, but with the involvement of the American people in the process, with an open Government, the job is a very gratifying one.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The American people now are facing, next Tuesday, a lonely decision.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Those listening to my voice will have to make a judgment about the future of this country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I think they ought to remember that one vote can make a lot of difference.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: If one vote per precinct had changed in 1960, John Kennedy would never have been President of this nation.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And if a few more people had gone to the polls and voted in 1968, Hubert Humphrey would have been President; Richard Nixon would not.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: There is a partnership involved in our nation.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: To stay strong, to stay at peace, to raise high the banner of human rights, to set an example for the rest of the world, to let our deep beliefs and commitments be felt by others in other nations, is my plan for the future.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I ask the American people to join me in this partnership.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Yes, I would like to add my words of thanks, too, to the ladies of the League of Women Voters for making these debates possible.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I'm sorry that we couldn't persuade the bringing in of the third candidate, so that he could have been seen also in these debates.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But still, it's good that at least once, all three of us were heard by the people of this country.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Next Tuesday all of you will go to the polls, will stand there in the polling place and make a decision.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think when you make that decision, it might be well if you would ask yourself, are you better off than you were four years ago?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Is it easier for you to go and buy things in the stores than it was four years ago?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Is there more or less unemployment in the country than there was four years ago?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Is America as respected throughout the world as it was?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Do you feel that our security is as safe, that we're as strong as we were four years ago?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And if you answer all of those questions yes, why then, I think your choice is very obvious as to whom you will vote for.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: If you don't agree, if you don't think that this course that we've been on for the last four years is what you would like to see us follow for the next four, then I could suggest another choice that you have.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: This country doesn't have to be in the shape that it is in.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We do not have to go on sharing in scarcity with the country getting worse off, with unemployment growing.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We talk about the unemployment lines.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: If all of the unemployed today were in a single line allowing two feet for each of them, that line would reach from New York City to Los Angeles, California.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: All of this can be cured and all of it can be solved.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I have not had the experience the President has had in holding that office, but I think in being Governor of California, the most populous state in the Union - if it were a nation, it would be the seventh-ranking economic power in the world - I, too, had some lonely moments and decisions to make.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I know because we did it there.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We returned $5.7 billion in tax rebates, credits and cuts to our people.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We, as I have said earlier, fell below the national average in inflation when we did that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I know that we did give back authority and autonomy to the people.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I would like to have a crusade today, and I would like to lead that crusade with your help.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And it would be one to take Government off the backs of the great people of this country, and turn you loose again to do those things that I know you can do so well, because you did them and made this country great.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I think you know that I've opposed the death penalty during all of my life.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I don't see any evidence that it's a deterrent, and I think there are better and more effective ways to deal with violent crime.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We've done so in my own state.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And it's one of the reasons why we have had the biggest drop in crime of any industrial state in America; why we have the lowest murder rate of any industrial state in America.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But we have work to do in this nation.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We have work to do to fight a real war, not a phony war, against drugs.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And that's something I want to lead, something we haven't had over the course of the past many years, even though the Vice President has been at least allegedly in charge of that war.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We have much to do to step up that war, to double the number of drug enforcement agents, to fight both here and abroad, to work with our neighbors in this hemisphere.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But we also have to deal with drug education prevention here at home.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And that's one of the things that I hope I can lead personally as the President of the United States.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We've had great success in my own state.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And we've reached out to young people and their families and been able to help them by beginning drug education and prevention in the early elementary grades.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: So we can fight this war, and we can win this war.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And we can do so in a way that marshals our forces, that provides real support for state and local law enforcement officers who have not been getting that support, and do it in a way which will bring down violence in this nation, will help our youngsters to stay away from drugs, will stop this avalanche of drugs that's pouring into the country, and will make it possible for our kids and our families to grow up in safe and secure and decent neighborhoods.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Well, a lot of what this campaign is about, it seems to me Bernie, goes to the question of values.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And here I do have, on this particular question, a big difference with my opponent.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You see, I do believe that some crimes are so heinous, so brutal, so outrageous, and I'd say particularly those that result in the death of a police officer, for those real brutal crimes, I do believe in the death penalty, and I think it is a deterrent, and I believe we need it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I'm glad that the Congress moved on this drug bill and have finally called for that related to these narcotics drug kingpins.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so we just have an honest difference of opinion: I support it and he doesn't.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'd have confidence in him.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I made a good selection.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I've never seen such a pounding, an unfair pounding, on a young Senator in my entire life.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I've never seen a presidential campaign where the presidential nominee runs against my vice presidential nominee; never seen one before.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But you know, Lloyd Bentsen jumped on Dan Quayle, when Dan Quayle said, he's had roughly the same amount of experience.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He had two terms in the Congress.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He had two terms in the Senate, serving his second term.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He founded authored, the job training partnership act.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It says to American working men and women that are thrown out of work for no fault of their own that they're going to have jobs.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We're moving into a new competitive age, and we need that kind of thing.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He, unlike my opponent, is an expert in national defense; helped amend the INF treaty so we got a good, sound treaty, when these people over here were talking about a freeze.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: If we'd listened to them, we would never have had a treaty.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so I have great confidence in him.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: They don't like it when there's an unfair pounding and kind of hooting about people.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so I'm proud of my choice.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And you know, I don't think age is the only criterion.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I'll tell you something, I'm proud that people who are 30 years old and 40 years old now have someone in their generation that is going to be vice president of the United States of America.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I made a good selection.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The American people are seeing it, and I'm proud of it; that's what I'd say.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And he could do the job.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Bernard, this was the first presidential decision that we as nominees were called upon to make.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And that's why people are so concerned.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Because it was an opportunity for us to demonstrate what we were looking for in a running mate.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: More than that, it was the first national security decision that we had to make.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The Vice President talks about national security.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Three times since World War II, the Vice President has had to suddenly become the President and commander in chief.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I picked Lloyd Bentsen, because I thought he was the best qualified person for the job.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Mr. Bush picked Dan Quayle, and before he did it, he said, watch my choice for vice president, it will tell all And it sure did.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: No, because I'm pledged to that, and yes, some taxes have gone up.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And the main point is, taxes have been cut, and yet income is up to the Federal Government by 25 percent in the last three years.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so what I want to do is keep this expansion going.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't want to kill it off by a tax increase.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: More Americans at work today than at any time in the history of the country, and a greater percentage of the work force.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And the way you kill expansions is to raise taxes.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And what I have proposed is something much better.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And that is what I call a flexible freeze that allows growth about 4 percent or the rate of inflation but does not permit the Congress just to add on spending.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I hear this talk about a blank check.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It is the United States Congress.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And by two to one, Congress is blamed for these deficits.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And the answer is to discipline both the executive branch and the congressional branch by holding the line on taxes.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So I'm pledged to do that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Ann, the Vice President made that pledge.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: He's broken it three times in the past year already.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: So it isn't worth the paper it's printed on.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And what I'm concerned about is that if we continue with the policies that Mr. Bush is talking about here this evening, the flexible freeze somebody described it the other day as a kind of economic slurpee he wants to spend billions on virtually every weapons system around.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: He says he's not going to raise taxes, though he has broken that pledge repeatedly.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And he's been proposing all kinds of programs for new spending costing billions.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Now if we continue with these policies, this trillion and a half dollars worth of new debt that's already been added on the backs of the American taxpayer is going to increase even more, and if we continue with this for another four years, then I'm worried about the next generation, whether we can ever turn this situation around.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: No, we need a chief executive who is prepared to lead; who won't blame the Congress; who will lead to bring down that deficit, who will make tough choices on spending
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: No, I'm not sure I can promise that; I don't think either one of us can really.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: There is no way of anticipating what may happen.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I will say this: that we will set as our goal a steady, gradual reduction of the deficit, which will require tough choices on spending; it will require a good strong rate of economic growth; it will require a plan that the president works out with the Congress doesn't blame them, works it out with them, which brings that deficit down; it will require us to go out and collect billions and billions of dollars in taxes owed that aren't being paid in this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And that's grossly unfair to the average American who is paying his taxes and paying them on time and doesn't have any alternative: it's taken out of his paycheck.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Mr. Bush says we are going to put the IRS on every taxpayer.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: That's not what we are going to do.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I'm for the taxpayer bill of rights.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But I think it's unconscionable, Ann, that we should be talking or thinking about imposing new taxes on average Americans when there are billions out there, over $100 billion, in taxes owed that aren't being paid.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Now, I think if we work together on it, and if you have a president that will work with the Congress and the American people, we can bring that deficit down steadily, $20, $25, $30 billion a year, build economic growth, build a good strong future for America, invest in those things which we must invest in economic development, good jobs, good schools for our kids, college opportunity for young people, decent health care and affordable housing, and a clean and safe environment.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Senator Bentsen said, as you recall at the debate with Senator Quayle, that if you give any of us $200 billion worth of hot checks a year, we can create an illusion of prosperity.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But sooner or later that credit card mentality isn't going to work.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And I want to bring to the White House a sense of strength and fiscal responsibility which will build a good strong foundation under which this country, or above which country can move, grow, invest, and build the best America for its people and for our kids and our grandkids.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: He has raised taxes several times.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I wish he would join me, as a matter of fact, in appealing to the American people for the balanced budget amendment for the federal government and for the line-item veto.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: (Applause) I'd like to have that line-item veto for the president, because I think that would be extraordinarily helpful.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I won't do one other thing that he's had to do: took $29 million out of his state pension fund that's equivalent at the federal level of taking out of the Social Security trust fund.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: (Applause) And so I'm still a little unclear as to whether he's for or against the tax increase.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I have been for the taxpayer bill of rights all along.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And this idea of unleashing a whole bunch-an army, a conventional force army, of IRS agents into everybody's kitchen I mean, he's against most defense matters, and now he wants to get an army of JRS auditors going out there.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: (Laughter) I'm against that; I oppose that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't know if the vice president agrees with that.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Margaret, may I go back and just say to the vice president that I didn't raid the pension fund of Massachusetts you are dead wrong, George, we didn't do that.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: (Applause) I have been in politics for twenty-five years, Margaret; I've won a lot of elections, I've lost a few, as you know, and learned from those losses.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I won the Democratic nomination in fifty-one separate contests.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think I'm a reasonably likable guy.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: (Laughter, scattered applause) I'm serious though I think I'm a little more lovable these days than I used to be back in my youth when I began in my state legislature.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But I'm also a serious guy.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: (Laughter) But I also think it's important to be somebody who is willing to make those tough choices.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Now, we have just heard two or three times from the vice president: he's not going to raise taxes.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I repeat, within days after you made that pledge, you broke it; you said, well, maybe as a last resort we'll do it.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And you supported legislation this year that's involved tax increases not once, but twice.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The fact of the matter is that the next president of the United States is going to have to go to the White House seriously, he is going to have to work with the Congress seriously he can't turn to the Congress and blame them for the fact that we don't have a balanced budget and that we have billions and billions of dollars in red ink.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And I think we know what they are: a good strong future, a future in which there is opportunity for all of our citizens.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I don't think it's a question of whether people like you or not to make you an effective leader.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You've got to understand that it is only the United States that can stand for freedom and democracy around the world and we can't turn it over to the United Nations or other multilateral organizations.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I know these campaigns get knocked a lot, but I think I'd be a better President now for having had to travel to these communities and understand the family values and the importance of neighborhood.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: What was he referring to?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think my dad would be pretty proud of me, because I think we've come a long long way and I think, you know three months ago, I remember some of the great publications in this country had written me off.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And what I've had to do is define, not just my position, but to define his and I hope I've done it fairly.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And the reason I've had to do that is that he ran on the left in the Democratic primary, ran firmly and ran with conviction and ran on his record.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And then at that Democratic convention, they made a determination and they said there, ideology doesn't matter, just competence.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And in the process the negatives began.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It wasn't me that was there at that convention.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Thank God I was up in the with Jimmy Baker camping out and I didn't have to hear all the personal attacks on me out of that Democratic convention.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I'm not the one that compared the President of the United States rotting from like a dead fish from the head down.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I have defined the issues and I am not going to let Governor Dukakis go through this election without explaining some of these very liberal position he's the one a liberal, traditional liberal a progressive liberal Democrat.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He's the one that brought up, to garner primary votes, the whole question of the ACLU.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I have enormous difference with the ACLU on their politic agenda.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Not on their defending some minority opinion on the right or the left.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But what I don't like is this left wing political agenda and therefore I have to help define that and if he's unwilling to do it, if he says ideology doesn't matter, I don't agree with him.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, Margaret, we've heard it again tonight and I'm not surprised, the labels.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I guess the Vice President two or three times, said I was coming from the left.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: In 1980, President Reagan called you a liberal for voting for Federal gun control.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And this is something Republicans have used for a long time.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: They tried it with Franklin Roosevelt and Harry Truman and John Kennedy.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And we have two fundamentally different visions of America.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The Vice President is complacent, thinks we ought to stick with the status quo, doesn't think we ought to move ahead, thinking things are okay as they are.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We've always been a nation which was ambitious for America and we move forward.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And that's the kind of America I want.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: There's nothing the matter with that.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But let's stop labeling each other and lets' get to the heart of the matter which is the future of this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: If I knew of three new weapons systems that I thought were purely waste and weren't protected by the Congress, they wouldn't be in the budget.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: They would not be in the budget, but you want one now?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'll give you one, that HMET, that heavy truck, that's cost what is it $850 million and the Pentagon didn't request it and, yet, a member of Congress, a very powerful one, put it in the budget.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think we can save money through this whole very sophisticated concept, Andrea, that I know you do understand of competitive strategies.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It is new and it is very very different than what's happened, but it's not quite ready to be totally implemented.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think we can say, through the Packard Commission Report and I'm very proud that David Packard, the originator of that report, is strongly supporting me.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So, it's not a question of saying our budget is full of a lot of waste.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We're in the serious stages of negotiation with the Soviet Union on the strategic arms control talks.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we're protecting a couple of options in terms of modernizing our strategic forces.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: My Secretary of Defense is going to have to make a very difficult decision in which system to go forward with.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But we are protecting both of them.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We are moving forward with negotiations and, you see, I just think it would be dumb negotiating policy with the Soviets to cut out one or the other of the two options right now.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We have to have modernization, especially if we achieve the 50 percent reduction in strategic weapons that our President is taking the leadership to attain.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And, so, that's the way I'd reply to it and I believe we can have the strongest and best defense possible if we modernize, if we go forward with competitive strategies and if we do follow through on the Packard Commission report.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, Andrea, we've just had another example of why the Vice President's mathematics just don't add up.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think you know because you've covered these issues, that there's no way that we can build all of the weapons the Vice President says he wants to build within the defense budget.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Everybody knows that including the people at the Pentagon.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We are not going to spend the billions and trillions that Mr. Bush wants to spend on Star Wars.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We're not going to spend billions on MX's on railroad cars, which is a weapons system we don't need, can't afford and won't help our defense posture at all.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We're not going to spend hundreds of millions on a space plane from Washington to Tokyo.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We're going to go forward with the Stealth and the D-5 and the advance cruise missile and good conventional forces.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But the next President of the United States will have to make some tough and difficult decisions.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I'm prepared to make them, the Vice President is not.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Well, Andrea, today we have 13,000 strategic nuclear warheads, on land, on air and in the sea.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: That's an incredibly powerful nuclear deterrent.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I don't rule out modernization, and there are discussions going on now in the Congress, I know with the Pentagon, about a less expensive modernized land-based leg of the triad.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But there are limits to what we can spend.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: There are limits to this nation's ability to finance these weapons systems.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And one of the things that the Vice President either ignores or won't address is the fact that you can't divorce our military security from our economic security.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: How can we build a strong America militarily that's teeter-tottering on a mountain of debt?
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And if we go forward with the kinds of policies that the Vice President is suggesting tonight and has in the past, that debt is going to grow bigger and bigger and bigger.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We're going to have conventional forces that are well maintained, well equipped, well trained, well supported.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And we have serious problems with our conventional forces at the present time, and they'll get worse unless we have a president who is willing to make some of these decisions.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And we also have important domestic priorities, in education and housing and health care, in economic development, in job training, in the environment.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And all of these things are going to have to be addressed.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: That's why I say again to all of you out there who have to deal with your household budgets and know how difficult it is that the next President has to do the same.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I want the men and women of our Armed Forces to have the support they need to defend us; the support they need when they risk our lives to keep us free and to keep this country free.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But we cannot continue to live on a credit card.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We cannot continue to tell the American people that we're going to build all of these systems, and at the same time, invest in important things here at home, and be serious about building a strong and good America.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And that's the kind of America I want to build.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think the foremost (Applause)
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I held off for the applause.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think the foremost responsibility of a president really gets down to the national security of this country.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The Governor talks about limits, what we can't do, opposes these two modernization systems, talks now about well, we'll develop some new kind of a missile.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It takes eight years, ten years, to do that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He talked about a nuclear freeze back at the time when I was in Europe trying to convince European public opinion that we ought to go forward with the deployment of the INF weapons.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And thank God, the freeze people were not heard.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And the result is, we deployed, and the Soviets kept deploying, and then we negotiated from strength.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And now we have the first arms control agreement in the nuclear age to ban weapons.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You just don't make unilateral cuts in the naive hope that the Soviets are going to behave themselves.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: World peace is important, and we have enhanced the peace.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I'm proud to have been a part of an administration that has done exactly that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, I think when I think of heroes, I think back, not presently, Ann.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But there are many people who I admire in this country today.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Some of them are in public life in the Senate, the Congress.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think of those young athletes who represented us at the Olympics were tremendously impressive.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We felt strongly about them, and they did so well by us.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I can think of doctors and scientists, Jonas Salk who for example discovered a vaccine which cured one of the most dread diseases we ever had.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think of classroom teachers, classroom teachers that I have had, classroom teachers that youngsters have today who are real heroes to our young people.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Members of the clergy who have done the same.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Drug counselors out there in the street who are providing help to youngsters who come up to me and others who ask for help and want help, are doing the hard work, the heroic work, which it takes to provide that kind of leadership, that kind of counseling, that kind of support.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think of people in the law enforcement community who are taking their lives in their hands everyday, when they go up to one of those doors and kick it down and try to stop this flow of drugs into our communities and into our kids.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: So there are many, many heroes in this country today.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: In many cases they are people in the community who are examples, and are role models.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And I would hope that one of the things I could do as president is to recognize them, to give them the kind of recognition that they need and deserve so that more and more young people can themselves become the heroes of tomorrow, can go into public service, can go into teaching, can go into drug counseling, can go into law enforcement, and be heroes themselves to generations yet to come.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think of a teacher right here, largely Hispanic school, Jaime Escalante, teaching calculus to young kids, 80 percent of them going on to college.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think of a young man now in this country named Villadaris, who was released from a Cuban jail.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Came out and told the truth in this brilliant book, Against All Hope, about what is actually happening in Cuba.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think of those people that took us back into space again, Rick Houk and that crew, as people that are worthy of this.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I agree with the Governor on athletics.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think of Dr. Fauci.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Probably never heard of him.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You did, Ann heard of him.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He's a very fine research, top doctor, at the National Institute of Health, working hard doing something about research on this disease of AIDS.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But look, I also think we ought to give a little credit to the President of the United States.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He is the one who has gotten us that first arms control agreement.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And he is leaving office with a popularity at an all-time high, because American people
Speaker: George Bush

Text: say, he is our hero.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: No, let me tell you something about that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And Barbara and I were sitting there before that Democratic convention.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we saw the Governor and his son on television the night before and his family, and his mother who was there.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I'm saying to Barbara, you know, we've always kept family as a bit of an oasis for us.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You all know me, and we've held it back a little.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But we used that as a role model, the way he took understandable pride in his heritage, what his family means to him.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we've got a strong family.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we said, hey, we've got to unleash the Bush kids.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so you saw ten grandchildren there jumping all over their grandfather at the convention.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You see our five kids, all over this country, and their spouses.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I would say, I don't know whether that's kind or not, it's just an objective statement.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think the man anybody that gets into this political arena and has to face you guys everyday deserves a word of praise.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Because it's gotten a little ugly out there.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It's gotten a little nasty.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It's not much fun sometimes.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I would cite again Dan Quayle.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I've been in politics a long time, and I don't remember that kind of piling on, that kind of ugly rumor that never was true, printed.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So some of it is unfair.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But he's in the arena.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Teddy Roosevelt used to talk about the arena, you know, daring to fail greatly or succeed, no matter.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So I salute these things.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Sam Raybum had a great expression on this.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He said here were all these intellectuals out there griping and complaining and saying it was negative coverage.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Rayburn says, yeah, and that guy never ran for sheriff either.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Michael Dukakis has run for sheriff, and so has George Bush.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I didn't hear the word "liberal" or "left" one time.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I thank you for that.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And doesn't that prove the point, George, which is that values like family and education and community, decent homes for young people that family on Long Island I visited on Monday where Lou and Betty Tolamo (phonetic) bought a house for some $19,000 back in 1962, have had seven children, they're all making good livings.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: They can't live in the community which they grew up in.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Those are basic American values.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think you believe in them.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: They're not left or right.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I guess the one thing that concerns me about this, Ann, is this attempt to label things which all of us believe in.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We may think that you deal with them in different ways.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But they're basically American, I believe in them.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: George Bush believes in them.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think the vast majority of Americans believe in them.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think the American people would appreciate that.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Because you left out one other exception, the health of the mother.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Let me answer your question and I hope it doesn't get too personal or maudlin.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Barb and I lost a child, you know that we lost a daughter, Robin.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I was over running records in west Texas, and I got a call from her, come home; went to the doctor; the doctor said, beautiful child, your child has a few weeks to live.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I said, what can we do about it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He said, no, she has leukemia, acute leukemia, a few weeks to live.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We took the child to New York.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Thanks to the miraculous sacrifice of doctors and nurses, the child stayed alive for six months and then died.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: If that child were here today, and I was told the same thing, my granddaughter, Noel for example that child could stay alive for ten or fifteen years, or maybe for the rest of her life.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so I don't think that you make an exception based on medical knowledge at the time.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think human life is very, very precious.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And, look, this hasn't been an easy decision for me to meet.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I know others disagree with it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But when I was in that little church across the river from Washington and saw our grandchild christened in our faith, I was very pleased indeed that the mother had not aborted that child, and put the child up for adoption.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so I just feel this is where I'm coming from.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I don't assail him on that issue, or others on that issue.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Margaret, Kitty and I had very much the same kind of experience that the Bushes had: we lost a baby, lived about twenty minutes after it was born.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But isn't the real question that we have to answer not how many exceptions we make, because the vice president himself is prepared to make exceptions.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It's who makes the decision, who makes this very difficult, very wrenching decision?
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: (Applause) And I think it has to be the woman, in the exercise of her own conscience and religious beliefs, that makes that decision.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Who are we to say, well, under certain circumstances, it's all right, but under other circumstances it isn't?
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: That's a decision that only a woman can make, after consulting her conscience and consulting her religious principles.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And I would hope that we would give to women in this country the right to make that decision, and to make it in the exercise of their conscience and religious beliefs.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And, incidentally, may I say that that's the decision of the Congress, and the president has concurred.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think I was on the advisory committee, Margaret.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: No, I don't happen to share that goal.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It's an example of how oftentimes we may be associated with organizations all of whose particular positions we don't support, even though we support in general the hope that over time, particularly if we can get those reductions in strategic weapons, if we can get a comprehensive test ban treaty, if we can negotiate with the Soviet Union and bring down the level of conventional forces in Europe with deeper cuts in the Soviet side, yes, at some point it may be possible to reduce defense outlays and use those for important things here at home, like jobs and job training and college opportunity and health and housing and the environment and the things that all of us care about.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But I do think this, that the next president, even within a relatively stable budget and that's what we are going to have for the foreseeable future will have to make those tough choices that I was talking about and that Mr. Bush doesn't seem to want to make.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And that really is going to be a challenge for the next president of the United States; I don't think there's any question about it.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But I also see a tremendous opportunity now to negotiate with the Soviet Union to build on the progress that we've made with the INF Treaty, which I strongly supported and most Democrats did to get those reductions in strategic weapons, to get a test ban treaty, and to really make progress on the reduction of conventional forces in Europe.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And if we can do that and do it in a way that gets deeper cuts on the Soviet side, which is where they ought to come from, then I think we have an opportunity over the long haul to begin to move some of our resources from the military to important domestic priorities that can provide college opportunity for that young woman whose mother wrote me from Texas just the other day, from Longview, Texas: two teachers, a mother and a father who have a child that's a freshman in college, an electrical engineering major, a very bright student and they can't afford to keep that child in college.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: So I hope that we can begin to move those resources.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But it certainly ought to be the long-term goal of all Americans and I think it is.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And you see, I think we're facing a real opportunity for world peace.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: This is a big question.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And it's a question as to whether the United States will continue to lead for peace.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So, what I'm saying is, we are going to have to make choices.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I said I would have the Secretary of Defense sit down.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But while the President is negotiating with the Soviet Union, I simply do not want to make these unilateral cuts.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I think those that advocated the freeze missed the point that there was a better way and that better way has resulted in a principle asymmetrical cuts.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The Soviets take out more than we do and the principle of intrusive verification.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And those two principles can now be applied to conventional forces, to strategic forces, provided
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And some domestic programs as well, Andrea.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: May I disagree with the premise of your question?
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: As a matter of reality, Fm going to have to because we have had not one but two detailed studies which indicate that there are billions and billions of dollars to be collected that are not being paid these are not taxes owed by average Americans.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We don't have an alternative.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We'll lose it when it's taken out of our paycheck before we even get it.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But it's the Internal Revenue Service which estimates now that we aren't collecting $100 billion or more in taxes owed in this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And that is just absolutely unfair to the vast majority of Americans who pay their taxes and pay them on time.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The Dorgan Task Force, which included two internal revenue commissioners, one a Republican, one a Democrat.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It was a bipartisan commission, a study by two respected economists, which indicated that we could collect some 40, 45, 50 billion dollars of those funds.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The point is you've got to have a president who's prepared to do this and to begin right away and, preferably, a president who was a governor of a state that's had very, very successful experience at doing this.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: In my own state, we did it.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: In other states, we've done it.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Republican governors as well as Democratic governors.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And we've had great success at revenue enforcement.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Now, the Vice President will probably tell you that it's going to take an army of IRS collectors again.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Well, his campaign manager, who used to be the secretary of the treasury, was taking great credit about a year ago and asking and receiving from the Congress substantial additional funds to hire internal revenue agents to go out and collect these funds, and I'm happy to join Jim Baker in saying that we agree on this.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But, the fact of the matter is that this is something that we must begin it's going to take at least the first year of the new administration.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But, the Dorgan Task Force, the bipartisan task force estimated that we could collect about $35 billion in the fifth year, $105 billion over five years, the other study even more than that
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: and that's where you begin.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Well, Andrea, you didn't predicate that lack of economists' support for what I call a flexible freeze, because some good very good economists do support that concept.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I think where I differ with the Governor of Massachusetts, because I am optimistic.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: They jumped on me yesterday for being a little optimistic about the United States.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I am optimistic and I believe we can keep this longest expansion going.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I was not out there when that stock market dropped wringing my hands and saying this was the end of the world as some political leaders were, because it isn't the end of the world.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And what we have to do is restrain the growth of spending.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we are doing a better job of it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The American working man and woman are not taxed too little.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The Federal Government continues to spend too much.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: More so you than me.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: No, but you got to go back to what social security was when it was created.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It wasn't created as a welfare program.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It wasn't created that is it was created as a whole retirement or supplement to retirement program.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It wasn't created as a welfare program.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We came into office and the Social Security Trust Fund was in great jeopardy and the President took the leadership working with the Democrats and the Republicans in Congress some tough calls were made and the Social Security Trust Fund was put back into sound, solvent condition.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So, I don't want to fool around with it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It always works that way.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: In precinct politics in Texas and I've seen it at the national level.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We have made the Social Security Trust Fund sound.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And it is going to be operating at surpluses and I don't want the liberal Democratic Congress to spend out of that Social Security Trust Fund or go and take the money out for some other purpose.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I will not go in there and suggest changes in Social Security.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I am going to keep that Social Security Trust Fund sound and keep our commitment to the elderly and maybe down the line, maybe when you get two decades or one into the next century, you're going to have to take another look at it, but not now.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Keep the trust with the older men and women of this country.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Andrea, I don't know which George Bush I'm listening to.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: George Bush, a few years ago, said that Social Security was basically a welfare system.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And in 1985, he flew back from the West Coast to cut that COLA.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I voted against that at the National Governors Association.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We won a majority, we didn't win the two-thirds that was necessary nor to pass that resolution, George.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But everybody knew what we were doing and I've opposed that.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The reason that we raise concerns, not just in election years, but every year, because Republicans, once they're elected and start cutting.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: You did it in 1985.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The Administration tried to do it repeatedly, repeatedly in 81 82.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And I'm sure you'll try to do it again.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Because there's no way you can finance what you want to spend.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: There's no way you can pay for that five year, $40 billion tax cut for the rich and still buy all those weapons systems you want to buy unless you raid the Social Security Trust Fund.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: One I don't have a list yet.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I feel pretty confident tonight, but not that confident.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Secondly, I don't have any litmus test.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But what I would do is appoint people to the Federal Bench that will not legislate from the Bench, who will interpret the Constitution.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I do not want to see us go to again and Fm using this word advisedly a liberal majority that is going to legislate from the Bench.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: They don't like the use of the word, but may I remind his strong supporters that only last year in the primary, to capture that Democratic nomination, he said, "I am a progressive liberal Democrat."
Speaker: George Bush

Text: There is no litmus test on any issue.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: If the Vice President of the United States thinks that Robert Bork was an outstanding appointment (Cheers and Applause)
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: that is a very good reason for voting for Mike Dukakis and Lloyd Bentsen on the 8th of November.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And I think the Vice President supported the Bork nomination.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: You know, Mr. Bush has never appointed a judge.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I've appointed over 130, so I have a record.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And I'm very proud of it.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I don't ask people whether they're Republicans or Democrats.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I've appointed prosecutors, I've appointed defenders.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I don't appoint people I think are liberal or people who think - who I think are conservative.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I appoint people of independence and integrity and intelligence, people who will be a credit to the Bench.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And those are the standards that I will use in nominating people to the Supreme Court of the United States.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: These appointments are for life.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: These appointments are for life.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And when the Vice President talks about liberals on the Bench, I wonder who he's talking about?
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Is he talking about a former Governor of the State of California, who is a former prosecutor, a Republican named Earl Warren, because I think Chief Justice Earl Warren was an outstanding Chief Justice and I think most Americans do too.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Andrea, why do people who want balanced budgets or to bring the deficit down always go to those programs which tend to benefit people of very modest means?
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And yet Mr. Bush tried to cut their cost of living increase in 1985.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Medicare is not getting less expensive; medical care for the elderly is getting more expensive, with greater deductibles, with fewer benefits, the kinds of things we've had under this Administration that have cut and chopped and reduced the kind of benefits that one gets under Medicare.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Yes, we now have catastrophic health insurance, but it's going to cost, and that's going to be an additional burden on elderly citizens.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It had bipartisan support; it should have had bipartisan support.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But I suggest that we understand that those are going to be additional costs on senior citizens across this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: So I'm not going to begin, and I'm not going to go to entitlements as a means for cutting that deficit when we're spending billions on something like Star Wars, when we're spending billions on other weapon systems which apparently the Vice President wants to keep in his back pocket or some place, but which, if we continue to spend billions on them, will force us to cut Social Security, to cut Medicare, to cut these basic entitlements to people of very, very modest means.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Now there are some things we can do to help people who currently do get entitlements to get off public assistance.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I talked in our first debate about the possibilities of helping millions and millions of welfare families to get off of welfare, and I'm proud to say that we finally have a welfare reform bill And the Ruby Samsons and Dan Lawsons, hundreds of thousands of welfare mothers in this country and in my state and across the country who today are working and earning are examples of what can happen when you provide training to those welfare mothers, some daycare for their children so that those mothers can go into a training program and get a decent job.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: That's the way you bring a deficit down and help to improve the quality of life for people at the same time.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think I've addressed it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But let me simply say for the record, I did not vote to cut COLAs.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I voted the same way that he did three months before in a national governors' conference.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And he said at that time, in a quote, and this is a paraphrase, a freeze, that's easy.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So I don't believe that we need to do what you've suggested here.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I've said that I'm going to keep this Social Security entitlement, to keep that trust fund sound.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I have made some good sound proposals.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But again, we have a big difference on child care, for example.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You see, I want the families to have the choice.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't want to see the Federal Government licensing grandmothers.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't want to see the Federal Government saying to communities, well, you can't do this any more.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want flexibility, and I do you know, these people laugh about the thousand points of light.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I want to keep it alive in child care and in other entitlements.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That is absolutely not true.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: That is absolutely not true.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It had nothing to do with the debate on Social Security.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It had to do with the discussion we had had the previous day on the overall question of reducing the budget.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: No, and I have to (Applause)
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Now, we're not a parliamentary body, the National Governors Association.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: If you don't get a two-thirds, then your resolution doesn't pass.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But everybody knew that those of us who voted against the freezing of COLAs did so, we did so emphatically.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And I never made that statement; never would.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The point is that as we look at this nation's future, and we have two very different visions of this future.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I want to move ahead.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The Vice President talks about a thousand points of light.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I'm interested in 240 million points of light.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I'm interested in 240 million citizens in this country who share in the American dream, all of them in every part of this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The Vice President did call Social Security a few years ago basically or largely a welfare program.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It's something that we pay into now so that we will have a secure retirement, and our parents and grandparents will have a secure retirement.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: It's a very sacred contract, and I believe in it.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: So that's not where we ought to go.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: There are plenty of places to cut.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: There's lots we can do in the Pentagon where dishonest contractors have been lining their pockets at the expense of the American taxpayer.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: There are we certainly ought to be able to
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Give our farm families a decent income with spending $20to $25 billion a year on farm subsidies, and I'm sure we can do that.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: That's where we ought to go, and those are the programs we ought to review first.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Well, let me take him up on this question of farm subsidies.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We have a fundamental difference, approach on agriculture.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He favors this supply maintenance or production controls.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He's been out in the state saying that, in Midwestern states.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think the farm bill that he criticizes was good legislation, outstanding legislation.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I believe the answer to the agricultural economy is not to get the government further involved, but to do what I'm suggesting.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: In the first place, never go back to that Democratic grain embargo, that liberal Democrat grain embargo that knocked the markets right out from under us and made Mr. Gorbachev say to me when I was here, how do I know you're reliable suppliers?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We never should go back to that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we ought to expand our markets abroad.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We ought to have rural enterprise zones.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But let's not go back and keep assailing a farm bill that passed with overwhelming Democrat and Republican support.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The farm payments are going down because the agricultural economy is coming back.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: 90 percent reductions in lead since I chaired that regulatory task force; 90 percent.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It's almost you remember that expression, get the lead out?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But what I'm not for what I'm not for is measuring it the way that the Democratic Congress does.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We sent up a good bill on clean water, a sound bill on clean water.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But the only way you can express your love for clean water is to double the appropriations for clean water, and then rant against the deficit.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I am for clean water.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I've been an outdoorsman and a sportsman all my life.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I've been to these national parks.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I led for the Earl Wallop bill or formerly Dingell-Johnson.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I headed the task force when I was a member of the Congress way back in the late '60s on these kinds of things, on the Republican side.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so I refuse to measure one's commitment as to whether you're going to double the spending.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That is the same old argument that's gotten us into trouble on the deficit side.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'm not going to go down there and try to dump the sludge from Massachusetts off the beaches off of New Jersey.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Can you add five seconds, Bernie, out of fairness?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Come on, give me five.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I mean, this guy, this is too much.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I'm not going to do that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I believe in the President's commission on outdoors.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I'll do a good job, because I am committed.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Margaret, I'm not sure I can get all of this in in one minute.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: George, we have supply management today under the 1985 bill.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Secondly, if you were so opposed to the grain embargo, why did you ask the godfather of the grain embargo to be one of your top foreign policy advisers?
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I'm against the grain embargo; it was a mistake.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I'm also against the pipeline embargo, which you folks attempted to impose.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: That was a mistake as well, and it cost thousands of jobs for American workers in the Midwest and all over the United States of America.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Margaret, once again, I don't know which George Bush I'm talking about here or looking at.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The George Bush who was the charter member of the environmental wrecking crew that went to Washington in the early '80s and did a job on the EPA, or the one we've been seeing and listening to the past two or three months.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But let me say this, because he spent millions and millions of dollars of advertising on the subject of Boston Harbor.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: George, Boston Harbor was polluted for 100 years.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I'm the first governor to clean it up.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We've been cleaning it up for four years.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We passed landmark legislation in '84.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: You did everything you could to kill the Clean Water Act
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And those grants which make it possible for states and local communities to clean up rivers and harbors and streams.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The American people are up to here with debates.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: They had thirty of them; we had seven of them.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Now we've got three of them.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I am going to carry this election debate all across this country in the last whatever remains of the last three and a half weeks, or whatever we have and the answer is no; I am not going to have any more debates, we don't need any more debates.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I've spelled out my position.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But take a look at the Democratic convention take a look at it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Do you remember the Senator from Boston chanting out there and the ridicule factor from that lady from Texas that was on there; I mean, come on, this was just outrageous.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: If you could accept a little criticism, I went all across central Illinois and spoke about agricultural issues, about seven stops.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We had some fun Crystal Gayle and Loretta Lynn with us, and they got up and sang, went to little towns and I talked agriculture.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And not one thing did I see, with respect, on your network about my views on agriculture, and not one did I read in any newspaper.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Because you are so interested in a poll that might have been coming out, or because somebody had said something nasty about somebody else.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so I don't know what the answer is.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Somebody hit me and said Barry Goldwater said you ought to talk on issues more.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: How can Barry Goldwater sitting in Arizona know whether I'm talking on the issues or not when we put out position paper after position paper, he puts out position paper after position paper; and we see this much about it, because everyone else is fascinated with polls and who's up or down today and who's going to be up or down tomorrow.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So I think we can all share, with respect, in the fact that maybe the message is not getting out.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: There will be no more debates.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I can understand, after the vice presidential debate, why Mr. Bush would want no more debates.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: (Laughter, boos) That's my five seconds.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Andrea, I think we both have a responsibility to try to address the issues.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Yes, we have fundamental differences.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think a great many of them have come out today.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And I think if we get rid of the labels--and I'm not keeping count, but I think Mr. Bush has used the label "liberal" at least ten times if I had a dollar, George, for every time you used that label, I'd qualify for one of those tax breaks for the rich that you want to give away.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I want to move forward, I want this nation to move forward.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I am concerned about the fact that 10 percent of our manufacturing and 20 percent of our banking and nearly half of the real estate in the city of Los Angeles are in the hands of foreign investors.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I am concerned about what that does to our future.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I'm concerned about the fact that so many of our securities are in the hands of foreign banks because of these massive deficits.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think we ought to be looking at modernization, I think we ought to be exploring less expensive ways to get it on land, and we ought to make sure that we have an effective and strong and credible nuclear deterrent.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And every defense expert I know, including people in the Pentagon itself, will tell you that given the level of defense spending and the level of defense appropriations which the Congress has now approved and the president has signed, there's no way that you can do all of these things and do them well.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: That's why tough choices will be required, choices I am prepared to make, Mr. Bush is not prepared to make.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But, Andrea, I think we can go far beyond this as well, because we have opportunities now step-by-step to bring down the level of strategic weapons, get a test ban treaty, negotiate those conventional force reductions.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I would challenge Mr. Gorbachev to join with us in limiting in eliminating regional conflict in the Middle East, in Central America.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: The democratic leaders of Central and Latin America want to work with us.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I've met with them, I know them, I've spent time in South America-speak the language, so does Senator Bentsen.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We want to work with them and build a new relationship, and they with us.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But not a one of those key democratic leaders support our policy in Central America.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Those are the kinds of priorities for national security and for foreign policy that I want to pursue Mr. Bush and I have major differences on these issues and I hope very much to be president and pursue them.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: In terms of regional tensions, we have now gotten the attention of the Soviet Union.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And the reason we've gotten it is because they see us now as unwilling to make the very kinds of unilateral cuts that have been called for and to go for the discredited freeze.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: My opponent had trouble, criticized us, on our policy in Angola.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It now looks, because of steady negotiation, that we may have an agreement that will remove the Cubans from Angola.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We see the Russians coming out of Afghanistan.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That wouldn't have stopped if we hadn't been willing wouldn't have even started, the Soviets coming out, if we hadn't even been willing to support the freedom fighters there.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And the policy in Central America, regrettably, has failed because the Congress has been unwilling to support those who have been fighting for freedom.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Those Sandinistas came in and betrayed the trust of the revolution; they said it was about democracy, and they have done nothing other than solidify their Marxist domination over that country.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, it's a great concern of mine and I think of all Americans, and perhaps the vice president can tell us what's been going on.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: This is another example of misplaced priorities.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: An administration which wants to billions on weapons systems that we don't need and can't afford, and now confronts us with a very serious problem, and plants that are supposed to be producing tritium and plutonium and providing the necessary materials for existing weapons.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Yes, if we don't do something about it, we may find ourselves unilaterally, if I may use that term, dismantling some of these weapons.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Who's been managing this system?
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Why have there been these safety violations?
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Why are these plants being closed down?
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I don't know what the latest cost estimates are, but it's going to be in the range of 25, 50, 75, $100 billion.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Now, somebody has to bear the responsibility for this.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And that's something which will be a priority of ours in the new administration because without it, we cannot have the effective and strong and credible nuclear deterrent we must have.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: That is the closest I have ever heard the Governor of Massachusetts come to support anything having to do with nuclear, that's about as close as I've ever heard him Yes, this Savannah River plant needs to be made more safe.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Will he join me in suggesting that we may need another plant?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I believe that the more dependent we become on foreign oil, the less our national security is enhanced.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And therefore, I've made some proposals to strengthen the domestic oil industry by more incentive going in to look for, and find, and produce oil; made some incentives in terms of secondary and tertiary production.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But we're going to have to use more gas, more coal and more safe nuclear power for our energy base.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: and must do what he's talking about now.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Yes, and I'll apply it to Congress too.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Because I think you see, I am one who I get kidded by being a little old fashioned on these things, but I do believe in public service.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I don't think anybody has a call on people in their Administrations going astray.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: His chief education adviser is in jail He's in jail because he betrayed the public trust.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And yet this man, the governor, equated the President to a rotting fish.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He said that a fish rots from the head down as he was going after Ed Meese.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Look, we need the highest possible ethical standards.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I will have an ethical office in the White House that will be under the President's personal concern.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I hope I will do a good job as one who has had a relatively clean record with no conflicts of interest in his own public life, as has the Governor, to exhort young people to get into public service.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But there is no corner on this sleaze factor, believe me.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And it's a disgrace, and I will do my level best to clean it up, recognizing that you can't legislate morality.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I do believe that with my record in Congress, having led the new Congressmen to a code of ethics through major main emphasis on it in full disclosure, that I've got a good record.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And there are more, if you want to talk about percentage appointments, more Members of Congress who have been under investigation percentage-wise that people in the executive branch.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so it isn't one and state governments have had a tough time.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: His some of his college presidents aren't exactly holier than thou.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So let's not be throwing stones about it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Let's say, this isn't Democrat or Republican, and it isn't liberal or conservative.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Let's vow to work together to do something about it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I would agree that integrity is not a Republican or a Democratic issue; it's an American issue.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But here again, I don't know which George Bush I'm listening to.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Wasn't this the George Bush that supported Mr. Meese?
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Called James Watt an excellent Secretary of the Interior?
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Provided support for some of these people, supported the nomination of Robert Bork to the Supreme Court of the United States.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We've had dozens we've had dozens and dozens of officials in this Administration who have left under a cloud, who have left with the special prosecutor in their arm, have been indicted, convicted.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: This isn't the kind of Administration we need.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And one of the reasons our selection of a running mate is so important, it is such a test of the kinds of standards we'll set, is because it tells the American people in advance of the election just what kind of people we're looking for.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Mr. Bush picked Dan Quayle.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I think that says a great deal to the American people about the standards we'll set and the quality of the people that we will pick to serve in our Administration.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis
