Text: 28 years ago, as a young man just graduated from law school, I came to this city, came clear across the country, to watch John Kennedy be nominated for the presidency of the United States, right here in Los Angeles.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: I never dreamed that some day I would win that nomination and be my party's nominee for president.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: That's why I'm proud and grateful to be a citizen of this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: 26 days from today you and millions of Americans will choose two people to lead us into the future as president and vice president of the United States.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Our opponents say, things are okay.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: They say we should be satisfied.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: But I don't think we can be satisfied when we're spending $150 billion a year in interest alone on the national debt, much of it going to foreign bankers; or when 25 percent of our high school students are dropping out of school; or when we have 2-1/2 million of our fellow citizens, a third of them veterans, who are homeless and living on streets and in doorways in this country, when Mr. Bush's prescription for our economic future is another tax giveaway to the rich.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We can do better than that.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Not working with government alone, but all of us working together.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Lloyd Bentsen and I are optimists, and so are the American people.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And we ask you for our hand for your hands and your hearts, and your votes on the 8th of November so we can move forward in the future.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Kitty and I are very grateful to all of you for the warmth and the hospitality that you've given to us in your homes and communities all across this country.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: We love you, and we're grateful to you for everything that you've given to us.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: And we hope that we'll be serving you in the White House in January of 1989.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: Thank you, and God bless you.
Speaker: Michael Dukakis

Text: So let me repeat, I do have respect for my opponent, for his family, for the justifiable pride he takes in his heritage.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But we have enormous differences.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to hold the line on taxes, and keep this the longest expansion in modern history going until everybody in America benefits.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Because I mean it when I say I want a kinder and gentler nation.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And by that I want to have child care where the families, the parents, have control.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to keep our neighborhoods much, much better in terms of anti-crime, and that's why I would appoint judges that have a little more sympathy for the victims of crime and a little less for the criminals.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That's why I do feel if some police officer is gunned down that the death penalty is required.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to help those with disabilities fit into the mainstream.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: There is much to be done.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: This election is about big things.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And perhaps the biggest is world peace.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I ask you to consider the experience I have had in working with a President who has revolutionized the situation around the world.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we have now achieved an historic arms control agreement.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to build on that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'd love to be able to say to my grandchildren, four years after my first term, I'd like to say, your grandfather, working with the leaders of the Soviet Union, working with the leaders of Europe, was able to ban chemical and biological weapons from the face of the earth.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Lincoln called this country the last best hope of man on earth.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And he was right then, and we still are the last best hope of man on earth.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I will be a good president.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Thank you very, very much.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: First of all is to recognize a tremendous economic strength in this country and to set the putting to - back to work of our people as a top priority.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is uh - an effort that ought to be done primarily by strong leadership in the White House, the inspiration of our people, the tapping of uh - business, agriculture, industry, labor and government at all levels to work on this uh project.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We'll never have uh - an end to the inflationary spiral, and we'll never have a balanced budget until we get our people back to work.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: There are several things that can be done specifically that are not now being done.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: First of all, to channel research and development funds into areas that will provide uh large numbers of jobs.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Secondly, we need to have a commitment in the uh private sector uh - to cooperate with government in matters like housing.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Here a very small investment of taxpayer's money - in the housing field can bring large numbers of extra jobs, and the guarantee of mortgage loans, and the uh - putting forward of uh - two-0-two programs for housing for older people and so forth to cut down the roughly 20 percent unemployment that now exists in the - in the construction industry.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Another thing is to deal with our - uh needs in the central cities, where the unemployment rate is extremely high: sometimes among minority groups, or those who don't speak English, or who're black, or young people, or - 40 percent of the employment.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Here a CCC type program would be appropriate to channel money into the ah - cha- in - in into the sharing with the private sector and also local and state governments to employ young people who are now out of work.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Another very important - uh aspect of our - uh economy would be to increase production in every way possible, uh to hold down - uh taxes on individuals, and to uh shift the tax burdens onto those who have avoided paying taxes in the past.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: These uh - kinds of specific things, uh none of which are being done now, would be a great help in - in reducing uh unemployment.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: There is uh - uh an additional factor that needs to be done and covered very - very succinctly, and that is, to make sure that we have a good relationship between management - business on the one hand, and labor, on the other.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In a > Transfer interrupted!
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: ery high, we might channel specific uh targeted job - job - uh opportunities by paying part of the salary of unemployed people - uh and also sharing with uh - local governments the uh - payment of salaries which would uh - let us cut down the unemployment rate much lower, before we hit the inflationary level.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But I believe that by the end of the first four years of uh - of the next term we could have the unemployment down to 3 percent adult unemployment, which is about uh - 4 to 4 and a half percent overall uh controlled inflation rate and have a uh balance of growth of about - uh 4 to 6 percent, around 5 percent which would give us a balanced budget.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Yes, in unemployment that is likely to create additional pressure on prices, how willing are you to consider an incomes policy, in other words, wage and price controls?
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Well - we now have such uh - a low utilization of uh - our productive capacity - uh about 73 percent; I think it's about the lowest since the Great Depression years - and such a high unemployment rate now - uh 7.9 percent - that - uh we have a long way to go in getting people to work before we have the inflationary pressures.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I think this would uh - this would be uh easy to accomplish, to get jobs down, without having strong in- inflationary pressures that - that would be necessary.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I would not favor the uh - payment of uh - of a given fixed income to people unless they are not able to work.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But with tax incentives for the low-income groups we could build up their uh - income levels uh - above the poverty level and not uh make welfare more uh - profitable than - than work.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I don't believe that uh that Mr. Carter's been any more specific in this case than he has been on many other instances.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I notice particularly that he didn't endorse the Humphrey-Hawkins bill which he has on occasions and which is included as a part of the Democratic platform.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: That legislation uh allegedly would help our unemployment, but uh - we all know that it would've controlled our economy, it would've added uh - ten to thirty billion dollars each year in additional expenditures by the Federal Government.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It would've called for export controls on agricultural products In my judgment the best way to get jobs is to uh - expand the private sector, where five out of six jobs today exist in our economy.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We can do that by reducing Federal taxes as I proposed uh - about a year ago when I called for a tax reduction of $28 billion - three-quarters of it to go to private uh taxpayers and uh one-quarter to the business sector.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We could add to jobs in the major metropolitan areas by a proposal that I recommended that would give tax incentives to business to move into the inner city and to expand or to build new plants so that they would take a plant, or expand a plant where people are, and people are currently unemployed.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We could uh - also uh - help our youths with some of the proposals that uh - would give to young people an opportunity to work and learn at the same time just like we give money to young people who are going to college.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: At the time, Mr. Gannon, that I made the recommendation for a $28 billion tax cut - three-quarters of it to go to individual taxpayers and 25 percent to American business.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I said at the time that we had to hold the lid an federal spending, that for every dollar of a tax reduction we had to have an equal reduction in federal expenditures - a one-for-one proposition.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And I recommended that to the Congress with a budget ceiling of three hundred and ninety-five billion dollars, and that would have permitted us to have a $25 billion tax reduction.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In my tax reduction program for middle-income taxpayers, I recommended that the Congress increase personal exemptions from seven hundred and fifty dollars per person to one thousand dollars per person.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: That would mean, of course, that for a family of four that that family would have a thousand dollars more personal exemption - money that they could spend for their own purposes, money that the government wouldn't have to spend.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But if we keep the lid on federal spending, which I think we can - with the help of the Congress, we can justify fully a $28 billion tax reduction.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In the budget that I submitted to the Congress in January this year, I re- recommended a 50 percent cutback in the rate of growth of federal spending.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: For the last ten years the budget of the United States has grown from uh - about 11 percent per year.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We can't afford that kind of growth in federal spending.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And in the budget that I recommended we cut it in half - a growth rate of 5 to 5 and one-half percent.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: With that kind of limitation, on federal spending, we can fully justify the tax reductions that I have proposed.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And it seems to me with the stimulant of more money in the hands of the taxpayers, and with more money in the hands of business to expand, to modernize, to provide more jobs, our economy stimulated so that we'll get more revenue and we'll have a more prosperous economy.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: That tax bill does not entirely meet the criteria that I established.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I think the Congress should have uh - added another $10 billion reduction in personal income taxes, including the increase of personal exemptions from seven hundred and fifty to a thousand dollars.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And Congress could have done that if the budget committees of the Congress, and the Congress as a whole, had not increased the spending that I recommended in the budget.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I'm sure that you know that in the resolutions passed by the Congress, that have added about $17 billion in more spending, by the Congress over the budget that I recommended.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: So I would prefer in that tax bill to have an additional tax cut and a further limitation on federal spending.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now this tax bill - that hasn't reached the White House yet, but is expected in a day or two - it's about fifteen hundred pages.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It has some good provisions in it.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It has - uh left out some that I have recommended, unfortunately.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: On the other hand, uh when you have a bill of that magnitude, with - tho- those many provisions, a president has to sit and decide if there's more good than bad.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And from the a- analysis that I've made so far, it seems to me that that tax bill does uh - justify my signature and my approval.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Well, Mr. Ford is - is uh changing uh considerably his previous philosophy.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The present tax structure is a disgrace to this country; it's just a welfare program for the rich.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: As a matter of fact, uh - 25 percent of the total tax deductions, go for only 1 percent of the richest people in this country, and over 50 percent of the tax uh credits go for the 14 percent of the richest people in this country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In uh - January of 1975 he asked for a tax change: a $5.6 billion increase on low-and-middle-income private individuals, a six and a half billion dollar decrease on the corporations and the special interests.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In uh - December of uh - 1975 he vetoed the roughly 18 to 20 billion dollar uh tax-reduction bill that had been passed by the Congress, and then he came back later on in January of this year and he did advocate a $10 billion tax reduction, but it would be offset by a $6 billion increase this coming January in deductions for Social Security payments and for unemployment compensation.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The whole philosophy of the Republican party, including uh - my opponent, has been to pile on taxes on low-income people to take 'em off on the corporations.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: As a matter fact, in - sin- since the late sixties when Mr. Nixon took office, we've had a reduction in uh - in the percentage of taxes paid by corporations from 30 percent down to about 20 percent.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've had an increase in taxes paid by individuals, payroll taxes, from14 Percent up to 20 percent.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And this is what the Republicans have done to us.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Well, as a matter of fact there is.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: If we assume the ah - uh - a rate of growth of our economy, equivalent to what it was during President Johnson, President Kennedy, even before the - the - the - uh wa uh - Vietnese- namese War, and if we assume that at the end of the four-year period we can cut our unemployment rate down to 4 to 4 and a half percent - under those circumstances, even assuming no elimination of unnecessary programs and assuming an increase in the ad- in the allotment of money to finance programs, increasing as the inflation rate does - my economic projections, I think confirmed by the House uh - and the Senate committees, have been with the $60 billion extra amount of money that can be spent in fiscal year '81 which will be the last year of this next term.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Within that sixty-billion dollars increase there would be fit the programs that I promised the American people.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I might say too, that - that if we see that these goals cannot be reached - and I believe they're reasonable goals - then I would cut back on the rate of implement- implementation of new programs in order to accommodate a balanced budget by fiscal year '81 which is the last year of the next term.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I believe that we ought to have a balanced budget during normal economic circumstances.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And uh - these projections have been very carefully made.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And if they should be in error slightly on the down side, then I'll phase in the programs that we've uh - advocated, more slowly.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Well, the uh - the assumption that - that you uh - have described as different is in the rate of growth of our economy.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And uh - with that uh - in that framework would befit the - any improvements in the programs.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Now this does not include uh - any uh - uh extra control over uh unnecessary spending, the weeding out of obsolete or obsolescent programs.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Uh - we'll have uh - a safety version built in with complete reorganization of the executive branch of government which I am pledged to do.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The present bureaucratic structure of the - of the Federal Government is a mess.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And if I'm elected president that's gonna be a top priority of mine to completely revise the structure of the federal government, to make it economical, efficient, purposeful and manageable for a change.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And also, I'm going to institute zero-based budgeting which I used four years in Georgia, which uh - assesses every program every year, and eliminates those programs that are obsolete or obsolescent.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But with these projections, we will have a balanced budget by fiscal year 1981, if I'm elected president.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Keep my promises to the American people.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And it's just predicated on very modest, but I think accurate, projections of employment increases and uh - a growth in our national economy equal to what was experienced under Kennedy, Johnson, before the Vietnam War.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: If it is uh true that there will be a $60 billion surplus by fiscal year 1981, rather than spend that money for all the new programs that Governor Carter recommends and endorses, and which are included in the Democratic platform, I think the American taxpayer ought to get an additional tax break - a tax reduction of that magnitude.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I feel that the taxpayers are the ones that need the relief: I don't think we should add additional programs of the magnitude that Governor Carter talks about.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It seems to me that our tax structure today has rates that are too high.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But I am uh - very glad to point out that since 1969, during a Republican administrations, we have had ten million people taken off of the tax rolls at the lower end of the taxpayer area.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And at the same time, assuming that I sign the tax bill that was mentioned by Mr. Gannon, we will in the last two tax bills have increased the minimum tax on all wealthy taxpayers.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And I believe that by eliminating ten million taxpayers in the last uh eight years, and by putting a heavier tax burden on those in the higher tax brackets, plus the other actions that've been taken uh - we can give taxpayers adequate tax relief.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now it seems to me that uh - as we look at the recommendations of the budget committees and our own projections, there isn't going to be any $60 billion dividend.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I've heard of those dividends in the past; it always happens.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We expected one at the time of the Vietnam War, but it was used up before we ever ended the war and taxpayers never got the adequate relief they deserved.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The amnesty program that I recommended in Chicago in September of 1974 would give to all draft evaders and - uh military deserters the opportunity to earn their uh - good record back.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: About fourteen to fifteen thousand did take advantage of that program.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We gave them ample time.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I am against- an across-the-board pardon of draft evaders or military deserters.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now in the case of Mr. Nixon, the reason the - the pardon was given, was that, when I took office this country was in a very, very divided condition.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: There was hatred, there was divisiveness - uh people had lost faith in their government in many, many respects.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Mr. Nixon resigned, and I became president.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It seemed to me that if I was to uh adequately and effectively handle the problems of high inflation, a growing recession, the uh - involvement of the United States still in Vietnam that I had to give a hundred percent of my time to those two major problems.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The first President out of thirty-eight that ever resigned from public office under pressure.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: So when you look at the penalty that he paid, and when you analyze the requirements that I had - to spend all of my time working on the economy, which was in trouble, that I inherited; working on our problems in Southeast Asia - which were still plaguing us - it seemed to me that Mr. Nixon had been penalized enough by his resignation in disgrace and the need, and necessity for me to concentrate on the problems of the country fully justified the action that I took.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Well, Mr. Carter has uh indicated that uh - he would give a blanket pardon to all uh - draft evaders.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I do not agree with that point of view.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I gave, in September of 1974, an opportunity for all draft evaders, all deserters, to come in voluntarily, clear their records by earning an opportunity to restore their good citizenship.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I think we gave them a good opportunity - we're - I don't think we should go any further.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Well I think it's uh... very difficult for President Ford to uh - explain the difference between the pardon of President Nixon and - and uh - his attitude toward those who violated the draft laws.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: As a matter of fact - now- I don't advocate amnesty; I advocate pardon.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: There's a difference in my opinion - uh and in accordance with the ruling of the Supreme Court and accordance with the definition in the dictionary.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Amnesty means that - that you uh - that what you did was right.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Pardon means that what you did, whether it's right or wrong, you're forgiven for it.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I do advocate a pardon for - for draft evaders.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think it's accurate to say that in uh - two years ago when Mr. Nixon - Mr. Ford put in this uh amnesty that three times as many deserters were uh - excused as were - as were the uh - the ones who evaded the draft.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've got a - a sharp distinction drawn between white collar crime - the - the - the big shots who are rich, who are influential uh very seldom go to jail; those who are poor and - and who have uh no influence - uh quite often are the ones who are punished.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And - and the whole uh subject of crime is one that concerns our people very much, and I believe that the fairness of it is - is what - uh - is a - is a major problem that addresses our - our leader and this is something that hasn't been addressed adequately by - by this administration.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But I - I hope to have a complete uh responsibility on my shoulders to help bring about a - a fair uh - criminal justice system and also to - to bring about uh - an end to the - to the divise- divisiveness that has occurred in our country uh as a result of the Vietnam War.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Well, I've been through this before, Mr. Gannon, as the governor of Georgia.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: When I took aver we had uh a bureaucratic mess, like we have in Washington now, and we had three hundred agencies, departments, bureaus, commissions - uh some uh - fully budgeted, some not, but all having responsibility to carry out that was in conflict.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And we cut those three hundred - uh agencies and so forth down substantially.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We eliminated two hundred and seventy-eight of them.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We set up a simple structure of government that could be administrated fairly and it was a - a tremendous success.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It hasn't been undone since I was there.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It resulted also in an ability to reshape our court system, our prison system, our education system, our mental health programs and - and a clear assignment of responsibility and - and authority and also to have uh our people once again understanding control our government.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I intend to do the same thing if I'm elected president.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: When I get to Washington, coming in as an outsider, one of the major responsibilities that - that I will have on my shoulder is a complete reorganization of the - of the executive branch of government.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We now have uh - a greatly expanded White House staff.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: When Mr. Nixon went in office, for instance, we had three and a half million dollars spent on - on the White House and its staff.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: That has escalated now to sixteen and a half million dollars, in the last uh Republican administration.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This needs to be changed.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We also need to have a great reduction in agencies and programs.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: For instance, we now have uh - in the health area three hundred and two different programs administered by eleven major departments and agencies, sixty other advisory commissions responsible for this.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Medicaid's in one agency; Medicare is in a different one.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The - the check on the quality of health care is in a different one.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: None of them uh are responsible for health care itself.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This makes it almost impossible for us to have a good health program.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We have uh - just advocated uh - this past week a consolidation of the responsibilities for energy.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Our country now has no comprehensive energy program or policy.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We have twenty different agencies in the federal government responsible for the production, the regulation, the uh - information about energy, the conservation of energy, spread all over government.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is a - a gross waste of money, so tough, competent management of government, giving us a simple efficient purposeful and manageable government would be a great step forward and if I'm elected - and I intend to be - then it's gonna be done.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I can't say for sure that we would have fewer federal employees when I go out of office than when I come in.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It took me about three years to completely reorganize the Georgia government.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Also, we had a - a 2 percent increase in the number of employees the last year.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But it was a tremendous shift from administrative jobs into the delivery of services.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: For instance, we uh - completely revised our prison system.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We established eighty-four new mental health treatment centers.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And we shifted people out of administrative jobs into the field to deliver better services.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The same thing will be done uh - at the federal government level.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I - I accomplished this with s - substantial reductions in employees in some departments.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: For instance, in the Transportation Department uh we had uh - we cut back about 25 percent of the total number of employees.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In giving our people better mental health care, we increased the number of employees.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But the efficiency of it, the simplicity of it, the uh ability of people to understand their own government and control it was a - was a uh - substantial benefit derived from complete reorganization.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: If we don't, the bureaucratic mess is going to continue.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: There's no way for our people now to understand what their government is.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: There's no way to get the answer to a question.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: When you come to Washington to try to - as a governor - to try to begin a new program for your people, like uh the treatment of drug addicts, I found there were thirteen different federal agencies that I had to go to, to manage the uh drug treatment program.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is the kind of change that would be made.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And uh - it would be of - of tremendous benefit in long-range planning, in tight budgeting, uh saving the taxpayers' money, making the government more efficient, cutting down on bureaucratic waste, having a clear delineation of authority and responsibility of employees, and giving our people a better chance to understand and control their government.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think the record should show, Mr. Newman, that uh - the Bureau of Census - we checked it just yesterday - indicates that uh - in the four years that uh - Governor Carter was governor of the state of Georgia, uh - expenditures by the government went up over 50 percent Uh - employees of the government in Georgia during his term of office went up over 25 percent; and the figures also show that the uh, uh - bonded indebtedness of the state of Georgia during his governorship went up over 20 percent.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And there was some very interesting testimony given by Governor Carter's successor, Governor Busby, before a Senate committee a few uh - months ago on how he found the Medicaid program when he came into office following Governor Carter.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: He testified, and these are his words - the present governor of Georgia - he says he found the Medicaid program in Georgia in shambles.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now let me talk about what we've done in the White House as far as federal employees are concerned The first order that I issued after I became president was to cut or eliminate the prospective forty-thousand increase in federal employees that had been scheduled by my predecessor.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And in the term that I've been president - some two years - we have reduced federal employment by eleven thousand.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In the White House staff itself, when I became president, we had roughly five hundred and forty employees.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We now have about four hundred and eighty-five employees, so we've made a rather significant reduction in the number of employees on the White House staff working for the president.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: So I think our record of cutting back employees, plus the failure on the part of the Governor's programs to actually save employment in Georgia, shows which is the better plan.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Well, in the uh - last two years, as I indicated before, we had a very tough time.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We were faced with uh - heavy inflation, over 12 percent; we were faced with substantial unemployment.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But in the last uh - twenty-four months we've turned the economy around and we've brought inflation down to under 6 percent, and we have reduced the uh - well, we have added employment of about four million in the last seventeen months to the point where we have eighty-eight million people working in America today - the most in the history of the country.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The net result is we are going to have some improvement in our receipts.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And I think we'll have some decrease in our disbursements.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We expect to have a lower deficit in fiscal year 1978.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We feel that with this improvement in the economy; we feel with more receipts and fewer disbursements we can in a moderate way increase, as I recommended, over the next ten years a new parks program that would cast a billion and a half dollars, doubling our national park system.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We have recommended that in the h- housing program we can reduce down payments and moderate monthly payments.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But that doesn't cost any more as far as the federal treasury is concerned.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We believe that we can uh do a better job in the area of crime, but that requires a tougher sentencing, mandatory certain prison sentences for those who violate our criminal laws.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We - uh believe that uh you can revise the federal criminal code, which has not been revised in a good many years.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: That doesn't cost any more money.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We believe that you can uhh - do something more effectively with a moderate increase in money in the drug abuse program.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We feel that uh - in education we can have a slight increase - not a major increase.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It's my understanding that Governor Carter has indicated that uh - he approves of a $30 billion uh - expenditure by the federal government as far as education is concerned.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: At the present time we're spending roughly three billion five hundred million dollars.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I don't know where that money would come from.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But as we look at the quality-of-life programs - jobs, health, education, crime, recreation - we feel that as we move forward with a healthier economy, we can absorb the small necessary cost that will be required.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We feel that uh - with the programs that I have recommended, the additional $10 billion tax cut, with the moderate increases in the quality-of-life area, we can still have a balanced budget which I will submit to the Congress in January of 1978.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We won't wait one year or two years longer, as Governor Carter uh - indicates.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: As the economy improves, and it is improving, our gross national product this year will average about 6 percent increase over last year.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We will have the lower rate of inflation for the uh - calendar year this year - something slightly under 6 percent.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Employment will be up, revenues will be up.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now I cannot, and would not, endorse the kind of program that uh - Governor Carter recommends.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: He endorses the Democratic uh - platform which, as I read it, calls for approximately sixty additional programs.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We estimate that those programs would add a hundred billion dollars minimum and probably two hundred billion dollars - uhh maximum each year to the federal budget.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Those programs you cannot afford and give tax relief.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We feel that you can hold the line and restrain federal spending, give a tax reduction and still have a balanced budget by 1978.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Well, Mr. Ford takes the uh - same attitude that the Republicans always take.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In the last three months before an election, they're always for the programs that they always fight the other three-and-one-half years.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Uh - I remember when uh - Herbert Hoover was against uh - jobs for people.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I remember when Alf Landon was against Social Security and uh - later President Nixon, sixteen years ago, was telling the public that John Kennedy's proposals would bankrupt the country and would double the cost.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The best thing to do is to look at the record uh - of Mr. Ford's Administration and Mr. Nixon's before his.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Uh - we had last year a $65 billion deficit - the largest deficit in the history of our country - more of a deficit spending than we had in the entire eight-year period under President Johnson and President Kennedy.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've got five hundred thousand more Americans out of jobs today than were out of work three months ago and since Mr. Ford's been in office two years, we've had a 50 percent increase in unemployment from five million people out of work to two and a half million more people out of work and a total of seven and a half million.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've also got uh - a comparison between himself and Mr. Nixon.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: He's got four times the size of the deficits that Mr. Nixon even had himself.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This uh - talking about more people at work - uh is distorted because with a 14 percent increase in the cost of living in the last uh - two years, it means that - that women and young people have had to go to work when they didn't want to because their fathers didn't make enough to pay the increased cost of uh - food and uh housing and clothing.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We have uh - in this last uh two years alone a hundred and twenty billion dollars total deficits under President Ford and uh - at the same time we've had, in the last eight years, a doubling in the number of bankruptcies for small business: we've had a negative growth in our - in our national economy measured in real dollars.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is the kind of record that's there and talk about the future and a drastic change or conversion on the part of Mr. Ford as of last minute is one that just doesn't go.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think I know the - the uh capabilities and limitations of atomic power.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But the energy - uh policy of our nation is one that uh has not yet been established under this administration.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think almost every other developed nation in the world has an energy policy except us.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We have seen uh - the Federal Energy Agency established, for instance.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Uh - in the crisis of 1973 it was supposed to be a temporary agency, uh now it's permanent, it's enormous, it's growing every day.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think the Wall Street Journal uh reported not too long ago they have a hundred and twelve public relations experts working for the Federal Energy Agency to try to justify to the American people its own existence.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've got to have a - a firm way to handle the energy question.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The reorganization proposal that I have put forward is one uh first step.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In addition to that, we need to have - uh a realization that we've got uh about thirty-five years worth of oil left in the whole world.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We're gonna run out of oil.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: When Mr. Nixon made his famous uh speech on Operation Independence we were importing about 35 percent of our oil.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Now we've increased that amount 25 percent.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We now import about 44 percent of our oil.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We need to shift from oil to coal.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We need to concentrate our research and development effort on uh coal burning and extraction, with safer mines, but also it's clean burning.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We need to shift very strongly toward solar energy and have strict conservation measures.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And then as a last resort only, continue to use atomic power.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I would certainly uh - not cut out atomic power altogether.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We can't afford to give up that opportunity until later.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But to the extent that we continue to use atomic power, I would be responsible as president to make sure that the safety precautions were initiated and maintained.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: For instance, some that have been forgotten; we need to have the reactor core - below ground level, the entire power plant that uses atomic uh - power tightly sealed and a heavy - heavy vacuum maintained.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: There ought to be a standardized design.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: There ought to be a full-time uh - atomic energy specialist, independent of the power company in the control room, full time, twenty-four hours a day, to shut down a plant if an abnormality develops.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: These kinds of uh - procedures, along with evacuation procedures, adequate insurance, ought to be initiated.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: So, shift from oil to coal, emphasize research and development on coal use and also on solar power, strict conservation measures, not yield every time that the special interest groups uh - put pressure on the president like uh this administration has done, and use atomic energy only as a last resort with the strictest possible safety precautions.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: That's the best overall energy policy in the brief time we have to discuss it.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Some of the things that can be done about this is a change in the rate structure of electric power companies.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We uh - now encourage people to waste electricity, and uh - by giving uh - the lowest rates to the biggest users.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We don't do anything to cut down on peak load requirements.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We don't have an adequate requirement for the insulation of homes, for the efficiency of automobiles.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And whenever the uh - automobile manufacturers come forward and say they can't meet the uh - amendments that the Congress has put forward, this Republican administration has delayed the implementation dates.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In addition to that, we ought to have a - a shift toward the use of coal, particularly in the Appalachian regions where the coal is located.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: A lot of uh - very high quality, low-carbon coal, uh - low-sulfur coal is there, it's where our employment is needed.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Uh - this would - would help a great deal.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: So mandatory conservation measures - yes.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Encouragement by the president for people to uh voluntarily conserve - yes.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And also the private sector ought to be encouraged to - to bring forward to the public the benefits from efficiency.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: One bank in uh - Washington, fo- for instance, gives lower interest loans for people who adequately insulate their homes or who buy efficient automobiles.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And some major uh - uh - manufacturing companies, like Dow Chemical, have through uh - very effective efficiency mechanism cut down the use of energy by uh - as much as 40 percent with the same out-product.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: These kinds of things uh - ought to be done, uh they ought to be encouraged and supported, and even required uh by the government, yes.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Governor Carter skims over a very serious and a very broad subject.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In January of uh - 1975 I submitted to the Congress and to the American people the first comprehensive energy program recommended by any president.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It called for an increase in the production of energy in the United States.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It called for uh - conservation measures so that we would save the energy that we have.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: If you're going to increase domestic oil and gas production - and we have to - you have to give those producers an opportunity to uh - develop their land or their wells.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I recommended to the Congress that we should increase production in this country from six hundred million tons a year to twel- a- a billion two hundred million tons by 1985.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In order to do that we have to improve our extraction of coal from the ground; we have to improve our utilization of coal - make it more efficient, make it cleaner.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In addition we uh - have to expand our research and development.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In my program for energy independence we have increased, for example, solar energy research from about $84 million a year to about a hundred and twenty million dollars a year.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We're going as fast as the experts say we should.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In nuclear power we have increased the research and development, uh - under the Energy Research and Development Agency uh - very substantially, to insure that our ener- uh - nuclear power plants are safer, that they are more efficient, and that we have adequate safeguards.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I think you have to have greater oil and gas production, more coal production, more nuclear production, and in addition you have to have energy conservation.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The bills that I vetoed, the one for an additional $6 billion, was not a bill that would have solved our unemployment problems.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Even the proponents of it admitted that no more than four hundred thousand jobs would be uh - made available.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Our analysis indicates that something in the magnitude of about one hundred fifty to two hundred thousand jobs would uh - be made available.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Each one of those jobs would've cost the taxpayers $25 thousand.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In addition, the jobs would not be available right now.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: They would not have materialized for about nine to eighteen months.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The immediate problem we have is to stimulate our economy now so that we can get rid of unemployment.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: What we have done is to hold the lid on spending in an effort to reduce the rate of inflation.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And we have proven, I think very conclusively, that you can reduce the rate of inflation and increase jobs.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: For example, as I have said, we have added some four million jobs in the last seventeen months.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We have now employed eighty-eight million people in America, the largest number in the history of the United States.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We've added five hundred thousand jobs in the last two months.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Inflation is the quickest way to destroy jobs.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And by holding the lid on federal spending we have been able to do an- a good job, an affirmative job in inflation and as a result have added to the jobs in this country.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I think it's uh - also appropriate to point out that through our tax policies we have stimulated uhh - added employment throughout the country, the investment tax credit, the tax incentives for expansion and modernization of our industrial capacity.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It's my - my opinion that the private sector, where five out of six jobs are, where you have permanent jobs, with the opportunity for advancement, is a better place than make-work jobs under the program recommended by the Congress.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Well, that bill has not yet come down to the Oval Office, so I am not in a position to make any judgment on it tonight.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But that is an extra $4 billion that would uh - add to the deficit which would add to the inflationary pressures, which would help to destroy jobs in the private sector - not make jobs, where the jobs really are.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: These make-work, temporary jobs - dead end as they are - are not the kind of jobs that we want for our people.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I think it's interesting to point out that uh - in the uh - two years that I've been president I've vetoed fifty-six bills.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: As a result, we have saved over $9 billion in federal expenditures.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And the Congress by overriding the bills that I did veto, the Congress has added some $13 billion to the federal expenditures and to the federal deficit.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now Governor Carter complains about the deficits that uh - uh - this administration has had.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And yet he condemns the vetoes that I have made that has - that have saved the taxpayer $9 billion and could have saved an additional $13 billion.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now he can't have it both ways.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And therefore, it seems to me that we should hold the lid, as we have, to the best of our ability so we can stimulate the private economy and get the jobs where the jobs are - five out of six in this economy.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Well, Mr. Ford doesn't seem to put into perspective the fact that when - when uh five hundred thousand more people are out of work than there were three months ago, while we have two and a half million more people out of work than were when he took office, that this touches human beings.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I was in uh - a city in uh - Pennsylvania not too long ago, near here, and uh - there were about four or five thousand people in the audience - it was on a - on a train trip.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I said, "How many uh - adults here are out of work?"
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: About a thousand raised their hands.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Mr. Ford uh - actually has fewer people now in the private sector in non-farm jobs than when he took office.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And still he talks about - uh success.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Seven point nine percent unemployment is a terrible tragedy in this country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: He says he's learned how to match unemployment with inflation.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've got the highest inflation we've had in twenty-five years right now, except under this administration, and that was fifty years ago.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And we've got uh - the highest unemployment we've had uh - under Mr. Ford's administration, since the Great Depression.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This affects human beings, and - and his insensitivity in providing those people a chance to work has made this a welfare administration, and not a work administration.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: He hasn't saved $9 billion with his vetoes.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: There's only been uh - a net savings of $4 billion.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And the cost in unemployment compensation, welfare compensation, and lost revenues has increased $23 billion in the last two years.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is a - a typical attitude that really causes havoc in people's lives, and then it's covered over by saying that our country has naturally got a 6 percent unemployment rate, or 7 percent unemployment rate and a 6 percent inflation.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It shows a lack of leadership.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And we've never had a president since the War between the States that vetoed more bills.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Mr. Ford has vetoed four times as many bills as Mr. Nixon - per year.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And eleven of 'em have been overridden.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: One of his bills that was overridden - he only got one vote in the Senate and seven votes in the House, from Republicans.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Now we have uh such a grossly unbalanced tax system - as I said earlier, that it is a disgrace - ah of all the tax - benefits now, 25 percent of 'em go to the 1 percent of the richest people in this country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Over 50 percent - 53 to be exact - percent of the tax benefits go to the 14 percent richest people in this country, and we've had a 50 percent increase in payroll deductions since Mr. Nixon went in office eight years ago.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Mr. Ford has - has advocated since he's been in office over $5 billion in reductions for corporations, special interest groups, and the very, very wealthy who derive their income - not from labor - but from investments.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: That's got to be changed.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: A few things that can be done: we have now a deferral system so that the multinational corporations who invest overseas - if they make a million dollars in profits overseas - they don't have to pay any of their taxes unless they bring their money back into this country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: When they don't pay their taxes, the average American pays the taxes for them.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Not only that, but it robs this country of jobs, because instead of coming back with that million dollars and creating a shoe factory, say in New Hampshire or Vermont, if the company takes the money down to Italy and - and builds a shoe factory, they don't have to pay any taxes on the money.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This permits a company to create uh - a dummy corporation, to export their products, and then not to pay the full amount of taxes on them.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This costs our uh - government about uh - $1.4 billion a year.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And when those rich corporations don't pay that tax, the average American taxpayer pays it for 'em.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Another one that's uh - that's very important is the uh - is the business deductions, uh - jet airplanes, uh - first class travel, the fifty-dollar martini lunch.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The average working person can't - uh - can't take advantage of that, but the - the wealthier people - uh can.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Uh - another system is where uhh - a dentist can invest money in say, raising cattle and uh - can put in a hundred thousand dollars of his own money, borrow nine hundred thousand dollars - nine hundred mi- thousand dollars - that makes a million - and mark off a great amount of uh - of loss uh - through that procedure.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Uh - there was one example, for instance, where uh - somebody uh - produced pornographic movies.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: They put in $30 thousand of their own money and got a hundred and twenty thousand dollars in tax savings.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Well, these special kinds of programs have - have robbed the average taxpayer and have benefited those who are powerful, and who can employ lobbyists, and who can have their CPAs and their lawyers to help them benefit from the roughly uh - eight thousand pages of the tax code.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The average uh American person can't do it.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: You can't hire a lobbyist uh out of unemployment compensation checks.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: You need about, according to Congressional committees on this, you need about $10 billion.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Now you listed some things - the uh - deferral on foreign income as estimated: that would save about $500 million.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: DISC, you said, was about 1.4 billion.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: uh - The estimate of the outside, if you eliminated all tax shelters, is 5 billion.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: No, I wouldn't do away with all - uh business deductions.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think that would be a - a very serious mistake.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But uh - if - if you could just do away with the ones that are unfair, you could lower taxes for everyone.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: What I wanna do is not to raise taxes, but to eliminate loopholes.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: These programs that I described to you earlier - the tax deferrals for overseas, the DISC, and the tax shelters, uh - they only apply to people in the $50 thousand-a-year bracket or up, and I think this is the very best way to approach it.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It's to make sure that everybody pays taxes on the income that they earn and make sure that you take whatever savings there is from the higher income levels and give it to the lower- and middle-income families.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: In that interview uh - Governor Carter indicated that uh - he would raise the taxes on those in the medium or middle-income brackets or higher.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now if you uh - take the medium or middle-income taxpayer - that's about $14 thousand per person - uh - Governor Carter has indicated, publicly, in an interview that he would increase the taxes on about 50 percent of the working people of this country.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I think uh - the way to get tax equity in this country is to give tax relief to the middle-income people who have an income from roughly $8 thousand up to twenty-five or thirty thousand dollars.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: They have been short-changed as we have taken ten million taxpayers off the tax rolls in the last eight years, and as we have uh - added to the minimum tax uh - provision to make all people pay more taxes.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I believe in tax equity for the middle-income taxpayer, increasing the personal exemption.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Mr. Carter wants to increase taxes for roughly half of the taxpayers of this country.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Now, the Governor has also played a little fast and loose with the facts about vetoes.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The records show that President Roosevelt vetoed an average of fifty-five bills a year.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: President Truman vetoed on the average, while he was president, about thirty-eight bills a year.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I understand that Governor Carter, when he was Governor of Georgia, vetoed between thirty-five and forty bills a year.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: My average in two years is twenty-six.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But in the process of that we have saved uhh - $9 billion.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And one final comment, uh - Governor Carter talks about the tax bills and all of the inequities that exist in the present law.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I must remind him the Democrats have controlled the Congress for the last twenty-two years and they wrote all the tax bills.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: There is a considerable anti-Washington feeling throughout the country.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In the last two years, we have restored integrity in the White House, and we've set high standards in the executive branch of the government.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The anti-Washington feeling, in my opinion, ought to be focused on the Congress of the United States.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: For example, this Congress, very shortly, will spend a billion dollars a year for its housekeeping, its salaries, its expenses and the like.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It - the next Congress will probably be the first billion-dollar Congress in the history of the United States.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I don't think the American people are getting their money's worth from the majority party that run this Congress.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We, in addition, see that uh - in the last uh - four years the number of employees hired by the Congress has gone up substantial- uh much more than uh - the gross national product, much more than any other increase throughout our society.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Congress is hiring people by the droves, and the cast as a result has gone up.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And I don't see any improvement in the performance of the Congress under the present leadership.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: So it seems to me instead of the anti-Washington feeling being aimed at everybody in Washington, it seems to me that the focus should be where the problem is, which is the Congress of the United States, and particularly the majority in the Congress.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: They spend too much money on themselves.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: They have too many employees.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: There's some question about their morality.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It seems to me that in this election, the focus should not be on the executive branch but the corrections should come as the voters vote for their members of the House of Representatives or for their United States senator.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Well, It seems to me that uh - we have a chance - the Republicans - to get a majority in the House of Representatives.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We will make some gains in the United States Senate.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: So there will be different ratios in the House, as well as in the Senate, and as president I will be able to uh - work with that Congress.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But let me take the other side of the coin, if I might.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Supposing we had - had a Democratic Congress for the last two years and we'd had uh - Governor Carter as President.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: He has, in effect, said that he would agree with all of - he would disapprove of the vetoes that I have made, and would have added significantly to expenditures and the deficit in the federal government.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I think it would be contrary to one of the basic concepts in our system of government - a system of checks and balances.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We have a Democratic Congress today, and fortunately we've had a Republican president to check their excesses with my vetoes.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I think the American people want a Republican president to check on any excesses that come out of the next Congress, if it is a Democratic Congress.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Well, it's not a matter of uh - Republican and Democrat.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It's a matter of leadership or no leadership.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: President Eisenhower worked with a Democratic Congress very well.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Even President Nixon, because he was a strong leader at least, worked with a Democratic Congress very well.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Uh - Mr. Ford has vetoed, as I said earlier, four times as many bills per year as Mr. Nixon.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Mr. Ford quite often puts forward a program just as a public relations stunt, and never tries to put it through the Congress by working with the Congress.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think under presidents For- uh - Nixon and Eisenhower they passed about 60 to 75 percent of their legislation.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This year Mr. Ford will not pass more than 26 percent of all the legislative proposals he puts forward.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is government by stalemate, and we've seen almost a complete breakdown in the proper relationship between the president, who represents this country, and the Congress, who collectively also represent this country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've had uh - Republican presidents before who've tried to run against a Democratic - uh Congress.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I don't think it's uh - the Congress is Mr. Ford's opponent; but if uh - if - if he insists that uh - that I be responsible for the Democratic Congress, of which I'm - have not been a part, then I think it's only fair that he be responsible for the Nixon administration in its entirety, of which he was a part.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: That, I think, is a good balance.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But the point is, that - that a president ought to lead this country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Mr. Ford, so far as I know, except for avoiding another Watergate, has not accomplished one single major program for this country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And there's been a constant squabbling between the president and the Congress, and that's not the way this country ought to be run.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Mr. Ford has uh - misquoted an AP uh - news story that was in error to begin with.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: That story reported several times that I would lower taxes for low and middle-income families and uh - that correction was delivered to the White House and I am sure that the president knows about this uh - correction, but he still insists uh - on repeating an erroneous statement.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: What I have said is that the president ought to have a chance to appoint a chairman of the Federal Reserve Board to have a coterminous uh term; in other words, both of 'em serve the same four - four years.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The Congress can modify the supply of money by modifying the income uh tax laws.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The president can modify the uh - economic structure of a country by public statements and general attitudes in the budget that he proposes.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The Federal Reserve has uh - an independent status that ought to be preserved; I think that Mr. uh - Burns did take a typical, erroneous Republican attitude in the 1973 year when inflation was so high.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: They assumed that the uh - inflation rate was because of excessive demand and uh - therefore put into effect tight constraint on the economy, very high interest rates, which is typical also of the Republican administration, uh - tried to increase the uh - the tax uh - payments by individuals, and cut the tax payments by corporations.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I would have uh - done it opposite.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I think the uh - problem should've been addressed by increasing productivity, by having uh - put - put people back to work so they could purchase more goods, lower income taxes on individuals, perhaps raise them, if necessary, on corporations in comparison.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But uh - Mr. Burns uh - in that respect made a very serious mistake.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I would not wanna destroy the - the independence of the uh Federal Reserve - uh Board.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But I do think we ought to have a cohesive economic policy with at - at least the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and the president's terms being uh - the same and letting the Congress, of course, be the third uh - entity with uh - with independence subject only to the president's veto.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board should be independent.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Fortunately, he has been during Democratic as well as Republican administrations.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: As the result in the last uh - two years uh - we have had a responsible monetary policy.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Uh the Federal Reserve Board indicated that the supply of money would be held between four to four and a half and seven and seven and a half.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: They have done a good job in integrating the money supply with the uh - fiscal policy of the uh - executive and legislative branches of the government.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It would be catastrophic if the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board became the tool of the political uh - party that was in power.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It's important for our future uhh - economic security that that job be nonpolitical and uh - separate from the executive and the Legislative branches.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: You are familiar, of course, with the fact that I am the first president in thirty years who has reorganized the intelligence agencies in the federal government: the CIA, the Defense Intelligence Agency, the National Security Agency and the others.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We've done that by executive order.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Uhh - and I think uh - we've tightened it up; we've uh - straightened out their problems that developed over the last few years.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It doesn't seem to me that it's needed or necessary to have legislation in this particular regard.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Uhh - I have recommended to the Congress, however - I'm sure you're familiar with this - legislation that would uhh - make it uhh - very uhh - proper in - in the right way, that the attorney general could go in and get the right for wiretapping under security cases.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: This was an effort that was made by the attorney general and myself, working with the Congress.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: But even in this area, where I think new legislation would be justified, uh the Congress has not responded.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: So, I feel in that case, as well as in the reorganization of the intelligence agencies, as I've done, we have to do it by executive order.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: And I'm glad that we have a good director in George Bush.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We have good executive orders, and the CIA and the DIA and NASA uh - uh - NSA are now doing a good job under proper supervision.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Well, one of the very serious things that's happened in our government in recent years, and has continued up until now, is a breakdown in the trust among our people in the [twenty-seven-minute delay]
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: There has been too much government secrecy and not uh - not enough respect for the personal privacy of American citizens.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Well, tonight we've had a chance to talk a lot about the past.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Our nation in the last eight years has been divided as never before.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It's a time for unity.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It's time for government, industry, labor, manufacturing, agriculture, education, other entities in our society to cooperate.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And it's a time for government to understand and to cooperate with our people.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: For a long time our American citizens have been excluded, sometimes misled, sometimes have been lied to.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is uh - not compatible with the purpose of our nation.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It needs to be competent.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: The government needs to be well-managed, efficient, economical, We need to have a government that's sensitive to our people's needs - to those who are poor, who don't have adequate health care, who have been cheated too long with our tax programs, who've been out of jobs, whose families have been torn apart.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We need to restore the faith and the trust of the American people in their own government.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've got a government of stalemate.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We've lost the vision of what our country can and ought to be.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: This is not the America that we've known in the past.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: It's not the America that we have to have in the future.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I don't claim to know all the answers.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: But I've got confidence in my country.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Our economic strength is still there.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: Our system of government - in spite of Vietnam, Cambodia, CIA, Watergate - is still the best system of government on earth.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And the greatest resource of all are the two hundred and fifteen million Americans who have within us the strength, the character, the intelligence, the experience, the patriotism, the idealism, the compassion, the sense of brotherhood on which we can rely in the future to restore the greatness to our country We ought not to be excluded from our government anymore.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: We need a president who can go in - who derives his strength from the people.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I owe the special interests nothing.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I believe that we can bind our wounds.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: I believe that we can work together.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: And I believe that if we can tap the tremendous untapped reservoir of innate strength in this country, that we can once again have a government as good as our people, and let the world know what we still know and hope for - that we still live in the greatest and the strongest and the best country on earth.
Speaker: Jimmy Carter

Text: On November second all of you will make a very, very important decision.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: One of the major issues in this campaign is trust.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: A president should never promise more than he can deliver and a president should always deliver everything that he's promised.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: A president can't be all things to all people.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: A president should be the same thing to all people.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Another issue in this campaign, Governor Carter has endorsed the Democratic platform, which calls for more spending, bigger deficits, more inflation or mare taxes.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Governor Carter has embraced the record of the present Congress, dominated by his political party.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It calls for more of the same.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Governor Carter in his acceptance speech called for more and more programs, which means more and more government.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I think the real issue in this campaign, and that which you must decide on November second, is whether you should vote for his promise or my performance in two years in the White House.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: On the fourth of July we had a wonderful two hundredth birthday - for our great country.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It was a superb occasion.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: It was a glorious day.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In the first century of our nation's history our forefathers gave us the finest form of government in the history of mankind.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In the second century of our nation's history, our forefathers developed the most productive industrial nation in the history of the globe.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Our third century should be the century of individual freedom for all our two hundred and fifteen million Americans today and all that join us.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: In the last few years government has gotten bigger and bigger; industry has gotten larger and larger; labor unions have gotten bigger and bigger; and our children have been the victims of mass education.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: We should never forget that a government big enough to give us everything we want is a government big enough to take from us everything we have.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The individual worker in the plants throughout the United States should not be a small cog in a big machine.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: The member of a labor union must have his rights strengthened and broadened and our children in their education should have an opportunity to improve themselves based on their talents and their abilities.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: My mother and father, during the Depression, worked very hard to give me an opportunity to do better in our great country.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Your mothers and fathers did the same thing for you and others.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: Betty and I have worked very hard to give our children a brighter future in the United States, our beloved country.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: You and others in this great country have worked hard and done a great deal to give your children and your grandchildren the blessings of a better America.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I believe we can all work together to make the individuals in the future have more and all of us working together can build a better America.
Speaker: Gerald R. Ford

Text: I have a plan -- not a secret plan.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: As a matter of fact, it is the economic recovery program that we presented when I took office in 1981.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It is true that earlier, working with some very prominent economists, I had come up, during the campaign, with an economic program that I thought could rectify the great problems confronting us -- the double-digit inflation, the high tax rates that I think were hurting the economy, the stagflation that we were undergoing.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Before even the election day, something that none of those economists had even predicted had happened, that the economy was so worsened that I was openly saying that what we had thought on the basis of our plan could have brought a balanced budget -- no, that was no longer possible.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So, the plan that we have had and that we are following is a plan that is based on growth in the economy, recovery without inflation, and reducing the share that the Government is taking from the gross national product, which has become a drag on the economy.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Already, we have a recovery that has been going on for about 21 months to the point that we can now call it an expansion.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan
