Text: Under that, this year, we have seen a $21 billion reduction in the deficit from last year, based mainly on the increased revenues the Government is getting without raising tax rates.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Our tax cut, we think, was very instrumental in bringing about this economic recovery.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have reduced inflation to about a third of what it was.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The interest rates have come down about 9 or 10 points and, we think, must come down further.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: In the last 21 months, more than 6 million people have gotten jobs -- there have been created new jobs for those people to where there are now 105 million civilians working, where there were only 99 million before; 107, if you count the military.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So, we believe that as we continue to reduce the level of government spending -- the increase, rate of increase in government spending, which has come down from 17 to 6 percent, and, at the same time, as the growth in the economy increases the revenues the Government gets, without raising taxes, those two lines will meet.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And when they meet, that is a balanced budget.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The deficit is the result of excessive government spending.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I do not, very frankly, take seriously the Congressional Budget Office projections, because they have been wrong on virtually all of them, including the fact that our recovery wasn't going to take place to begin with.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But it has taken place.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But, as I said, we have the rate of increase in government spending down to 6 percent.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: If the rate of increase in government spending can be held at 5 percent -- we're not far from there -- by 1989 that would have reduced the budget deficits down to a $30 or $40 billion level.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Actually, in constant dollars, in the domestic side of the budget, there has been no spending increase in the 4 years that we have been here.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: One of the key tests of leadership is whether one sees clearly the nature of the problems confronted by our nation.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And perhaps the dominant domestic issue of our times is what do we do about these enormous deficits.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I respect the President; I respect the Presidency, and I think he knows that.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But the fact of it is, every estimate by this administration about the size of the deficit has been off by billions and billions of dollars.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We were told we would have a balanced budget in 1983.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It was $200 billion deficit instead.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And now we have a major question facing the American people as to whether we'll deal with this deficit and get it down for the sake of a healthy recovery.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Virtually every economic analysis that I've heard of, including the distinguished Congressional Budget Office, which is respected by, I think, almost everyone, says that even with historically high levels of economic growth, we will suffer a $263 billion deficit.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: In other words, it doesn't converge as the President suggests.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It gets larger even with growth.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: What that means is that we will continue to have devastating problems with foreign trade.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: This is the worst trade year in American history by far.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Our rural and farm friends will have continued devastation.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Real interest rates -- the real cost of interest -- will remain very, very high, and many economists are predicting that we're moving into a period of very slow growth because the economy is tapering off and may be a recession.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I get it down to a level below 2 percent of gross national product with a policy that's fair.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I've stood up and told the American people that I think it's a real problem, that it can destroy long-term economic growth, and I've told you what I think should be done.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: These people depend upon all of us for the little security that they have, and I'm not going to do it that way.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The rate of defense spending increase can be slowed.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Certainly we can find a coffeepot that costs something less than $7,000.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And there are other ways of squeezing this budget without constantly picking on our senior citizens and the most vulnerable in American life.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And that's why the Congress, including the Republicans, have not gone along with the President's recommendations.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I don't believe that Mr. Mondale has a plan for balancing the budget; he has a plan for raising taxes.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And, as a matter of fact, the biggest single tax increase in our nation's history took place 1977.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And for the 5 years previous to our taking office, taxes doubled in the United States, and the budgets increased $318 billion.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So, there is no ratio between taxing and balancing a budget.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Whether you borrow the money or whether you simply tax it away from the people, you're taking the same amount of money out of the private sector, unless and until you bring down government's share of what it is taking.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: With regard to Social Security, I hope there'll be more time than just this minute to mention that, but I will say this: A President should never say "never.''
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But I'm going to violate that rule and say "never.''
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I will never stand for a reduction of the Social Security benefits to the people that are now getting them.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Well, that's exactly the commitment that was made to the American people in 1980: He would never reduce benefits.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And of course, what happened right after the election is they proposed to cut Social Security benefits by 25 percent -- reducing the adjustment for inflation, cutting out minimum benefits for the poorest on Social Security, removing educational benefits for dependents whose widows were trying -- with widows trying to get them through college.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I have fought for Social Security and Medicare and for things to help people who are vulnerable all my life, and I will do it as President of the United States.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Well, first of all, I think the first answer this evening suggests exactly what I'm saying.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: There is no question that we face this massive deficit, and almost everybody agrees unless we get it down, the chances for long-term, healthy growth are nil.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And it's also unfair to dump these tremendous bills on our children.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The President says it will disappear overnight because of some reason.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: No one else believes that's the case.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I do, and I'm standing up to the issue with an answer that's fair.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I think that's what leadership is all about.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: There's a difference between being a quarterback and a cheerleader, and when there's a real problem, a President must confront it.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: What I was referring to, of course, in the comment that you referred to was the situation in Lebanon.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Now, for three occasions, one after another, our Embassies were assaulted in the same way by a truck with demolitions.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The first time -- and I did not criticize the President, because these things can happen -- once, and sometimes twice -- the second time the barracks in Lebanon were assaulted, as we all remember.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: There was two or three commission reports, recommendations by the CIA, the State Department, and the others, and the third time there was even a warning from the terrorists themselves.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Now, I believe that a President must command that White House and those who work for him.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It's the toughest job on Earth, and you must master the facts and insist that things that must be done are done.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I believe that the way in which I will approach the Presidency is what's needed, because all my life that has been the way in which I have sought to lead.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And that's why in this campaign I'm telling you exactly what I want to do.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I am answering your questions.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I am trying to provide leadership now, before the election, so that the American people can participate in that decision.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Well, I think we're getting better all the time.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And I think tonight, as we contrast for the first time our differing approach to government, to values, to the leadership in this country, I think as this debate goes forward, the American people will have for the first time a chance to weigh the two of us against each other.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And I think, as a part of that process, what I am trying to say will come across, and that is that we must lead, we must command, we must direct, and a President must see it like it is.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: He must stand for the values of decency that the American people stand for, and he must use the power of the White House to try to control these nuclear weapons and lead this world toward a safer world.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Well, whether he does or not, let me suggest my own idea about the leadership factor, since you've asked it.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And, incidentally, I might say that with regard to the 25-percent cut in Social Security -- before I get to the answer to your question -- the only 25-percent cut that I know of was accompanying that huge 1977 tax increase, was a cut of 25 percent in the benefits for every American who was born after 1916.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: First of all, I think you must have some principles you believe in.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: In mine, I happen to believe in the people and believe that the people are supposed to be dominant in our society -- that they, not government, are to have control of their own affairs to the greatest extent possible, with an orderly society.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, having that, I think also that in leadership -- well, I believe that you find people, positions such as I'm in who have the talent and ability to do the things that are needed in the various departments of government.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I don't believe that a leader should be spending his time in the Oval Office deciding who's going to play tennis on the White House court.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And you let those people go with the guidelines of overall policy, not looking over their shoulder and nitpicking the manner in which they go at the job.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: You are ultimately responsible, however, for that job.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But I also believe something else about that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I believe that -- and when I became Governor of California, I started this, and I continue it in this office -- that any issue that comes before me, I have instructed Cabinet members and staff they are not to bring up any of the political ramifications that might surround the issue.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I don't want to hear them.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I want to hear only arguments as to whether it is good or bad for the people -- is it morally right?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And on that basis and that basis alone, we make a decision on every issue.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, with regard to my feeling about why I thought that his record bespoke his possible taking us back to the same things that we knew under the previous administration, his record is that he spoke in praise of deficits several times, said they weren't to be abhorred -- that, as a matter of fact, he at one time said he wished the deficit could be doubled, because they stimulate the economy and helped reduce unemployment.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Our policy was not to cut subsidies.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have believed in partnership, and that was an example of a partnership between, not only local government and the Federal Government but also between the private sector that built that particular structure.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And this is what we've been trying to do, is involve the Federal Government in such partnerships.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have no thought of throwing people out into the snow, whether because of age or need.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have preserved the safety net for the people with true need in this country, and it has been pure demagoguery that we have in some way shut off all the charitable programs or many of them for the people who have real need.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The safety net is there, and we're taking care of more people than has ever been taken care of before by any administration in this country.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Well, I guess I'm reminded a little bit of what Will Rogers once said about Hoover.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: He said, "It's not what he doesn't know that bothers me; it's what he knows for sure that just ain't so.''
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: [Laughter] The fact of it is: The President's budget sought to cut Social Security by 25 percent.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It's not an opinion; it's a fact.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And when the President was asked the other day, "What do you want to cut in the budget?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: '', he said, "Cut those things I asked for but didn't get.''
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That's Social Security and Medicare.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The second fact is that the housing unit for senior citizens that the President dedicated in Buffalo was only made possible through a Federal assistance program for senior citizens that the President's budget sought to terminate.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: So, if he'd had his way, there wouldn't have been any housing project there at all.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: This administration has taken a meat cleaver out, in terms of Federal-assisted housing, and the record is there.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We have to see the facts before we can draw conclusions.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Well, let me just respond with regard to Social Security.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: When we took office, we discovered that the program that the Carter-Mondale administration had said would solve the fiscal problems of Social Security for the next 50 years wouldn't solve them for 5.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Social Security was due to go bankrupt before 1983.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Any proposals that I made at that time were at the request of the chairman, a Democrat, of one of the leading committees, who said we have to do something before the program goes broke and the checks bounce.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And so, we made a proposal.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And then in 1982, they used that proposal in a demagogic fashion for the 1982 campaign.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And 3 days after the election in 1982, they came to us and said, Social Security, we know, is broke.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Indeed, we had to borrow $17 billion to pay the checks.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And then I asked for a bipartisan commission, which I'd asked for from the beginning, to sit down and work out a solution.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And so, the whole matter of what to do with Social Security has been resolved by bipartisan legislation, and it is on a sound basis now for as far as you can see into the next century.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Well, I was raised to have a faith and a belief and have been a member of a church since I was a small boy.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: In our particular church, we did not use that term, "born again,'' so I don't know whether I would fit that -- that particular term.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But I have -- thanks to my mother, God rest her soul -- the firmest possible belief and faith in God.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I don't believe -- I believe, I should say, as Lincoln once said, that I could not -- I would be the most stupid man in the world if I thought I could confront the duties of the office I hold if I could not turn to someone who was stronger and greater than all others.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I do resort to prayer.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: At the same time, however, I have not believed that prayer should be introduced into an election or be a part of a political campaign -- or religion a part of that campaign.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: As a matter of fact, I think religion became a part of this campaign when Mr. Mondale's running mate said I wasn't a good Christian.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So, it does play a part in my life.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I have no hesitancy in saying so.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And, as I say, I don't believe that I could carry on unless I had a belief in a higher authority and a belief that prayers are answered.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The answer to your question is very simple about why I don't go to church.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I have gone to church regularly all my life, and I started to here in Washington.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And now, in the position I hold and in the world in which we live, where Embassies do get blown up in Beirut -- we're supposed to talk about that on the debate the 21st, I understand -- but I pose a threat to several hundred people if I go to church.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I know the threats that are made against me.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have seen the barricades that have had to be built around the White House.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And, therefore, I don't feel -- and my minister knows this and supports me in this position -- I don't feel that I have a right to go to church, knowing that my being there could cause something of the kind that we have seen in other places, in Beirut, for example.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I miss going to church, but I think the Lord understands.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: First of all, I accept President Reagan's affirmation of faith.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I'm sure that we all accept and admire his commitment to his faith, and we are strengthened, all of us, by that fact.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: My wife is the daughter of a Presbyterian minister.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And I don't know if I've been born again, but I know I was born into a Christian family.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And I believe I have sung at more weddings and more funerals than anybody ever to seek the Presidency.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Whether that helps or not, I don't know.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I have a deep religious faith.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It's probably the reason that I'm in politics.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And I think we're all together on that.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: What bothers me is this growing tendency to try to use one's own personal interpretation of faith politically, to question others' faith, and to try to use the instrumentalities of government to impose those views on others.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: All history tells us that that's a mistake.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: This nation is the most religious nation on Earth -- more people go to church and synagogues than any other nation on Earth -- and it's because we kept the politicians and the state out of the personal exercise of our faith.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That's why faith in the United States is pure and unpolluted by the intervention of politicians.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And I think if we want to continue -- as I do -- to have a religious nation, lets keep that line and never cross it.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: What I object to -- [applause] -- what I object to -- what I object to is someone seeking to use his faith to question the faith of another or to use that faith and seek to use the power of government to impose it on others.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: A minister who is in civil rights or in the conservative movement, because he believes his faith instructs him to do that, I admire.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The fact that the faith speaks to us and that we are moral people, hopefully, I accept and rejoice in.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It's when you try to use that to undermine the integrity of private political -- or private religious faith and the use of the state is where -- for the most personal decisions in American life -- that's where I draw the line.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Yes, it's very difficult to rebut, because I find myself in so much agreement with Mr. Mondale.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I, too, want that wall that is in the Constitution of separation of church and state to remain there.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The only attacks I have made are on people who apparently would break away at that wall from the government side, using the government, using the power of the courts and so forth to hinder that part of the Constitution that says the government shall not only not establish a religion, it shall not inhibit the practice of religion.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And they have been using these things to have government, through court orders, inhibit the practice of religion.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: A child wants to say grace in a school cafeteria and a court rules that they can't do it because it's school property.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: These are they types of things that I think have been happening in a kind of a secular way that have been eroding that separation, and I am opposed to that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: With regard to a platform on the Supreme Court, I can only say one thing about that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I have appointed one member to the Supreme Court: Sandra Day O'Connor.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I'll stand on my record on that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And if I have the opportunity to appoint any more, I'll do it in the same manner that I did in selecting her.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The platform to which the President refers, in fact, calls for a religious test in the selection of judges.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And Jerry Falwell says that means we get two or three judges.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And it would involve a religious test for the first time in American life.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Let's take the example that the President cites.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We've never had any difficulty finding time to pray.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But do we want a constitutional amendment adopted of the kind proposed by the President that gets the local politicians into the business of selecting prayers that our children must either recite in school or be embarrassed and asked to excuse themselves?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Who would write the prayer?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: How would it be resolved when those disputes occur?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: My answer is that this campaign isn't over yet.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And when people vote, I think you're going to see a very strong verdict by the American people that they favor the approach that I'm talking about.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The American people want arms control.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: They don't want this arms race.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And they don't want this deadly new effort to bring weapons into the heavens.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And they want an American foreign policy that leads toward a safer world.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The American people see this debt, and they know it's got to come down.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And if it won't come down, the economy's going to slow down, maybe go into a recession.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: They see this tremendous influx and swamping of cheap foreign imports in this country that has cost over 3 million jobs, given farmers the worst year in American history.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And they know this debt must come down as well, because it's unfair to our children.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The American people want this environment protected.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: They know that these toxic waste dumps should have been cleaned up a long time ago, and they know that people's lives and health are being risked, because we've had an administration that has been totally insensitive to the law and the demand for the protection of the environment.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The American people want their children educated.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: They want to get our edge back in science, and they want a policy headed by the President that helps close this gap that's widening between the United States and Europe and Japan.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: They want those civil rights laws enforced.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: They want the equal rights amendment ratified.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: They want equal pay for comparable effort for women.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And they want it because they've understood from the beginning that when we open doors, we're all stronger, just as we were at the Olympics.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I think as you make the case, the American people will increasingly come to our cause.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Well, tonight we had the first debate over the deficit.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The President says it'll disappear automatically.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I've said it's going to take some work.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I think the American people will draw their own conclusions.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Secondly, I've said that I will not support the cuts in Social Security and Medicare and the rest that the President has proposed.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The President answers that it didn't happen or, if it did, it was resolved later in a commission.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: As the record develops, I think it's going to become increasingly clear that what I am saying and where I want to take this country is exactly where the country wants to go, and the comparison of approaches is such that I think will lead to further strength.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Well, again, I'm running on the record.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think sometimes Mr. Mondale's running away from his.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But I'm running on the record of what we have asked for.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We'll continue to try to get things that we didn't get in a program that has already brought the rate of spending of government down from 17 percent to 6.1 percent, a program of returning authority and autonomy to the local and State governments that has been unjustly seized by the Federal Government.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And you might find those words in a Democratic platform of some years ago -- I know, because I was a Democrat at that time.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I left the party eventually, because I could no longer follow the turn in the Democratic leadership that took us down an entirely different path, a path of centralizing authority in the Federal Government, lacking trust in the American people.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I promised, when we took office, that we would reduce inflation.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have, to one-third of what it was.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I promised that we would reduce taxes.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We did, 25 percent across the board.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: That barely held even with -- if it did that much -- with the gigantic tax increase imposed in 1977.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But at least it took that burden away from them.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I said that we would become respected in the world once again and that we would refurbish our national defense to the place that we could deal on the world scene and then seek disarmament, reduction of arms, and, hopefully, an elimination of nuclear weapons.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I think this is something the American people see.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think they also know that we had a commission that came in a year ago with a recommendation on education -- on excellence in education.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And today, without the Federal Government being involved other than passing on to them, the school districts, the words from that commission, we find 35 States with task forces now dealing with their educational problems.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We find that schools are extending the curriculum to now have forced teaching of mathematics and science and so forth.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: All of these things have brought an improvement in the college entrance exams for the first time in some 20 years.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So, I think that many Democrats are seeing the same thing this Democrat saw: The leadership isn't taking us where we want to go.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: There are tasks that government legitimately should enforce and tasks that government performs well, and you've named some of them.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Crime has come down the last 2 years, for the first time in many, many decades that it has come down -- or since we've kept records -- 2 consecutive years, and last year it came down the biggest drop in crime that we've had.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think that we've had something to do with that, just as we have with the drug problem nationwide.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Yes, I feel as strongly as anyone about the preservation of the environment.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: When we took office, we found that the national parks were so dirty and contained so many hazards, lack of safety features, that we stopped buying additional park land until we had rectified this with what was to be a 5-year program -- but it's just about finished already -- a billion dollars.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And now we're going back to budgeting for additional lands for our parks.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have added millions of acres to the wilderness lands, to the game refuges.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think that we're out in front of most -- and I see that the red light is blinking, so I can't continue.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The President says that when the Democratic Party made its turn, he left it.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The year that he decided we had lost our way was the year that John F. Kennedy was running against Richard Nixon.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I was chairman of "Minnesotans for Kennedy;'' President Reagan was chairman of a thing called "Democrats for Nixon.''
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Now, maybe we made a wrong turn with Kennedy, but I'll be proud of supporting him all of my life.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And I'm very happy that John Kennedy was elected, because John Kennedy looked at the future with courage, saw what needed to be done, and understood his own government.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The President just said that his government is shrinking.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And instead of retreating -- instead of being strong where we should be strong, he wants to make it strong and intervene in the most private and personal questions in American life.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That's where government should not be.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Before I campaigned as a Democrat for a Republican candidate for President, I had already voted for Dwight Eisenhower to be President of the United States.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And so, my change had come earlier than that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I hadn't gotten around to reregistering as yet.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I found that was rather difficult to do.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But I finally did it.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: There are some other things that have been said here -- back, and you said that I might be able to dredge them up.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Mr. Mondale referred to the farmers' worst year.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The farmers are not the victims of anything this administration has done.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The farmers were the victims of the double-digit inflation and the 211/2-percent interest rates of the Carter-Mondale administration and the grain embargo, which destroyed our reliability nationwide as a supplier.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: All of these things are presently being rectified, and I think that we are going to salvage the farmers.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I have believed that in the appointment of judges that all that was specified in the party platform was that they respect the sanctity of human life.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, that I would want to see in any judge and with regard to any issue having to do with human life.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But with regard to abortion, and I have a feeling that this is -- there's been some reference without naming it here in the remarks of Mr. Mondale tied to injecting religion into government.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: With me, abortion is not a problem of religion, it's a problem of the Constitution.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I believe that until and unless someone can establish that the unborn child is not a living human being, then that child is already protected by the Constitution, which guarantees life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness to all of us.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I think that this is what we should concentrate on, is trying -- I know there were weeks and weeks of testimony before a Senate committee, there were medical authorities, there were religious -- there were clerics there -- everyone talking about this matter of prolife.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And at the end of all of that, not one shred of evidence was introduced that the unborn child was not alive.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have seen premature births that are now grown-up, happy people going around.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Also, there is a strange dichotomy in this whole position about our courts ruling that abortion is not the taking of a human life.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: In California, sometime ago, a man beat a woman so savagely that her unborn child was born dead with a fractured skull, and the California State Legislature unanimously passed a law that was signed by the then-Democratic Governor -- signed a law that said that any man who so abuses a pregnant woman that he causes the death of her unborn child shall be charged with murder.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, isn't it strange that that same woman could have taken the life of her unborn child, and it was abortion and not murder, but if somebody else does it, that's murder?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And it used the term "death of the unborn child.''
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So, this has been my feeling about abortion, that we have a problem now to determine -- and all the evidence so far comes down on the side of the unborn child being a living human being.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The laws regarding that always were State laws.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It was only when the Supreme Court handed down a decision that the Federal Government intervened in what had always been a State policy.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Our laws against murder are State laws.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So, I would think that this would be the point of enforcement on this.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: As I say, I feel that we have a problem here to resolve.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And no one has approached it from that matter.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It does not happen that the church that I belong to had that as part of its dogma.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I know that some churches do.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, it is a sin if you're taking a human life.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: At the same time, in our Judeo-Christian tradition, we recognize the right of taking a human life in self-defense.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And therefore, I've always believed that a mother, if medically it is determined that her life is at risk if she goes through with the pregnancy, she has a right then to take the life of even her own unborn child in defense of her own.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think your questions, however, underscore the fact there is probably no way that government should or could answer this question in every individual case and in the private lives of the American people.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The constitutional amendment proposed by President Reagan would make it a crime for a woman to have an abortion if she had been raped or suffered from incest.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Is it really the view of the American people, however you feel on the question of abortion, that government ought to be reaching into your livingrooms and making choices like this?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I think it cannot work, won't work, and will lead to all kinds of cynical evasions of the law.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Those who can afford to have them will continue to have them.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The disadvantaged will go out in the back alley as they used to do.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I think these questions are inherently personal and moral, and every individual instance is different.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Every American should be aware of the seriousness of the step.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Now, the example that the President cites has nothing to do with abortion.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Somebody went to a woman and nearly killed her.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That's always been a serious crime and always should be a serious crime.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But how does that compare with the problem of a woman who is raped?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Do we really want those decisions made by judges who've been picked because they will agree to find the person guilty?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I don't think so, and I think it's going in exactly the wrong direction.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: In America, on basic moral questions we have always let the people decide in their own personal lives.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We haven't felt so insecure that we've reached for the club of state to have our point of view.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It's been a good instinct.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And we're the most religious people on Earth.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: One final point: President Reagan, as Governor of California, signed a bill which is perhaps the most liberal proabortion bill of any State in the Union.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The basic decision of the Supreme Court is that each person has to make this judgment in her own life, and that's the way it's been done.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And it's a personal and private, moral judgment.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I don't know the answer to when life begins.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And it's not that simple, either.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And if it's rape, how do you draw moral judgments on that?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: If it's incest, how do you draw moral judgments on that?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Well, with regard to this being a personal choice, isn't that what a murderer is insisting on, his or her right to kill someone because of whatever fault they think justifies that?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, I'm not capable, and I don't think you are, any of us, to make this determination that must be made with regard to human life.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I am simply saying that I believe that that's where the effort should be directed -- to make that determination.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I don't think that any of us should be called upon here to stand and make a decision as to what other things might come under the self-defense tradition.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: That, too, would have to be worked out then, when you once recognize that we're talking about a life.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: There are a million and a half people out there standing in line waiting to adopt children who can't have them any other way.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I agree with that, and that's why I was a principal sponsor of a liberal adoption law, so that more of these children could come to term, so that the young mothers were educated, so we found an option, an alternative.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But the question is whether this other option proposed by the President should be pursued.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And I don't agree with it.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Since I've got about 20 seconds, let me just say one thing.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The question of agriculture came up a minute ago.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Net farm income is off 50 percent in the last 3 years, and every farmer knows it.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And the effect of these economic policies is like a massive grain embargo, which has caused farm exports to drop 20 percent.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It's been a big failure.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I opposed the grain embargo in my administration.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I'm opposed to these policies as well.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Under the 1981 tax bill, people making $200,000 a year got $60,000 in tax relief over 3 years, while people making $30,000 a year, all taxes considered, got no relief at all or their taxes actually went up.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That's why my proposal protects everybody from $25,000 a year or less against any tax increases, and treats those $70,000 and under in a way that is more beneficial than the way the President proposes with a sales tax or a flat tax.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: What does this mean in real life?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Well, the other day, Vice President Bush disclosed his tax returns to the American people.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: He's one of the wealthiest Americans, and he's our Vice President.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: In 1981 I think he paid about 40 percent in taxes.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: In 1983, as a result of these tax preferences, he paid a little over 12 percent, 12.8 percent in taxes.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That meant that he paid a lower percent in taxes than the janitor who cleaned up his office or the chauffeur who drives him to work.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I believe we need some fairness.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And that's why I've proposed what I think is a fair and a responsible proposal that helps protect these people who've already got no relief or actually got a tax increase.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The first thing is, everybody 25,000 and under would have no tax increase.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Mr. Reagan, after the election, is going to have to propose a tax increase, and you will have to compare what he proposes.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And his Secretary of the Treasury said he's studying a sales tax or a value-added tax.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: They hit middle- and moderate-income Americans and leave wealthy Americans largely untouched.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Up until about $70,000, as you go up the ladder, my proposals will be far more beneficial.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: As soon as we get the economy on a sound ground as well, I'd like to see the total repeal of indexing.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I don't think we can do that for a few years.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But at some point, we want to do that as well.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: You know, I wasn't going to say this at all, but I can't help it.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: [Laughter] I don't have a plan to tax -- or increase taxes.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I can understand why you are, Mr. Mondale, because as a Senator you voted 16 times to increase taxes.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, I believe that our problem has not been that anybody in our country is undertaxed; it's that government is overfed.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I think that most of our people -- this is why we had a 25-percent tax cut across the board which maintained the same progressivity of our tax structure in the brackets on up.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And, as a matter of fact, it just so happens that in the quirks of administering these taxes, those above $50,000 actually did not get quite as big a tax cut percentage-wise as did those from 50,000 down.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: From 50,000 down, those people paid two-thirds of the taxes, and those people got two-thirds of the tax cut.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, the Social Security tax of '77 -- this indeed was a tax that hit people in the lower brackets the hardest.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It had several tax increases phased in over a period of time -- there are two more yet to come between now and 1989.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: At the same time every year, it increased the amount of money -- virtually every year, there may have been one or two that were skipped in there -- that was subject to that tax.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Today it is up to about $38,000 of earnings that is subject to the payroll tax for Social Security.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And that tax, there are no deductions, so a person making anywhere from 10, 15, 20 -- they're paying that tax on the full gross earnings that they have after they have already paid an income tax on that same amount of money.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, I don't think that to try and say that we were taxing the rich, and not the other way around, it just doesn't work out that way.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The system is still where it was with regard to the progressivity, as I've said, and that has not been changed.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But if you take it in numbers of dollars instead of percentage, yes, you could say, well, that person got 10 times as much as this other person.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Yes, but he paid 10 times as much, also.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But if you take it in percentages, then you find out that it is fair and equitable across the board.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Yes, I had used -- "last resort'' would always be with me.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: If you got the Government down to the lowest level, that you yourself could say it could not go any lower and still perform the services for the people, and if the recovery was so complete that you knew you were getting the ultimate amount of revenues that you could get through that growth, and there was still some slight difference there between those two lines, then I had said once that, yes, you would have to then look to see if taxes should not be adjusted.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I don't foresee those things happening, so I say with great confidence I'm not going to go for a tax.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: With regard to assailing Mr. Bush about his tax problems and the difference from the tax he once paid and then the later tax he paid, I think if you looked at the deductions, there were great legal expenses in there -- had to do, possibly, with the sale of his home, and they had to do with his setting up of a blind trust.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: All of those are legally deductions, deductible in computing your tax, and it was a 1-year thing with him.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Well, first of all, I gave him the benefit of the doubt on the house deal.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I'm just talking about the 12.8 percent that he paid, and that's what's happening all over this country with wealthy Americans.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: They've got so many loopholes they don't have to pay much in taxes.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Now, Mr. President, you said, "There you go again,'' right?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: You said it when President Carter said that you were going to cut Medicare, and you said, "Oh, no, there you go again, Mr.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And what did you do right after the election?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: You went out and tried to cut $20 billion out of Medicare.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And so, when you say, "There you go again'' -- people remember this, you know.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: [Laughter] And people will remember that you signed the biggest tax increase in the history of California and the biggest tax increase in the history of the United States, and what are you going to do?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: You've got a $260 billion deficit.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: You won't slow defense spending; you refuse to do that -- --
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: With regard to Medicare, no, but it's time for us to say that Medicare is in pretty much the same condition that Social Security was, and something is going to have to be done in the next several years to make it fiscally sound.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And, no, I never proposed any $20 billion should come out of Medicare; I have proposed that the program we must treat with that particular problem.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And maybe part of that problem is because during the 4 years of the Carter-Mondale administration medical costs in this country went up 87 percent.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I gave you back some of that time.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Well, some of those facts and figures just don't stand up.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Yes, there has been an increase in poverty, but it is a lower rate of increase than it was in the preceding years before we got here.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It has begun to decline, but it is still going up.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have found also in our studies that in this increase in poverty, it all had to do with their private earnings.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It had nothing to do with the transfer of payments from government by way of many programs.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We're spending a third more on all of the -- well, all of the programs of human service.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have more people receiving food stamps than were ever receiving them before -- 2,300,000 more are receiving them -- even though we took 850,000 off the food stamp rolls because they were making an income that was above anything that warranted their fellow citizens having to support them.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We found people making 185 percent of the poverty level were getting government benefits.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have set a line at 130 percent so that we can direct that aid down to the truly needy.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Some time ago, Mr. Mondale said something about education and college students and help of that kind.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But there, again, we found people that there under the previous administration, families that had no limit to income were still eligible for low-interest college loans.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We didn't think that was right.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And so, we have set a standard that those loans and those grants are directed to the people who otherwise could not go to college, their family incomes were so low.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So, there are a host of other figures that reveal that the grant programs are greater than they have ever been, taking care of more people than they ever have.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: 7.7 million elderly citizens who were living in the lowest 20 percent of earnings -- 7.7 million have moved up into another bracket since our administration took over, leaving only 5 million of the elderly in that bracket when there had been more than 13 million.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I remember distinctly, I was segueing into another subject.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I was talking about the things that have been accomplished, and that was referring to the revival of patriotism and optimism, the new spirit that we're finding all over America.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And it is a wonderful thing to see when you get out there among the people.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So, that was the only place that that was used.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I did avoid, I'm afraid, in my previous answer, also, the idea of uneven, yes.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: There is no way that the recovery is even across the country, just as in the depths of the recession, there were some parts of the country that were worse off, but some that didn't even feel the pain of the recession.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We're not going to rest and not going to be happy until every person in this country who wants a job can have one, until the recovery is complete across the country.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Number one, we've got to get the debt down to get the interest rates down so the economy will grow and people will be employed.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Number two, we have to work with cities and others to help generate economic growth in those communities -- through the Urban Development Action Grant Program.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I don't mind those enterprise zones; let's try them, but not as a substitute for the others.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: If these young Americans don't have the skills that make them attractive to employees, they're not going to get jobs.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The next thing is to try to get more entrepreneurship in business within the reach of minorities so that these businesses are located in the communities in which they're found.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The other thing is, we need the business community as well as government heavily involved in these communities to try to get economic growth.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: There is no question that the poor are worse off.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But the figures show that about 8 million more people are below the poverty line than 4 years ago.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: How you can cut school lunches, how you can cut student assistance, how you can cut housing, how you can cut disability benefits, how you can do all of these things and then the people receiving them -- for example, the disabled, who have no alternative -- how they're going to do better, I don't know.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Now, we need a tight budget, but there's no question that this administration has singled out things that affect the most vulnerable in American life, and they're hurting.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: One final point if I might.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: There's another part of the lopsided economy that we're in today, and that is that these heavy deficits have killed exports and are swamping the Nation with cheap imports.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That's another reason to get the deficit down.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I think they stand for civil rights.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I know they're all for education in science and training, which I strongly support.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: They want these young people to have a chance to get jobs and the rest.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I think the business community wants to get involved.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I think they're asking for new and creative ways to try to reach it with everyone involved.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I think that's part of it.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I think also that the American people want a balanced program that gives us long-term growth so that they're not having to take money that's desperate to themselves and their families and give it to someone else.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I'm opposed to that, too.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The connection that's been made again between the deficit and the interest rates -- there is no connection between them.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: There is a connection between interest rates and inflation, but I would call to your attention that in 1981 while we were operating still on the Carter-Mondale budget that we inherited -- that the interest rates came down from 211/2, down toward the 12 or 13 figure.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And while they were coming down, the deficits had started their great increase.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, if there was a connection I think that there would be a different parallel between deficits getting larger and interest rates going down.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The interest rates are based on inflation.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And right now I have to tell you I don't think there is any excuse for the interest rates being as high as they are because we have brought inflation down so low.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think it can only be that they're anticipating or hope -- expecting, not hoping, that maybe we don't have a control of inflation and it's going to go back up again.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Well, it isn't going to go back up.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We're going to see that it doesn't.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I haven't got time to answer with regard to the disabled.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Mr. President, if I heard you correctly, you said that these deficits don't have anything to do with interest rates.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I will grant you that interest rates were too high in 1980, and we can have another debate as to why -- energy prices and so on.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But when these huge deficits went in place in 1981, what's called the real interest rates -- the spread between inflation and what a loan costs you doubled -- and that's still the case today.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And the result is interest costs that have never been seen before in terms of real charges, and it's attributable to the deficit.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Everybody -- every economist, every businessman -- believes that.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Your own Council of Economic Advisers -- Mr. Feldstein in his report told you that.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Every chairman of the Finance and Ways and Means Committee, Republican leaders in the Senate and the House are telling you that.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That deficit is ruining the long-term hopes for this economy.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It's causing high interest rates.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It's ruining us in trade.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It's given us the highest small business failure in 50 years.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The economy is starting downhill with housing failure -- --
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Do you want to give me some suggestions?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: [Laughter] I'm going to use my time a little differently.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I'm going to give the President some credit.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I think the President has done some things to raise the sense of spirit, morale, good feeling in this country, and he's entitled to credit for that.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: What I think we need, however, is not just that but to move forward, not just congratulating ourselves but challenging ourselves to get on with the business of dealing with America's problems.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I think in education, when he lectured the country about the importance of discipline, I didn't like it at first, but I think it helped a little bit.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And this is not personal -- there are deep differences about our future, and that's the basis of my campaign.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Without any doubt, I have stood up and told the American people that that $263 billion deficit must come down.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And I've done what no candidate for President has ever done, I told you before the election what I'd do.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Mr. Reagan, as you saw tonight -- President Reagan takes the position it will disappear by magic.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It was once called voodoo economics.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I wish the President would say: Yes, the CBO is right.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Yes, we have a $263 billion deficit.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: This is how I'm going to get it done.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Don't talk about growth, because even though we need growth, that's not helping.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It's going to go in the other direction, as they've estimated.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And give us a plan.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Whose taxes will you raise?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Are you going to go after Social Security and Medicare and student assistance and the handicapped again as you did last time?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: If you'd just tell us what you're going to do, then the American people could compare my plan for the future with your plan.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And that's the way it should be.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The American people would be in charge.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Well, now, I have to start with a smile, since his kind words to me.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And that is the continued discussion and claim that somehow I am the villain who is going to pull the Social Security checks out from those people who are dependent on them.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And why I think it is outrageous -- first of all, it isn't true.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But why it is outrageous is because, for political advantage, every time they do that, they scare millions of senior citizens who are totally dependent on Social Security, have no place else to turn.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And they have to live and go to bed at night thinking, "Is this true?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Is someone going to take our check away from us and leave us destitute?''
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I don't think that that should be a part of political dialog.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, to -- I still -- I just have a minute here?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, Social Security, let's lay it to rest once and for all.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I told you never would I do such a thing.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But I tell you also now, Social Security has nothing to do with the deficit.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Social Security is totally funded by the payroll tax levied on employer and employee.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: If you reduce the out-go of Social Security, that money would not go into the general fund to reduce a deficit.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It would go into the Social Security Trust Fund.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So, Social Security has nothing to do with balancing a budget or erasing or lowering the deficit.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, again, to get to whether I am depending on magic, I think I have talked in straight economic terms about a program of recovery that I was told wouldn't work.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And then, after it worked, I was told that lowering taxes would increase inflation.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And none of these things happened.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It is working, and we're going to continue on that same line.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: As to what we might do, and find in further savings cuts, no, we're not going to starve the hungry.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But we have 2,478 specific recommendations from a commission of more than 2,000 business people in this country, through the Grace commission, that we're studying right now -- and we've already implemented 17 percent of them -- that are recommendations as to how to make government more efficient, more economic.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Why the deficits are so much of a problem for him now, but that in 1976, when the deficit was $52 billion and everyone was panicking about that, he said, no, that he thought it ought to be bigger, because a bigger deficit would stimulate the economy and would help do away with unemployment.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: In 1979 he made similar statements, the same effect, that the deficits -- there was nothing wrong with having deficits.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Remember, there was a trillion dollars in debt before we got here.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: That's got to be paid by our children and grandchildren, too, if we don't do it.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I'm hoping we can start some payments on it before we get through here.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: That's why I want another 4 years.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Well, we've just finished almost the whole debate.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And the American people don't have the slightest clue about what President Reagan will do about these deficits.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: [Laughter] And yet, that's the most important single issue of our time.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But I will say as a Democrat, I was a real piker, Mr. President.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: In 1979 we ran a $29 billion deficit all year.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: This administration seems to run that every morning.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And the result is exactly what we see.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: This economy is starting to run downhill.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Last report on new purchases, it's the lowest since 1982.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Growth is a little over 3 percent now.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Many people are predicting a recession.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And the flow of imports into this country is swamping the American people.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We've got to deal with this problem, and those of us who want to be your President should tell you now what we're going to do, so you can make a judgment.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: No, I might as well just go with -- --
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Well, we'll include it in that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Four years ago, in similar circumstances to this, I asked you, the American people, a question.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I asked: "Are you better off than you were 4 years before?''
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The answer to that obviously was no, and as the result, I was elected to this office and promised a new beginning.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, maybe I'm expected to ask that same question again.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I'm not going to, because I think that all of you -- or not everyone, those people that are in those pockets of poverty and haven't caught up, they couldn't answer the way I would want them to -- but I think that most of the people in this country would say, yes, they are better off than they were 4 years ago.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The question, I think, should be enlarged.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I believe the answer to that has to also be "yes.''
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I promised a new beginning.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So far, it is only a beginning.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: If the job were finished, I might have thought twice about seeking reelection for this job.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The first half of '84 it's up 81/2 percent.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Productivity in the first half of 1980 was down a minus 2 percent.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Personal earnings after taxes per capita have gone up almost $3,000 in these 4 years.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: In 1980 -- or 1979, a person with a fixed income of $8,000 was $500 above the poverty line, and this maybe explains why there are the numbers still in poverty.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: By 1980 that same person was $500 below the poverty line.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have restored much of our economy.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: With regard to business investment, it is higher than it has been since 1949.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So, there seems to be no shortage of investment capital.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have, as I said, cut the taxes, but we have reduced inflation, and for 2 years now it has stayed down there, not at double digit, but in the range of 4 or below.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We believe that we had also promised that we would make our country more secure.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Yes, we have an increase in the defense budget.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But back then we had planes that couldn't fly for lack of spare parts or pilots.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We had navy vessels that couldn't leave harbor because of lack of crew or, again, lack of spare parts.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Today we're well on our way to a 600-ship navy.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have 543 at present.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have -- our military, the morale is high.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think the people should understand that two-thirds of the defense budget pays for pay and salary, or pay and pension.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And then you add to that food and wardrobe, and all the other things, and you only have a small portion going for weapons.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But I am determined that if ever our men are called on, they should have the best that we can provide in the manner of tools and weapons.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: There has been reference to expensive spare parts, hammers costing $500.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Well, we are the ones who found those.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think we've given the American people back their spirit.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think there's an optimism in the land and a patriotism, and I think that we're in a position once again to heed the words of Thomas Paine, who said: "We have it in our power to begin the world over again.''
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I want to thank the League of Women Voters and the city of Louisville for hosting this evening's debate.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: He didn't have to, and he did, and we all appreciate it.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The President's favorite question is: Are you better off?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Well, if you're wealthy, you're better off.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: If you're middle income, you're about where you were.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And if you're modest income, you're worse off.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That's what the economists tell us.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But is that really the question that should be asked?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Isn't the real question is will we be better off?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Will our children be better off?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Are we building the future that this nation needs?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I believe that if we ask those questions that bear on our future, not just congratulate ourselves but challenge us to solve those problems, you'll see that we need new leadership.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Are we better of with this arms race?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Will we be better off if we start this star wars escalation into the heavens?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Are we better off when we deemphasize our values in human rights?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Would fathers and mothers feel proud of themselves if they loaded their children with debts like this nation is now -- over a trillion dollars on the shoulders of our children?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Can we say, really say that we will be better off when we pull away from sort of that basic American instinct of decency and fairness?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I would rather lose a campaign about decency than win a campaign about self-interest.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I don't think this nation is composed of people who care only for themselves.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And when we sought to assault Social Security and Medicare, as the record shows we did, I think that was mean-spirited.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: When we terminated 400,000 desperate, hopeless, defenseless Americans who were on disability -- confused and unable to defend themselves, and just laid them out on the street, as we did for 4 years, I don't think that's what America is all about.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: America is a fair society, and it is not right that Vice President Bush pays less in taxes than the janitor who helps him.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I believe there's fundamental fairness crying out that needs to be achieved in our tax system.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I believe that we will be better off if we protect this environment.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And contrary to what the President says, I think their record on the environment is inexcusable and often shameful.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: These laws are not being enforced, have not been enforced, and the public health and the air and the water are paying the price.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That's not fair for our future.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I think our future requires a President to lead us in an all-out search to advance our education, our learning, and our science and training, because this world is more complex and we're being pressed harder all the time.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I believe in opening doors.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We won the Olympics, in part, because we've had civil rights laws and the laws that prohibit discrimination against women.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I have been for those efforts all my life.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The President's record is quite different.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The question is our future.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: President Kennedy once said in response to similar arguments, "We are great, but we can be greater.''
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We can be better if we face our future, rejoice in our strengths, face our problems, and by solving them, build a better society for our children.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But before I answer further, let me thank you for moderating.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I want to thank the University of Miami for hosting us.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I know the president will join me in welcoming all of Florida to this debate.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You've been through the roughest weeks anybody could imagine.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Our hearts go out to you.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we admire your pluck and perseverance.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I can make American safer than President Bush has made us.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I believe President Bush and I both love our country equally.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But we just have a different set of convictions about how you make America safe.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I believe America is safest and strongest when we are leading the world and we are leading strong alliances.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'll never give a veto to any country over our security.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But I also know how to lead those alliances.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think that's wrong, and I think we can do better.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I have a better plan for homeland security.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I have a better plan to be able to fight the war on terror by strengthening our military, strengthening our intelligence, by going after the financing more authoritatively, by doing what we need to do to rebuild the alliances, by reaching out to the Muslim world, which the president has almost not done, and beginning to isolate the radical Islamic Muslims, not have them isolate the United States of America.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I know I can do a better job in Iraq.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I have a plan to have a summit with all of the allies, something this president has not yet achieved, not yet been able to do to bring people to the table.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We can do a better job of training the Iraqi forces to defend themselves, and I know that we can do a better job of preparing for elections.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: All of these, and especially homeland security, which we'll talk about a little bit later.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I, too, thank the University of Miami, and say our prayers are with the good people of this state, who've suffered a lot.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: September the 11th changed how America must look at the world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And since that day, our nation has been on a multi-pronged strategy to keep our country safer.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We pursued Al Qaida wherever Al Qaida tries to hide.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Seventy-five percent of known Al Qaida leaders have been brought to justice.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The rest of them know we're after them.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've upheld the doctrine that said if you harbor a terrorist, you're equally as guilty as the terrorist.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And the Taliban are no longer in power.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Ten million people have registered to vote in Afghanistan in the upcoming presidential election.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In Iraq, we saw a threat, and we realized that after September the 11th, we must take threats seriously, before they fully materialize.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Saddam Hussein now sits in a prison cell.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: America and the world are safer for it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We continue to pursue our policy of disrupting those who proliferate weapons of mass destruction.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Khan network has been brought to justice.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And, as well, we're pursuing a strategy of freedom around the world, because I understand free nations will reject terror.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Free nations will answer the hopes and aspirations of their people.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Free nations will help us achieve the peace we all want.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: No, I don't believe it's going to happen.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe I'm going to win, because the American people know I know how to lead.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've shown the American people I know how to lead.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I have -- I understand everybody in this country doesn't agree with the decisions I've made.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I made some tough decisions.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But people know where I stand.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's how best it is to keep the peace.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This nation of ours has got a solemn duty to defeat this ideology of hate.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's what they are.
