Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This is a group of killers who will not only kill here, but kill children in Russia, that'll attack unmercifully in Iraq, hoping to shake our will.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We have a duty to defeat this enemy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We have a duty to protect our children and grandchildren.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The best way to defeat them is to never waver, to be strong, to use every asset at our disposal, is to constantly stay on the offensive and, at the same time, spread liberty.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's what people are seeing now is happening in Afghanistan.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Ten million citizens have registered to vote.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That if given a chance to be free, they will show up at the polls.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Forty-one percent of those 10 million are women.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In Iraq, no doubt about it, it's tough.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Because an enemy realizes the stakes.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The enemy understands a free Iraq will be a major defeat in their ideology of hatred.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's why they're fighting so vociferously.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They showed up in Afghanistan when they were there, because they tried to beat us and they didn't.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And they're showing up in Iraq for the same reason.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They're trying to defeat us.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And if we lose our will, we lose.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But if we remain strong and resolute, we will defeat this enemy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe in being strong and resolute and determined.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I will hunt down and kill the terrorists, wherever they are.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But we also have to be smart, Jim.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And smart means not diverting your attention from the real war on terror in Afghanistan against Osama bin Laden and taking if off to Iraq where the 9/11 Commission confirms there was no connection to 9/11 itself and Saddam Hussein, and where the reason for going to war was weapons of mass destruction, not the removal of Saddam Hussein.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: This president has made, I regret to say, a colossal error of judgment.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And judgment is what we look for in the president of the United States of America.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm proud that important military figures who are supporting me in this race: former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff John Shalikashvili; just yesterday, General Eisenhower's son, General John Eisenhower, endorsed me; General Admiral William Crown; General Tony McBeak, who ran the Air Force war so effectively for his father -- all believe I would make a stronger commander in chief.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And they believe it because they know I would not take my eye off of the goal: Osama bin Laden.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Unfortunately, he escaped in the mountains of Tora Bora.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But we didn't use American forces, the best trained in the world, to go kill him.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president relied on Afghan warlords and he outsourced that job too.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Well, where do you want me to begin?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: First of all, he made the misjudgment of saying to America that he was going to build a true alliance, that he would exhaust the remedies of the United Nations and go through the inspections.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: In fact, he first didn't even want to do that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And it wasn't until former Secretary of State Jim Baker and General Scowcroft and others pushed publicly and said you've got to go to the U.N., that the president finally changed his mind -- his campaign has a word for that -- and went to the United Nations.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, once there, we could have continued those inspections.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We had Saddam Hussein trapped.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He also promised America that he would go to war as a last resort.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Those words mean something to me, as somebody who has been in combat.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You've got to be able to look in the eyes of families and say to those parents, "I tried to do everything in my power to prevent the loss of your son and daughter."
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I don't believe the United States did that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we pushed our allies aside.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And so, today, we are 90 percent of the casualties and 90 percent of the cost: $200 billion -- $200 billion that could have been used for health care, for schools, for construction, for prescription drugs for seniors, and it's in Iraq.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And Iraq is not even the center of the focus of the war on terror.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The center is Afghanistan, where, incidentally, there were more Americans killed last year than the year before; where the opium production is 75 percent of the world's opium production; where 40 to 60 percent of the economy of Afghanistan is based on opium; where the elections have been postponed three times.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president moved the troops, so he's got 10 times the number of troops in Iraq than he has in Afghanistan, where Osama bin Laden is.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Does that mean that Saddam Hussein was 10 times more important than Osama bin Laden -- than, excuse me, Saddam Hussein more important than Osama bin Laden?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: My opponent looked at the same intelligence I looked at and declared in 2002 that Saddam Hussein was a grave threat.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He also said in December of 2003 that anyone who doubts that the world is safer without Saddam Hussein does not have the judgment to be president.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The world is better off without Saddam Hussein.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I was hoping diplomacy would work.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I understand the serious consequences of committing our troops into harm's way.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So I went to the United Nations.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I didn't need anybody to tell me to go to the United Nations.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I decided to go there myself.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I went there hoping that, once and for all, the free world would act in concert to get Saddam Hussein to listen to our demands.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They passed the resolution that said, "Disclose, disarm, or face serious consequences."
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe, when an international body speaks, it must mean what it says.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Saddam Hussein had no intention of disarming.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He had 16 other resolutions and nothing took place.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: As a matter of fact, my opponent talks about inspectors.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The facts are that he was systematically deceiving the inspectors.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That wasn't going to work.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's kind of a pre-September 10th mentality, the hope that somehow resolutions and failed inspections would make this world a more peaceful place.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He was hoping we'd turn away.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But there was fortunately others beside myself who believed that we ought to take action.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The world is safer without Saddam Hussein.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Jim, we've got the capability of doing both.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: As a matter of fact, this is a global effort.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're facing a group of folks who have such hatred in their heart, they'll strike anywhere, with any means.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's why it's essential that we have strong alliances, and we do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's why it's essential that we make sure that we keep weapons of mass destruction out of the hands of people like Al Qaida, which we are.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But to say that there's only one focus on the war on terror doesn't really understand the nature of the war on terror.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Of course we're after Saddam Hussein -- I mean bin Laden.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Seventy-five percent of his people have been brought to justice.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The killer -- the mastermind of the September 11th attacks, Khalid Sheik Mohammed, is in prison.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But the front on this war is more than just one place.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The Philippines -- we've got help -- we're helping them there to bring -- to bring Al Qaida affiliates to justice there.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And, of course, Iraq is a central part in the war on terror.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's why Zarqawi and his people are trying to fight us.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Their hope is that we grow weary and we leave.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The biggest disaster that could happen is that we not succeed in Iraq.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've got a plan to do so.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And the main reason we'll succeed is because the Iraqis want to be free.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I had the honor of visiting with Prime Minister Allawi.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He's a strong, courageous leader.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He doesn't want U.S. leadership, however, to send mixed signals, to not stand with the Iraqi people.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He believes, like I believe, that the Iraqis are ready to fight for their own freedom.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There will be elections in January.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And our alliance is strong.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's the plan for victory.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And when Iraq if free, America will be more secure.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The president just talked about Iraq as a center of the war on terror.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Iraq was not even close to the center of the war on terror before the president invaded it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president made the judgment to divert forces from under General Tommy Franks from Afghanistan before the Congress even approved it to begin to prepare to go to war in Iraq.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And he rushed the war in Iraq without a plan to win the peace.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, that is not the judgment that a president of the United States ought to make.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You don't take America to war unless have the plan to win the peace.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You don't send troops to war without the body armor that they need.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've met kids in Ohio, parents in Wisconsin places, Iowa, where they're going out on the Internet to get the state-of-the-art body gear to send to their kids.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Some of them got it for a birthday present.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Humvees -- 10,000 out of 12,000 Humvees that are over there aren't armored.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And you go visit some of those kids in the hospitals today who were maimed because they don't have the armament.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But it's getting worse by the day.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: More soldiers killed in June than before.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: More in July than June.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: More in August than July.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: More in September than in August.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And now we see beheadings.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we got weapons of mass destruction crossing the border every single day, and they're blowing people up.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we don't have enough troops there.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Can I respond to that?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: First of all, what my opponent wants you to forget is that he voted to authorize the use of force and now says it's the wrong war at the wrong time at the wrong place.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't see how you can lead this country to succeed in Iraq if you say wrong war, wrong time, wrong place.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: What message does that send our troops?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: What message does that send to our allies?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: What message does that send the Iraqis?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: No, the way to win this is to be steadfast and resolved and to follow through on the plan that I've just outlined.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Yes, we have to be steadfast and resolved, and I am.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I will succeed for those troops, now that we're there.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We can't leave a failed Iraq.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But that doesn't mean it wasn't a mistake of judgment to go there and take the focus off of Osama bin Laden.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But I don't believe this president can.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think we need a president who has the credibility to bring the allies back to the table and to do what's necessary to make it so America isn't doing this alone.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Jim, let me tell you exactly what I'll do.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And there are a long list of thing.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: First of all, what kind of mixed message does it send when you have $500 million going over to Iraq to put police officers in the streets of Iraq, and the president is cutting the COPS program in America?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: What kind of message does it send to be sending money to open firehouses in Iraq, but we're shutting firehouses who are the first- responders here in America.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president hasn't put one nickel, not one nickel into the effort to fix some of our tunnels and bridges and most exposed subway systems.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's why they had to close down the subway in New York when the Republican Convention was there.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We hadn't done the work that ought to be done.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president -- 95 percent of the containers that come into the ports, right here in Florida, are not inspected.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Civilians get onto aircraft, and their luggage is X-rayed, but the cargo hold is not X- rayed.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Does that make you feel safer in America?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: This president thought it was more important to give the wealthiest people in America a tax cut rather than invest in homeland security.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I believe in protecting America first.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And long before President Bush and I get a tax cut -- and that's who gets it -- long before we do, I'm going to invest in homeland security and I'm going to make sure we're not cutting COPS programs in America and we're fully staffed in our firehouses and that we protect the nuclear and chemical plants.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president also unfortunately gave in to the chemical industry, which didn't want to do some of the things necessary to strengthen our chemical plant exposure.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And there's an enormous undone job to protect the loose nuclear materials in the world that are able to get to terrorists.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's a whole other subject, but I see we still have a little bit more time.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Let me just quickly say, at the current pace, the president will not secure the loose material in the Soviet Union -- former Soviet Union for 13 years.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm going to do it in four years.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we're going to keep it out of the hands of terrorists.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I don't think we want to get to how he's going to pay for all these promises.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's like a huge tax gap.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Anyway, that's for another debate.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My administration has tripled the amount of money we're spending on homeland security to $30 billion a year.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My administration worked with the Congress to create the Department of Homeland Security so we could better coordinate our borders and ports.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've got 1,000 extra border patrol on the southern border; want 1,000 on the northern border.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We spent $3.1 billion for fire and police, $3.1 billion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're doing our duty to provide the funding.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But the best way to protect this homeland is to stay on the offense.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You know, we have to be right 100 percent of the time.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And the enemy only has to be right once to hurt us.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There's a lot of good people working hard.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And by the way, we've also changed the culture of the FBI to have counterterrorism as its number one priority.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're going to reform our intelligence services to make sure that we get the best intelligence possible.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The Patriot Act is vital -- is vital that the Congress renew the Patriot Act which enables our law enforcement to disrupt terror cells.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But again, I repeat to my fellow citizens, the best way to protection is to stay on the offense.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The president just said the FBI had changed its culture.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We just read on the front pages of America's papers that there are over 100,000 hours of tapes, unlistened to.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: On one of those tapes may be the enemy being right the next time.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And the test is not whether you're spending more money.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The test is, are you doing everything possible to make America safe?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We didn't need that tax cut.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: America needed to be safe.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Of course we're doing everything we can to protect America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I wake up every day thinking about how best to protect America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I work with Director Mueller of the FBI; comes in my office when I'm in Washington every morning, talking about how to protect us.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There's a lot of really good people working hard to do so.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Let me first tell you that the best way for Iraq to be safe and secure is for Iraqi citizens to be trained to do the job.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's what we're doing.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've got 100,000 trained now, 125,000 by the end of this year, 200,000 by the end of next year.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That is the best way.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We'll never succeed in Iraq if the Iraqi citizens do not want to take matters into their own hands to protect themselves.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe they want to.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Prime Minister Allawi believes they want to.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so the best indication about when we can bring our troops home -- which I really want to do, but I don't want to do so for the sake of bringing them home; I want to do so because we've achieved an objective -- is to see the Iraqis perform and to see the Iraqis step up and take responsibility.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so, the answer to your question is: When our general is on the ground and Ambassador Negroponte tells me that Iraq is ready to defend herself from these terrorists, that elections will have been held by then, that their stability and that they're on their way to, you know, a nation that's free; that's when.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I hope it's as soon as possible.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I know putting artificial deadlines won't work.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My opponent at one time said, "Well, get me elected, I'll have them out of there in six months."
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You can't do that and expect to win the war on terror.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My message to our troops is, "Thank you for what you're doing.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're standing with you strong.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We'll give you all the equipment you need.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we'll get you home as soon as the mission's done, because this is a vital mission."
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: A free Iraq will be an ally in the war on terror, and that's essential.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: A free Iraq will set a powerful example in the part of the world that is desperate for freedom.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: A free Iraq will help secure Israel.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: A free Iraq will enforce the hopes and aspirations of the reformers in places like Iran.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: A free Iraq is essential for the security of this country.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My message to the troops is also: Thank you for what they're doing, but it's also help is on the way.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I believe those troops deserve better than what they are getting today.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: When I was in a rope line just the other day, coming out here from Wisconsin, a couple of young returnees were in the line, one active duty, one from the Guard.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And they both looked at me and said: We need you.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You've got to help us over there.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now I believe there's a better way to do this.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You know, the president's father did not go into Iraq, into Baghdad, beyond Basra.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And the reason he didn't is, he said -- he wrote in his book -- because there was no viable exit strategy.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And he said our troops would be occupiers in a bitterly hostile land.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's exactly where we find ourselves today.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: There's a sense of American occupation.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The only building that was guarded when the troops when into Baghdad was the oil ministry.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We didn't guard the nuclear facilities.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We didn't guard the foreign office, where you might have found information about weapons of mass destruction.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We didn't guard the borders.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Almost every step of the way, our troops have been left on these extraordinarily difficult missions.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I know what it's like to go out on one of those missions when you don't know what's around the corner.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I believe our troops need other allies helping.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm going to hold that summit.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I will bring fresh credibility, a new start, and we will get the job done right.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think it's worthy for a follow-up.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My opponent says help is on the way, but what kind of message does it say to our troops in harm's way, "wrong war, wrong place, wrong time"?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Not a message a commander in chief gives, or this is a "great diversion."
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: As well, help is on the way, but it's certainly hard to tell it when he voted against the $87-billion supplemental to provide equipment for our troops, and then said he actually did vote for it before he voted against it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Not what a commander in chief does when you're trying to lead troops.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, you know, when I talked about the $87 billion, I made a mistake in how I talk about the war.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But the president made a mistake in invading Iraq.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I believe that when you know something's going wrong, you make it right.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's what I learned in Vietnam.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: When I came back from that war I saw that it was wrong.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Some people don't like the fact that I stood up to say no, but I did.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And that's what I did with that vote.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I'm going to lead those troops to victory.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: No, and they don't have to, providing we have the leadership that we put -- that I'm offering.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I believe that we have to win this.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president and I have always agreed on that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And from the beginning, I did vote to give the authority, because I thought Saddam Hussein was a threat, and I did accept that intelligence.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But I also laid out a very strict series of things we needed to do in order to proceed from a position of strength.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Then the president, in fact, promised them.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He went to Cincinnati and he gave a speech in which he said, "We will plan carefully.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We will not make war inevitable.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We will go with our allies."
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He didn't do any of those things.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They didn't do the planning.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They left the planning of the State Department in the State Department desks.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They avoided even the advice of their own general.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: General Shinsheki, the Army chief of staff, said you're going to need several hundred thousand troops.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Instead of listening to him, they retired him.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The terrorism czar, who has worked for every president since Ronald Reagan, said, "Invading Iraq in response to 9/11 would be like Franklin Roosevelt invading Mexico in response to Pearl Harbor."
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's what we have here.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And what we need now is a president who understands how to bring these other countries together to recognize their stakes in this.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They do have stakes in it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They've always had stakes in it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The Arab countries have a stake in not having a civil war.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The European countries have a stake in not having total disorder on their doorstep.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But this president hasn't even held the kind of statesman-like summits that pull people together and get them to invest in those states.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: In fact, he's done the opposite.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: When the Secretary General Kofi Annan offered the United Nations, he said, "No, no, we'll go do this alone."
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: To save for Halliburton the spoils of the war, they actually issued a memorandum from the Defense Department saying, "If you weren't with us in the war, don't bother applying for any construction."
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's not a way to invite people.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Of course, the U.N. was invited in.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we support the U.N. efforts there.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They pulled out after Sergio de Mello got killed.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But they're now back in helping with elections.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My opponent says we didn't have any allies in this war.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: What's he say to Tony Blair?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: What's he say to Alexander Kwasniewski of Poland?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You can't expect to build an alliance when you denigrate the contributions of those who are serving side by side with American troops in Iraq.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Plus, he says the cornerstone of his plan to succeed in Iraq is to call upon nations to serve.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So what's the message going to be: "Please join us in Iraq.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Join us for a war that is the wrong war at the wrong place at the wrong time?"
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I know how these people think.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I deal with them all the time.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I sit down with the world leaders frequently and talk to them on the phone frequently.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They're not going to follow somebody who says, "This is the wrong war at the wrong place at the wrong time."
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They're not going to follow somebody who says this is the wrong war at the wrong place at the wrong time.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They're not going to follow somebody whose core convictions keep changing because of politics in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And finally, he says we ought to have a summit.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, there are summits being held.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Japan is going to have a summit for the donors; $14 billion pledged.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And Prime Minister Koizumi is going to call countries to account, to get them to contribute.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And there's going to be an Arab summit, of the neighborhood countries.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And Colin Powell helped set up that summit.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The United Nations, Kofi Annan offered help after Baghdad fell.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we never picked him up on that and did what was necessary to transfer authority and to transfer reconstruction.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Secondly, when we went in, there were three countries: Great Britain, Australia and the United States.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's not a grand coalition.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Well, actually, he forgot Poland.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And now there's 30 nations involved, standing side by side with our American troops.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I honor their sacrifices.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I don't appreciate it when a candidate for president denigrates the contributions of these brave soldiers.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You cannot lead the world if you do not honor the contributions of those who are with us.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He called them coerced and the bribed.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's not how you bring people together.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It will remain strong, so long as I'm the president.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: No, what I said was that, because we achieved such a rapid victory, more of the Saddam loyalists were around.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I mean, we thought we'd whip more of them going in.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But because Tommy Franks did such a great job in planning the operations, we moved rapidly, and a lot of the Baathists and Saddam loyalists laid down their arms and disappeared.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I thought they would stay and fight, but they didn't.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And now we're fighting them now.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I see on the TV screens how hard it is.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: See, I think you can be realistic and optimistic at the same time.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm optimistic we'll achieve -- I know we won't achieve if we send mixed signals.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I know we're not going to achieve our objective if we send mixed signals to our troops, our friends, the Iraqi citizens.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've got a plan in place.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The plan says there will be elections in January, and there will be.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The plan says we'll train Iraqi soldiers so they can do the hard work, and we are.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And it's not only just America, but NATO is now helping, Jordan's helping train police, UAE is helping train police.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've allocated $7 billion over the next months for reconstruction efforts.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we're making progress there.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And our alliance is strong.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And as I just told you, there's going to be a summit of the Arab nations.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Japan will be hosting a summit.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It is hard work to go from a tyranny to a democracy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's hard work to go from a place where people get their hands cut off, or executed, to a place where people are free.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And a free Iraq is going to make this world a more peaceful place.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: What I think troubles a lot of people in our country is that the president has just sort of described one kind of mistake.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But what he has said is that, even knowing there were no weapons of mass destruction, even knowing there was no imminent threat, even knowing there was no connection with Al Qaida, he would still have done everything the same way.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: So what I'm trying to do is just talk the truth to the American people and to the world.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The truth is what good policy is based on.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president says that I'm denigrating these troops.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But you can't tell me that when the most troops any other country has on the ground is Great Britain, with 8,300, and below that the four others are below 4,000, and below that, there isn't anybody out of the hundreds, that we have a genuine coalition to get this job done.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You can't tell me that on the day that we went into that war and it started -- it was principally the United States, the America and Great Britain and one or two others.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And today, we are 90 percent of the casualties and 90 percent of the costs.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And meanwhile, North Korea has got nuclear weapons.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president is the one that said, "We can't allow countries to get nuclear weapons."
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Well, I've never, ever used the harshest word, as you did just then.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I try not to.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've been -- but I'll nevertheless tell you that I think he has not been candid with the American people.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I'll tell you exactly how.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: First of all, we all know that in his state of the union message, he told Congress about nuclear materials that didn't exist.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We know that he promised America that he was going to build this coalition.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I just described the coalition.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It is not the kind of coalition we were described when we were talking about voting for this.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president said he would exhaust the remedies of the United Nations and go through that full process.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He cut if off, sort of arbitrarily.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we know that there were further diplomatic efforts under way.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They just decided the time for diplomacy is over and rushed to war without planning for what happens afterwards.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, he misled the American people in his speech when he said we will plan carefully.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He misled the American people when he said we'd go to war as a last resort.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We did not go as a last resort.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And most Americans know the difference.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, this has cost us deeply in the world.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I believe that it is important to tell the truth to the American people.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've worked with those leaders the president talks about, I've worked with them for 20 years, for longer than this president.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I know what many of them say today, and I know how to bring them back to the table.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I believe that a fresh start, new credibility, a president who can understand what we have to do to reach out to the Muslim world to make it clear that this is not, you know -- Osama bin Laden uses the invasion of Iraq in order to go out to people and say that America has declared war on Islam.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We need to be smarter about now we wage a war on terror.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We need to deny them the recruits.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We need to deny them the safe havens.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We need to rebuild our alliances.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I believe that Ronald Reagan, John Kennedy, and the others did that more effectively, and I'm going to try to follow in their footsteps.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: My opponent just said something amazing.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He said Osama bin Laden uses the invasion of Iraq as an excuse to spread hatred for America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Osama bin Laden isn't going to determine how we defend ourselves.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Osama bin Laden doesn't get to decide.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I decided the right action was in Iraq.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My opponent calls it a mistake.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He said I misled on Iraq.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't think he was misleading when he called Iraq a grave threat in the fall of 2002.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't think he was misleading when he said that it was right to disarm Iraq in the spring of 2003.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't think he misled you when he said that, you know, anyone who doubted whether the world was better off without Saddam Hussein in power didn't have the judgment to be president.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't think he was misleading.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think what is misleading is to say you can lead and succeed in Iraq if you keep changing your positions on this war.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: As the politics change, his positions change.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's not how a commander in chief acts.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The intelligence I looked at was the same intelligence my opponent looked at, the very same intelligence.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And when I stood up there and spoke to the Congress, I was speaking off the same intelligence he looked at to make his decisions to support the authorization of force.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I wasn't misleading when I said he was a threat.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Nor was I misleading on the day that the president decided to go to war when I said that he had made a mistake in not building strong alliances and that I would have preferred that he did more diplomacy.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've had one position, one consistent position, that Saddam Hussein was a threat.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: There was a right way to disarm him and a wrong way.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And the president chose the wrong way.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The only thing consistent about my opponent's position is that he's been inconsistent.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And you cannot change positions in this war on terror if you expect to win.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I expect to win.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're being challenged like never before.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we have a duty to our country and to future generations of America to achieve a free Iraq, a free Afghanistan, and to rid the world of weapons of mass destruction.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You know, every life is precious.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You know, my hardest -- the hardest part of the job is to know that I committed the troops in harm's way and then do the best I can to provide comfort for the loved ones who lost a son or a daughter or a husband or wife.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You know, I think about Missy Johnson.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: She's a fantastic lady I met in Charlotte, North Carolina.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: She and her son Bryan, they came to see me.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Her husband PJ got killed.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He'd been in Afghanistan, went to Iraq.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You know, it's hard work to try to love her as best as I can, knowing full well that the decision I made caused her loved one to be in harm's way.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I told her after we prayed and teared up and laughed some that I thought her husband's sacrifice was noble and worthy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Because I understand the stakes of this war on terror.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I understand that we must find Al Qaida wherever they hide.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We must deal with threats before they fully materialize.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And Saddam Hussein was a threat, and that we must spread liberty because in the long run, the way to defeat hatred and tyranny and oppression is to spread freedom.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's what she told me her husband understood.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's what distinguishes us from the enemy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I think it's worth it, Jim.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think it's worth it, because I think -- I know in the long term a free Iraq, a free Afghanistan, will set such a powerful example in a part of the world that's desperate for freedom.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It will help change the world; that we can look back and say we did our duty.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I understand what the president is talking about, because I know what it means to lose people in combat.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And the question, is it worth the cost, reminds me of my own thinking when I came back from fighting in that war.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And it reminds me that it is vital for us not to confuse the war, ever, with the warriors.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And that's one of the reasons why I believe I can get this job done, because I am determined for those soldiers and for those families, for those kids who put their lives on the line.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's the most noble thing that anybody can do.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I want to make sure the outcome honors that nobility.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, we have a choice here.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've laid out a plan by which I think we can be successful in Iraq: with a summit, by doing better training, faster, by cutting -- by doing what we need to do with respect to the U.N. and the elections.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: There's only 25 percent of the people in there.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They can't have an election right now.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president's not getting the job done.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: So the choice for America is, you can have a plan that I've laid out in four points, each of which I can tell you more about or you can go to johnkerry.com and see more of it; or you have the president's plan, which is four words: more of the same.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think my plan is better.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And my plan has a better chance of standing up and fighting for those troops.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I will never let those troops down, and will hunt and kill the terrorists wherever they are.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Yes, I understand what it means to the commander in chief.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And if I were to ever say, "This is the wrong war at the wrong time at the wrong place," the troops would wonder, how can I follow this guy?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You cannot lead the war on terror if you keep changing positions on the war on terror and say things like, "Well, this is just a grand diversion."
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's not a grand diversion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This is an essential that we get it right.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so, the plan he talks about simply won't work.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Secretary of State Colin Powell told this president the Pottery Barn rule: If you break it, you fix it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, if you break it, you made a mistake.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It's the wrong thing to do.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And then you've got to fix it and do something with it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now that's what we have to do.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Soldiers know over there that this isn't being done right yet.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm going to get it right for those soldiers, because it's important to Israel, it's important to America, it's important to the world, it's important to the fight on terror.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But I have a plan to do it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The time line that I've set out -- and again, I want to correct the president, because he's misled again this evening on what I've said.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I didn't say I would bring troops out in six months.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I said, if we do the things that I've set out and we are successful, we could begin to draw the troops down in six months.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I think a critical component of success in Iraq is being able to convince the Iraqis and the Arab world that the United States doesn't have long-term designs on it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: As I understand it, we're building some 14 military bases there now, and some people say they've got a rather permanent concept to them.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: When you guard the oil ministry, but you don't guard the nuclear facilities, the message to a lot of people is maybe, "Wow, maybe they're interested in our oil."
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, the problem is that they didn't think these things through properly.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And these are the things you have to think through.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: What I want to do is change the dynamics on the ground.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And you have to do that by beginning to not back off of the Fallujahs and other places, and send the wrong message to the terrorists.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You have to close the borders.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You've got to show you're serious in that regard.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But you've also got to show that you are prepared to bring the rest of the world in and share the stakes.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I will make a flat statement: The United States of America has no long-term designs on staying in Iraq.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And our goal in my administration would be to get all of the troops out of there with a minimal amount you need for training and logistics as we do in some other countries in the world after a war to be able to sustain the peace.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But that's how we're going to win the peace, by rapidly training the Iraqis themselves.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Even the administration has admitted they haven't done the training, because they came back to Congress a few weeks ago and asked for a complete reprogramming of the money.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now what greater admission is there, 16 months afterwards.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: "Oops, we haven't done the job.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We have to start to spend the money now.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Will you guys give us permission to shift it over into training?"
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: There are 100,000 troops trained, police, guard, special units, border patrol.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There's going to be 125,000 trained by the end of this year.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Yes, we're getting the job done.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Everybody knows it's hard work, because there's a determined enemy that's trying to defeat us.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Now, my opponent says he's going to try to change the dynamics on the ground.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, Prime Minister Allawi was here.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He is the leader of that country.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: When he came, after giving a speech to the Congress, my opponent questioned his credibility.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You can't change the dynamics on the ground if you've criticized the brave leader of Iraq.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One of his campaign people alleged that Prime Minister Allawi was like a puppet.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's no way to treat somebody who's courageous and brave, that is trying to lead his country forward.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The way to make sure that we succeed is to send consistent, sound messages to the Iraqi people that when we give our word, we will keep our word, that we stand with you, that we believe you want to be free.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe that 25 million people, the vast majority, long to have elections.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I reject this notion -- and I'm suggesting my opponent isn't -- I reject the notion that some say that if you're Muslim you can't free, you don't desire freedom.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I disagree, strongly disagree with that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I couldn't agree more that the Iraqis want to be free and that they could be free.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But I think the president, again, still hasn't shown how he's going to go about it the right way.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He has more of the same.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, Prime Minister Allawi came here, and he said the terrorists are pouring over the border.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The national intelligence assessment that was given to the president in July said, best-case scenario, more of the same of what we see today; worst-case scenario, civil war.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The reason why Prime Minister Allawi said they're coming across the border is because he recognizes that this is a central part of the war on terror.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They're fighting us because they're fighting freedom.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They understand that a free Afghanistan or a free Iraq will be a major defeat for them.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And those are the stakes.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's why it is essential we not leave.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's why it's essential we hold the line.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's why it's essential we win.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Under my leadership we're going to win this war in Iraq.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I would hope I never have to.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I understand how hard it is to commit troops.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Never wanted to commit troops.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: When I was running -- when we had the debate in 2000, never dreamt I'd be doing that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But the enemy attacked us, Jim, and I have a solemn duty to protect the American people, to do everything I can to protect us.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think that by speaking clearly and doing what we say and not sending mixed messages, it is less likely we'll ever have to use troops.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It must -- as a last resort.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I was hopeful diplomacy would work in Iraq.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There was no doubt in my mind that Saddam Hussein was hoping that the world would turn a blind eye.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And if he had been in power, in other words, if we would have said, "Let the inspectors work, or let's, you know, hope to talk him out.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Maybe an 18th resolution would work," he would have been stronger and tougher, and the world would have been a lot worse off.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There's just no doubt in my mind we would rue the day, had Saddam Hussein been in power.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So we use diplomacy every chance we get, believe me.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I would hope to never have to use force.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But by speaking clearly and sending messages that we mean what we say, we've affected the world in a positive way.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Libya is now peacefully dismantling its weapons programs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Libya understood that America and others will enforce doctrine and that the world is better for it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So to answer your question, I would hope we never have to.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think by acting firmly and decisively, it will mean it is less likely we have to use force.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Jim, the president just said something extraordinarily revealing and frankly very important in this debate.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: In answer to your question about Iraq and sending people into Iraq, he just said, "The enemy attacked us."
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Saddam Hussein didn't attack us.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Osama bin Laden attacked us.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And when we had Osama bin Laden cornered in the mountains of Tora Bora, 1,000 of his cohorts with him in those mountains.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: With the American military forces nearby and in the field, we didn't use the best trained troops in the world to go kill the world's number one criminal and terrorist.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They outsourced the job to Afghan warlords, who only a week earlier had been on the other side fighting against us, neither of whom trusted each other.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's the enemy that attacked us.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's the enemy that was allowed to walk out of those mountains.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's the enemy that is now in 60 countries, with stronger recruits.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He also said Saddam Hussein would have been stronger.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That is just factually incorrect.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Two-thirds of the country was a no-fly zone when we started this war.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We would have had sanctions.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We would have had the U.N. inspectors.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Saddam Hussein would have been continually weakening.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: If the president had shown the patience to go through another round of resolution, to sit down with those leaders, say, "What do you need, what do you need now, how much more will it take to get you to join us?"
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: we'd be in a stronger place today.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: First of all, of course I know Osama bin Laden attacked us.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And secondly, to think that another round of resolutions would have caused Saddam Hussein to disarm, disclose, is ludicrous, in my judgment.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It just shows a significant difference of opinion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He was hoping to turn a blind eye.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And, yes, he would have been stronger had we not dealt with him.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He had the capability of making weapons, and he would have made weapons.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Thirty-five to forty countries in the world had a greater capability of making weapons at the moment the president invaded than Saddam Hussein.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And while he's been diverted, with 9 out of 10 active duty divisions of our Army, either going to Iraq, coming back from Iraq, or getting ready to go, North Korea's gotten nuclear weapons and the world is more dangerous.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Iran is moving toward nuclear weapons and the world is more dangerous.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The world is more dangerous.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'd have made a better choice.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president always has the right, and always has had the right, for preemptive strike.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That was a great doctrine throughout the Cold War.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And it was always one of the things we argued about with respect to arms control.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: No president, through all of American history, has ever ceded, and nor would I, the right to preempt in any way necessary to protect the United States of America.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But if and when you do it, Jim, you have to do it in a way that passes the test, that passes the global test where your countrymen, your people understand fully why you're doing what you're doing and you can prove to the world that you did it for legitimate reasons.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Here we have our own secretary of state who has had to apologize to the world for the presentation he made to the United Nations.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I mean, we can remember when President Kennedy in the Cuban missile crisis sent his secretary of state to Paris to meet with DeGaulle.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And in the middle of the discussion, to tell them about the missiles in Cuba, he said, "Here, let me show you the photos."
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And DeGaulle waved them off and said, "No, no, no, no.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The word of the president of the United States is good enough for me."
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: How many leaders in the world today would respond to us, as a result of what we've done, in that way?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: So what is at test here is the credibility of the United States of America and how we lead the world.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And Iran and Iraq are now more dangerous -- Iran and North Korea are now more dangerous.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, whether preemption is ultimately what has to happen, I don't know yet.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But I'll tell you this: As president, I'll never take my eye off that ball.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've been fighting for proliferation the entire time -- anti-proliferation the entire time I've been in the Congress.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we've watched this president actually turn away from some of the treaties that were on the table.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You don't help yourself with other nations when you turn away from the global warming treaty, for instance, or when you refuse to deal at length with the United Nations.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You have to earn that respect.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I think we have a lot of earning back to do.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Let me -- I'm not exactly sure what you mean, "passes the global test," you take preemptive action if you pass a global test.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My attitude is you take preemptive action in order to protect the American people, that you act in order to make this country secure.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My opponent talks about me not signing certain treaties.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Let me tell you one thing I didn't sign, and I think it shows the difference of our opinion -- the difference of opinions.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that is, I wouldn't join the International Criminal Court.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This is a body based in The Hague where unaccountable judges and prosecutors can pull our troops or diplomats up for trial.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I wouldn't join it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I understand that in certain capitals around the world that that wasn't a popular move.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But it's the right move not to join a foreign court that could -- where our people could be prosecuted.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My opponent is for joining the International Criminal Court.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I just think trying to be popular, kind of, in the global sense, if it's not in our best interest makes no sense.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm interested in working with our nations and do a lot of it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I'm not going to make decisions that I think are wrong for America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: North Korea, first, I do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Let me say -- I certainly hope so.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Before I was sworn in, the policy of this government was to have bilateral negotiations with North Korea.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we signed an agreement with North Korea that my administration found out that was not being honored by the North Koreans.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so I decided that a better way to approach the issue was to get other nations involved, just besides us.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And in Crawford, Texas, Jiang Zemin and I agreed that the nuclear-weapons-free peninsula, Korean Peninsula, was in his interest and our interest and the world's interest.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so we began a new dialogue with North Korea, one that included not only the United States, but now China.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And China's a got a lot of influence over North Korea, some ways more than we do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: As well, we included South Korea, Japan and Russia.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So now there are five voices speaking to Kim Jong Il, not just one.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so if Kim Jong Il decides again to not honor an agreement, he's not only doing injustice to America, he'd be doing injustice to China, as well.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I think this will work.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's not going to work if we open up a dialogue with Kim Jong Il.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He wants to unravel the six- party talks, or the five-nation coalition that's sending him a clear message.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: On Iran, I hope we can do the same thing, continue to work with the world to convince the Iranian mullahs to abandon their nuclear ambitions.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We worked very closely with the foreign ministers of France, Germany and Great Britain, who have been the folks delivering the message to the mullahs that if you expect to be part of the world of nations, get rid of your nuclear programs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There's a special protocol recently been passed that allows for inspections.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I hope we can do it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we've got a good strategy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: With respect to Iran, the British, French, and Germans were the ones who initiated an effort without the United States, regrettably, to begin to try to move to curb the nuclear possibilities in Iran.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I believe we could have done better.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think the United States should have offered the opportunity to provide the nuclear fuel, test them, see whether or not they were actually looking for it for peaceful purposes.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: If they weren't willing to work a deal, then we could have put sanctions together.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: With respect to North Korea, the real story: We had inspectors and television cameras in the nuclear reactor in North Korea.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Secretary Bill Perry negotiated that under President Clinton.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we knew where the fuel rods were.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we knew the limits on their nuclear power.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Colin Powell, our secretary of state, announced one day that we were going to continue the dialog of working with the North Koreans.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president reversed it publicly while the president of South Korea was here.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And the president of South Korea went back to South Korea bewildered and embarrassed because it went against his policy.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And for two years, this administration didn't talk at all to North Korea.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: While they didn't talk at all, the fuel rods came out, the inspectors were kicked out, the television cameras were kicked out.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And today, there are four to seven nuclear weapons in the hands of North Korea.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That happened on this president's watch.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, that, I think, is one of the most serious, sort of, reversals or mixed messages that you could possibly send.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I want bilateral talks which put all of the issues, from the armistice of 1952, the economic issues, the human rights issues, the artillery disposal issues, the DMZ issues and the nuclear issues on the table.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's exactly what Kim Jong Il wants.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And by the way, the breach on the agreement was not through plutonium.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The breach on the agreement is highly enriched uranium.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's what we caught him doing.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's where he was breaking the agreement.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Secondly, he said -- my opponent said where he worked to put sanctions on Iran -- we've already sanctioned Iran.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We can't sanction them any more.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There are sanctions in place on Iran.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And finally, we were a party to the convention -- to working with Germany, France and Great Britain to send their foreign ministers into Iran.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, I'll tell you exactly why not, but I first want to say something about those sanctions on Iran.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Only the United States put the sanctions on alone, and that's exactly what I'm talking about.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: In order for the sanctions to be effective, we should have been working with the British, French and Germans and other countries.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And that's the difference between the president and me.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And there, again, he sort of slid by the question.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, with respect to Darfur, yes, it is a genocide.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And months ago, many of us were pressing for action.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think the reason that we're not saying send American troops in at this point is severalfold.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Number one, we can do this through the African Union, providing we give them the logistical support.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Right now all the president is providing is humanitarian support.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We need to do more than that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They've got to have the logistical capacity to go in and stop the killing.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And that's going to require more than is on the table today.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I also believe that it is -- one of the reasons we can't do it is we're overextended.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Ask the people in the armed forces today.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We've got Guards and Reserves who are doing double duties.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We've got a backdoor draft taking place in America today: people with stop-loss programs where they're told you can't get out of the military; nine out of our 10 active duty divisions committed to Iraq one way or the other, either going, coming or preparing.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: So this is the way the president has overextended the United States.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's why, in my plan, I add two active duty divisions to the United States Army, not for Iraq, but for our general demands across the globe.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I also intend to double the number of special forces so that we can do the job we need to do with respect fighting the terrorists around the world.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And if we do that, then we have the ability to be able to respond more rapidly.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But I'll tell you this, as president, if it took American forces to some degree to coalesce the African Union, I'd be prepared to do it because we could never allow another Rwanda.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It's a moral responsibility for us and the world.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Back to Iran, just for a second.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It was not my administration that put the sanctions on Iran.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That happened long before I arrived in Washington, D.C.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In terms of Darfur, I agree it's genocide.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And Colin Powell so stated.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We have committed $200 million worth of aid.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're the leading donor in the world to help the suffering people there.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We will commit more over time to help.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We were very much involved at the U.N. on the sanction policy of the Bashir government in the Sudan.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Prior to Darfur, Ambassador Jack Danforth had been negotiating a north-south agreement that we would have hoped would have brought peace to the Sudan.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I agree with my opponent that we shouldn't be committing troops.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We ought to be working with the African Union to do so -- precisely what we did in Liberia.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We helped stabilize the situation with some troops, and when the African Union came, we moved them out.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My hope is that the African Union moves rapidly to help save lives.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And fortunately the rainy season will be ending shortly, which will make it easier to get aid there and help the long-suffering people there.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, first of all, I admire Senator Kerry's service to our country.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I admire the fact that he is a great dad.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I appreciate the fact that his daughters have been so kind to my daughters in what has been a pretty hard experience for, I guess, young girls, seeing their dads out there campaigning.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I admire the fact that he served for 20 years in the Senate.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Although I'm not so sure I admire the record.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I won't hold it against him that he went to Yale.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There's nothing wrong with that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My concerns about the senator is that, in the course of this campaign, I've been listening very carefully to what he says, and he changes positions on the war in Iraq.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He changes positions on something as fundamental as what you believe in your core, in your heart of hearts, is right in Iraq.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You cannot lead if you send mixed messages.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Mixed messages send the wrong signals to our troops.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Mixed messages send the wrong signals to our allies.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Mixed messages send the wrong signals to the Iraqi citizens.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's my biggest concern about my opponent.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I just know how this world works, and that in the councils of government, there must be certainty from the U.S. president.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Of course, we change tactics when need to, but we never change our beliefs, the strategic beliefs that are necessary to protect this country in the world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, first of all, I appreciate enormously the personal comments the president just made.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I share them with him.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think only if you're doing this -- and he's done it more than I have in terms of the presidency -- can you begin to get a sense of what it means to your families.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And so I acknowledge that his daughters -- I've watched them.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've chuckled a few times at some of their comments.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm trying to put a leash on them.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've learned not to do that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: ... and a great first lady.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But we do have differences.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm not going to talk about a difference of character.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I don't think that's my job or my business.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But let me talk about something that the president just sort of finished up with.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Maybe someone would call it a character trait, maybe somebody wouldn't.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But this issue of certainty.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It's one thing to be certain, but you can be certain and be wrong.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It's another to be certain and be right, or to be certain and be moving in the right direction, or be certain about a principle and then learn new facts and take those new facts and put them to use in order to change and get your policy right.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: What I worry about with the president is that he's not acknowledging what's on the ground, he's not acknowledging the realities of North Korea, he's not acknowledging the truth of the science of stem-cell research or of global warming and other issues.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And certainty sometimes can get you in trouble.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Well, I think -- listen, I fully agree that one should shift tactics, and we will, in Iraq.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Our commanders have got all the flexibility to do what is necessary to succeed.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But what I won't do is change my core values because of politics or because of pressure.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And it is one of the things I've learned in the White House, is that there's enormous pressure on the president, and he cannot wilt under that pressure.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Otherwise, the world won't be better off.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I have no intention of wilting.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've never wilted in my life.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I've never wavered in my life.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I know exactly what we need to do in Iraq, and my position has been consistent: Saddam Hussein is a threat.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He needed to be disarmed.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We needed to go to the U.N.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president needed the authority to use force in order to be able to get him to do something, because he never did it without the threat of force.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But we didn't need to rush to war without a plan to win the peace.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: There's some 600-plus tons of unsecured material still in the former Soviet Union and Russia.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: At the rate that the president is currently securing it, it'll take 13 years to get it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I did a lot of work on this.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I wrote a book about it several years ago -- six, seven years ago -- called "The New War," which saw the difficulties of this international criminal network.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And back then, we intercepted a suitcase in a Middle Eastern country with nuclear materials in it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And the black market sale price was about $250 million.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, there are terrorists trying to get their hands on that stuff today.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And this president, I regret to say, has secured less nuclear material in the last two years since 9/11 than we did in the two years preceding 9/11.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We have to do this job.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And to do the job, you can't cut the money for it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president actually cut the money for it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You have to put the money into it and the funding and the leadership.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And part of that leadership is sending the right message to places like North Korea.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Right now the president is spending hundreds of millions of dollars to research bunker-busting nuclear weapons.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The United States is pursuing a new set of nuclear weapons.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You talk about mixed messages.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We're telling other people, "You can't have nuclear weapons," but we're pursuing a new nuclear weapon that we might even contemplate using.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm going to shut that program down, and we're going to make it clear to the world we're serious about containing nuclear proliferation.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we're going to get the job of containing all of that nuclear material in Russia done in four years.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we're going to build the strongest international network to prevent nuclear proliferation.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: This is the scale of what President Kennedy set out to do with the nuclear test ban treaty.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I intend to get it done.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Secondly, we've set up what's called the -- well, first of all, I agree with my opponent that the biggest threat facing this country is weapons of mass destruction in the hands of a terrorist network.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's why proliferation is one of the centerpieces of a multi-prong strategy to make the country safer.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My administration started what's called the Proliferation Security Initiative.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Over 60 nations involved with disrupting the trans-shipment of information and/or weapons of mass destruction materials.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This was a proliferator out of Pakistan that was selling secrets to places like North Korea and Libya.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We convinced Libya to disarm.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's a central part of dealing with weapons of mass destruction and proliferation.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'll tell you another way to help protect America in the long run is to continue with missile defenses.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we've got a robust research and development program that has been ongoing during my administration.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We'll be implementing a missile-defense system relatively quickly.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that is another way to help deal with the threats that we face in the 21st century.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In the hands of a terrorist enemy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Weapons of mass destruction, nuclear proliferation.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But again, the test or the difference between us, the president has had four years to try to do something about it, and North Korea has got more weapons; Iran is moving towards weapons.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And at his pace, it will take 13 years to secure those weapons in Russia.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm going to do it in four years, and I'm going to immediately set out to have bilateral talks with North Korea.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Again, I can't tell you how big a mistake I think that is, to have bilateral talks with North Korea.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's precisely what Kim Jong Il wants.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It will cause the six-party talks to evaporate.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It will mean that China no longer is involved in convincing, along with us, for Kim Jong Il to get rid of his weapons.
