Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's a big mistake to do that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We must have China's leverage on Kim Jong Il, besides ourselves.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And if you enter bilateral talks, they'll be happy to walk away from the table.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't think that'll work.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: No, I don't think it's OK, and said so publicly.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think that there needs to be checks and balances in a democracy, and made that very clear that by consolidating power in the central government, he's sending a signal to the Western world and United States that perhaps he doesn't believe in checks and balances, and I told him that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I mean, he's also a strong ally in the war on terror.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He is -- listen, they went through a horrible situation in Beslan, where these terrorists gunned down young school kids.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's the nature of the enemy, by the way.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's why we need to be firm and resolved in bringing them to justice.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's precisely what Vladimir Putin understands, as well.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've got a good relation with Vladimir.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And it's important that we do have a good relation, because that enables me to better comment to him, and to better to discuss with him, some of the decisions he makes.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I found that, in this world, that it's important to establish good personal relationships with people so that when you have disagreements, you're able to disagree in a way that is effective.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so I've told him my opinion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I look forward to discussing it more with him, as time goes on.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Russia is a country in transition.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Vladimir is going to have to make some hard choices.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I think it's very important for the American president, as well as other Western leaders, to remind him of the great benefits of democracy, that democracy will best help the people realize their hopes and aspirations and dreams.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I will continue working with him over the next four years.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, let me just say quickly that I've had an extraordinary experience of watching up close and personal that transition in Russia, because I was there right after the transformation.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I was probably one of the first senators, along with Senator Bob Smith of New Hampshire, a former senator, to go down into the KGB underneath Treblinka Square and see reams of files with names in them.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It sort of brought home the transition to democracy that Russia was trying to make.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I regret what's happened in these past months.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I think it goes beyond just the response to terror.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Mr. Putin now controls all the television stations.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: His political opposition is being put in jail.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I think it's very important to the United States, obviously, to have a working relationship that is good.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: This is a very important country to us.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But we always have to stand up for democracy.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: As George Will said the other day, "Freedom on the march; not in Russia right now."
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, I'd like to come back for a quick moment, if I can, to that issue about China and the talks.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Because that's one of the most critical issues here: North Korea.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Just because the president says it can't be done, that you'd lose China, doesn't mean it can't be done.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I mean, this is the president who said "There were weapons of mass destruction," said "Mission accomplished," said we could fight the war on the cheap -- none of which were true.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We could have bilateral talks with Kim Jong Il.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we can get those weapons at the same time as we get China.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Because China has an interest in the outcome, too.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You know my opinion on North Korea.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I can't say it any more plainly.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Oh, I'm a pretty calm guy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't take it personally.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You know, we looked at the same intelligence and came to the same conclusion: that Saddam Hussein was a grave threat.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I don't hold it against him that he said grave threat.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm not going to go around the country saying he didn't tell the truth, when he looked at the same intelligence I did.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The president said he was going to build a true coalition, exhaust the remedies of the U.N. and go to war as a last resort.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Those words really have to mean something.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And, unfortunately, he didn't go to war as a last resort.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now we have this incredible mess in Iraq -- $200 billion.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It's not what the American people thought they were getting when they voted.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Thank you, Jim, very much.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Thank you very much to the university, again.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: My fellow Americans, as I've said at the very beginning of this debate, both President Bush and I love this country very much.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: There's no doubt, I think, about that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But we have a different set of convictions about how we make our country stronger here at home and respected again in the world.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I know that for many of you sitting at home, parents of kids in Iraq, you want to know who's the person who could be a commander in chief who could get your kids home and get the job done and win the peace.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And for all the rest of the parents in America who are wondering about their kids going to the school or anywhere else in the world, what kind of world they're going to grow up in, let me look you in the eye and say to you: I defended this country as a young man in war, and I will defend it as president of the United States.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But I have a difference with this president.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I believe when we're strongest when we reach out and lead the world and build strong alliances.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I have a plan for Iraq.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I believe we can be successful.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm not talking about leaving.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we need a fresh start, a new credibility, a president who can bring allies to our side.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I also have a plan to win the war on terror, funding homeland security, strengthening our military, cutting our finances, reaching out to the world, again building strong alliances.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I believe America's best days are ahead of us because I believe that the future belongs to freedom, not to fear.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's the country that I'm going to fight for.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I ask you to give me the opportunity to make you proud.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I ask you to give me the opportunity to lead this great nation, so that we can be stronger here at home, respected again in the world, and have responsible leadership that we deserve.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Thank you very much tonight, Jim.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If America shows uncertainty or weakness in this decade, the world will drift toward tragedy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's not going to happen, so long as I'm your president.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The next four years we will continue to strengthen our homeland defenses.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We will strengthen our intelligence-gathering services.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We will reform our military.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The military will be an all-volunteer army.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We will continue to stay on the offense.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We will fight the terrorists around the world so we do not have to face them here at home.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We'll continue to build our alliances.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'll never turn over America's national security needs to leaders of other countries, as we continue to build those alliances.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we'll continue to spread freedom.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe in the transformational power of liberty.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe that the free Iraq is in this nation's interests.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe a free Afghanistan is in this nation's interest.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I believe both a free Afghanistan and a free Iraq will serve as a powerful example for millions who plead in silence for liberty in the broader Middle East.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've done a lot of hard work together over the last three and a half years.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've been challenged, and we've risen to those challenges.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've climbed the mighty mountain.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I see the valley below, and it's a valley of peace.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: By being steadfast and resolute and strong, by keeping our word, by supporting our troops, we can achieve the peace we all want.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I ask for your vote.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And thank you to the people of Hartford, our hosts.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I want to begin by saying again how much I respect Senator Dole and his record of public service and how hard I will try to make this campaign and this debate one of ideas, not insults.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Four years ago I ran for president at a time of high unemployment and rising frustration.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I wanted to turn this country around with a program of opportunity for all, responsibility from all, and an American community where everybody has a role to play.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I wanted a government that was smaller and less bureaucratic to help people make the most of their own lives.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Four years ago you took me on faith.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now there's a record: Ten and a half million more jobs, rising incomes, falling crime rates and welfare rolls, a strong America at peace.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We are better off than we were four years ago.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We cut the deficit by 60 percent.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now, let's balance the budget and protect Medicare, Medicaid, education and the environment.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We cut taxes for 15 million working Americans.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now let's pass the tax cuts for education and child rearing, help with medical emergencies, and buying a home.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We passed family and medical leave.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now let's expand it so more people can succeed as parents and in the work force.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We passed 100,000 police, the assault weapons ban, the Brady Bill.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now let's keep going by finishing the work of putting the police on the street and tackling juvenile gangs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now let's move a million people from welfare to work.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And most important, let's make education our highest priority so that every eight-year-old will be able to read, every 12-year-old can log onto the Internet, every 18-year-old can go to college.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We can build that bridge to the 21st Century.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I look forward to discussing exactly how we're going to do it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Thank you, Mr. President, for those kind words.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Thank the people of Hartford, the Commission, and all those out here who may be listening or watching.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's a great honor for me to be here standing here as the Republican nominee.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I'm very proud to be the Republican nominee reaching out to Democrats and Independents.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I have three very special people with me tonight: My wife, Elizabeth; my daughter, Robin, who has never let me down, and a fellow named Frank Carafa from New York, along with Ollie Manninen who helped me out in the mountains of Italy a few years back.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I've learned from them that people do have tough times.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And sometimes you can't go it alone.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And that's what America is all about.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I remember getting my future back from doctors and nurses and a doctor in Chicago named Dr. Kalikian .
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And ever since that time, I've tried to give something back to my country, to the people who are watching us tonight.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: America is the greatest place on the face of the earth.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now, I know millions of you still have anxieties.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You work harder and harder to make ends meet and put food on the table.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You worry about the quality and the safety of your children, and the quality of education.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But even more importantly, you worry about the future and will they have the same opportunities that you and I have had.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And Jack Kemp and I want to share with you some ideas tonight.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Jack Kemp is my running mate, doing an outstanding job.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now, I'm a plain-speaking man and I learned long ago that your word was your bond.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I promise you tonight that I'll try to address your concerns and not try to exploit them.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's a tall order, but I've been running against the odds for a long time and, again, I'm honored to be here this evening.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Well, Jim, I believe that the Federal government should give people the tools and try to establish the conditions in which they can make the most of their own lives.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That, to me, is the key.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And that leads me to some different conclusions from Senator Dole.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: For example, we have reduced the size of the Federal government to its smallest size in 30 years.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We reduced more regulations, eliminated more programs than my two Republican predecessors.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But I have worked hard for things like the Family and Medical Leave Law, the Brady Bill, the assault weapons ban, the program to put 100,000 police on the street.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: All of these are programs that Senator Dole opposed that I supported, because I felt they were a legitimate effort to help people make the most of their own lives.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I've worked hard to help families impart values to their own children.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I supported the V-chip so that parents would be able to control what their kids watch on television when they're young, along with the ratings systems for television and educational television.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I supported strong action against the tobacco companies to stop the marketing, advertising, and sale of tobacco to young people.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I supported a big increase in the safe and drug-free schools program.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: These were areas on which Senator Dole and I differed, but I believed they were the right areas for America to be acting together as one country to help individuals and families make the most of their own lives and raise their kids with good values and a good future.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think the basic difference is, and I have had some experience in this, I think the basic difference, I trust the people.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The President trusts the government.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We go back and look at the healthcare plan that he wanted to impose on the American people.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: One seventh the total economy, 17 new taxes, price controls, 35 to 50 new bureaucracies that cost $1.5 trillion.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Don't forget that, that happened in 1993.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: A tax increase, a tax on everybody in America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If you made 25,000 as the original proposal, you got your Social Security taxes increased.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We had a BTU tax we turned into a $35 million gas tax, a $265 billion tax increase.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I guess I rely more on the individual.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I carry a little card in my pocket called the Tenth Amendment.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Where possible, I want to give power back to the states and back to the people.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That's my difference with the President.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We'll have specific differences later.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: He noted a few, but there are others.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We've done a lot to give the people more powers to make their own decisions over their own lives.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But I do think we are right when we try to, for example, give mothers and newborns 48 hours before they can be kicked out of the hospital, ending these drive-by deliveries.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think we were right to pass the Kassebaum-Kennedy bill, which says you can't lose your health insurance just because you change jobs or because someone in your family's been sick.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Our government is smaller and less bureaucratic and has given more authority to the states than its two predecessors under Republican presidents.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But I do believe we have to help our people get ready to succeed in the 21st Century.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, he's better off than he was four years ago.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I may be better off four years from now, but I don't know.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I looked at the slowest growth in the century.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: He inherited a growth of 4.7 4.8 percent, now it's down to about 2.4 percent.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're going to pass a million bankruptcies this year for the first time in history.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: In fact, women's wages have dropped 2.2 percent.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Men's wages haven't gone up, gone down.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We have the highest foreign debt in history.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And it seems to me that if you take a look, are you better off?
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Well, I guess some may be better off.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Saddam Hussein is probably better off than he was four years ago.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Renee Proval (ph) is probably better off than he was four years ago.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But are the American people?
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They're working harder and higher and harder paying more taxes.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: For the first time in history, you pay about 40 percent of what you earn.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: More than you spend for food, clothing and shelter combined for taxes under this administration.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So some may be better off.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They talk about family income being up.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That's not true in Connecticut, family income is down.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And it's up in some cases because both parents are working.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: One works for the family, and one works to pay taxes for the government.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're going to give them tax cuts so they can spend more time with their children, maybe even take a vacation.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That's what America is all about.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Well, let me say, first of all, in February Senator Dole acknowledged that the American economy was in the best shape it's been in in 30 years.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have ten and a half million more jobs, a faster job growth rate than under any Republican administration since the 1920s.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Wages are goings up for the first time in a decade.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have record numbers of new small businesses.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have the biggest drop in the number of people in poverty in 27 years.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: All groups of people are growing.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We had the biggest drop in income inequality in 27 years in 1995.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The average family's income has gone up over $1600 just since our economic plan passed.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I think it's clear that we're better off than we were four years ago.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now we need to focus on what do we need to do to be better off still.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: How can we help people as we are to get their retirements when they work for small businesses, to be able to afford health insurance, to be able to educate their children.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's what I want to focus on.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But we are clearly better off than we were four years ago, as Senator Dole acknowledged this year.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I doubt that I acknowledged that this year.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But in any event, I think we just look at the facts.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We ask the people that are viewing tonight, are you better off than you were four years ago.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's not whether we're better off, it's whether they're better off.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Are you working harder to put food on the table, feed your children.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Are your children getting a better education.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Drug use has doubled the past 44 months all across America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Crime has gone down but it's because the mayors like Rudy Giuliani where one third of the drop happened in one city, New York City.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So, yes, some may be better off.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But of the people listening tonight, the working families who will benefit from economic packages, they'll be better off when Bob Dole is president and Jack Kemp is vice president.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Let's look at the position.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: First of all, remember that in this campaign season, since Senator Dole's been a candidate, he has bragged about the fact that he voted against Medicare in the beginning, in 1965, one of only 12 members.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: He said he did the right thing then, he knew it wouldn't work at the time.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Then his budget that he passed along with Speaker Gingrich cut Medicare $270 billion, more than was necessary to repair the Medicare trust fund.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It would have charged seniors more for out-of-pocket costs as well as more in premiums because doctors could have charged them more.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The American Medical, Hospital Association, the Nurses Association, the Catholic Hospital Association all said hundreds of hospitals could close and people would be hurt badly under the Dole-Gingrich Medicare plan that I vetoed.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And now with this risky $550 billion tax scheme of Senator Dole's, even his own friends, his campaign co-chair, Senator D'Amato, says that they can't possibly pay for it without cutting Medicare more and cutting Social Security as well, according to him.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now, my balanced budget plan adds ten years to the life of the Medicare trust fund, ten years.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And we'll have time to deal with the long-term problems of the baby boomers.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But it was simply wrong to finance their last scheme to cut Medicare $270 billion to run the risk of it withering on the vine.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We always had to reform it over the years, but we need somebody who believes it in to reform it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, I must say, I look back at the vote on Medicare in 1965, we had a program called Eldercare that also provided drugs and means tests to people who needed medical attention received it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I thought it was a good program.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But I've supported Medicare ever since.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: In fact, I used to go home, my mother would tell me, Bob, all I've got is my Social Security and my Medicare, don't cut it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I wouldn't violate anything my mother said.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: In fact, we had a conversation about our mothers one day, a very poignant conversation in the White House.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I've had the best healthcare from government hospitals, Army hospitals and I know its importance, but we've got to fix it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's his trustees, the President's trustees, not mine, who says it's going to go broke.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: He doesn't fix it for ten years.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We ought to appoint a commission, just as we did in Social Security in 1983, when we rescued Social Security, and I was proud to be on that commission, along with Claude Pepper, the champion of senior citizens from Florida.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And we can do it again, if we take politics out of it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Stop scaring the seniors, Mr. President.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You've already spent $45 million scaring seniors and tearing me apart.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I think it's time to have a truce.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Well, let me say, first of all, I'd be happy to have a commission deal with this and I appreciate what Senator Dole did on the '83 Social Security commission.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But it won't be possible to do, if his tax scheme passes because even his own campaign co-chair, Senator D'Amato, says he'll have to cut Medicare even more than was cut in the bill that I vetoed.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I vetoed that bill because it cut more Medicare and and basically ran the risk of breaking up the system.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: My balanced budget plan puts ten years on the Medicare.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We ought to do that, then we can have a commission.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And so will the former President, yes.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Well, the people need it, that's the point.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This is not a Wall Street tax cut.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This is a family tax cut.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This is a Main Street tax cut, 15 percent across -- let's take a family making $30,000 a year, that's $1261.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now, maybe to some in this Bushnell Memorial that it's not a lot of money, but people watching tonight with a couple of kids, a working family, that's four or five months of day care, maybe a personal computer; it's may be three or four months of mortgage payments.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This economic package is about families but it's a six-point package.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: First of all, it's a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution which President Clinton defeated.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: He twisted arms and got six Democrats to vote the other way, but we lost by one vote.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's balancing a budget by the year 2002.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's a tax cut, cutting capital gains 50 percent.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So you can go out and create more jobs and more opportunities.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's a state tax relief.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's a $500 per child tax credit.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now that the President gets millions of dollars from the trial lawyers, he probably doesn't like this provision.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: In fact, when I fell off the podium in Chico, before I lit the ground, hit the ground I had call on my cell phone from a trial lawyer saying I think we've got a case here.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And it's also regulatory reform.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's a good package, Mr. President.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We'd like to have your support.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Well, here's the problem with it: It sounds very good, but there's a reason that 500 economists, including seven Nobel prize winners and business periodicals like Business Week, and even Senator Dole's friends, Senator Warren Rudman, former Republican senator from New Hampshire, says it's not a practical program.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's a $550 billion tax scheme that will cause a big hole in the deficit which will raise interest rates and slow down the economy and cause people to pay more for home mortgages, car payments, credit card payments, college loans, and small business loans.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's not good to raise the deficit.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We worked too hard to lower it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It will actually raise taxes on nine million people and, in addition to that, it will force bigger cuts in Medicare, Medicaid, education and the environment than the ones that he and Mr. Gingrich passed that I vetoed last year.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So it sounds great, but our targeted tax cut for education, child rearing, healthcare and home buying, which is paid for in my balanced budget plan, something that he has not done, certified by the Congressional budget office, that's the right way to go.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The President wants to increase spending 20 percent over the next six years.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I want to increase spending 14 percent, that's how simple it is.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I want the government to pinch pennies for a change instead of the American families.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're talking about six percentage points over six years, and with that money you give it back to the working people.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You also provide opportunity scholarships so low income parents will have the same choice that others have in sending their children to better schools.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It will work, and when it does work, Mr. President, I know you'll congratulate me.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Well, I try to articulate my positions as clearly as possible, tell people what I stand for and let them decide whether they're going to support me or not.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The Senator mentioned the trial lawyers.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: In the case of the product liability bill, which they passed and I vetoed, I think that's what he's talking about, I actually wanted to sign that bill.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I told the people exactly what the Congress exactly what kind of bill I would sign.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now, a lot of the trial lawyers didn't want me to sign any bill at all, but I had thought we ought to do what we could to cut frivolous lawsuits, but they wouldn't make some of the changes that I thought should be made.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now, let me just give you an example.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I had a person in the Oval Office who lost a child in a school bus accident where a drunk driver caused the accident directly, but there were problems with the school bus.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The drunk driver had no money.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Under the new bill, if I had signed it, a person like that could never have had any recovery.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I thought that was wrong.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I gave four or five specific examples to the Congress and said, prove to me that these people could recover but we're going to eliminate frivolous lawsuits, I'll sign the bill.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But generally I believe that a president has to be willing to do what he thinks is right.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I've done a lot of things that were controversial.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: My economic plan, my trade position, Bosnia, Haiti, taking on the NRA for the first time, taking on the tobacco companies for the first time.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Sometimes you just have to do that because you know it's right for the country over the long run.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's what I've tried to do and that's what I will continue to do as president.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: How does he avoid conflict?
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Well, I don't know in the case of the trial lawyers.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I look at the trial lawyers, and when you're a few million short, you run out to Hollywood and pick up two to four million and organized labor comes to Washington, D.C. and puts 35 million into the pot.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now, if these aren't special interests, I've got a lot to learn.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I was there for a while before I left on June the 11th.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The trial lawyers and I don't -- you know, my wife's a lawyer.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're the only two lawyers in Washington that trust each other.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But we're lawyers, I like lawyers.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I don't dislike trial lawyers.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But it seemed to me there's got to be some end to the frivolous lawsuits and there's got to be some cap on punitive damage.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You're putting a lot of business people out of business.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Small businessmen and businesswomen who paid 70 percent of your ninteen , your$265 billion tax increase, the largest tax increase in the history of America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I said that one day and Pat Moynihan, a Democrat, say, no, he said, in the history of the world.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So I modified it, the largest tax increase in the history of the world.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And it seems to me that there is a problem there, Mr. President.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I will address you as Mr. President.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You didn't do that with Mr. with President Bush in 1992.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Let me say, first of all, I signed a tort reform bill that dealt with civilian aviation a couple of years ago.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I proved that I will sign reasonable tort reform.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Secondly, Senator Dole had some pretty harsh comments about special interest money, but it wasn't me who opposed what we tried to do to save the lives of children who were subject to tobacco and then went to the tobacco growers and bragged about standing up for the Federal government when we tried to stop the advertising, marketing, and sales of tobacco to children.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And it wasn't me that let the polluters actually come into the halls of Congress, into the rooms, and rewrite the environmental laws.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's what Speaker Gingrich and Senator Dole did, not me.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I believe that we should take a different approach to this and talk about how we stand on the issues instead of trying to characterize each other's motivations.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think Senator Dole and I just honestly disagree.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think it's very difficult.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Let's be honest about it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That's why we need campaign finance reform.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That's why I reach out to the Perot voters.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We've done about all, we are the reform party, the Republican Party.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And the Perot voters that are looking for a home ought to take a look at the Republican record.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Whatever it is, whatever the checklist was in '92, it's all done with campaign finance reform.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I worked with Senator Mitchell, who played me, I guess, in the debate warmup.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We tried six or eight years ago.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: He appointed three people, I appointed three people to get campaign finance reform.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We couldn't get it done, because I wasn't enforceable.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You've suggested a commission, Newt Gingrich did, I suggested that at least four or five years ago.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We have a commission on campaign finance reform.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They send it to Congress, and we have to vote it up or down.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We are never going to fix it by the parties, because Democrats want a better advantage for themselves, we want a better advantage as Republicans, and that's not how it's going to work.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But I want to touch on this is tobacco thing.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I know the President's been puffing a lot on that.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But I want to go back to 1965.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That was my first vote against tobacco companies when I said we ought to label cigarettes.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I've had a consistent record ever since 1965.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We passed a bill in 1992 that encouraged the states to adopt programs to stop kids from smoking.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: All 50 states did it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It took three and a half years.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It wasn't until election year, Mr. President, that you ever thought about stopping smoking.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: What about drugs that have increased, doubled in the last 44 months?
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Cocaine is up 141 percent -- marijuana, cocaine up 166 percent.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It seems to me that you have a selective memory.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You know, mine doesn't work that way.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So I just want to try to correct it as we go along.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Mr. Lehrer, I hope we'll have a chance to discuss drugs later in the program.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But let me respond to what you said.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I agree that too many incumbent politicians in Washington in both parties have consistently opposed campaign finance reform.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That was certainly the case from the minute I got there.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So after Speaker Gingrich and Senator Dole took over the Congress, I went to New Hampshire and a man suggested -- a gentleman that unfortunately just passed away a couple of days ago, suggested that we appoint a commission.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I shook hands with him on it and I appointed my members, and the commission never met.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And then Senator Dole's ardent supporters, Senator McCain, who's out there today, along with Senator Feingold, supported, sponsored a campaign finance reform proposal.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And members of Senator Dole's own party in the Senate killed it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And he was not out there urging them to vote for the McCain-Feingold bill.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I think the American people, including the Perot supporters, know that I have had a consistent record in favor of campaign finance reform, and I will continue to have.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I hope we can finally get it in the next session of Congress, because we need it badly.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, on campaign reform itself, we're going to get it when we have a bipartisan commission, take it out of politics.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Get people who don't have any interest in politics but understand the issue and let them make the recommendation to Congress.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now, we're now kidding anybody, Mr. President.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: These are sophisticated people watching tonight.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Millions and millions of Americans.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They know the Republican Party hasn't done it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They know the Democratic party won't do it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We ought to agree that somebody else should do it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And we have to vote it up or down, Mr. President.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Well, Jim, I think every American in any position of responsibility should be concerned about what's happened.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But let's look at the overall record.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Overall in America cocaine use has dropped 30 percent in the last four years, casual drug use down 13 percent.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The tragedy is that our young people are still increasing their use of drugs up to about 11 percent total with marijuana, and I regret it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me tell you what I tried to do about it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I appointed a four-star general who led our efforts south of the border to keep drugs from coming into the country as our nation's drug czar.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The most heavily directed, decorated solder in uniform when he retired.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We submitted the biggest drug budget ever.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have dramatically increased control and enforcement at the border.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We supported a a crime bill that had 60 death penalties including, including the death penalty for drug kingpins.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I supported a big expansion in safe and drug-free schools program to support things like the DARE program because I thought all those things were very important.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Do I think that I bear some responsibility for the fact that too many of our children still don't understand drugs are wrong, drugs can kill you.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Even though I have consistently opposed the legalization of drugs all my public life and worked hard against them.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think we all do.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I don't think this issue should be politicized because my record is clear and I don't think Senator Dole supports using using drugs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think we just have to continue to work on this until those who think it isn't dangerous and won't kill them and won't destroy their lives, get the message and change.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Again, well it's, you are very selective, Mr. President.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You don't want to politicize drugs, but it's already politicized Medicare, go out and scare senior citizens and other vulnerable groups, veterans and people who get Pell Grants and things like this.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I mean, you say we've done all these bad things, which isn't the case.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But it seems to me the record is clear.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The record is pretty clear in Arkansas, when you were governor.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You resisted the appointment of a drug czar there because you thought it might interfere with treatment.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But here you cut the drug czar's office 83 percent.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I mean that's what, I want to stop it from coming across the border.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And in my administration, we're going to train the National Guard to stop it from coming across the border.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This is a invasion of drugs from all over the world.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And we have a responsibility.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You had a surgeon -- or before General McCaffrey (ph) you had a lady who said we ought to consider legalizing drugs.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Is that the kind of leadership we need?
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I won't comment on other things that happened in your administration or your past about drugs.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But it seems to me the kids ought to -- if they've started, they ought to stop and just don't do it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Let me say again, we did have a drug czar in Arkansas, but he answered to the governor, just like this one answers to the President.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's what I thought we ought to do.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Secondly, Senator Dole, you voted against the crime bill that had the death penalty for drug kingpins in it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And you voted to cut services to 23 million school children under the safe and drug-free schools act.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I don't think that means you're soft on drugs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We just have a different approach.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But let me remind you, my family has suffered from drug abuse.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I know what it's like to see somebody you love nearly lose their lives, and I hate drugs, Senator.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We need to do this together and we can.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Not if I didn't have a better idea.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But I've got a better idea.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's something I've worked on for 15 years.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's called the automated check or the instant check.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's being used in 17 states right now.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: States like Florida, Colorado, Virginia, and other states.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You don't buy any gun.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You don't get any gun.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We've got 20 million names on a computer in Washington, D.C. of people who should not have guns.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We ought to keep guns out of the hands of criminals.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And, there are eight other categories that should not have guns.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I've been working on this for a long, long time.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You walk in, you put your little card in there.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If it says tilt, you don't get any gun.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You don't get a hand gun, you don't get a rifle, you don't get a shot gun, you get zippo.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If we're going to protect American children and American families and people who live as prisoners in their own home, we've got to stop guns from being dumped on the street.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The administration says they support the instant check.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They've appropriated about $200 million, but only spent about $3 million to get it underway.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: In our administration, in my administration, we will expedite.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This keeps up with technology.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It keeps guns out of the hands of people who should not have guns.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That is the bottom line.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I believe it's a good idea, has strong bipartisan support.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And perhaps that's another thing we can depoliticize.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You talk about the Brady Bill.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: There has only been one prosecution under the Brady -- only one under the assault weapon ban and only seven under the Brady Bill that you talk about all the time.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And on the assault weapon ban, out of 17 weapons that were banned, only six banned now because eleven have been modified and are back on the street.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Let's get together on this instant check because that will really make a difference.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Let me say, first of all, Senator Dole has gone back and forth about whether he'd be for repealing the Brady Bill or repealing the assault weapons ban.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I think his present position is he would not do so, and if that's true I'm grateful for it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But let's look at the facts here.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The Brady Bill has kept at least 60,000 felons, fugitives and stalkers from getting hand guns.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Senator Dole led the fight against the Brady Bill.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: He tried to keep it from coming to my desk.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: He didn't succeed and I signed it and I'm glad I did.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Then when we had the assault weapons ban in the Senate, Senator Dole fought it bitterly and opposed the entire crime bill and almost brought the entire crime bill down because the National Rifle Association didn't want the assault weapons ban, just like they didn't want the Brady Bill.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But two years later nobody's lost their handguns.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've expanded the Brady Bill to cover people who beat up their spouses and their kids.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And this is a safer country.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I'm glad I took on that fight and I believe, with all respect, I was right and he was wrong.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, the President doesn't have it quite right.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I mean, it seemed to me at the time the assault weapon ban was not effective.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I told the NRA that's history.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You're not going to worry about it anymore.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I'm not going to worry about it anymore.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Let's stop, you know, playing the political game, Mr. President.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Talking about this and this.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You add all the states that've used the instant check and how many weapons they keep, kept out of the hands of criminals.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It would far surpass the numbers you mentioned.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So in my view, if you want to be protected, you ought to vote for Bob Dole and we'll get the instant check passed and we'll keep guns out of the hands of criminals.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If he, that's what he said, he's not right about that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Look at where we are today.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The United States is still the indispensable nation in the aftermath of the Cold War and on the brink of the 21st Century.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I have worked to support our country as the world's strongest force for peace and freedom, prosperity and security.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have done the following things: Number one, we've managed the aftermath of the Cold War, supporting a big drop in nuclear weapons in Russia.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The removal of Russian troops from the Baltics.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The integration of Central and Eastern European democracies into a new partnership with NATO.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And, I might add, with the democratic Russia.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: There are no nuclear missiles pointed at the children of the United States tonight and have not been in our administration for the first time since the dawn of the nuclear age.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have worked hard for peace and freedom.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: When I took office, Haiti was governed by a dictator that had defied the United States.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: When I took office, the worst war in Europe was waging in Bosnia.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now there is a the democratically elected president in Haiti.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We just had the election there.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've made progress in Northern Ireland, in the Middle East.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've also stood up to the new threats of terrorism.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, organized crime, and we have worked hard to expand America's economic presence around the world with the biggest increase in trade with the largest new number of trade agreements in history And that's one of the reasons America is number one in auto production again.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, I have a different view.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Again, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve supported the President on Bosnia, and I think we were told the troops would be out in a year.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now I understand it's been extended 'til some time next year.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But, let's start with Somalia, where they dragged Americans through the streets, and where 18 Americans were killed one day, because they didn't have, they were pinned down for eight hours, the rangers.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They didn't have the weapons, they didn't have the tanks.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They asked for the tanks.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They didn't get the tanks from this administration because we were nation building.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We turn it over to the United Nations.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The President didn't have much to do about it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You look at Haiti, where we spend about three billion dollars and we got an alarm call there about two weeks ago.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You got to send down some more people, because the president's found out there are death squads on his on his, in his own property.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So we need more protection from America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: There's no ceasefire in Bosnia.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I think there are still lot of problems in Bosnia.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We agreed to train and arm the Muslims so they could defend themselves, the policy you had when you ran in 1992.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're way behind, which means Americans can't come home.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Americans shouldn't have gone there in the first place, had we let them defend themselves, as they have a right to do under Article 57 of the United Nations charter.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: First of all, I take full responsibility for what happened in Somalia, but the American people must remember that those soldiers were under an American commander when that happened.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I believe they did the best they could under the circumstances, and let's not forget that hundreds of thousands of lives were saved there.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Secondly, in Haiti, political violence is much, much smaller than it was.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Thirdly, in Bosnia it's a virtual miracle that there has been no return to war and at least there has now been an election.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And institutions are beginning to function.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: In Northern Ireland, in the Middle East we are better off than we were four years ago.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: There will always be problems in this whole world.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But if we're moving in the right direction and America is leading, we're better off.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well it, after World War I, we had, you know, a policy of disengagement.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Then from World War I to World War II we had sort of a compulsory engagement policy.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now I think we have a selective engagement policy.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We have to determine when our interests are involved, not the United Nations' interests.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And many of the things the President talked about, he turned over to the United Nations.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: He's deployed more troops than any president in history around the world.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's cost us billions and billions of dollars for peace-keeping operations.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And it seems to me that when you make a decision, the decision is made by the President of the United States, by the Commander-in-Chief.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: He makes that decision when he commits young men or young women who are going to go round and defend our liberty and our freedom.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That would be my position.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Then I'm going to have a top down review at the Pentagon, not a bottom up review.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We all fight over how much money is there.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I want a top down review to determine what our priorities are and what we should do in defense, and then follow that policy instead of this bottom up review with all the services fighting for the money.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You know, the President said he was going to cut defense $60 billion, he cut defense $112 billion.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Devastated states like California and others.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I think now we've got a problem.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We've got to go back and look.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's just like you said in Texas one day, you know raised taxes too much, and you did, and you cut defense too much, Mr. President, and you did.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You may have said that, too.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But the bottom line is, we are the strongest nation in the world.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We provide the leadership and we're going to have to continue to provide the leadership, but let's do it on our terms when our interests are involved and not when somebody blows the whistle at the United Nations.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Our military is the strongest military in the world.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It is the strongest, best prepared, best equipped it has ever been.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: There is very little difference in the budget that I proposed and the Republican budget over the next six-year period.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We are spending a lot of money to modernize our weapons system.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I have proposed a lot of new investments to improve the quality of life for our soldiers, for our men and women in uniform, for their families, for their training.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That is my solemn obligation.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You ask when do you decide to deploy them.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The interests of the American people must be at stake.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Our values must be at stake.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have to be able to make a difference.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And frankly we have to consider what the risks are to our young men and women in uniform.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But I believe the evidence is that our deployments have been successful, in Haiti, in Bosnia, when we moved to Kuwait to repel Saddam Hussein's threatened invasion of Kuwait.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: When I have sent the fleet into the Taiwan straits.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: When we've worked hard to end the Northern Korean nuclear threat.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I believe the United States is at peace tonight in part because of the disciplined, careful, effective deployment of our military resources.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well I failed to mention North Korea and Cuba, a while ago.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You look at North Korea where they have enough plutonium to build six nuclear bombs.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We've sort of distanced ourselves from our ally, South Korea.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They lost about a million people in the war, the Korean War, the forgotten war.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We shouldn't be doing any favors for North Korea.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We don't have any inspection.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We don't know whether it's going to work or not, but we keep giving the incentives.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Someone called them something else.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We don't know what's going to happen.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Here we have Cuba 90 miles from our shores, and what have we done, we passed the law that gave people a right to sue and the President postponed it for six months.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And it seemed to me if you want to send a signal, you've got to send a signal, Mr. President.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The sooner the better off we'll be, if you put tougher sanctions on Castro, not try to make it easier for him.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Well, first of all, for the last four years we have worked had to put more and more pressure on the Castro government to bring about more openness and move toward democracy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: In 1992, before I became President, the Congress passed the Cuba Democracy Act and I enforced it vigorously.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We made the embargo tougher but we increased contacts people to people with the Cubans, including direct telephone service, which was largely supported by the Cuban-American community.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Then Cuba shot down two of our planes and murdered four people in international air space.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They were completely beyond the pale of the law, and I signed the Helms-Burton legislation.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I did give about six months before the effective date of the act before lawsuits can actually be filed, even though they're effective now, and can be legally binding, because I want to change Cuba.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And the United States needs help from other countries.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Nobody in the world agrees with our policy on Cuba now.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But this law can be used as leverage to get other countries to help us to move Cuba to democracy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Every single country in Latin America, Central America and the Caribbean is a democracy tonight but Cuba.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And if we stay firm and strong, we will be able to bring Cuba around as well.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's the point I made.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We have to be firm and strong.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I hope that will happen.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It will happen starting next January and maybe it can happen the balance of this year.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We have not been firm and strong.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You look at the poor people who still live in Cuba.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's a haven for drug smugglers and we don't have a firm policy when it comes to Fidel Castro.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: In my view, the policy has failed.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So Congress passes the law, the President signs it, like he does a lot of things.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But he, like welfare reform, I'm going to sign it but I'm going to try to change it next year.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: A lot of these election-year conversions, the President talks about the drug money, and all the other things, all this antismoking campaign all happened in 1996.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I think the people viewing out there ought to go back and take a look at the record when he fought a balanced budget amendment.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: When he gave you that biggest tax increase in history; when he tried to take over your healthcare system.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: When he fought regulatory reform that cost the average family 6 to $7,000 a year.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This is a serious business.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's about your family; it's about your business, and in this case it's about a firmer policy with Cuba.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: There were several off-the-subject quaffers in that litany.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me just mention, Senator Dole voted for $900 billion in tax increases.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: His running mate Jack Kemp once said that Bob Dole never met a tax he didn't hike.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So we ought to at least get the facts out here on the table so we can know where to go from here.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me first answer that question about the 1982 tax cut.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We were closing loopholes, we were going after big corporations.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I know you probably would oppose it, Mr. President, but I think we should have a fairer system and a flatter system, and we'll have a fairer and flatter system and we're going to make the economic package work.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Well, we finally passed the Kassebaum bill.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The President was opposed to it in 1993.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: He wanted to give us this big system, that took over about one-seventh of the economy, that put on price controls, created all these state alliances, and would cost $1.5 trillion and force people into managed care, whether they wanted it or not.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Most people want to see their own doctor.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They're going to see their own doctor when Bob Dole is president.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So we passed the Kassebaum-Kennedy, the Kennedy Kassebaum bill that will cover about 20 to 25 million people.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We've been for that for four, five, six years.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The President held it up.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And even when it finally got near passage, Senator Kennedy held it up for 100 days, because he wasn't satisfied with one provision.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But it will cover preexisting conditions.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If you change your job, you're going to be covered.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So there are a lot of good things in this bill we should have done instead of trying this massive, massive takeover by the Federal government.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But then of course we had a Democratic Congress and they didn't want to do that.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Until we got a Republican Congress, we finally got action, I'm proud of my colleagues in the Republican Party for getting that done.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It means a lot to a lot of people watching us tonight.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Well, that sounds very good, but it's very wrong.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Senator Dole remembers well that we actually offered not to even put in a healthcare bill in 1994, uh '93, but instead to work with the Senate Republicans and write a joint bill.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And they said no because they got a memo from one of their political advisers saying that instead they should characterize whatever we did as big government and make sure nothing was done to aid healthcare before the '94 elections so they could make that claim.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, maybe we bit off more than we could chew, but we're pursuing a step-by-step reform now.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The Kennedy-Kassebaum bill that I signed will make it possible for 25 million people to keep their health insurance when they change jobs or when somebody in their family's been sick.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I signed a bill to stop these drive-by deliveries when insurance companies can force people out of the hospital after 24 hours and I vetoed Senator Dole's Medicare plan that would have forced a lot of seniors into managed care and taken a lot more money out of their pockets and led to Medicare withering on the vine.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, many of the provisions in the Kassebaum bill were provisions that -- my provisions, like deductions for long-term care, making certain that self-employed people that are watching tonight can deduct not 30 percent but 80 percent of you pay for premiums.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You can also deduct long-term care now, so it's a good it's a good start.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I think there's enough -- we're even looking at our tax cut proposal, our economic package.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: There may be a way of reaching out to the uninsured, because there are a lot of uninsured people in the country, particularly children, that should be covered.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Another way you can do is to expand Medicaid.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: In America no one will go without healthcare, no one will go without food.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Well, I believe that we did the appropriate thing under the circumstances.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Saddam Hussein is under a U.N. resolution not to threaten his neighbors or threaten his own, repress his own citizens.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Unfortunately, a lot of people, have never been as concerned about the Kurds as the United States has tried to be, and we've been flying an operation to protect them out of Turkey for many years now.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: What happened was one of the Turkish, one of the Kurdish leaders invited him to go up north, but we felt since the whole world community had told him not to do it, that once he did it we had to do something.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We did not feel that I could commit.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I certainly didn't feel I should commit American troops to throw him out of where he had gone, and that was the only way to do that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So the appropriate thing strategically to do was to reduce his ability to threaten his neighbors.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We did that by expanding what's called the no-fly zone by increasing our allies' control of the air space now from the Kuwait border to the suburbs of Baghdad.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Was it the right thing to do?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Did it make him withdraw from the north?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, he does , he has a little bit, and I hope he will continue.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have learned that you give him an inch he'll take a mile.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We had to do something, and even though not all of our allies supported it at first, I think most of them now believe that what we did was an appropriate thing to do.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, the president's own CIA director says Saddam is stronger now than he was.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I don't understand extending the no-fly zone in the south when the trouble was in the north.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And what we've done during the Bush administration, the Kurds were at the State Department, negotiating, trying to work their differences out.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now we've got all thousands and thousands of refugees.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're even shipping 3,000 Kurds to Guam.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Saddam is probably about as strong as he ever was.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We shot, what, 44 cruise missiles, worth about a million-two a piece, and hit some radar, that repaired in a couple, three days.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Did we inflict any damage?
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Did we have any allies helping?
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Well, we have Great Britain.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They're always very loyal to us, and I appreciate that.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Even though they had to find out they had 5,000 troops coming, they didn't even understand that.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We had to get their permission.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The bottom line is, we went in there alone.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We are supposed to be operating under a U.N. resolution.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We did it without any of our allies that helped in the Gulf.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Senator Dole has two or three times before tonight criticized me for working with the U.N. Now I'm being criticized for not working with the U.N.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Sometimes the United States has to act alone or at least has to act first.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Sometimes we cannot let other countries have a veto on our foreign policy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I could not send soldiers into the north of Iraq, that would have been wrong.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It could reduce Saddam Hussein's abilities to threaten Kuwait and his other neighbors again.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I still believe it was the right thing to do.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, there were some good pictures, but does it fall into that category?
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I want to be very serious.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I've supported the President when I thought he was right on Bosnia.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I supported him on NAFTA and GATT.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So it's not that we always disagree.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The Mideast is very difficult.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But it seemed to me just as an observer that you know before you'd call somebody to America, you'd have some notion what the end result might be.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now maybe it's better just to get together and sit down and talk.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Maybe that was the purpose.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I know talks have started again today.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But again it's almost like an ad hoc foreign policy.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's ad hoc, it's sort of we get up in the morning and read the papers, what country's in trouble, we'll have a meeting.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now, to me that's not the strategy that I think people expect from America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I think we have lost credibility, and I say this very honestly without any partisanship.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We've lost credibility around the world.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Our allies know, -- they're not certain what we're going to do, what our reaction, what our response is going to be.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Nobody suggested sending troops to Iraq, if that was the hint there from the President.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But I do think that Saddam Hussein is stronger than he was.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I do believe that we didn't gain a great deal in the Mideast by bringing three of the four leaders, one refused to come, to Washington D.C.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We have a very consistent policy in the Middle East: It is to support the peace process; to support the security of Israel; and to support those who are prepared to take risks for peace.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It is a very difficult environment.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The feelings are very strong.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: There are extremists in all parts of the Middle East who want to kill that peace process.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Prime Minister Rabin gave his life because someone in his own country literally hated him for trying to bring peace.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I would like to have had a big, organized summit, but those people were killing each other, rapidly, innocent Arab children, innocent Israeli people, they were dying.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And there is ,so much trust has broken down in the aftermath of the change of government.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I felt that if I could just get the parties together to say let's stop the violence, start talking, commit to the negotiations, that would be a plus.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now today the Secretary of State is in the Middle East and they've started negotiations and all those leaders promised me they would not quit until they resolved the issues between them and got the peace process going forward again.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The President has not called for an unconditional end to the violence.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It seemed to me the violence stopped when these leaders came to America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The killing and tragedies had taken place.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And it is unfortunate, it is a difficult area, no doubt about it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It shouldn't be politicized in any way by the President or by his opponent.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I don't intend to politicize it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I hope they talked and I hope they've reached some result and that the killing will end.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Well, I'm saying that Senator Dole said in his fine speech in San Diego that he wanted to build a bridge to the past.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I think I know what he meant by that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: He's troubled, as I am, by some of the things that go on today.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But I believe America is the greatest country in human history because we have maintained freedom and increasing prosperity by relentlessly pushing the barriers of knowledge, the barriers of the present, always moving into the future.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's why when I became President I was determined to kind of move beyond this whole stale debate that had gone on in Washington for too long to get this country moving again.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And that's why we've got a country with ten and a half million more jobs, and record numbers of new businesses, and rising incomes, and falling crime rates, and welfare roll rates.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's why we're moving in the right direction.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I'm trying to emphasize that what I want to do is to continue to do that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's why my balanced budget plan will still invest and grow this economy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's why I want a tax cut for education and child rearing, but it's got to be paid for.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's why I want to continue the work we have done over partisan opposition, to work with communities to bring that crime rate down until our streets are all safe again.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I am very oriented toward the future.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think this election has to be geared toward the future.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think America's best days are still ahead, but we've got to build the right bridge.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You know, the President reminds me sometimes of my brother Kenny, who is no longer alive.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But Kenny was a great talker.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And he used to tell me things that I knew were not quite accurate.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So we always had a rule, we divided by six.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Maybe in your case maybe just two.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But 11 million new jobs and everything, I mean the President can't take credit for everything that governors are doing, whether that's happening in New York City when it comes to the murder rate and then not be responsible for the bad things that happen, whether it's drug use or something else in America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So it seems to me that we can talk about what we call Kenny, the great exaggerator.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: He just liked to make it sound exager, a little better, made him feel better.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: When it comes to bridges, I want a bridge to the future.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I also want a bridge to the truth.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We have to tell the truth.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We've got people watching tonight and listening tonight trying to find the truth.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And the truth is, there is a lot wrong with America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We need a strong economic package; we need a tax cut; we need the $500 child credit, and we'll have that soon.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I do not for a moment think I'm entitled to all the credit for all the good things that have happened in America.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But where I have moved to work with the American people to help them have the tools to make the most of their own lives, I think I should get some credit for that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I also personally took responsibility tonight when Senator Dole asked me about the drug problem.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But, you know, I think my ideas are better for the future.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Senator Dole voted against student loans, against Headstart, against creating the Department of Education.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: If he gets elected president, we'll start the new century without anyone in the cabinet of the President representing education in our children.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I personally don't think that's the right kind of future for America, and I think we ought to take a different tack.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I didn't favor it when it was in, started.
