Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It was a tribute after President Carter's election to the National Education Association who send a lot of delegates to the Democratic convention, who gives 99.5 percent of their money, Democrat Democrats, and the President, and a lot of the teachers send their kids to private schools or better public schools.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So what we want to do is called opportunity scholarships.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now, some say, oh, you're a Republican, you can't be reaching out to these people.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I've reached out to people all my life.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I've worked on the food stamp program, proudly.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And the WIC program, and the school lunch program with senators like George McGovern, Hubert Humphrey and others, to name a few of my Democratic friends.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I'm not some extremist out here.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I have my own little foundation that's raised about $10 million for the disabled.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I try to do a lot of things that I think might be helpful to people.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So it seems to me that we ought to take that money we can save from the Department of Education, put it into opportunity scholarships and tell little Landale Shakespeare out in Cleveland, Ohio, and tell your mother and father, you're going to get to go to school because we're going to match what the state puts up, and you're going to go to the school of your choice.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I don't fault the President or the vice president for sending their children to private schools or better schools.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I applaud them for it, I don't criticize them.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But why shouldn't everybody have that choice.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Why shouldn't low income Americans and low middle income Americans.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's going to be a big, big opportunity for a lot of people.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Let me say first of all, I'm all for students having more choices.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've worked hard to expand public school choice in my balanced budget bill.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: There's funds for 3,000 new schools created by teachers and parents, sometimes by business people, called charter schools that have no rules, they're free of bureaucracy and can only stay in existence if they perform and teach children.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The ones that are out there are doing well.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: What I'm against is Senator Dole's plan to take money away from all the children we now help with limited Federal funds and help far fewer.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: If we're going to have a private voucher plan, that ought to be done at the local level or the state level.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But Senator Dole has consistently opposed Federal help to education.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: He voted against student loans; he voted against my improved student loan plan; he voted against the National Service bill, against the HeadStart bill; he voted against our efforts in safe and drug-free schools.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: He voted against these programs, he does not believe it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: 90 percent of our kids are out there in those public schools and we need to lift their standards and move them forward with the programs like those I've outlined in this campaign.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'd better correct the President.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I don't know what time it is, but it's probably getting late.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I want to correct, the all these things I voted against, they were probably part of some big package that had a lot of pork in it or a lot of things that we shouldn't have had and we probably voted no.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I've supported all the education programs.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I've supported Headstart, I think we ought to look at it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So I don't want anybody out there to think we've just been voting no, no, no.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Let's give low income parents the same right that people of power and prestige have in America and let them go to better schools.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Let's not, let's help, let's turn the schools back to the teachers and back to the parents and take it away from the National Education Association.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I have advocated expansions of public school choice alternatives and I said the creation of 3,000 new schools that we are going to help the states to finance.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But if you're going to have a private voucher plan, that ought to be determined by states in localities where they're raising and spending most of the money.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I simply think it's wrong to take money away from programs that are helping build basic skills for kids, 90 percent of them are in the public schools; to take money away from programs that are helping fund the school lunch program, that are helping to fund the other programs, that are helping our schools to improve their standards.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Our schools are getting better, and our schools can be made to be even better still with the right kind of community leadership and partnership at the school level.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I have been a strong force for reform.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And, Senator, I remind you that a few years ago when I supported teacher testing while in my home state I was pretty well lambasted by the teachers association.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I just don't believe we ought to be out there running down teachers and attacking them the way you did at the Republican convention.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think we ought to be lifting them up and moving our children forward.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And let me just say that budget that you passed that I vetoed would have cut 50,000 kids out of Headstart.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It would have eliminated the AmeriCorps plan and it would have cut back on student loans and scholarships.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's one of the big reasons I vetoed it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We need to be doing more in education, not less.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, the AmeriCorps program, I must say, if that's one of your successes, I wouldn't speak about it too loudly.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It costs about $27,000 to pay people to volunteer.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We've got four million young people volunteering every year, the number hasn't gone down.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And you pick out 20,000, whether they need the money or not, and they get paid for volunteering.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I'm a product of a public school.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You attended a private school for some time in your life.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You're not for school choice, you can't be for school choice, because this is that special interest money again.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: When you get 99.5 percent of the money, we don't know what happened to the other .5 percent, we're looking for it, somebody got it, but it all went to Democrats.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And this is part of that liberal establishment, one of those liberal things that you just can't do.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You're for school uniforms and curfews and you're opposed to truancy.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now that's not reform, Mr. President.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Why can't Landale Shakespeare in Cleveland or Pilar Gonzales in Milwaukee give their children an opportunity to go to a better school.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Some schools aren't even safe.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Let's give them a real choice, the kind of choice you had, and the kind of choice a lot of people have in America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If we want to stop crime and teenage pregnancy, let's start with education.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: First of all, Senator Dole, let's set the record straight.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I was able for two years when I was in, a very young boy to go to a Catholic school, but I basically went to public schools all my life.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I've worked hard for a long time to make them better, 90 percent of our kids are there.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You, it's amazing to me, you are all for having more responsibility at the local level for everything except schools.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Where we don't have very much money at the Federal level to spend on education, we ought to spend it helping the 90 percent of the kids that we can help.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: If a local school district in Cleveland or anyplace else wants to have a private choice plan like Milwaukee did, let them have at it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I might say the results are highly ambiguous.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But I want to get out there and give a better education opportunity to all of our children and that's why I vetoed the budget you passed with $30 billion in education cuts.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It was wrong, and my plan for the future is better.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I had precisely in mind a lot of the people that were in the White House and other agencies who've never been had any experience, who came to Washington without any experience, they all were very liberal, of course, or they wouldn't be in the administration.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And their idea was that they knew what was best for the American people.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now, I feel very strongly about a lot of things.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I feel strongly about education.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I want to help young people have an education, just as I had an education after World War II with the GI bill of Rights.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We've had millions of young men and women in subsequent subsequent wars change the face of the nation because the government helped with their education.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now the reason they don't have, The reason the President can't support this is pretty obvious.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's not taking anything away from schools, it's new money.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's not being taken away from anybody else, except we'll downsize the Department of Education.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But this is a very liberal administration.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This is an administration that gave you the big tax cut.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This administration tried to take over healthcare and impose a governmental system.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This is the administration that fought regulatory reform that is putting a lot of small businessmen and small businesswomen out of business.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This is the administration that fought the balanced budget amendment and vetoed a balanced budget and vetoed welfare reform twice, and the list goes on and on and on, that's what I had in mind.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I want people in my administration and will have people in my administration who understand America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: There won't be 10 millionaires and 14 lawyers in the cabinet.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: There will be people with experience and people who understand America and people who've made it and know the hard knocks in life.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: When Senator Dole made that remark about all the elitists, all the young elitists in the administration, one of the young men who works for me who grew up in a house trailer looked at me and said, Mr. President, I know how you grew up, who is he talking about.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And you know this liberal charge, that's what their party always drags out when they get in a tight race.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's sort of their golden oldie, you know.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's a record they think they can play that everybody loves to hear.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I just don't think that dog will hunt this time.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The American people should make up their own mind.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've got ten and a half million new jobs; we've got record numbers of those new small businesses.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've made every one of them eligible for a tax cut.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've got declining crime rates, two million fewer people on welfare rolls before welfare reform passed, and a 50 percent increase in child support and a crime bill with 60 death penalties and 100,000 police and the assault weapons ban.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The American people can make up their mind about whether that's a liberal record or a record that's good for America.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Liberal, conservative, you put whatever label you want on it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, I think it's pretty liberal, I'll put that label on it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You take a look at all the programs you've advocated, Mr. President.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Thank goodness we had a Republican Congress there.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The first thing you did when you came into office was set up the stimulus package, said we've got a little pork we want to scatter around America, $16 billion.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And even some in your own party couldn't buy that.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I remember talking by the telephone.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I'm not even certain you were too excited about that.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I won't, I never repeat what I've talked to the President about.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: In any event, we saved the taxpayers $16 billion.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And then came some other program, and then came healthcare, and then came the tax increase and a lot of these things stopped in 1994 because then the Congress changed, and I think we've done a good job.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I believe that the purpose of politics is to give people the tools to make the most of their own lives; to reinforce the values of opportunity and responsibility, and to build a sense of community so we're all working together.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I don't believe in discrimination.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I believe you can protect the environment and grow the economy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I believe that we have to do these things with a government that's smaller and less bureaucratic, but that we have to do them nonetheless.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's inconvenient for Senator Dole, but the truth is I've reduced the size of government more than my Republican predecessors.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I did stop them, I admit that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I sure stopped their budget.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Their budget cut enforcement for the Environmental Protection Agency by a third.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It cut funds to clean up toxic waste dumps with 10 million of our kids still living within four miles of a toxic waste dump, by a third.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It ended the principle that the polluters should pay for those toxic waste dumps unless it was very recent.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Their budget weakened our support for education.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: $30 billion, even cut funds for scholarships and college loans.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Their budget cut $270 billion in Medicare and, finally, their budget withdrew the national guarantee of healthcare to poor children, families with children with handicaps, the elderly in nursing homes, poor pregnant women.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It was wrong for the country and calling it conservative won't make it right.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It was a bad decision for America and would have been bad for our future if I hadn't stopped it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, the President can define himself in any way he wants, but I think we have to look at the record.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Go back to the time he was, what, Texas director for George McGovern.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: George McGovern is a friend of mine, so I don't mean, but he was a liberal, proud liberal.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I've just finished reading a book, I think it's called -- what is it called, what is it, The Demise of the Democratic Party by Ronald Cardash (ph) or something talking about all the liberal influences in the administration.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Whether it's organized labor or whether it's the Hollywood elite or whether some of the media elite or whether it's the labor unions or whatever.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And so I think you take a look at it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The bottom line is this: I think the American people, thought he'd recite all these bills and all these things, they want to know what's going to happen to them.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They've all got a lot of anxieties out there.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Did anybody complain when you raised taxes?
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Did anybody go out and ask the people, how are you going to pay the extra money?
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That's why we want an economic package.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We want the government to pinch their pennies for a change instead of the people pinching their pennies.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That's what our message is to the people watching.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Not all this back and forth, you voted this way, you voted that way, we want a better America as we go into the next century.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The way you get a better America is to balance the budget and protect Medicare, Medicaid, education and the environment; to give a targeted tax cut -- and let me talk about the education tax cut -- to let people have a $10,000 deduction for the cost of college tuition in any year, any kind of college tuition; to give families a tax credit, a dollar for dollar reduction in their taxes for the cost of a typical community college so we can open that to everybody.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And then to let people save in an IRA and withdraw from it without a tax penalty for education, home buying or medical expenses, that's the right way to go into the 21st Century, balance the budget and cut taxes, not balloon with this $550 billion tax scheme.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me say first, on the President's promise for another tax cut.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I mean, I've told people as I've traveled around, all of you that got the tax cut he promised last time, vote for him in '96 and not many hands go up.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So the question is, would you buy a used election promise from my opponent.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The people want economic reform.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They're having a hard time making ends meet.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You've got one parent working for the government, the other parent working for the family.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This is about getting the economy moving again.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This is about American jobs and opportunities.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's about the government, as I said before, pinching its pennies for a change instead of the poor taxpayer.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: When they raise your taxes nobody runs around asking people where are you going to get the extra money.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I think the government can do better.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Well, my blood pressure is lower, my weight, my cholesterol, but I will not make health an issue in this campaign.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So I think he's a bit taller than I am.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But I think there are personal differences.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I mean, I'm not I don't like to get into personal matters.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: As far as I'm concerned, this is a campaign about issues.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's about my vision for America and about his liberal vision for America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And not about personal things.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You know, I think his liberal vision is a thing of the past.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I know he wants to disown it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I wouldn't want to be a liberal either, Mr. President, but you're stuck with it because that's your record, that's your record in Arkansas: The biggest tax increase in history.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The biggest crime increase in history, the biggest drug increase in history in Arkansas.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Well, just for the record, when I was governor we had the lowest -- second lowest tax burden of any state in the country, the highest job growth rate of any state when I ran for president and were widely recognized for a lot of other advances.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But the important thing is, what are we going to do now.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think a targeted tax cut is better for our future, targeted to education and child rearing, with the rest of the education plan, hooking up all of our classrooms to the Internet by the year 2000.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Making sure we've got an army of reading volunteers, trained people to teach with parents and teachers so that our eight year olds can learn to read.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Cleaning up two-thirds of the worst toxic waste dumps.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Those plans are better than this $550 billion tax scheme.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now, remember, folks, even Senator Dole's campaign co-chair here, Senator D'Amato, says he's got to cut Medicare to pay for this.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Everybody who's looked at it, 500 economists, seven Nobel prize winners, say it's bad for the economy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's going to blow a hole in the deficit It's going to raise taxes on nine million people and require bigger cuts than the one I vetoed.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Our plan is better, it will take us into the future with a growing economy and healthier families.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, I'm really encouraged to know of your renewed friendship with Al D'Amato, and I know he appreciates it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You didn't even have tax cuts in your budget, Mr. President, the first two years you were president.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It wasn't until we had a Republican Congress you even thought about, you talked about tax cuts.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Getting back to personal differences, I think, Jim, if you are a little more specific, but I think the President could clarify one thing tonight and that's the question of pardons.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I know you talked about it on the Jim, with Jim Lehrer on the PBS show.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I've never discussed Whitewater, as I've told you personally.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I'm not discussing Whitewater now.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But I am discussing the power the President has to grant pardons.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And hopefully in the next segment you could lay that to rest.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Well, first of all, you know, he made that remark about Senator D'Amato.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: He's arranged for me to spend a lot more time with Senator D'Amato in the last couple years so I'm more familiar with his comments than I used to be.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me say what I've said already about this pardon issue.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: This is an issue they've brought up.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's under, there's been no consideration of it, no discussion of it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I will tell you this: I will not give anyone special treatment and I will strictly adhere to the law.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And that is what every president has done, as far as I know, in the past but what every other president's has done.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: This is something I take seriously and that's my position.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But it seems to me the president shouldn't have any comment at all.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Particularly where it's someone where you've had business dealings.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I mean, you may be sending a signal.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I don't know, I'm not questioning anybody.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But as a President of the United States, when somebody asks you about pardons, you say no comment, period.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I think he made a mistake.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I think when you make a mistake, you say I made a mistake.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But apparently his position hasn't changed.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If there are other specific areas, but beyond that I haven't gotten into any of these things, as the President knows.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And again I know Senator D'Amato I think may have had a hearing or two on Whitewater, I can't remember, but he's not my general chairman, he's a friend of mine.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And so is Senator Kennedy a friend of yours.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I remember one day on the floor I said now, gentlemen, let me tax your memories, and Kennedy jumped up and said, why haven't we thought of that before.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You know, so one of your liberal friends.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: See, if I say anything it's going to be misconstrued.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I don't think there is even a race between the two, it's about our vision for America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I happen to like President Clinton personally.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I'm addressing him all evening as Mr. President.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I said in 1992 he didn't extend that courtesy to President Bush.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But I respect the presidency.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I've served under a number of presidents.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They all have their strengths and they all have their weaknesses.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So I'd rather talk about my strengths.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I think I have my strengths and I think the best thing going for Bob Dole is that Bob Dole keeps his word.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's a question between trust and fear, and I would say, I think, Mr. President, about all you've got going in this campaign is fear.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You're spending millions and millions of dollars in negative ads frightening senior citizens.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I know this to be a fact because I had one tell me last week, Senator don't cut my Medicare.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I'm trying to save your Medicare, just as I rescued Social Security with a bipartisan commission.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I have relatives on Medicare.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I used to sign welfare checks for my grandparents.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I know all about poverty and all about need and all about taking care of people, and that's been my career in the United States Senate.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I'll keep my word on the economic package.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If I couldn't cut taxes and balance the budget the same time, I wouldn't look at you in the eye in your living room or wherever you might be and say that this is good for America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: People will tell you who served with Bob Dole, agree or disagree, he kept his word.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That's what this race is all about.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I'd like the American people to know that I have worked very hard to be on their side.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And to move this country forward and we're better off than we were four years ago.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But the most important thing is my plan for the 21st Century is a better plan.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: A targeted tax cut, a real commitment to educational reform.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: A deep commitment to making welfare reform work with incentives to the private sector to move people from welfare to work.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now we have to create those jobs, now that we're requiring people to go do work.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: A commitment to continuing step-by-step healthcare reform with the next step helping people who are between jobs to access healthcare and not lose it just because they are out of work for a while.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: A commitment to grow the economy while protecting the environment.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's what I'd like them to know about me; that I've gotten up every day and worked for the American people and worked so that their children could have their dreams come true.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I believe we've got the results to show we're on the right track.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The most important thing is, I believe we've got the right ideas for the future.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I like, I like Senator Dole, you can probably tell we like each other.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We just see the world in different ways.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And you folks out there are going to have to choose who you think is right.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, I'd say the first homeless bill in the Senate was the Dole-Byrd Byrd-Dole bill, I can't remember who was in control then.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I remember working with Senator Ribicoff from Connecticut on the Hospice program.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We now have 2500 hospices.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: As I said, I've worked all my life when I was in the Congress.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I left on June 11th because I wanted the American people to know that I was willing to give up something.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: President Clinton ran for governor in 1990 and said he's going to fill out his term, but he didn't.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: He's president so I guess it's a little better deal.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But I wanted the American people to know I was willing to give up something.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I wasn't just getting more power and more power.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So I rolled the dice, I put my career on the line because I really believe the future of America is on the line.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We can give you all these numbers, they don't mean a thing.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If you are out of work, you have nothing to eat or you can't have medical care, or you're holding a crack baby in your arms right now, what do you do next?
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You know, America's best days are ahead of us.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I've seen the tough times, I know they can be better and I'll lead America to a brighter future.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: When I ran for president, I said we'd cut the deficit in half in four years; we cut it by 60 percent.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I said that our economic plan would produce eight million jobs, we have ten and a half million new jobs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We're number one in autos again, record numbers of new small businesses.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I said we'd put, pass a crime bill that would put 100,000 police on the street, ban assault weapons, and deal with the problems that ought to be dealt with with capital punishment, including capital punishment for drug kingpins, and we did that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I said we would change the way welfare works, and even before the bill passed we'd moved nearly two million people from welfare to work, working with states and communities.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I said we'd get tougher with child support and child support enforcement's up 50 percent.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I said that I would work for tax relief for middle class Americans.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The deficit was bigger than I thought it was going to be.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think they're better off, all of us are, that we got the interest rates down and the deficit down.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Republicans talk about it, but we're the first the first administration in anybody's lifetime looking at this program to bring that deficit down four years in a row.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We still gave tax cuts to 15 million working Americans, and now I've got a plan that's been out there for two years, it could have been passed already, but instead the Republicans shut the government down to try to force their budget and their plan on me, and I couldn't take that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But we'll get the rest of that tax relief.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And so I think when you look at those results, you know the plan I've laid out for the future has a very good chance of being enacted if you'll give me a chance to build that bridge to the 21st Century.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, there he goes again, that line has been used before, I mean, exaggerating all the things that he did.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: He didn't do all these things.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Let's take all these four years in a row.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: He came in with a high growth rate, the 1990 budget agreement, which some, you know, didn't like, had some very tough cost controls, put a lot of pressure on Congress.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The S & L crisis was over, they're starting to sell assets, all that money was coming in.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And he cut defense an extra $60 billion, threw a lot of people out of work.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: He talks about a smaller government.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: There are actually more people in government except for people in defense related jobs.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The government's bigger than it was when President Kennedy was around, even though he says it's not.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: In addition, Republican Congress cut $53 billion.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So let's just, let's give credit where credit is due.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So did Governor Thompson, so did Governor Rowland.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: A lot of people ought to deserve credit, Mr. President.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: When I'm President of the United States we're going to have a governors' council and we're going to work directly with the governors to get power back to the people and back to the states.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I think a lot of people deserve credit and I've tried to give it to them.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But I believe that my plan is better than Senator Dole's ill-advised $550 billion scheme which I'll say again will blow a hole in the deficit.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Our plan will balance the budget, grow the economy, preserve the environment, and invest in education.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have the right approach for the future and looks at the results.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It is not midnight in America, Senator.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We are better off than we were four years ago.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, first, Jim, let me thank you and thank you, Senator Dole, and thank you, ladies and gentlemen, all of you listening tonight for the chance you've given us to appear.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I want to say in the beginning that I am profoundly grateful for the chance that you have given me to serve as president for the last four years.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I never could have dreamed anything like this would come my way in life, and I've done my best to be faithful to the charge you've given me.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'm proud of the fact that America is stronger and more prosperous and more secure than we were four years ago.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I'm glad we're going in the right direction.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I've done my best tonight to lay out my plans for going forward to an even better future in the next century.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'd like to leave you with the thought that the things I do as president are basically driven by the people whose lives I have seen affected by what does or doesn't happen in this country.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The auto worker in Toledo who was unemployed when I was elected and now has a great job because we're number one in auto production again.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: All the people I've met who used to be on welfare who are now working and raising their children.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I think what others could do for our country and themselves if we did the welfare reform thing in the proper way.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think of the man who grabbed me by the shoulder once with tears in his eyes and said his daughter was dying of cancer and he thanked me for giving him a chance to spend some time with her without losing his job because of the Family and Medical Leave Act.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think of all the people I grew up with and went to school with and who I stay in touch with and who nerve let me forget how what we do in Washington affects all of you out there in America.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Folks, we can build that bridge to the 21st Century, big enough and strong enough for all of us to walk across, and I hope you will help me build it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Thank you, Jim; thank you, Mr. President; thank everyone for watching and listening.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I want to address my remarks to the young people of America, because they're the ones that are going to spend most of their life in the 21st Century.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They're the ones who have the challenges and they are people out there making predictions that it's not going to be the same.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You're not going to have the opportunities; there are going to be more deficits, more drugs, more crime, and less confidence in the American people.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And that's what you're faced with, the parents are faced with, and the grand parents are faced with.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's important, it's their future.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I would say to those I know there are more young people experimenting with drugs today than ever before; drug use has gone up.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And if you care about the future of America, if you care about your future, just don't do it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I know that I'm someone older than you.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But I've had my anxious moments in my life.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I've learned to feed myself and to walk and to dress.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I'm standing here as proof that in America the possibilities are unlimited.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I know who I am, and I know where I'm from, and I know where I want to take America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We are the greatest country on the face of the earth.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We do more good things for more people in our communities, our neighborhoods, than anywhere that I know of.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I ask for your support, I ask for your help.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And if you really want to get involved, just tap into my home page, www.DoleKemp96.org.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Well, Jim, first of all, I would like to thank the sponsors of this debate and the people of Boston for hosting the debate.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I would like to thank Governor Bush for participating, and I would like to say I'm happy to be here with Tipper and our family.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I have actually not questioned Governor Bush's experience.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I have questioned his proposals.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think this is a very important moment for our country.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We have achieved extraordinary prosperity.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And in this election, America has to make an important choice.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Will we use our prosperity to enrich not just the few, but all of our families?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I believe we have to make the right and responsible choices.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If I'm entrusted with the presidency, here are the choices that I will make.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I will balance the budget every year.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I will pay down the national debt.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I will put Medicare and Social Security in a lockbox and protect them.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I will cut taxes for middle-class families.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I believe it's important to resist the temptation to squander our surplus.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If we make the right choices, we can have a prosperity that endures and enriches all of our people.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If I'm entrusted with the presidency, I will help parents and strengthen families because, you know, if we have prosperity that grows and grows, we still won't be successful unless we strengthen families by, for example, ensuring that children can always go to schools that are safe.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: By giving parents the tools to protect their children against cultural pollution.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I will make sure that we invest in our country and our families.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I mean investing in education, health care, the environment, and middle-class tax cuts and retirement security.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: That is my agenda and that is why I think that it's not just a question of experience.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Well, we do come from different places.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I come from West Texas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The governor is the chief executive officer.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We know how to set agendas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think you'll find the difference reflected in our budgets.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to take one-half of the surplus and dedicate it to Social Security.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One-quarter of the surplus for important projects, and I want to send one-quarter of the surplus back to the people who pay the bills.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want everybody who pays taxes to have their tax rates cut.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that stands in contrast to my worthy opponent's plan, which will increase the size of government dramatically.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: His plan is three times larger than President Clinton's proposed plan eight years ago.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It is a plan that will have 200 new programs -- expanded programs and creates 20,000 new bureaucrats.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Tonight youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re going to hear that my passion and my vision is to empower Americans to be able to make decisions for themselves in their own lives.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I said that his tax cut plan, for example, raises the question of whether it's the right choice for the country.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And let me give you an example of what I mean.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Under Governor Bush's tax cut proposal, he would spend more money on tax cuts for the wealthiest 1% than all of the new spending that he proposes for education, health care, prescription drugs and national defense all combined.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, I think those are the wrong priorities.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, under my proposal, for every dollar that I propose in spending for things like education and health care, I will put another dollar into middle class tax cuts.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And for every dollar that I spend in those two categories, I'll put $2 toward paying down the national debt.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think it's very important to keep the debt going down and completely eliminate it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I also think it's very important to go to the next stage of welfare reform.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Our country has cut the welfare rolls in half.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I fought hard from my days in the Senate and as vice president to cut the welfare rolls and we've moved millions of people in America into good jobs.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But it's now time for the next stage of welfare reform, and include fathers and not only mothers.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Let me just say that obviously tonight we're going to hear some phony numbers about what I think and what we ought to do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: People need to know that over the next ten years it is going to be $25 trillion of revenue that comes into our treasurey and we anticipate spending $21 trillion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And my plan say why don't we pass 1.3 trillion of that back to the people who pay the bills?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Surely we can afford 5% of the $25 trillion that are coming into the treasury to the hard working people that pay the bills.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There is a difference of opinion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My opponent thinks the government -- the surplus is the government's money.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's not what I think.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think it's the hard-working people of America's money and I want to share some of that money with you so you have more money to build and save and dream for your families.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's a difference of opinion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's a difference between government making decisions for you and you getting more of your money to make decisions for yourself.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I take him for his word.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Look, I fully recognize I'm not of Washington.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And he's got a lot of experience, but so do I.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I've been the chief executive officer of the second biggest state in the union.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I have a proud record of working with both Republicans and Democrats, which is what our nation needs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Somebody that can come to Washington and say let's forget all the finger pointing and get positive things done on Medicare, prescription drugs, Social Security, and so I take him for his word.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Jim, if I could just respond.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The governor used the phrase phony numbers, but if you look at the plan and add the numbers up, these numbers are correct.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: He spends more money for tax cuts for the wealthiest 1% than all of his new spending proposals for health care, prescription drugs, education and national defense all combined.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I agree that the surplus is the American people's money, it's your money.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: That's why I don't think we should give nearly half of it to the wealthiest 1%, because the other 99% have had an awful lot to do with building the surplus in our prosperity.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I hope itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s about wealthy people.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Actually what I've said, Jim.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've said that eight years ago they campaigned on prescription drugs for seniors.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And four years ago they campaigned on getting prescription drugs for seniors.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And now they're campaigning on getting prescription drugs for seniors.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It seems like they can't get it done.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Now, they may blame other folks, but it's time to get somebody in Washington who is going to work with both Republicans and Democrats to get some positive things done when it comes to our seniors.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so what I've said is that there's been some missed opportunities.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They've had a chance to form consensus.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've got a plan on Medicare, for example, that's a two-stage plan that says we'll have immediate help for seniors and what I call immediate Helping Hand, a $48 billion program.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I also want to say to seniors, if you're happy with Medicare the way it is, fine, you can stay in the program.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But we're going to give you additional choices like they give federal employees in the federal employee health plan.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They have a variety of choices to choose, so should seniors.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And my point has been, as opposed to politicizing an issue like Medicare, in other words, holding it up as an issue, hoping somebody bites it and try to clobber them over the head with it for political purposes, this year, in the year 2000, it's time to get it done once and for all.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's what I've been critical about the administration for.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think there was a good opportunity to bring Republicans and Democrats together to reform the Social Security system so seniors will never go without.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Those on Social Security today will have their promise made, but also to give younger workers the option at their choice of being able to manage some of their own money in the private sector to make sure there's a Social Security system around tomorrow.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There are a lot of young workers at our rallies we go to that when they hear I'll trust them at their option to be able to manage, under certain guidelines, some of their own money to get a better rate of return so that they'll have a retirement plan in the future, they begin to nod their heads and they want a different attitude in Washington.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, Jim, under my plan all seniors will get prescription drugs under Medicare.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The governor has described Medicare as a government HMO.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It's not, and let me explain the difference.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Under the Medicare prescription drug proposal I'm making, here is how it works, you go to your own doctor.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Your doctor chooses your prescription.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: No HMO or insurance company can take those choices away from you.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Then you go to your own pharmacy.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: You fill the prescription and Medicare pays half the cost.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you're in a very poor family or if you have very high costs, Medicare will pay all the costs, a $25 premium, and much better benefits than you can possibly find in the private sector.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now here is the contrast.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: 95% of all seniors would get no help whatsoever under my opponent's plan for the first four or five years.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, one thing I don't understand, Jim, is why is it that the wealthiest 1% get their tax cuts the first year, but 95% of seniors have to wait four to five years before they get a single penny?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I guess my answer to that is the man is running on Medi-scare.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Trying to frighten people in the voting booth.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's just not the way I think and it's not my intentions and not my plan.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want all seniors to have prescription drugs in Medicare.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We need to reform Medicare.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: ThereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s been opportunity to do so but this administration has failed to do it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so seniors will have not only a Medicare plan where the poor seniors will have prescription drugs paid for, but there will be a variety of options.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The current system today has meant a lot for a lot of seniors, and I really appreciate the intentions of the current system as I mentioned.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If you're happy with the system you can stay in it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But there are a lot of procedures that haven't kept up in Medicare with the current times.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: No prescription drug benefits, no drug therapy, no preventative medicines, no vision care.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We need to have a modern system to help seniors, and the idea of supporting a federally controlled 132,000-page document bureaucracy as being a compassionate way for seniors, and the only compassionate source of care for seniors is not my vision.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe we ought to give seniors more options.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe we ought to make the system work better.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I know it will require a different kind of leader to go to Washington to say to both Republicans and Democrats, let's come together.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You've had your chance, Vice President, you've been there for eight years and nothing has been done.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My point is, is that my plan not only trusts seniors with options, my plan sets aside $3.4 trillion for Medicare over the next ten years.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My plan also says it requires a new approach in Washington, D.C.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's going to require somebody who can work across the partisan divide.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If I could respond to that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Under my plan I will put Medicare in an iron clad lockbox and prevent the money from being used for anything other than Medicare.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The governor has declined to endorse that idea even though the Republican as well as Democratic leaders in Congress have endorsed it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I would be interested to see if he would say this evening he'll put Medicare in a lockbox.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t think he will because under his plan if you work out the numbers Ã‚ $100 billion comes out of Medicare just for the wealthiest 1% in the tax cut.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now here is the difference.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Some people who say the word reform actually mean cuts.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Under the governor's plan, if you kept the same fee for service that you have now under Medicare, your premiums would go up by between 18% and 47%, and that is the study of the Congressional plan that he's modeled his proposal on by the Medicare actuaries.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Let me give you one quick example.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: There is a man here tonight named George McKinney from Milwaukee.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: He's 70 years old, has high blood pressure, his wife has heart trouble.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: They have an income of $25,000 a year.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: They can't pay for their prescription drugs and so they're some of the ones that go to Canada regularly in order to get their prescription drugs.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Under my plan, half of their costs would be paid right away.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Under Governor Bush's plan, they would get not one penny for four to five years and then they would be forced to go into an HMO or to an insurance company and ask them for coverage, but there would be no limit on the premiums or the deductibles or any of the terms and conditions.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I cannot let this go by, the old-style Washington politics, of we're going to scare you in the voting booth.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Under my plan the man gets immediate help with prescription drugs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's called Immediate Helping Hand.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Instead of squabbling and finger pointing, he gets immediate help.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Can I make another point?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: They get $25,000 a year income, that makes them ineligible.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Look, this is a man who has great numbers.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm beginning to think not only did he invent the Internet, but he invented the calculator.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's a scaring -- he's trying to scare people in the voting booth.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Under my tax plan that he continues to criticize, I set one-third.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The federal government should take no more than a third of anybody's check.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I also dropped the bottom rate from 15% to 10%.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Because by far the vast majority of the help goes to people at the bottom end of the economic ladder.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If you're a family of four in Massachusetts, making $50,000, you get a 50% cut in the federal income taxes you pay.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's from $4000 to about $2000.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Now, the difference in our plans is I want that $2,000 to go to you, and the vice president would like to be spending the $2,000 on your behalf.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's just clear you can go to the website and look.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you make more than $25,000 a year you don't get a penny of help under the Bush prescription drug proposal for at least four to five years, and then you're pushed into a Medicare -- into an HMO or insurance company plan, and there's no limit on the premiums or the deductibles or any of the conditions.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And the insurance companies say it won't work and they won't offer these plans.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The difference is I want to bring it to 100% and he wants to bring it to 5%.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: That's totally false for him to stand up here and say that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Let me make sure the seniors hear me loud and clear.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They have had their chance to get something done.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm going to work with Democrats and Republicans to reform the system.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: All seniors will be covered, all poor seniors will have their prescription drugs paid for, and in the meantime, we'll have a plan to help poor seniors and in the meantime it could be one year or two years.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Let me call your attention to the key word there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: He said all poor seniors.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: All seniors are covered under prescription drugs in my plan.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If we can get it done in the first year, you bet.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Yours is phased in in eight years.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: For the first four years -- it takes a year to pass it and for the first four years only the poor are covered.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Middle class seniors like George McKinney and his wife are not covered for four to five years.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And here is the simple difference.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: My plan has not only a short-term component, but also a long-term component.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And it focuses not only on increasing the supply, which I think we have to do, but also on working on the consumption side.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, in the short-term we have to free ourselves from the domination of the big oil companies that have the ability to manipulate the price from OPEC when they want to raise the price.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And in the long-term we have to give new incentives for the development of domestic resources like deep gas in the western Gulf, like stripper wells for oil, but also renewable sources of energy.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And domestic sources that are cleaner and better.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I'm proposing a plan that will give tax credits and tax incentives for the rapid development of new kinds of cars and trucks and buses and factories and boilers and furnaces that don't have as much pollution, that don't burn as much energy, and that help us get out on the cutting edge of the new technologies that will create millions of new jobs.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Because, when we sell these new products here, we'll then be able to sell them overseas.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: There is a ravenous demand for them overseas.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, another big difference is Governor Bush is proposing to open up some of our most precious environmental treasures, like the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for the big oil companies to go in and start producing oil there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that is the wrong choice.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It would only give us a few months' worth of oil and the oil wouldn't start flowing for many years into the future.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I don't think it's a fair price to pay to destroy precious parts of America's environment.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We have to bet on the future and move beyond the current technologies to have a whole new generation of more efficient, cleaner, energy technology.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It's an issue I know a lot about.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I was a small oil person for a while in west Texas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This is an administration that's had no plan.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And all of a sudden the results of having no plan have caught up with America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: First and foremost we have to fully fund LIHEAP which is a way to help low income folks, particularly here in the east to pay for high fuel bills.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Secondly, we need an active exploration program in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The only way to become less dependent on foreign sources of crude oil is to explore at home.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You bet I want to open up a small part of Alaska.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: When that field is online it will produce one million barrels a day.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Today we import one million barrels from Saddam Hussein.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I would rather that a million come from our own hemisphere, our own country as opposed to Saddam Hussein.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to build more pipelines to move natural gas throughout this hemisphere.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to develop the coal resources in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve got abundant supplies of energy here in America and weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d better get after it, we better start exploring it or otherwise we'll be in deep trouble in the future because of our dependency upon foreign sources of crude.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm for doing something both on the supply side and production side and on the consumption side.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Let me say, that I found one thing in Governor Bush's answer that we certainly agree on, and that's the low income heating assistance program.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I commend you for supporting that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I worked to get $400 million just a couple of weeks ago.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And to establish a permanent home heating oil reserve here in the northeast.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, as for the proposals that I've worked for for renewables and conservation and efficiencies and new technologies.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The fact is for the last few years in the Congress, we've faced a lot of opposition to them.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: They've only approved about 10% of the agenda I've helped to send up there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think we need to get serious about this energy crisis, both in the Congress and in the White House, and if you entrust me with the presidency, I will tackle this problem and focus on new technologies that will make us less dependent on big oil or foreign oil.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Well I would first say he should have been tackling it for the last seven years.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Secondly the difference is we need to explore at home.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And the vice president doesn't believe in exploration in Alaska.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There's a lot of shut-in gas that we need to be moving out of Alaska by pipeline.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There's an interesting issue up in the northwest as well.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Do we remove dams that produce hydroelectric energy?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm against removing dams in the northwest.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t know where the vice president stands but thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a renewable energy source of energy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We need to keep that in line.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There is an abundant supply of coal in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I know we can do a better job of clean coal technologies.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm going to ask the Congress for $2 billion to make sure we have the cleanest coal technologies in the world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My answer to you is in the short-term we need to get after it here in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We need to explore our resources and we need to develop our reservoirs of domestic production.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We also need to have a hemispheric energy policy where Canada, Mexico and the United States come together.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I brought this up recently with Vincent Fox the newly elected president in Mexico, he's a man I know from Mexico.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I talked to him about how best to expedite the exploration of natural gas in Mexico and transport it up to the United States so we become less dependent on foreign sources of crude oil.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This is a major problem facing America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The administration did not deal with it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's time for a new administration to deal with the energy problem.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If I may just briefly, Jim, note.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I found a couple of other things we agree upon.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We may not find that many this evening, so I wanted to emphasize.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I strongly support new investments in clean coal technology.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I made a proposal three months ago on this.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And also domestic exploration yes, but not in the environmental treasures of our country.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We don't have to do that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I know the oil companies have been itching to do that, but it is not the right thing for the future.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It's the right thing for the consumers.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Less dependency upon foreign sources of crude is good for consumers.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we can do so in an environmentally friendly way.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well can I have the last word on this?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I don't think a president can do that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I was disappointed in the ruling because I think abortions ought to be more rare in America, and I'm worried that that pill will create more abortions and cause more people to have abortions.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This is a very important topic and it's a very sensitive topic, because a lot of good people disagree on the issue.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think what the next president ought to do is to promote a culture of life in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Life of the elderly and life of those living all across the country.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: As a matter of fact, I think a noble goal for this country is that every child, born or unborn, need to be protected by law and welcomed to life.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I know we need to change a lot of minds before we get there in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: What I do believe is that we can find good, common ground on issues of parental consent or parental notification.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I know we need to ban partial birth abortions.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This is a place where my opponent and I have strong disagreement.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe banning partial birth abortions would be a positive step to reducing the number of abortions in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This is an issue that will require a new attitude.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've been battling over abortion for a long period of time.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Surely this nation can come together to promote the value of life.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Surely we can fight off these laws that will encourage doctors to -- to allow doctors to take the lives of our seniors.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Surely we can work together to create a cultural life so some of these youngsters who feel like they can take a neighbor's life with a gun will understand that that's not the way America is meant to be.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Surely we can find common ground to reduce the number of abortions in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: As to the drug itself, I mentioned I was disappointed.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I hope the FDA took its time to make sure that American women will be safe who use this drug.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, Jim, the FDA took 12 years, and I do support that decision.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: They determined it was medically safe for the women who use that drug.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: This is indeed a very important issue.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: First of all on the issue of partial birth or so-called late-term abortion, I would sign a law banning that procedure, provided that doctors have the ability to save a woman's life or to act if her health is severely at risk.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: That's not the main issue.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The main issue is whether or not the Roe v. Wade decision is going to be overturned.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I support a woman's right to choose.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It is important because the next president is going to appoint three and maybe even four justices of the Supreme Court.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And Governor Bush has declared to the anti-choice groups that he will appoint justices in the mold of Scalia and Clarence Thomas, who are known for being the most vigorous opponents of a woman's right to choose.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: He trusts the government to order a woman to do what it thinks she ought to do.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I trust women to make the decisions that affect their lives, their destinies and their bodies.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I think a woman's right to choose ought to be protected and defended.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I don't think a president can unilaterally overturn it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The FDA has made its decision.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think once a decision has been made, it's been made unless it's proven to be unsafe to women.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Jim, the question you asked, if I heard you correctly, was would he support legislation to overturn it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And if I heard the statement day before yesterday, you said you would order -- he said he would order his FDA appointee to review the decision.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now that sounds to me a little bit different.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I just think that we ought to support the decision.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I said I would make sure that women would be safe who used the drug.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The voters should assume I have no litmus test on that issue or any other issue.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Voters will know I'll put competent judges on the bench.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: People who will strictly interpret the Constitution and not use the bench to write social policy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That is going to be a big difference between my opponent and me.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe that the judges ought not to take the place of the legislative branch of government.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That they're appointed for life and that they ought to look at the Constitution as sacred.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They shouldn't misuse their bench.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't believe in liberal activist judges.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe in strict constructionists.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Those are the kind of judges I will appoint.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've named four supreme court justices in the State of Texas and would ask the people to check out their qualifications, their deliberations.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They're good, solid men and women who have made good, sound judgments on behalf of the people of Texas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We both use similar language to reach an exactly opposite outcome.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I don't favor a litmus test, but I know that there are ways to assess how a potential justice interprets the Constitution.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And in my view, the Constitution ought to be interpreted as a document that grows with our country and our history.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I believe, for example, that there is a right of privacy in the Fourth Amendment.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And when the phrase a strict constructionist is used and when the names of Scalia and Thomas are used as the benchmarks for who would be appointed, those are code words, and nobody should mistake this, for saying the governor would appoint people who would overturn Roe v. Wade.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It's very clear to me.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I would appoint people that have a philosophy that I think would have it quite likely they would uphold Roe v. Wade.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It sounds like the vice presidentÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not right very many times tonight.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I just told you the criteria on which I'll appoint judges.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I have a record of appointing judges in the State of Texas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's what a governor gets to do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: A governor gets to name supreme court judges.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He also reads all kinds of things into my tax plan and into my Medicare plan.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want the viewers out there to listen to what I have to say about it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It would be likely that they would uphold Roe v. Wade.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I do believe it's wrong to use a litmus test.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you look at the history of a lower court judge's rulings, you can get a pretty good idea of how they'll interpret questions.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: A lot of questions are first impression, and these questions that have been seen many times come up in a new context and so -- but, you know, this is a very important issue.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Because a lot of young women in this country take this right for granted and it could be lost.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It is on the ballot in this election, make no mistake about it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I'll tell you what kind of judges he'll put on.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He'll put liberal activists justices who will use their bench to subvert the legislature, that's what he'll do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, Milosevic has lost the election.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: His opponent, Kostunica, has won the election.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Milosevic's government refuses to release the vote count.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: There's now a general strike going on.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think we should support the people of Serbia and Yugoslavia, as they call the Serbia plus Montenegro, and put pressure in every way possible to recognize the lawful outcome of the election.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The people of Serbia have acted very bravely in kicking this guy out of office.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now he is trying to not release the votes and then go straight to a so-called runoff election without even announcing the results of the first vote.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, we've made it clear, along with our allies, that when Milosevic leaves, then Serbia will be able to have a more normal relationship with the rest of the world.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: That is a very strong incentive that we've given them to do the right thing.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Bear in mind also, Milosevic has been indicted as a war criminal and he should be held accountable for his actions.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, we have to take measured steps because the sentiment within Serbia is, for understandable reasons, against the United States because their nationalism -- even if they don't like Milosevic, they still have some feelings lingering from the NATO action there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: So we have to be intelligent in the way we go about it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But make no mistake about it, we should do everything we can to see that the will of the Serbian people expressed in this extraordinary election is done.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I hope that he'll be out of office very shortly.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Well, I'm pleased with the results of the election.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: As the vice president is.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's time for the man to go.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It means that the United States must have a strong diplomatic hand with our friends in NATO.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's why it's important to make sure our alliances are as strong as they possibly can be to keep the pressure on Mr. Milosevic.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But this will be an interesting moment for the Russians to step up and lead as well.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Be a wonderful time for the Russians to step into the Balkans and convince Mr. Milosevic that it's in his best interest and his country's best interest to leave office.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The Russians have a lot of sway in that part of the world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We would like to see the Russians use that sway to encourage democracy to take hold.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's time for the man to leave.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In this particular situation, no.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Bear in mind that we have a lot of sanctions in force against Serbia right now.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And the people of Serbia know that they can escape all those sanctions if this guy is turned out of power.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, I understand what the governor has said about asking the Russians to be involved, and under some circumstances that might be a good idea.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But being as they have not yet been willing to recognize Kostunica as the lawful winner of the election, I'm not sure it's right for us to invite the president of Russia to mediate this -- this dispute there because we might not like the results that comes out of that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: They currently favor going forward with a runoff election.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that's the wrong thing.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think the governor's instinct is not necessarily bad because we have worked with the Russians in a constructive way in Kosovo, for example, to end the conflict there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But I think we need to be very careful in the present situation before we invite the Russians to play the lead role in mediating.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Well obviously we wouldn't use the Russians if they didn't agree with our answer, Mr. Vice President.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Let me say this to you, I wouldn't use force.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's not in our national interest to use force in this case.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I would use pressure and diplomacy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There is a difference with what the president did in Kosovo which I supported and this.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's up to the people in this region to take control of their country.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, if it's in our vital national interests, and that means whether our territory is threatened or people could be harmed, whether or not the alliances are -- our defense alliances are threatened, whether or not our friends in the Middle East are threatened.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That would be a time to seriously consider the use of force.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Secondly, whether or not the mission was clear.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Whether or not it was a clear understanding as to what the mission would be.
Speaker: George W. Bush
