Text: Thirdly, whether or not we were prepared and trained to win.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Whether or not our forces were of high morale and high standing and well-equipped.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And finally, whether or not there was an exit strategy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I would take the use of force very seriously.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I would be guarded in my approach.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't think we can be all things to all people in the world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think we've got to be very careful when we commit our troops.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The vice president and I have a disagreement about the use of troops.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He believes in nation building.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I would be very careful about using our troops as nation builders.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe the role of the military is to fight and win war and therefore prevent war from happening in the first place.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So I would take my responsibility seriously.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And it starts with making sure we rebuild our military power.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Morale in today's military is too low.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're having trouble meeting recruiting goals.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We met the goals this year, but in the previous years we have not met recruiting goals.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Some of our troops are not well-equipped.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe we're overextended in too many places.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And therefore I want to rebuild the military power.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It starts with a billion dollar pay raise for the men and women who wear the uniform.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: A billion dollars more than the president recently signed into law.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's to make sure our troops are well-housed and well-equipped.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Bonus plans to keep some of our high-skilled folks in the services and a commander in chief who clearly sets the mission.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The mission is to fight and win war and therefore prevent war from happening in the first place.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Let me tell you what IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll do.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: First of all Ã‚ I want to make it clear, our military is the strongest, best-trained, best-equipped, best-led fighting force in the world and in the history of the world.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Nobody should have any doubt about that, least of all our adversaries or potential adversaries.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you entrust me with the presidency, I will do whatever is necessary in order to make sure our forces stay the strongest in the world.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: In fact, in my ten-year budget proposal I've set aside more than twice as much for this purpose as Governor Bush has in his proposal.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, I think we should be reluctant to get involved in someplace in a foreign country.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But if our national security is at stake, if we have allies, if we've tried every other course, if we're sure military action will succeed, and if the costs are proportionate to the benefits, we should get involved.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, just because we don't want to get involved everywhere doesn't mean we should back off anywhere it comes up.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I disagree with the proposal that maybe only when oil supplies are at stake that our national security is at risk.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that there are situations like in Bosnia or Kosovo where there's a genocide, where our national security is at stake there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I agree our military is the strongest in the world today, that's not the question.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The question is will it be the strongest in the years to come?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The warning signs are real.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Everywhere I go on the campaign trail I see moms and dads whose son or daughter may wear the uniform and they tell me about how discouraged their son or daughter may be.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: A recent poll was taken among 1,000 enlisted personnel, as well as officers, over half of whom will leave the service when their time of enlistment is up.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The captains are leaving the service.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And it's going to require a new commander in chief to rebuild the military power.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The other day I was honored to be flanked by Colin Powell and General Norman Schwartzkopf recently stood by me side and agreed with me.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They said even if we are the strongest if we donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t do something if we don't have a clear vision of the military, if we don't stop extending our troops all around the world and nation building missions, then we're going to have a serious problem coming down the road, and I'm going to prevent that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm going to rebuild our military power.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's one of the major priorities of my administration.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, they should look at our proposals and look at us as people and make up their own minds.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: When I was a young man, I volunteered for the Army.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I served my country in Vietnam.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: My father was a senator who strongly opposed the Vietnam War.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I went to college in this great city, and most of my peers felt against the war as I did.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But I went anyway because I knew if I didn't, somebody else in the small town of Carthage, Tennessee, would have to go in my place.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I served for eight years in the House of Representatives and I served on the Intelligence Committee, specialized in looking at arms control.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I served for eight years in the United States Senate and served on the Armed Services Committee.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: For the last eight years I've served on the National Security Council, and when the conflict came up in Bosnia, I saw a genocide in the heart of Europe with the most violent war on the continent of Europe since World War II.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Look, that's where World War I started in the Balkans.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: My uncle was a victim of poisonous gas there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Millions of Americans saw the results of that conflict.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We have to be willing to make good, sound judgments.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Incidentally, I know the value of making sure our troops have the latest technology.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The governor has proposed skipping the next generation of weapons.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that's a big mistake, because I think we have to stay at the cutting edge.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think you've got to look at how one has handled responsibility in office.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Whether or not it's -- the same in domestic policy as well.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Whether or not you have the capacity to convince people to follow?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Whether or not one makes decisions based on sound principles or whether or not you rely upon polls and focus groups on how to decide what the course of action is.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We have too much polling and focus groups going on in Washington today.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We need decisions made on sound principles.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've been the governor of a big state.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think one of the hallmarks of my relationship in Austin, Texas, is that I've had the capacity to work with both Republicans and Democrats.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think that's an important part of leadership.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think what it means to build consensus.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've shown I know how to do so.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Tonight in the audience there's one elected state senator who is a Democrat, a former state-wide officer who is a Democrat, a lot of Democrats who are here in the debate to -- because they want to show their support that shows I know how to lead.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so the fundamental answer to your question, who can lead and who's shown the ability to get things done?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If I could say one thing.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: One of the key points in foreign policy and national security policy is the need to re-establish the old-fashioned principle that politics ought to stop at the water's edge.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: When I was in the United States Congress, I worked with former President Reagan to modernize our strategic weaponry and to pursue arms control in a responsible way.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I was one of only a few Democrats in the Senate to support the Persian Gulf War.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think bipartisanship is a national asset.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We have to find ways to reestablish it in foreign policy and national security policy.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Why haven't they done it in seven years?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This is a very important moment in the history of our country.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Look, we've got the biggest surpluses in all of American history.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The key question that has to be answered in this election is will we use that prosperity wisely in a way that benefits all of our people and doesn't go just to the few.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Almost half of all the tax cut benefits, as I said under Governor Bush's plan, go to the wealthiest 1%.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think we have to make the right and responsible choices.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think we have to invest in education, protecting the environment, health care, a prescription drug benefit that goes to all seniors, not just to the poor, under Medicare, not relying on HMOs and insurance companies.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that we have to help parents and strengthen families by dealing with the kind of inappropriate entertainment material that families are just heart sick that their children are exposed to.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think we've got to have welfare reform taken to the next stage.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that we have got to balance the budget every single year, pay down the national debt and, in fact, under my proposal the national debt will be completely eliminated by the year 2012.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think we need to put Medicare and Social Security in a lockbox.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The governor will not put Medicare in a lockbox.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I don't think it should be used as a piggy bank for other programs.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think it needs to be moved out of the budget and protected.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: That extends the life of Social Security for 55 years.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, I think that it's very important to understand that cutting benefits under Social Security means that people like Winifred Skinner from Des Moines, Iowa, who is here, would really have a much harder time.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Because there are millions of seniors who are living almost hand to mouth.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And you talk about cutting benefits.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I don't go along with it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I am opposed to it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I'm also opposed to a plan that diverts 1 out of every $6 away from the Social Security Trust Fund.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Social Security is a trust fund that pays the checks this year with the money that is paid into Social Security this year.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The governor wants to divert 1 out of every $6 off into the stock market, which means that he would drain a trillion dollars out of the Social Security Trust Fund in this generation over the next ten years, and Social Security under that approach would go bankrupt within this generation.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: His leading advisor on this plan actually said that would be okay, because then the Social Security Trust Fund could start borrowing.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It would borrow up to $3 trillion.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, Social Security has never done that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I don't think it should do that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think it should stay in a lockbox, and I'll tell you this.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I will veto anything that takes money out of Social Security for privatization or anything else other than Social Security.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I thought it was interesting that on the two minutes he spent about a million-and-a-half on my plan, which means he doesn't want you to know what he's doing is loading up IOUs for future generations.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He puts no real assets into the Social Security system.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The revenues exceed the expenses in Social Security until the year 2015 which means all retirees are going to get the promises made.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: For those of you who he wants to scare into the voting booth to vote for him, hear me loud and clear.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: A promise made will be a promise kept.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You bet we want to allow younger workers to take some of their own money.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's the difference of opinion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The vice president thinks it's the government's money.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The payroll taxes are your money.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You ought to put it in prudent, safe investments so that $1 trillion over the next ten years grows to be $3 trillion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The money stays within the Social Security system.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's a part of the Social Security system.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He claims it will be out of Social Security.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's your money, it's a part of your retirement benefit.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's a fundamental difference between what we believe.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want you to have your own asset that you can call your own.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That you can pass on from one generation to the next.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to get a better rate of return for your own money than the paltry 2% that the current Social Security Trust gets today.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Mr. Greenspan I thought missed an opportunity to say there's a third way, and that is to get a better rate of return on the Social Security monies coming into the trust.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There is $2.3 trillion of surplus that we can use to make sure that younger workers have a Social Security plan in the future.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If we're smart and if we trust workers and if we understand the power of the compounding rate of interest.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I give a new incentive for younger workers to save their own money and invest their own money, but not at the expense of Social Security, on top of Social Security.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: My plan is Social Security plus.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The governor's plan is Social Security minus.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Your future benefits would be cut by the amount that's diverted into the stock market.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you make bad investments, that's too bad.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But even before then the problem hits because the money contributed to Social Security this year is an entitlement.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And the money is used to pay the benefits for seniors this year.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you cut the amount going in 1 out of every $6, then you have to cut the value of each check by 1 out of every $6 unless you come up with the money from somewhere else.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I would like to know from the governor -- I know we're not supposed to ask each other questions -- but I'd be interested in knowing, does that trillion dollars come from the trust fund, or does it come from the rest of the budget?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: There's enough money to pay seniors today in the current affairs of Social Security.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The trillion comes from the surplus.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Surplus is money -- more money than needed.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Let me tell you what your plan is.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's not Social Security plus, it's Social Security plus huge debt.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That is what it is.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You leave future generations with tremendous IOUs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's time to have a leader that doesn't put off tomorrow what we should do today.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's time to have somebody to step up and say look, let's let younger workers take some of their own money and under certain guidelines invest it in the private markets.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The safest of federal investments yields 4%.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's twice the amount of rate of return than the current Social Security Trust.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's a fundamental difference of opinion here, folks.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Younger worker after younger worker hears my call that says I trust you.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And you know what, the issue is changing.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Seniors now understand that the promise made will be a promise kept, but younger workers now understand we better have a government that trusts them and that's exactly what I'm going to do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Could I respond to that, Jim?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: This is a big issue.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Could we do another round on it?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: When FDR established Social Security, they didn't call them IOUs, they called it the full faith and credit of the United States.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you don't have trust in that, I do.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you take it out of the surplus in the trust fund, that means the trust fund goes bankrupt in this generation within 20 years.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: This is a government that thinks a 2% rate of return on your money is satisfactory.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This is a government that says younger workers can't possibly have their own assets.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We need to think differently about the issue.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We need to make sure our seniors get the promise made.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If we don't trust younger workers to manage some of their own money with the Social Security surplus, to grow from $1 trillion to $3 trillion, it will be impossible to bridge the gap without it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: What Mr. Gore's plan will do causing huge payroll taxes or major benefit reductions.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The man loves his wife and I appreciate that a lot.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The man loves his family a lot, and I appreciate that, because I love my family.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think the thing that discouraged me about the vice president was uttering those famous words, "No controlling legal authority."
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I felt like there needed to be a better sense of responsibility of what was going on in the White House.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe that -- I believe they've moved that sign, "The buck stops here" from the Oval Office desk to "The buck stops here" on the Lincoln bedroom.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's not good for the country and it's not right.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We need to have a new look about how we conduct ourselves in office.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I see it all the time when people come up to me and say, I don't want you to let me down again.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we can do better than the past administration has done.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's time for a fresh start.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's time for a new look.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's time for a fresh start after a season of cynicism.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so I don't know the man well, but I've been disappointed about how he and his administration have conducted the fundraising affairs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You know, going to a Buddhist temple and then claiming it wasn't a fundraiser isn't my view of responsibility.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think we ought to attack our country's problems, not attack each other.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I want to spend my time making this country even better than it is, not trying to make you out to be a bad person.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: You may want to focus on scandal.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I want to focus on results.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: As I said a couple of months ago, I stand here as my own man and I want you to see me for who I really am.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Tipper and I have been married for 30 years.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We became grandparents a year-and-a-half ago.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I have devoted 24 years of my life to public service and I've said this before and I'll say it again, if you entrust me with the presidency, I may not be the most exciting politician, but I will work hard for you every day.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I will fight for middle-class families and working men and women and I will never let you down.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: They ought to factor in it when they go to the voting booth.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think people need to be held responsible for the actions they take in life.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think that -- well, I think that's part of the need for a cultural change.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We need to say we each need to be responsible for what we do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: People in the highest office of the land must be responsible for decisions they make in life.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's the way I've conducted myself as Governor of Texas and that's the way I'll conduct myself as President of the United States, should I be fortunate enough to earn your vote.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think the American people should take into account who we are as individuals, what our experience is, what our positions are on the issues and proposals are.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I'm asking you to see me for who I really am.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I'm offering you my own vision, my own experience, my own proposals.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And incidentally, one of them is this.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: This current campaign financing system has not reflected credit on anybody in either party.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And that's one of the reasons I've said before, and I'll pledge here tonight, if I'm president, the very first bill that Joe Lieberman and I will send to the United States Congress is the McCain-Feingold campaign finance reform bill.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And the reason it's that important is that all of the other issues, whether prescription drugs for all seniors that are opposed by the drug companies or the patient's bill of rights to take the decisions away from the HMOs and give them to the doctors and nurses, opposed by the HMOs and insurance companies, all these other proposals are going to be a lot easier to get passed for the American people if we limit the influence of special interest money and give democracy back to the American people.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I wish Governor Bush would join me this evening in endorsing the McCain-Feingold Campaign Finance Reform Bill.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: You know, this man has no credibility on the issue.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: As a matter of fact, I read in the "New York Times" where he said he co-sponsored the McCain-Feingold Campaign Fundraising Bill.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But he wasn't in the Senate with Senator Feingold.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so, look, I'm going to -- what you need to know about me is I will uphold the law, I'm going to have an attorney general that enforces the law.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The time for campaign funding reform is after the election.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This man has outspent me and the special interests are outspending me.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I am not going to lay down my arms in the middle of the campaign for somebody who has got no credibility on the issue.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I would support an effort to ban corporate soft money and labor union soft money so long as there was dues check-off.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've campaigned on this since the primaries.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe there needs to be instant disclosure on the Internet as to who has given to who.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think we need to fully enforce the law.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think we need to have an attorney general that says if a law is broken, we'll enforce it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Be strict and firm about it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Look, Governor Bush, you have attacked my character and credibility and I am not going to respond in kind.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think we ought to focus on the problems and not attack each other.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: One of the serious problems, hear me well, is that our system of government is being undermined by too much influence coming from special interest money.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We have to get a handle on it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And like John McCain, I have learned from experience, and it's not a new position for me.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: 24 years ago I supported full public financing of all federal elections.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And anybody who thinks I'm just saying it, it will be the first bill I send to the Congress.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I want you to know I care passionately about this and I will fight until it becomes law.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I want people to hear what he just said.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He is for full public financing of Congressional elections.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm absolutely, adamently opposed to that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't want the government financing congressional elections.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Thank the University of Massachusetts and Mr. Vice President, thank you.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It has been a good, lively exchange.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There is a huge difference of opinion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Mine is I want to empower people in their own lives.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I also want to go to Washington to get some positive things done.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It is going to require a new spirit.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It will require the ability of a Republican president to reach out across the partisan divide and to say to Democrats, let's come together to do what is right for America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's been my record as Governor of Texas, it will be how I conduct myself if I'm fortunate enough to earn your vote as President of the United States.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to finally get something done on Medicare.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to make sure prescription drugs are available for all seniors.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I want seniors to have additional choices when it comes to choosing their health care plans.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to finally get something done on Social Security.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to make sure the seniors have the promise made will be a promise kept, but I want younger workers to be able to manage some of their own money, some of their own payroll taxes in the private sector under certain guidelines to get a better rate of return on your own money.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to have a strong hand when it comes to the United States in world affairs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't want to try to put our troops in all places at all times.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't want to be the world's policeman, I want to be the world's peacemaker by having a military of high morale and a military that is well-equipped.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want anti-ballistic missile systems to protect ourselves and our allies from a rogue nation that may try to hold us hostage or blackmail our allies and friends.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to make sure the education system fulfills its hope and promise.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've had a strong record of working with Democrats and Republicans in Texas to make sure no child is left behind.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I understand the limited role of the federal government, but it could be a constructive role when it comes to reform, by insisting that there be a strong accountability systems.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My intentions are to earn your vote and earn your confidence.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm asking for your vote.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want you to be on my team.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And for those of you working, thanks from the bottom of my heart.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: For those of you making up your mind, I would be honored to have your support.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to thank everybody who watched and listened tonight because this is indeed a crucial time in American history.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We're at a fork in the road.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We have this incredible prosperity, but a lot of people have been left behind.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And we have a very important decision to make.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Will we use the prosperity to enrich all of our families and not just a few?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: One important way of looking at this is to ask who are you going to fight for?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Throughout my career in public service, I have fought for the working men and women of this country, middle-class families.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Because you are the ones who have the hardest time paying taxes, the hardest time making ends meet.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: You are the ones who are making car payments and mortgage payments and doing right by your kids.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And a lot of times there are powerful forces that are against you.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Make no mistake about it, they do have undue influence in Washington, D.C. and it makes a difference if you have a president who will fight for you.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I know one thing about the position of president, it's the only position in our Constitution that is filled by an individual who is given the responsibility to fight not just for one state or one district or the well-connected or wealthy, but to fight for all of the people, including especially those who most need somebody who will stand up and take on whatever powerful forces might stand in the way.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: There is a woman named Winifred Skinner here tonight from Iowa.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I'm not going to cut her benefits or support any proposal that would.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: She gets a small pension, but in order to pay for her prescription drug benefits, she has to go out seven days a week several hours a day picking up cans.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: She came all the way from Iowa in a Winnebago with her poodle in order attend here tonight.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I want to tell her, I'll fight for a prescription drug benefit for all seniors and fight for the people of this country for a prosperity that benefits all.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: That's right at the top of my agenda.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We've shipped millions of jobs overseas and we have a strange situation because we have a process in Washington where after you've served for a while you cash in, become a foreign lobbyist, make $30,000 a month, then take a leave, work on presidential campaigns, make sure you've got good contacts and then go back out.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, if you just want to get down to brass tacks, first thing you ought to do is get all these folks who've got these 1-way trade agreements that we've negotiated over the years and say fellas, we'll take the same deal we gave you.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And they'll gridlock right at that point because for example, we've got international competitors who simply could not unload their cars off the ships if they had to comply -- you see, if it was a 2-way street, just couldn't do it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We have got to stop sending jobs overseas.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: To those of you in the audience who are business people: pretty simple.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If you're paying $12, $13, $14 an hour for a factory worker, and you can move your factory south of the border, pay $1 an hour for labor, hire a young -- let's assume you've been in business for a long time.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You've got a mature workforce.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Pay $1 an hour for your labor, have no health care -- that's the most expensive single element in making the car.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Have no environmental controls, no pollution controls and no retirement.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And you don't care about anything but making money.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: There will be a job-sucking sound going south.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If the people send me to Washington the first thing I'll do is study that 2000-page agreement and make sure it's a 2-way street.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I decided I was dumb and didn't understand it so I called a "Who's Who" of the folks that have been around it, and I said why won't everybody go south; they said it will be disruptive; I said for how long.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I finally got 'em for 12 to 15 years.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And I said, well, how does it stop being disruptive?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And that is when their jobs come up from a dollar an hour to $6 an hour, and ours go down to $6 an hour; then it's leveled again, but in the meantime you've wrecked the country with these kind of deals.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We got to cut it out.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Carole, the thing that saved us in this global economic slowdown has been our exports, and what I'm trying to do is increase our exports.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And if indeed all the jobs were going to move south because there are lower wages, there are lower wages now and they haven't done that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so I have just negotiated with the president of Mexico the North American Free Trade Agreement -- and the prime minister of Canada, I might add -- and I want to have more of these free trade agreements, because export jobs are increasing far faster than any jobs that may have moved overseas.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That's a scare tactic, because it's not that many.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But any one that's here, we want to have more jobs here.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And the way to do that is to increase our exports.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't; I believe in free and fair trade, and that's the thing that saved us.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So I will keep on as president trying to get a successful conclusion to the GATT Round, the big Uruguay Round of trade which will really open up markets for our agriculture particularly.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to continue to work after we get this NAFTA agreement ratified this coming year.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to get one with Eastern Europe; I want to get one with Chile.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And free and fair trade is the answer, not protection.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And, as I say, we've had tough economic times, and it's exports that have saved us, exports that have built.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'd like to answer the question, because I've actually been a governor for 12 years, so I've known a lot of people who have lost their jobs because of jobs moving overseas, and I know a lot of people whose plants have been strengthened by increasing exports.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The trick is to expand our export base and to expand trade on terms that are fair to us.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It is true that our exports to Mexico, for example, have gone up and our trade deficit has gone down; it's also true that just today a record high trade deficit was announced with Japan.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So what is the answer?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me just mention three things very quickly.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Number one, make sure that other countries are as open to our markets as our markets are to them, and, if they're not, have measures on the books that don't take forever and a day to implement.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Number two, change the tax code.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: There are more deductions in the tax code for shutting plants down and moving overseas than there are for modernizing plant and equipment here.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Our competitors don't do that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Emphasize and subsidize modernizing plant and equipment here, not moving plants overseas.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Number three, stop the federal government's program that now gives low-interest loans and job training funds to companies that will actually shut down and move to other countries, but we won't do the same thing for plants that stay here.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So more trade but on fair terms -- and favor investment in America.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I'll tell you exactly why.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Because the deficit now has been building up for 12 years.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'll tell you exactly what I think can be done.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think we can bring it down by 50% in 4 years and grow the economy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now, I could get rid of it in 4 years in theory on the books now, but to do it you'd have to raise taxes too much and cut benefits too much to people who need them and it would even make the economy worse.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Mr. Perot will tell you, for example, that the expert he hired to analyze his plan says that it will bring the deficit down in 5 years but it will make unemployment bad for 4 more years.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So my view is, sir, you have to increase investment, grow the economy and reduce the deficit by controlling health care costs, prudent reductions in defense, cuts in domestic programs and asking the wealthiest Americans and foreign corporations to pay their fair share of taxes and investing and growing this economy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I ask everybody to look at my economic ideas and 9 Nobel prize winners and over 500 economists and hundreds of business people, including a lot of Republicans said, this is the way you've got to go.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: If you don't grow the economy you can't get it done.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But I can't foresee all the things that will happen, and I don't think a president should be judged solely on the deficit.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me also say, we're having an election today.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You'll have a shot at me in 4 years and you can vote me right out if you think I've done a lousy job and I would welcome you to do that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, I'm a little confused here, because I don't see how you can grow the deficit down by raising people's taxes.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You see, I don't think the American people are taxed too little.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think they're taxed too much.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I went for one tax increase and when I make a mistake I admit it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I said that wasn't the right thing to do.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Governor Clinton's program wants to tax more and spend more -- $150 billion in new taxes, spend another $220.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't believe that's the way to do it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Here's some thing that'll help.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Give us a balanced budget amendment.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He always talks about Arkansas having a balanced budget and they do, but he has a balanced budget amendment.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'd like the government to have that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I think it would discipline not only the Congress, which needs it, but also the executive branch.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'd like to have what 43 governors have -- the line item veto, so if the Congress can't cut, and we've got a reckless spending Congress, let the president have a shot at it by wiping out things that are pork barrel or something of that nature.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Some sophisticates think it may be a little gimmicky.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It says to you as a taxpayer -- say you're going to pay a tax of 1000 bucks or something.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You can check 10% of that if you want to, in the 1 box, and that 10%, $100, or if you're paying $10,000, whatever it is, $1000, check it off and make the government, make it lower the deficit by that amount.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And if the Congress won't do it, if they can't get together and negotiate how to do that, then you'd have a sequester across the board.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You'd exempt Social Security -- I don't want to tax or touch Social Security.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'm the president that said hey, don't mess with Social Security, and we haven't.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So I believe that we need to control the growth of mandatory spending, back to this gentleman's question.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That's the main growing thing in the budget.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The program that the president -- two-thirds of the budget, I as president never get to look at, never get to touch.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We've got to control that growth to inflation and population increase, but not raise taxes on the American people now.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I just don't believe that would stimulate any kind of growth at all.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, we're $4 trillion in debt.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We're going into debt an additional $1 billion, little more than $1 billion every working day of the year.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, the thing I love about it -- I'm just a businessman.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I was down in Texas taking care of business, tending to my family.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: This situation got so bad that I decided I'd better get into it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The American people asked me to get into it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But I just find it fascinating that while we sit here tonight we will go into debt an additional $50 million in an hour and a half.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, it's not the Republicans' fault, of course, and it's not the Democrats' fault.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And what I'm looking for is who did it?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, they're the 2 folks involved so maybe if you put them together, they did it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, the facts are we have to fix it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'm here tonight for these young people up here in the balcony from this college.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: When I was a young man, when I got out of the Navy I had multiple job offers.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Young people with high grades can't get a job.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: People -- the 18- to 24-year-old high school graduates 10 years ago were making more than they are now.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: In other words, we were down to 18% of them were making -- 18- to 24-year- olds were making less than $12,000.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now that's up to 40%.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And what's happened in the meantime?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The dollar's gone through the floor.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, whose fault is that?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Somewhere out there there's an extraterrestrial that's doing this to us, I guess.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And everybody says they take responsibility.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Somebody somewhere has to take responsibility for this.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Put it to you bluntly, American people.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If you want me to be your president, we're going to face our problems.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll deal with our problems, weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll solve our problems.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We'll pass on the American dream to our children, and I will not leave our children a situation that they have today.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: When I was a boy it took 2 generations to double the standard of living.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Today it will take 12 generations.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Our children will not see the American dream because of this debt that somebody somewhere dropped on us.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: No, I don't have an answer for everything.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: As you all know, I've been buying 30-minute segments to talk about issues.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And tomorrow night on NBC, from 10:30 to 11 Eastern, we're going to talk about how you pay the debt down, so we're going to come right down to that one.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We'll be on again Saturday night, 8 to 9 o'clock on ABC.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So the point is --
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Like Jerry Brown, the 800 number.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: -- I couldn't agree with you more, couldn't agree with you more.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And I have said again and again and again let's get off mud wrestling, let's get off personalities and let's talk about jobs, health care, crime, the things that concern the American people.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'm spending my money -- not PAC money, not foreign money, my money -- to take this message to the people.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Well, in the first place, I believe that character is a part of being president.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think you have to look at it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think that has to be a part of a candidate for president or being president.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: In terms of programs, I've submitted, what, 4 different budgets to the US Congress in great detail.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It's so heavy they'd give you a broken back.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And everything in there says what I am for.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Now I've come out with a new agenda for America's renewal, a plan that I believe really will help stimulate the growth of this economy.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: My record on world affairs is pretty well known because I've been president for 4 years, so I feel I've been talking issues.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You know, nobody likes who shot John, but I think the first negative campaign run in this election was by Governor Clinton, and I'm not going to sit there and be a punching bag; I'm going to stand up and say, hey, listen, here's my side of it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But character is an important part of the equation.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The other night Governor Clinton raised my -- I don't know if you saw the debate the other night.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You did -- suffered through that?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, he raised the question of my father -- it was a good line, well rehearsed and well delivered.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But he raised the question of my father and said, well, your father, Prescott Bush, was against McCarthy, you should be ashamed of yourself, McCarthyism.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I remember something my dad told me -- I was 18 years old going to Penn Station to go on into the Navy, and he said write your mother -- which I faithfully did; he said serve your country -- my father was an honor, duty and country man; and he said tell the truth.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I've tried to do that in public life, all through it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That says something about character.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: My argument with Governor Clinton -- you can call it mud wrestling, but I think it's fair to put it in focus is -- I am deeply troubled by someone who demonstrates and organizes demonstration in a foreign land when his country's at war.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Probably a lot of kids here disagree with me.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But that's what I feel.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That's what I feel passionately about.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'm thinking of Ross Perot's running mate sitting in the jail.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: How would he feel about it?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But the big argument I have with the governor on this is this taking different positions on different issues -- trying to be one thing to one person here that's opposing the NAFTA agreement and then for it -- what we call waffling.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I do think that you can't turn the White House into the Waffle House.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You've got to say what you're for and you've got to --
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't want to --
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't want to --
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I get wound up because I feel strongly --
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Let me say first of all to you that I believe so strongly in the question you asked that I suggested this format tonight.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I started doing these formats a year ago in New Hampshire and I found that we had huge crowds because all I did was let people ask questions and I tried to give very specific answers.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I also had a program starting last year.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I've been disturbed by the tone and the tenor of this campaign.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Thank goodness the networks have a fact check so I don't have to just go blue in the face anymore.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Mr. Bush said once again I was going to have $150 billion tax increase.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: When Mr. Quayle said that all the networks said, that's not true.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: He's got over $100 billion of tax cuts and incentives.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I'm not going to take up your time tonight, but let me just say this.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We'll have a debate in 4 days and we can talk about this character thing again.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But the Washington Post ran a long editorial today saying they couldn't believe Mr. Bush was making character an issue and they said he was the greatest quote "political chameleon" for changing his positions of all times.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now, I don't want to get into that --
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Please don't get into the Washington Post.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Let's don't -- you don't have to believe it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'm not interested in his character.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I want to change the character of the presidency.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I'm interested in what we can trust him to do and what you can trust me to do and what you can trust Mr. Perot to do for the next 4 years.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I think you're right and I hope the rest of the night belongs to you.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let's talk about programs for children.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think it depends how you define it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I mean, I think in general, let's talk about these issues.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Let's talk about the programs.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But in the presidency, a lot goes into it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That's not specific in terms of a program.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: This is what a president has to do.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So in principle, though, I'll take your point and think we ought to discuss child care or whatever else it is.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Ross had his hand up.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Just no hedges, no ifs, ands and buts.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'll take the pledge because I know the American people want to talk about issues and not tabloid journalism.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So I'll take the pledge and will stay on the issues.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, just for the record, I don't have any spin doctors.

Text: I don't have any speechwriters.

Text: I make those charts you see on television.

Text: But you don't have to wonder if it's me talking.

Text: See, what you see is what you get and if you don't like it, you got two other choices, right?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I want to say just one thing now, Ross, in fairness.

Text: The ideas I express are mine.

Text: I've worked on these things for 12 years and I'm the only person up here who hasn't been part of Washington in any way for the last 20 years.

Text: So I don't want the implication to be that somehow everything we say is just cooked up and put in our head by somebody else.

Text: I worked 12 years very hard as a governor on the real problems of real people.

Text: I'm just as sick as you are by having to wake up and figure out how to defend myself every day.

Text: I never thought I'd ever be involved in anything like this.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I don't have any foreign lobbyists on leave in my campaign.

Text: I don't have any PAC money in my campaign.

Text: I've got 5.5 million hard-working people who put me on the ballot, and I belong to them.

Text: And they're interested in what you're interested in.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I've already taken the pledge on cutting the deficit in half.
