Text: I never got to say that.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: There's a great young group, Lead or Leave, college students, young people, who don't want us to spend their money.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I took the pledge we'd cut it out.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'll be glad to take a shot at it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'm not sure that -- and I can understand if you haven't seen this, because there's been a lot of hue and cry.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We passed this year the most furthest looking transportation bill in the history of this country since Eisenhower started the interstate highways -- $150 billion for improving the infrastructure.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That happened when I was president.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so I'm very proud of the way that came about and I think it's a very, very good beginning.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Like Mr. Perot, I am concerned about the deficits and $150 billion is a lot of money, but it's awful hard to say we're going to go out and spend more money when we're trying to get the deficit down.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I would cite that as a major accomplishment.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We hear all the negatives.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: When you're president you expect this.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Everybody's running against the incumbent.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But here's something that we can take great pride in because it really does get to what you're talking about.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Our home initiative -- our home ownership initiative -- HOPE -- that passed the Congress is a good start for having people own their own homes instead of living in these deadly tenements.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Our enterprise zones, that we hear a lot of lip service about in Congress, would bring jobs into the inner city.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I need the help of everybody across this country to get it passed in a substantial way by the Congress.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: When we went out to south central in Los Angeles -- some of you may remember the riots there.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I went to a boys' club.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And everyone of them -- the boys' club leaders, the ministers -- all of them were saying pass enterprise zones.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We go back to Washington and very difficult to get it through the Congress.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But there's going to be a new Congress.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: There's going to be a new Congress because the old one -- I don't want to get this man made at me -- but there was a post office scandal and a bank scandal.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You're going to have a lot of new members of Congress.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And then you can sit down and say, help me do what we should for the cities.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Help me pass these programs.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Sure, but the problem is, you get so many things included in a great big bill that you have to look at the overall good.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That's the problem with our system.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: If you had a line item veto you could knock out the pork.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You could knock out the tax increases and you could do what the people want, and that's create enterprise zones.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That bill pays for these urban enterprise zones by asking the wealthiest Americans to pay a little more.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And that's why he wants to veto it, just like he vetoed an earlier bill this year.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: This is not mud slinging.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: This is fact slinging -- a bill earlier this year.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: This is facts -- that would have given investment tax credits and other incentives to reinvest in our cities, in our country.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But it asked the wealthiest Americans to pay a little more.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Mr. Perot wants to do the same thing.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I mean, we agree with that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But let me tell you specifically what my plan does.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: My plan would dedicate $20 billion a year in each of the next 4 years for investments in new transportation, communications, environmental clean-ups and new technologies for the 21st century.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And we would target it especially in areas that have been either depressed or which have lost a lot of defense related jobs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: There are 200,000 people in California, for example, who have lost their defense related jobs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They ought to be engaged in breaking ground in other technologies, doing waste recycling, clean water technology and things of that kind.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We can create millions of jobs in these new technologies- -more than we're going to lose in defense -- if we target it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But we're investing a much smaller percentage of our income in the things you just asked about than all of our major competitors, and our wealth growth is going down as a result of it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's making the country poorer, which is why I answered the gentleman the way I did before.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have to both bring down the deficit and get our economy going through these kinds of investments in order to get the kind of wealth and jobs and incomes we need in America.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: First you've got to have money to pay for these things.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So you've got to create jobs.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: There are all kinds of ways to create jobs in the inner city.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'm not a politician, but I think I could go to Washington in a week and get everybody holding hands and get this bill signed because I talk to the Democratic leaders and they want it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I talk to the Republican leaders and they want it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But since they're bred from childhood to fight with one another rather than get results, you know, I would be glad to drop out and spend a little time and see if we couldn't build some bridges.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, results is what counts.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The president can't order Congress around.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Congress can't order the president around.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: That's not bad for a guy that's never been there, right?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But you have to work together.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, I have talked to the chairmen of the committees that want this.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The president wants it, but we can't get it because we sit here in gridlock because it's a campaign year.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We didn't fund a lot of other things this year, like the savings and loan mess.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: That's another story that we're going to pay a big price for right after the election.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The facts are though -- the facts are -- the American people are hurting.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: These people are hurting in the inner cities.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We're shipping the quote, "low paying jobs" overseas.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: What are low paying jobs?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Textiles, shoes, things like that that we say are yesterday's industries.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They're tomorrow's industries in the inner cities.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Let me say in my case, if I'm out of work, I'll cut grass tomorrow to take care of my family; I'll be happy to make shoes, I'll be happy to make clothing, I'll make sausage.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You just give me a job.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Put those jobs in the inner cities instead of doing diplomatic deals and shipping them to China where prison labor does the work.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If you ask me if I could fly a fighter plane or be an astronaut, I can't.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I've spent my life creating jobs.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: That's something I know how to do.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And, very simply, in the inner city, they're starved -- you see, small business is the way to jump start the inner city, not --
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You want jobs in the inner city?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Do you want jobs in the inner city?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Well, I've listened to both sides, and if they would talk to one another instead of throwing rocks, I think we could get a lot done.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And, among other things, I would say, okay, over here in this Senate committee to the chairman who is anxious to get this bill passed, the president who is anxious, I'd say rather than just yelling at one another, why don't we find out where we're apart, try to get together, get the bill passed and give the people the benefits and not play party politics right now.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And I think the press would follow that so closely that probably they would get it done.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: That's the way I would do it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I doubt if they'll give me the chance, but I will drop everything and go work on it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I support the right to keep and bear arms.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I live in a state where over half the adults have hunting or fishing licenses, or both.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But I believe we have to have some way of checking hand guns before they're sold, to check the criminal history, the mental health history, and the age of people who are buying them.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Therefore I support the Brady bill which would impose a national waiting period unless and until a state did what only Virginia has done now, which is to automate its records.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Once you automate your records, then you don't have to have a waiting period, but at least you can check.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I also think we should have frankly restrictions on assault weapons whose only purpose is to kill.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We need to give the police a fighting chance in our urban areas where the gangs are building up.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The third thing I would say -- it doesn't bear directly on gun control, but it's very important -- we need more police on the street.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: There is a crime bill which would put more police on the street, which was killed for this session by a filibuster in the Senate, mostly be Republican senators, and I think it's a shame it didn't pass, I think it should be made the law -- but it had the Brady bill in it, the waiting period.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I also believe that we should offer college scholarships to people who will agree to work them off as police officers, and I think, as we reduce our military forces, we should let people earn military retirement by coming out and working as police officers.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: In the communities which have had real success putting police officers near schools where kids carry weapons, to get the weapons out of the schools, are on the same blocks, you've seen crime go down.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: In Houston there's been a 15- percent drop in the crime rate in the last year because of the work the mayor did there in increasing the police force.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I know it can work; I've seen it happen.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think you put your finger on a major problem.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I talk about strengthening the American family and it's very hard to strengthen the family if people are scared to walk down to the corner store and, you know, send their kid down to get a loaf of bread.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I have been fighting for very strong anti-crime legislation -- habeas corpus reform, so you don't have these endless appeals, so when somebody gets sentenced, hey, this is for real.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I've been fighting for changes in the exclusionary rule so if an honest cop stops somebody and makes a technical mistake, the criminal doesn't go away.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'll probably get into a fight in this room with some but I happen to think that we need stronger death penalties for those that kill police officers.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Virginia's in the lead in this, as Governor Clinton properly said, on this identification system for firearms.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I am not for national registration of firearms.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Some of the states that have the toughest anti-gun laws have the highest levels of crime.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I am for the right, as the governor says- -I'm a sportsman and I don't think you ought to eliminate all kinds of weapons.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I was not for the bill that he was talking about because it was not tough enough on the criminal.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'm very pleased that the Fraternal Order of Police in Little Rock, Arkansas endorsed me because I think they see I'm trying to strengthen the anti-crime legislation.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We've got more money going out for local police than any previous administration.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So we've got to get it under control and there's one last point I'd make.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We have got to win our national strategy against drugs, the fight against drugs.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we're making some progress, doing a little better on interdiction.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We're not doing as well amongst the people that get to be habitual drug-users.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The good news is, and I think it's true in Richmond, teenage use is down of cocaine, substantially, 60% in the last couple of years.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So we're making progress but until we get that one done, we're not going to solve the neighborhood crime problem.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I didn't get to make a comment on this.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Oh, you're going to let me.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: On any program, and this includes crime, you'll find we have all kinds of great plans lying around that never get enacted into law and implemented.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I don't care what it is -- competitiveness, health care, crime, you name it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Brady Bill, I agree that it's a timid step in the right direction but it won't fix it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So why pass a law that won't fix it?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, what it really boils down to is can you live -- we become so preoccupied with the rights of the criminal that we've forgotten the rights of the innocent.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And in our country we have evolved to a point where we've put millions of innocent people in jail because you go to the poor neighborhoods and they've put bars on their windows and bars on their doors and put themselves in jail to protect the things that they acquired legitimately.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We have got to become more concerned about people who play by the rules and get the balance we require.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: This is going to take first, building a consensus at grassroots America.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Right from the bottom up, the American people have got to say they want it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And at that point, we can pick from a variety of plans and develop new plans.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And the way you get things done is bury yourselves in the room with one another, put together the best program, take it to the American people, use the electronic town hall, the kind of thing you're doing here tonight, build a consensus and then do it and then go on to the next one.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But don't just sit here slow dancing for 4 years doing nothing.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'll be glad to respond.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I strongly support term limits for members of the US Congress.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I believe it would return the government closer to the people, the way that Ross Perot is talking about.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The president's terms are limited to 2, a total of 8 years.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: What's wrong with limiting the terms of members of Congress to 12?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Congress has gotten kind of institutionalized.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: For 38 years one party has controlled the House of Representatives, and the result, a sorry little post office that can't do anything right and a bank that has more overdrafts than all the Chase Bank and Citibank put together.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We've got to do something about it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I think you get a certain arrogance, bureaucratic arrogance, if people stay there too long.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so I favor, strongly favor, term limits.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And how to get them passed?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Send us some people that will pass the idea.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I think you will.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think the American people want it now.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Every place I go I talk about it, and I think they want it done.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Actually, you'd have to have some amendments to the Constitution because of the way the Constitution reads.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I know they're popular, but I'm against them.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I believe, number one, it would pose a real problem for a lot of smaller states in the Congress who have enough trouble now making sure their interests are heard.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Number 2, I think it would increase the influence of unelected staff members in the Congress who have too much influence already.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I want to cut the size of the congressional staffs, but I think you're going to have too much influence there with people who were never elected, who have lots of expertise.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Number 3, if the people really have a mind to change, they can.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You're going to have 120 to 150 new members of Congress.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now, let me tell you what I favor instead.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I favor strict controls on how much you can spend running for Congress, strict limits on political action committees, requirements that people running for Congress appear in open public debates like we're doing now.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: If you did that you could take away the incumbents' advantage because challengers like me would have a chance to run against incumbents like him for House races and Senate races, and then the voters could make up their own mind without being subject to an unfair fight.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So that's how I feel about it, and I think if we had the right kind of campaign reform, we'd get the changes you want.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me do first on a personal level.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If the American people send me up to do this job, I intend to be there one term.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I do not intend to spend one minute of one day thinking about re-election.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And as a matter of principle -- and my situation is unique, and I understand it -- I would take absolutely no compensation; I go as their servant.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, I have set as strong an example as I can, then at that point when we sit down over at Capitol Hill -- tomorrow night I'm going to be talking about government reform -- it's a long subject, you wouldn't let me finish tonight.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If you want to hear it, you get it tomorrow night -- you'll hear it tomorrow night.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But we have got to reform government.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If you put term limits in and don't reform government, you won't get the benefits you thought.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So we need to do the reforms and the term limits.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And after we reform it, it won't be a lifetime career opportunity; good people will go serve and then go back to their homes and not become foreign lobbyists and cash in at 30,000 bucks a month and then take time off to run some president's campaign.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They're all nice people, they're just in a bad system.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I don't think there are any villains, but, boy, is the system rotten.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I've had more people talk to me about their health care problems I guess than anything else, all across America -- you know, people who've lost their jobs, lost their businesses, had to give up their jobs because of sick children.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So let me try to answer you in this way.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let's start with a premise.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We spend 30% more of our income than any nation on earth on health care, and yet we insure fewer people.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have 35 million people without any insurance at all -- and I see them all the time.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: A hundred thousand Americans a month have lost their health insurance just in the last 4 years.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So if you analyze where we're out of line with other countries, you come up with the following conclusions.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Number one, we spend at least $60 billion a year on insurance, administrative cost, bureaucracy, and government regulation that wouldn't be spent in any other nation.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So we have to have, in my judgment, a drastic simplification of the basic health insurance policies of this country, be very comprehensive for everybody.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Employers would cover their employees, government would cover the unemployed.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Number 2, I think you have to take on specifically the insurance companies and require them to make some significant change in the way they rate people in the big community pools.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think you have to tell the pharmaceutical companies they can't keep raising drug prices at three times the rate of inflation.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think you have to take on medical fraud.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think you have to help doctors stop practicing defensive medicine.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I've recommended that our doctors be given a set of national practice guidelines and that if they follow those guidelines that raises the presumption that they didn't do anything wrong.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think you have to have a system of primary and preventive clinics in our inner cities and our rural areas so people can have access to health care.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The key is to control the cost and maintain the quality.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: To do that you need a system of managed competition where all of us are covered in big groups and we can choose our doctors and our hospitals, a wide range, but there is an incentive to control costs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I think there has to be -- I think Mr. Perot and I agree on this, there has to be a national commission of health care providers and health care consumers that set ceilings to keep health costs in line with inflation, plus population growth.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now, let me say, some people say we can't do this but Hawaii does it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They cover 98% of their people and their insurance premiums are much cheaper than the rest of America, and so does Rochester, New York.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They now have a plan to cover everybody and their premiums are two-thirds of the rest of the country.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's a big human problem and a devastating economic problem for America, and I'm going to send a plan to do this within the first 100 days of my presidency.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I just have to say something.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't want to stampede.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Ross was very articulate across the country.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't want anybody to stampede to cut the president's salary off altogether.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Barbara's sitting over here and I -- but what I have proposed, 10% cut, downsize the government, and we can get that done.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: She asked a question, I think, is whether the health care profession was to blame.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: One thing to blame is these malpractice lawsuits.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It costs $20-25 billion a year, and I want to see those outrageous claims capped.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Doctors don't dare to deliver babies sometimes because they're afraid that somebody's going to sue them.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: People don't dare -- medical practitioners, to help somebody along the highway that are hurt because they're afraid that some lawyer's going to come along and get a big lawsuit.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So you can't blame the practitioners for the health problem.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And my program is this.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Keep the government as far out of it as possible, make insurance available to the poorest of the poor, through vouchers, next range in the income bracket, through tax credits, and get on about the business of pooling insurance.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: A great big company can buy -- Ross has got a good-sized company, been very successful.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He can buy insurance cheaper than Mom and Pop's store on the corner.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But if those Mom and Pop stores all get together and pool, they too can bring the cost of insurance down.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So I want to keep the quality of health care.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That means keep government out of it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to do -- I don't like this idea of these boards.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It all sounds to me like you're going to have some government setting price.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want competition and I want to pool the insurance and take care of it that way and have -- oh, here's the other point.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think medical care should go with the person.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: If you leave a business, I think your insurance should go with you to some other business.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You shouldn't be worrying if you get a new job as to whether that's gonna -- and part of our plan is to make it what they call portable -- big word, but that means if you're working for the Jones Company and you go to the Smith Company, your insurance goes with you.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think it's a good program.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'm really excited about getting it done, too.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We have the most expensive health care system in the world.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Twelve percent of our gross national product goes to health care.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Our industrial competitors, who are beating us in competition, spend less and have better health care.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Japan spends a little over 6% of its gross national product.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You've bought a front row box seat and you're not happy with your health care and you're saying tonight we've got bad health care but very expensive health care.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Go home and look in the mirror.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You own this country but you have no voice in it the way it's organized now, and if you want to have a high risk experience, comparable to bungee jumping, go into Congress some time when they're working on this kind of legislation, when the lobbyists are running up and down the halls.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Wear your safety toe shoes when you go.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And as a private citizen, believe me, you are looked on as a major nuisance.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The facts are you now have a government that comes at you.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You're supposed to have a government that comes from you.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, there are all kinds of good ideas, brilliant ideas, terrific ideas on health care.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: None of them ever get implemented because -- let me give you an example.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: A senator runs every 6 years.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: He's got to raise 20,000 bucks a week to have enough money to run.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Who's he gonna listen to -- us or the folks running up and down the aisles with money, the lobbyists, the PAC money?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, you've got to have a government that comes from you again.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You've got to reassert your ownership in this country and you've got to completely reform our government.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And at that point they'll just be like apples falling out of a tree.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The programs will be good because the elected officials will be listening to -- I said the other night I was all ears and I would listen to any good idea.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I think we ought to do plastic surgery on a lot of these guys so that they're all ears, too, and listen to you.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Then you get what you want, and shouldn't you?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Why shouldn't you get what you want, as opposed to what some lobbyist cuts a deal, writes a little piece in the law and he goes through.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: That's the way the game's played now.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Till you change it you're gonna be unhappy.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We have elections so people can make decisions about this.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The point I want to make to you is, a bipartisan commission reviewed my plan and the Bush plan and there were as many Republicans as Democratic health care experts on it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They concluded that my plan would cover everybody and his would leave 27 million behind by the year 2000 and that my plan in the next 12 years would save $2.2 trillion in public and private money to reinvest in this economy and the average family would save $1200 a year under the plan that I offered without any erosion in the quality of health care
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I ask you to look at that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And you have to vote for somebody with a plan.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's what you have elections for.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: If people would say, well, he got elected to do this and then the Congress says, okay, I'm going to do it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's what the election was about.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Who do you want to start with?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: It caused me to disrupt my private life and my business to get involved in this activity.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: That's how much I care about it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And believe me, if you knew my family and if you knew the private life I have, you would agree in a minute that that's a whole lot more fun than getting involved in politics.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But I have lived the American dream.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I came from very modest background.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Nobody's been luckier than I've been, all the way across the spectrum, and the greatest riches of all are my wife and children.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: That's true of any family.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But I want all the children -- I want these young people up here to be able to start with nothing but an idea like I did and build a business.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But they've got to have a strong basic economy and if you're in debt, it's like having a ball and chain around you.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I just figure, as lucky as I've been, I owe it to them and I owe it to the future generations and on a very personal basis, I owe it to my children and grandchildren.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Well, I think the national debt affects everybody.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Obviously it has a lot to do with interest rates --
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I love my grandchildren --
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I want to think that they're going to be able to afford an education.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think that that's an important part of being a parent.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: If the question -- maybe I -- get it wrong.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Are you suggesting that if somebody has means that the national debt doesn't affect them?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'm not sure I get -- help me with the question and I'll try to answer it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, listen, you ought to be in the White House for a day and hear what I hear and see what I see and read the mail I read and touch the people that I touch from time to time.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It's a black church just outside of Washington, DC.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I read in the bulletin about teenage pregnancies, about the difficulties that families are having to make ends meet.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I mean, you've got to care.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Everybody cares if people aren't doing well.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I don't think it's fair to say, you haven't had cancer.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't think it's fair to say, you know, whatever it is, that if you haven't been hit by it personally.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But everybody's affected by the debt because of the tremendous interest that goes into paying on that debt everything's more expensive.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Everything comes out of your pocket and my pocket.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I think in terms of the recession, of course you feel it when you're president of the US.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And that's why I'm trying to do something about it by stimulating the export, vesting more, better education systems.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'm glad you clarified it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Tell me how it's affected you again.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You know people who've lost their jobs and lost their homes?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, I've been governor of a small state for 12 years.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'll tell you how it's affected me.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Every year Congress and the president sign laws that make us do more things and gives us less money to do it with.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I see people in my state, middle class people -- their taxes have gone up in Washington and their services have gone down while the wealthy have gotten tax cuts.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I have seen what's happened in this last 4 years when -- in my state, when people lose their jobs there's a good chance I'll know them by their names.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: When a factory closes, I know the people who ran it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: When the businesses go bankrupt, I know them.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I've been out here for 13 months meeting in meetings just like this ever since October, with people like you all over America, people that have lost their jobs, lost their livelihood, lost their health insurance.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: What I want you to understand is the national debt is not the only cause of that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It is because America has not invested in its people.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It is because we have not grown.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It is because we've had 12 years of trickle down economics.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've gone from first to twelfth in the world in wages.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've had 4 years where we've produced no private sector jobs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Most people are working harder for less money than they were making ten years ago.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It is because we are in the grip of a failed economic theory.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And this decision you're about to make better be about what kind of economic theory you want, not just people saying I'm going to go fix it but what are we going to do?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think we have to do is invest in American jobs, American education, control American health care costs and bring the American people together again.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, the Social Security -- you're an expert and I could, I'm sure, learn from you the details of the Pension Guarantee Fund and the Social Security Fund.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The Social Security system was fixed about 5 years, and I think it's projected out to be sound beyond that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So at least we have time to work with it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But on all of these things, a sound economy is the only way to get it going.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Growth in the economy is gonna add to the overall prosperity and wealth.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I can't give you a specific answer on Pension Guarantee Fund.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: All I know is that we have firm government credit to guarantee the pensions.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And that is very important.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But it's -- the full faith and credit of the US, in spite of our difficulties, is still pretty good.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It's still the most respected credit.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So I would simply say, as these dates get close, you're going to have to reorganize and refix as we did with the Social Security Fund.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I think that's the only answer.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But the more immediate answer is to do what this lady was suggesting we do, and that is to get this deficit down and get on without adding to the woes, and then restructure.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: One thing I've called for that has been stymied, and I'll keep on working for it, is a whole financial reform legislation.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It is absolutely essential in terms of bringing our banking system and credit system into the new age instead of having it living back in the dark ages.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And it's a big fight.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I don't want to give my friend Ross another shot at me here but I am fighting with the Congress to get this through.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And you can't just go up and say I'm going to fix it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You've got some pretty strong-willed guys up there that argue with you.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But that's what the election's about.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I agree with the governor.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That's what the election's about.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And sound fiscal policy is the best answer, I think, to all the three problems you mentioned.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: On the broad issue here, when you're trying to solve a problem, you get the best plans.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You have a raging debate about those plans.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Then out of that debate, with leadership, comes consensus.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Then, if the plans are huge and complex like health care, I would urge you to implement pilot programs.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Like the old carpenter says measure twice, cut once.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Let's make sure this thing's as good as we all think it is at the end of the meeting.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Then finally, our government passes laws and freezes the plan in concrete.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Anybody that's ever built a successful business will tell you you optimize, optimize, optimize after you've put something into effect.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The reason Medicare and Medicaid are a mess is we froze them.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Everybody knows how to fix them.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: There are people all over the federal government, if they could just touch it with a screwdriver, could fix it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: See, we've got a $4 trillion debt and only in America would you have $2.8 trillion of it or 70% of it financed 5 years or less.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, that's another thing for you to think about when you go home tonight.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You don't finance long-term debt with short-term money.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Why did our government do it?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: To get the interest rates down.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: A 1% increase in interest rates in that $2.8 trillion is $28 billion a year.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, when you look at what Germany pays for money and what we don't pay for money, you realize there's quite a spread, right, and you realize this is a temporary thing and there's going to be another sucking sound that runs our deficit through the roof.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You know, and everybody's ducking it so I'm gonna say it, that we are not letting that surplus stay in the bank.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We are not investing that surplus like a pension fund.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We are spending that surplus to make the deficit look smaller to you than it really is.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, that -- put you in jail in corporate America if you kept books that way but in government it's just kind of the way things are.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: That's because it comes at you, not from you.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now then, that money needs to be -- they don't even pay interest on it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They just write a note for the interest.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Do you want to fix the problem or sound-bite it?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I understand the importance of time but see, here's how we get to this mess we're in.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: This is just 1 of 1000.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now then, to nail it, there's one way out -- a growing, expanding job base.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: A growing, expanding job base to generate the funds and the tax revenues to pay off the mess and rebuild America.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If we're $4 trillion down, we should have everything perfect, but we don't.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We've got to pay it off and build money to renew it- -spend money to renew it, and that's going to take a growing, expanding job base.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: That is priority one in this country.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Put everybody that's breathing to work.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And I'd love to be out of workers and have to import them, like some of our international competitors.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I think I remember the question.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me say first of all, I want to answer your specific question but first of all, we all agree that there should be a growing economy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: What you have to decide is who's got the best economic plan.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And we all have ideas out there, and Mr. Bush has a record.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I don't want you to read my lips and I sure don't want you to read his.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I do hope you will read our plans.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now, specifically, one, on Medicare, it is not true that everyone knows how to fix it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: There are different ideas -- the Bush plan, the Perot plan, the Clinton -- we have different ideas.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I am convinced, having studied health care for a year hard and talking to hundreds and hundreds of people all across America, that you cannot control the cost of Medicare until you control the cost of private health care and public health care, with managed competition, ceiling on cost, and radical reorganization of the insurance markets.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You've got to do that; we got to get those costs down.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Number 2, with regard to Social Security, that program -- a lot of you may not know this -- it produces a $70 billion surplus a year.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Social Security is in surplus $70 billion.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Six increases in the payroll tax -- that means people with incomes of $51,000 a year or less pay a disproportionally high share of the federal tax burden, which is why I want some middle-class tax relief.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: What do we have to do?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: By the time the century turns, we have got to have our deficit under control, we have to work out of so that surplus is building up so when the baby boomers like me retire, we're okay.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Number 3, on the pension funds, I don't know as much about it, but I will say this.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: What I would do is to bring in the pension experts of the country, take a look at it, and strengthen the pension requirements further, because it's not just enough to have the guarantee.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We had a guarantee on the S&Ls, right?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We had a guarantee -- and what happened?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You picked up a $500-billion bill because of the dumb way the federal government deregulated it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I think we are going to have to change and strengthen the pension requirements on private retirement plans.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, we have come to that position.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Since I became president, 43, 44 countries have gone democratic, no longer totalitarian, no longer living under dictatorship or communist rule.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: New world order to me means freedom and democracy.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think we will have a continuing responsibility, as the only remaining superpower, to stay involved.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: If we pull back in some isolation and say we don't have to do our share, or more than our share, anymore, I believe you are going to just ask for conflagration that we'll get involved in the future.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: NATO, for example, has kept the peace for many, many years, and I want to see us keep fully staffed in NATO so we'll continue to guarantee the peace in Europe.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But the exciting thing is, the fear of nuclear war is down.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And you hear all the bad stuff that's happened on my watch; I hope people will recognize that this is something pretty good for mankind.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I hope they'll think it's good that democracy and freedom is on the move.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we're going to stay engaged, as long as I'm president, working to improve things.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You know, it's so easy now to say, hey, cut out foreign aid, we got a problem at home.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think the US has to still have the Statue of Liberty as a symbol, caring for others.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Right this very minute we're sending supplies in to help these little starving kids in Somalia.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It's the US that's taken the lead in humanitarian aid into Bosnia.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We're doing this all around the world.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Yes, we got problems at home.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I think I got a good plan to help fix those problems at home.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But because of our leadership, because we didn't listen to the freeze -- the nuclear-freeze group, do you remember -- freeze it, back in the late 70s -- freeze, don't touch it; we're going to lock it in now or else we'll have war.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: President Reagan said no, peace through strength.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The Soviet Union is no more, and now we're working to help them become totally democratic through the Freedom Support Act that I led on, a great Democratic ambassador, Bob Strauss, over there, Jim Baker, all of us got this thing passed -- through cooperation, Ross -- it worked with cooperation, and you're for that, I'm sure, helping Russia become democratic.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So the new world order to me means freedom and democracy, keep engaged, do not pull back into isolation.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we are the US, and we have a responsibility to lead and to guarantee the security.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: If it hadn't been for us, Saddam Hussein would be sitting on top of three-fifths of the oil supply of the world and he'd have nuclear weapons.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And only the US could do this.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, it's cost-effective to help Russia succeed in its revolution; it's pennies on the dollar compared to going back to the Cold War.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Russia is still very unstable; they could go back to square one, and worse.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: All the nuclear weapons are not dismantled.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I am particularly concerned about the intercontinental weapons, the ones that can hit us.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We've got agreements, but they are still there.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: With all this instability and breaking into republics, and all the Middle Eastern countries going over there and shopping for weapons, we've got our work cut out for us.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So we need to stay right on top of that and constructively help them move toward democracy and capitalism.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We have to have money to do that.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We have to have our people at work.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: See, for 45 years we were preoccupied with the Red Army.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I suggest now that our number one preoccupation is red ink and our country and we've got to put our people back to work so that we can afford to do these things we want to do in Russia.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We cannot be the policeman for the world any longer.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We spent $300 billion a year defending the world.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Germany and Japan spend around $30 billion a piece.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If I can get you to defend me and I can spend all my money building industry that's a home run for me.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Coming out of World War II it made sense.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, the other superpowers need to do their part.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'll close on this point.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You can't be a superpower unless you're an economic superpower.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If we're not an economic superpower, we're a used to be and we will no longer be a force for good throughout the world.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And if nothing else gets you excited about rebuilding our industrial base maybe that will because job one is to put our people back to work.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'd rather answer her question first and then I'll be glad to.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Because the question you ask is important.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The end of the Cold War brings an incredible opportunity for change.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Winds of freedom blowing around the world, Russia demilitarizing.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And it also requires us to maintain some continuity -- some bipartisan American commitment to certain principles.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I would just say there are three things that I would like to say -- number one -- we do have to maintain the world's strongest defense.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We may differ about what the elements of that are.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think that defense needs to be -- with fewer people in permanent armed services but with greater mobility on the land, in the air and on the sea, with a real dedication to continuing development of high technology weaponry and well trained people.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think we're going to have to work to stop the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Got to keep going until all those nuclear weapons in Russia are gone and the other republics.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Number 2, if you don't rebuild the economic strength of this country at home, we won't be a superpower.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We can't have any more instances like what happened when Mr. Bush went to Japan and the Japanese prime minister said he felt sympathy for our country.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have to be the strongest economic power in the world.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's what got me into this race, so we could rebuild the American economy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And number three, we need to be a force for freedom and democracy and we need to use our unique position to support freedom, whether it's in Haiti or in China or in any other place, wherever the seeds of freedom are sprouting.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We can't impose it, but we need to nourish it and that's the kind of thing that I would do as president -- follow those three commitments into the future.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'd be delighted to, because you can't do it the old way.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You can't do it with the school bureaucracy controlling everything and that's why we have a new program that I hope people have heard about.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It's being worked now in 1700 communities -- bypassed Congress on this one, Ross -- 1700 communities across the country.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And it literally says to the communities, re-invent the schools, not just the bricks and mortar but the curriculum and everything else.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We have a concept called the New American School Corporation where we're doing exactly that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so I believe that we've got to get the power in the hands of the teachers, not the teachers' union.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: (Laughter) And so our America 2000 program also says this.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It says let's give parents the choice of a public, private or public school -- public, private or religious school.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And it works- -it works in Milwaukee.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Democratic woman up there -- taking the lead in this.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The mayor up there, on the program.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And the schools that are not chosen are improved -- competition does that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So we've got to innovate through school choice.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We've got to innovate through this America 2000 program.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But she is absolutely right.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The programs that we've been trying where you control everything and mandate it from Washington don't work.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The governors -- and I believe Governor Clinton was in on this -- but maybe -- I don't want to invoke him here.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But they come to me and they say, please get the Congress to stop passing so many mandates telling us how to control things.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We know better how to do it in California or Texas or wherever it is.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So this is what our program is all about.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I believe you're right on to something, that if we don't change the education we're not going to be able to compete.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Federal funding for education is up substantially -- Pell grants are up.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But it isn't going to get the job done if we don't change K through 12.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: First of all, let me say that I've spent more of my time and life on this in the last 12 years than any other issue.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Seventy percent of my state's money goes to the public schools, and I was really honored when Time magazine said that our schools have shown more improvement than any other state in the country except one other -- they named 2 states showing real strides forward in the 80s.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I care a lot about this, and I've spent countless hours in schools.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But let me start with what you said.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I agree with some of what Mr. Bush said, but it's nowhere near enough.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We live in a world where what you earn depends on what you can learn, where the average 18- year-old will change jobs 8 times in a lifetime and where none of us can promise any of you that what you now do for a living is absolutely safe from now on.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Nobody running can promise that, there's too much change in the world.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So what should we do?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me reel some things off real quick, because you said you wanted specifics.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Number one, under my program we would provide matching funds to states to teach everybody with a job to read in the next 5 years and give everybody with a job the chance to get a high school diploma, in big places on the job.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Number 2, we would provide 2-year apprenticeship programs to high school graduates who don't go to college.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And community colleges are on the job.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Number three, we'd open the doors to college education to high school graduates without regard to income.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They could borrow the money and pay it back as a percentage of their income or with a couple of years of service to our nation here at home.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Number 4, we would fully fund the Head Start program to get little kids off to a good start.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And, 5, I would have an aggressive program of school reform, more choices -- I favor public schools or these new charter schools -- we can talk about that if you want.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I don't think we should spend tax money on private schools.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But I favor public school choice, and I favor radical decentralization in giving more power to better-trained principals and teachers with parent councils to control their schools.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Those things would revolutionize American education and take us to the top economically.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: In 6 years -- I budget all this in my budget, and in 6 years the college program would cost 8 billion dollars over and above what -- the present student loan program costs 4; you pay 3 billion dollars for busted loans, because we don't have an automatic recovery system, and a billion dollars in bank fees.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So the net cost would be 8 billion 6 years from now in a trillion-plus budget -- not very much.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The other stuff -- all the other stuff I mentioned -- costs much less than that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The Head Start program full funding would cost about 5 billion more.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And it's all covered in my budget from -- the plans that I've laid out -- from raising taxes on families with incomes above $200,000 and asking foreign corporations to pay the same tax that American corporations do on the same income, from $140 billion in budget cuts, including what I think are very prudent cuts in the defense budget.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's all covered in the plan.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Yes, I've got scars to show for being around education reform.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And the first word you need to say in every city and state, and just draw a line in the sand, is public schools exist for the benefit of the children.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You're going to see a lot of people fall over it, because any time you're spending $199 billion dollars a year, somebody's getting it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And the children get lost in the process.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Keep in mind in 1960, when our schools were the envy of the world, we were spending $16 billion on them; now we spend more than any other nation in the world -- 199 billion a year -- and rank at the bottom of the industrialized world in terms of education achievement.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: One more time you've bought a front-row box seat and got a third-rate performance.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: This is a government that is not serving you.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: By and large it should be local -- the more local, the better.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Interesting phenomenon: small towns have good schools, big cities have terrible schools.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The best people in a small town will serve on the school board; you get into big cities, it's political patronage, stepping stones -- you get the job, give your relatives a janitor's job at $57,000 a year, more than the teachers make, and with luck they clean the cafeteria once a week.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, you're paying for that.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Those schools belong to you.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And we put up with that.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, as long as we put up with that, that's what you're going to get.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And these folks are just dividing up 199 billion bucks and the children get lost.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If I could wish for one thing for great public schools, it would be a strong family unit in every home -- nothing will ever replace that.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You say, well, gee, what are you going to do about that?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Well, the White House is a bully pulpit, and I think we ought to be pounding on the table every day.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: There's nothing -- the most efficient unit of government the world will ever know is a strong loving family unit.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You need small schools, not big schools.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: In a little school everybody is somebody; individualism is very important.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Everybody told me they were cost-effective.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I did a study on it; they're cost- ineffective.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: 5000 students -- why is a high school that big?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Sooner or later you get 11 more boys that can run like the devil that weigh 250 pounds and they might win district.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, that has nothing to do with learning.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Secondly, across Texas, typically half of the school day was non-academic pursuits -- in one place it was 35%.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: In Texas you could have unlimited absences to go to livestock shows.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Found a boy -- excuse me, but this gives the flavor -- a boy in Houston kept a chicken in the bathtub in downtown Houston and missed 65 days going to livestock shows.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Finally had to come back to school, the chicken lost its feathers.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: That's the only way we got him back.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: (Laughter) Now, that's your tax money being wasted.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: It is terrible to bus tiny little children across town.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And it is particularly terrible to take poor tiny little children and wait until the first grade and bus them across town to Mars, where the children know their numbers, know their letters, have had every advantage.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: At the end of the first day, that little child wants out.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You've got to have world class teachers, world class books.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If you ever got close to how textbooks were selected, you wouldn't want to go back the second day.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I don't have time to tell you the stories.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Finally, if we don't fix this, you're right.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We can't have the industries of tomorrow unless we have the best educated workforce.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And here you've got, for the disadvantaged children, you've got to have early childhood development.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Cheapest money you'll ever spend.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: First contact should be with the money when she's pregnant.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: That little child needs to be loved and hugged and nurtured and made to feel special, like your children were.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They learn to think well or poorly of themselves in the first 18 months.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And in the first few years they either learn how to learn or don't learn how to learn.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And if they don't, they wind up in prison.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And it costs more to keep them in prison than it does to send them to Harvard.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I just had a word of clarification because of something Governor Clinton said.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: My school choice program, GI Bill for Kids, does not take public money and give it to private schools.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It does what the GI Bill itself did when I came out of World War II.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It takes public money and gives it to families or individuals to choose the school they want.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And where it's been done, those schools, like in Rochester, those schools that weren't chosen find that they then compete and do better.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So I think it's worth a shot.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We've got a pilot program.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It ought to be tried.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: School choice -- public, private or religious.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Not to the schools but to -- you know, 46% of the teachers in Chicago, public school teachers, send their kids to private school.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Now, I think we ought to try to help families and see if it will do what I think -- make all schools better.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I just want to mention if I could --
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Including the parents in the preschool education of their kids, even if they're poor and uneducated, can make a huge difference.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have a big program in my state that teaches mothers or fathers to teach their kids to get ready for school.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's the most successful thing we've ever done.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Just a fact clarification real quickly.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We do not spend a higher percentage of our income on public education than every other country.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: There are 9 countries that spend more than we do on public education.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We spend more on education 'cause we spend so much more on colleges.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But if you look at public education alone and you take into account the fact that we have more racial diversity and more poverty, it makes a big difference.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: There are great public schools where there's public school choice, accountability and brilliant principals.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'll just mention one -- the Beasley Academic Center in Chicago.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I commend it to anybody.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's as good as any private school in the country.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, I don't have any idea but I hope it will happen some time in my lifetime.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I believe that this country is electing more and more African Americans and Latinos and Asian Americans who are representing districts that are themselves not necessarily of a majority of their race.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The American people are beginning to vote across racial lines, and I hope it will happen more and more.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: More and more women are being elected.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Look at all these women Senate candidates we have here.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And you know, according to my mother and my wife and my daughter, this world would be a lot better place if women were running it most of the time.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I do think there are special experiences and judgments and backgrounds and understandings that women bring to this process, by the way.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: This lady said here, how have you been affected by the economy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I mean, women know what's it like to be paid an unequal amount for equal work.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They know what it's like not to have flexible working hours.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They know what it's like not to have family leave or childcare.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I think it would be a good thing for America if it happened.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I think it will happen in my lifetime.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think if Barbara Bush were running this year she'd be elected.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: (Laughter) You don't want us to mention appointees, but when you see the quality of people in our administration, see how Colin Powell performed -- I say administration --
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You weren't impressed with the fact that he --
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Yeah, but wouldn't that suggest to the American people, then, here's a quality person, if he decided that he could automatically get the nomination of either party?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't know -- starting after 4 years.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: No, I think you'll see --
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think you'll see more minority candidates and women candidates coming forward.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: This is supposed to be the year of the women in the Senate.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Let's see how they do.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I hope a lot of --
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I have a fearless forecast.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: A message just won't do it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Colin Powell will be on somebody's ticket 4 years from now -- right?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: He wanted that said -- 4 years.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, if won't be, General Waller would be -- you say, why do you keep picking military people.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: These are people that I just happen to know and have a high regard for.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'm sure there are hundreds of others.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: How about Dr. Lou Sullivan?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I can think of many.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: How about Sandra Day O'Connor as an example?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: May I ask for an exception because I think we owe Carole Simpson -- anybody who can stand in between these three characters here and get the job done -- we owe her a round of applause.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: (Applause) But don't take it out of my time!
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I feel strongly about it because I don't want it to come out of my time.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: No, but let me just stay to the American people in 2 and a half weeks we're going to choose who should sit in this Oval Office, who to lead the economic recovery, who to be the leader of the free world, who to get the deficit down.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: three ways to do that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: One is to raise taxes.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: One is to reduce spending -- controlling that mandatory spending.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Another one is to invest and save and to stimulate growth.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I do not want to raise taxes.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I differ with the 2 here on that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'm just not going to do that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I do believe that we need to control mandatory spending.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think we need to invest and save more.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I believe that we need to educate better and retrain better.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I believe that we need to export more so I'll keep working for export agreements where we can sell more abroad and I believe that we must strengthen the family.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We've got to strengthen the family.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Now, let me pose this question to America.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: If in the next 5 minutes a television announcer came on and said, there is a major international crisis -- there is a major threat to the world or in this country a major threat -- my question is, who, if you were appointed to name 1 of the 3 of us, who would you choose?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Who has the perseverance, the character, the integrity, the maturity, to get the job done?
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I hope I'm that person.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Thank you very, very much.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: If the American people want to do it and not talk about it, then they ought to -- you know, I'm one person they ought to consider.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If they just want to keep slow dancing and talk about it and not do it, I'm not your man.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Getting things done in three months that my competitors took 18 months to do.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Everybody says you can't do that with Congress.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Sure, you can do that with Congress.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Congress -- they're all good people.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They're all patriots but you've got to link arms and work with them.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We have them all day every day.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But we get the job done.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, I have to come back in my clothes to one thing because I am passionate about education.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I was talking about early childhood education for disadvantaged little children.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And let me tell you one specific pilot program where children who don't have a chance go to this program when they're 3.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now we're going back to when the mother's pregnant and they'll start right after they're born.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Starting when they're 3 and going to this school until they're 9 and then going into the public school in the 4th grade.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Ninety percent are on the honor role.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now that will change America.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Those children will all go to college.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They will live the American dream.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And I beg the American people, any time they think about reforming education to take this piece of society that doesn't have a chance and take these little pieces of clay that can be shaped and molded and give them the same love and nurture and affection and support you give your children and teach them that they're unique and that they're precious and that there's only one person in the world like them and you will see this nation bloom.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And we will have so many people who are qualified for the top job that it will be terrific.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, finally, if you can't pay the bills you're dead in the water.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And we have got to put our nation back to work.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, if you don't want to really do that I'm not your man.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: In other words, unless we're going to do it, then pick somebody who likes to talk about it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, just remember when you think about me -- I didn't create this mess.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I've been paying taxes just like you and Lord knows, I've paid my share -- over a billion in taxes.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And for a guy that started out with everything he owned in the trunk of his car --
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But it's in your hands.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'll see you tomorrow night -- (Laughter) on NBC -- 10:30 to 11:00 Eastern Time.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Thank you, Carole, and thank you, ladies and gentlemen.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Since I suggested this format I hope it's been good for all of you.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I really tried to be faithful to your request that we answer the questions specifically and pointedly.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I thought I owed that to you and I respect you for being here and for the impact you've had on making this a more positive experience.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: These problems are not easy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They're not going to be solved overnight.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But I want you to think about just 2 or 3 things.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: First of all, the people of my state have let me be their governor for 12 years because I made commitments to 2 things -- more jobs and better schools.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Our schools are now better.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Our children get off to a better start from pre-school programs and smaller classes in the early grades, and we have one of the most aggressive adult education programs in the country.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: This year my state ranks first in the country in job growth, 4th in manufacturing in job growth, 4th in income growth, 4th in the decline of poverty.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It happened because I could work with people -- Republicans and Democrats.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's why we've had 24 retired generals and admirals, hundreds of business people, many of them Republican, support this campaign.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You have to decide whether you want to change or not.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We do not need 4 more years of an economic theory that doesn't work.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've had 12 years of trickle down economics.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's time to put the American people first, to invest and grow this economy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'm the only person here who's ever balanced a government budget and I've presented 12 of them and cut spending repeatedly.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But you cannot just get there by balancing the budget.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've got to grow the economy by putting people first -- real people like you.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I got into this race because I did not want my child to grow up to be part of the first generation of Americans to do worse than her parents.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We can do better than that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I want to make America as great as it can be and I ask for your help in doing it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But let me just first, Cheryl, if you will, I want to thank Charlie for moderating.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I want to thank Washington University for hosting us here this evening.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Mr. President, it's good to be with you again this evening, sir.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Cheryl, the president didn't find weapons of mass destruction in Iraq, so he's really turned his campaign into a weapon of mass deception.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And the result is that you've been bombarded with advertisements suggesting that I've changed a position on this or that or the other.
Speaker: John Kerry

Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I just don't like the way John Ashcroft has applied it, and we're going to change a few things.
