Speaker: John Kerry

Text: No Child Left Behind Act, I voted for it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But the president has underfunded it by $28 billion.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Right here in St. Louis, you've laid off 350 teachers.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You're 150 -- excuse me, I think it's a little more, about $100 million shy of what you ought to be under the No Child Left Behind Act to help your education system here.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: So I complain about that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've argued that we should fully funded it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president says I've changed my mind.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I haven't changed my mind: I'm going to fully fund it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: So these are the differences.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, the president has presided over an economy where we've lost 1.6 million jobs.

Speaker: John Kerry

Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president wants to keep them open.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm going to give you a tax cut.

Text: The president gave the top 1 percent of income-earners in America, got $89 billion last year, more than the 80 percent of people who earn $100,000 or less all put together.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's not wishy-washy, and that's what I'm fighting for, you.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Charlie, thank you, and thank our panelists.

Text: I can -- and thanks, Washington U. as well.

Text: I can see why people at your workplace think he changes positions a lot, because he does.

Speaker: George W. Bush

Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Each situation is different, Robin.

Speaker: George W. Bush

Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that was the serious, serious threat.

Text: And they looked me in the eye and said, "Yes, sir, Mr.

Text: I hear there's rumors on the Internets (sic) that we're going to have a draft.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Speaker: George W. Bush

Speaker: George W. Bush

Speaker: George W. Bush

Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We don't need mass armies anymore.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One of the things we've done is we've taken the -- we're beginning to transform our military.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And by that I mean we're moving troops out of Korea and replacing them with more effective weapons.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We don't need as much manpower on the Korean Peninsula to keep a deterrent.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In Europe, we have massed troops as if the Soviet Union existed and was going to invade into Europe, but those days are over with.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so we're moving troops out of Europe and replacing it with more effective equipment.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So to answer your question is, we're withdrawing, not from the world, we're withdrawing manpower so they can be stationed here in America, so there's less rotation, so life is easier on their families and therefore more likely to be -- we'll be more likely to be able to keep people in the all-volunteer army.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One of the more important things we're doing in this administration is transformation.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There are some really interesting technologies.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: For instance, we're flying unmanned vehicles that can send real- time messages back to stations in the United States.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That saves manpower, and it saves equipment.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It also means that we can target things easier and move more quickly, which means we need to be lighter and quicker and more facile and highly trained.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Now, forget all this talk about a draft.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're not going to have a draft so long as I am the president.

Text: But let me tell you where the president's policies have put us.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president -- and this is one of the reasons why I am very proud in this race to have the support of General John Shalikashvili, former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; Admiral William Crowe, former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; General Tony McPeak, who ran the air war for the president's father and did a brilliant job, supporting me; General Wes Clark, who won the war in Kosovo, supporting me; because they all -- and General Baca, who was the head of the National Guard, supporting me.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Because they understand that our military is overextended under the president.
Speaker: John Kerry

Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You've got stop-loss policies, so people can't get out when they were supposed to.

Text: You've got a back-door draft right now.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And a lot of our military are underpaid.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: These are families that get hurt.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It hurts the middle class.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It hurts communities, because these are our first responders.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And they're over there, not over here.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, I'm going to add 40,000 active duty forces to the military, and I'm going to make people feel good about being safe in our military, and not overextended, because I'm going to run a foreign policy that actually does what President Reagan did, President Eisenhower did, and others.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We're going to build alliances.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We're not going to go unilaterally.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We're not going to go alone like this president did.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Let me just -- I've got to answer this.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Let me answer what he just said, about around the world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You tell Tony Blair we're going alone.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Tell Tony Blair we're going alone.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Tell Silvio Berlusconi we're going alone.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Tell Aleksander Kwasniewski of Poland we're going alone.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There are 30 countries there.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It denigrates an alliance to say we're going alone, to discount their sacrifices.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You cannot lead an alliance if you say, you know, you're going alone.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Mr. President, countries are leaving the coalition, not joining.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Eight countries have left it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: If Missouri, just given the number of people from Missouri who are in the military over there today, were a country, it would be the third largest country in the coalition, behind Great Britain and the United States.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's not a grand coalition.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Ninety percent of the casualties are American.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Ninety percent of the costs are coming out of your pockets.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I could do a better job.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: My plan does a better job.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And that's why I'll be a better commander in chief.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Thank you very much, Ann.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've asked in my security briefings why that is, and I can't go into all the answers, et cetera, but let me say this to you.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: This president and his administration have told you and all of us it's not a question of when, it's a question of -- excuse me -- not a question of if, it's a question of when.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The when I can't tell you.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Between the World Trade Center bombing in, what was it, 1993 or so, and the next time was five years, seven years.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I agree with the president that we have to go after them and get them wherever they are.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I just think I can do that far more effectively, because the most important weapon in doing that is intelligence.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You've got to have the best intelligence in the world.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And in order to have the best intelligence in the world to know who the terrorists are and where they are and what they're plotting, you've got to have the best cooperation you've ever had in the world.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, to go back to your question, Nikki, we're not getting the best cooperation in the world today.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We've got a whole bunch of countries that pay a price for dealing with the United States of America now.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm going to change that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I'm going to put in place a better homeland security effort.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Look, 95 percent of our containers coming into this country are not inspected today.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: When you get on an airplane, your bag is X- rayed, but the cargo hold isn't X-rayed.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: This president in the last debate said, "Well, that would be a big tax gap if we did that."
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Ladies and gentlemen, it's his tax plan.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He chose a tax cut for the wealthiest Americans over getting that equipment out into the homeland as fast as possible.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We have bridges and tunnels that aren't being secured, chemical plants, nuclear plants that aren't secured, hospitals that are overcrowded with their emergency rooms.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: If we had a disaster today, could they handle it?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: This president chose a tax cut over homeland security.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's an odd thing to say, since we've tripled the homeland security budget from $10 billion to $30 billion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Listen, we'll do everything we can to protect the homeland.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My opponent's right, we need good intelligence.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's also a curious thing for him to say since right after 1993 he voted to cut the intelligence budget by $7.5 billion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The best way to defend America in this world we live in is to stay on the offense.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We got to be right 100 percent of the time here at home, and they got to be right once.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And there's a lot of good people working hard.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're doing the best we possibly can to share information.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's why the Patriot Act was important.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The Patriot Act is vital, by the way.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's a tool that law enforcement now uses to be able to talk between each other.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My opponent says he hadn't changed his position on it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: No, but he's for weakening it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't think my opponent has got the right view about the world to make us safe; I really don't.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: First of all, I don't think he can succeed in Iraq.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And if Iraq were to fail, it'd be a haven for terrorists, and there would be money and the world would be much more dangerous.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't see how you can win in Iraq if you don't believe we should be there in the first place.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't see how you can lead troops if you say it's the wrong war at the wrong place at the wrong time.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't see how the Iraqis are going to have confidence in the American president if all they hear is that it was a mistake to be there in the first place.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This war is a long, long war, and it requires steadfast determination and it requires a complete understanding that we not only chase down Al Qaida but we disrupt terrorist safe havens as well as people who could provide the terrorists with support.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, the president and his experts have told America that it's not a question of if; it's a question of when.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I accept what the president has said.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: These terrorists are serious, they're deadly, and they know nothing except trying to kill.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's why I will never stop at anything to hunt down and kill the terrorists.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But you heard the president just say to you that we've added money.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Folks, the test is not if you've added money; the test is that you've done everything possible to make America secure.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He chose a tax cut for wealthy Americans over the things that I listed to you.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Well, we'll talk about the tax cut for middle class here in a minute.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm worried about our country.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And all I can tell you is every day I know that there's people working overtime, doing the very best they can.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And the reason I'm worried is because there's a vicious enemy that has an ideology of hate.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And the way to defeat them long-term, by the way, is to spread freedom.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's what's happening in Afghanistan and Iraq.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Just want to make sure they're safe.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: When a drug comes in from Canada, I want to make sure it cures you and doesn't kill you.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's why the FDA and that's why the surgeon general are looking very carefully to make sure it can be done in a safe way.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've got an obligation to make sure our government does everything we can to protect you.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And what my worry is is that, you know, it looks like it's from Canada, and it might be from a third world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we've just got to make sure, before somebody thinks they're buying a product, that it works.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's why we're doing what we're doing.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Now, it may very well be here in December you'll hear me say, I think there's a safe way to do it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There are other ways to make sure drugs are cheaper.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One is to speed up generic drugs to the marketplace, quicker.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Pharmaceuticals were using loopholes to keep brand -- brand drugs in place, and generics are much less expensive than brand drugs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we're doing just that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Another is to pass -- to get our seniors to sign up to these drug discount cards, and they're working.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Wanda Blackmore I met here from Missouri, the first time she bought drugs with her drug discount card, she paid $1.14, I think it was, for about $10 worth of drugs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And, you know, in 2006 seniors are going to get prescription drug coverage for the first time in Medicare.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Because I went to Washington to fix problems.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Medicare -- the issue of Medicare used to be called "Mediscare."
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: People didn't want to touch it for fear of getting hurt politically.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I wanted to get something done.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think our seniors deserve a modern medical system.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And in 2006, our seniors will get prescription drug coverage.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: John, you heard the president just say that he thought he might try to be for it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Four years ago, right here in this forum, he was asked the same question: Can't people be able to import drugs from Canada?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You know what he said?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: "I think that makes sense.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think that's a good idea" -- four years ago.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, the president said, "I'm not blocking that."
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Ladies and gentlemen, the president just didn't level with you right now again.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He did block it, because we passed it in the United States Senate.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We sent it over to the House, that you could import drugs.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We took care of the safety issues.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We're not talking about third-world drugs.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We're talking about drugs made right here in the United States of America that have American brand names on them and American bottles.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we're asking to be able to allow you to get them.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president also took Medicare, which belongs to you.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And he could have lowered the cost of Medicare and lowered your taxes and lowered the costs to seniors.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You know what he did?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He made it illegal, illegal for Medicare to do what the V.A.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: does, which is bulk purchase drugs so that you can lower the price and get them out to you lower.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He put $139 billion of windfall profit into the pockets of the drug companies right out of your pockets.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's the difference between us.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president sides with the power companies, the oil companies, the drug companies.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I'm fighting to let you get those drugs from Canada, and I'm fighting to let Medicare survive.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm fighting for the middle class.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: If they're safe, they're coming.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to remind you that it wasn't just my administration that made the decision on safety.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: President Clinton did the same thing, because we have an obligation to protect you.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Now, he talks about Medicare.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He's been in the United States Senate 20 years.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Show me one accomplishment toward Medicare that he accomplished.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've been in Washington, D.C., three and a half years and led the Congress to reform Medicare so our seniors have got a modern health care system.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's what leadership is all about.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Actually, Mr. President, in 1997 we fixed Medicare, and I was one of the people involved in it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We not only fixed Medicare and took it way out into the future, we did something that you don't know how to do: We balanced the budget.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And it's the president's fiscal policies that have driven up the biggest deficits in American history.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He's added more debt to the debt of the United States in four years than all the way from George Washington to Ronald Reagan put together.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: John Edwards is the author of the Patients' Bill of Rights.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He wanted to give people rights.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: John Edwards and I support tort reform.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We both believe that, as lawyers -- I'm a lawyer, too.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I believe that we will be able to get a fix that has alluded everybody else because we know how to do it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It's in my health-care proposal.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You can pull it off of the Internet.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And you'll find a tort reform plan.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, ladies and gentlemen, important to understand, the president and his friends try to make a big deal out of it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Do we need to fix it, particularly for OGBYNs (sic) and for brain surgeons and others?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But it's less than 1 percent of the total cost of health care.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Your premiums are going up.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You've gone up, in Missouri, about $3,500.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You've gone up 64 percent.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You've seen co-pays go up, deductibles go up.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Five million people have lost their health insurance under this president.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He's done nothing about it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I have a plan to lower the cost of health care for you.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I have a plan to cover all children.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I have a plan to let you buy into the same health care senators and congressmen give themselves.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I have a plan that's going to allow people 55 to 64 to buy into Medicare early.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I have a plan that will take the catastrophic cases out of the system, off your backs, pay for it out of a federal fund, which lowers the premiums for everybody in America, makes American business more competitive and makes health care more affordable.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, all of that can happen, but I have to ask you to do one thing: Join me in rolling back the president's unaffordable tax cut for people earning more than $200,000 a year.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Ninety-eight percent of America, I'm giving you a tax cut and I'm giving you health care.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Let me see where to start here.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: First, the National Journal named Senator Kennedy the most liberal senator of all.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's saying something in that bunch.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You might say that took a lot of hard work.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The reason I bring that up is because he's proposed $2.2 trillion in new spending, and he says he going to tax the rich to close the tax gap.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He's going to tax everybody here to fund his programs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And what are his health programs?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: First, he says he's for medical liability reform, particularly for OB/GYNs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There's a bill on the floor of the United States Senate that he could have showed up and voted for if he's so much for it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Secondly, he says that medical liability costs only cause a 1 percent increase.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That shows a lack of understanding.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Doctors practice defensive medicine because of all the frivolous lawsuits that cost our government $28 billion a year.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And finally, he said he's going to have a novel health care plan.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You know what it is?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The federal government is going to run it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's the largest increase in federal government health care ever.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And it fits with his philosophy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's why I told you about the award he won from the National Journal.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They create government-sponsored health care.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Maybe you think that makes sense.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Government-sponsored health care would lead to rationing.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It would ruin the quality of health care in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Yes, I think we should look at the punitive and we should have some limitations.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But look, what's really important, Charlie, is the president is just trying to scare everybody here with throwing labels around.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I mean, "compassionate conservative," what does that mean?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Cutting 500,000 kids from after-school programs, cutting 365,000 kids from health care, running up the biggest deficits in American history.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Mr. President, you're batting 0 for 2.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I mean, seriously -- labels don't mean anything.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: What means something is: Do you have a plan?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I want to talk about my plan some more -- I hope we can.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You're right, what does matter is a plan.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He said he's for -- you're now for capping punitive damages?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You should have shown up on the floor in the Senate and voted for it then.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Medical liability issues are a problem, a significant problem.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He's been in the United States Senate for 20 years and he hasn't addressed it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We passed it out of the House of Representatives.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's stuck in the Senate, because the trial lawyers won't act on it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And he put a trial lawyer on the ticket.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Right, thank you for that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We have a deficit because this country went into a recession.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You might remember the stock market started to decline dramatically six months before I came to office, and then the bubble of the 1990s popped.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that cost us revenue.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I'm going to spend what it takes to win the war, more than just $120 billion for Iraq and Afghanistan.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've got to pay our troops more.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've increased money for ammunition and weapons and pay and homeland security.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I just told this lady over here we spent -- went from $10 billion to $30 billion to protect the homeland.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think we have an obligation to spend that kind of money.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And plus, we cut taxes for everybody.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Everybody got tax relief, so that they get out of the recession.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think if you raise taxes during a recession, you head to depression.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I come from the school of thought that says when people have more money in their pocket during economic times, it increases demand or investment.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Small businesses begin to grow, and jobs are added.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We found out today that over the past 13 months, we've added 1.9 million new jobs in the last 13 months.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I proposed a plan, detailed budget, that shows us cutting the deficit in half by five years.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And you're right, I haven't vetoed any spending bills, because we work together.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Non-homeland, non-defense discretionary spending was raising at 15 percent a year when I got into office.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And today it's less than 1 percent, because we're working together to try to bring this deficit under control.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Like you, I'm concerned about the deficit.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I am not going to shortchange our troops in harm's way.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I'm not going to run up taxes, which will cost this economy jobs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Thank you for your question.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Let me begin by saying that my health-care plan is not what the president described.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It is not a government takeover.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Choose your doctor, choose your plan.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The government has nothing to do with it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: In fact, it doesn't ask you to do anything -- if you don't want to take it, you don't have to.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: If you like your high premiums, you keep them.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's the way we leave it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now with respect to the deficit, the president was handed a $5.6 trillion surplus, ladies and gentlemen.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's where he was when he came into office.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We now have a $2.6 trillion deficit.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: This is the biggest turnaround in the history of the country.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He's the first president in 72 years to lose jobs.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: This is the first time the United States of America has ever had a tax cut when we're at war.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Franklin Roosevelt, Harry Truman, others, knew how to lead.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They knew how to ask the American people for the right things.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: One percent of America, the highest one percent of income earners in America, got $89 billion of tax cut last year.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: One percent of America got more than the 80 percent of America that earned from $100,000 down.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president thinks it's more important to fight for that top 1 percent than to fight for fiscal responsibility and to fight for you.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I want to put money in your pocket.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I am -- I have a proposal for a tax cut for all people earning less than the $200,000.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The only people affected by my plan are the top income earners of America.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Well, look at the budget.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One is make sure Congress doesn't overspend.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But let me talk back about where we've been.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The stock market was declining six months prior to my arrival.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It was the largest stock market correction -- one of the largest in history, which foretold a recession.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Because we cut taxes on everybody -- remember, we ran up the child credit by $1,000, we reduced the marriage penalty, we created a 10 percent bracket, everybody who pays taxes got relief -- the recession was one of the shortest in our nation's history.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: After 9/11, after the recession had ended, the president asked for another tax cut and promised 5.6 million jobs would be created.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He lost 1.6 million, ladies and gentlemen.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And most of that tax cut went to the wealthiest people in the country.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He came and asked for a tax cut -- we wanted a tax cut to kick the economy into gear.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Do you know what he presented us with?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: A $25 billion giveaway to the biggest corporations in America, including a $254 million refund check to Enron.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I am not going to raise taxes.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I have a tax cut.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And here's my tax cut.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I raise the child-care credit by $1,000 for families to help them be able to take care of their kids.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I have a $4,000 tuition tax credit that goes to parents -- and kids, if they're earning for themselves -- to be able to pay for college.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I lower the cost of health care in the way that I described to you.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Every part of my program I've shown how I'm going to pay for it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I've gotten good people, like former Secretary of the Treasury Bob Rubin, for instance, who showed how to balance budgets and give you a good economy, to help me crunch these numbers and make them work.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've even scaled back some of my favorite programs already, like the child-care program I wanted to fund and the national service program, because the president's deficit keeps growing and I've said as a pledge, "I'm going to cut the deficit in half in four years."
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, I'm going to restore what we did in the 1990s, ladies and gentlemen: pay as you go.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We're going to do it like you do it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president broke the pay-as-you-go rule.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Somebody here asked the question about, "Why haven't you vetoed something?"
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: If you care about it, why don't you veto it?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think John McCain called the energy bill the "No Lobbyist Left Behind" bill.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I mean, you've got to stand up and fight somewhere, folks.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm pledging I will not raise taxes; I'm giving a tax cut to the people earning less than $200,000 a year.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, for the people earning more than $200,000 a year, you're going to see a rollback to the level we were at with Bill Clinton, when people made a lot of money.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And looking around here, at this group here, I suspect there are only three people here who are going to be affected: the president, me, and, Charlie, I'm sorry, you too.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He's just not credible when he talks about being fiscally conservative.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If you look at his record in the Senate, he voted to break the caps -- the spending caps -- over 200 times.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And here he says he's going to be a fiscal conservative, all of a sudden.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And of course he's going to raise your taxes.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You see, he's proposed $2.2 trillion of new spending.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And you say: Well, how are you going to pay for it?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He says, well, he's going to raise the taxes on the rich -- that's what he said -- the top two brackets.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That raises, he says $800 billion; we say $600 billion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've got battling green eye shades.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Somewhere in between those numbers -- and so there's a difference, what he's promised and what he can raise.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Now, either he's going to break all these wonderful promises he's told you about or he's going to raise taxes.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I suspect, given his record, he's going to raise taxes.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Is my time up yet?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You looked at me like my clock was up.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think that the way to grow this economy is to keep taxes low, is have an energy plan, is to have litigation reform.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: As I told you, we've just got a report that said over the past 13 months, we've created 1.9 million new jobs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so the fundamental question of this campaign is: Who's going to keep the economy growing so people can work?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, first of all, the president's figures of $2.2 trillion just aren't accurate.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Those are the fuzzy math figures put together by some group that works for the campaign.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Number two, John McCain and I have a proposal, jointly, for a commission that closes corporate giveaway loopholes.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We've got $40 billion going to Bermuda.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We've got all kinds of giveaways.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We ought to be shutting those down.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And third, credible: Ladies and gentlemen, in 1985, I was one of the first Democrats to move to balance the budget.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I voted for the balanced budget in '93 and '97.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Yes, I mean, he's got a record.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's been there for 20 years.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You can run, but you can't hide.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He voted 98 times to raise taxes.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I mean, these aren't make-up figures.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so people are going to have to look at the record.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Look at the record of the man running for the president.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They don't name him the most liberal in the United States Senate because he hasn't shown up to many meetings.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They named him because of his votes.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's just not credible to say he's going to keep taxes down and balance budgets.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Off-road diesel engines -- we have reached an agreement to reduce pollution from off-road diesel engines by 90 percent.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've got a plan to increase the wetlands by 3 million.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've got an aggressive brown field program to refurbish inner-city sore spots to useful pieces of property.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I proposed to the United States Congress a Clear Skies Initiative to reduce sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxide and mercury by 70 percent.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I have -- was fought for a very strong title in the farm bill for the conservation reserve program to set aside millions of acres of land to help improve wildlife and the habitat.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We proposed and passed a healthy forest bill which was essential to working with -- particularly in Western states -- to make sure that our forests were protected.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: What happens in those forests, because of lousy federal policy, is they grow to be -- they are not -- they're not harvested.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They're not taken care of.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And as a result, they're like tinderboxes.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And over the last summers I've flown over there.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so, this is a reasonable policy to protect old stands of trees and at the same time make sure our forests aren't vulnerable to the forest fires that have destroyed acres after acres in the West.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've got a good, common-sense policy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Now, I'm going to tell you what I really think is going to happen over time is technology is going to change the way we live for the good for the environment.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's why I proposed a hydrogen automobile -- hydrogen-generated automobile.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're spending $1 billion to come up with the technologies to do that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's why I'm a big proponent of clean coal technology, to make sure we can use coal but in a clean way.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I guess you'd say I'm a good steward of the land.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The quality of the air's cleaner since I've been the president.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Fewer water complaints since I've been the president.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: More land being restored since I've been the president.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Thank you for your question.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Boy, to listen to that -- the president, I don't think, is living in a world of reality with respect to the environment.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, if you're a Red Sox fan, that's OK.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But if you're a president, it's not.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Let me just say to you, number one, don't throw the labels around.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I led the fight to put 100,000 cops on the streets of America.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've been for faith-based initiatives helping to intervene in the lives of young children for years.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I was -- broke with my party in 1985, one of the first three Democrats to fight for a balanced budget when it was heresy.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Labels don't fit, ladies and gentlemen.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, when it comes to the issue of the environment, this is one of the worst administrations in modern history.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The Clear Skies bill that he just talked about, it's one of those Orwellian names you pull out of the sky, slap it onto something, like "No Child Left Behind" but you leave millions of children behind.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Here they're leaving the skies and the environment behind.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: If they just left the Clean Air Act all alone the way it is today, no change, the air would be cleaner than it is if you pass the Clear Skies act.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: In fact, his environmental enforcement chief air-quality person at the EPA resigned in protest over what they're doing to what they are calling the new source performance standards for air quality.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They're going backwards on the definition for wetlands.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They're going backwards on the water quality.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They pulled out of the global warming, declared it dead, didn't even accept the science.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm going to be a president who believes in science.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Well, had we joined the Kyoto treaty, which I guess he's referring to, it would have cost America a lot of jobs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's one of these deals where, in order to be popular in the halls of Europe, you sign a treaty.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I thought it would cost a lot -- I think there's a better way to do it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I just told you the facts, sir.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The quality of the air is cleaner since I've been the president of the United States.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we'll continue to spend money on research and development, because I truly believe that's the way to get from how we live today to being able to live a standard of living that we're accustomed to and being able to protect our environment better, the use of technologies.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The fact is that the Kyoto treaty was flawed.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I was in Kyoto, and I was part of that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But this president didn't try to fix it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He just declared it dead, ladies and gentlemen, and we walked away from the work of 160 nations over 10 years.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You wonder, Nikki, why it is that people don't like us in some parts of the world.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You just say: Hey, we don't agree with you.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president's done nothing to try to fix it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Jane, there are a lot of ways to be competitive.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And unfortunately again I regret this administration has not seized them and embraced them.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Let me give you an example.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: There is a tax loophole right now.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: If you're a company in St. Louis working, trying to make jobs here, there is actually an incentive for you to go away.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You get more money, you keep more of your taxes by going abroad.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm going to shut that loophole, and I'm going to give the tax benefit to the companies that stay here in America to help make them more competitive.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Secondly, we're going to create a manufacturing jobs credit and a new jobs credit for people to be able to help hire and be more competitive here in America.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Third, what's really hurting American business more than anything else is the cost of health care.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, you didn't hear any plan from the president, because he doesn't have a plan to lower the cost of health care.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Five million Americans have lost their health care; 620,000 Missourians have no health care at all; 96,000 Missourians have lost their health care under President Bush.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I have a plan to cover those folks.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And it's a plan that lowers cost for everybody, covers all children.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And the way I pay for it -- I'm not fiscally irresponsible -- is I roll back the tax cut this president so fiercely wants to defend, the one for him and me and Charlie.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think you ought to get the break.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I want to lower your cost to health care.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I want to fully fund education, No Child Left Behind, special-needs education.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And that's how we're going to be more competitive, by making sure our kids are graduating from school and college.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We've got to create the products of the future.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's why I have a plan for energy independence within 10 years.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we're going to put our laboratories and our colleges and our universities to work.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And we're going to get the great entrepreneurial spirit of this country, and we're going to free ourselves from this dependency on Mideast oil.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's how you create jobs and become competitive.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Let me start with how to control the cost of health care: medical liability reform, for starters, which he's opposed.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Secondly, allow small businesses to pool together so they can share risk and buy insurance at the same discounts big businesses get to do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Thirdly, spread what's called health savings accounts.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's good for small businesses, good for owners.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You own your own account.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You get a catastrophic plan to help you on it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This is different from saying, "OK, let me incent you to go on the government."
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He's talking about his plan to keep jobs here.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You know he calls it an outsourcing to keep -- stop outsourcing.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Robert Rubin looked at his plan and said it won't work.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The best way to keep jobs here in America is, one, have an energy plan.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I proposed one to the Congress two years ago, encourages conservation, encourages technology to explore for environmentally friendly ways for coal -- to use coal and gas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It encourages the use of renewables like ethanol and biodiesel.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's stuck in the Senate.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He and his running-mate didn't show up to vote when they could have got it going in the Senate.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Less regulations if we want jobs here; legal reform if we want jobs here; and we've got to keep taxes low.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Now, he says he's only going to tax the rich.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Do you realize, 900,000 small businesses will be taxed under his plan because most small businesses are Subchapter S corps or limited partnerships, and they pay tax at the individual income tax level.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so when you're running up the taxes like that, you're taxing job creators, and that's not how you keep jobs here.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You can't stop all outsourcing, Charlie.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm not going to, because that would be pandering.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But what you can do is create a fair playing field, and that's what I'm talking about.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But let me just address what the president just said.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Ladies and gentlemen, that's just not true what he said.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The Wall Street Journal said 96 percent of small businesses are not affected at all by my plan.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And you know why he gets that count?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president got $84 from a timber company that owns, and he's counted as a small business.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Dick Cheney's counted as a small business.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's how they do things.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I own a timber company?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Most small businesses are Subchapter S corps.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I met Grant Milliron, Mansfield, Ohio.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Most small businesses -- 70 percent of the new jobs in America are created by small businesses.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Taxes are going up when you run up the top two brackets.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I really don't think your rights are being watered down.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: As a matter of fact, I wouldn't support it if I thought that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Every action being taken against terrorists requires court order, requires scrutiny.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: As a matter of fact, the tools now given to the terrorist fighters are the same tools that we've been using against drug dealers and white-collar criminals.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So I really don't think so.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I hope you don't think that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I mean, I -- because I think whoever is the president must guard your liberties, must not erode your rights in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The Patriot Act is necessary, for example, because parts of the FBI couldn't talk to each other.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The intelligence-gathering and the law-enforcement arms of the FBI just couldn't share intelligence under the old law.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that didn't make any sense.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Our law enforcement must have every tool necessary to find and disrupt terrorists at home and abroad before they hurt us again.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's the task of the 21st century.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so, I don't think the Patriot Act abridges your rights at all.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I know it's necessary.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I can remember being in upstate New York talking to FBI agents that helped bust a Lackawanna cell up there.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And they told me they could not have performed their duty, the duty we all expect of them, if they did not have the ability to communicate with each other under the Patriot Act.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Former Governor Racicot, as chairman of the Republican Party, said he thought that the Patriot Act has to be changed and fixed.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Congressman Jim Sensenbrenner, he is the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, said over his dead body before it gets renewed without being thoroughly rechecked.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: A whole bunch of folks in America are concerned about the way the Patriot Act has been applied.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: In fact, the inspector general of the Justice Department found that John Ashcroft had twice applied it in ways that were inappropriate.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: People's rights have been abused.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I met a man who spent eight months in prison, wasn't even allowed to call his lawyer, wasn't allowed to get -- finally, Senator Dick Durbin of Illinois intervened and was able to get him out.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: This is in our country, folks, the United States of America.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They've got sneak-and-peek searches that are allowed.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They've got people allowed to go into churches now and political meetings without any showing of potential criminal activity or otherwise.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, I voted for the Patriot Act.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Ninety-nine United States senators voted for it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And the president's been very busy running around the country using what I just described to you as a reason to say I'm wishy-washy, that I'm a flip-flopper.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now that's not a flip-flop.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I believe in the Patriot Act.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We need the things in it that coordinate the FBI and the CIA.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We need to be stronger on terrorism.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But you know what we also need to do as Americans is never let the terrorists change the Constitution of the United States in a way that disadvantages our rights.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You know, Elizabeth, I really respect your -- the feeling that's in your question.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I know the morality that's prompting that question, and I respect it enormously.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But like Nancy Reagan, and so many other people -- you know, I was at a forum with Michael J.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Fox the other day in New Hampshire, who's suffering from Parkinson's, and he wants us to do stem cell, embryonic stem cell.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And this fellow stood up, and he was quivering.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: His whole body was shaking from the nerve disease, the muscular disease that he had.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And he said to me and to the whole hall, he said, "You know, don't take away my hope, because my hope is what keeps me going."
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Chris Reeve is a friend of mine.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Chris Reeve exercises every single day to keep those muscles alive for the day when he believes he can walk again, and I want him to walk again.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think we can save lives.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, I think we can do ethically guided embryonic stem-cell research.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We have 100,000 to 200,000 embryos that are frozen in nitrogen today from fertility clinics.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: These weren't taken from abortion or something like that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They're from a fertility clinic.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And they're either going to be destroyed or left frozen.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I believe if we have the option, which scientists tell us we do, of curing Parkinson's, curing diabetes, curing, you know, some kind of a, you know, paraplegic or quadriplegic or, you know, a spinal cord injury, anything, that's the nature of the human spirit.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think it is respecting life to reach for that cure.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I think it is respecting life to do it in an ethical way.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And the president has chosen a policy that makes it impossible for our scientists to do that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I want the future, and I think we have to grab it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Embryonic stem-cell research requires the destruction of life to create a stem cell.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm the first president ever to allow funding -- federal funding -- for embryonic stem-cell research.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I did to because I too hope that we'll discover cures from the stem cells and from the research derived.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I think we've got to be very careful in balancing the ethics and the science.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so I made the decision we wouldn't spend any more money beyond the 70 lines, 22 of which are now in action, because science is important, but so is ethics, so is balancing life.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: To destroy life to save life is -- it's one of the real ethical dilemmas that we face.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There is going to be hundreds of experiments off the 22 lines that now exist that are active, and hopefully we find a cure.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But as well, we need to continue to pursue adult stem-cell research.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I helped double the NIH budget to $28 billion a year to find cures.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And the approach I took is one that I think is a balanced and necessary approach, to balance science and the concerns for life.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, you talk about walking a waffle line -- he says he's allowed it, which means he's going to allow the destruction of life up to a certain amount and then he isn't going to allow it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I don't know how you draw that line.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But let me tell you, point blank, the lines of stem cells that he's made available, every scientist in the country will tell you, "Not adequate," because they're contaminated by mouse cells, and because there aren't 60 or 70 -- they're are only about 11 to 20 now -- and there aren't enough to be able to do the research because they're contaminated.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We've got to open up the possibilities of this research.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And when I am president, I'm going to do it because we have to.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Let me make sure you understand my decision.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Those stem- cells lines already existed.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The embryo had already been destroyed prior to my decision.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I had to make the decision to destroy more life, so do we continue to destroy life -- I made the decision to balance science and ethics.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I really don't have -- haven't picked anybody yet.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I would pick somebody who would not allow their personal opinion to get in the way of the law.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I would pick somebody who would strictly interpret the Constitution of the United States.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Let me give you a couple of examples, I guess, of the kind of person I wouldn't pick.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I wouldn't pick a judge who said that the Pledge of Allegiance couldn't be said in a school because it had the words "under God" in it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think that's an example of a judge allowing personal opinion to enter into the decision-making process as opposed to a strict interpretation of the Constitution.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Another example would be the Dred Scott case, which is where judges, years ago, said that the Constitution allowed slavery because of personal property rights.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's not what the Constitution says.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The Constitution of the United States says we're all -- you know, it doesn't say that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It doesn't speak to the equality of America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so, I would pick people that would be strict constructionists.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've got plenty of lawmakers in Washington, D.C.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Legislators make law; judges interpret the Constitution.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I suspect one of us will have a pick at the end of next year -- the next four years.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's the kind of judge I'm going to put on there.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: No litmus test except for how they interpret the Constitution.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: A few years ago when he came to office, the president said -- these are his words -- "What we need are some good conservative judges on the courts."
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And he said also that his two favorite justices are Justice Scalia and Justice Thomas.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: So you get a pretty good sense of where he's heading if he were to appoint somebody.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, here's what I believe.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I don't believe we need a good conservative judge, and I don't believe we need a good liberal judge.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I don't believe we need a good judge of that kind of definition on either side.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I subscribe to the Justice Potter Stewart standard.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He was a justice on the Supreme Court of the United States.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And he said the mark of a good judge, good justice, is that when you're reading their decision, their opinion, you can't tell if it's written by a man or woman, a liberal or a conservative, a Muslim, a Jew or a Christian.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You just know you're reading a good judicial decision.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: What I want to find, if I am privileged to have the opportunity to do it -- and the Supreme Court of the United States is at stake in this race, ladies and gentlemen.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The future of things that matter to you -- in terms of civil rights, what kind of Justice Department you'll have, whether we'll enforce the law.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Will we have equal opportunity?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Will women's rights be protected?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Will we have equal pay for women, which is going backwards?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Will a woman's right to choose be protected?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: These are constitutional rights, and I want to make sure we have judges who interpret the Constitution of the United States according to the law.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I would say to that person exactly what I will say to you right now.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: First of all, I cannot tell you how deeply I respect the belief about life and when it begins.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm a Catholic, raised a Catholic.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Religion has been a huge part of my life.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It helped lead me through a war, leads me today.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But I can't take what is an article of faith for me and legislate it for someone who doesn't share that article of faith, whether they be agnostic, atheist, Jew, Protestant, whatever.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But I can counsel people.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I can talk reasonably about life and about responsibility.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I can talk to people, as my wife Teresa does, about making other choices, and about abstinence, and about all these other things that we ought to do as a responsible society.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But as a president, I have to represent all the people in the nation.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I have to make that judgment.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, I believe that you can take that position and not be pro- abortion, but you have to afford people their constitutional rights.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And that means being smart about allowing people to be fully educated, to know what their options are in life, and making certain that you don't deny a poor person the right to be able to have whatever the constitution affords them if they can't afford it otherwise.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's why I think it's important.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's why I think it's important for the United States, for instance, not to have this rigid ideological restriction on helping families around the world to be able to make a smart decision about family planning.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You'll help prevent unwanted children, unwanted pregnancies.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You'll actually do a better job, I think, of passing on the moral responsibility that is expressed in your question.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I truly respect it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm trying to decipher that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My answer is, we're not going to spend taxpayers' money on abortion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This is an issue that divides America, but certainly reasonable people can agree on how to reduce abortions in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I signed the partial-birth -- the ban on partial-birth abortion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's one way to help reduce abortions.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My opponent voted against the ban.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think there ought to be parental notification laws.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I signed a bill called the Unborn Victims of Violence Act.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In other words, if you're a mom and you're pregnant and you get killed, the murderer gets tried for two cases, not just one.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: My opponent was against that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: These are reasonable ways to help promote a culture of life in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think it is a worthy goal in America to have every child protected by law and welcomed in life.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I also think we ought to continue to have good adoption law as an alternative to abortion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we need to promote maternity group homes, which my administration has done.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Culture of life is really important for a country to have if it's going to be a hospitable society.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, again, the president just said, categorically, my opponent is against this, my opponent is against that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: You know, it's just not that simple.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm against the partial-birth abortion, but you've got to have an exception for the life of the mother and the health of the mother under the strictest test of bodily injury to the mother.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Secondly, with respect to parental notification, I'm not going to require a 16-or 17-year-old kid who's been raped by her father and who's pregnant to have to notify her father.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: So you got to have a judicial intervention.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And because they didn't have a judicial intervention where she could go somewhere and get help, I voted against it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: It's never quite as simple as the president wants you to believe.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Well, it's pretty simple when they say: Are you for a ban on partial birth abortion?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And he was given a chance to vote, and he voted no.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's just the way it is.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's clear for everybody to see.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And as I said: You can run but you can't hide the reality.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Put a head fake on us.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I have made a lot of decisions, and some of them little, like appointments to boards you never heard of, and some of them big.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And in a war, there's a lot of -- there's a lot of tactical decisions that historians will look back and say: He shouldn't have done that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He shouldn't have made that decision.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I'll take responsibility for them.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But on the big questions, about whether or not we should have gone into Afghanistan, the big question about whether we should have removed somebody in Iraq, I'll stand by those decisions, because I think they're right.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's really what you're -- when they ask about the mistakes, that's what they're talking about.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They're trying to say, "Did you make a mistake going into Iraq?"
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And the answer is, "Absolutely not."
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It was the right decision.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The Duelfer report confirmed that decision today, because what Saddam Hussein was doing was trying to get rid of sanctions so he could reconstitute a weapons program.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And the biggest threat facing America is terrorists with weapons of mass destruction.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We knew he hated us.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We knew he'd been -- invaded other countries.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We knew he tortured his own people.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: On the tax cut, it's a big decision.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I did the right decision.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Our recession was one of the shallowest in modern history.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Now, you asked what mistakes.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I made some mistakes in appointing people, but I'm not going to name them.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't want to hurt their feelings on national TV.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But history will look back, and I'm fully prepared to accept any mistakes that history judges to my administration, because the president makes the decisions, the president has to take the responsibility.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe the president made a huge mistake, a catastrophic mistake, not to live up to his own standard, which was: build a true global coalition, give the inspectors time to finish their job and go through the U.N. process to its end and go to war as a last resort.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I ask each of you just to look into your hearts, look into your guts.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Was this really going to war as a last resort?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: The president rushed our nation to war without a plan to win the peace.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And simple things weren't done.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's why Senator Lugar says: incompetent in the delivery of services.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That's why Senator Hagel, Republican, says, you know: beyond pitiful, beyond embarrassing, in the zone of dangerous.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We didn't guard 850,000 tons of ammo.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: That ammo is now being used against our kids.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Ten thousand out of 12,000 Humvees aren't armored.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I visited some of those kids with no limbs today, because they didn't have the armor on those vehicles.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: They didn't have the right body armor.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I've met parents who've on the Internet gotten the armor to send their kids.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: There is no bigger judgment for a president of the United states than how you take a nation to war.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And you can't say, because Saddam might have done it 10 years from now, that's a reason; that's an excuse.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He complains about the fact our troops don't have adequate equipment, yet he voted against the $87 billion supplemental I sent to the Congress and then issued one of the most amazing quotes in political history: "I actually did vote for the $87 billion before I voted against it."
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Saddam Hussein was a risk to our country, ma'am.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And he was a risk that -- and this is where we just have a difference of opinion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The truth of that matter is, if you listen carefully, Saddam would still be in power if he were the president of the United States, "And the world would be a lot better off."
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Not necessarily be in power, but here's what I'll say about the $87 billion.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I made a mistake in the way I talk about it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He made a mistake in invading Iraq.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Which is a worse decision?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Now, I voted the way I voted because I saw that he had the policy wrong and I wanted accountability.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I didn't want to give a slush fund to Halliburton.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I also thought the wealthiest people in America ought to pay for it, ladies and gentlemen.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: He wants your kids to pay for it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I wanted us to pay for it, since we're at war.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I don't think that's a bad decision.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Do you want to go first?
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Thank you, all of you, for taking part.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Obviously the president and I both have very strong convictions.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I respect him for that.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But we have a very different view about how to make America stronger and safer.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I will never cede the authority of our country or our security to any other nation.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'll never give a veto over American security to any other entity -- not a nation, not a country, not an institution.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But I know, as I think you do, that our country is strongest when we lead the world, when we lead strong alliances.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And that's the way Eisenhower and Reagan and Kennedy and others did it.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: We are not doing that today.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I have a plan that will help us go out and kill and find the terrorists.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I will not stop in our efforts to hunt down and kill the terrorists.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: But I'll also have a better plan of how we're going to deal with Iraq: training the Iraqi forces more rapidly, getting our allies back to the table with a fresh start, with new credibility, with a president whose judgment the rest of the world trusts.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: In addition to that, I believe we have a crisis here at home, a crisis of the middle class that is increasingly squeezed, health-care costs going up.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I have a plan to provide health care to all Americans.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I have a plan to provide for our schools so we keep the standards but we help our teachers teach and elevate our schools by funding No Child Left Behind.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I have a plan to protect the environment so that we leave this place in better shape to our children than we were handed it by our parents.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: I'm an optimist, but we have to make the right choices, to be fiscally responsible and to create the new jobs of the future.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: And I ask you for the privilege of leading our nation to be stronger at home and respected again in the world.
Speaker: John Kerry

Text: Thank you all very much.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The great contest for the presidency is about the future, who can lead, who can get things done.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've been through a lot together as a country -- been through a recession, corporate scandals, war.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And yet think about where we are: Added 1.9 million new jobs over the past 13 months.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The farm income in America is high.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Homeownership rate is at an all-time high in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Tonight I had a chance to discuss with you what to do to keep this economy going: keep the taxes low, don't increase the scope of the federal government, keep regulations down, legal reform, a health- care policy that does not empower the federal government but empowers individuals, and an energy plan that will help us become less dependent on foreign sources of energy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And abroad, we're at war.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And it requires a president who is steadfast and strong and determined.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I vowed to the American people after that fateful day of September the 11th that we would not rest nor tire until we're safe.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The 9/11 Commission put out a report that said America is safer but not yet safe.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There is more work to be done.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We'll stay on the hunt on Al Qaida.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We'll deny sanctuary to these terrorists.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We'll make sure they do not end up with weapons of mass destruction.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The great threat to our country is that these haters end up with weapons of mass destruction.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But our long-term security depends on our deep faith in liberty.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we'll continue to promote freedom around the world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Freedom is on the march.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Tomorrow, Afghanistan will be voting for a president.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In Iraq, we'll be having free elections, and a free society will make this world more peaceful.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think the principal that separates me is that 5 and a half million people came together on their own and put me on the ballot.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: This is a movement that came from the people.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: This is the way the framers of the Constitution intended our government to be, a government that comes from the people.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The thing that separates my candidacy and makes it unique is that this came from millions of people in 50 states all over this country who wanted a candidate that worked and belonged to nobody but them.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I go into this race as their servant, and I belong to them.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So this comes from the people.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The most important distinction in this campaign is that I represent real hope for change, a departure from trickle-down economics, a departure from tax and spend economics, to invest in growth.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But before I can do that, I must challenge the American people to change, and they must decide.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Tonight I say to the President: Mr. Bush, for 12 years you've had it your way.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You've had your chance and it didn't work.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I want to bring that change to the American people.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But we must all decide first we have the courage to change for hope and a better tomorrow.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, I think one thing that distinguishes is experience.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think we've dramatically changed the world.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'll talk about that a little bit later, but the changes are mind-boggling for world peace.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Kids go to bed at night without the same fear of nuclear war.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And change for change sake isn't enough.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We saw that message in the late 70s when heard a lot about change, and what happened, that misery index went right through the roof.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But my economic program is the kind of change we want.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And the way we're going to get it done is we're going to have a brand new Congress.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: A lot of them are thrown out because of all the scandals.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'll sit down with them, Democrats and Republicans alike, and work for my agenda for American renewal, which represents real change.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I'd say, if you had to separate out, I think it's experience at this level.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Values, judgment, and the record that I have amassed in my state also should count for something.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I've worked hard to create good jobs and to educate people.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: My state now ranks first in the country in job growth this year, fourth in income growth, fourth in reduction of poverty, third in overall economic performance, according to a major news magazine.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's because we believe in investing in education and in jobs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You know, my wife, Hillary, gave me a book about a year ago in which the author defined insanity as just doing the same old thing over and over again and expecting a different result.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have got to have the courage to change.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I've gotten a lot of good experience in dealing with ordinary people over the last year and month.
Speaker: Bill Clinton
