Text: I've touched more people's lives and seen more heartbreak and hope, more pain and more promise, than anybody else who's run for president this year.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think the American people deserve better than they're getting.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have gone from first to thirteenth in wages in the world in the last twelve years, since Mr. Bush and Mr. Reagan have been in.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Personal income has dropped while people have worked harder.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We're living in a new world after the Cold War, and what works in this new world is not trickle down, not government for the benefit of the privileged few, not tax and spend, but a commitment to invest in American jobs and American education, controlling American health care costs, and bringing the American people together.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And you can have the right kind of experience and the wrong kind of experience.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Mine is rooted in the real lives of real people, and it will bring real results if we have the courage to change.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I just thought of another -- another big difference here between me.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't believe Mr. Perot feels this way, but I know Governor Clinton did because I want to accurately quote him.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He thinks, I think he said, that the country is coming apart at the seams.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Now, I know that the only way he can win is to make everybody believe the economy's worse than it is.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But this country is not coming apart at the seams, for heaven's sakes.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We're the United States of America.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: In spite of the economic problems, we're the most respected economy around the world.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Many would trade for it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We've been caught up in a global slowdown.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We can do much, much better, but we ought not try to convince the American people that America is a country that's coming apart at the seams.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I would hate to be running for president and think that the only way I could win would be to convince everybody how horrible things are.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Yes, there are big problems, and yes, people are hurting.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I believe that this Agenda for American renewal I have is the answer to do it, and I believe we can get it done now, whereas we didn't in the past, because you're going to have a whole brand new bunch of people in the Congress that are going to have to listen to the same American people I'm listening to.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, they've got a point.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I don't have any experience in running up a $4 trillion debt.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I don't have any experience in gridlock government where nobody takes responsibility for anything and everybody blames everybody else.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I don't have any experience in creating the worst public school system in the industrialized world, the most violent crime-ridden society in the industrialized world.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Ã‚ But I do have a lot of experience in getting things done.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So, if we're at a point in history where we want to stop talking about it and do it, I've got a lot of experience in figuring out how to solve problems, making the solutions work, and then moving on to the next one.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I've got a lot of experience in not taking 10 years to solve a 10-minute problem.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So, if it's time for action, I think I have experience that counts.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I think the American people should be the judge of that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think character is a very important question.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I said something the other day where I was accused of being like Joe McCarthy because I questioned -- I put it this way; I think it's wrong to demonstrate against your own country or organize demonstrations against your own country in foreign soil.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I just think it's wrong.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I -- well, maybe they say, "Well, it was a youthful indiscretion."
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I was 19 or 20 flying off an aircraft carrier and that shaped me to be Commander-in-Chief of the armed forces.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: They get on me -- Bill's gotten on me about, "read my lips."
Speaker: George Bush

Text: When I make a mistake I'll admit it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But he has made -- not admitted a mistake and I just find it impossible to understand how an American can demonstrate against his own country in a foreign land -- organizing demonstrations against it when young men are held prisoner in Hanoi or kids out of the ghetto were drafted.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Some say, "well, you're a little old fashioned."
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Maybe I am, but I just don't think that's right.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Now, whether it's character or judgment -- whatever it is -- I have a big difference here on this issue and so we'll just have to see how it plays out.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I -- I couldn't do that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I don't think most Americans could do that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And they all say, "Well, it was a long time ago."
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Well, let's admit it then.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Say, "I made a terrible mistake."
Speaker: George Bush

Text: How could you be Commander-in-Chief of the armed forces and have some kid say -- when you have to make a tough decision, as I did in Panama or Kuwait and then have some kid jump up and say, "Well, I'm not going to go.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The Commander-in-Chief was organizing demonstrations halfway around the world during another era.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So there are differences but that's about the main area where I think we have a difference.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't know about -- we'll talk about that a little with Ross here in a bit.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think the American people will make their own decisions on character and at a time when we have work to do and we need action I think they need to clearly understand the backgrounds of each person.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I think the press can play a huge roll in making sure that the backgrounds are clearly presented in an objective way.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Certainly anyone in the White House should have the character to be there.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But, I think it's very important to measure when and where things occurred.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Did they occur when you were a young person, in your formative years?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Or did they occur while you were a senior official in the federal government?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: When youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re a senior official in the federal government spending billions of dollars in taxpayerÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s money and youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re a mature individual and you make a mistake, then that was on our ticket.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If you make it as a young man, time passes.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So I would say just, you know, look at all three of us.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Decide who you think will do the job.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Pick that person in November because believe me, as I've said before, "The party's over and it's time for the clean-up crew."
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And we do have to have change and people who never take responsibility for anything when it happens on their watch and people who are in charge --
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Ross gave a good answer but I've got to respond directly to Mr. Bush.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You have questioned my patriotism.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You even brought some right-wing congressman into the White House to plot how to attack me for going to Russia in 1969-70, when over 50,000 other Americans did.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now, I honor your service in World War II, I honor Mr. Perot's service in uniform and the service of every man and woman who ever served, including Admiral Crowe, who was your Chairman of the joint Chiefs and who's supporting me.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But when Joe McCarthy went around this country attacking people's patriotism he was wrong.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And a senator from Connecticut stood up to him named Prescott Bush.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Your father was right to stand up to Joe McCarthy, you were wrong to attack my patriotism.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I was opposed to the war but I loved my country and we need a president who will bring this country together, not divide it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I want to lead a unified country.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The tax increase I have proposed triggers in at family incomes of $200,000 and above.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Those are the people who in the 1980s had their incomes go up while their taxes went down.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Middle-class people, defined as people with incomes of $52,000 and down, had their incomes go down while their taxes went up in the Reagan-Bush years because of 6 increases in the payroll taxes.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So that is where my income limit would trigger.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: --notwithstanding my opponent's ad, my plan triggers in at gross incomes, family incomes of $200,000 and above.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Then we want to give modest middle-class tax relief to restore some fairness, especially to middle- class people with families with incomes of under $60,000.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: In addition to that, the money that I raise from upper-income people and from asking foreign corporations just to pay the same income on their income earned in America that American corporations do will be used to give incentives back to upper-income people.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We don't need across-the-board tax cuts for the wealthy for nothing.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We need to say here's your tax incentive: if you create American jobs, the old-fashioned way.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'd like to create more millionaires than were created under Mr. Bush and Mr. Reagan, but I don't want to have 4 years where we have no growth in the private sector, and that's what's happened in the last 4 years.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We're down 35,000 jobs in the private sector.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We need to invest and grow, and that's what I want to do.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, let me--I have to correct one thing.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I didn't question the man's patriotism.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I questioned his judgment and his character.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: What he did in Moscow, that's fine.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: What I don't accept is demonstrating and organizing demonstrations in a foreign country when your country's at war.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: In terms of this one on taxes spells out the biggest difference between us.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I do not believe we need to go back to the Mondale proposals or the Dukakis proposals of tax and spend.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Taxing people over $200,000 will not get you $150 billion.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: That old adage they use--we're going to soak the rich- -we're going to soak the rich--it always ends up being the poor cab driver or the working man that ends up paying the bill.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so I just have a different approach.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I believe the way to get the deficit down is to control the growth of mandatory spending programs, and not raise taxes on the American people.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We've got a big difference there.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We've got to have a growing, expanding job base to give us a growing, expanding tax base.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Right now we have a flat to deteriorating job base and where it appears to be growing, it's minimum-wage jobs.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So we've got to really rebuild our job base.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: That's going to take money for infrastructure and investment to do that.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Our foreign competitors are doing it; we're not.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We cannot pay off the $4 trillion debt, balance the budget and have the industries of the future and the high- paying jobs in this country without having the revenue.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We're going to go through a period of shared sacrifice.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: It's got to be fair.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We've created a mess, don't have much to show for it and we have got to fix it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Well, Sander, that's a good question, and the answer is: for 40-some years we kept the peace.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I have cut defense spending.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And the reason we could do that is because of our fantastic success in winning the Cold War.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We never would have got there if we had gone for the nuclear freeze crowd; we never would have got there if we had listened to those that wanted to cut defense spending.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think it is important that the US stay in Europe and continue to guarantee the peace.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We simply cannot pull back.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Now, when anybody has a spending program they want to spend money on at home, they say, well, let's cut money out of the Defense Dept.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I will accept and have accepted the recommendations of 2 proven leaders, General Colin Powell and Secretary Dick Cheney.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: They feel that the levels we're operating at and the reductions that I have proposed are proper.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so I simply do not think we should go back to the isolation days and starting blaming foreigners.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We are the sole remaining superpower, and we should be that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we have a certain disproportionate responsibility.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But I would ask the American people to understand that if we make imprudent cuts, if we go too far, we risk the peace.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I don't want to do that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Because of our programs we have been able to significantly cut defense spending.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But let's not cut into the muscle, and let's not cut down our insurance policy, which is participation of American forces in NATO, the greatest peace- keeping organization ever made.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Today you've got problems in Europe, still bubbling along even though Europe's gone democracy's route.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But we are there, and I think this insurance policy is necessary.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think it goes with world leadership, and I think the levels we've come up with are just about right.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: If I'm poor and you're rich, and I can get you to defend me, that's good.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But when the tables get turned, I ought to do my share.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Right now we spend about $300 billion a year on defense, the Japanese spend around 30 billion in Asia, the Germans spend around 30 billion in Europe.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: For example, Germany will spend a trillion dollars building infrastructure over the next 10 years.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: It's kind of easy to do if you only have to pick up a $30-billion tab to defend your country.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The European Community is in a position to pay a lot more than they have in the past.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I agree with the president: when they couldn't, we should have; now that they can, they should.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We sort of seem to have a desire to try to stay over there and control it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They don't want us to control it, very candidly.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I disagree that we need 150,000 troops to fulfill our role in Europe.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We certainly must maintain an engagement there.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: There are certainly dangers there, there are certainly other trouble spots in the world which are closer to Europe than to the US.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But 2 former defense secretaries recently issued a report saying that 100,000 or slightly fewer troops would be enough, including President Reagan's former defense secretary, Mr. Carlucci.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Many of the military experts whom I consulted on this agreed.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We're going to have to spend more money in the future on military technology and on greater mobility, greater airlift, greater sealift, the B-22 airplane.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We're going to have to do some things that are quite costly.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I simply don't believe we can afford nor do we need to keep 150,000 troops in Europe given how much the Red Army, now under the control of Russia, has been cut, the arms control agreement concluded between Mr. Bush and Mr. Yeltsin, something I have applauded.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I don't think we need 150,000 troops.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me make one other point.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Mr. Bush talked about taxes.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: He didn't tell you that he vetoed a middle class tax cut because it would be paid for by raising taxes on the wealthy and vetoed an investment tax credit paid for by raising taxes on the wealthy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's 10 cents a year cumulative.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: It finally gets to 50 cents at the end of the 5th year.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I think "punish" is the wrong word.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Again, see, I didn't create this problem.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We're trying to solve it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, if you study our international competitors, some of our international competitors collect up to $3.50 a gallon in taxes, and they use that money to build infrastructure and to create jobs.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We collect 35 cents, and we don't have it to spend.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I know it's not popular, and I understand the nature of your question.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But the people who will be helped the most by it are the working people who will get the jobs created because of this tax.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Because we have so mismanaged our country over the years, and it is now time to pay the fiddler.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And if we don't, we will be spending our children's money.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We have spent $4 trillion worth.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: An incredible number of young people are active in supporting my effort because they are deeply concerned that we have taken the American dream from them.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I think it's fitting that we're on the campus of a university tonight.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: These young people, when they get out of this wonderful university, will have difficulty finding a job.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We've got to clean this mess up, leave this country in good shape, and pass on the American dream to them.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We've got to collect the taxes to do it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If there's a fairer way, I'm all ears (laughter) --aah.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If people don't have the stomach to fix these problems, I think it's a good time to face it, November.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'm not playing Lawrence Welk music tonight.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I think Mr. Perot has confronted this deficit issue, but I think it's important to point out that we really have 2 deficits in America, not one.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have a budget deficit in the federal government, but we also have an investment, a jobs, an income deficit.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: People are working harder for less money than they were making 10 years ago, 2- 3rds of our people--a $1600 drop in average income in just the last 2 years.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The problem I have with the Perot prescription is that almost all economists who've looked at it say that if you cut the deficit this much this quick it will increase unemployment, it will slow down the economy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's why I think we shouldn't do it that quickly.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have a disciplined reduction in the deficit of 50 % over the next 4 years, but first get incentives to invest in this economy, put the American people back to work.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've got to invest and grow.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: 9 Nobel Prize-winning economists and 500 others, including numerous Republican and Democratic business executives, have endorsed this approach because it offers the best hope to put America back to work and get our incomes rising instead of falling.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Your question was on fairness.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I just disagree with Mr. Perot.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't believe it is fair to slap a 50-cent-a-gallon tax over whatever many years on the people that have to drive for a living, people that go long distances.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I don't think we need to do it.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I agree with what he's talking about in trying to get this spending down and the discipline, although I think we ought to totally exempt Social Security.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But he's talking tough medicine, and I think that's good.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I disagree with the tax-and-spend philosophy.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You see, I don't think we need to tax more and spend more, and then say that's going to make the problem better.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I'm afraid that's what I think I'm hearing from Governor Clinton.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I believe what you need to do is some of what Ross is talking about: control the growth of mandatory spending and get taxes down.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He's mentioned some ways to do it--and I agree with those.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I've been talking about getting a capital gains cut forever, and his friends in Congress have been telling me that's a tax break for the rich.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'm for an investment tax allowance; I'm for a tax break for first- time homebuyers.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And with this new Congress coming in, gridlock will be gone, and I'll sit down with them and say let's get this done.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I assume she was supportive of the decision on McDonnell Douglas, I assume she was supporting me on the decision to sell those airplanes.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think it's a good decision--took a little heat for it, but I think it was the correct decision to do.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we worked it out, and indeed we're moving forward all around the world in a much more peaceful way.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So that one we came away with in creating jobs for the American people.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I would simply say to her, look, take a look at what the president has proposed on job retraining.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: When you cut back on defense spending, some people are going to be thrown out of work.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: If you throw another 50,000 kids on the street because of cutting recklessly in troop levels, you're going to put a lot more out of work.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I would say to them, look at the job retraining programs that we're proposing.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Therein is the best answer to her.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And another one is: stimulate investment and savings.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I mean, we've got big economic problems, but we are not coming apart at the seams; we're ready for a recovery.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: With interest rates down and inflation down, the cruelest tax of all, caught up in a global slowdown right now, that that will change if you go with the programs I've talked about and if you help with job retraining and education.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I am a firm believer that our America 2000 education problem is the answer--a little longer run; it's going to take awhile to educate.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But it is a good program.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But tell her it's not all that gloomy; we're the US, we faced tough problems before.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Look at the misery index when the Democrats had both the White House and the Congress.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It was just right through the roof.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Now, we can do better.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And the way to do better is not to tax and spend but to retrain, get that control of the mandatory spending programs.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'm much more optimistic about this country than some.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Defense industries are going to have to convert to civilian industries.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And the sooner they start, the sooner they'll finish.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And there will be a significant transition.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And it's very important that we not continue to let our industrial base deteriorate.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We had someone who I'm sure regrets said it in the president's staff said he didn't care whether we made potato chips or computer chips.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Well, anybody that thinks about it cares a great deal.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Number one, you make more making computer chips than potato chips; and, number 2, 19 out of 20 computer chips that we have in this country now come from Japan.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We've given away whole industries.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So as we phase these industries over, there's a whole of intellectual talent in these industries.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: A lot of these people in industries can be converted to the industries of tomorrow, and that's where the high-paying jobs are.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We need to have a very carefully thought through phase-over.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, see, we practice 19th century capitalism.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The rest of the world practices 21st century capitalism.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I can't handle that in a minute, but I hope we can get back into it later.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: In the rest of the world, the countries and the businesses would be working together to make this transition in an intelligent way.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We must have a transition plan to plan to convert from a defense to a domestic economy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: There are 200,000 people unemployed in California alone because we have cut defense without planning to retrain them and to reinvest in the technologies of the future here at home.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That is what I want to do.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: This administration may say they have a plan, but the truth is they have not even released all the money, the paltry sum of money, that Congress appropriated.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I want to take very dollar by which we reduce defense and reinvest it in technologies for the 21st century--in new transportation, in communication, in environmental clean-up technologies.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let's put the American people to work, and let's build the kind of high-tech, high-wage, high-growth economy that the American people deserve.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Step one, the American people send me up there, the day after election, I'll get with congressional--we won't even wait till inauguration, and I'll ask the president to help me and I'll ask his staff to help me.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And we will start putting together teams to put together--to take all the plans that exist and do something with them.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: There are great plans lying all over Washington nobody ever executes.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: It's like having a blueprint for a house you never built.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You don't have anywhere to sleep.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now our challenge is to take these things, do something with them.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Step one, we want to put America back to work, clean up the small business problem, have one task force at work on that.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The second, you've got your big companies that are in trouble, including the defense industries--have another one on that.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Have a 3rd task force on new industries of the future to make sure we nail those for our country and they don't wind up in Europe and Asia.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Convert from 19th to 21st century capitalism.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: See, we have an adversarial relationship between government and business.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Our international competitors that are cleaning our plate have an intelligent relationship between government and business, and a supportive relationship.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Then have another task force on crime because, next to jobs, our people are concerned about their safety.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Health care, schools--one on the debt and deficit.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And finally in that 90- day period before the inauguration, put together the framework for the town hall and give the American people a Christmas present.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Show them by Christmas the first cut at these plans.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: By the time Congress comes into session to go to work, have those plans ready to go in front of Congress.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Then get off to a flying start in '93 to execute these plans.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, there are people in this room and people on this stage who've been in meetings when I would sit there and say, "Is this the one we're going to talk about or do something about?"
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now, put together your plans by Christmas, be ready to go when Congress goes, nail these things.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Small business--you've got to have capital, you've got to credit, and many of them need mentors or coaches.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And we can create more jobs there in a hurry than any other place.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: This country desperately needs a jobs program, and my first priority would be to pass a jobs program, to introduce it on the first day I was inaugurated.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I would meet with the leaders of the Congress, with all the newly elected members of the Congress and as many others with whom I could meet between the time of the election and the inauguration, and we would present a jobs program.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Then we would present a plan to control health care costs and phase in health care coverage for all Americans.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Until we control health care costs, we're not going to control the deficit.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It is the number one culprit.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I live in a state where manufacturing job growth has far outpaced the nation in the last few years, where we have created more private sector jobs since Mr. Bush has been president than have been created in the entire rest of the country, where Mr. Bush's labor secretary said job growth has been enormous.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've done it in Arkansas.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Give me a chance to create these kind of jobs in America.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've got the plan announced for what we can do for small business.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I've already put forward things that'll get this country working fast, some of which have been echoed here tonight--investment tax allowance, capital gains reduction, more on research and development, tax credit for first-time home buyers.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: What I'm going to do is say to Jim Baker when this campaign is over, all right, let's sit down now, you do in domestic affairs what you've done in foreign affairs, be kind of the economic coordinator of all the domestic side of the House, and that includes all the economic side, all the training side, and bring this program together.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We're going to have a new Congress, and we're going to say to them, you've listened to the voters the way we have.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Nobody wants gridlock anymore, and so let's get the program through.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I believe it'll work because, as Ross said, we got the plans.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The plans are all over Washington.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I've put ours together in something called the Agenda for American Renewal, and it makes sense, it's sensible, it creates jobs, it gets to the base of the kind of jobs we need.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so I'll just be asking for support to get that put into effect.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But frankly, I don't think that's the problem today.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have low interest rates today.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: At least we have low interest rates that the Fed can control.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Our long-term interest rates are still pretty high because of our deficit and because of our economic performance.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And there was a terrible reaction internationally to Mr. Bush saying he was going to give us 4 more years of trickle-down economics--another across-the- board tax cut and most of it going to the wealthy, with no real guarantee of investment.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But I think the important thing--the important thing-- is to use the powers the president does have on the assumption that, given the condition of this economy, we're going to keep interest rates down if we have the discipline to increase investment and reduce the debt at the same time.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think the American people are ready for action.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think Congress is hungry for someone who will work with them instead of manipulate them.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Someone who will not veto a bill that has an investment tax credit, middle class tax relief, research and development tax credits as Mr. Bush has done.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Give me a chance to do that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I don't have to worry in the near term about the Federal Reserve.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Their policies so far, it seems to me, are pretty sound.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: There is a separation there.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I've had some arguments with him about the speed in which we might have lowered interest rates, but Governor Clinton, he talks about the reaction to the markets.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: There was a momentary fear that he might win and that the markets went phwee, down like that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So I don't think we can judge on, the stock market has been strong.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: It's been very strong since I've been president.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And they recognize we got great difficulties, but they're also much more optimistic than the pessimists we have up here tonight.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I'm going to keep on vetoing them, because I don't think we're taxed too little.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think the government's spending too much.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So Governor Clinton can label it tax for the rich or anything he wants.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I'm going to protect the working man by continuing to veto, and to threaten to veto until we get this new Congress, and then we're going to move forward on our plan.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve got to protect them.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Keep the Federal Reserve independent, but let's live in a world of reality.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We live in a global economy, not a national economy.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: These interest rates we have now don't make any sense.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We have a four trillion dollar debt, and only in America would you finance seventy percent of it five years or less.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So seventy percent of our debt is five years or less.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We have a four percent gap between what we pay for treasuries, and what Germany pays for one to five year treasuries.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: That gap is going to close, because the Arabs, the Japanese and folks in this country are going to start buying German treasuries because they can get more money.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Every time our interest rates go up one percent, that adds 28 billion dollars to the deficit or to the debt.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Whichever place you put it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We are sitting on a ticking time bomb folks, because we have totally mismanaged our country, and we had better get it back under control.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Just think in your own business, if you had all of your long term problems financed short term.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You'd go broke in a hurry.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Again, if you're not rich, you're not a superpower.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: So we have two that I'd put as number one.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I have number 1 and 1A.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: One is we've got to have the money to be able to pay for defense, and we've got to manufacture here.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Believe it or not folks, you can't ship it all overseas, you've got to make it here.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And you can't convert from potato chips to airplanes in an emergency.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: See, Willow Run could be converted from cars to airplanes in World War II because it was here.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We've got to make things here.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You can't ship them overseas anymore.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I hope we can talk more about that.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We've got to help Russia succeed in its revolution and all of its republics.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: When we think of Russia, remember we're thinking of many countries, now.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We've got to help them.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Third, we've got all kinds of agreements on paper, and some that are being executed on getting rid of nuclear warheads.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Russia and its republics are out of control or at best in weak control right now.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: It's a very unstable situation.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: You've got every rich Middle Eastern country over there trying to buy nuclear weapons.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And that will lead to another five star migraine headache down the road.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We really need to nail down the big intercontinental ballistic missiles, the ones that can hit us from Russia.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And we've focused on the tactical.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We've made real progress there.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We've got some agreement on the nuclear, but we don't have those things put away yet.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Number two, we've got to take care of this missile situation and try to get the nuclear war behind us and give this thing very high priority.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And number three, we need to help and support Russia and the republics in every possible way to become democratic capitalistic societies, and not just sit back and let those countries continue in turmoil.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Because they could go back worse than things used to be.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And believe me there are a lot of old boys in the K.G.B.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: and the military that liked it better the way it used to be.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: In order to keep America the strongest nation in the world, we need some continuity and some change.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: There are three fundamental challenges.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: First of all, the world is still a dangerous and uncertain place.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We need a new military and a new national security policy equal to the challenges of a post cold war era, a smaller permanent military force, but one that is more mobile, well trained with high technology equipment.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We need to continue the negotiations to reduce the nuclear arsenals in the Soviet Union, the former Soviet Union, and the United States.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We need to stop this proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Second, we have to face that in this world, economic security is a whole lot of national security.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Our dollar's at an all time low against some foreign currencies.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We're weak in the world.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We must rebuild America's strength at home.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And finally, we ought to be promoting the democratic impulses around the world.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They don't go to war with each other.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They're reliable friends in the future.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: National security, economic strength, democracy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, we still are the envy of the world in terms of our military.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: There's no question about that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We're the envy of the world in terms of our economy, despite the difficulties we're having.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: There's no question about that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Our exports are dramatically up.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I might say to Mr. Perot, I can understand why you might have missed it, because there's so much fascination with trivia, but I worked out a deal with Boris Yeltsin to eliminate, get rid of entirely, the most destabilizing weapons of all, the SS-18, the intercontinental ballistic missile.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I mean, that's been done.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And thank God, it has, because the parents of these young people around here go to bed at night without the same fear of nuclear war.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And so, we've got a good military.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: the question, to sort of get a new military, get the best in the world, we got it, and theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re keeping the peace, and they're respected around the world.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we're more respected because of the way we have conducted ourselves.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We didn't listen to the nuclear freeze crowd.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We said, "Peace through strength," and it worked and the cold war is over.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But we're so, turned so inward we don't understand the global picture.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we are helping democracy, Ross.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The Freedom Support Act is something I got through the Congress, and it's a very good thing, because it does exactly what you say, and I think you agree with that, to help Russian democracy.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we're going to keep on doing that.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I think our relationships with China are important and I don't want to isolate China, but I think it is a mistake for us to do what this Administration did when all those kids went out there carrying the Statue of Liberty in Tiananmen Square.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They rewarded him by opening negotiations with Iran to transfer nuclear technology.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That was their response to that sort of action.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now that the voices in the Congress and throughout the country have insisted that we do something about China, look at what has happened.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: China has finally agreed to stop sending us products made with prison labor.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Not because we coddled them, but because the Administration was pushed into doing something about it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The second biggest surplus next to Japan.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I would be firm.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I would say if you want to continue as Most Favored Nation status for your government owned industries as well as your private ones, observe human rights in the future.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Recognize the legitimacy of those kids that were carrying the Statue of Liberty.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And over the long run they will be more reliable partners.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, the Administration was the first major country to stand up to the abuse in Tiananmen Square.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We are the one that worked out the prison labor deal.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We are the ones that lowered the barrier to products with Carla Hill's negotiation.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I am the one that said let's keep the M.F.N.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: because you see China moving towards a free market economy.
Speaker: George Bush

Speaker: George Bush

Text: They are making some progress, not enough for us.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We were the first ones to put sanctions on.

Text: But keep in mind we are spending 30% more on health care than any country in the world, any country, and yet we have 35 million people uninsured, we have no preventing and primary care.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I say if Germany can cover everybody and keep costs under inflation, if Hawaii can cover 98% of their people at lower health care costs than the rest of us, if Rochester, New York, can do it with two-thirds of the cost of the rest of it, America can do it, too.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'm tired of being told we can't.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, I don't have time in 30 seconds, or whatever -- a minute -- to talk about our health care reform plan.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The Oregon plan made some good sense, but it's easy to dismiss the concerns of the disabled.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: As president I have to be sure that those waivers, which we're approving all over the place, are covered under the law.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Maybe we can work it out.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: But the Americans with Disabilities Act, speaking about sound and sensible civil rights legislation, was the most foremost piece of legislation passed in modern times, and so we do have something more than a technical problem.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Governor Clinton clicked off the things -- he's going to take on insurance companies and bureaucracies.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: He failed to take on somebody else -- the malpractice suit people, those that bring these lawsuits against -- these frivolous trial lawyers' lawsuits that are running the costs of medical care up 25 to 50 billion.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And he refuses to put anything, controls, on these crazy lawsuits.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: If you want to help somebody, don't run the costs up by making doctors have to have 5 or 6 tests where one would do for fear of being sued, or have somebody along the highway not stop to pick up a guy and help him because he's afraid a trial lawyer will come along and sue him.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We're suing each other too much and caring for each other too little.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: So we don't have the best.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Pretty simple, folks -- if you're paying more and you don't have the best, if all else fails go copy the people who have the best who spend less, right?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Well, we can do better than that.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Again, we've got plans lying all over the place in Washington.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Now I'm back to square one.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: If you want to stop talking about it and do it, then I'll be glad to go up there and we'll get it done.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: But if you just want to keep the music going, just stay traditional this next time around, and 4 years from now you'll have everybody blaming everybody else for a bad health care system.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Talk is cheap; words are plentiful, deeds are precious.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Let's get on with it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Well, it's been a privilege to be able to talk to the American people tonight.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I make no bones about it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I love the principle it's founded on.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I love the people here.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I don't like to see the country's principles violated.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: The people in Washington are good people.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We just have a bad system.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We've got to change the system.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We've got to put our house in order.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: When you go to bed tonight, look at your children.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Isn't it time to stop creating images?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Isn't it time to do it?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Aren't you sick of being treated like an unprogrammed robot?
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: Every 4 years, they send you all kinds of messages to tell you how to vote and then go back to business as usual.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They told you at the tax and budget summit that if you agreed to a tax increase, we could balance the budget.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They didn't tell you that that same year they increased spending $1.83 for every dollar we increased taxes.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: That's Washington in a nutshell right there.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: In the final analysis, I'm doing this for your children when you look at them tonight.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: There's another group that I feel very close to, and these at the men and women who fought on the battlefield, the children -- the families -- of the ones who died and the people who left parts of their bodies over there.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'd never ask you to do anything for me, but I owe you this, and I'm doing it for you.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And I can't tell you what it means to me at these rallies when I see you and you come up and the look in your eyes -- and I know how you feel and you know how I feel.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And then I think of the older people who are retired.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They grew up in the Depression.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: They fought and won World War II.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: We owe you a debt we can never repay you.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: And the greatest repayment I can ever give is to recreate the American dream for your children and grandchildren.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'll give you everything I have, if you want me to do it.
Speaker: Ross Perot

Text: I'd like to thank the people of St. Louis and Washington University, the Presidential Debate Commission and all those who made this night possible.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Most of all, I'd like to thank all of you who have touched me in some way over this last year, all the thousands of you whom I've seen.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'd like to thank the hundreds of executives who came to Chicago, a third of them Republicans, who said they wanted to change.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'd like to thank the people who've started with Mr. Perot who've come on to help our campaign.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'd like to thank all the folks around America that no one ever knows about -- the woman that was holding the AIDS baby she adopted in Cedar Rapids, Iowa who asked me to do something more for adoption; the woman who stopped along the road in Wisconsin and wept because her husband had lost his job after 27 years; all the people who are having a tough time and the people who are winning but who know how desperately we need to change.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: This debate tonight has made crystal clear a challenge that is as old as America -- the choice between hope and fear, change or more of the same, the courage to move into a new tomorrow or to listen to the crowd who says things could be worse.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Mr. Bush has said some very compelling things tonight that don't quite square with the record.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I offer a new direction.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Invest in American jobs, American education, control health care costs, bring this country together again.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I want the future of this country to be as bright and brilliant as its past, and it can be if we have the courage to change.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me tell you a little what it's like to be president.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: In the Oval Office, you can't predict what kind of crisis is going to come up.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You have to make tough calls.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You can't be on one hand this way and one hand another.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: You can't take different positions on these difficult issues.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And then you need a philosophical -- I'd call it a philosophical underpinning.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Mine for foreign affairs is democracy and freedom, and look at the dramatic changes around the world.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The Cold War is over.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The Soviet Union is no more and we're working with a democratic country.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, the Baltics are free.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Take a look at the Middle East.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We had to stand up against a tyrant.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: The US came together as we haven't in many, many years.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we kicked this man out of Kuwait.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And in the process, as a result of that will and that decision and that toughness, we now have ancient enemies talking peace in the Middle East.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Nobody would have dreamed it possible.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And I think the biggest dividend of making these tough calls is the fact that we are less afraid of nuclear war.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Every parent out there has much less worry that their kids are going to be faced with nuclear holocaust.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: What we need to do is empower people.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We need to invest and save.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We need to do better in education.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We need to do better in job retraining.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: We need to expand our exports, and they're going very, very well, indeed.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: And we need to strengthen the American family.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I hope as president that I've earned your trust.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I've admitted it when I make a mistake, but then I go on and help, try to solve the problems.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I hope I've earned your trust because a lot of being president is about trust and character.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: Thank you very, very much.
Speaker: George Bush

Text: I believe that the question oversimplifies the difficulties of what we must do in Central America.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Our objectives ought to be to strengthen the democracies, to stop Communist and other extremist influences, and stabilize the community in that area.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: To do that we need a three-pronged attack: one is military assistance to our friends who are being pressured; secondly, a strong and sophisticated economic aid program and human rights program that offers a better life and a sharper alternative to the alternative offered by the totalitarians who oppose us; and finally, a strong diplomatic effort that pursues the possibilities of peace in the area.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That's one of the big disagreements that we have with the President -- that they have not pursued the diplomatic opportunities either within El Salvador or as between the countries and have lost time during which we might have been able to achieve a peace
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: This brings up the whole question of what Presidential leadership is all about.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I think the lesson in Central America, this recent embarrassment in Nicaragua where we are giving instructions for hired assassins, hiring criminals, and the rest -- all of this has strengthened our opponents.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: A President must not only assure that we're tough, but we must also be wise and smart in the exercise of that power.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We saw the same thing in Lebanon, where we spent a good deal of America's assets.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But because the leadership of this government did not pursue wise policies, we have been humiliated, and our opponents are stronger.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The bottom line of national strength is that the President must be in command, he must lead.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And when a President doesn't know that submarine missiles are recallable, says that 70 percent of our strategic forces are conventional, discovers 3 years into his administration that our arms control efforts have failed because he didn't know that most Soviet missiles were on land -- these are things a President must know to command.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: A President is called the Commander in Chief.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And he's called that because he's supposed to be in charge of the facts and run our government and strengthen our nation.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We absolutely must, which is why I responded to your first question the way I did.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: You must understand the region; you must understand the politics in the area; you must provide a strong alternative; and you must show strength -- and all at the same time.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That's why I object to the covert action in Nicaragua.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That's a classic example of a strategy that's embarrassed us, strengthened our opposition, and undermined the moral authority of our people and our country in the region.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We've seen in the Nicaraguan example a policy that has actually hurt us, strengthened our opposition, and undermined the moral authority of our country in that region.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: No, but I'm glad you asked that question, because I know it's on many peoples' minds.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I have ordered an investigation.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I know that the CIA is already going forward with one.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have a gentleman down in Nicaragua who is on contract to the CIA, advising -- supposedly on military tactics -- the contras.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And he drew up this manual.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It was turned over to the agency head of the CIA in Nicaragua to be printed.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And a number of pages were excised by that agency head there, the man in charge, and he sent it on up here to CIA, where more pages were excised before it was printed.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But some way or other, there were 12 of the original copies that got out down there and were not submitted for this printing process by the CIA.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, those are the details as we have them.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And as soon as we have an investigation and find out where any blame lies for the few that did not get excised or changed, we certainly are going to do something about that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We'll take the proper action at the proper time.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I was very interested to hear about Central America and our process down there, and I thought for a moment that instead of a debate I was going to find Mr. Mondale in complete agreement with what we're doing, because the plan that he has outlined is the one we've been following for quite some time, including diplomatic processes throughout Central America and working closely with the Contadora group.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So, I can only tell you about the manual -- that we're not in the habit of assigning guilt before there has been proper evidence produced and proof of that guilt.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But if guilt is established, whoever is guilty we will treat with that situation then, and they will be removed.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I'm afraid I misspoke when I said a CIA head in Nicaragua.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: There's not someone there directing all of this activity.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: There are, as you know, CIA men stationed in other countries in the world and, certainly, in Central America.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And so it was a man down there in that area that this was delivered to, and he recognized that what was in that manual was in direct contravention of my own Executive order, in December of 1981, that we would have nothing to do with regard to political assassinations.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: What is a President charged with doing when he takes his oath of office?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: He raises his right hand and takes an oath of office to take care to faithfully execute the laws of the land.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: A President can't know everything, but a President has to know those things that are essential to his leadership and the enforcement of our laws.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: This manual -- several thousands of which were produced -- was distributed, ordering political assassinations, hiring of criminals, and other forms of terrorism.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Some of it was excised, but the part dealing with political terrorism was continued.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: How can something this serious occur in an administration and have a President of the United States in a situation like this say he didn't know?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: A President must know these things.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I don't know which is worse, not knowing or knowing and not stopping it.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And what about the mining of the harbors in Nicaragua which violated international law?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: This has hurt this country, and a President's supposed to command.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I have so many things there to respond to, I'm going to pick out something you said earlier.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: You've been all over the country repeating something that, I will admit, the press has also been repeating -- that I believed that nuclear missiles could be fired and then called back.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I never, ever conceived of such a thing.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I never said any such thing.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: In a discussion of our strategic arms negotiations, I said that submarines carrying missiles and airplanes carrying missiles were more conventional-type weapons, not as destabilizing as the land-based missiles, and that they were also weapons that -- or carriers -- that if they were sent out and there was a change, you could call them back before they had launched their missiles.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But I hope that from here on you will no longer be saying that particular thing, which is absolutely false.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: How anyone could think that any sane person would believe you could call back a nuclear missile, I think is as ridiculous as the whole concept has been.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So, thank you for giving me a chance to straighten the record.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I'm sure that you appreciate that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I have said on a number of occasions exactly what I believe about the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I retract nothing that I have said.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I believe that many of the things they have done are evil in any concept of morality that we have.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But I also recognize that as the two great superpowers in the world, we have to live with each other.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I told Mr. Gromyko we don't like their system.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And we're not going to change their system, and they sure better not try to change ours.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But between us, we can either destroy the world or we can save it.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I suggested that, certainly, it was to their common interest, along with ours, to avoid a conflict and to attempt to save the world and remove the nuclear weapons.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I think that perhaps we established a little better understanding.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think that in dealing with the Soviet Union one has to be realistic.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I know that Mr. Mondale, in the past, has made statements as if they were just people like ourselves, and if we were kind and good and did something nice, they would respond accordingly.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And the result was unilateral disarmament.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We canceled the B - 1 under the previous administration.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The Soviet Union has been engaged in the biggest military buildup in the history of man at the same time that we tried the policy of unilateral disarmament, of weakness, if you will.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And now we are putting up a defense of our own.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I've made it very plain to them, we seek no superiority.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We simply are going to provide a deterrent so that it will be too costly for them if they are nursing any ideas of aggression against us.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, they claim they're not.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I made it plain to them, we're not.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: There's been no change in my attitude at all.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I just thought when I came into office it was time that there was some realistic talk to and about the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And we did get their attention.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Ah, well, now you've added a hypothetical there at the end, Mr. Kalb, about where we would send troops in to fight.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I am not going to make the decision as to what the tactics could be, but obviously there are a number of areas in the world that are of importance to us.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: One is the Middle East, and that is of interest to the whole Western World and the industrialized nations, because of the great supply of energy upon which so many depend there.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Our neighbors here in America are vital to us.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We're working right now in trying to be of help in southern Africa with regard to the independence of Namibia and the removal of the Cuban surrogates, the thousands of them, from Angola.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So, I can say there are a great many interests.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I believe that we have a great interest in the Pacific Basin.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: That is where I think the future of the world lies.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But I am not going to pick out one and, in advance, hypothetically say, "Oh, yes, we would send troops there.''
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I don't want to send troops any place.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Because the only type of agreements to reach with the Soviet Union are the types that are specifically defined, so we know exactly what they must do; subject to full verification, which means we know every day whether they're living up to it; and followups, wherever we find suggestions that they're violating it; and the strongest possible terms.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I have no illusions about the Soviet Union leadership or the nature of that state.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: They are a tough and a ruthless adversary, and we must be prepared to meet that challenge, and I would.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Where I part with the President is that despite all of those differences we must, as past Presidents before this one have done, meet on the common ground of survival.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And that's where the President has opposed practically every arms control agreement, by every President, of both political parties, since the bomb went off.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And he now completes this term with no progress toward arms control at all, but with a very dangerous arms race underway instead.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: There are now over 2,000 more warheads pointed at us today than there were when he was sworn in, and that does not strengthen us.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We must be very, very realistic in the nature of that leadership, but we must grind away and talk to find ways of reducing these differences, particularly where arms races are concerned and other dangerous exercises of Soviet power.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: There will be no unilateral disarmament under my administration.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I will keep this nation strong.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I understand exactly what the Soviets are up to, but that, too, is a part of national strength.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: To do that, a President must know what is essential to command and to leadership and to strength.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And that's where the President's failure to master, in my opinion, the essential elements of arms control has cost us dearly.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: He's 3 years into this administration.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: He said he just discovered that most Soviet missiles are on land, and that's why his proposal didn't work.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I invite the American people tomorrow -- because I will issue the statement quoting President Reagan -- he said exactly what I said he said.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: He said that these missiles were less dangerous than ballistic missiles because you could fire them, and you could recall them if you decided there'd been a miscalculation.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: A President must know those things.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I think the essential strategy of the United States ought not accept any Soviet control over Eastern Europe.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We ought to deal with each of these countries separately.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We ought to pursue strategies with each of them, economic and the rest, that help them pull away from their dependence upon the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Where the Soviet Union has acted irresponsibly, as they have in many of those countries, especially, recently, in Poland, I believe we ought to insist that Western credits extended to the Soviet Union bear the market rate.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Make the Soviets pay for their irresponsibility.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That is a very important objective -- to make certain that we continue to look forward to progress toward greater independence by these nations and work with each of them separately.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I'm not going to continue trying to respond to these repetitions of the falsehoods that have already been stated here.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But with regard to whether Mr. Mondale would be strong, as he said he would be, I know that he has a commercial out where he's appearing on the deck of the Nimitz and watching the F - 14's take off.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And that's an image of strength -- except that if he had had his way when the Nimitz was being planned, he would have been deep in the water out there because there wouldn't have been any Nimitz to stand on -- he was against it.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: He was against the F - 14 fighter, he was against the M - 1 tank, he was against the B - 1 bomber, he wanted to cut the salary of all of the military, he wanted to bring home half of the American forces in Europe.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And he has a record of weakness with regard to our national defense that is second to none.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Indeed, he was on that side virtually throughout all his years in the Senate.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And he opposed even President Carter, when toward the end of his term President Carter wanted to increase the defense budget.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Mr. President, I accept your commitment to peace, but I want you to accept my commitment to a strong national defense.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: [Applause] I propose a budget -- I have proposed a budget which would increase our nation's strength, in real terms, by double that of the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I'll tell you where we disagree.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It is true over 10 years ago I voted to delay production of the F - 14, and I'll tell you why.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The plane wasn't flying the way it was supposed to be; it was a waste of money.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Your definition of national strength is to throw money at the Defense Department.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: My definition of national strength is to make certain that a dollar spent buys us a dollar's worth of defense.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: There's a big difference between the two of us.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: A President must manage that budget.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I will keep us strong, but you'll not do that unless you command that budget and make certain we get the strength that we need.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: You pay $500 for a $5 hammer, you're not buying strength.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: As a matter of fact, I believe every one of those standards is essential to the exercise of power by this country.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And we can see that in both Lebanon and in Central America.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: In Lebanon, this President exercised American power, all right, but the management of it was such that our marines were killed, we had to leave in humiliation, the Soviet Union became stronger, terrorists became emboldened.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And it was because they did not think through how power should be exercised, did not have the American public with them on a plan that worked, that we ended up the way we did.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Similarly, in Central America: What we're doing in Nicaragua with this covert war -- which the Congress, including many Republicans, have tried to stop -- is finally end up with a public definition of American power that hurts us, where we get associated with political assassins and the rest.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We have to decline, for the first time in modern history, jurisdiction in the World Court because they'll find us guilty of illegal actions.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And our enemies are strengthened from all of this.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We need to be strong, we need to be prepared to use that strength, but we must understand that we are a democracy.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We are a government by the people, and when we move, it should be for very severe and extreme reasons that serve our national interests and end up with a stronger country behind us.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It is only in that way that we can persevere.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: What I'm referring to there is the mutual self-defense provisions that exist in the Inter-American treaty, the so-called Rio Pact, that permits the nations, our friends in that region, to combine to take steps -- diplomatic and otherwise -- to prevent Nicaragua, when she acts irresponsibly in asserting power in other parts outside of her border, to take those steps, whatever they might be, to stop it.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The Nicaraguans must know that it is the policy of our government that that leadership must stay behind the boundaries of their nation, not interfere in other nations.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And by working with all of the nations in the region -- unlike the policies of this administration and unlike the President said, they have not supported negotiations in that region -- we will be much stronger, because we'll have the moral authority that goes with those efforts.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: No, Morton, I don't agree to all of those things.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: First of all, when we and our allies -- the Italians, the French, and the United Kingdom -- went into Lebanon, we went in there at the request of what was left of the Lebanese Government to be a stabilizing force while they tried to establish a government.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But the first -- pardon me -- the first time we went in, we went in at their request because the war was going on right in Beirut between Israel and the PLO terrorists.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Israel could not be blamed for that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Those terrorists had been violating their northern border consistently, and Israel chased them all the way to there.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Then we went in with the multinational force to help remove, and did remove, more than 13,000 of those terrorists from Lebanon.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And then the Government of Lebanon asked us back in as a stabilizing force while they established a government and sought to get the foreign forces all the way out of Lebanon and that they could then take care of their own borders.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We were there for the better part of a year.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Our position happened to be at the airport.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Oh, there were occasional snipings and sometimes some artillery fire, but we did not engage in conflict that was out of line with our mission.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I will never send troops anywhere on a mission of that kind without telling them that if somebody shoots at them, they can darn well shoot back.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And this is what we did.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We never initiated any kind of action; we defended ourselves there.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But we were succeeding to the point that the Lebanese Government had been organized -- if you will remember, there were the meetings in Geneva in which they began to meet with the hostile factional forces and try to put together some kind of a peace plan.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We were succeeding, and that was why the terrorist acts began.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: There are forces there -- and that includes Syria, in my mind -- who don't want us to succeed, who don't want that kind of a peace with a dominant Lebanon, dominant over its own territory.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And so, the terrorist acts began and led to the one great tragedy when they were killed in that suicide bombing of the building.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Then the multilateral force withdrew for only one reason: We withdrew because we were no longer able to carry out the mission for which we had been sent in.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But we went in in the interest of peace and to keep Israel and Syria from getting into the sixth war between them.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I have no apologies for our going on a peace mission.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan
