Text: I think there's a great difference between the Government of Iran threatening our diplomatic personnel, and there is a government that you can see and can put your hand on.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: In the terrorist situation, there are terrorist factions all over.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: In a recent 30-day period, 37 terrorist acts in 20 countries have been committed.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The most recent has been the one in Brighton.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: In dealing with terrorists, yes, we want to retaliate, but only if we can put our finger on the people responsible and not endanger the lives of innocent civilians there in the various communities and in the city of Beirut where these terrorists are operating.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I have just signed legislation to add to our ability to deal, along with our allies, with this terrorist problem.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And it's going to take all the nations together, just as when we banded together we pretty much resolved the whole problem of skyjackings sometime ago.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Well, the red light went on.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I could have gone on forever.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Groucho Marx said, "Who do you believe?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: -- me, or your own eyes?''
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And what we have in Lebanon is something that the American people have seen.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The Joint Chiefs urged the President not to put our troops in that barracks because they were indefensible.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: They went to him 5 days before they were killed and said, "Please, take them out of there.''
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The Secretary of State admitted that this morning.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: He did not do so.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The report following the explosion of the barracks disclosed that we had not taken any of the steps that we should have taken.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That was the second time.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Then the Embassy was blown up a few weeks ago, and once again none of the steps that should have been taken were taken.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And we were warned 5 days before that explosives were on their way, and they weren't taken.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The terrorists have won each time.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The President told the terrorists he was going to retaliate.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And the bottom line is that the United States left in humiliation, and our enemies are stronger.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: First of all, Mr. Mondale should know that the President of the United States did not order the marines into that barracks.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: That was a command decision made by the commanders on the spot and based with what they thought was best for the men there.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: On the other things that you've just said about the terrorists, I'm tempted to ask you what you would do.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: These are unidentified people, and after the bomb goes off, they're blown to bits because they are suicidal individuals who think they're going to go to paradise if they perpetrate such an act and lose their life in doing it.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We are going to, as I say, we're busy trying to find the centers where these operations stem from, and retaliation will be taken.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But we're not going to simply kill some people to say, "Oh, look, we got even.''
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We want to know when we retaliate that we're retaliating with those who are responsible for the terrorist acts.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And terrorist acts are such that our own United States Capitol in Washington has been bombed twice.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Not at all, Mr. Trewhitt, and I want you to know that also I will not make age an issue of this campaign.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I am not going to exploit, for political purposes, my opponent's youth and inexperience.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: [Laughter and applause] If I still have time, I might add, Mr. Trewhitt, I might add that it was Seneca or it was Cicero, I don't know which, that said, "If it was not for the elders correcting the mistakes of the young, there would be no state.''
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Mr. President, I'd like to head for the fence and try to catch that one before it goes over, but I'll go on to another question.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: You and Mr. Mondale have already disagreed about what you had to say about recalling submarine-launched missiles.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: There's another, a similar issue out there that relates to your -- it is said, at least, that you were unaware that the Soviet retaliatory power was based on land-based missiles.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Secondly, if it is correct, have you informed yourself in the meantime?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And third, is it even necessary for the President to be so intimately involved in strategic details?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Yes, this had to do with our disarmament talks.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And the whole controversy about land missiles came up because we thought that the strategic nuclear weapons, the most destabilizing are the land-based.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: You put your thumb on a button and somebody blows up 20 minutes later.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So, we thought that it would be simpler to negotiate first with those.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And then we made it plain, a second phase, take up the submarine-launched or the airborne missiles.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The Soviet Union, to our surprise -- and not just mine -- made it plain when we brought this up that they placed, they thought, a greater reliance on the land-based missiles and, therefore, they wanted to take up all three.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We said, "All right, if that's what you want to do.''
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But it was a surprise to us, because they outnumbered us 64 to 36 in submarines and 20 percent more bombers capable of carrying nuclear missiles than we had.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So, why should we believe that they had placed that much more reliance on land-based?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But even after we gave in and said, "All right, let's discuss it all,'' they walked away from the table.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Mr. Mondale, I'm going to hang in there.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Should the President's age and stamina be an issue in the political campaign?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I have not made it an issue, nor should it be.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: What's at issue here is the President's application of his authority to understand what a President must know to lead this nation, secure our defense, and make the decisions and the judgments that are necessary.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: A minute ago the President quoted Cicero, I believe.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I want to quote somebody a little closer to home, Harry Truman.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: He said, "The buck stops here.''
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We just heard the President's answer for the problems at the barracks in Lebanon, where 241 marines were killed.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: First, the Joint Chiefs of Staff went to the President, said, "Don't put those troops there.''
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And then 5 days before the troops were killed, they went back to the President, through the Secretary of Defense, and said, "Please, Mr. President, take those troops out of there because we can't defend them.''
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And we know what happened.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: After that, once again, our Embassy was exploded.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: This is the fourth time this has happened -- an identical attack, in the same region, despite warnings -- even public warnings -- from the terrorists.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Now, on arms control, we're completing 4 years.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: This is the first administration since the bomb went off that made no progress.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We have an arms race underway instead.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: A President has to lead his government or it won't be done.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Different people with different views fight with each other.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: For 31/2 years, this administration avoided arms control, resisted tabling arms control proposals that had any hope of agreeing, rebuked their negotiator in 1981 when he came close to an agreement, at least in principle, on medium-range weapons.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And we have this arms race underway.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And a recent book that just came out by perhaps the Nation's most respected author in this field, Strobe Talbott, called "Deadly Gambits,'' concludes that this President has failed to master the essential details needed to command and lead us, both in terms of security and terms of arms control.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That's why they call the President the Commander in Chief.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But it takes more than that.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: You must be tough and smart.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: This question of leadership keeps arising in different forms in this discussion already.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And the President, Mr. Mondale, has called you whining and vacillating, among the more charitable phrases -- weak, I believe.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It is a question of leadership.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And he has made the point that you have not repudiated some of the semidiplomatic activity of the Reverend Jackson, particularly in Central America.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Did you approve of his diplomatic activity?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And are you prepared to repudiate him now?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I read his statement the other day.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I don't admire Fidel Castro at all.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Che Guevara was a contemptible figure in civilization's history.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I know the Cuban state as a police state, and all my life I've worked in a way that demonstrates that.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But Jesse Jackson is an independent person.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And let's talk about people we do control.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: In the last debate,1 (FOOTNOTE) the Vice President of the United States said that I said the marines had died shamefully and died in shame in Lebanon.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I demanded an apology from Vice President Bush because I had, instead, honored these young men, grieved for their families, and think they were wonderful Americans that honored us all.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: What does the President have to say about taking responsibility for a Vice President who won't apologize for something like that?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Mondale was referring to an earlier debate between George Bush and Geraldine Ferarro, the Vice-Presidential candidates.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I know it'll come as a surprise to Mr. Mondale, but I am in charge.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And, as a matter of fact, we haven't avoided arms control talks with the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Very early in my administration I proposed -- and I think something that had never been proposed by any previous administration -- I proposed a total elimination of intermediate-range missiles, where the Soviets had better than a 10 -- and still have -- better than a 10-to-1 advantage over the allies in Europe.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: When they protested that and suggested a smaller number, perhaps, I went along with that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The so-called negotiation that you said I walked out on was the so-called walk in the woods between one of our representatives and one of the Soviet Union, and it wasn't me that turned it down, the Soviet Union disavowed it.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: There are two distinguished authors on arms control in this country -- there are many others, but two that I want to cite tonight.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: One is Strobe Talbott in his classic book, "Deadly Gambits.''
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The other is John Neuhaus, who's one of the most distinguished arms control specialists in our country.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Both said that this administration turned down the "walk in the woods'' agreement first, and that would have been a perfect agreement from the standpoint of the United States in Europe and our security.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: When Mr. Nitze, a good negotiator, returned, he was rebuked, and his boss was fired.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: This is the kind of leadership that we've had in this administration on the most deadly issue of our times.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Now we have a runaway arms race.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: All they've got to show for 4 years in U.S.-Soviet relations is one meeting in the last weeks of an administration, and nothing before.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: They're tough negotiators, but all previous Presidents have made progress.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: This is a very serious problem in our country, and it has to be dealt with.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I object to that part of the Simpson-Mazzoli bill which I think is very unfair and would prove to be so.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That is the part that requires employers to determine the citizenship of an employee before they're hired.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I'm convinced that the result of this would be that people who are Hispanic, people who have different languages or speak with an accent, would find it difficult to be employed.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We've never had citizenship tests in our country before, and I don't think we should have a citizenship card today.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I do support the other aspects of the Simpson-Mazzoli bill that strengthen enforcement at the border, strengthen other ways of dealing with undocumented workers in this difficult area and dealing with the problem of settling people who have lived here for many, many years and do not have an established status.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I have further strongly recommended that this administration do something it has not done, and that is to strengthen enforcement at the border, strengthen the officials in this government that deal with undocumented workers, and to do so in a way that's responsible and within the Constitution of the United States.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We need an answer to this problem, but it must be an American answer that is consistent with justice and due process.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Everyone in this room, practically, here tonight, is an immigrant.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We came here loving this nation, serving it, and it has served all of our most bountiful dreams.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And one of those dreams is justice.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And we need a measure -- and I will support a measure -- that brings about those objectives but avoids that one aspect that I think is very serious.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The second part is to maintain and improve relations with our friends to the south.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We cannot solve this problem all on our own.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And that's why the failure of this administration to deal in an effective and a good-faith way with Mexico, with Costa Rica, with the other nations in trying to find a peaceful settlement to the dispute in Central America has undermined our capacity to effectively deal diplomatically in this area as well.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I think you're right that the polls show that the majority of Hispanics want that bill, so I'm not doing it for political reasons.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I'm doing it because all my life I've fought for a system of justice in this country, a system in which every American has a chance to achieve the fullness in life without discrimination.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: This bill imposes upon employers the responsibility of determining whether somebody who applies for a job is an American or not.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And just inevitably, they're going to be reluctant to hire Hispanics or people with a different accent.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: If I were dealing with politics here, the polls show the American people want this.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I am for reform in this area, for tough enforcement at the border, and for many other aspects of the Simpson-Mazzoli bill, but all my life I've fought for a fair nation.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And despite the politics of it, I stand where I stand, and I think I'm right, and before this fight is over we're going to come up with a better bill, a more effective bill that does not undermine the liberties of our people.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Georgie Anne, we, believe me, supported the Simpson-Mazzoli bill strongly -- and the bill that came out of the Senate.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: However, there were things added in in the House side that we felt made it less of a good bill; as a matter of fact, made it a bad bill.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And in conference -- we stayed with them in conference all the way to where even Senator Simpson did not want the bill in the manner in which it would come out of the conference committee.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: There were a number of things in there that weakened that bill.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I can't go into detail about them here.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But it is true our borders are out of control.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It is also true that this has been a situation on our borders back through a number of administrations.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I supported this bill.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I believe in the idea of amnesty for those who have put down roots and who have lived here even though sometime back they may have entered illegally.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: With regard to the employer sanctions, we must have that not only to ensure that we can identify the illegal aliens, but also, while some keep protesting about what it would do to employers, there is another employer that we shouldn't be so concerned about, and these are employers down through the years who have encouraged the illegal entry into this country because they then hire these individuals and hire them at starvation wages and with none of the benefits that we think are normal and natural for workers in our country, and the individuals can't complain because of their illegal status.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We don't think that those people should be allowed to continue operating free.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And this was why the provisions that we had in with regard to sanctions, and so forth -- and I'm going to do everything I can, and all of us in the administration are, to join in again when Congress is back at it to get an immigration bill that will give us, once again, control of our borders.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And with regard to friendship below the border and with the countries down there, yes, no administration that I know has established the relationship that we have with our Latin friends.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But as long as they have an economy that leaves so many people in dire poverty and unemployment, they are going to seek that employment across our borders.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And we work with those other countries.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: As a matter of fact, the population explosion, if you look at the actual figures, has been vastly exaggerated -- over exaggerated.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: As a matter of fact, there are some pretty scientific and solid figures about how much space there still is in the world and how many more people we can have.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It's almost like going back to the Malthusian theory, when even then they were saying that everyone would starve with the limited population they had then.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But the problem of population growth is one, here, with regard to our immigration.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And we have been the safety valve, whether we wanted to or not, with the illegal entry here, in Mexico, where their population is increasing and they don't have an economy that can absorb them and provide the jobs.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And this is what we're trying to work out, not only to protect our own borders but to have some kind of fairness and recognition of that problem.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: One of the biggest problems today is that the countries to our south are so desperately poor that these people who will almost lose their lives if they don't come north, come north despite all the risks.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And if we're going to find a permanent, fundamental answer to this, it goes to American economic and trade policies that permit these nations to have a chance to get on their own two feet and to get prosperity, so that they can have jobs for themselves and their people.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And that's why this enormous national debt, engineered by this administration, is harming these countries in fueling this immigration.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: These high interest rates -- real rates that have doubled under this administration -- have had the same effect on Mexico and so on, and the cost of repaying those debts is so enormous that it results in massive unemployment, hardship, and heartache.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And that drives our friends to the south up into our region, and we need to end those deficits as well.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Well, my rebuttal is I've heard the national debt blamed for a lot of things, but not for illegal immigration across our border -- [laughter] -- and it has nothing to do with it.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But with regard to these high interest rates, too, at least give us the recognition of the fact that when you left office, Mr. Mondale, they were 211/2 -- the prime rate.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It's now 121/4, and I predict it'll be coming down a little more shortly.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So, we're trying to undo some of the things that your administration did.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Mr. Kalb, I think what has been hailed as something I'm supposedly, as President, discussing as principle is the recall of just some philosophical discussions with people who are interested in the same things; and that is the prophecies down through the years, the biblical prophecies of what would portend the coming of Armageddon, and so forth, and the fact that a number of theologians for the last decade or more have believed that this was true, that the prophecies are coming together that portend that.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But no one knows whether Armageddon, those prophecies mean that Armageddon is a thousand years away or day after tomorrow.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: So, I have never seriously warned and said we must plan according to Armageddon.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, with regard to having to say whether we would try to survive in the event of a nuclear war, of course we would.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But let me also point out that to several parliaments around the world, in Europe and in Asia, I have made a statement to each one of them, and I'll repeat it here: A nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And that is why we are maintaining a deterrent and trying to achieve a deterrent capacity to where no one would believe that they could start such a war and escape with limited damage.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But the deterrent -- and that's what it is for -- is also what led me to propose what is now being called the Star Wars concept, but propose that we research to see if there isn't a defensive weapon that could defend against incoming missiles.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And if such a defense could be found, wouldn't it be far more humanitarian to say that now we can defend against a nuclear war by destroying missiles instead of slaughtering millions of people?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: What if we did -- and I hope we can; we're still researching -- what if we come up with a weapon that renders those missiles obsolete?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: There has never been a weapon invented in the history of man that has not led to a defensive, a counterweapon.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But suppose we came up with that?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, some people have said, "Ah, that would make war imminent, because they would think that we could launch a first strike because we could defend against the enemy.''
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But why not do what I have offered to do and asked the Soviet Union to do?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Say, "Look, here's what we can do.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We'll even give it to you.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, will you sit down with us and once and for all get rid, all of us, of these nuclear weapons and free mankind from that threat?''
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think that would be the greatest use of a defensive weapon.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: First of all, let me sharply disagree with the President on sharing the most advanced, the most dangerous, the most important technology in America with the Soviet Union.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We have had for many years, understandably, a system of restraints on high technology because the Soviets are behind us.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And any research or development along the Star Wars schemes would inevitably involve our most advanced computers, our most advanced engineering.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And the thought that we would share this with the Soviet Union is, in my opinion, a total non-STARTer.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I would not let the Soviet Union get their hands on it at all.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Now, what's wrong with Star Wars?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: There's nothing wrong with the theory of it.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: If we could develop a principle that would say both sides could fire all their missiles and no one would get hurt, I suppose it's a good idea.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But the fact of it is we're so far away from research that even comes close to that, that the Director of Engineering Research at the Defense Department said to get there we would have to solve eight problems, each of which are more difficult than the atomic bomb and the Manhattan project.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It would cost something like a trillion dollars to test and deploy weapons.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The second thing is this all assumes that the Soviets wouldn't respond in kind.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And that's been the tragic story of the arms race.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We have more at stake in space satellites than they do.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: If we could stop, right now, the testing and the deployment of these space weapons -- and the President's proposals go clear beyond research; if it was just research we wouldn't have any argument, because maybe someday, somebody will think of something -- but to commit this nation to a buildup of antisatellite and space weapons at this time, in their crude state, would bring about an arms race that's very dangerous indeed.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The most dangerous aspect of this proposal is, for the first time, we would delegate to computers the decision as to whether to start a war.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: There wouldn't be time for a President to decide; it would be decided by these remote computers.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It might be an oil fire, it might be a jet exhaust, the computer might decide it's a missile -- and off we go.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Why don't we stop this madness now and draw a line and keep the heavens free from war?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Every system that is verifiable should be placed on the table for negotiations for an agreement.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I would not agree to any negotiations or any agreement that involved conduct on the part of the Soviet Union that we couldn't verify every day.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I would not agree to any agreement in which the United States security interest was not fully recognized and supported.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That's why we say mutual and verifiable freezes.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Now, why do I support the freeze?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Because this ever-rising arms race madness makes both nations less secure.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It's more difficult to defend this nation.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It's putting a hair-trigger on nuclear war.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: This administration, by going into the Star Wars system, is going to add a dangerous new escalation.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We have to be tough on the Soviet Union, but I think the American people -- --
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: -- -- and the people of the Soviet Union want it to stop.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Yes, my rebuttal, once again, is that this invention that has just been created here of how I would go about rolling over for the Soviet Union -- no, Mr. Mondale, my idea would be with that defensive weapon that we would sit down with them and then say, "Now, are you willing to join us?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Here's what we'' -- give them a demonstration and then say -- "Here's what we can do.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Now, if you're willing to join us in getting rid of all the nuclear weapons in the world, then we'll give you this one, so that we would both know that no one can cheat; that we're both got something that if anyone tries to cheat .
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But when you keep star-warring it -- I never suggested where the weapons should be or what kind; I'm not a scientist.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I said, and the Joint Chiefs of Staff agreed with me, that it was time for us to turn our research ability to seeing if we could not find this kind of defensive weapon.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And suddenly somebody says, "Oh, it's got to be up there, and it's Star Wars,'' and so forth.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I don't know what it would be, but if we can come up with one, I think the world will be better off.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Well, that's what a President's supposed to know -- where those weapons are going to be.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: If they're space weapons, I assume they'll be in space.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: [Laughter] If they're antisatellite weapons, I assume they're going to be aimed against satellites.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Now, this is the most dangerous technology that we possess.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The Soviets try to spy on us, steal this stuff.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And to give them technology of this kind, I disagree with.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: You haven't just accepted research, Mr. President.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: You've set up a Strategic Defense Initiative, an agency, you're beginning to test, you're talking about deploying, you're asking for a budget of some $30 billion for this purpose.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: This is an arms escalation.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And we will be better off, far better off, if we stop right now, because we have more to lose in space then they do.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: If someday, somebody comes along with an answer, that's something else.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But that there would be an answer in our lifetime is unimaginable.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Why do we start things that we know the Soviets will match and make us all less secure?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That's what a President's for.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: As a matter of fact, we have a vast range of technology and weaponry right now that provides all the bargaining chips that we need.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And I support the air launch cruise missile, the ground launch cruise missile, the Pershing missile, the Trident submarine, the D - 5 submarine, Stealth technology, the Midgetman -- we have a whole range of technology.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Why I disagree with the MX is that it's a sitting duck.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It puts a hair-trigger, and it is a dangerous, destabilizing weapon.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And the B - 1 is similarly to be opposed, because for 15 years the Soviet Union has been preparing to meet the B - 1.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The Secretary of Defense himself said it would be a suicide mission if it were built.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Instead, I want to build the Midgetman, which is mobile and thus less vulnerable, contributing to stability, and a weapon that will give us security and contribute to an incentive for arms control.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That's why I'm for Stealth technology, to build a Stealth bomber -- which I've supported for years -- that can penetrate the Soviet air defense system without any hope that they can perceive where it is because their radar system is frustrated.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: In other words, a President has to make choices.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The final point is that we can use this money that we save on these weapons to spend on things that we really need.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Our conventional strength in Europe is under strength.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We need to strengthen that in order to assure our Western allies of our presence there, a strong defense, but also to diminish and reduce the likelihood of a commencement of a war and the use of nuclear weapons.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It's in this way, by making wise choices, that we're stronger, we enhance the chances of arms control.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Every President until this one has been able to do it, and this nation -- or the world is more dangerous as a result.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I will not agree to any arms control agreement, including a freeze, that's not verifiable.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Let's take your warhead principle.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The warhead principle -- there have been counting rules for years.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Whenever a weapon is tested we count the number of warheads on it, and whenever that warhead is used we count that number of warheads, whether they have that number or less on it, or not.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I will not agree to any production restrictions -- or agreements, unless we have the ability to verify those agreements.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I don't trust the Russians.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I believe that every agreement we reach must be verifiable, and I will not agree to anything that we cannot tell every day.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: In other words, we've got to be tough.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But in order to stop this arms madness, we've got to push ahead with tough negotiations that are verifiable so that we know the Soviets are agreeing and living up to their agreement.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Morton, I did criticize the President because of our undercutting of what was a stalwart ally -- the Shah of Iran.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I am not at all convinced that he was that far out of line with his people or that they wanted that to happen.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The Shah had done our bidding and carried our load in the Middle East for quite some time, and I did think that it was a blot on our record that we let him down.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The Shah, whatever he might have done, was building low-cost housing, had taken land away from the Mullahs and was distributing it to the peasants so they could be landowners -- things of that kind.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But we turned it over to a maniacal fanatic who has slaughtered thousands and thousands of people, calling it executions.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The matter of Somoza -- no, I never defended Somoza.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And, as a matter of fact, the previous administration stood by and so did I -- not that I could have done anything in my position at that time -- but for this revolution to take place.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And the promise of the revolution was democracy, human rights, free labor unions, free press.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And then, just as Castro had done in Cuba, the Sandinistas ousted the other parties to the revolution.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Many of them are now the contras.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: They exiled some, they jailed some, they murdered some.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And they installed a Marxist-Leninist totalitarian government.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And what I have to say about this is, many times -- and this has to do with the Philippines, also, I know there are things there in the Philippines that do not look good to us from the standpoint right now of democratic rights, but what is the alternative?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It is a large Communist movement to take over the Philippines.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: They have been our friend since their inception as a nation.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I think that we've had enough of a record of letting -- under the guise of revolution -- someone that we thought was a little more right than we would be, letting that person go, and then winding up with totalitarianism, pure and simple, as the alternative.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I think that we're better off, for example with the Philippines, of trying to retain our friendship and help them right the wrongs we see, rather than throwing them to the wolves and then facing a Communist power in the Pacific.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Well, as I say, we have to look at what an overthrow there would mean and what the government would be that would follow.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And there is every evidence, every indication that that government would be hostile to the United States.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And that would be a severe blow to our abilities there in the Pacific.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Perhaps in no area do we disagree more than this administration's policies on human rights.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I went to the Philippines as Vice President, pressed for human rights, called for the release of Aquino, and made progress that had been stalled on both the Subic and the Clark airfield bases.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: What explains this administration cozying up to the Argentine dictators after they took over?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Fortunately, a democracy took over, but this nation was embarrassed by this current administration's adoption of their policies.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: What happens in South Africa, where, for example, the Nobel Prize winner, 2 days ago, said this administration is seen as working with the oppressive government of South Africa.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We need to stand for human rights.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We need to make it clear we're for human liberty.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: National security and human rights must go together.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But this administration time and time again has lost its way in this field.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Well, the invasion of Afghanistan didn't take place on our watch.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I have described what has happened in Iran, and we weren't here then either.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I don't think that our record of human rights can be assailed.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think that we have observed, ourselves, and have done our best to see that human rights are extended throughout the world.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Mr. Mondale has recently announced a plan of his to get the democracies together and to work with the whole world to turn to democracy.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I was glad to hear him say that, because that's what we've been doing ever since I announced to the British Parliament that I thought we should do this.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Human rights are not advanced when, at the same time, you then stand back and say, "Whoops, we didn't know the gun was loaded,'' and you have another totalitarian power on your hands.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Well, I can't say that I have roundtabled that and sat down with the Chiefs of Staff, but I have said that it seems to me that this could be a logical step in what is my ultimate goal, my ultimate dream, and that is the elimination of nuclear weapons in the world.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And it seems to me that this could be an adjunct, or certainly a great assisting agent in getting that done.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I am not going to roll over, as Mr. Mondale suggests, and give them something that could turn around and be used against us.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But I think it's a very interesting proposal, to see if we can find, first of all, something that renders those weapons obsolete, incapable of their mission.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But Mr. Mondale seems to approve MAD -- MAD is mutual assured destruction -- meaning, if you use nuclear weapons on us, the only thing we have to keep you from doing it is that we'll kill as many people of yours as you'll kill of ours.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think that to do everything we can to find, as I say, something that would destroy weapons and not humans is a great step forward in human rights.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Mr. Mondale, could I ask you to address the question of nuclear strategy then?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The formal doctrine is very arcane, but I'm going to ask you to deal with it anyway.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Do you believe in MAD, mutual assured destruction, mutual deterrence as it has been practiced for the last generation?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I believe in a sensible arms control approach that brings down these weapons to manageable levels.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And in the meantime, we have to be strong enough to make certain that the Soviet Union never tempts us.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Now, here we have to decide between generalized objectives and reality.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: The President says he wants to eliminate or reduce the number of nuclear weapons.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But, in fact, these last 4 years have seen more weapons built, a wider and more vigorous arms race than in human history.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: He says he wants a system that will make nuclear wars safe, so nobody's going to get hurt.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Well, maybe someday, somebody can dream of that.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But why start an arms race now?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Why threaten our space satellites upon which we depend?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Why pursue a strategy that would delegate to computers the question of starting a war?
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: A President, to defend this country and to get arms control, must master what's going on.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I accept his objective and his dream; we all do.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But the hard reality is that we must know what we're doing and pursue those objectives that are possible in our time.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: He's opposed every effort of every President to do so, and in the 4 years of his administration he's failed to do so.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And if you want a tough President who uses that strength to get arms control and draws the line in the heavens, vote for Walter Mondale.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I want to thank the League of Women Voters, the good citizens of Kansas City, and President Reagan for agreeing to debate this evening.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: This evening we talked about national strength.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I believe we need to be strong, and I will keep us strong.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But I think strength must also require wisdom and smarts in its exercise.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That's key to the strength of our nation.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: A President must know the essential facts essential to command.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But a President must also have a vision of where this nation should go.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Tonight, as Americans, you have a choice.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And you're entitled to know where we would take this country if you decide to elect us.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: As President, I would press for long-term, vigorous economic growth.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That's why I want to get these debts down and these interest rates down, restore America's exports, help rural America, which is suffering so much, and bring the jobs back here for our children.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I want this next generation to be the best educated in American history, to invest in the human mind and science again, so we're out front.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I want this nation to protect its air, its water, its land, and its public health.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: America is not temporary; we're forever.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And as Americans, our generation should protect this wonderful land for our children.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I want a nation of fairness, where no one is denied the fullness of life or discriminated against, and we deal compassionately with those in our midst who are in trouble.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And, above all, I want a nation that's strong.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Since we debated 2 weeks ago, the United States and the Soviet Union have built a hundred more warheads, enough to kill millions of Americans and millions of Soviet citizens.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: This weakens the chances of civilization to survive.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I remember the night before I became Vice President.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: I was given the briefing and told that any time, night or day, I might be called upon to make the most fateful decision on Earth -- whether to fire these atomic weapons that could destroy the human species.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: That lesson tells us two things: One, pick a President that you know will know if that tragic moment ever comes what he must know, because there'll be no time for staffing committees or advisers.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: A President must know right then.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: But above all, pick a President who will fight to avoid the day when that God-awful decision ever needs to be made.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: And that's why this election is so terribly important.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: America and Americans decide not just what's happening in this country.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We are the strongest and most powerful free society on Earth.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: When you make that judgment, you are deciding not only the future of our nation; in a very profound respect, you're deciding the future of the world.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: We need to move on.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: It's time for America to find new leadership.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: Please, join me in this cause to move confidently and with a sense of assurance and command to build the blessed future of our nation.
Speaker: Walter Mondale

Text: My thanks to the League of Women Voters, to the panelists, the moderator, and to the people of Kansas City for their warm hospitality and greeting.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I think the American people tonight have much to be grateful for -- an economic recovery that has become expansion, freedom and, most of all, we are at peace.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I am grateful for the chance to reaffirm my commitment to reduce nuclear weapons and, one day, to eliminate them entirely.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The question before you comes down to this: Do you want to see America return to the policies of weakness of the last 4 years?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Or do we want to go forward, marching together, as a nation of strength and that's going to continue to be strong?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We shouldn't be dwelling on the past, or even the present.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: The meaning of this election is the future and whether we're going to grow and provide the jobs and the opportunities for all Americans and that they need.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Several years ago, I was given an assignment to write a letter.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: It was to go into a time capsule and would be read in 100 years when that time capsule was opened.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I remember driving down the California coast one day.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: My mind was full of what I was going to put in that letter about the problems and the issues that confront us in our time and what we did about them.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: But I couldn't completely neglect the beauty around me -- the Pacific out there on one side of the highway, shining in the sunlight, the mountains of the coast range rising on the other side.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And I found myself wondering what it would be like for someone -- wondering if someone 100 years from now would be driving down that highway, and if they would see the same thing.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And with that thought, I realized what a job I had with that letter.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I would be writing a letter to people who know everything there is to know about us.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We know nothing about them.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: They would know all about our problems.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: They would know how we solved them, and whether our solution was beneficial to them down through the years or whether it hurt them.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: They would also know that we lived in a world with terrible weapons, nuclear weapons of terrible destructive power, aimed at each other, capable of crossing the ocean in a matter of minutes and destroying civilization as we knew it.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: And then I thought to myself, what are they going to say about us, what are those people 100 years from now going to think?
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: They will know whether we used those weapons or not.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Well, what they will say about us 100 years from now depends on how we keep our rendezvous with destiny.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Will we do the things that we know must be done and know that one day, down in history 100 years or perhaps before, someone will say, "Thank God for those people back in the 1980's for preserving our freedom, for saving for us this blessed planet called Earth, with all its grandeur and its beauty.''
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: You know, I am grateful to all of you for giving me the opportunity to serve you for these 4 years, and I seek reelection because I want more than anything else to try to complete the new beginning that we charted 4 years ago.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: George Bush, who I think is one of the finest Vice Presidents this country has ever had -- George Bush and I have crisscrossed the country, and we've had, in these last few months, a wonderful experience.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have met young America.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: We have met your sons and daughters.
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: I was just going to -- --
Speaker: Ronald Reagan

Text: Thank you very much, Jim.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Let me first give you a sports update.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The Braves, one; the Cardinals, nothing, early on.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I want to thank you and I want to thank everybody here tonight.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I want to give a special thanks to my wife Elizabeth, my daughter Robin for their love and support, and thank the people who are listening and watching all over America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: In 20 days, you will help decide who will lead this country into the next century.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And you must ask yourself, do you know enough about the candidates?
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You should know as much as possible about each of us.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Sometimes the views have been distorted.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: There's been millions and millions of dollars of negative advertising spent distorting my views.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But I hope tonight you will get a better feel of who Bob Dole is and what he's all about.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I think first you should -- I should understand that the question on your mind is do I understand your problem.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Would I understand it if it occurred to me, and I might just say I'm from a large family.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I got lots of relatives and they're good, average, middle-class, hardworking Americans.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They live all across the country.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But in any event, I understand the problems.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Whether it's two parents working because one has to pay the taxes and one has to provide for the family, whether it's a single parent who just barely pays the pressing bills or whether you're worried about an education for your children going to the best schools, or whether you're worried about safe playgrounds, drug-free schools, crime-free schools.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This is what this election is all about.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And hopefully tonight when we conclude this debate you will have a better understanding and the viewing and listening audience will have a better understanding.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I was going to applaud, too.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And thanks to the people of San Diego for giving us this opportunity to have another discussion about the decision we all face in front of people who will make the decision.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Again, I will say I will do my best to make this a discussion of ideas and issues, not insults.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: What really matters is what happens to your future and what happens to our country as we stand on the brink of a new century, a time of extraordinary possibility.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I have a simple philosophy that I tried to follow for the last four years: Do what creates opportunity for all, what reinforces responsibility from all of us, and what will help us build a community where everybody's got a role to play and a place at the table.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Compared to four years ago, we're clearly better off.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've got ten and a half million more jobs, the deficit's been reduced by 60 percent.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Incomes are rising for the first time in a decade, the crime rates, the welfare rolls are falling, we're putting , 100,000 more police on the street.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: 60,000 felons, fugitives and stalkers have been denied handguns.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But that progress is only the beginning.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: What we really should focus on tonight is what we still have to do to help the American people make the most of this future that's out there.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think what really matters is what we can do to build strong families.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Strong families need a strong economy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: To me that means we have to go on and balance this budget while we protect Medicare and Medicaid and education and the environment.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We should give a tax cut, targeted to child rearing and education, to buying a first home and paying for health care.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We ought to help protect our kids from drugs and guns and gangs and tobacco.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We ought to help move a million people from welfare to work and we ought to create the finest education system in the world where every 18-year-old can go on to college and all of our younger children have great educational opportunities.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: If we do those things, we can build that bridge to the 21st century.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's what I hope to get to talk about tonight.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, I would say first of all, I think, it's a very good question.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I appreciate the quote from the young man.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: There's no doubt about it that many American people have lost their faith in government.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They see scandals almost on a daily basis.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They see ethical problems in the Whitehouse today.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They see 900 FBI files, private person, being gathered up by somebody in the Whitehouse.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Nobody knows who hired this man.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So there's a great deal of cynicism out there.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But I've always tried in whatever I've done is to bring people together.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I said in my acceptance speech in San Diego about two months ago that the exits are clearly marked.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If you think the Republican party is some place for you to come if you're narrow minded or bigoted or don't like certain people in America, the exits are clearly marked for you to walk out of as I stand here without compromise, because this is the party of Lincoln.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I think we have a real obligation, obviously public officials.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I'm no longer a public official.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I left public life on June the 11th of this year.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But it is very important.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Young people are looking to us.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They're looking to us for leadership.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They're watching what we do, what we say, what we promise and what we finally deliver.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I would think, it seems to me that there are opportunities here.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: When I'm President of the United States, I will keep my word.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: My word is my bond.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: One of the reasons that I ran for president, Sandy, is because not just children, a lot of grownups felt that way.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And if you remember four years ago, we had not only rising unemployment, but a lot of rising cynicism.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I had never worked in Washington as an elected official.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It seemed to me that most of the arguments were partisan, Republican, Democrat, left, right, liberal, conservative.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's why I said tonight I'm for opportunity, responsibility and community.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And we've gotten some real progress in the last four years.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I've also done everything I could at every moment of division in this country, after Oklahoma City, when these churches were burned, to bring people together and remind people that we are stronger because of our diversity.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have to respect one another.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You mentioned Washington and Lincoln.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They were presidents at historic times.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: This is an historic time.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's important we go beyond those old partisan arguments and focus on people and their future.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: When we do that, instead of shutting the government down over a partisan fight over the budget, we're a better country and that's why we're making progress now.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, bringing people together, again, is obviously a responsibility we all have.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I know you do it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You do a lot of things nobody knows about.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I have a little foundation for the disabled called the Dole Foundation.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We've raised about $10 million.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We don't talk about it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We try to help people with disabilities.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Bring them back into the mainstream of public life.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So it seems to me that there's also a public trust.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: When you're the president of the United States, you have a public trust and you have to keep that public trust, as George Washington, as Abraham Lincoln did.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I think now that trust is being violated and it seems to me we ought to face up to it, and the president ought to say tonight that he's not going to pardon anybody that he was involved in business with who might implicate him later on.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: First of all, let me say what we have done.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: In the last four years we've worked hard to promote more competition to bring down the rate of inflation in health care costs without eroding health care quality.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The government pays for Medicare and Medicaid, as you know, and that's very important.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Secondly, we've added a million more children to the ranks of the insured through the Medicaid program.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have protected 25 million people through the passage of the Kennedy-Kassebaum bill that says you can use your health insurance if you change jobs or someone in your family has been sick.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We just recently ended those drive-by deliveries saying people can't be kicked out of the hospital by insurance companies when they've just had babies.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So this is, that's a good start.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: In the next four years, I want to focus on the following things.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Number one, add another million children to the insured ranks through the Medicaid program.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Number two, keep working with the states, as we are now, to add 2.2 million more people to the insurance system.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Number three, cover people who are between jobs for up to six months.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That could protect 3 million families, 700,000 kids.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Number four, make sure we protect the integrity with the Medicare program and Medicaid program and not do anything in cutting costs which would cause hundreds of hospitals to close which could have been the case if the 270billion dollar Medicare cut that I vetoed, had been enacted in the law.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, first, let me say there you go again, Mr. President, talking about a Medicare cut.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I have heard you say this time after time.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I have heard you say on one TV appearance, "the media made me do it."
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You were trying to defend your cut which was not a cut either, Reduction in the growth of spending.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We've always had at least 7 percent.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You've said publicly that it's now three times the rate of inflation.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We ought to cut the growth to twice the rate of inflation.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's about where we are now.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So let's stop talking about cutting Medicare.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: In my economic plan we increase it 39percent.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Don't forget what he tried to do with health care.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: 17 new taxes, spend 1.5 trillion dollars, 50 new bureaucracies.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You couldn't even have been a cardiologist because he had quotas.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You're a cardiologist, it wouldn't affect you.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But if somebody wanted to be a cardiologist, ten years from now, you'd have to be certain you complied with some of the rules in this extreme medical plan the government was going to take over for all Americans.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: There are things we can do like the Kassebaum bill.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We changed many provisions I authored, cover preexisting conditions, portability, and there are other things we can do.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We still need to cover about 20million people and a lot of children.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I don't have time in 30 seconds to respond to fix all that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But let me just say the American Hospital Association said that the budget I vetoed could have closed 700 hospitals.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: On a per-person basis, it did cut way below the rate of inflation in medical costs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But the important thing is what are we going to do now?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We need to help people who are between jobs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We need to cover more kids.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: My balanced budget covers mammograms for ladies, women on Medicare and also gives respite care to the million-plus families who have someone with AlzheimerÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: These things are paid for in the balanced budget plan.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Jason, I appreciate that very much, being a former military man myself.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You know, we have 17,000 men and women today wearing our uniform that receive food stamps.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It shouldn't happen in America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We have men and women wearing our uniform in substandard housing.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It shouldn't happen in America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And it's time we take a look at the pay scales.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Did get a 3 percent increase this year, but that's not enough.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If we're going to ask young men and young women to protect us and defend us around the world, and we've had more deployments under this administration than any time in history.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Fifty times we deployed troops around the world.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Every time you do that you take a risk.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Somebody, you know, maybe your son, maybe your grandson, maybe somebody else.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But I think anybody who wears a uniform is a great American.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Remember when people almost used to walk across the street rather than have a contact with somebody who was in Vietnam?
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That's all behind us now, and it should be behind us, and the forgotten war, the Korean War, but I guess I can just answer you very plainly, Jason.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Thank you for doing what you're doing.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: America owes you a debt of gratitude.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: May I ask you a question?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: What service are you in?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And what kind of small business do you have?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me say, if Senator Dole mentioned this, I just signed a bill that we got through Congress to increase the amount of pay increase we could give for military personnel and to make sure the pay increase this year was above the rate of inflation.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I also presented to the Congress and they adopted a large package of quality-of-life improvements, which are very important.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I spent a lot of time talking to military families as well as military members all over the world and in bases all across the United States, and I became convinced after talking to the families and the personnel in uniform that we needed to not only have the pay raise but we needed to invest more in child care, housing, and other things to support families, especially when there are longer deployments because of the downsizing of the military.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I, we're going to do better, and we'll do better still, but this is a commitment I think that all Americans share without regard to party.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I don't disagree with anything that the President said, except he waited four years to do these things, and my view is it ought to be, it will be done on Day 1.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We'll start working on Day 1 in the Dole- Kemp administration.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We only have ten divisions now.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We used to have 18.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We had 25 fighter wings.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're down to 336 ships.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I mean, we've cut defense spending too much in the first place.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The President told you in '92 he would cut it 67 billion.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: He cut 112 billion dollars, so we're right on the edge right now.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But the last thing we ought to do is make those who wear the uniforms sacrifice.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Let me just take two seconds of my time because I'm the Commander-in-Chief to respond to one thing that was said.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I propose to spend 1.6 trillion dollars on defense between now and the year 2002 and there's less than 1 percent difference between my budget and the Republican budget on defense.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now, on the Middle East, as you know, I worked very hard for peace in the Middle East.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The agreement between the Palestinians and the Israelis was signed at the White House and the agreement -- the peace treaty with Jordan, I was -- I went to Jordan to sign that -- to be there.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But -- and I think the United States can do whatever we reasonably can.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I can say this: I do not believe Yassir Arafat wants us to send troops to the West Bank.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have never been asked to send troops to the West Bank.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I saw the agreement that Prime Minister Rabin and Yassir Arafat signed on the West Bank.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It had 26 separate maps they had to sign, literally thousands of delineations of who would do what on the West Bank, and I believe if the parties will get together and in a good-faith manner make that agreement, that they'll be able to do it if we cannot impose a peace on the Middle East.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: My position has always been that the job of the United States was to minimize the risks of peace.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You know, if they asked me to be part of some monitoring force -- as we are in the Sinai and have been since 1978 -- to monitor the peace between Egypt and Israel, frankly, I would have to think about it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I would have to see what they wanted to do, but I don't believe that will be the request.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think what Mr. Arafat wants us to do is to make sure that everybody honors the agreements they've already made.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's why I brought the leaders to Washington a few days ago.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think they will, and I think we'll get there.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me, Jason, come back to you a minute because there is a big difference in the defense budget.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We had 7 billion this year and 10 billion more than the president.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: He puts his money in the outyears, and even if he were re-elected, he'd be gone before anything would happen, and nothing is going to happen.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We don't have modernization now.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If we don't build more B-2 bombers in California and we lost about 500,000 jobs out in California, because of this devastation, these big, big cuts.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We had to make cuts.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We didn't have the cuts the president promised he'd make and then he doubled.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I think we need to go back and take a look.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're increasing defense reasonably -- not too much, but we are increasing defense some -- because we want to be prepared in case somebody here gets called up, Jason.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I would say I didn't hear what Yassir Arafat had to say, but I don't want to -- you know, I think foreign policy, I want to be very careful about, and I'm not here to argue about the President with some ongoing foreign policy matter.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: What I want the President to do, and I think he may have done it, his last statement, call for an unconditional end of the violence and have the parties keep on talking as they should talk and have a resolution.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The last thing we want to do is commit more forces anywhere.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But let's sort of keep this out of politics because it's pretty dicey right now.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: When the change of government occurred in Israel, the people of Israel were saying we don't want to abandon the peace process.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Then a lot of mutual distrust developed.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: A lot of things happened which maybe shouldn't have happened.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: When I asked Yassir Arafat and Prime Minister Netanyahu to come to Washington and got them together and they talked alone for three hours, I was convinced that they had to have a chance to make that peace.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Again, I'd say if they asked us to play some reasonable role, I don't know how I would respond.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It would depend entirely on what they asked us to do, but the real secret there is for them to abide by the agreements they've made and find a way to trust each other, and they're going to have to spend some time and trust each other.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Prime Minister Rabin gave his life believing that that trust could be materialized, and I still think it can be.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: My record going back to 1965 in the Congress, the first vote we had was whether or not you should put a little notice on cigarettes.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They may be danger -- I voted I for everything since that time.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: In fact, 1992 we had a bill come before us that all the states had to comply or they're going to lose certain money.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We sent it to the Clinton Administration for implementation, and they waited three and a half years.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And during that period about 3,000 young kids every day started smoking.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So you add it up.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Not until again in 1996 -- I don't want anybody to smoke.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: My brother probably died partly because of cigarettes.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I was asked a technical question.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Maybe they -- they probably are addictive.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You ought to be glad you quit, Oscar, 30 years.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And it seems to me what we need to do is to talk about not only tobacco but drugs, because drug use between 12- and 17-year-olds has doubled in this administration in the last 44 months.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Cocaine use up 160 percent.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's all happening in this administration because they cut funding and they cut interdiction.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: When I'm President of the United States, we're going to use the National Guard and whatever sources we need to stop some of the drugs coming into America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If you stop the drugs, nobody is going to use the drugs; so don't smoke, don't drink, don't use drugs.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Oscar, the question of what the federal government should do to limit the access of tobacco to young people is one of the biggest differences between Senator Dole and me.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We did propose a regulation six months after I became President under the law he mentioned.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It simply says all these states -- it made it illegal for kids to smoke.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now they have to try harder if they want to keep getting federal funds.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Then we took comments, as we always do, and there were tens of thousands of comments as to how we ought to do it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's what drug it out.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Meanwhile, we started the -- also in '93 to look into whether cigarettes were addictive enough for the Federal Food and Drug Administration to ban the ability of cigarette companies to advertise, market and distribute their products to our kids.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: No president had ever taken on the tobacco lobby before.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: He went down and made a speech to people who were on his side saying that I did the wrong thing.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think I did the right thing.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: On drugs, I have repeatedly said drugs are wrong and illegal and can kill you.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have strengthened enforcement, and everybody in San Diego knows we strengthened control of the border.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have done a lot more, and I hope we get a chance to talk about it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, they also know if they live in San Diego, Mr. President, if you're caught with 125 pounds of marijuana or less, you go back to Mexico.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You have a U.S. attorney here that sends `em back home, so I think that's pretty important.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That's a lot of marijuana.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But don't get into this smoke screen here Oscar.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The President in the election year decided I ought to do something, I haven't done anything on drugs.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I've been AWOL for 44 months, so let's take on smoking, see they haven't even done it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They haven't said what's going to happen, whether they're going to have it declared addictive.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Once it's a drug, does it apply only to teenagers or everybody in America?
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Nobody should smoke, young or old, but particularly young people should not smoke, but my record is there.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I've voted eight, ten times since 1965.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: First of all, there are two different things.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Social Security and Medicare are entirely different in terms of the financial stabilities.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let's talk about them separately.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Social Security is stable until, as you pointed out, at least the third decade of the next century.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But we'd like to have a Social Security fund that has about 70 years of life instead of about 30 years of life.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: What we have to do is simply to make some adjustments to take account of the fact that the baby boomers, people like me, are bigger in number than the people that went just before us and the people that come just after us.
