Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I think what we'll plainly do is what we did in 1983 when Senator Dole served, and this is something I think he did a good job on when he served on the Social Security commission and they made some modest changes in Social Security to make sure that it would be alive and well into the 21st century.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And we will do that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's obvious that there are certain things that have to be done and there are 50 or 60 different options, and a bipartisan commission to take it out of politics, will make recommendations and build support for the people.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I have proposed a budget which would put ten years on the life of the Medicare trust fund.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's more than it's had a lot of the time in the last years.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It would save a lot of money through more managed care, by giving more options, more preventative care and lowering the inflation rate and the prices we're paying providers without having the kind of big premium increases and out-of-pocket costs that the budget I vetoed would provide.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Then that would give us ten years to do with Medicare what we're going to do with Social Security; have a bipartisan group look at what we have to do to save it when the baby boomers retire.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But now we can, we ought to pass this budget now and put ten years on it right away so no one has to worry about it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well again, if you're somebody thinking about the future, I think it's fair to say that it'll be -- we'll work it out.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This is a political year, and the President is playing politics with Medicare.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: After this year is over, we'll resolve it just as we did with Social Security in `83.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Ronald Reagan got together with Tip O'Neill and Howard Baker, two Republicans and one Democrat.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They appointed a commission I was on that commission.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We resolved, we rescued Social Security.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We suggested -- I think it has been over a year ago now -- we do the same with Medicare, and the White House called it a gimmick.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now last week I guess it was Donna Shalala said well we'll cut Medicare a hundred billion and appoint a commission.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It will probably have to be done by a commission.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Take it out of politics.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I think if I were a senior citizen I would be a little fed up with all these ads scaring seniors, scaring veterans and scaring students about education.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: When you don't have any ideas, you don't have any agenda, and all you have is fear, that's all you can use.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We have ideas in the Dole-Kemp campaign and we will rescue Medicare as we did Social Security.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Their idea was to have the poorest seniors in the country pay $270 more this year.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Their idea was a budget that the that the American Hospital Association said could close 700 hospitals.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Their idea was to charge everybody more out-of-pocket costs in their budget that I vetoed.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Not in an election year, sir.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I told them in early '95.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Senator Dole said 30 years ago he was one of 12 people who voted against Medicare and he was proud of it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: A year ago he said, "I was right then.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I knew it wouldn't work."
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We need to reform it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, we've taken the first step.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Took it three steps, twice we sent welfare reform to the president and he vetoed it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: On the third time we sent welfare reform to the president he signed it but announced he would change it next year, and the vice president said they were going to do something else through the line item veto which I've never understood, but that's sort of inside baseball.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: What we need to do is make certain we try to return people to work.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I'm standing here as someone who, a long time ago as the county attorney in Russell, Kansas, one of our jobs every month was go through all the welfare checks and sign them.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And three of those checks were my grandparents'.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So I know what it's like to have to look welfare head-on.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Obviously some people are going to need help.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This is the United States of America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You're not going to go without food and you're not going to go without medical care.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But at the same time, if you want to get off Medicare, get back in the mainstream, we're going to provide jobs.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're going to say you have a five-year limit.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You can be on welfare.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You got two years to look for a job.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We provided more money for daycare in the bill that passed the senate, was vetoed, then it came back and the president signed pretty much the same bill.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But this is an important issue.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I don't think we ought to be giving welfare payments to illegal immigrants.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It puts a heavy burden on a state like -- except for emergencies.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It puts a heavy burden on a states like California.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It costs California taxpayers 3 billion dollars a year.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Let me get out of your way here.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's illegal right now and has been for years for illegal immigrants to get welfare benefits.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me say that this is one of the most important issues in the world to me.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I started working on welfare reform in 1980 because I was sick of seeing people trapped in a system that was increasingly isolating them and making their kids more vulnerable to get in trouble.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I've been working on it when I was a governor for a long time.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: When I became president I used the authority I had in this law to get out from certain federal rules to help states move people to work.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now, I've got a plan with this new welfare reform law to work with the private sector, to give employees specific tax incentives to hire people off welfare, and to do some other things which will create more jobs in the private sector, at least a million, and move more people from welfare to work.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I hope we get a chance to talk about this more.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: There's not a more important issue.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I, I still remember a woman that I met ten years ago who said she wanted to get off welfare so her kids could tell, give an answer when they say, "What does your mother do for a job?"
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I met that woman again.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: One's got a good job, one's studying to be a doctor.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: One's in technical school, one's an honor student in high school.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I want to make more people like that woman, Lily Harden, so I've got a plan to do it, and it's just beginning.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well another thing we can do.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We've got a great economic package which I hope we will discuss later.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: $500 per child under 18.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Reduce the capital gains rate.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Create more jobs and opportunities for people on and off welfare.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The trial lawyers, big supporters of the president.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The trial lawyers, of course they like lawsuits, so every time they have a bill that they want vetoed, the president vetoes it for them.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We've got to understand in America that we've got to have growth, create more jobs and more opportunities in the private sector.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The president takes credit for all these people off welfare.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Federal government doesn't do that.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And the government doesn't create jobs.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They're created in the private sector.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: First of all, we have a big plan to reduce the capital gains tax when people sell their homes.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Part of my tax package which is paid for in my balanced budget plan would exempt up to half a million dollars in gains from people when they sell their homes, which I think is the biggest capital gains benefit we could give to most ordinary Americans.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We also have capital gains now for people that invest in new small businesses and hold the investment for five years.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It was part of our other economic plan.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And these are things I think that will go a long way toward helping America build a stronger economy and a better tax system.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think the most important thing to emphasize, though, is that we also have to help people in other ways to build a strong economy and we can't have any tax cut that's not paid for.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: One of the big differences between Senator Dole and myself is that I told you how I'm going to pay for every penny of the tax cuts I recommend and we've worked hard to bring this deficit down and that's helped people in the real estate business because the interest rates are lower.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've got home ownership at a 15-year high.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've got this country going in the right direction.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So we can have a tax cut but my priority would be to help the families who need it with child rearing and education and buying a first-time home and helping for health care costs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So from your business, helping in buying a first-time home, exempting the capital gains on the sale of the home would be the most important things that you asked about.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Pam, what the president didn't tell you is all his tax cuts expire the year 2000, but these increases go on forever.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You know, give you a little tax cut, give you a couple of years, then make the tax increases go on forever.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So the net tax increase in his plan's somewhere between 60 and 80 billion dollars.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We have in the Dole-Kemp economic plan, unless unless your home's worth over 500,000 dollars.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And if it is, I appreciate it congratulate you.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But in any event, no tax.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's a good idea, they saw it, they picked it up and put it in theirs, but it's only temporary.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Ours are permanent, ours is a good plan.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Capital gains rate, cut it in half, cut it 28 percent to 14 percent.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: There are 7 trillion dollars in assets locked up in America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If we cut the capital gains rate, I'm told everyday, I had a letter from a former constituent in Kansas saying I want to sell property in California, put it in my business in Kansas, I can't, because the capital gains rate's too high.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That'll help people who want to get off welfare.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Before Senator Dole left the Senate, he and Mr. Gingrich also were recommending that we pass these tax cuts only insofar as we could pay for them.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We all assume that the tax cuts will be permanent.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: After he left the senate, we abandoned that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's why most experts say that this tax scheme will blow a huge hole in the deficit, raise interest rates and weaken the economy and that will take away all the benefits of the tax cut with a weaker economy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's why we have to balance the budget, and I will tell you how I'm going to pay for anything I promise you, line by line.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You should expect that from both of us.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, I think age is very -- you know, wisdom comes from age, experience and intelligence.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And if you have some of each -- and I have some age, some experience and some intelligence -- that adds up to wisdom.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I think it also is a strength.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I have a lot of young people work in my office, work in my campaign.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This is about, somebody said earlier, one of the first questions, we're together.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's one America, one nation.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I'm looking at our economic plan because I'm concerned about the future for young people.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The president has been AWOL for four years.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: He'll claim credit now for crime going down, but it happens because mayors and governors and others have brought crime down.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Rudy Giuliani, Mayor of New York, brought crime down 25 percent just in New York City.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Of course the president will take credit for that.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: My view is we want to find jobs and opportunities and education.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This year the Republican Congress, as far as student loans went from 24 billion to 36 billion over the next six years.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: 6 billion dollars for Pell Grants, very, very important.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We also raised the amount of each Pell Grant.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: In our economic plan, the $500 child credit can be used for young people, rolled over and over and over, you, of course not this age, but if you have a child two years old, 7 percent interest would be worth about $18,000 by the time that child was ready for college.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I can only tell you that I don't think Senator Dole is too old to be president.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's the age of his ideas that I question.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You're almost not old enough to remember this.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But we tried this before, promising people an election year tax cut that's not paid for.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You tried it last time you ran.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Tell him you can have everything you got.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And so let me just say this.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Did you hear him say that Congress just voted to increase student loans and scholarships?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They did after he left.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The last budget he led cut Pell Grants, cut student loans.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I vetoed it when they shut the government down.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: My plan would give students a dollar-for-dollar reduction for the cost of a typical community college tuition.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: A $10,000 deduction a year for the cost of college tuition.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We let families save in an IRA, withdraw tax free to pay for the cost of education and it's all paid for.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: My whole administration is about your future.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's about what the 21st century is going to be like for you.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I hope you will look at the ideas in it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: When you don't have any ideas, I guess you say the other person's ideas are old.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: As I said earlier, they don't have any ideas.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Their ideas is to raise taxes and spend more money.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That's what you like, you've got a perfect candidate.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: President Clinton came to California in 1992.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: He said the centerpiece in my first four years is going to be a middle class tax cut.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now all you got that tax cut, congratulations.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Because you got a big tax increase.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You got a 265 billion dollar tax increase.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And he stands here and says politicians who make promises like that ought to be ignored.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Well he made the promise.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I keep my word, and you will have a tax cut.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It will help you in whatever you're going to do in the next few years.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I'm against giving anybody any kind of preference for something they're not qualified for.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But because I still believe that there is some discrimination and that not everybody has an opportunity to prove they're qualified, I favor the right kind of Affirmative Action.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I've done more to eliminate Affirmative Action programs I didn't think were fair and tighten others up than my predecessors have, since affirmative action's been around.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But I have also worked hard to give people a chance to prove that they are qualified.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me just give you some examples.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've doubled the number of loans from the small business administration, tripled the number of loans to women business people, no one unqualified, everybody had to meet the standards.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But the joint chiefs say we're stronger and more confident and solid than ever.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me give you another example of what I mean.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: To me, Affirmative Action is making that extra effort.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's sort of like what Senator Dole did when he sponsored the Americans with Disabilities Act and said to certain stores, okay, you have to make it accessible to people in wheelchairs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We weren't guaranteeing anything, anybody anything except the chance to prove they were qualified, the chance to prove that they could do it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And that's why I must say I agree with General Colin Powell that we're not there yet.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We ought to keep making those extra effort Affirmative Action programs, the law and the policy of the land.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, we may not be there yet but we're not going to get there by giving preferences and quotas.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I supported that route for some time and again I think it gets back to experience.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: A little experience, a little age, a little intelligence.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I noted that nobody was really benefitting except a very small group at the top.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The average person wasn't benefitting.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: People who had the money were benefiting.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: People who got all the jobs were benefiting.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It seems to me that we ought to support the California civil rights initiative.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It ought to be not based on gender or ethnicity or color.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I shouldn't have a preference.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I would like to have one in this race, come to think of it, but I don't get one.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Maybe we can work that out.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I get a 10-point spot.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Discrimination ought to be punished but there ought to be equal opportunity.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We ought to reach out, make certain everybody has a chance to participate.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But we cannot guarantee equal results in America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That's not how America became the greatest country on the face of the earth.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I have never supported quotas.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I've always been against them.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I don't favor equal results, but I do favor making sure everybody has a chance to prove they're competent.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The reason I have opposed that initiative is because I'm afraid it will end those extra effort programs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Again I say, think of the Americans with Disabilities Act.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Make an effort to put a ramp up there so someone in a wheelchair can get up.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You don't guarantee they get the job.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You guarantee they have a chance to prove they're competent.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And as I said, this is not a partisan thing with me.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: General Colin Powell said the same thing, he fears the initiative would take away the extra effort programs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: No preferences to unqualified people, no quotas, but don't give up on making an extra effort until you're sure everybody has a chance to prove they're qualified.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well I'm glad you asked.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I first want to say the President didn't quite give you all of the stuff on the quotas, because the Justice Department had what we called the Piscataway case up in New Jersey.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's pretty clear that was a quota case, and just because one teacher was white and one black and they had the same qualifications, you know they decided who would stay there.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It shouldn't be that way.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now, the President can say well he wants to mend it, not end it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: There are 168 federal programs that allow quotas.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now, this economic package, Tim, I'm glad you asked, because you look like the type that might be able to benefit from a 15 percent across- the-board tax cut and $500-per-child tax credit, or -- you know, estate tax relief which you're not interested in right now, but capital gains rate reduction.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If you're taking care of an elderly parent, you get a $1,000 deduction.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We think that's very important because a lot of people take care of their parents.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: How do we pay for it?
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You can have a constitutional amendment to balance the budget, which the President opposed and defeated.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: He twisted arms and got six Democrats to vote with him and lost by one vote.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're going to balance the budget, by the year 2002.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The President wants to spend 20 percent more in the next six years, and I want to spend 14 percent more and give that 6 percent back to the people.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Remember, it's your money; it's not his money.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And it's not my money.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And you shouldn't have to apologize for wanting to keep all you can of it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But he ought to apologize for wanting to take more and more.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: He wants to give you sort of a government tax cut, which really doesn't mean anything.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You know, one of the responsibilities of growing older, it seems to me, is being able to tell people something they may not want to hear just because it's true.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: When they had a 250 billion dollar tax scheme, that is half the size of this one.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: They have 270 billion dollars in Medicare cuts the first education cuts in history, cut environmental enforcement by 25 percent, took away the guarantee of quality standards in nursing homes, took away the guarantee of health care for folks with disabilities.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Don't take my word for this.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The Economist magazine polled lots of economists, seven Nobel prize winners who said if this tax scheme passes, it will require huge cuts, 40 percent, in the environment and law enforcement and education.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It will require bigger cuts in Medicare than I vetoed last time.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: My targeted tax cut is for child-rearing, buying a first-time home, paying for health care costs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And it's paid for, and I'll tell you how I'll pay for it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: He won't tell you because he can't.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Your targeted tax cut, Mr. President, never hits anybody.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That's the problem with it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But I must say I'm a little offended by this word "scheme."
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You talked about it last time, you talked about a risky scheme and Vice President Gore repeated it about ten times in St. Petersburg.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If I have anything in politics, it's my word.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: My colleagues, Democrats and Republicans, will tell you that Bob Dole kept his word.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I'm going to keep my word to you.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I'm going to keep my word to the American people.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're going to tax -- cut taxes and balance the budget.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're not going to touch Medicare.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's going to grow 39 percent, and Social Security is going to grow 34 percent.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The President doesn't have any ideas so he's out trashing ours.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This isn't going to blow a hole in the deficit.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: He promised you a tax cut in 1992, and if you got one, you ought to vote for him.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Thank you, well, first let me say that I signed the Family Leave Act.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It was my very first bill, and I'm very proud of it because it symbolizes what I think we ought to be doing.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I don't take credit for all the good things that have happened in America, but I take credit for what I've tried to do to work with others to make good things happen.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Most important good things that happen in America happen in families.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Just about every family I know, the main concern is how am I going to succeed at work and still do right by my children.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Family medical leave has let 12 million families take a little time off for the birth of a child or a family illness without losing their job.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'd like to see it expanded in two ways.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'd like to say you can also take a little time off without losing your job to go to a regular parent-teacher conference or to go to a regular doctor's appointment with a family member.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'd also like to see the overtime laws change so that we could have some more flex time so that at the discretion of the worker, the worker, if you earn overtime, you could decide when you want that time to be taken, in cash or in time with your family if you've got a family problem.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I never go anywhere, it seems like, where I don't meet somebody who has benefited from a Family Leave Law.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: In Longview, Texas the other day, I met a woman who was almost in tears because she had been able to keep her job while spending time with her husband who had cancer.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: One of the people who's here with me today met a woman in the airport saying her son, Jess was able to be present at the birth of her child because of the Family Leave Law.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So yes, I think it should be expanded.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have to help people succeed at home and at work.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We had a better idea.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We had a better idea.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now we have a majority and we get a president.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That was a tax credit for the employer.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Instead of the federal government, we had that tax credit, pick up some of the costs, because if you have to hire a replacement worker, that's a cost.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This is the way it ought to work, give more power back to the states and back to the people back to the taxpayers, not always the long arm of the federal government.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But keep in mind this bill covers 5 percent of the employers, and 95 percent of the employers and all those employees they employ are not covered in this act.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And according to Investors Daily, which I read just a couple of days ago, 88 percent of the people he claims credit for are already covered in collective bargaining agreements or other agreements.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We had family leave in our office, I'm certain.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I see my friend Senator Mitchell.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I work every day with people.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I spend a lot of time in hospitals.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I know what it's like to be in a hospital.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Sure we want family leave.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But there's a better way to do it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I only have 30 seconds.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I can't fix the statistics.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It covers the majority of the work force.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Employers of under 50 are exempted.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The bill originally covered employers of 25 and more, but because of opposition, we went up to 50.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Senator Dole led the opposition to it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: He said it was a mistake.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: He said it would hurt the economy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've had record numbers of new small businesses and 10 and a half million jobs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It didn't hurt the economy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: He still believes it's a mistake.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You can decide which of us you think are right.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've lost 357,000 manufacturing jobs.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The Bureau of Labor Statistics today said they made a mistake.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's probably going to take a much, much higher figure.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So we talk about all these new jobs.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We'd better wait and see what the results are.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're going to do that with a more aggressive trade policy.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're going to do that with an economic package.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're going to do that with regulatory reform.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You know, regulations cost the average family right here, Democrat or Republican, about $7,000 a year.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's put a lot of people out of business.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I met a lady in Colorado Springs about seven weeks ago now.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: She had a small business with 63 employees.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: She finally gave it up.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Because of paperwork and regulation.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Congress passed a paperwork reduction act.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The President exempts the IRS which creates three-fourths of the paperwork.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're going to have regulatory -- we're gonna have litigation reform.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You know, I fell off a platform out in California, Chico, a while back.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Before I hit the ground, my cell phone rang and this trial lawyer said, I think we've got a case here.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We've got to stop some of these frivolous lawsuits.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They're putting people out of business, men and women.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Get the economy going, cut the capital gains rate, create more jobs and opportunities for everybody in America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That's what we will do.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And my word is good.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I don't break my promises after the election, and I don't make new promises in an election year.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're going to get it done.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're going to grow some of these jobs in America, because we need to get it -- they're going the wrong way.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Let's look at the facts.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We lost a lot of manufacturing jobs in the 12 years before I became President.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've gained manufacturing jobs since I've been President.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We've negotiated over 200 separate trade agreements.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: In California, we made 37 billion dollars' worth of telecommunications equipment eligible for export for the first time.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We're selling everything from from -- from telephones to CDs to rice in Japan.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We're selling American automobiles in Japan now.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I visited a Chrysler dealership in Japan.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We're No.1 in automobile manufacturing production and sales around the world again, the first time since 1970s.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Because we've had tough aggressive trade policies, and because we've got interest rates down.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have a good, stable economic policy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Because we reduced the deficit four years in a row.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: For the first time in the 20th century the President has done that in all four years and that's why I don't want to see us blow a big hole in the deficit with a tax program we can't pay for, so your interest rates will go up, and you'll have to pay back in higher interest rates what you allegedly will get in a tax cut, so I say keep working on expanding the markets.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: More than half of these 10 and a half million new jobs are in higher wage areas and we'll have more manufacturing and sales around the world.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You may think the biggest employer in America is General Motors, but I've got news for you.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Hiring people temporarily who have lost their jobs and they get to work for 30 days or 60 days.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They're setting new records this year.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We had the worst economy in a century.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We had the slowest growth, about 2.5 percent.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The president inherited growth of over 5 percent.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We don't have the S&L crisis anymore.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Republicans have cut 53 billion dollars in spending, that's why the budget looked good.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It didn't look good the first two years when we had a Democratic president and Ã‚ Democratic Congress.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I believe that any law- abiding, tax-paying citizen who shows up in the morning and doesn't break the law and doesn't interfere with his or her neighbors ought to have the ability to work in our country and shouldn't be subject to unfair discrimination.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now, I have a little time left so let me just say that I get attacked so many times on these questions; it's hard to answer these things.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Senator Dole just said we had the worst economy in the century.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: In February he said we had the best economy in Ã‚ 30 years, just February.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I don't want to respond in kind to all these things.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I could answer a lot of these things tit for tat.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But I hope we can talk about what we're going to do in the future.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: No attack ever created a job or educated a child, or helped a family make ends meet.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: No insult ever cleaned up a toxic waste dump or helped an elderly person.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now, for four years that's what I worked on.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: If you give me four years more I will work on it some more and I will try to answer these charges, but I prefer to emphasize direct answers to the future and I gave you a direct answer.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, I'm opposed to discrimination in any form but I don't favor creating special rights for any group.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That would be my answer to this question.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I'm, you know -- there would be special rights for different groups in America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But I'm totally opposed to discrimination.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I don't have any policy against hiring anyone; whether it's lifestyle or whatever, we don't have any policy of that kind, never have had in my office or will we have in the future.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But as far as special rights, I'm opposed to same-sex marriages, which the President signed well after midnight one morning in the dark of night.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But I will get back to the economic package because, again, I think this is very important.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If there's anything that's going to change America it's get the economy growing.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The President inherited a good economy, sure the S&L crisis then were selling assets.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Got a Republican Congress cutting spending finally and he said it's the best four years ever.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We had a 1.2 million bankruptcy, set a new record.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Credit card debt has never been higher.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I just told you about this manufacturing job loss which is going to increase.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We need a good strong economic package, let the private sector creates the jobs and they can do it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If you believe that the California economy was better in 1992 than it is today, you should vote for Bob Dole.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I have worked so hard out here to help turn this economy around.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me just give you one tiny example.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: In San Diego where we had some defense cutbacks, we funded a project for the University of California San Diego to use airplane composite materials to build lighter, stronger bridges, a little project in a program that Senator Dole opposed.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And that composite now is going to be built around the bridges on the Santa Monica Freeway to help minimize the impact of earthquakes and create more jobs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's just one tiny example.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Maybe we will talk about some more before it's over.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, one thing I did was oppose the government takeover health care that President Clinton offered in 1993, which created 17 new taxes and 50 new bureaucracies and price controls, because we were afraid the very thing you mentioned would have happened.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Everybody would have been forced into managed care.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You couldn't have chosen your own doctor and that would have been the end.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I think right now we got to go back.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I know they've appointed a commission to take a look at managed care.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Maybe that's part of the answer.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But it seems to me if we start to take choices away from people and if we drive them into one type care, eliminate fee-for-service altogether or eliminate the fact you can go to your own doctor, you have to go somewhere else, then I think we've taken a giant step backward in the United States of America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We have the best health care delivery system in the world and we want to keep it that way.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That's why we opposed the government take over health care plan that President Clinton tried and tried and tried to get through Congress.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And ended up we had more votes than he had, then they decided to pull the plug.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It was a big, big mistake.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now whether or not he'll do that again I've heard some of the people say, well, that's the model we ought to use and if he's reelected maybe he will come back and try it again.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I hope not in both cases.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But it does seem to me that you've raised a very important point that needs to be addressed.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You're going to have to watch it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Gonna have to take a look at all the managed care going on in California, or we're going to end up losing our best care that we have in the world.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: How many of you are under managed care plans?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Raise your hand if you're in managed care plan.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: How many of you like it?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, one of the things that I tried to do was to make sure that everybody in the country who was under a managed care plan should at least have three choices of plans, and would have the right to get out without penalty every year.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now that's not a government takeover.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's like the family of medical-leave law; it just tries to set the rules of the game.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'm strongly in favor of a federal bill to repeal any gag rules on providers.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: In other words, I believe that doctors should not be able to be kicked out of managed care plans just because they tell the patients what they need and what more expensive care options might be.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: If we're saving money and managing resources better, that's a good thing.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: If we're saving money and depriving people of care, that's a bad thing.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: A good place to start is to say no managed care provider can gag a doctor and kick the doctor out of the managed care plan for the doctor, telling the patient, you need a more expensive test, you need a more expensive procedure, your health requires it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, I don't have any quarrel with that.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I think that would help.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But I think what we want to avoid is falling back into this nationalized health care system that President Clinton wanted to give us in 1993.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If that isn't a liberal idea, I've never heard one.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: 17 new taxes, price controls, 50 new bureaucracies.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We'd have that trouble all over America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We need to deal with managed care.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It not only happened in California.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's happening in other states that we visit, too.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Not just a state problem.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: First of all, I think it's important to make voting more accessible.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's why I strongly supported the Motor Voter law.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: There was a big story I think in U.S.A. Today of the millions of people who have now registered because of it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Secondly, I think we need to look at making the elections more accessible.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You know several states now are letting people vote over three weeks.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: A lot of people are busy and it's hard for them to just get there and vote.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Third thing I think we need is more forums like this, which is one of the reasons I have so strongly supported campaign finance reform.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Because if you want to cut the cost of campaigns, you have to open the airways, because what drives the cost of campaigns are the cost of advertising on television, radio, newspaper, mass mailing.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And if you open the airways to more things like this, you see it's not just you that are participating here.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: For every one of you who stood up here and asked a question tonight, I promise you there's a 100,000 Americans who said I wish I could have asked that question.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I think we have to change the nature of politics.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The last thing I think we should do is something I have been trying to do since I have been president, is every time I do something in a public way, I try to have a real American citizen there who is directly affected by it so that people can see the connection of what happens way across the country, in Washington with more police on the street, in San Diego, clean up the sewage here in San Diego, doubling the border guards here in Southern California, that there is a connection between what we do way back there and what we do here.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, I don't know of any perfect solution.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I have been in politics for some time, and I worry about the people who don't vote.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I wonder if it's our fault, the candidates' fault.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: People say, "I don't care.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: One vote doesn't make a difference."
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I can give you hundreds of -- you can probably give me 200 cases where one vote made a difference.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I know it made a lot of difference many times in the Congress.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It might help the contributions from coming in from Indonesia or other foreign countries, rich people in those countries, and then being sent back after the L.A. Times discovers it, $250,000.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But maybe there ought to be more debates.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I would be willing to have another debate this year.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We can invite all the candidates.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And talk about the economy.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If we don't get the economy to grow, if we don't cut taxes, and give people child credits, and cut the capital gains rate, and get this economy growing, we're going to limp into the next century.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If we grow the economy it's going to help Social Security.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's going to help jobs.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's going to help everything.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Let me make one other suggestion, because you're a teacher, you can have an impact on that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: One of the things I think that really frustrates people is that so often political campaigns seem to be more about the politicians that are running than the people.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And there is a connection.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And I think what we have to do is convince people there is a big difference, if you vote one way you will have a Department of Education in the 21st century, if you vote the other way, you won't.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: If you vote one way you will have an expansion of family leave.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: If you vote the other way, you will be lucky to save it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But these are important questions.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And people have to decide.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think that the American people also need to be a little more responsible and think about whether there's a connection with their lives and what we do in Washington.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, we have in our economic pack, -- individual retirement accounts where we think it will encourage savings.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You can also use those accounts for health care or education or a first home.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're doing that precisely, and I think one thing sooner or later we're going to have to consider is take a look at the Social Security system.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Because we've got a lot of people advocating we don't want to put our money into Social Security.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You have to be very careful of that because you have to protect the people who are already in the pipeline.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's something you might consider.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I'm not suggesting it will be done, but at least we ought to look at it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's been looked, When I was chairman of the finance committee which handled Social Security we looked at all these options, and one thing we've got to make certain, when I used to go home my mother would tell me all I've got is my Social Security, don't touch it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And we didn't touch it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Your your Social Security is going to be there when you retire.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It will probably happen in the year 2012 or 2015.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: In 1983 we thought we had a 75 -year fix.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Much, much less, but at least we fixed it for some time and 37 to 40 million people get their checks on time.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So we need to preserve the system.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And we need to make it stronger.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But we also need to look at some options, whether or not we -- depending on what the options are.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: In fact, they have got a commission right now in Congress, a bipartisan commission, looking at all the different options they will present to the next Congress.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: so I think we will wait, see what they present, take a look at it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Iris, this is one where we have some agreement, I think.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Only about half the people in this country have pension plans.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And Social Security is not enough for a lot of people to live on, or at least is not enough for them to maintain anything like their previous lifestyle.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So we've got to figure out how are we going to have more people with pension plans, and pension coverage has been declining as more and more people work for small businesses and fewer people work for big businesses.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So what, what is in my plan and I think it's almost identical in Senator Dole's plans is we make more people eligible to save in an IRA and let couples, married couples save more and then they could withdraw from it tax-free if they needed to, for medical emergencies or buy a home or education, but they could also save to supplement retirement.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: In addition to that, we just passed a sweeping small business reform that makes it easier for small business people to take out 401 K plans for themselves and employees and much easier for employees to carry it from job to job.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: My best friend from grade school is a computer software salesman and he told me last time he changed employers it took him nine months to figure out how to transfer his 401K plan.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now none of that will happen anymore.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I hope over the next ten years you will see a big increase over the percentage of people that have pension plans, plus a secure Social Security system.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Did you say you're unemployed?
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: See, the first thing we have to do is get you a job.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And that's the economic package again.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Reduce the capital gains rate.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Stop some of this senseless litigation and let people work in America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I think that's that's the thrust we will make.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Obviously if Social Security is a very important program, it should -- it will be preserved.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Democrats or Republicans, it will be preserved.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We want to make certain we protect those in the pipeline just as we did back in 1983 and we did it on a bipartisan basis.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We took it out of politics.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: people get so tired of politics.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We ought to do the same with Medicare.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Maybe we can make a deal here tonight.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Let me tell you what we have done.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have concluded with Japan 21 -- about to be 22 -- trade agreements now.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And since we did that, in the areas where we concluded, trade agreements or exports to Japan have gone up by 85 percent in the last four years and our trade deficit with Japan has gone down.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Until about five months ago the Japanese economy was in a deep recession.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's coming back now, so they can buy even more American products, and I think it will go down more.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But I'm very -- that's one of the real success stories here of the work we've done.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We're selling Japanese rice from California for the first time.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I visited a Chrysler dealership in Tokyo.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I visited a Jeep plant, oldest plant in America, a plant in Toledo, Ohio, where they're going to export 41,000 right hand drive Jeeps this year, and they've got 700 new jobs because of it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: There's no easy way to do this when you're dealing with an economy that's traditionally been more closed than one that's traditionally been more open.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You have to gut it out, issue by issue by issue.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We agreed in principle on an insurance agreement, and we're working on three or four other areas now, but the way you have to do it is make sure you're competitive.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We're the most competitive country in the world now, and then just fight to open those markets and go try to make the sale, and that's what our trade ambassador our commerce secretary and all the other people in our administration are trying to do.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, the bottom line is we have to stop exporting jobs here.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: There are 357, 000 good jobs -- manufacturing jobs, which are lost.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I assume some of those are because of our trading partners.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We didn't have access to their markets.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We ought to insist on access.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: If we don't have access to their markets the same way they've access our markets, we ought to say, "Wait, that's enough.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: When you give us access, we'll give you access."
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's very hard to get into the Japan market, as everybody knows.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They want to get into our market.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They sell a lot of automobiles here, create a lot of jobs -- those who sell exports.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And that's very important to the economy, but I think we want to make certain.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I supported the President's trade policy.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But we got to be more aggressive.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Once you have a policy, then you have to go out and be aggressive and enforce that policy.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: There are American jobs that are being lost.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This is what Ross Perot complains about.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I'd say to the Reform party, take a look at the Republican party.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're the reform party, and we're going to make things better, and one of the things we're going to do is stop exporting jobs.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Let me say again, we've had over 200 separate trade agreements in the last four years.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: By far, the largest number in American history -- not just the big ones you read about, but a lot of smaller ones.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And now what we have to do is to focus on those things we're real good at and make sure we're getting a fair deal.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We just had a pretty serious dispute with China because they were copying our CDs, and costing thousands of jobs in places like California.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So we have -- as we said, if you want to keep doing business and selling your products over here, you're going to have to quit pirating our CDs, and they agreed to do things and verify that they had done it, which will make the problem much better.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: There is not a simple answer.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You have to work on this day in and day out, every month ,every year, every issue, to make sure that we have not only free trade but fair trade.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I'm proud that we're better off on that than we were four years ago.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well no doubt about it, our founding fathers had a great deal of wisdom.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: In addition to what you mentioned, they also were concerned about this all-powerful central government in Washington, D.C., that'd in effect confiscate your property, so -- I carry it in my pocket -- I can't pull it out or I'd violate the rules -- a copy of the Tenth Amendment which says we ought to return power to the states and the people, the people here.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You ought to make more decisions.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Honor, duty, and country, that's what America is all about.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Certainly the President of the United States, the highest office in the world, the most important office in the world, has a responsibility to young people, as we talked about earlier.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And when it comes to public ethics, he has a responsibility.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And you have 30-some in your administration, either left or being investigated or in jail or whatever, then you've got an ethical problem.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This is public ethics; I'm not talking about private ethics.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: When you have 900 files gathered up by some guy who is a bouncer in a bar and hired a security officer to collect files, in Watergate -- I know a person who went to jail for looking at one file, one FBI file.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: There are 900 sequestered in the White House.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Why should they be rifling through your files?
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The president has a great responsibility.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: That's one that I understand and certainly will carry out.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This is the most religious, great country in history.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And yet, interestingly enough, we have the most religious freedom of any country in the world, including the freedom not to believe.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And now we have all these people just up the road in Los Angeles County, we have people from 150 different racial and ethnic groups and tons of different religions, but the fundamental tenets of virtually every religion are the same, and what I try to do is to support policies that would respect religion and then help parents inculcate those values to their children.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me very briefly give you some examples.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: One of my proudest moments was signing the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, that says the government has got to bend over backwards before we interfere with religious practice.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So I changed the Justice Department's effort to get a church to pay back a man tithe, because he was bankrupt when he gave it.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I have supported character education programs in our schools, drug-free schools programs.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I supported giving parents a V-chip on their television so if they don't want their young kids to watch things they shouldn't watch, they wouldn't have to.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That is the kind of thing we have to do, give people like you and our families the power to give those values to our children.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I think it's -- before I came in, my wife and daughter and I had a prayer.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Because it's God's will, whatever happens.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's God's will, it'll happen.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: The constitutional amendment for voluntary prayer in school, in my view would be a great idea.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I support it; the president opposes it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It seems to me the president, whoever the president may be, this is one of his highest responsibilities.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: People look to the President of the United States more than any other person in America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And that's the way it's always been, and that's the way it always will be.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I want to answer your question, but let me say one other thing.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We don't need a constitutional amendment for kids to pray, and what I did was to have the justice department and the education department for the first time ever issue a set of guidelines that we gave to every school in America, saying that children could not be interfered with in religious advocacy when they were praying, when they were doing whatever they could do under the constitution, just because they were on a public school ground, and I think anyone who's experienced this will tell you that our administration has done more than any in years to clarify the freedom of religion in the public square, including in the public schools.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Now, I think I have to let Senator Dole speak for himself.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It wouldn't be fair for me to do that.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I would wind up -- I mean, it's the last question and I would mischaracterize it to try to make you happy.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Let me tell you what I feel.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We have a lot of differences in our country, and some of us believe that other people's decisions are wrong, even immoral.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: But under our constitution, if you show up tomorrow and obey the law, and you work hard and you do what you're supposed to do, you are entitled to equal treatment.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: That's the way the system works.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: All over the world, people are being torn apart -- Bosnia, the Middle East, Northern Ireland, Rwanda, Burundi -- you name it -- because of all their differences.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We still have some of that hatred inside us.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You see it in the church burnings.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And one of the things I've tried hardest to do is to tell the American people that we have to get beyond that, we have to understand that we're stronger when we unite around shared values instead of being divided by our differences.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, I hope I made my answer clear.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I said I'm opposed to discrimination.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: You know we've suffered discrimination in the disability community.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: There are 43 million of us.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I can recall cases where people would cross the street rather than meet somebody in a wheelchair.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So we want to end discrimination.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I think that answers itself.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I would just say that it seems to me that that's the way it ought to be.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We shouldn't discriminate -- race, color, whatever -- life-style, disability.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And we're all proud of it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But we're not there yet.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: What we need is good, strong leadership going in the next century.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I'm sorry we didn't have a foreign policy question, because just this week Secretary Christopher said, "Well, we really didn't know much the first couple of years about foreign policy."
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Now that was quite an admission.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It underscores what I had to say in the Hartford debate, that there is really no foreign policy in this administration.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's sort of ad hoc, just whatever comes up, we'll deal with it.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Unfortunately, we didn't have more questions on that.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Let me say again, there is no more important responsibility for the president than to say if you believe in the constitution, the Bill of Rights, and the Declaration of Independence, that's all we need to know.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And you can be part of our America and you can walk across that bridge to the 21st century with us.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And we are not well served when we attack each other in a kind of ad hominem way.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: We need to be disagreeing on ideas, honestly, and talking about the future.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The future will be the greatest time in this country's history if we can beat this division that is bedeviling the whole rest of the world.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Well, let me thank everybody here at the University and, Jim, thank you.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This is what it's all about.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's not about President Clinton.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's about selecting a president of the United States.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: So we have our differences.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We should have our differences.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We all agreed it would be a pretty dull place.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We should have more debates.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Maybe we will have another debate on the economy.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But I would just say this.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: This is the highest honor that I have ever had in my life, to think that somebody from Russell, Kansas, somebody who grew up living in a basement apartment, someone whose parents didn't finish high school, somebody who spent about 39 months in hospitals after World War II, someone who uses a buttonhook every day to get dressed.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Somebody who understands that there're real Americans out there with real problems, whether soccer moms, or the single parents, the families or the seniors, or people with disabilities, whoever it may be.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: There are some very fundamental differences in this campaign.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: President Clinton opposes term limits, President Clinton opposes a constitutional amendment to balance the budget.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: President Clinton opposes voluntary prayer amendment.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Opposes an amendment to protect the flag of the United States of America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Couple of service men here.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: They sacrifice, they give everything for America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We ought to protect the American flag with a constitutional amendment.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: But beyond that we need to address the economy.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I will just say my time is running out here.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: It's a very proud moment for me.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: What I want the voters to do is to make a decision.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I want them to be proud of their vote in the years ahead.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Proud that they voted for the right candidate.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Proud that they voted hopefully for me.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And I'll just make you one promise, my word is good.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: Democrats and Republicans said Bob Dole's word is good.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: I promise you the economy is going to get better.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: We're going into the next century a better America.
Speaker: Bob Dole

Text: And thank you, ladies and gentlemen, and all the people who are watching.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: One thing I would like to say is I agree with what Senator Dole said.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: It's a remarkable thing in a country like ours, a man who grew up in Russell, Kansas, and one who was born to a widowed mother in Hope, Arkansas, could wind up running for president.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Could have a chance to serve as president.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: First thing I want to say is thank you for giving me the chance to be president.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: This election is about two different visions about how we should go into the 21st Century.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Would we be better off as I believe, working together to give each other the tools we need to make the most of our God-given potential, or are we better off saying, you're on your own?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Would we be better off building that bridge to the future together so we can all walk across it or saying you can get across yourself?
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: If you don't agree -- leave this room with anything else tonight and if the people watching us don't leave with anything else, I hope you will leave with this.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: This is a real important election.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: The world is changing dramatically in how we work and how we live, how we relate to each other, huge changes.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And the decisions we make will have enormous practical consequences.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: So we've talked about our responsibility tonight.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: I want to talk about your responsibility, and your responsibility.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Your responsibility is to show up on November the 5th.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Because you're going to decide whether we're going to balance the budget now, but protect Medicare, Medicaid, education and the environment.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: You will decide whether we're going to keep fighting crime with a Brady Bill, assault weapons and finish putting those 100,000 police.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Whether we're going to move a million people from welfare to work.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Whether we're going to give our families more protection for their kids against drugs and tobacco and gangs and guns.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Whether we're going to give our children a world-class education.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Where every eight-year-old can read.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Every 12-year-old can log in on the Internet.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: Every 18-year-old can go to college.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: If we do those things we will build that bridge to the 21st Century and the greatest country in history will be even greater.
Speaker: Bill Clinton

Text: And thank you for agreeing to moderate this debate this evening.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Thank you to Lynn University for welcoming us here.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And Mr. President, it's good to be with you again.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We were together at a humorous event a little earlier, and it's nice to maybe funny this time, not on purpose.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is obviously an area of great concern to the entire world, and to America in particular, which is to see a -- a complete change in the -- the structure and the -- the environment in the Middle East.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: With the Arab Spring, came a great deal of hope that there would be a change towards more moderation, and opportunity for greater participation on the part of women in public life, and in economic life in the Middle East.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But instead, we've seen in nation after nation, a number of disturbing events.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Of course we see in Syria, 30,000 civilians having been killed by the military there.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We see in -- in Libya, an attack apparently by, I think we know now, by terrorists of some kind against -- against our people there, four people dead.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Our hearts and -- and minds go out to them.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Mali has been taken over, the northern part of Mali by al-Qaeda type individuals.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have in -- in Egypt, a Muslim Brotherhood president.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And so what we're seeing is a pretty dramatic reversal in the kind of hopes we had for that region.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Of course the greatest threat of all is Iran, four years closer to a nuclear weapon.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And -- and we're going to have to recognize that we have to do as the president has done.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I congratulate him on -- on taking out Osama bin Laden and going after the leadership in al-Qaeda.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But we can't kill our way out of this mess.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're going to have to put in place a very comprehensive and robust strategy to help the -- the world of Islam and other parts of the world, reject this radical violent extremism, which is -- it's certainly not on the run.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is a group that is now involved in 10 or 12 countries, and it presents an enormous threat to our friends, to the world, to America, long term, and we must have a comprehensive strategy to help reject this kind of extremism.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, my first job as commander in chief, Bob, is to keep the American people safe.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's what we've done over the last four years.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We ended the war in Iraq, refocused our attention on those who actually killed us on 9/11.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And as a consequence, Al Qaeda's core leadership has been decimated.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In addition, we're now able to transition out of Afghanistan in a responsible way, making sure that Afghans take responsibility for their own security.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that allows us also to rebuild alliances and make friends around the world to combat future threats.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now with respect to Libya, as I indicated in the last debate, when we received that phone call, I immediately made sure that, number one, that we did everything we could to secure those Americans who were still in harm's way; number two, that we would investigate exactly what happened, and number three, most importantly, that we would go after those who killed Americans and we would bring them to justice.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's exactly what we're going to do.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I think it's important to step back and think about what happened in Libya.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Keep in mind that I and Americans took leadership in organizing an international coalition that made sure that we were able to, without putting troops on the ground at the cost of less than what we spent in two weeks in Iraq, liberate a country that had been under the yoke of dictatorship for 40 years.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Got rid of a despot who had killed Americans and as a consequence, despite this tragedy, you had tens of thousands of Libyans after the events in Benghazi marching and saying America is our friend.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now that represents the opportunity we have to take advantage of.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, you know, Governor Romney, I'm glad that you agree that we have been successful in going after Al Qaida, but I have to tell you that, you know, your strategy previously has been one that has been all over the map and is not designed to keep Americans safe or to build on the opportunities that exist in the Middle East.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, my strategy is pretty straightforward, which is to go after the bad guys, to make sure we do our very best to interrupt them, to -- to kill them, to take them out of the picture.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But my strategy is broader than that.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's -- that's important, of course.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But the key that we're going to have to pursue is a -- is a pathway to get the Muslim world to be able to reject extremism on its own.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We don't want another Iraq, we don't want another Afghanistan.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's not the right course for us.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The right course for us is to make sure that we go after the -- the people who are leaders of these various anti-American groups and these -- these jihadists, but also help the Muslim world.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And how do we do that?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: A group of Arab scholars came together, organized by the U.N., to look at how we can help the -- the world reject these -- these terrorists.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And the answer they came up with was this:
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We should key our foreign aid, our direct foreign investment, and that of our friends, we should coordinate it to make sure that we -- we push back and give them more economic development.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number four, the rule of law.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have to help these nations create civil societies.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But what's been happening over the last couple of years is, as we've watched this tumult in the Middle East, this rising tide of chaos occur, you see Al Qaida rushing in, you see other jihadist groups rushing in.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And -- and they're throughout many nations in the Middle East.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's wonderful that Libya seems to be making some progress, despite this terrible tragedy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But next door, of course, we have Egypt.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Libya's 6 million population; Egypt, 80 million population.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We want -- we want to make sure that we're seeing progress throughout the Middle East.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: With Mali now having North Mali taken over by Al Qaida; with Syria having Assad continuing to -- to kill, to murder his own people, this is a region in tumult.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And, of course, Iran on the path to a nuclear weapon, we've got real (inaudible).
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Governor Romney, I'm glad that you recognize that Al Qaida is a threat, because a few months ago when you were asked what's the biggest geopolitical threat facing America, you said Russia, not Al Qaida; you said Russia, in the 1980s, they're now calling to ask for their foreign policy back because, you know, the Cold War's been over for 20 years.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But Governor, when it comes to our foreign policy, you seem to want to import the foreign policies of the 1980s, just like the social policies of the 1950s and the economic policies of the 1920s.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You say that you're not interested in duplicating what happened in Iraq.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But just a few weeks ago, you said you think we should have more troops in Iraq right now.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the -- the challenge we have -- I know you haven't been in a position to actually execute foreign policy -- but every time you've offered an opinion, you've been wrong.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You said we should have gone into Iraq, despite that fact that there were no weapons of mass destruction.
Speaker: Barack Obama
