Text: You said that we should still have troops in Iraq to this day.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You indicated that we shouldn't be passing nuclear treaties with Russia despite the fact that 71 senators, Democrats and Republicans, voted for it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You said that, first, we should not have a timeline in Afghanistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Then you said we should.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now you say maybe or it depends, which means not only were you wrong, but you were also confusing in sending mixed messages both to our troops and our allies.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So, what -- what we need to do with respect to the Middle East is strong, steady leadership, not wrong and reckless leadership that is all over the map.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And unfortunately, that's the kind of opinions that you've offered throughout this campaign, and it is not a recipe for American strength, or keeping America safe over the long haul.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, of course I don't concur with what the president said about my own record and the things that I've said.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They don't happen to be accurate.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But -- but I can say this, that we're talking about the Middle East and how to help the Middle East reject the kind of terrorism we're seeing, and the rising tide of tumult and -- and confusion.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And -- and attacking me is not an agenda.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Attacking me is not talking about how we're going to deal with the challenges that exist in the Middle East, and take advantage of the opportunity there, and stem the tide of this violence.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: First of all, Russia I indicated is a geopolitical foe.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's a geopolitical foe, and I said in the same -- in the same paragraph I said, and Iran is the greatest national security threat we face.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Russia does continue to battle us in the U.N. time and time again.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I have clear eyes on this.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm not going to wear rose-colored glasses when it comes to Russia, or Mr. Putin.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I'm certainly not going to say to him, I'll give you more flexibility after the election.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: After the election, he'll get more backbone.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number two, with regards to Iraq, you and I agreed I believe that there should be a status of forces agreement.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You didn't want a status of...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: What I would not have had done was left 10,000 troops in Iraq that would tie us down.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that certainly would not help us in the Middle East.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I'm sorry, you actually -- there was a -- there was an effort on the part of the president to have a status of forces agreement, and I concurred in that, and said that we should have some number of troops that stayed on.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That was something I concurred with...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That was my posture as well.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You thought it should have been 5,000 troops...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I thought there should have been more troops, but you know what?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The answer was we got...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: ... no troops through whatsoever.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This was just a few weeks ago that you indicated that we should still have troops in Iraq.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: ...that's a -- I indicated...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: ...I indicated that you failed to put in place a status...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: ...of forces agreement at the end of the conflict that existed.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Governor -- here -- here's -- here's one thing...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: ...here's one thing I've learned as commander in chief.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You've got to be clear, both to our allies and our enemies, about where you stand and what you mean.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You just gave a speech a few weeks ago in which you said we should still have troops in Iraq.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That is not a recipe for making sure that we are taking advantage of the opportunities and meeting the challenges of the Middle East.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, it is absolutely true that we cannot just meet these challenges militarily.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so what I've done throughout my presidency and will continue to do is, number one, make sure that these countries are supporting our counterterrorism efforts.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number two, make sure that they are standing by our interests in Israel's security, because it is a true friend and our greatest ally in the region.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number three, we do have to make sure that we're protecting religious minorities and women because these countries can't develop unless all the population, not just half of it, is developing.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Number four, we do have to develop their economic -- their economic capabilities.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But number five, the other thing that we have to do is recognize that we can't continue to do nation building in these regions.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Part of American leadership is making sure that we're doing nation building here at home.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That will help us maintain the kind of American leadership that we need.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What we've done is organize the international community, saying Assad has to go.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've mobilized sanctions against that government.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We have made sure that they are isolated.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We have provided humanitarian assistance and we are helping the opposition organize, and we're particularly interested in making sure that we're mobilizing the moderate forces inside of Syria.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But ultimately, Syrians are going to have to determine their own future.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so everything we're doing, we're doing in consultation with our partners in the region, including Israel which obviously has a huge interest in seeing what happens in Syria; coordinating with Turkey and other countries in the region that have a great interest in this.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: This -- what we're seeing taking place in Syria is heartbreaking, and that's why we are going to do everything we can to make sure that we are helping the opposition.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But we also have to recognize that, you know, for us to get more entangled militarily in Syria is a serious step, and we have to do so making absolutely certain that we know who we are helping; that we're not putting arms in the hands of folks who eventually could turn them against us or allies in the region.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I am confident that Assad's days are numbered.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But what we can't do is to simply suggest that, as Governor Romney at times has suggested, that giving heavy weapons, for example, to the Syrian opposition is a simple proposition that would lead us to be safer over the long term.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, let's step back and talk about what's happening in Syria and how important it is.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: First of all, 30,000 people being killed by their government is a humanitarian disaster.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Secondly, Syria is an opportunity for us because Syria plays an important role in the Middle East, particularly right now.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Syria is Iran's only ally in the Arab world.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's their route to the sea.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's the route for them to arm Hezbollah in Lebanon, which threatens, of course, our ally, Israel.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And so seeing Syria remove Assad is a very high priority for us.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number two, seeing a -- a replacement government being responsible people is critical for us.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And finally, we don't want to have military involvement there.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We don't want to get drawn into a military conflict.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And so the right course for us, is working through our partners and with our own resources, to identify responsible parties within Syria, organize them, bring them together in a -- in a form of -- if not government, a form of -- of -- of council that can take the lead in Syria.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And then make sure they have the arms necessary to defend themselves.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We do need to make sure that they don't have arms that get into the -- the wrong hands.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Those arms could be used to hurt us down the road.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We need to make sure as well that we coordinate this effort with our allies, and particularly with -- with Israel.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But the Saudi's and the Qatari, and -- and the Turks are all very concerned about this.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They're willing to work with us.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We need to have a very effective leadership effort in Syria, making sure that the -- the insurgent there are armed and that the insurgents that become armed, are people who will be the responsible parties.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Recognize -- I believe that Assad must go.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I believe he will go.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But I believe -- we want to make sure that we have the relationships of friendship with the people that take his place, steps that in the years to come we see Syria as a -- as a friend, and Syria as a responsible party in the Middle East.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This -- this is a critical opportunity for America.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And what I'm afraid of is we've watched over the past year or so, first the president saying, well we'll let the U.N. deal with it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And Assad -- excuse me, Kofi Annan came in and said we're going to try to have a ceasefire.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Then it went to the Russians and said, let's see if you can do something.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We are playing the leadership role.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We organized the Friends of Syria.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We are mobilizing humanitarian support, and support for the opposition.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But going back to Libya -- because this is an example of how we make choices.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: When we went in to Libya, and we were able to immediately stop the massacre there, because of the unique circumstances and the coalition that we had helped to organize.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We also had to make sure that Moammar Gadhafi didn't stay there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And to the governor's credit, you supported us going into Libya and the coalition that we organized.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But when it came time to making sure that Gadhafi did not stay in power, that he was captured, Governor, your suggestion was that this was mission creep, that this was mission muddle.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so we were going to make sure that we finished the job.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's part of the reason why the Libyans stand with us.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But we did so in a careful, thoughtful way, making certain that we knew who we were dealing with, that those forces of moderation on the ground were ones that we could work with, and we have to take the same kind of steady, thoughtful leadership when it comes to Syria.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's exactly what we're doing.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I don't want to have our military involved in Syria.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I don't think there is a necessity to put our military in Syria at this stage.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I don't anticipate that in the future.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: As I indicated, our objectives are to replace Assad and to have in place a new government which is friendly to us, a responsible government, if possible.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I want to make sure they get armed and they have the arms necessary to defend themselves, but also to remove -- to remove Assad.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But I do not want to see a military involvement on the part of our -- of our troops.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And this isn't -- this isn't going to be necessary.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We -- we have, with our partners in the region, we have sufficient resources to support those groups.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But look, this has been going on for a year.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is a time -- this should have been a time for American leadership.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We should have taken a leading role, not militarily, but a leading role organizationally, governmentally to bring together the parties; to find responsible parties.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: As you hear from intelligence sources even today, the -- the insurgents are highly disparate.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They haven't formed a unity group, a council of some kind.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: America can help that happen.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And we need to make sure they have the arms they need to carry out the very important role which is getting rid of Assad.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, I'll -- I'll be very quick.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What you just heard Governor Romney said is he doesn't have different ideas.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's because we're doing exactly what we should be doing to try to promote a moderate Syrian leadership and a -- an effective transition so that we get Assad out.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's the kind of leadership we've shown.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's the kind of leadership we'll continue to show.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: No, I don't, because I think that America has to stand with democracy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The notion that we would have tanks run over those young people who were in Tahrir Square, that is not the kind of American leadership that John F. Kennedy talked about 50 years ago.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But what I've also said is that now that you have a democratically elected government in Egypt, that they have to make sure that they take responsibility for protecting religious minorities.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we have put significant pressure on them to make sure they're doing that; to recognize the rights of women, which is critical throughout the region.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: These countries can't develop if young women are not given the kind of education that they need.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They have to abide by their treaty with Israel.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That is a red line for us, because not only is Israel's security at stake, but our security is at stake if that unravels.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They have to make sure that they're cooperating with us when it comes to counterterrorism.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we will help them with respect to developing their own economy, because ultimately what's going to make the Egyptian revolution successful for the people of Egypt, but also for the world, is if those young people who gathered there are seeing opportunities.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Their aspirations are similar to young people's here.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They want jobs, they want to be able to make sure their kids are going to a good school.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They want to make sure that they have a roof over their heads and that they have the prospects of a better life in the future.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so one of the things that we've been doing is, is, for example, organizing entrepreneurship conferences with these Egyptians to give them a sense of how they can start rebuilding their economy in a way that's noncorrupt, that's transparent.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But what is also important for us to understand is, is that for America to be successful in this region there's some things that we're going to have to do here at home as well.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, one of the challenges over the last decade is we've done experiments in nation building in places like Iraq and Afghanistan and we've neglected, for example, developing our own economy, our own energy sectors, our own education system.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And it's very hard for us to project leadership around the world when we're not doing what we need to do...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I believe, as the president indicated, and said at the time that I supported his -- his action there.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I wish that, looking back at the beginning of the president's term and even further back than that, that we'd have recognized that there was a growing energy and passion for freedom in that part of the world, and that we would have worked more aggressively with our friend and with other friends in the region to have them make the transition towards a more representative form of government, such that it didn't explode in the way that it did.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But once it exploded, I felt the same as the president did, which is these freedom voices and the streets of Egypt, where the people who were speaking of our principles and the President Mubarak had done things which were unimaginable and the idea of him crushing his people was not something that we could possibly support.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Let me step back and talk about what I think our mission has to be in the Middle East and even more broadly, because our purpose is to make sure the world is more -- is peaceful.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We want a peaceful planet.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We want people to be able to enjoy their lives and know they're going to have a bright and prosperous future, not be at war.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And the mantle of leadership for the -- promoting the principles of peace has fallen to America.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We didn't ask for it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But it's an honor that we have it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But for us to be able to promote those principles of peace requires us to be strong.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And that begins with a strong economy here at home.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Unfortunately, the economy is not stronger.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Former chief of the -- Joint Chiefs of Staff said that -- Admiral Mullen said that our debt is the biggest national security threat we face.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This -- we have weakened our economy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We need a strong economy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We need to have as well a strong military.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Our military is second to none in the world.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're blessed with terrific soldiers, and extraordinary technology and intelligence.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But the idea of a trillion dollar in cuts through sequestration and budget cuts to the military would change that.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We need to have strong allies.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Our association and connection with our allies is essential to America's strength.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're the great nation that has allies, 42 allies and friends around the world.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And if we're strong in each of those things, American influence will grow.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But unfortunately, in nowhere in the world is America's influence will grow.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But unfortunately, in -- nowhere in the world is America's influence greater today than it was four years ago.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And that's because we've become weaker in each of those four...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well I -- I absolutely believe that America has a -- a responsibility, and the privilege of helping defend freedom and promote the principles that -- that make the world more peaceful.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And those principles include human rights, human dignity, free enterprise, freedom of expression, elections.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Because when there are elections, people tend to vote for peace.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They don't vote for war.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So we want to promote those principles around the world.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We recognize that there are places of conflict in the world.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We want to end those conflicts to the extent humanly possible.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But in order to be able to fulfill our role in the world, America must be strong.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And for that to happen, we have to strengthen our economy here at home.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You can't have 23 million people struggling to get a job.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You can't have an economy that over the last three years keeps slowing down its growth rate.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You can't have kids coming out of college, half of them can't find a job today, or a job that's commensurate with their college degree.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have to get our economy going.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And our military, we've got to strengthen our military long-term.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We don't know what the world is going to throw at us down the road.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We -- we make decisions today in the military that -- that will confront challenges we can't imagine.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: In the 2000 debates, there was no mention of terrorism, for instance.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And a year later, 9/11 happened.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So, we have to make decisions based upon uncertainty, and that means a strong military.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I will not cut our military budget.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have to also stand by our allies.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I -- I think the tension that existed between Israel and the United States was very unfortunate.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I think also that pulling our missile defense program out of Poland in the way we did was also unfortunate in terms of, if you will, disrupting the relationship in some ways that existed between us.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And then, of course, with regards to standing for our principles, when -- when the students took to the streets in Tehran and the people there protested, the Green Revolution occurred, for the president to be silent I thought was an enormous mistake.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have to stand for our principles, stand for our allies, stand for a strong military and stand for a stronger economy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: America remains the one indispensable nation.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the world needs a strong America, and it is stronger now than when I came into office.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Because we ended the war in Iraq, we were able to refocus our attention on not only the terrorist threat, but also beginning a transition process in Afghanistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It also allowed us to refocus on alliances and relationships that had been neglected for a decade.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And Governor Romney, our alliances have never been stronger, in Asia, in Europe, in Africa, with Israel, where we have unprecedented military and intelligence cooperation, including dealing with the Iranian threat.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But what we also have been able to do is position ourselves so we can start rebuilding America, and that's what my plan does.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Making sure that we're bringing manufacturing back to our shores so that we're creating jobs here, as we've done with the auto industry, not rewarding companies that are shipping jobs overseas.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Making sure that we've got the best education system in the world, including retraining our workers for the jobs of tomorrow.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Doing everything we can to control our own energy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've cut our oil imports to the lowest level in two decades because we've developed oil and natural gas.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But we also have to develop clean energy technologies that will allow us to cut our exports in half by 2020.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's the kind of leadership that we need to show.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we've got to make sure that we reduce our deficit.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Unfortunately, Governor Romney's plan doesn't do it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've got to do it in a responsible way by cutting out spending we don't need, but also asking the wealthiest to pay a little bit more.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That way we can invest in the research and technology that's always kept us at the cutting edge.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, Governor Romney has taken a different approach throughout this campaign.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Both at home and abroad, he has proposed wrong and reckless policies.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: He's praised George Bush as a good economic steward and Dick Cheney as somebody who's -- who shows great wisdom and judgment.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And taking us back to those kinds of strategies that got us into this mess are not the way that we are going to maintain leadership in the 21st century.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I've got a policy for the future and agenda for the future.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And when it comes to our economy here at home, I know what it takes to create 12 million new jobs and rising take-home pay.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And what we've seen over the last four years is something I don't want to see over the next four years.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The president said by now we'd be a 5.4 percent unemployment.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're 9 million jobs short of that.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I will get America working again and see rising take-home pay again, and I'll do it with five simple steps.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number one, we are going to have North American energy independence.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're going to do it by taking full advantage of oil, coal, gas, nuclear and our renewables.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number two, we're going to increase our trade.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Trade grows about 12 percent year.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It doubles about every -- every five or so years.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We can do better than that, particularly in Latin America.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The opportunities for us in Latin America we have just not taken advantage of fully.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: As a matter of fact, Latin America's economy is almost as big as the economy of China.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're all focused on China.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Latin America is a huge opportunity for us -- time zone, language opportunities.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number three, we're going to have to have training programs that work for our workers and schools that finally put the parents and the teachers and the kids first, and the teachers' unions going to have to go behind.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And then we're going to have to get to a balanced budget.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We can't expect entrepreneurs and businesses large and small to take their life savings or their company's money and invest in America if they think we're headed to the road to Greece.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And that's where we're going right now unless we finally get off this spending and borrowing binge.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I'll get us on track to a balanced budget.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And finally, number five, we've got to champion small business.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Small business is where jobs come from.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Two-thirds of our jobs come from small businesses.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: New business formation is down to the lowest level in 30 years under this administration.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I want to bring it back and get back good jobs and rising take-home pay.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, let's talk about what we need to compete.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: First of all, Governor Romney talks about small businesses.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But, Governor, when you were in Massachusetts, small businesses development ranked about 48th, I think out of 50 states in Massachusetts, because the policies that you are promoting actually don't help small businesses.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the way you define small businesses includes folks at the very top.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And they include you and me.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's not the kind of small business promotion we need.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But let's take an example that we know is going to make a difference in the 21st century and that's our education policy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We didn't have a lot of chance to talk about this in the last debate.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, under my leadership, what we've done is reformed education, working with governors, 46 states.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've seen progress and gains in schools that were having a terrible time.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And they're starting to finally make progress.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And what I now want to do is to hire more teachers, especially in math and science, because we know that we've fallen behind when it comes to math and science.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And those teachers can make a difference.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, Governor Romney, when you were asked by teachers whether or not this would help the economy grow, you said this isn't going to help the economy grow.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: When you were asked about reduced class sizes, you said class sizes don't make a difference.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I tell you, if you talk to teachers, they will tell you it does make a difference.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And if we've got math teachers who are able to provide the kind of support that they need for our kids, that's what's going to determine whether or not the new businesses are created here.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Companies are going to locate here depending on whether we've got the most highly skilled workforce.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the kinds of budget proposals that you've put forward, when we don't ask either you or me to pay a dime more in terms of reducing the deficit, but instead we slash support for education, that's undermining our long-term competitiveness.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That is not good for America's position in the world, and the world notices.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well -- well, I need to speak a moment...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: ... if you'll let me, Bob, just about education...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: ... because I'm -- I'm so proud of the state that I had the chance to be governor of.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have every two years tests that look at how well our kids are doing.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Fourth graders and eighth graders are tested in English and math.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: While I was governor, I was proud that our fourth graders came out number one of all 50 states in English, and then also in math.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And our eighth graders number one in English and also in math.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: First time one state had been number one in all four measures.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: How did we do that?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, Republicans and Democrats came together on a bipartisan basis to put in place education principles that focused on having great teachers in the classroom.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And that was -- that was -- that was what allowed us to become the number one state in the nation.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But that was 10 years before you took office.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And then you cut education spending when you came into office.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The first -- the first -- the first -- and we kept our schools number one in the nation.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They're still number one today.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And the principles that we put in place, we also gave kids not just a graduation exam that determined whether they were up to the skills needed to -- to be able compete, but also if they graduated the quarter of their class, they got a four-year tuition- free ride at any Massachusetts public institution of higher learning.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That happened before you came into office.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That was actually mine, actually, Mr. President.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You got that fact wrong.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, let's come back and talk about the military, but all the way -- all the way through.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: First of all, I'm going through from the very beginning -- we're going to cut about 5 percent of the discretionary budget, excluding military.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The good news is (inaudible).
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'd be happy to have you take a look.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You look at how we get to a balanced budget within eight to 10 years.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We do it by getting -- by reducing spending in a whole series of programs.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: By the way, number one I get rid of is Obamacare.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: There are a number of things that sound good, but frankly, we just can't afford them.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And that one doesn't sound good and it's not affordable.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So I'd get rid of that one from day one.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: To the extent humanly possible, we get that out.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We take program after program that we don't absolutely have to have, and we get rid of them.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number two, we take some programs that we are doing to keep, like Medicaid, which is a program for the poor; we'll take that healthcare program for the poor and we give it to the states to run because states run these programs more efficiently.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: As a governor, I thought please, give me this program.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I can run this more efficiently than the federal government and states, by the way, are proving it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: States like Arizona, Rhode Island have taken these -- these Medicaid dollars; have shown they can run these programs more cost-effectively.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I want to do those two things and get this -- get this to a balanced budget with eight -- eight to 10 years.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But the military -- let's get back to the military, though.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: He should have answered the first question.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Look, Governor Romney's called for $5 trillion of tax cuts that he says he's going to pay for by closing deductions.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, the math doesn't work, but he continues to claim that he's going to do it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: He then wants to spend another $2 trillion on military spending that our military is not asking for.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, keep in mind that our military spending has gone up every single year that I've been in office.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We spend more on our military than the next 10 countries combined; China, Russia, France, the United Kingdom, you name it.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And what I did was work with our joint chiefs of staff to think about, what are we going to need in the future to make sure that we are safe?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's the budget that we've put forward.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But, what you can't do is spend $2 trillion in additional military spending that the military is not asking for, $5 trillion on tax cuts.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You say that you're going to pay for it by closing loopholes and deductions, without naming what those loopholes and deductions are.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And then somehow you're also going to deal with the deficit that we've already got.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The math simply doesn't work.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But when it comes to our military, what we have to think about is not, you know just budgets, we've got to think about capabilities.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We need to be thinking about cyber security.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We need to be talking about space.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's exactly what our budget does, but it's driven by strategy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's not driven by politics.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's not driven by members of Congress, and what they would like to see.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's driven by, what are we going to need to keep the American people safe?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's exactly what our budget does, and it also then allows us to reduce our deficit, which is a significant national security concern.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Because we've got to make sure that our economy is strong at home so that we can project military power overseas.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I'm pleased that I've balanced budgets.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I was on the world of business for 25 years.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: If you didn't balance your budget, you went out of business.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I went into the Olympics that was out of balance, and we got it on balance, and made a success there.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I had the chance to be governor of a state.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Four years in a row, Democrats and Republicans came together to balance the budget.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We cut taxes 19 times and balanced our budget.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The president hasn't balanced a budget yet.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I expect to have the opportunity to do so myself.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm going to be able to balance the budget.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Let's talk about military spending, and that's this.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The Navy said they needed 313 ships to carry out their mission.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're now at under 285.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're headed down to the low 200s if we go through a sequestration.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I want to make sure that we have the ships that are required by our Navy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We've changed for the first time since FDR -- since FDR we had the -- we've always had the strategy of saying we could fight in two conflicts at once.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Now we're changing to one conflict.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Look, this, in my view, is the highest responsibility of the President of the United States, which is to maintain the safety of the American people.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I will not cut our military budget by a trillion dollars, which is a combination of the budget cuts the president has, as well as the sequestration cuts.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That, in my view, is making -- is making our future less certain and less secure.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Bob, I just need to comment on this.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: First of all, the sequester is not something that I've proposed.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It is something that Congress has proposed.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The budget that we are talking about is not reducing our military spending.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You mentioned the Navy, for example, and that we have fewer ships than we did in 1916.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, Governor, we also have fewer horses and bayonets, because the nature of our military's changed.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We have these things called aircraft carriers, where planes land on them.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We have these ships that go underwater, nuclear submarines.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so the question is not a game of Battleship, where we're counting slips.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's what are our capabilities.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so when I sit down with the Secretary of the Navy and the Joint Chiefs of Staff, we determine how are we going to be best able to meet all of our defense needs in a way that also keeps faith with our troops, that also makes sure that our veterans have the kind of support that they need when they come home.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that is not reflected in the kind of budget that you're putting forward because it just doesn't work.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, you know, we visited the website quite a bit and it still doesn't work.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: First of all, Israel is a true friend.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It is our greatest ally in the region.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And if Israel is attacked, America will stand with Israel.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I've made that clear throughout my presidency.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I will stand with Israel if they are attacked.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And this is the reason why, working with Israel, we have created the strongest military and intelligence cooperation between our two countries in history.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In fact, this week we'll be carrying out the largest military exercise with Israel in history, this very week.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But to the issue of Iran, as long as I'm president of the United States Iran will not get a nuclear weapon.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I made that clear when I came into office.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We then organized the strongest coalition and the strongest sanctions against Iran in history, and it is crippling their economy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Their currency has dropped 80 percent.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Their oil production has plunged to the lowest level since they were fighting a war with Iraq 20 years ago.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So their economy is in a shambles.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the reason we did this is because a nuclear Iran is a threat to our national security, and it is a threat to Israel's national security.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We cannot afford to have a nuclear arms race in the most volatile region of the world.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Iran is a state sponsor of terrorism.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And for them to be able to provide nuclear technology to non-state actors, that's unacceptable.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And they have said that they want to see Israel wiped off the map.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So the work that we've done with respect to sanctions now offers Iran a choice.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They can take the diplomatic route and end their nuclear program or they will have to face a united world and a United States president, me, who said we're not going to take any options off the table.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The disagreement I have with Governor Romney is that, during the course of this campaign, he's often talked as if we should take premature military action.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I think that would be a mistake, because when I've sent young men and women into harm's way, I always understand that that is the last resort, not the first resort.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, first of all, I want to underscore the same point the president mad,e which is that if I'm President of the United States, when I'm President of the United States, we will stand with Israel.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And if Israel is attacked, we have their back, not just diplomatically, not just culturally, but militarily.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number two, with regards to Iran and the threat of Iran, there's no question but that a nuclear Iran, a nuclear-capable Iran is unacceptable to America.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It presents a threat not only to our friends but ultimately a threat to us to have Iran have nuclear material, nuclear weapons that could be used against us or used to be threatening to us.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It is also essential for us to understand what our mission is in Iran, and that is to dissuade Iran from having a nuclear weapon through peaceful and diplomatic means.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And crippling sanctions are something I called for five years ago, when I was in Israel, speaking at the Herzliya Conference.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I laid out seven steps, crippling sanctions were number one.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You're seeing it right now in the economy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's absolutely the right thing to do, to have crippling sanctions.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I would have put them in place earlier.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But it's good that we have them.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number two, something I would add today is I would tighten those sanctions.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I would say that ships that carry Iranian oil, can't come into our ports.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: would agree with us as well.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Not only ships couldn't, but I'd say companies that are moving their oil can't, people who are trading in their oil can't.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I would tighten those sanctions further.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Secondly, I'd take on diplomatic isolation efforts.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'd make sure that Ahmadinejad is indicted under the Genocide Convention.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: His words amount to genocide incitation.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I would indict him for it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I would also make sure that their diplomats are treated like the pariah they are around the world.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The same way we treated the apartheid diplomats of South Africa.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We need to increase pressure time, and time again on Iran because anything other than a -- a -- a solution to this, which says -- which stops this -- this nuclear folly of theirs, is unacceptable to America.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And of course, a military action is the last resort.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It is something one would only - only consider if all of the other avenues had been -- had been tried to their full extent.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, first of all those are reports in the newspaper.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But our goal is to get Iran to recognize it needs to give up its nuclear program and abide by the U.N. resolutions that have been in place.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Because they have the opportunity to reenter the community of nations, and we would welcome that.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There -- there are people in Iran who have the same aspirations as people all around the world for a better life.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we hope that their leadership takes the right decision, but the deal we'll accept is they end their nuclear program.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I'm glad that Governor Romney agrees with the steps that we're taking.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, there have been times, Governor, frankly, during the course of this campaign, where it sounded like you thought that you'd do the same things we did, but you'd say them louder and somehow that -- that would make a difference.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And it turns out that the work involved in setting up these crippling sanctions is painstaking.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We started from the day we got into office.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the reason is was so important -- and this is a testament to how we've restored American credibility and strength around the world -- is we had to make sure that all the countries participated, even countries like Russia and China.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Because if it's just us that are imposing sanctions -- we've had sanctions in place a long time.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It's because we got everybody to agree that Iran is seeing so much pressure.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we've got to maintain that pressure.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There is a deal to be had, and that is that they abide by the rules that have already been established.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They convince the international community they are not pursuing a nuclear program.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: There are inspections that are very intrusive.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But over time, what they can do is regain credibility.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In the meantime, though, we're not going to let up the pressure until we have clear evidence that that takes place.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And one last thing -- just -- just to make this point.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We're not going to allow Iran to perpetually engage in negotiations that lead nowhere.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I've been very clear to them.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, because of the intelligence coordination that we do with a range of countries, including Israel, we have a sense of when they would get breakout capacity, which means that we would not be able to intervene in time to stop their nuclear program.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that clock is ticking.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I think from the very beginning, one of the challenges we've had with Iran is that they have looked at this administration, and felt that the administration was not as strong as it needed to be.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I think they saw weakness where they had expected to find American strength.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I say that because from the very beginning, the president in his campaign four years ago, said he would meet with all the world's worst actors in his first year, he'd sit down with Chavez and Kim Jong-il, with Castro and President Ahmadinejad of Iran.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I think they looked and thought, well, that's an unusual honor to receive from the President of the United States.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And then the president began what I have called an apology tour, of going to various nations in the Middle East and criticizing America.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I think they looked at that and saw weakness.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Then when there were dissidents in the streets of Tehran, a Green Revolution, holding signs saying, is America with us, the president was silent.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I think they noticed that as well.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I think that when the president said he was going to create daylight between ourselves and Israel, that they noticed that as well.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: All of these things suggested, I think, to the Iranian mullahs that, hey, you know, we can keep on pushing along here, we can keep talks going on, we're just going to keep on spinning centrifuges.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Now there are some 10,000 centrifuges spinning uranium, preparing to create a nuclear threat to the United States and to the world.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's unacceptable for us, and it's essential for a president to show strength from the very beginning, to make it very clear what is acceptable and not acceptable.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And an Iranian nuclear program is not acceptable to us.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They must not develop nuclear capability.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They need to be tightened.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Our diplomatic isolation needs to be tougher.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We need to indict Ahmadinejad.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We need to put the pressure on them as hard as we possibly can, because if we do that, we won't have to take the military action.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Bob, let me just respond.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Nothing Governor Romney just said is true, starting with this notion of me apologizing.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: This has been probably the biggest whopper that's been told during the course of this campaign.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And every fact checker and every reporter who's looked at it, Governor, has said this is not true.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And when it comes to tightening sanctions, look, as I said before, we've put in the toughest, most crippling sanctions ever.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the fact is, while we were coordinating an international coalition to make sure these sanctions were effective, you were still invested in a Chinese state oil company that was doing business with the Iranian oil sector.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So I'll let the American people decide, judge, who's going to be more effective and more credible when it comes to imposing crippling sanctions.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And with respect to our attitude about the Iranian revolution, I was very clear about the murderous activities that had taken place and that was contrary to international law and everything that civilized people stand for.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And -- and so the strength that we have shown in Iran is shown by the fact that we've been able to mobilize the world.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: When I came into office, the world was divided.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Iran is at its weakest point, economically, strategically, militarily, then since -- then in many years.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we are going to continue to keep the pressure on to make sure that they do not get a nuclear weapon.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's in America's national interest and that will be the case so long as I'm president.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We're four years closer to a nuclear Iran.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're four years closer to a nuclear Iran.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And -- and -- we should not have wasted these four years to the extent they -- they continue to be able to spin these centrifuges and get that much closer.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Number two, Mr. President, the reason I call it an apology tour is because you went to the Middle East and you flew to Egypt and to Saudi Arabia and to Turkey and Iraq.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And by the way, you skipped Israel, our closest friend in the region, but you went to the other nations.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And by the way, they noticed that you skipped Israel.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And then in those nations, and on Arabic TV, you said that America had been dismissive and derisive.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You said that on occasion America had dictated to other nations.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Mr. President, America has not dictated to other nations.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have freed other nations from dictators.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Bob, let me -- let me respond.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If we're going to talk about trips that we've taken -- when I was a candidate for office, first trip I took was to visit our troops.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And when I went to Israel as a candidate, I didn't take donors.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I went to Yad Beshef (ph), the Holocaust museum there, to remind myself the nature of evil and why our bond with Israel will be unbreakable.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And then I went down to the border towns of Storok (ph), which had experienced missiles raining dowm from Hamas.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I saw families there who showed me there where missiles had come down near their children's bedrooms.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I was reminded of what that would mean if those were my kids.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Which is why as president, we funded an Iron Dome program to stop those missiles.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So that's how I've used my travels, when I travel to Israel and when I travel to the region.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the -- the central question at this point is going to be: Who is going to be credible to all parties involved?
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And they can look at my track record, whether it's Iran sanctions, whether it's dealing with counterterrorism, whether it's supporting democracy, whether it's supporting women's rights, whether it's supporting religious minorities.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And they can say that the President of the United States and the United States of America has stood on the right side of history.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that kind of credibility is precisely why we've been able to show leadership on a wide range of issues facing the world right now.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Bob, let's not go into hypotheticals of that nature.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Our relationship with Israel, my relationship with the prime minister of Israel is such that we would not get a call saying our bombers are on the way, or their fighters are on the way.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is the kind of thing that would have been discussed and thoroughly evaluated well before that kind of --
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But let me -- let me come back -- we can come back.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Let's come back to what the president was speaking about, which is what's happening in the world and the president's statement that things are going so well.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Look, I look at what's happening around the world, and i see Iran four years closer to a bomb.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I see the Middle East with a rising tide of violence, chaos, tumult.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I see jihadists continuing to spread, whether they're rising or just about the same level, hard to precisely measure, but it's clear they're there.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I see Syria with 30,000 civilians dead, Assad still in power.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I see our trade deficit with China, larger than it's -- growing larger every year, as a matter of fact.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I look around the world and I don't feel that you see North Korea, continuing to export their nuclear technology, Russia said they're not going to follow Nunn-Lugar any more.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They're back away from a nuclear proliferation treaty that we had with them.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I look around the world, I don't see our influence growing around the world.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I see our influence receding, in part because of the failure of the president to deal with our economic challenges at home; in part because of our withdrawal from our commitment to our military in the way I think it ought to be; in part because of the -- the -- the turmoil with Israel.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I mean, the president received a letter from 38 Democrat senators saying the tensions with Israel were a real problem.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They asked him, please repair the tension -- Democrat senators -- please repair the tension...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: ... the damage in his -- in his own party.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Governor, the problem is, is that on a whole range of issues, whether it's the Middle East, whether it's Afghanistan, whether it's Iraq, whether it's now Iran, you've been all over the map.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I mean, I'm -- I'm pleased that you now are endorsing our policy of applying diplomatic pressure and potentially having bilateral discussions with the Iranians to end their nuclear program.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But just a few years ago you said that's something you'd never do.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In the same way that you initially opposed a timetable in Afghanistan, now you're for it, although it depends.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In the same way that you say you would have ended the war in Iraq, but recently gave a speech saying that we should have 20,000 more folks in there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The same way that you said that it was mission creep to go after Gadhafi.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: When it comes to going after Osama bin Laden, you said, well, any president would make that call.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But when you were a candidate in 2008, as I was, and I said if I got bin Laden in our sights I would take that shot, you said we shouldn't move heaven and earth to get one man.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And you said we should ask Pakistan for permission.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And if we had asked Pakistan permission, we would not have gotten him.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And it was worth moving heaven and earth to get him.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, after we killed bin Laden I was at ground zero for a memorial and talked to a young women who was four years old when 9/11 happened.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the last conversation she had with her father was him calling from the twin towers, saying "Peyton (ph), I love you and I will always watch over you."
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And for the next decade, she was haunted by that conversation.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And she said to me, "You know, by finally getting bin Laden, that brought some closure to me."
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And when we do things like that -- when we bring those who have harmed us to justice, that sends a message to the world and it tells Peyton (ph) that we did not forget her father.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I make that point because that's the kind of clarity of leadership, and those decisions are not always popular.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Those decisions generally -- generally are not poll-tested.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And even some in my own party, including my current vice president, had the same critique as you did.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But what the American people understand is that I look at what we need to get done to keep the American people safe and to move our interests forward, and I make those decisions.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You can't -- but you can't have the president just lay out a whole series of items without giving me a chance to respond.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, we're going to be finished by 2014, and when I'm president, we'll make sure we bring our troops out by the end of 2014.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The commanders and the generals there are on track to do so.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We've seen progress over the past several years.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The surge has been successful and the training program is proceeding apace.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: There are now a large number of Afghan Security Forces, 350,000 that are ready to step in to provide security and we're going to be able to make that transition by the end of 2014.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So our troops will come home at that point.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I can tell you at the same time, that we will make sure that we look at what's happening in Pakistan, and recognize that what's happening in Pakistan is going to have a major impact on the success in Afghanistan.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I say that because I know a lot of people that feel like we should just brush our hands and walk away.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I don't mean you, Mr. President, but some people in the -- in our nation feel that Pakistan is being nice to us, and that we should walk away fro mthem.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But Pakistan is important to the region, to the world and to us, because Pakistan has 100 nuclear warheads and they're rushing to build a lot more.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They'll have more than Great Britain sometime in the -- in the relatively near future.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They also have the Haqqani Network and the Taliban existent within their country.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And so a Pakistan that falls apart, becomes a failed state, would be of extraordinary danger to Afghanistan and to us.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And so we're going to have to remain helpful in encouraging Pakistan to move towards a more stable government and rebuild the relationship with us.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And that means that our aid that we provide to Pakistan is going to have to be conditioned upon certain benchmarks being met.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So for me, I look at this as both a need to help move Pakistan in the right direction, and also to get Afghanistan to be ready, and they will be ready by the end of 2014.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: When I came into office, we were still bogged down in Iraq and Afghanistan had been drifting for a decade.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We ended the war in Iraq, refocused our attention on Afghanistan, and we did deliver a surge of troops.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That was facilitated in part because we had ended the war in Iraq.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we are now in a position where we have met many of the objectives that got us there in the first place.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Part of what had happened is we'd forgotten why we had gone.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We went because there were people who were responsible for 3,000 American deaths.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And so we decimated Al Qaida's core leadership in the border regions between Afghanistan and Pakistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We then started to build up Afghan forces.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we're now in a position where we can transition out, because there's no reason why Americans should die when Afghans are perfectly capable of defending their own country.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now, that transition has to take place in a responsible fashion.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We've been there a long time, and we've got to make sure that we and our coalition partners are pulling out responsibly and giving Afghans the capabilities that they need.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But what I think the American people recognize is after a decade of war it's time to do some nation building here at home.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And what we can now do is free up some resources, to, for example, put Americans back to work, especially our veterans, rebuilding our roads, our bridges, our schools, making sure that, you know, our veterans are getting the care that they need when it comes to post-traumatic stress disorder and traumatic brain injury, making sure that the certifications that they need for good jobs of the future are in place.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You know, I was having lunch with some -- a veteran in Minnesota who had been a medic dealing with the most extreme circumstances.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: When he came home and he wanted to become a nurse, he had to start from scratch.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And what we've said is let's change those certifications.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The first lady has done great work with an organization called Joining Forces putting our veterans back to work.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And as a consequence, veterans' unemployment is actually now lower than general population.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: It was higher when I came into office.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So those are the kinds of things that we can now do because we're making that transition in Afghanistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: No, it's not time to divorce a nation on Earth that has 100 nuclear weapons and is on the way to double that at some point, a nation that has serious threats from terrorist groups within its nation, as I indicated before, the Taliban, Haqqani Network.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's a nation that's not like -- like others and it does not have a civilian leadership that is calling the shots there.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You have the ISI, their intelligence organization, is probably the most powerful of the -- of three branches there.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Then you have the military and then you have the civilian government.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is a nation, which, if it falls apart, if it -- if it becomes a failed state, there are nuclear weapons there and you've got -- you've got terrorists there who could grab their -- their hands onto those nuclear weapons.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is -- this is an important part of the world for us.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Pakistan is -- is technically an ally, and they're not acting very much like an ally right now.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But we have some work to do.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I -- I don't blame the administration for the fact that the relationship with Pakistan is strained.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We -- we had to go into Pakistan.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We had to go in there to get Osama bin Laden.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That was the right thing to do.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And -- and that upset them, but obviously there was a great deal of anger even before that.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But we're going to have to work with the -- with the people in Pakistan to try and help them move to a more responsible course than the one that they're on.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And it's important for them.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's important for the nuclear weapons.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's important for the success of Afghanistan.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Because inside Pakistan, you have a -- a large group of Pashtun that are -- that are Taliban.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And that's one of the reasons the Afghan Security Forces have so much work to do to be able to fight against that.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But it's important for us to recognize that we can't just walk away from Pakistan.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But we do need to make sure that as we -- as we send support for them, that this is tied to them making progress on -- on matters that would lead them to becoming a civil society.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And it's widely reported that drones are being used in drone strikes, and I support that and entirely, and feel the president was right to up the usage of that technology, and believe that we should continue to use it, to continue to go after the people that represent a threat to this nation and to our friends.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But let me also note that as I said earlier, we're going to have to do more than just going after leaders and -- and killing bad guys, important as that is.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're also going to have to have a farm more effective and comprehensive strategy to help move the world away from terror and Islamic extremism.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We haven't done that yet.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We talk a lot about these things, but you look at the -- the record, you look at the record.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You look at the record of the last four years and say is Iran closer to a bomb?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Is the Middle East in tumult?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Is -- is al-Qaida on the run, on its heels?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Is -- are Israel and the Palestinians closer to reaching a peace agreement?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: No, they haven't had talks in two years.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have not seen the progress we need to have, and I'm convinced that with strong leadership and an effort to build a strategy based upon helping these nations reject extremism, we can see the kind of peace and prosperity the world demands.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, keep in mind our strategy wasn't just going after bin Laden.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We created partnerships throughout the region to deal with extremism in Somalia, in Yemen, in Pakistan.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And what we've also done is engaged these governments in the kind of reforms that are actually going to make a difference in people's lives day to day, to make sure that their governments aren't corrupt, to make sure that they're treating women with the kind of respect and dignity that every nation that succeeds has shown and to make sure that they've got a free market system that works.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So across the board, we are engaging them in building capacity in these countries.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we have stood on the side of democracy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: One thing I think Americans should be proud of, when Tunisians began to protest, this nation -- me, my administration -- stood with them earlier than just about any country.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In Egypt we stood on the side of democracy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In Libya we stood on the side of the people.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And as a consequence, there's no doubt that attitudes about Americans have changed.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But there are always going to be elements in these countries that potentially threaten the United States.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we want to shrink those groups and those networks and we can do that.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But we're always also going to have to maintain vigilance when it comes to terrorist activities.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The truth, though, is that Al Qaeda is much weaker than it was when I came into office.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And they don't have the same capacities to attack the U.S. homeland and our allies as they did four years ago.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, I think it will continue to be terrorist networks.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But with respect to China, China is both an adversary, but also a potential partner in the international community if it's following the rules.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So my attitude coming into office was that we are going to insist that China plays by the same rules as everybody else.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I know Americans had seen jobs being shipped overseas; businesses and workers not getting a level playing field when it came to trade.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And that's the reason why I set up a trade task force to go after cheaters when it came to international trade.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's the reason why we have brought more cases against China for violating trade rules than the other -- the previous administration had done in two terms.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we've won just about every case that we've filed, that has been decided.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: In fact, just recently steelworkers in Ohio and throughout the Midwest -- Pennsylvania -- are in a position now to sell steel to China because we won that case.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We had a tire case in which they were flooding us with cheap domestic tires -- or -- or cheap Chinese tires.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we put a stop to it and as a consequence saved jobs throughout America.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I have to say that Governor Romney criticized me for being too tough in that tire case; said this wouldn't be good for American workers and that it would be protectionist.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I tell you, those workers don't feel that way.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They feel as if they had finally an administration who was going to take this issue seriously.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Over the long term, in order for us to compete with China, we've also got to make sure, though, that we're taking -- taking care of business here at home.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If we don't have the best education system in the world, if we don't continue to put money into research and technology that will allow us to create great businesses here in the United States, that's how we lose the competition.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, unfortunately, Governor Romney's budget and his proposals would not allow us to make those investments.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Well, first of all, it's not government that makes business successful.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's not government investments that makes businesses grow and hire people.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Let me also note that the greatest threat that the world faces, the greatest national security threat is a nuclear Iran.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: China has an interest that's very much like ours in one respect, and that is they want a stable world.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They don't want to see protectionism.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They don't want to see the world break out into -- into various forms of chaos, because they have to -- they have to manufacture goods and put people to work and they have about 20,000 -- 20 million, rather, people coming out of the farms every year coming into the cities, needing jobs.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So they want the economy to work and the world to be free and open.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And so we can be a partner with China.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We don't have to be an adversary in any way, shape or form.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We can work with them, we can collaborate with them, if they're willing to be responsible.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Now, they look at us and say, Is it a good idea to be with America?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: How strong are we going to be?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: How strong is our economy?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They look at the fact that we owe 'em a trillion dollars and owe other people $16 trillion in total, including that.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They look at our -- our decision to -- to cut back on our military capabilities.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The secretary of defense called these trillion dollars of cuts to our military devastating.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's not my term, it's the president's own secretary of defense called these trillion dollars of cuts to our military devastating.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's not my term, it's the president's own Secretary of Defense, called them devastating.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They look at America's commitments around the world and they see what's happening, and they say, well, OK. Is America going to be strong?
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And the answer is, yes, if I'm president, America will be very strong.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We'll also make sure that we have trade relations with China that work for us.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I've watched year in and year out as companies have shut down and people have lost their jobs because China has not played by the same rules, in part by holding down artificially the value of their currency.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It holds down the prices of their goods.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It means our goods aren't as competitive and we lose jobs.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They're making some progress; they need to make more.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's why on day one, i will label them a currency manipulator, which allows us to apply tariffs where they're taking jobs.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They're stealing our intellectual property, our patents, our designs, our technology, hacking into our computers, counterfeiting our goods.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They have to understand we want to trade with them.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We want a world that's stable.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We like free enterprise, but you got to play by the rules.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, they sell us about this much stuff every year, and we sell them about this much stuff every year.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: So it's pretty clear who doesn't want a trade war.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And there's one going on right now, which we don't know about it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney
