Text: We have enormous trade imbalance with China, and it's worse this year than last year, and it's worse last year than the year before.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And so we have to understand that we can't just surrender and lose jobs year in and year out.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have to say to our friend in China, look, you guys are playing aggressively.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But this can't keep on going.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You can't keep on holding down the value of your currency, stealing our intellectual property, counterfeiting our products, selling them around the world, even to the United States.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I was with one company that makes valves and -- and process industries and they said, look, we were -- we were having some valves coming in that -- that were broken and we had to repair them under warranty and we looked them and -- and they had our serial number on them.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And then we noticed that there was more than one with that same serial number.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They were counterfeit products being made overseas with the same serial number as a U.S. company, the same packaging, these were being sold into our market and around the world as if they were made by the U.S. competitor.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I want a great relationship with China.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: China can be our partner, but -- but that doesn't mean they can just roll all over us and steal our jobs on an unfair basis.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, Governor Romney's right, you are familiar with jobs being shipped overseas because you invested in companies that were shipping jobs overseas.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And, you know, that's -- you're right.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I mean that's how our free market works.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But I've made a different bet on American workers.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If we had taken your advice Governor Romney about our auto industry, we'd be buying cars from China instead of selling cars to China.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: If we take your advice with respect to how we change our tax codes so that companies that earn profits overseas don't pay U.S. taxes compared to companies here that are paying taxes.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now that's estimated to create 800,000 jobs, the problem is they won't be here, they'll be in places like China.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And if we're not making investments in education and basic research, which is not something that the private sector is doing at a sufficient pace right now and has never done, then we will lose the (inaudible) in things like clean energy technology.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Now with respect to what we've done with China already, U.S. exports have doubled since I came into office, to China and actually currencies are at their most advantageous point for U.S. exporters since 1993.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We absolutely have to make more progress and that's why we're going to keep on pressing.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And when it comes to our military and Chinese security, part of the reason that we were able to pivot to the Asia-Pacific region after having ended the war in Iraq and transitioning out of Afghanistan, is precisely because this is going to be a massive growth area in the future.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we believe China can be a partner, but we're also sending a very clear signal that America is a Pacific power; that we are going to have a presence there.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: We are working with countries in the region to make sure, for example, that ships can pass through; that commerce continues.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we're organizing trade relations with countries other than China so that China starts feeling more pressure about meeting basic international standards.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's the kind of leadership we've shown in the region.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's the kind of leadership that we'll continue to show.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I just want to take one of those points, again, attacking me as not talking about an agenda for -- for getting more trade and opening up more jobs in this country.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But the president mentioned the auto industry and that somehow I would be in favor of jobs being elsewhere.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Nothing could be further from the truth.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm a son of Detroit.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And I would do nothing to hurt the U.S. auto industry.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: My plan to get the industry on its feet when it was in real trouble was not to start writing checks.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It was President Bush that wrote the first checks.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I said they need -- these companies need to go through a managed bankruptcy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And in that process, they can get government help and government guarantees, but they need to go through bankruptcy to get rid of excess cost and the debt burden that they'd -- they'd built up.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Governor Romney, that's not what you said...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Governor Romney, you did not...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You did not say that you would provide government help.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I said that we would provide guarantees, and -- and that was what was able to allow these companies to go through bankruptcy, to come out of bankruptcy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Under no circumstances would I do anything other than to help this industry get on its feet.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And the idea that has been suggested that I would liquidate the industry, of course not.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's the height of silliness...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Let -- let -- let's...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I have never said I would liquidate...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: ...I would liquidate the industry.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Governor, the people in Detroit don't forget.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: ...and -- and that's why I have the kind of commitment to ensure that our industries in this country can compete and be successful.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We in this country can -- can compete successfully with anyone in the world, and we're going to.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're going to have to have a president, however, that doesn't think that somehow the government investing in -- in car companies like Tesla and -- and Fisker, making electric battery cars.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is not research, Mr President, these are the government investing in companies.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This is a company, this isn't basic research.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I -- I want to invest in research.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Providing funding to universities and think tanks is great.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: That's the wrong way to go.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The fact of the matter is...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: So I want to make sure that we make -- we make America more competitive.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And that we do those things that make America the most attractive place in the world for entrepreneurs, innovators, businesses to grow.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But you're investing in companies doesn't do that.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: In fact it makes it less likely for them to come here...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: ...because the private sector's not going to invest in a...
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm -- I'm -- I'm happy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: ...you've had the floor for a while.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: The -- look, I think anybody out there can check the record.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Governor Romney, you keep on trying to, you know airbrush history here.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You were very clear that you would not provide, government assistance to the U.S. auto companies, even if they went through bankruptcy.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You said that they could get it in the private marketplace.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: They would have gone through a...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: ...they would have gone through a...
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: No, I am not wrong.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: People can look it up, you're right.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: People will look it up.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: But more importantly it is true that in order for us to be competitive, we're going to have to make some smart choices right now.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Cutting our education budget, that's not a smart choice.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That will not help us compete with China.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Cutting our investments in research and technology, that's not a smart choice.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That will not help us compete with China.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Bringing down our deficit by adding $7 trillion of tax cuts and military spending that our military is not asking for, before we even get to the debt that we currently have, that is not going to make us more competitive.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Those are the kinds of choices that the American people face right now.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Having a tax code that rewards companies that are shipping jobs overseas instead of companies that are investing here in the United States, that will not make us more competitive.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And the one thing that I'm absolutely clear about is that after a decade in which we saw drift, jobs being shipped overseas, nobody championing American workers and American businesses, we've now begun to make some real progress.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: What we can't do is go back to the same policies that got us into such difficulty in the first place.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: That's why we have to move forward and not go back.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I couldn't agree more about going forward, but I certainly don't want to go back to the policies of the last four years.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The policies of the last four years have seen incomes in America decline every year for middle income families, now down $4,300 during your term.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Twenty-three million Americans still struggling to find a good job.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: When you came to office 32 million people on food stamps.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Today, 47 million people on food stamps.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: When you came to office, just over $10 trillion in debt, now $16 trillion in debt.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: You said by now we'd be at 5.4 percent unemployment.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We're 9 million jobs short of that.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I've met some of those people.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I've met them in Appleton, Wisconsin.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I met a young woman in -- in Philadelphia who's coming out of -- out of college, can't find work.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I've been -- Ann was with someone just the other day that was just weeping about not being able to get work.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: It's just a tragedy in a nation so prosperous as ours, that the last four years have been so hard.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And that's why it's so critical, that we make America once again the most attractive place in the world to start businesses, to build jobs, to grow the economy.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And that's not going to happen by just hiring teachers.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Look, I love to -- I love teachers, and I'm happy to have states and communities that want to hire teachers do that.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: By the way, I don't like to have the federal government start pushing its weight deeper and deeper into our schools.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Let the states and localities do that.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The federal government didn't hire our teachers.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: But I want to get our private sector growing and I know how to do it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Well, thank you very much, Bob, Governor Romney, and to Lynn University.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: You've now heard three debates, months of campaigning and way too many TV commercials.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And now you've got a choice.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Over the last four years we've made real progress digging our way out of policies that gave us two prolonged wars, record deficits and the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And Governor Romney wants to take us back to those policies, a foreign policy that's wrong and reckless, economic policies that won't create jobs, won't reduce our deficit, but will make sure that folks at the very top don't have to play by the same rules that you do.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I've got a different vision for America.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I want to build on our strengths.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And I've put forward a plan to make sure that we're bringing manufacturing jobs back to our shores by rewarding companies and small businesses that are investing here, not overseas.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I want to make sure we've got the best education system in the world.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: And we're retaining our workers for the jobs of tomorrow.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I want to control our own energy by developing oil and natural gas but also the energy sources of the future.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: As Commander in Chief, I will maintain the strongest military in the world, keep faith with our troops and go after those who would do us harm.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: but after a decade of war, I think we all recognize we've got to do some nation building here at home, rebuilding our roads, our bridges and especially caring for our Veterans who sacrificed so much for our freedom.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: I will fight for your families and I will work every single day to make sure that America continues to be the greatest nation on earth.
Speaker: Barack Obama

Text: Bob, Mr. President, folks at Lynn University, good to be with you.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm excited about our prospects as a nation.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I want to see peace.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I want to see growing peace in this country.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We have an opportunity to have real leadership.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: America's going to have that kind of leadership and continue to promote principles of peace to make a world a safer place and make people in this country more confident that their future is secure.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I also want to make sure that we get this economy going.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: And there are two very different paths the country can take.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: One is a path represented by the president, which at the end of four years would mean we'd have $20 trillion in debt heading towards Greece.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'll get us on track to a balanced budget.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The president's path will mean continuing declining in take-home pay.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I want to make sure our take-home pay turns around and starts to grow.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The president's path will mean continuing declining in take-home pay.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I want to make sure take-home pay turns around and starts to grow.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: The president's path means 20 million people out of work struggling for a good job.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'll get people back to work with 12 million new jobs.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm going to make sure that we get people off of food stamps, not by cutting the program, but by getting them good jobs.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: America's going to come back, and for that to happen, we're going to have to have a president who can work across the aisle.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I learned how to get along on the other side of the aisle.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We've got to do that in Washington.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I know what it takes to get this country back, and will work with good Democrats and good Republicans to do that.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: This nation is the hope of the earth.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: We've been blessed by having a nation that's free and prosperous thanks to the contributions of the greatest generation.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: They've held a torch for the world to see -- the torch of freedom and hope and opportunity.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: Now, it's our turn to take that torch.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm convinced we'll do it.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'd like to be that leader with your support.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'll lead you in an open and honest way, and I ask for your vote.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'd like to be the next president of the United States to support and help this great nation and to make sure that we all together remain America as the hope of the earth.
Speaker: Mitt Romney

Text: I'm glad you clarified that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Mr. Hankins, I don't feel good about it, and I think we ought to have a patient's bill of rights to take the medical decisions away from the HMOs and give them back to the doctors and nurses.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I want to come back and tell you why, but if you will forgive me, I would like to say something right now at the beginning of this debate following on the moment of silence for Mel Carnahan and Randy Carnahan and Chris Sifford.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Tipper and I were good friends with Mel and Randy, and I know that all of us here want to extend our sympathy and condolences to Jean and the family and to the Sifford family.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I would just like to say that this debate in a way is a living tribute to Mel Carnahan because he loved the vigorous discussion of ideas in our democracy.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: He was a fantastic governor of Missouri.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: This state became one of the top five in the nation for health care coverage for children under his leadership.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: One of the best in advancing all kinds of benefits for children to grow up healthy and strong.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And of course, this debate also takes place at a time when the tragedy of the USS Cole is on our minds and hearts and insofar as the memorial service is tomorrow, I would like to also extend sympathy to the families of those who have died and those who are still missing, and the injured.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, Mr. Hankins, I think that the situation that you describe has gotten completely out of hand.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Doctors are giving prescriptions, they're recommending treatments, and then their recommendations are being overruled by HMOs and insurance companies.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I support a strong national patient's bill of rights.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It is actually a disagreement between us, a national law that is pending on this, the Dingle-Norwood bill, a bipartisan bill, is one that I support and that the governor does not.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I, too, want to extend my prayers and blessings, God's blessings on the families whose lives were overturned yes -- tod -- last night.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Actually, Mr. Vice President, it's not true.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I do support a national patient's bill of rights.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: As a matter of fact, I brought Republicans and Democrats together to do just that in the State of Texas to get a patient's bill of rights through.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It requires a different kind of leadership style to do it, though.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You see, in order to get something done on behalf of the people, you have to put partisanship aside, and that's what we did in my state.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We have one of the most advanced patient's bill of rights.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It says, for example, that a woman doesn't have to go through a gate keeper to go to her gynecologist.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It says that you can't gag a doctor, doctor can advise you.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The HMO, the insurance company, can't gag that doctor from giving you full advice.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And this particular bill, it allows patients to choose a doctor, their own doctor if they want to.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But we did something else that was interesting.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're one of the first states that said you can sue an HMO for denying you proper coverage.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Now there's what's called an Independent Review Organization that you have to go through first.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It says if youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve got a complaint with your insurance company, you can take your complaint to an objective body.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If the objective body rules on your behalf, the insurance company must follow those rules.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: However, if the insurance company doesn't follow the findings of the IRO, then that becomes a cause of action in a court of law.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's time for our nation to come together and do what's right for the people, and I think this is right for the people.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You know, I support a national patient's bill of rights, Mr. Vice President, and I want all people covered.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't want the law to supersede good law like we've got in Texas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Jim, we have a direct disagreement on this.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I referred to the Dingle-Norwood bill.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It is the bipartisan bill that is now pending in the Congress.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The HMOs and the insurance companies support the other bill that's pending, the one that the Republican majority has put forward.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: They like it because it doesn't accomplish what I think really needs to be accomplished to give the decisions back to the doctors and nurses and give you a right of appeal to somebody other than the HMO or insurance company, let you go to the nearest emergency room without having to call an HMO before you call 911, to let you see a specialist if you need to, and it has strong bipartisan support.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It is being blocked by the Republican leadership in the Congress.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I specifically would like to know whether Governor Bush will support the Dingle-Norwood bill, which is the main one pending.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Well, the difference is is that I can get it done.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That I can get something positive done on behalf of the people.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's what the question in this campaign is about.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's not only what's your philosophy and what's your position on issues, but can you get things done?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I believe I can.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: What about the Dingle-Norwood bill?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I talked about the principles and the issues that I think are important in a patient's bill of rights.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's kind of Washington, D.C. focus.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, it's in this committee or it's got this sponsor.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If I'm the president, we're going to have emergency room care, we're going have gag orders, we're going to have direct access to OB/GYN.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: People will be able to take their HMO insurance company to court.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's what I've done in Texas and that's the kind of leadership style I'll bring to Washington.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, that's a great question.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think one of the problems we have, particularly for seniors, is there is no prescription drug coverage in Medicare.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And therefore, when they have to try to purchase drugs they do so on their own, there's no kind of collective bargaining, no power of purchasing among seniors.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So I think step one to make sure prescription drugs is more affordable for seniors, and those are the folks who really rely upon prescription drugs a lot these days, is to reform the Medicare system, is to have prescription drugs as an integral part of Medicare once and for all.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The problem we have today is like the patient's bill of rights, particularly with health care, there's a lot of bickering in Washington, D.C.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's kind of like a political issue as opposed to a people issue.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So what I want to do is I want to call upon Republicans and Democrats to forget all the arguing and finger pointing, and come together and take care of our seniors' prescription drug program, that says we'll pay for the poor seniors, we'll help all seniors with prescription drugs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In the meantime, I think it's important to have what's called Immediate Helping Hand, which is direct money to states so that seniors, poor seniors, don't have to choose between food and medicine.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's part of an overall overhaul.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I'm against price controls.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think price controls would hurt our ability to continue important research and development.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Drug therapies are replacing a lot of medicines as we used to know it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One of the most important things is to continue the research and development component.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so I'm against price controls.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Expediting drugs through the FDA makes sense, of course.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Allowing the new bill that was passed in the Congress made sense to allow for, you know, drugs that were sold overseas to come back and other countries to come back into the United States.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But the best thing to do is to reform Medicare.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: All right, here we go again.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now look, if you want someone who will spend a lot of words describing a whole convoluted process and then end up supporting legislation that is supported by the big drug companies, this is your man.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you want someone who will fight for you and who will fight for the middle-class families and working men and women, who are sick and tired of having their parents and grandparents pay higher prices for prescription drugs than anybody else, then I want to fight for you.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And you asked a great question because it's not only seniors.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Listen, for 24 years I have never been afraid to take on the big drug companies.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: They do some great things.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: They discover great new cures and that's great.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We want them to continue that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But they are now spending more money on advertising and promotion.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: You see all these ads?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Than they are on research and development.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And they are trying artificially extend the monopoly patent protection so they can keep charging these very high prices.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I want to streamline the approval of the competing generic drugs and the new kinds of treatments that can compete with them so we bring the price down for everybody.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, briefly, let me tell you how my prescription drug plan works.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The governor talked about Medicare.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: You pick your own doctor, and nobody can take that away from you.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The doctor chooses the prescription that you need and nobody can overrule your doctor.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: You go to your own pharmacy and then Medicare pays half the price.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you're poor, they pay all of it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you have extraordinarily high cost, then they pay all over $4,000 out-of-pocket.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I'll bring new competition to bring the price down.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And if you pass the big drug companies' bill, nothing will happen.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that we should move step-by-step toward universal health coverage, but I am not in favor of government doing it all.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We've spent 65 years now on the development of a hybrid system, partly private, partly public, and 85% of our people have health insurance, 15% don't.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: That adds up to 44 million people.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: That is a national outrage.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We have got to get health coverage for those who do not have it and we've got to improve the quality for those who do with a patient's bill of rights that's real and that works, the Dingle-Norwood bill, and we have got to fill in the gaps in coverage by finally bringing parity for the treatment of mental illness, because that's been left out.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We have got to deal with long-term care.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, here are the steps that I would take, first of all.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I will make a commitment to bring health care coverage of high quality that is affordable to every single child in America within four years.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And then we'll fill other gaps by covering the parents of those children when the family is poor or up to two and a half times the poverty rate.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I want to give a tax credit for the purchase of individual health insurance plans.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I want to give small business employers a tax credit, 25%, to encourage the providing of health insurance for the employees in small businesses.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I want to give seniors who are, well, the near elderly, I don't like that term because I am just about in that category, but those 55 to 65 ought to be able to buy into Medicare for premiums that are reasonable and fair and significantly below what they have to get now.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, we have a big difference on this.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And you need to know the record here.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Under Governor Bush, Texas has sunk to be 50th out of 50 in health care -- in health insurance for their citizens.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Last week he said that they were spending 3.7 billion dollars, or 4.7 billion dollars on this.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I'm absolutely opposed to a national health care plan.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't want the federal government making decisions for consumers or for providers.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I remember what the administration tried to do in 1993.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They tried to have a national health care plan.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I trust people, I don't trust the federal government.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's going to be one of the themes you hear tonight.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't want the federal government making decisions on behalf of everybody.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There is an issue with the uninsured, there sure is.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And we have uninsured people in my state.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Ours is a big state, a fast-growing state.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We share a common border with another nation.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But we're providing health care for our people.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One thing about insurance, that's a Washington term.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The question is, are people getting health care, and we have a strong safety net, and there needs to be a safety net in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There needs to be more community health clinics where the poor can go get health care.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We need a program for the uninsured.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They've been talking about it in Washington, D.C.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The number of uninsured has now gone up for the past seven years.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We need a $2,000 credit, rebate for people, working people that don't have insurance, they can get in the marketplace and start purchasing insurance.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We need to have -- allow small businesses to write insurance across jurisdictional lines so small business can afford health care, small restaurants can afford health care.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So health care needs to be affordable and available.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We have to trust people to make decisions with their lives.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In the Medicare reform I talk about it says if you are a senior, you can stay in Medicare if you like it, and that's fine, but we're going to give you other choices to choose if you want to do so, just like they do the federal employees.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The people that work in Washington, D.C. for the U.S. Congress or the United States senate.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Get a variety of choices to make in their lives.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's what we ought to do for all people in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Trying to find my light.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, you know, it's hard to make people love one another.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I wish I knew the law because I would darn sure sign it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I wish I knew the law that said all of us would be good parents.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One of the things the next president must do is to remind people that if we are going to have a responsible period in America, that each of us must love our children with all our heart and all our soul.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I happened to believe strong accountability encourages parental involvement, though.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think when you measure and post results on the Internet or in the town newspapers, most parents say wait a minute, my child's school isn't doing what I want it to do and, therefore, become involved in education.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I recognize there are some who just don't seem to care.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But there are a lot of parents who feel like everything is going well in their child's school, and all of a sudden they wake up and realize that wait a minute, standards aren't being met.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's why I'm so strong for accountability.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe we ought to measure a lot, three, four, five, six, seven, eighth grade.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We do so in my state of Texas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One of the good things we've gone in Texas is we have strong accountability because you can't cure unless you know.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You can't solve a problem unless you diagnose it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I strongly believe that one of the best things to encourage parental involvement also is to know that the classrooms will be safe and secure.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's why I support a teacher liability act at the federal level, that says if a teacher or principal upholds reasonable standards of classroom discipline they can't be sued.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think parents will be more involved with education when they know their children's classrooms are safe and secure as well.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I also believe that we need to say to people that if you cannot meet standards, there has to be a consequence.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Instead of just comes the soft bigotry of low expectations, that there has to be a consequence.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We can't continue to shuffle children through school.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And one of the consequences to allow parents to have different choices.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We have huge difference between us on this question.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I'd like to start by telling you what my vision is.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I see a day in the United States of America where all of our public schools are considered excellent, world class.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Where there are no failing schools, where the classrooms are small enough in size, number of students, so that the teacher can spend enough one-on-one time with each student.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now that means recruiting new teachers for the public schools.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It means in my plan hiring bonuses to get 100,000 new teachers in the public schools within the next four years.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It means also helping local school districts that sometimes find the parents of school age children outvoted on bond issues, to give them some help with interest-free bonding authority so that we can build new schools and modernize the classrooms.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We need to give teachers the training and professional development that they need, including a paid time off to go visit the classroom of a master teacher to pick up some new skills.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I want to give every middle-class family a $10,000 a year tax deduction for college tuition so that middle-class families will always be able to send their kids on to college.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I want to work for universal free school because we know from all the studies that the youngsters learn, kids learn more in the first few years of life than any where else.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, I said there was a contrast.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Governor Bush is for vouchers, and in his plan he proposes to drain more money, more taxpayer money out of the public schools for private school vouchers than all of the money that he proposes in his entire budget for public schools themselves.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And only one in 20 students would be eligible for these vouchers, and they wouldn't even pay the full tuition to private school.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that's a mistake.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I don't think we should give up on the private schools and leave kids trapped in failing schools.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think we -- I think we should make it the number one priority to make our schools the best in the world, all of them.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think any time we end with one of these attacks, it's appropriate to respond.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: First of all, vouchers are up to states.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I strongly believe in local control of schools.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm a governor of state and I don't like it when the federal government tells us what to do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe in local control of schools.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But here's what I said.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've said to the extent we spend federal money on disadvantaged children, we want the schools to show us whether or not the children are learning.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We expect there to be standards met and we expect there to be measurement.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And if we find success we'll praise it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But when we find children trapped in schools that will not change and will not teach, instead of saying oh, this is okay in America just to shuffle poor kids through schools, there has to be a consequence.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And the consequence is that federal portion or federal money will go to the parent, so the parent can go to a tutoring program or another public school or another private school.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You see, there has to be a consequence.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We've got a society that says hey, the status quo is fine, just move them through.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, the program that he's proposing is not the one that he just described.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Described under your plan, Governor Bush, states would be required to pay vouchers to students to match the vouchers so that the federal government would put up.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, you're -- and the way it would happen is that under his plan, if a school was designated as failing, the kids would be trapped there for another three years and then some of them would get federal vouchers and the state would be forced to match those, that money.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Under my plan, if a school is failing, we work with the states to give them the authority and the resources to close down that school and reopen it right away with a new principal, a new faculty, a turn-around team of specialists who know what they're doing.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It's based on the plan of Governor Jim Hunt in North Carolina, and it works great.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If I thought that there was no alternative, then I might feel differently.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But I have an obligation to fight to make sure there are no failing schools.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We have to turn around -- most schools are excellent, but we have to make sure that all of them are.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: What grade do you teach?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I mentioned before that the local communities are having a harder time passing bond issues.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Traditionally, if you've been involved in a campaign like that, you know that the parents with kids in school are the ones that turn out and vote.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It's ironic that there are now -- there is now a smaller percentage of the voters made up of parents with children than ever in American history because of the aging of our population, but at the same time we've got the largest generation of students in public schools ever.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And it's the largest number ever this year and they'll break the record next year and every year for ten years running.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We've got to do something about this.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And local -- it's not enough to leave it up to the local school districts.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: They're not able to do it and our future depends upon it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Look, we're in an information age.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Our economic future depends upon whether or not our children are going to get the kind of education that lets them go on to college.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And again, I want to make it possible for all middle-class families to send their kids to college and more Pell grants for those who are in the lower income groups also, and then I want to make sure that we have job training on top of that and lifelong learning, but it all starts with the public school teachers.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: My proposal gives $10,000 hiring bonuses for those teachers who are -- who get certified to teach in the areas where they're most needed.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, accountability, we basically agree on accountability.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: My plan requires testing of all students.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It also requires something that Governor Bush's plan doesn't.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It requires testing of all new teachers, including in the subjects that they teach.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We have to start treating teachers like the professionals that they are, and give them the respect and the kind of quality of life that will draw more people into teaching because we need a lot more teachers.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: When you total up all the federal spending he wants to do, it's the largest increase in federal spending in years.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And there's just not going to be enough money.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I have been a governor of a big state, I have made education my number one priority.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's what governors ought to do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They ought to say this is the most important thing we do as a state.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The federal government puts about 6% of the money up.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They put about, you know, 60% of the strings where you have to fill out the paperwork.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't know if you have to be a paperwork filler-outer, but most of it's because of the federal government.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: What I want to do is to send flexibility and authority to the local folks so you can choose what to do with the money.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One size does not fit all.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I worry about federalizing education if I were you.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe strongly that the federal government can help, we need to fund Headstart.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We need to have accountability.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The Vice President's plan does not have annual accountability, third grade, fourth grade, fifth grade.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We need to demand on results.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe strongly in a teacher protection act like I mentioned.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I hear from teachers all the time about the lawsuits and the threats, respect in the classroom.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Part of it's because you can't -- you can't control the classroom.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You can't have a consequence for somebody without fear of getting sued under federal law.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So I'm going to ask the Congress to pass a teacher protection act.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So I believe in flexibility, I believe in a national reading initiative for local districts to access with K through 2 diagnostic testing, curriculum that works, phonics works, by the way, it needs to be a part of our curriculum.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There needs to be flexibility for teacher training and teacher hiring with federal money.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The federal government can be a part, but don't fall prey to all this stuff about money here and money there because education is really funded at the local level.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: 94% comes from the local level.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm so glad that I have the chance to knock that down.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Look, the problem is that under Governor Bush's plan, $1.6 trillion tax cut, mostly to the wealthy, under his own budget numbers, he proposes spending more money for a tax cut just for the wealthiest 1% than all the new money he budgets for education, health care and national defense combined.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now under my plan we'll balance the budget every year.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I'm not just saying this.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I have helped to balance the budget for the first time in 30 years, paid down the debt.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And under my plan, in four years, as the percentage of our gross domestic product, federal spending will be the smallest that it has been in 50 years.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: One reason is, you know, the third biggest spending item in our budget is interest on the national debt?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We get nothing for it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We keep the good faith and credit of the United States.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: That gets rid of the third biggest intrusion of the federal government in our economy.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, because the governor has all this money for a tax cut mostly to the wealthy, there is no money left over, so schools get testing and lawsuit reform and not much else.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: (LAUGHTER) Just add up all the numbers.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's three times bigger than what President Clinton proposed.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That was in an ad, Jim, that was knocked down by the journalists who analyzed the ad and said it was misleading.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: He proposed more than Walter Mondale and Michael Dukakis combined.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This is a big spender.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And he ought to be proud of it, it's part of his record.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We just have a different philosophy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Let me talk about tax relief.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If you pay taxes, you ought to get tax relief.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The Vice President believes only the right people ought to get tax relief.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think if you're going to have tax relief, everybody ought to get it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And therefore, wealthy people are going to get it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But the top 1% will end up paying one-third of the taxes in America and they get one-fifth of the benefits.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's because we structured the plan so that six million additional American families pay no taxes.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If you're a family of four making $50,000 in Missouri, you get a 50% cut in your federal income taxes.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: What I've done is set priorities and funded them.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I believe the people who pay the bills ought to get some money back.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's a difference of opinion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He wants to grow the government and I trust you with your own money.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I wish we could spend an hour talking about trusting people.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's just the right position to take.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Can we take the time --
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you pay taxes, you are going to get a benefit.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: People who pay taxes will get tax relief.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Under my plan, if you make -- the top -- the wealthy people pay 62% of the taxes today.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Because the tax code is unfair for people at the bottom end of the economic ladder.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If you're a single mother making $22,000 a year today and you're trying to raise two children, for every additional dollar you earn you pay a higher marginal rate on that dollar than someone making $200,000, and that's not right.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So I want to do something about that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Look, this isn't about Governor Bush, it's not about me.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I want to come back to something I said before.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you want somebody who believes that we were better off eight years ago than we are now and that we ought to go back to the kind of policies that we had back then, emphasizing tax cuts mainly for the wealthy, here is your man.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you want somebody who will fight for you and who will fight to have middle-class tax cuts, then I am your man.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, I doubt anybody here makes more than $330,000 a year.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I won't ask you, but if you do, you're in the top 1%.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I'm not going to ask them.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But if everyone here in this audience was dead on in the middle of the middle-class, then the tax cuts for every single one of you all added up would be less than the tax cut his plan would give to just one member of that top wealthiest 1%.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now you judge for yourselves whether or not that's fair.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: 50 million Americans get no tax relief under his plan.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You may not be one of them, you're just not one of the right people.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And secondly, we've had enough fighting.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You talk about eight years?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: In eight years they haven't gotten anything done on Medicare, on Social Security, a patient's bill of rights.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's time to get something done.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Hey, I've got to answer that, Jim.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Medicare -- I cast the tie-breaking vote to add 26 years to the life of Medicare.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It was due to go bankrupt in 1999 and that 50 million figure again, the newspapers -- I said -- you said forget the journalists, but they are the keepers of the score card and whether or not you're using facts that aren't right.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And that fact is just not right.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I've got a strategy for the Middle East.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And first let me say that our nation now needs to speak with one voice during this time, and I applaud the president for working hard to diffuse tensions.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Our nation needs to be credible and strong.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: When we say we're somebody's friend, everybody has got to believe it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Israel is our friend and we'll stand by Israel.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We need to reach out to moderate Arab nations as well to build coalitions to keep the peace.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I also need -- the next leader needs to be patient.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We can't put the Middle East peace process on our timetable.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's got to be on the timetable of the people that we're trying to bring to the peace table.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We can't dictate the terms of peace, which means that you have to be steady.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You can't worry about polls or focus groups.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You've got to have a clear vision.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's what a leader does.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: A leader also understands that the United States must be strong to keep the peace.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Saddam Hussein still is a threat in the Middle East.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Our coalition against Saddam is unraveling.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The man who may be developing weapons of mass destruction, we don't know because inspectors aren't in.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So to answer your question, it requires a clear vision, a willingness to stand by our friends, and the credibility for people both friend and foe to understand when America says something, we mean it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I see a future when the world is at peace, with the United States of America promoting the values of democracy and human rights and freedom all around the world.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Even in Iran they have had an election that began to bring about some change.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We stand for those values and we have to be willing to assert them.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Right now our military is the strongest in the entire history of the world.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I will -- I pledge to you I will do whatever is necessary to make sure that it stays that way.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, what can I bring to that challenge?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: When I was a young man, my father was a senator opposed to the Vietnam War.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: When I graduated from college, there were plenty of fancy ways to get out of going and being a part of that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I went and I volunteered, and I went to Vietnam.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I didn't do the most or run the greatest risk by a long shot, but I learned what it was like to be an enlisted man in the United States Army.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: In the Congress, in the House of Representatives, I served on the House Intelligence Committee and I worked hard to learn the subject of nuclear arms control and how we can diffuse these tensions and deal with non-proliferation and deal with the problems of terrorism and these new weapons of mass destruction.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Look, we're gonna face some serious new challenges in the next four years.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I've worked on that long and hard.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: When I went to the United States Senate, I asked for an assignment to the Armed Services Committee.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And while I was there I worked on a bipartisan basis, as I did in the House, I worked with former President Reagan on the modernization of our strategic weaponry.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: In the Senate I was one of only ten Democrats, along with Senator Joe Lieberman, to support Governor Bush's dad in the Persian Gulf War Resolution.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And for the last eight years I've served on the National Security Council.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Can I say just one other thing here?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think he gets a -- oh, I'm sorry, you're right, go ahead.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Just to finish briefly, I started to say that for the last eight years I've been on the National Security Council.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Last week I broke up -- I suspended campaigning for two days, or parts of two days, to go back and participate in the meetings that charted the President's summit meeting that he just returned from earlier today.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And our team of -- our country's team over there did a great job.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The United States has to be strong in order to make sure that we can help promote peace and security and stability.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And that means keeping our military strong.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, I said earlier that we are the strongest military, but we need to continue improving readiness and making sure that our military personnel are adequately paid and that the combination of their pay and their benefits and their retirement as veterans is comparable to the stiff competition that's coming in this strong economy from the private sector.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I have supported the largest pay raise in many a year, and I support another one now.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I also support modernization of our strategic and tactical weaponry.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The governor has proposed skipping a generation of technology.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that would be a mistake, because I think one of the ways we've been able to be so successful in Kosovo and Bosnia and Haiti and in other places is by having the technological edge.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: You know, we won that conflict in Kosovo without losing a single human life in combat, a single American life in combat.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The trends before we -- before I got my current job were on the decline, the number of divisions were reduced.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I argued that we should reverse that trend and take it back up.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I'm happy to tell you that we have.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, in my budget for the next ten years I propose $100 billion for this purpose.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The governor proposes $45 billion.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I propose more than twice as much because I think it's needed.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If this were a spending contest, I would come in second.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I readily admit I'm not going to grow the size of the federal government like he is.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It must be in the national interests, must be in our vital interests whether we ever send troops.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The mission must be clear.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Soldiers must understand why we're going.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The force must be strong enough so that the mission can be accomplished.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And the exit strategy needs to be well-defined.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm concerned that we're overdeployed around the world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: See, I think the mission has somewhat become fuzzy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Should I be fortunate enough to earn your confidence, the mission of the United States military will be to be prepared and ready to fight and win war.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And therefore prevent war from happening in the first place.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There may be some moments when we use our troops as peacekeepers, but not often.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The Vice President mentioned my view of long-term for the military.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to make sure the equipment for our military is the best it can possibly be, of course.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But we have an opportunity -- we have an opportunity to use our research and development capacities, the great technology of the United States, to make our military lighter, harder to find, more lethal.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We have an opportunity, really, if you think about it, if we're smart and have got a strategic vision and a leader who understands strategic planning, to make sure that we change the terms of the battlefield of the future so we can keep the peace.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This is a peaceful nation, and I intend to keep the peace.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Spending money is one thing.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But spending money without a strategic plan can oftentimes be wasted.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: First thing I'm going to do is ask the Secretary of Defense to develop a plan so we are making sure we're not spending our money on political projects, but on projects to make sure our soldiers are well-paid, well-housed, and have the best equipment in the world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm sorry, I didn't hear that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't think the National Rifle Association ran that ad.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But let me just tell you my position on guns in general, sir, if you don't mind.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, I don't think I ran the ad.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think somebody who doesn't want me to be president might have run that ad.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think it might have been one of my opponent's ads.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Here is what I believe, sir.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe law-abiding citizens ought to be allowed to protect themselves and their families.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe that we ought to keep guns out of the hands of people that shouldn't have them.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's why I'm for instant background checks at gun shows, I'm for trigger locks, I think that makes sense.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Matter of fact, we distributed free trigger locks in the State of Texas so that people can get them and put them on their guns to make their guns more safe.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think we ought to raise the age at which juveniles can have a gun.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I also believe strongly that we need to enforce laws on the books that the best way to make sure that we keep our society safe and secure is to hold people accountable for breaking the law.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If we catch somebody illegally selling a gun, there needs to be a consequence.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If we keep somebody -- you know, illegally using a gun, there needs to be a consequence.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Enforcement of law, and the federal government can help.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There is a great program called Project Exile in Richmond, Virginia, where we focused federal taxpayers' money and federal prosecutors and went after people who were illegally using guns.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: To me that's how you make society the safest it can be.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so, yeah, sometimes I agree with some of these groups in Washington and sometimes I don't.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm a pretty independent thinker.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The one thing I'm for is a safe society.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I'm for enforcing laws on the books.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's what is going to happen should I earn your confidence.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, it was not one of my ads, either, Governor.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But I am familiar with the statement, and it was made by one of the top-ranking officials of that organization.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Let me tell you my position.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that some common sense gun safety measures are certainly needed with the flood of cheap handguns that have sometimes been working their way into the hands of the wrong people.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But all of my proposals are focused on that problem, gun safety.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: None of my proposals would have any effect on hunters, or sportsmen, or people who use rifles.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: They're aimed at the real problem.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Let's make our schools safe, let's make our neighborhoods safe.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Let's have a three-day waiting period, cooling off, so we can have a background check to make sure that criminals and people who really shouldn't have guns don't get them.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But I would like to use my remaining time on this exchange, Jim, to respond to an exchange that took place just a moment ago.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Because a couple of times the governor has said that I am for a bigger government.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And let me tell you what the record shows.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: For the last eight years I have had the challenge of running the streamlining program called Reinventing Government.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And if there are any federal employees in this group, you know what that means.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The federal government has been reduced in size by more than 300,000 people.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And it's now the smallest number that we have had since the -- the smallest in size since John Kennedy's administration.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: During the last five years, Texas's government has gone up in size.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Federal government has gone down, Texas's government has gone up.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, my plan for the future, I see a time when we have smaller, smarter government where you don't have to wait in line because you can get services online cheaper, better, faster.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We've got a bumper crop this year.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But that's the good news.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: You know what the bad news is that follows on that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: In the last several years, the so-called Freedom To Farm Law has, in my view, been mostly a failure.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I want to change many of its provisions.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Because the 2% of the country that is involved in farming is important because the rest of us wouldn't eat except for them.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And you guys have been having a hard time, and I want to fight for you.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I want to change those provisions.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I want to restore a meaningful safety net.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I think that you pointed the way in your comments, because when you say there are multiple things accomplished by farmers, you're specifically including conservation and protection of the environment.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And yes, farmers are the first environmentalists.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And when they decide not to plow a field that is vulnerable to soil erosion, that may cost them a little money, but it helps the environment.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that we ought to have an expanded conservation reserve program.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I think that the environmental benefits that come from sound management of the land ought to represent a new way for farmers to get some income that will enable them -- enable you to make sensible choices in crop rotation, and when you leave the land fallow and the rest.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, I'll go beyond that and say I think we need much more focus on rural economic development programs.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I see a time when the Internet-based activities are more available in the rural areas and where the extra source of income that farm families used to have from shoe factories is replaced by an extra source of income from working in the information economy.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: So we need to do a lot of things, but we ought to start with a better safety net.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I would like our farmers feeding the world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're the best producers in the world, and I want -- I want the farmers feeding the world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We need to open up markets.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Exports are down, and every time an export number goes down, it hurts the farmer.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want the next president to have fast track negotiating authority to open up markets around the world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re the best and the most efficient farmers.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't want to use food as a diplomatic weapon from this point forward.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We shouldn't be using food.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's not the right thing to do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We need more work on value-added processing.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You take the raw product you produce, I presume you're a farmer, off your farm, and you convert it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm for research and development.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Spending research and development money so that we can use our technological base to figure out new uses for farm products.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm for getting rid of the death tax, completely getting rid of the death tax.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One reason family farmers are forced to sell early is because of the death tax.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: This is a bad tax.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The President shouldn't have vetoed that bill.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's a tax that taxes people twice.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It penalizes the family farmer.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So should I be fortunate enough to earn your vote, I also understand -- I want to open up markets, but I also understand that farming is a part of our national security.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm from a big farm state.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We're the second biggest state -- farming state in the country.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I hear from my farmers and friends all the time.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The Vice President is right, by the way.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Every day is earth day if you own the land.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I like the policies that will encourage farmers to put -- set aside land as well for conservation purposes.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm for a massive reform of the estate tax or the death tax.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And under the plan that I've proposed, 80% of all family farms will be completely exempt from the estate tax.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And the vast majority of all family businesses would be completely exempt, and all of the others would have sharply reduced.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: So 80% -- now the problem with completely eliminating it goes back to the wealthiest 1%.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The amount of money that has to be raised in taxes for middle-class families to make up for completely eliminating that on the very wealthiest, the billionaires, that would be an extra heavy burden on middle-class families.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And so let's do it for most all, but not completely eliminate it for the very top.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Because people shouldn't be taxed twice on their assets.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's either unfair for some or unfair for all.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Again, this is just a difference of opinion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If you're from Washington, you want to pick and choose winners.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't think that's the role of the president.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think if you're going to have tax relief, everybody benefits.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Secondly, I think your plan -- a lot of fine print in your plan, Mr. Vice President, with all due respect.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It is -- I'm not so sure 80% of the people get the death tax.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I just don't think it's fair to tax people's assets twice regardless of your status.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's an issue of principle, not politics.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Laura and I are proud parents of teenage girls, twin daughters, and I know what you're saying.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Government ought to stand on the side of parents.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Parents are teaching their children right from wrong, and the message oftentimes gets undermined by the popular culture.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You bet there's things that government can do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We can work with the entertainment industry to provide family hour.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We can have filters on Internets where public money is spent.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There ought to be filters in public libraries and filters in public schools so if kids get on the Internet, there is not going to be pornography or violence coming in.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think we ought to have character education in our schools.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I know that doesn't directly talk about Hollywood, but it does reinforce the values you're teaching.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Greatly expand character education funding so that public schools will teach children values, values which have stood the test of time.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think that afterschool money ought to be available for faith-based programs and charitable programs that exist because somebody has heard the call to love a neighbor like you would like to be loved yourself.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That will help reinforce the values that parents teach at home as well.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Ours is a great land, and one of the reasons why is because we're free.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And so I don't support censorship.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I do believe that we ought to talk plainly to the Hollywood moguls and people who produce this stuff and explain the consequences.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think we need to have rating systems that are clear.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I happen to like the idea of having technology for the TV, easy for parents to use so you can tune out these programs you don't want in your house.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'll remind mothers and dads the best weapon is the off/on button, and paying attention to your children, and eating dinner with them and being -- I'm sorry.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I was on my peroration.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I care a lot about this.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It's not just movies; television, video games, music, the Internet.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Parents now feel like you have to compete with the mass culture in order to raise your kids with the values that you want them to have.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Tipper and I have four children.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And God bless them, every one of them decided on their own to come here this evening.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: She and her husband made us grandparents almost a year-and-a-half ago, and yet if she'll forgive me, when she was little, she brought a record home that had some awful lyrics in it and Tipper hit the ceiling.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And that launched a campaign to try to get the record companies to put ratings that -- warning labels for parents.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I'm so proud of what she accomplished in getting them on there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I've been involved myself in negotiating and helping to move along the negotiations with the Internet service providers to get a parents' protection page every time 95% of the pages come up.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And a feature that allows parents to automatically check with one click what sites your kids have visited lately.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: You know, some parents are worried about those filters, that you will have to ask your kids how to put them on there.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But if you can check up on them, that's real power.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And recently the Federal Trade Commission pointed out that some of these entertainment companies have warned parents that the material is inappropriate for children, and then they've turned around behind the backs of the parents and advertised that same adult material directly to children.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Joe Lieberman and I gave them six months to clean up their act.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And if they don't do it, we're gonna ask for tougher authority in the hands of the FTC on the false and deceptive advertising.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I'll tell you this, I want to do something about this.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Respect the First Amendment, but I will do something to help you raise your kids without that garbage.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Right next to the last.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We've got to change it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I spend a good deal of time talking to young people, and in my standard speech out there on the stump I usually end my speech by saying, I want to ask you for something and I want to direct it especially to the young people in the audience.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I want to tell you what I tell them.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Sometimes people who are very idealistic and have great dreams, as young people do, are apt to stay at arm's length from the political process because they think their good hearts might be brittle, and if they invest their hopes and allow themselves to believe, then they're gonna be let down and disappointed.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But thank goodness we've always had enough people who have been willing in every generation to push past the fear of a broken heart and become deeply involved in forming a more perfect union.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, we've got to address one of the biggest threats to our democracy.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And that is the current campaign financing system.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I know they say it doesn't rank anywhere on the polls.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I'm telling you, I will make it the -- I will make the McCain-Feingold Campaign Finance Reform bill the very first measure that I send to the Congress as president.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I wish that he would consider changing his mind on that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Because I think that the special interests have too much power, and we need to give our democracy back to the American people.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Let me tell you why.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Those issues you mentioned, Social Security, prescription drugs, the big drug companies are against the prescription drug proposal that I've made.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The HMOs are against the patient's rights bill, the Dingle-Norwood bill that I support, and that Gov.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The big oil companies are against the measures to get more energy independence and renewable fuel.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: They ought to have their voices heard, but they shouldn't have a big megaphone that drowns out the American people.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We need campaign finance reform and we need to shoot straight with young and old alike and tell them what the real choices are.
Speaker: Al Gore
