Text: And we can renew and rekindle the American spirit and make our future what our founders dreamed it could be.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Tell you what I hear.

Text: A lot of people are sick and tired of the bitterness in Washington, D.C. and therefore they don't want any part of politics.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: They look at Washington and see people pointing fingers and casting blame and saying one thing and doing another.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There's a lot of young folks saying, you know, why do I want to be involved with this mess?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And what I think needs to happen in order to encourage the young to become involved is to shoot straight, is to set aside the partisan differences, and set an agenda that will make sense.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Medicare, I know you talked about it, but Medicare is relevant for all of us, young and old alike.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: We better get it right now.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Tax reform is relevant for old and young alike.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't think it's the issues that turn kids off.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think it's the tone.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think it's the attitude.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think it's a cynicism in Washington and it doesn't have to be that way.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Before I decided to run, I had to resolve two issues in my mind.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One, could our family endure all this business.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I came to the conclusion that our love was strong enough to be able to do it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The other was could an administration change the tone in Washington, D.C. And I believe the answer is yes, otherwise I wouldn't be asking for your vote.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's what happened in Texas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There is a man here in this audience named Hugo Berlanga.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: He came here for a reason, to tout our record on health in Texas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I didn't care whether he was a Republican or Democrat.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: What I cared about is could we work together.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's what Washington, D.C. needs.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And finally, sir, to answer your question, you need somebody in office who will tell the truth.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's the best way to get people back in the system.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've had a record of bringing people from all walks of life into my administration, and my administration is better off for it in Texas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm going to find people that want to serve their country.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But I want a diverse administration, I think it's important.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've worked hard in the State of Texas to make sure our institutions reflect the state with good, smart policy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Quotas tend to pit one group of people against another.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's not the way America is all about.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But policies that give people a helping hand so they can help themselves.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: For example, in our State of Texas I worked with the legislature, both Republicans and Democrats, to pass a law that said if you come in the top 10% of your high school class, you're automatically admitted to one of our higher institutions of learning, college.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And as a result, our universities are now more diverse.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It was a smart thing to do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: What I called it, I labeled it affirmative access.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think the contracting business in government can help.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Not with quotas, but help meet a goal of ownership of small businesses, for example.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The contracts need to be smaller, the agencies need to be -- need to recruit and to work hard to find people to bid on the state contracts.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think we can do that in a way that represents what America is all about, which is equal opportunity and an opportunity for people to realize their potential.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So to answer your question, I support, I guess the way to put it, is affirmative access.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'll have an administration that will make you proud.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I believe in this goal and effort with all my heart.

Text: I believe that our future as a nation depends upon whether or not we can break down these barriers that have been used to pit group against group, and bring our people together.

Text: Well, you establish respect for differences.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It's all too easy for somebody in the majority in the population to say oh, we're just all the same, without an understanding of the different life experience that you've had, that others have had.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Once you have that understanding and mutual respect, then we can transcend the differences and embrace the highest common denominator of the American spirit.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I don't know what affirmative access means.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I do know what affirmative action means.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I know the governor is against it, and I know that I'm for it.

Text: I know what a hate crime statute pending at the national level is all about in the aftermath of James Byrd's death.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I'm for that proposed law, the governor is against it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I know what it means to have a commitment to diversity.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I am part of an administration that has the finest record on diversity.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And incidentally, an excellent -- I mean, I think our success over the last eight years has not been in spite of diversity but because of it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Because we're able to draw on the wisdom and experience from different parts of the society that hadn't been tapped in the same way before.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And incidentally, Mel Carnahan in Missouri had the finest record on diversity in any governor in the entire history of the State of Missouri.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I want to honor that among his other achievements here.

Text: Now, I just believe that what we have to do is enforce the civil rights laws.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: This is, with all due respect, Governor, that's a red herring.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I'm against quotas, they're illegal.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: They're against the American way.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Affirmative action means that you take extra steps to acknowledge the history of discrimination and injustice and prejudice and bring all people into the American dream because it helps everybody, not just those who are directly benefitting.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If affirmative action means quotas, I'm against it.

Text: If affirmative action means what I just described what I'm for, then I'm for it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You heard what I was for.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: No, it doesn't speak for itself, Mr. Vice President, it speaks for the fact that there are certain rules in this that we all agree to, but evidently rules don't mean anything.

Text: If you make less than $60,000 a year and you decide to invest $1,000 in a savings account, you'll get a tax credit, which means in essence that the federal government will match your $1,000 with another $1,000.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you make less than $30,000 a year and you put $500 in a savings account, the federal government will match it with $1500.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you make more than $60,000 and up to 100 you'll still get a match, but not as generous.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: You'll get an access to life-long learning and education, help with tuition if you want to get a new skill or training.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you want to purchase health insurance, you will get help with that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you want to participate in some of the dynamic changes that are going on in our country, you will get specific help in doing that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you are part of the -- of the bottom 20% or so of wage earners, then you will get an expanded earned income tax credit.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now, the tax relief that I propose is directed specifically at middle-income individuals and families.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And if you have a -- if you have an elderly parent or grandparent who needs long-term care, then you will get help with that.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: $3,000 tax credit to help your expenses in taking care of a loved one who needs long-term care.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: You're going to get a tax relief in my plan.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You're not going to be targeted in or targeted out.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Everybody that pays taxes is going to get tax relief.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If you take care of an elderly in your home, you're going to get the personal exemption increased.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think also what you need to think about is not the immediate, but what about Medicare?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You get a plan that will include prescription drugs, a plan that will give you options.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Now, I hope people understand that Medicare today is important, but it doesn't keep up with the new medicines.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If you're a Medicare person, on Medicare, you don't get the new procedures.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You're stuck in a time warp in many ways.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: So it will be a modern Medicare system that trusts you to make a variety of options for you.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You're going to live in a peaceful world.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It will be a world of peace because we're going to have a clear sight of foreign policy based upon a strong military and a mission that stands by our friends.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: A mission that doesn't try to be all things to all people.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: A judicious use of the military which will help keep the peace.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You'll live in a world, hopefully, that is more educated so it's less likely you'll be harmed in your neighborhood.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: See, an educated child is one much more likely to be hopeful and optimistic.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You'll be in a world in which fits into my philosophy.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The harder you work, the more you can keep.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Government shouldn't be a heavy hand.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's what the federal government does to you.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It should be a helping hand, and tax relief and the proposals I just described should be a good helping hand.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: No, I'm not proud of that.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: The death penalty is a very serious business, Leo.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's an issue that good people obviously disagree on.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I take my job seriously.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I was sworn to uphold the laws of my state.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: During the course of the campaign in 1994 I was asked do you support the death penalty.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I said I did if administered fairly and justly.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Because I believe it saves lives, Leo, I do.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: If it's administered swiftly, justly and fairly, it saves lives.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One of the things that happens when you're a governor, at least oftentimes you have to make tough decisions.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You can't let public persuasion sway you, because the job is to enforce the law.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's what I did, sir.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There have been some tough cases come across my desk.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Some of the hardest moments since I've been the governor of the State of Texas is to deal with those cases.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But my job is to ask two questions, sir.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Is the person guilty of the crime?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And did the person have full access to the courts of law?
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I can tell you looking at you right now, in all cases those answers were affirmative.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm not proud of any record.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm proud of the fact that violent crime is down in the State of Texas.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm proud of the fact that we hold people accountable.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I support the death penalty.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think that it has to be administered not only fairly with attention to things like DNA evidence, which I think should be used in all capital cases, but also with very careful attention.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If, for example, somebody confesses to the crime and somebody is waiting on death row, there has to be alertness to say wait a minute, have we got the wrong guy?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If the wrong guy is put to death, then that's a double tragedy.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Not only has an innocent person been executed, but the real perpetrator of the crime has not been held accountable for it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And in some cases may be still at large.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But I support the death penalty in the most heinous cases.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It's the only reason to be for it.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't think you should support the death penalty to seek revenge.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't think that's right.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think the reason to support the death penalty is because it saves other people's lives.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think it is a deterrent.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I know that's a controversial view, but I do believe it's a deterrent.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: (LAUGHTER) I am a person who keeps promises.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And, you know, we've heard a lot about -- from the governor about not much being done in the last eight years, as if the promises that I made eight years ago have not been kept.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I think the record shows otherwise.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We have gone from the biggest deficits eight years ago to the biggest surpluses in history today.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Instead of high unemployment, we now have the lowest African-American unemployment, the lowest Latino unemployment ever measured.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: 22 million new jobs, very low unemployment nationally.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Instead of ballooning the debt and multiplying it four times over, we have seen the debt actually begun to be paid down.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Here are some promises that I'll make to you now.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I will balance the budget every year.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I will pay down the debt every year.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I will give middle-class Americans tax cuts, meaningful ones.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I will invest in education, health care, protecting the environment and retirement security.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We both made promises in this campaign.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Let me tell you about one of the governor's.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: But he's promised seniors that their Social Security benefits will not be cut, and he's promised the same trillion dollars to them.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: So this is a show me state.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Reminds me of the line from the movie, "Show me the money."
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Which one of those promises will you keep and which will you break, Governor?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Thank you for your question.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You were promised that Medicare would be reformed, and that Social Security would be reformed.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: You were promised a middle-class tax cut in 1992.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There's too much bitterness in Washington.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's time to have a fresh start.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One of the reasons I was successful as the governor of Texas is because I didn't try to be all things to all people.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: When I campaigned in a race, a lot of folks didn't think I could win including, by the way, my mother.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: (LAUGHTER) I said I'd do four things; tort reform, education reform, welfare reform and juvenile justice reform.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And I had the will of the people in my state behind me.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And then I brought folks together to get it done.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And that's what we need, I think, in this election.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: To me that's what it's all about.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm sure your 6th grade kids are listening and saying, these guys will say anything to get elected.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But there's a record, and that's what I hope people look at.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: One of my promises is going to be Social Security reform, and you bet, we need to take a trillion dollars out of that $2.4 trillion surplus.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Now remember, Social Security revenue exceeds expenses up until 2015.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: People are going to get paid.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But if you're a younger worker, if you're younger, you better hope this country thinks differently, otherwise you're gonna be faced with huge payroll taxes or reduced benefits.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And you bet we're gonna take a trillion dollars of your own money and let you invest it under safe guidelines so you get a better rate of return on the money than the paltry 2% that the federal government gets for you today.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: That's one of my promises.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: But it's gonna require people to bring both Republicans and Democrats together to get it done.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There was a chance to get this done.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It was a bipartisan approach, but it's been rejected.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm going to bring them together.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, first of all, Jim, I would like to respond to what the governor just said.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Because the trillion dollars that has been promised to young people has also been promised to older people.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And you cannot keep both promises.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you're in your mid-40's under the governor's plan, Social Security will be bankrupt by the time you retire, if he takes it out of the Social Security Trust Fund.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Under my plan it will be -- its solvency will be extended until you're 100.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now that is the difference.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And the governor may not want to answer that question, he may want to call it a high school debating trick, but let me tell you this.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: This election is not about debating tricks, it is about your future.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: The reason Social Security -- he says it gets 2%.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: You know, it's not a bank account that just pays back money that's invested.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: It is also used to give your mothers and fathers the Social Security checks that they live on.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you take a trillion dollars out of that Social Security Trust Fund, how are the checks going to be -- how are you going to keep faith with the seniors?
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Now let me come directly to your question.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: One reason people are skeptical is because people don't answer the questions they've been asked.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There's just a difference of opinion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want workers to have their own assets.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's who you trust, government or people.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Thank you very much, Jim, and I'll begin by answering your questions -- your last question.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I believe that a lot of people are skeptical about people in politics today because we have seen a time of great challenge for our country.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Since the assassination of our best leaders in the '60's, since the Vietnam War, since Watergate, and because we need campaign finance reform.
Speaker: Al Gore

Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I have kept the faith.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I've kept the faith with my country.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I volunteered for the Army.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I kept the faith with my family.
Speaker: Al Gore

Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We have devoted ourselves to our children and now our nearly one-and-a-half-year-old grandson.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I have kept the faith with our country.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Nine times I have raised my hand to take an oath to the Constitution, and I have never violated that oath.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I have not spent the last quarter century in pursuit of personal wealth.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I have spent the last quarter century fighting for middle-class working men and women in the United States of America.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: I believe very deeply that you have to be willing to stand up and fight no matter what powerful forces might be on the other side.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: If you want somebody who is willing to fight for you, I am asking for your support and your vote and, yes, your confidence and your willingness to believe that we can do the right thing in America, and be the better for it.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We've made some progress during the last eight years.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: We have seen the strongest economy in the history of the United States.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Lower crime rates for eight years in a row.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Highest private home ownership ever, but I'll make you one promise here.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: You ain't seen nothing yet.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: And I will keep that promise.
Speaker: Al Gore

Text: Well, Jim, I want to thank you and thank the folks here at Washington University and the vice president.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Appreciate the chance to have a good, honest dialogue about our differences of opinion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think after three debates the good people of this country understand there is a difference of opinion.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: There is a difference between big federal government and somebody who is coming from outside of Washington who will trust individuals.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I've got an agenda that I want to get done for the country.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's an agenda that says we're going to reform Medicare to make sure seniors have got prescription drugs and to give seniors different options from which they can choose.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: It's an agenda that says we're listen to the young voices in Social Security and say we're going to think differently about making sure we have a system, but also fulfill the promise to the seniors in America.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: A promise made will be a promise kept should I be fortunate enough to become your president.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to have the military keeping the peace.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I want to make sure the public school system in America keeps its promise so not one child is left behind.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: After setting priorities, I want to give some of your money back.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't think the surplus is the government's money.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I think it's the people's money.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I don't think the surplus exists because of the ingenuity and hard work of the federal government, I think it exists because of the ingenuity and hard work of the American people.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: And you ought to have some of this surplus so you can save and dream and build.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: I'm asking for your vote.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: For those of you for my opponent, please only vote once.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: (LAUGHTER) But for those who have not made up their mind, I would like to conclude by this promise.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Should I be fortunate enough to become your president, when I put my hand on the Bible, I will swear to not only uphold the laws of the land, but I will also swear to uphold the honor and the dignity of the office to which I have been elected, so help me God.
Speaker: George W. Bush

Text: Well, thank you, Lester, and thanks to Hofstra for hosting us.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: The central question in this election is really what kind of country we want to be and what kind of future we'll build together.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Today is my granddaughter's second birthday, so I think about this a lot.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: First, we have to build an economy that works for everyone, not just those at the top.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: That means we need new jobs, good jobs, with rising incomes.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: I want us to invest in you.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: I want us to invest in your future.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: That means jobs in infrastructure, in advanced manufacturing, innovation and technology, clean, renewable energy, and small business, because most of the new jobs will come from small business.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: We also have to make the economy fairer.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: That starts with raising the national minimum wage and also guarantee, finally, equal pay for women's work.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: I also want to see more companies do profit-sharing.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: If you help create the profits, you should be able to share in them, not just the executives at the top.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And I want us to do more to support people who are struggling to balance family and work.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: I've heard from so many of you about the difficult choices you face and the stresses that you're under.

Text: So let's have paid family leave, earned sick days.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Let's be sure we have affordable child care and debt-free college.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: How are we going to do it?
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: We're going to do it by having the wealthy pay their fair share and close the corporate loopholes.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Finally, we tonight are on the stage together, Donald Trump and I. Donald, it's good to be with you.

Text: We're going to have a debate where we are talking about the important issues facing our country.

Text: You have to judge us, who can shoulder the immense, awesome responsibilities of the presidency, who can put into action the plans that will make your life better.

Text: And so what I believe is the more we can do for the middle class, the more we can invest in you, your education, your skills, your future, the better we will be off and the better we'll grow.

Text: Well, for one thing -- and before we start on that -- my father gave me a very small loan in 1975, and I built it into a company that's worth many, many billions of dollars, with some of the greatest assets in the world, and I say that only because that's the kind of thinking that our country needs.

Text: Instead of that, they're leaving our country to get their money, because they can't bring their money back into our country, because of bureaucratic red tape, because they can't get together.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Because we have -- we have a president that can't sit them around a table and get them to approve something.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Republicans and Democrats agree that this should be done, $2.5 trillion.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: I happen to think it's double that.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: It's probably $5 trillion that we can't bring into our country, Lester.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And with a little leadership, you'd get it in here very quickly, and it could be put to use on the inner cities and lots of other things, and it would be beautiful.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: But we have no leadership.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And honestly, that starts with Secretary Clinton.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: I have a feeling that by, the end of this evening, I'm going to be blamed for everything that's ever happened.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: You know, just join the debate by saying more crazy things.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Now, let me say this, it is absolutely the case...
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: There's nothing crazy about not letting our companies bring their money back into their country.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Yeah, well, let's start the clock again, Lester.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: We've looked at your tax proposals.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: I don't see changes in the corporate tax rates or the kinds of proposals you're referring to that would cause the repatriation, bringing back of money that's stranded overseas.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: I happen to support that.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Then you didn't read it.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: I happen to -- I happen to support that in a way that will actually work to our benefit.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: But when I look at what you have proposed, you have what is called now the Trump loophole, because it would so advantage you and the business you do.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: You've proposed an approach that has a...
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Who gave it that name?
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: The first I've -- who gave it that name?
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: ... $4 billion tax benefit for your family.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And when you look at what you are proposing...
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: How much for my family?
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: ... as I said, trumped-up trickle-down.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: It got us into the mess we were in, in 2008 and 2009.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Slashing taxes on the wealthy hasn't worked.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And a lot of really smart, wealthy people know that.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And they are saying, hey, we need to do more to make the contributions we should be making to rebuild the middle class.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: I don't think top-down works in America.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: I think building the middle class, investing in the middle class, making college debt-free so more young people can get their education, helping people refinance their -- their debt from college at a lower rate.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Those are the kinds of things that will really boost the economy.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Broad-based, inclusive growth is what we need in America, not more advantages for people at the very top.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Our country is suffering because people like Secretary Clinton have made such bad decisions in terms of our jobs and in terms of what's going on.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Now, look, we have the worst revival of an economy since the Great Depression.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And believe me: We're in a bubble right now.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And the only thing that looks good is the stock market, but if you raise interest rates even a little bit, that's going to come crashing down.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: We are in a big, fat, ugly bubble.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And we better be awfully careful.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And we have a Fed that's doing political things.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: This Janet Yellen of the Fed.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: The Fed is doing political -- by keeping the interest rates at this level.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And believe me: The day Obama goes off, and he leaves, and goes out to the golf course for the rest of his life to play golf, when they raise interest rates, you're going to see some very bad things happen, because the Fed is not doing their job.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: The Fed is being more political than Secretary Clinton.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: I don't mind releasing -- I'm under a routine audit.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And -- as soon as the audit's finished, it will be released.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: But you will learn more about Donald Trump by going down to the federal elections, where I filed a 104-page essentially financial statement of sorts, the forms that they have.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: It shows income -- in fact, the income -- I just looked today -- the income is filed at $694 million for this past year, $694 million.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: If you would have told me I was going to make that 15 or 20 years ago, I would have been very surprised.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: But that's the kind of thinking that our country needs.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: When we have a country that's doing so badly, that's being ripped off by every single country in the world, it's the kind of thinking that our country needs, because everybody -- Lester, we have a trade deficit with all of the countries that we do business with, of almost $800 billion a year.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: You know what that is?
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: That means, who's negotiating these trade deals?
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: We have people that are political hacks negotiating our trade deals.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Well, I told you, I will release them as soon as the audit.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Look, I've been under audit almost for 15 years.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: I know a lot of wealthy people that have never been audited.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: I said, do you get audited?
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: I get audited almost every year.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And in a way, I should be complaining.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: It's almost become a way of life.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: I get audited by the IRS.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: We have a situation in this country that has to be taken care of.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: I will release my tax returns -- against my lawyer's wishes -- when she releases her 33,000 e-mails that have been deleted.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: As soon as she releases them, I will release.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: I will release my tax returns.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And that's against -- my lawyers, they say, "Don't do it."
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: I will tell you this.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: No -- in fact, watching shows, they're reading the papers.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Almost every lawyer says, you don't release your returns until the audit's complete.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: When the audit's complete, I'll do it.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: But I would go against them if she releases her e-mails.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Let her release the e-mails.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Why did she delete 33,000...

Text: Well, I think you've seen another example of bait-and- switch here.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: For 40 years, everyone running for president has released their tax returns.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: You can go and see nearly, I think, 39, 40 years of our tax returns, but everyone has done it.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: We know the IRS has made clear there is no prohibition on releasing it when you're under audit.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: So you've got to ask yourself, why won't he release his tax returns?
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And I think there may be a couple of reasons.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: First, maybe he's not as rich as he says he is.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Second, maybe he's not as charitable as he claims to be.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Third, we don't know all of his business dealings, but we have been told through investigative reporting that he owes about $650 million to Wall Street and foreign banks.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Or maybe he doesn't want the American people, all of you watching tonight, to know that he's paid nothing in federal taxes, because the only years that anybody's ever seen were a couple of years when he had to turn them over to state authorities when he was trying to get a casino license, and they showed he didn't pay any federal income tax.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: So if he's paid zero, that means zero for troops, zero for vets, zero for schools or health.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And I think probably he's not all that enthusiastic about having the rest of our country see what the real reasons are, because it must be something really important, even terrible, that he's trying to hide.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And the financial disclosure statements, they don't give you the tax rate.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: They don't give you all the details that tax returns would.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And it just seems to me that this is something that the American people deserve to see.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And I have no reason to believe that he's ever going to release his tax returns, because there's something he's hiding.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: We'll keep guessing at what it might be that he's hiding.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: But I think the question is, were he ever to get near the White House, what would be those conflicts?
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Who does he owe money to?
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Well, he owes you the answers to that, and he should provide them.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: You know, I made a mistake using a private e- mail.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And if I had to do it over again, I would, obviously, do it differently.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: But I'm not going to make any excuses.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: It was a mistake, and I take responsibility for that.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: That was more than a mistake.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: That was not a mistake.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: When you have your staff taking the Fifth Amendment, taking the Fifth so they're not prosecuted, when you have the man that set up the illegal server taking the Fifth, I think it's disgraceful.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And believe me, this country thinks it's -- really thinks it's disgraceful, also.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: As far as my tax returns, you don't learn that much from tax returns.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: That I can tell you.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: You learn a lot from financial disclosure.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And you should go down and take a look at that.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: The other thing, I'm extremely underleveraged.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: The report that said $650 -- which, by the way, a lot of friends of mine that know my business say, boy, that's really not a lot of money.

Text: It's not a lot of money relative to what I had.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: The buildings that were in question, they said in the same report, which was -- actually, it wasn't even a bad story, to be honest with you, but the buildings are worth $3.9 billion.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And the $650 isn't even on that.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: It's much less than that.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: But I could give you a list of banks, I would -- if that would help you, I would give you a list of banks.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: These are very fine institutions, very fine banks.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: I could do that very quickly.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: I have a great company.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: I have a tremendous income.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And the reason I say that is not in a braggadocios way.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: It's because it's about time that this country had somebody running it that has an idea about money.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: When we have $20 trillion in debt, and our country's a mess, you know, it's one thing to have $20 trillion in debt and our roads are good and our bridges are good and everything's in great shape, our airports.

Text: Our airports are like from a third world country.

Text: You land at LaGuardia, you land at Kennedy, you land at LAX, you land at Newark, and you come in from Dubai and Qatar and you see these incredible -- you come in from China, you see these incredible airports, and you land -- we've become a third world country.

Text: So the worst of all things has happened.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: We owe $20 trillion, and we're a mess.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And we've spent $6 trillion in the Middle East, according to a report that I just saw.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Whether it's 6 or 5, but it looks like it's 6, $6 trillion in the Middle East, we could have rebuilt our country twice.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And it's really a shame.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And it's politicians like Secretary Clinton that have caused this problem.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Our country has tremendous problems.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: We're a serious debtor nation.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And we have a country that needs new roads, new tunnels, new bridges, new airports, new schools, new hospitals.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And we don't have the money, because it's been squandered on so many of your ideas.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And maybe because you haven't paid any federal income tax for a lot of years.

Text: And the other thing I think is important...
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: It would be squandered, too, believe me.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: ... is if your -- if your main claim to be president of the United States is your business, then I think we should talk about that.

Text: You know, your campaign manager said that you built a lot of businesses on the backs of little guys.

Text: And, indeed, I have met a lot of the people who were stiffed by you and your businesses, Donald.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: I've met dishwashers, painters, architects, glass installers, marble installers, drapery installers, like my dad was, who you refused to pay when they finished the work that you asked them to do.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: We have an architect in the audience who designed one of your clubhouses at one of your golf courses.

Text: It immediately was put to use.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And you wouldn't pay what the man needed to be paid, what he was charging you to do...
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Maybe he didn't do a good job and I was unsatisfied with his work...
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Which our country should do, too.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Do the thousands of people that you have stiffed over the course of your business not deserve some kind of apology from someone who has taken their labor, taken the goods that they produced, and then refused to pay them?
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: I can only say that I'm certainly relieved that my late father never did business with you.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: He provided a good middle-class life for us, but the people he worked for, he expected the bargain to be kept on both sides.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And when we talk about your business, you've taken business bankruptcy six times.

Text: There are a lot of great businesspeople that have never taken bankruptcy once.

Text: You call yourself the King of Debt.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: You even at one time suggested that you would try to negotiate down the national debt of the United States.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Well, sometimes there's not a direct transfer of skills from business to government, but sometimes what happened in business would be really bad for government.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And we need to be very clear about that.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: So, yeah, I think -- I do think it's time.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Look, it's all words, it's all sound bites.

Text: I built an unbelievable company.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Some of the greatest assets anywhere in the world, real estate assets anywhere in the world, beyond the United States, in Europe, lots of different places.

Text: But on occasion, four times, we used certain laws that are there.

Text: And when Secretary Clinton talks about people that didn't get paid, first of all, they did get paid a lot, but taken advantage of the laws of the nation.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Now, if you want to change the laws, you've been there a long time, change the laws.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: But I take advantage of the laws of the nation because I'm running a company.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: My obligation right now is to do well for myself, my family, my employees, for my companies.

Text: And that's what I do.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: But what she doesn't say is that tens of thousands of people that are unbelievably happy and that love me.

Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: We're just opening up on Pennsylvania Avenue right next to the White House, so if I don't get there one way, I'm going to get to Pennsylvania Avenue another.

Text: But we're opening the Old Post Office.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Under budget, ahead of schedule, saved tremendous money.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: I'm a year ahead of schedule.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And that's what this country should be doing.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: We build roads and they cost two and three and four times what they're supposed to cost.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: We buy products for our military and they come in at costs that are so far above what they were supposed to be, because we don't have people that know what they're doing.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: When we look at the budget, the budget is bad to a large extent because we have people that have no idea as to what to do and how to buy.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: The Trump International is way under budget and way ahead of schedule.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And we should be able to do that for our country.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Race remains a significant challenge in our country.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Unfortunately, race still determines too much, often determines where people live, determines what kind of education in their public schools they can get, and, yes, it determines how they're treated in the criminal justice system.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: We've just seen those two tragic examples in both Tulsa and Charlotte.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And we've got to do several things at the same time.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: We have to restore trust between communities and the police.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: We have to work to make sure that our police are using the best training, the best techniques, that they're well prepared to use force only when necessary.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Everyone should be respected by the law, and everyone should respect the law.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Right now, that's not the case in a lot of our neighborhoods.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: So I have, ever since the first day of my campaign, called for criminal justice reform.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: I've laid out a platform that I think would begin to remedy some of the problems we have in the criminal justice system.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: But we also have to recognize, in addition to the challenges that we face with policing, there are so many good, brave police officers who equally want reform.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: So we have to bring communities together in order to begin working on that as a mutual goal.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And we've got to get guns out of the hands of people who should not have them.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: The gun epidemic is the leading cause of death of young African- American men, more than the next nine causes put together.

Text: So we have to do two things, as I said.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: We have to restore trust.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: We have to work with the police.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: We have to make sure they respect the communities and the communities respect them.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And we have to tackle the plague of gun violence, which is a big contributor to a lot of the problems that we're seeing today.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Well, first of all, Secretary Clinton doesn't want to use a couple of words, and that's law and order.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And we need law and order.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: If we don't have it, we're not going to have a country.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And when I look at what's going on in Charlotte, a city I love, a city where I have investments, when I look at what's going on throughout various parts of our country, whether it's -- I mean, I can just keep naming them all day long -- we need law and order in our country.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: I just got today the, as you know, the endorsement of the Fraternal Order of Police, we just -- just came in.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: We have endorsements from, I think, almost every police group, very -- I mean, a large percentage of them in the United States.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: We have a situation where we have our inner cities, African- Americans, Hispanics are living in he'll because it's so dangerous.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: You walk down the street, you get shot.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: In Chicago, they've had thousands of shootings, thousands since January 1st.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And I'm saying, where is this?
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Is this a war-torn country?
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And we have to stop the violence.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: We have to bring back law and order.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: In a place like Chicago, where thousands of people have been killed, thousands over the last number of years, in fact, almost 4,000 have been killed since Barack Obama became president, over -- almost 4,000 people in Chicago have been killed.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: We have to bring back law and order.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Now, whether or not in a place like Chicago you do stop and frisk, which worked very well, Mayor Giuliani is here, worked very well in New York.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: It brought the crime rate way down.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: But you take the gun away from criminals that shouldn't be having it.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: We have gangs roaming the street.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And in many cases, they're illegally here, illegal immigrants.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And we have to be very strong.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And we have to be very vigilant.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: We have to be -- we have to know what we're doing.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Right now, our police, in many cases, are afraid to do anything.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: We have to protect our inner cities, because African-American communities are being decimated by crime, decimated.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: It went before a judge, who was a very against-police judge.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: It was taken away from her.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And our mayor, our new mayor, refused to go forward with the case.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: They would have won an appeal.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: If you look at it, throughout the country, there are many places where it's allowed.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: No, the argument is that we have to take the guns away from these people that have them and they are bad people that shouldn't have them.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: These are people that are bad people that shouldn't be -- when you have 3,000 shootings in Chicago from January 1st, when you have 4,000 people killed in Chicago by guns, from the beginning of the presidency of Barack Obama, his hometown, you have to have stop-and-frisk.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: You need a better community, you know, relation.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: You don't have good community relations in Chicago.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: It's terrible what's going on in Chicago.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: But when you look -- and Chicago's not the only -- you go to Ferguson, you go to so many different places.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: I agree with Secretary Clinton on this.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: You need better relationships between the communities and the police, because in some cases, it's not good.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: But you look at Dallas, where the relationships were really studied, the relationships were really a beautiful thing, and then five police officers were killed one night very violently.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: So there's some bad things going on.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: But we need -- Lester, we need law and order.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And we need law and order in the inner cities, because the people that are most affected by what's happening are African-American and Hispanic people.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And it's very unfair to them what our politicians are allowing to happen.
Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: Well, I've heard -- I've heard Donald say this at his rallies, and it's really unfortunate that he paints such a dire negative picture of black communities in our country.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: You know, the vibrancy of the black church, the black businesses that employ so many people, the opportunities that so many families are working to provide for their kids.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: There's a lot that we should be proud of and we should be supporting and lifting up.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: But we do always have to make sure we keep people safe.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: There are the right ways of doing it, and then there are ways that are ineffective.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Stop-and-frisk was found to be unconstitutional and, in part, because it was ineffective.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: It did not do what it needed to do.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Now, I believe in community policing.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And, in fact, violent crime is one-half of what it was in 1991.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Property crime is down 40 percent.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: We just don't want to see it creep back up.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: We've had 25 years of very good cooperation.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: But there were some problems, some unintended consequences.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Too many young African-American and Latino men ended up in jail for nonviolent offenses.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And it's just a fact that if you're a young African-American man and you do the same thing as a young white man, you are more likely to be arrested, charged, convicted, and incarcerated.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: So we've got to address the systemic racism in our criminal justice system.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: We cannot just say law and order.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: We have to say -- we have to come forward with a plan that is going to divert people from the criminal justice system, deal with mandatory minimum sentences, which have put too many people away for too long for doing too little.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: We need to have more second chance programs.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: I'm glad that we're ending private prisons in the federal system; I want to see them ended in the state system.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: You shouldn't have a profit motivation to fill prison cells with young Americans.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: So there are some positive ways we can work on this.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And I believe strongly that commonsense gun safety measures would assist us.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Right now -- and this is something Donald has supported, along with the gun lobby -- right now, we've got too many military- style weapons on the streets.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: In a lot of places, our police are outgunned.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: We need comprehensive background checks, and we need to keep guns out of the hands of those who will do harm.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And we finally need to pass a prohibition on anyone who's on the terrorist watch list from being able to buy a gun in our country.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: If you're too dangerous to fly, you are too dangerous to buy a gun.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: So there are things we can do, and we ought to do it in a bipartisan way.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Lester, I think implicit bias is a problem for everyone, not just police.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: I think, unfortunately, too many of us in our great country jump to conclusions about each other.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And therefore, I think we need all of us to be asking hard questions about, you know, why am I feeling this way?
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: But when it comes to policing, since it can have literally fatal consequences, I have said, in my first budget, we would put money into that budget to help us deal with implicit bias by retraining a lot of our police officers.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: I've met with a group of very distinguished, experienced police chiefs a few weeks ago.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: They admit it's an issue.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: They've got a lot of concerns.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Mental health is one of the biggest concerns, because now police are having to handle a lot of really difficult mental health problems on the street.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: They want support, they want more training, they want more assistance.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And I think the federal government could be in a position where we would offer and provide that.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Well, I think cyber security, cyber warfare will be one of the biggest challenges facing the next president, because clearly we're facing at this point two different kinds of adversaries.

Text: It's one of the most consequential elections that we've had.

Text: You know, I think when we talk about the Supreme Court, it really raises the central issue in this election, namely, what kind of country are we going to be?
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: What kind of opportunities will we provide for our citizens?
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: What kind of rights will Americans have?
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And I feel strongly that the Supreme Court needs to stand on the side of the American people, not on the side of the powerful corporations and the wealthy.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: For me, that means that we need a Supreme Court that will stand up on behalf of women's rights, on behalf of the rights of the LGBT community, that will stand up and say no to Citizens United, a decision that has undermined the election system in our country because of the way it permits dark, unaccountable money to come into our electoral system.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: I have major disagreements with my opponent about these issues and others that will be before the Supreme Court.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: But I feel that at this point in our country's history, it is important that we not reverse marriage equality, that we not reverse Roe v. Wade, that we stand up against Citizens United, we stand up for the rights of people in the workplace, that we stand up and basically say: The Supreme Court should represent all of us.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: That's how I see the court, and the kind of people that I would be looking to nominate to the court would be in the great tradition of standing up to the powerful, standing up on behalf of our rights as Americans.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: And I look forward to having that opportunity.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: I would hope that the Senate would do its job and confirm the nominee that President Obama has sent to them.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: That's the way the Constitution fundamentally should operate.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: The president nominates, and then the Senate advises and consents, or not, but they go forward with the process.
Speaker: Hillary Clinton

Text: Well, first of all, it's great to be with you, and thank you, everybody.

Speaker: Donald Trump

Text: And the court didn't accept that reasonable regulation, but they've accepted many others.
